HEADLINE: Review/Photography;
The Personal Side of Johnson as President

BYLINE: By ANDY GRUNDBERG

 BODY:
THOSE who were not around in the 1960's will find ''L.B.J.: The White House Years,'' a show of some 120 black-and-white photographs at the International Center of Photography, an intriguing and occasionally edifying pictorial history of the Presidency of Lyndon Baines Johnson. Those who experienced the years 1963 to 1968, however, may recognize the exhibition as something else: an ingenious attempt to rehabilitate the memory of a politician whose integrity and accomplishments are as much under attack today as they were some 25 years ago.
The exhibition, which is based on an illustrated book of the same title written by Harry Middleton and published by Harry N. Abrams, begins with an image that is etched into the memories of all Americans over the age of 40. Taken by the photojournalist Cecil Stoughton, it shows Johnson being sworn in as President in the cabin of Air Force One, with his wife, Lady Bird, to his right and Jacqueline Kennedy, still wearing a blood-stained wool suit, to his left. The photograph, which remains discomfiting because of its ungainly mix of public event and private grief, might be said to foreshadow the end of the exhibition, which is dominated by images related to the war in Vietnam. 
In between, there are pictures of Johnson campaigning for election in 1964, visiting Appalachia in a helicopter as part of what he called his War on Poverty, huddling with his staff, Congressmen and civil rights and labor leaders while organizing legislation for the Great Society he envisioned, face to face with Richard M. Nixon in a White House office, and entertaining visitors to his Texas ranch. Most are apparently behind-the-scenes views taken by Yoichi Okamoto, a United States Information Agency photographer assigned to the White House. Okamoto, who died in 1985, managed to cover the Johnson Presidency in a photojournalistic fashion, capturing such intimate moments as Johnson's 1968 phone call to console the family of Robert F. Kennedy after his assassination, as well as more reportorial ones, including images of the President in the hospital before and after a gallbladder operation.
But the notorious photograph of Johnson pulling up his shirt to reveal his scar from the operation - the scar was later transformed by a political cartoonist into a map of Vietnam - was taken by a United Press International photographer, not by Okamoto or any other photographer on his staff. This suggests that there were limits to the candid approach the White House photographers employed, limits determined at least in part by the public relations value of the images that were released to the news media.
Indeed, the image of Johnson portrayed throughout the exhibit - of an avuncular, high-spirited but sincere and caring man who tried to make the Presidency more human and humane, in the tradition of Andrew Jackson - is at radical odds with the portrait of venality and chicanery meticulously traced by Robert A. Caro in his best-selling biography of Johnson's political rise, ''Means of Ascent'' (Alfred A. Knopf). One might even say that the pictures of ''L.B.J.: The White House Years'' resemble a public relations campaign as much now as they did when they were first taken.
Johnson's Presidency could be said to have ended as it began, in tragedy. The war in Vietnam led to domestic protest and discontent, and the projected Great Society never materialized. A picture in the exhibition of Johnson with his head down while listening to a tape-recorded account of action in Vietnam speaks eloquently (albeit metaphorically) of the war's impact on his state of mind. But overall the show masks the extent to which the war had become a major public and political preoccupation by 1968.
This neglect is partly remedied by a second exhibition at the photography center, ''Sal Lopes: The Wall.'' Consisting of 50 vivid color photographs taken at the Vietnam Veterans Memorial in Washington by Mr. Lopes, a Boston photojournalist, ''The Wall'' gives the war's toll an emotional immediacy missing from ''L.B.J.: The White House Years.'' Mr. Lopes has done well with the powerful monument designed by Maya Ying Lin and dedicated in 1982, using it as a backdrop to highlight the human interactions it provokes. In some prints the monument is a dense ebony, isolating arms that reach out to touch the names inscribed in its surface. Elsewhere, it appears forest green, reflecting a visitor's pained expression.
Mr. Lopes's pictures of tear-stained faces and fatigue-clad men embracing one another convey some of the emotion one feels when experiencing the wall in person. This is no small accomplishment, but it is in the final analysis a derivative one: without the pre-existing power of Miss Lin's 250-foot-long wedge of granite, the photographs would not carry as much weight. In the final analysis, both the Lopes and Okamoto photographs are of interest primarily because of the information they provide, not because of any esthetic or pictorial values. This is a distinction that is essential to any definition of art, photographs or not, and one that the International Center of Photography has yet to clearly perceive.
''L.B.J.: The White House Years'' was organized by the International Center of Photography in collaboration with the Lyndon Baines Johnson Library and Museum in Austin, Tex., and is sponsored by the professional division of the Eastman Kodak Company. ''Sal Lopes: The Wall'' was organized by the Chrysler Museum in Norfolk, Va. Both exhibitions remain on view at the photography center, 1130 Fifth Avenue, at 94th Street, through July 15.
 
Barbara Steinman: 'Icon'
Museum of Modern Art
11 West 53d Street
Through July 31
Although it is a video installation, Barbara Steinman's ''Icon'' resists video's seemingly inherent propensity for spectacle and entertainment. The installation is remarkably low key and understated: on passing a color photograph of a marble Madonna, one enters a room populated by a backlighted, black-and-white image of the same Madonna and two black-and-white video monitors. On the screens, which lie behind sheets of frosted glass with oval apertures, are images of test tubes. One tube remains still, while the other slowly fills with a dark fluid (blood, presumably), despite being tilted so that it normally would empty. At intervals of a minute or so, a voice fills the room with the words, ''Take a deep breath.''
Given the test tubes, and what appears to be an X-ray machine pointed at the photograph in the entry, Ms. Steinman seems to be making a connection between the technologies of medicine and art conservation. But there is more to it than that: the use of the Madonna figure within this technological arena suggests an eerie equation of religion, art and medicine. Art and Christianity, the Canadian artist seems to be saying, are linked by a faith in their transformative powers. And by alluding to the taking of blood and the X-raying of a painting, she implies that both are being emptied of their mythic vitality. These are large subjects for any artist to take on, especially in an installation this small in scope, but Ms. Steinman grapples with them with admirable economy and aplomb.
 
Edward Maxey
James Danziger Gallery 415 West Broadway (near Spring Street)
Through June 9
In the tradition of Elaine Sturtevant and Sherrie Levine, Edward Maxey reinterprets well-known 20th-century art, in Mr. Maxey's case, the photographs of Robert Mapplethorpe. What distinguishes Mr. Maxey, however, is that he apparently doesn't mean to. He is simply under the spell of the now much-talked-about photographer, who died last year. This is not particularly surprising, since Mr. Maxey is Mapplethorpe's youngest brother and one-time studio assistant, but it does make his first one-man show of 31 black-and-white photographs an unnerving experience.
Like his brother, Mr. Maxey makes crisp, dramatic photographs of nudes, still lifes, demimonde celebrities and himself. At their best, they may rival his brother's images - his portraits of Annie Lennox and Sandra Bernhard, in particular - and occasionally he strays into new territory, as in an untitled close-up of a cat's face. But to equal an already clearly defined style is clearly a Sisyphean enterprise, as followers of Henri Cartier-Bresson and Walker Evans have already discovered. Mr. Maxey needs to learn to despise his brother's style as much as he loves it; as it is, this exhibition is merely the season's most haunting curiosity.

GRAPHIC: photos: Yoichi Okamoto's 1968 portrait of Lyndon Johnson at his ranch is in a show of Johnson photographs. (Lyndon B. Johnson Library/ICP) (pg. C1); One of 50 photographs, taken by Sal Lopes at the Vietnam Veterans Memorial, in an exhibit at the International Center of Photography. (Sal Lopes/International Center of Photography) (pg. C26)

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: June 1, 1990

SECTION: Section D; Page 1, Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 585 words

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

COMPANIES

HEADLINE: Going to the Rescue of an Insurer

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE

 BODY:
Richard H. Jenrette loves to restore stately old homes as a hobby. ''I like working with something that's beautiful, strong and powerful, but that has stumbled,'' said the 61-year-old executive who helped found the brokerage firm of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette and who today owns estates in the Hudson Valley, on the Battery in Charleston, S.C., and on St. Croix.
His next undertaking, he notes, is much the same. As the new chief executive of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, he is being asked to turn around a 131-year-old company that is the nation's third-largest insurer, with more than $135 billion in assets, but that has faltered of late. To start, earnings have declined steadily since the mid-1980's and last year's profits of $126 million were only half the earnings of 1986.
The company is also reeling from a disastrous foray into ''guaranteed investment contracts,'' which are long-term annuities that assured high returns to buyers. Equitable underwrote about $17 billion of these contracts, and when interest rates turned down, losses mounted; they are expected to reach about $1.5 billion before most of the contracts mature later this year. 
And Mr. Jenrette is also being asked to reverse an overreaching corporate expansion that drove up operating costs - so much so that Mr. Jenrette has pledged to cut $100 million in costs within 100 days. Equitable's board also wants the company's credit rating improved. Equitable, which is more highly leveraged than other life insurers, was downgraded two years ago by Moody's Investors Service to a level three steps below that of its industry peers.
Despite these problems, Mr. Jenrette, who joined Equitable as its chief investment officer after its 1985 acquisition of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, thinks Equitable's worst days are behind it, and he points to an improving capital ratio to prove it. ''It's a fundamentally stronger and better company than recent accounts suggest,'' he said. ''Those get my dander up and I want to polish up Equitable's image.''
A mutual company, Equitable is owned by its policyholders and competes with such mutual life giants as Prudential, Metropolitan Life, Mutual of New York and John Hancock. But as the world of financial services has become more competitive and complex, what was once the sleepy business of selling profitable long-term life insurance policies and investing the proceeds has been radically transformed over the last decade. Insurance giants are affected by the same financial strains as banks, brokerage firms and savings and loan institutions.
Buyers of insurance products are demanding more in the way of investment returns and less in the form of straight insurance - which means less profit for insurers like Equitable. And the search for high returns has led companies like Equitable into such risky investments as ''junk bonds,'' real estate and leveraged buyouts.
Nor is Equitable simply an insurance company. In addition to DLJ -as Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette is generally known today - the parent owns a broad array of financial service companies that are collected under the Equitable Investment Corporation. Among them are Equitable Capital Management, which acts as a private investment bank; Alliance Capital Management, which manages pension assets, and Equitable Real Estate, which holds more than $35 billion in real estate assets.
Mr. Jenrette's vision is to marry the insurance and investment sides of the company, all the while keeping costs down. Specific parts of this plan include redesigning some of the company's insurance products to make them more profitable and more sensitive to interest rates, switching to more fee-generating business like managing money for pension funds and other institutions, and increasing the profitability of Equitable's own investment portfolio.
Mr. Jenrette talks of having Equitable's force of 11,000 insurance agents sell more securities-like products invented by the investment side. It is hardly a new idea; it was the theory behind Prudential's acquisition of Bache Securities and American Express's purchase of Shearson Lehman. None of these acquisitions, including Equitable's, have lived up to their stated promise, but Mr. Jenrette thinks he can change that.
 
'No Miracle Formula'
''This is a gradual process that we've begun only five years ago,'' said Mr. Jenrette, in a 48th-floor office filled with Federal-period antiques. ''Then, only a small number of agents were licensed to sell securities; now a majority are. It comes down to focus and commitment. Insurance people have always felt their job was selling insurance. Now we've got to wed the two together. There's no miracle formula, I just feel that more can be done along these lines.''
To take this position, Mr. Jenrette had to turn down an appealing alternative. Last month, a nominating committee from the New York Stock Exchange appoached him about replacing John J. Phelan Jr. as the exchange's chief executive. In the cutthroat world of Wall Street, the soft-spoken Mr. Jenrette is a survivor.
Twice he has risen to the top spot at major financial institutions - and at both DLJ and Equitable he was not the obvious man for the job. DLJ's two other founders were far more visible, while Equitable has a well-entrenched cadre of executives. But his tenacity, Southern charm and investment acumen paid off for Mr. Jenrette when both firms faced hard times and turned to him for leadership. At DLJ, for instance, he turned around the firm with a strategy of catering to institutional investors after it had gone public and floundered.
Equitable's board, worried about the lagging profitability and the unimpressive credit rating, two weeks ago replaced John B. Carter, a career executive, with Mr. Jenrette.
 
'The Ideal Candidate'
''The change reflects the desire of the board to seek an improvement in bottom-line results,'' said Arthur Levitt Jr., a board member and former head of the American Stock Exchange. ''Dick Jenrette's record prior to and subsequent to his arrival at Equitable makes him the ideal candidate.''
Outsiders say Mr. Jenrette's success at Equitable will depend on the company's ability to hold on to its traditional life insurance business while broadening its investment activities. ''The individual life insurance marketplace is now growing by leaps and bounds and Mr. Jenrette will have quite a challenge to keep commission businesses up,'' said Weston M. Hicks, a vice president at Moody's. ''How well they emerge from their past problems is a function of how their investments perform and whether they avoid major investment problems.''
On the investment side, Mr. Jenrette is confident. He brushes aside concerns about nearly $2 billion in junk bonds held in Equitable's investment portfolio by making a distinction between high- and low-quality junk bonds. ''We don't have a very risky portfolio,'' he said. ''We have a vast analytical capability and our batting average is better.'' And he notes that real estate represents about 10 percent of Equitable's equity holdings, compared with an industry average of 6 percent, and down from 12 percent a year ago. ''I don't think that's an extreme position,'' he added.
The DLJ subsidiary, which Equitable bought for $435 million, has returned about $100 million in cash annually to the parent, Mr. Jenrette said. While some on Wall Street have expressed concern about DLJ's extensive involvement in risky but highly lucrative bridge-loan financing and junk-bond underwriting, DLJ has so far been adept at thriving in the current junk-bond downturn. $300 Million Junk Debt Move Last week, for instance, DLJ privately placed some $300 million in junk debt for Caldor retail stores, which was used to pay off a DLJ bridge loan. To have placed so much debt in a weakened junk-bond market was generally seen on Wall Street as a sign of DLJ's prowess.
Mr. Jenrette said one overlooked element of Equitable's financial strength is what he calls his ''hidden equity'' portfolio, which consists of equity stakes in leveraged buyouts that Mr. Jenrette estimates will produce some $1 billion over the next four to five years.
He therefore thinks Equitable is a stronger company than its rating indicates, and he said he would consider selling pieces of his investment subsidiaries to establish a market value for them and prove his point. But he rejects the idea of taking Equitable public. Insurance agents have generally opposed the idea, thinking it would hurt policyholders, and he notes that the equity market is soft for financial institutions.
''By selling some of the pieces we could demonstrate the value of this stream of earnings from our investment subsidiaries,'' Mr. Jenrette said. ''And that might convince Moody's and Standard & Poor's about our hidden assets.''
In fact, it was to protect those investment subsidiaries that the board turned to Mr. Jenrette. Under Mr. Carter, growth came so fast and at such a cost that Equitable was faced with two choices: drastically cut costs or begin to sell major subsidiaries. Mr. Carter was also a protege of Leo Walsh, Equitable's former chief investment officer, who was ousted in 1988 and blamed for the debacle involving guaranteed investment contracts.
''I think the board's patience ran out,'' said Mr. Jenrette, who himself is a board member. ''They wanted to get the rating up. And people had convinced Mr. Carter that one way was to sell the subsidiaries and return to just being an insurance company. But when the board saw that staring them in the face, they decided that we should take the cuts and not sell the crown jewels.''

GRAPHIC: photo: As the new chief executive of the Equitable Life Assurance Society, Richard H. Jenrette hopes to turn around a 131-year-old company that is the nation's third-largest insurer, with more than $135 billion in assets. (William E. Sauro/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: World Trade Talks Advance Despite Farm-Price Dispute

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, May 31

 BODY:
A meeting of the industrial democracies' finance ministers ended today with officials saying they had made some progress in global trade talks despite sharp differences between the United States and the European Community over agricultural trade.
The finance ministers said in a communique issued today that ''the successful outcome'' of the current four-year round of trade talks, known as the Uruguay Round, was of ''the highest priority.''
Notwithstanding the sharp disagreements between the United Staes and the European Community on how best and how fast to reduce farm subsidies, the ministers said they had agreed to take ''urgent steps'' to reshape agricultural policy.
On Wednesday, the first day of the two-day annual meeting of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, the United States and members of the European Community detailed their differences on farm trade and acknowledged that they were stalemated on that issue. 
American officials said they worried that the standoff on farm trade could imperil the success of the Uruguay Round, a comprehensive set of talks that aims to liberalize world trade rules. The round, involving 105 nations, began in Uruguay in 1986 and will end in December.
But many officials said the meeting had helped move trade negotiations forward by allowing the two sides to voice their differences.
''It is quite normal in negotiations to have positions that are not the same,' said Jean-Claude Paye, Secretary General of the O.E.C.D., a 24-nation organization that seeks to foster economic growth and cooperation. ''This was not the time for the gap to be bridged.''
O.E.C.D. officials said that since the positions had been clarified, there might soon be some compromises. The ministers said they would ''make every effort'' at the July trade talks in Geneva to develop ''an appropriate framework to achieve the objective'' of reducing farm subsidies.
But some officials said they expected the negotiations to go down to the deadline in December.
This week the O.E.C.D. released a report stating that farm subsidies cost consumers and taxpayers $245 billion last year.
To advance the stalled agricultural talks, the United States sought to get the 12-nation European Community to commit itself to eliminating export subsidies, reducing import barriers and cutting price supports.
But community officials refused to commit themselves in all three areas, saying they preferred ''a global approach'' to reduce overall farm aid. Under the European proposal, some farm supports would be reduced, while others might be increased.
 
Unusual in Its Candor
Today's communique was unusual in its candor, stating that ''only limited and uneven progress'' has been made in reducing farm subsidies. In a rare move, the communique stated that Washington and Brussels had clashing views, and it outlined their differences.
The communique issued today made several key points:
* The ministers called for an increase in the savings rate in industrialized nations. In recent months, many ministers have voiced dismay about the shrinking savings rate because savings are needed to help increase investment to spur growth in the West.
* The ministers said ''countries where public-sector borrowing is still too high'' should make further efforts to reduce their budget deficits as quickly as possible. Many officials said this reference was aimed at the United States.
* The O.E.C.D. members said they ''are determined to continue to offer all feasible support to the countries of Central and Eastern Europe.'' The O.E.C.D. has set up the Center for Cooperation with European Economies in Transition to provide Eastern European nations with expert economic advice on privatization, labor retraining and other aspects of moving toward a market economy.
* The ministers expressed growing concern about the high level of subsidies that prop up declining industries. The communique said these subsidies hurt economic growth by diverting money and manpower away from more efficient industries.
The ministers also said that mechanisms for resolving trade disputes should be strengthened and that more steps should be taken to liberalize trade in textiles and tropical products.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Savings Rescue: Figuring the Cost

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
THE cost of the savings and loan bailout could be a lot larger than anyone has expected - indeed, more than $1 trillion.
In the most comprehensive look at the problem to date, the Stanford Law and Policy Review has tried, in a series of articles in its spring issue, to take the full measure of the savings and loan crisis and the costs of a bailout. The estimates in the Review, based on reports of the Office of Management and Budget, the General Accounting Office and the U.S. League of Savings Institutions, are that the costs will come to $456.3 billion over the 10-year period from 1989-99.
The G.A.O. the investigative arm of Congress, has put the cost at $325 billion to $500 billion over three decades. 
But the costs will go on rising as taxpayers put up the money to pay off bondholders. The Stanford Review, published by Stanford University, presents a second table extending the costs out over 40 years, since the rescue is being financed with 30- to 40-year bonds: the total cost estimate climbs to $1,369.9 billion.
That figure breaks down into three categories: the initial $456.3 billion for 1989-99; $274.8 billion for interest on non-Treasury debt during the years 2000-29, and $638.8 billion for Treasury debt from 2000-29. That projection assumes that all costs except interest end by 1999. And it excludes the interest costs of borrowing to pay Treasury interest -that is, the compounding effect of paying interest on interest.
Some Administration economists have been seeking to minimize the costs of the bailout by discounting the outlays, at interest rates assumed to continue at about their present level, back to their present value, as though they represented an investment decision. But Charles L. Schultze, a senior fellow of the Brookings Institution, regards the present-value method of estimating the costs of the bailout as inapplicable to its continuing costs. Money for interest payments will still have to be raised from taxpayers, year after year.
Mr. Schultze said in an interview that the cost of paying off depositors would come to about $160 billion plus interest of roughly $13 billion a year ''forever,'' assuming an average interest rate of only about 8 percent. He says it would be more sensible to create a sinking fund to pay off the bonds in, say, 16 years; that would raise the annual cost to taxpayers to about $22 billion from $13 billion, but would hold the total cost of the bailout to about a third of the Stanford Review's 40-year cost estimate of $1.3 trillion.
Joseph A. Grundfest, who served as a commissioner of the Securities and Exchange Commission from 1985 to 1990 and is now teaching at the Stanford Law School, contends in his article in the Review that the savings crisis was caused primarily by underpriced deposit insurance and inadequate supervision by the regulators. This, he asserts, was no accident but was a result of intense lobbying by the U.S. League. The league declined the Review's invitation to contribute to its symposium.
''Although the losses generated by hundreds of poorly or criminally managed thrifts came to dominate the industry,'' Mr. Grundfest writes, ''well-managed S.&L.'s wanted no part of the fiscal shenanigans that characterized much of the industry's behavior.'' He notes that Warren E. Buffett, the investor, took his solvent and well-managed savings institution out of the league, describing its lobbying campaign as ''so flawed, indeed disgraceful'' that he was resigning.
Even if one believes that the savings crisis is now past, Mr. Grundfest warns that ''complacency is premature'' because ''several other constituencies operate under conditions similar to those that gave rise to the S.&L. debacle.'' To one degree or another, he maintains, other constituencies have broad geographic bases, provide political contributions, and seek off-budget benefits with dollar costs that are either negligible or difficult to measure but have the potential to generate multibillion-dollar losses.
The problems facing the commercial banking industry, he says, are ''hauntingly reminiscent of the difficulties faced by the savings and loan industry in the early 1980's.'' Stressing the need for deposit insurance reform, he quotes analysts like R. Dan Brumbaugh Jr. of Stanford University, who contributes an article to the symposium, as warning that ''more than 1,000 banks with about one-half of the nation's banking assets are undercapitalized.''
Outside the banking industry, Mr. Grundfest says, the Government has more than $745 billion in outstanding loans and loan guarantees. The Federal Government's total exposure is much larger, coming to $5.6 trillion, according to the latest data of the Office of Management and Budget. That includes $2.7 trillion for insured checking and savings accounts, and credit unions; $1.3 trillion in insurance for pensions, crops, overseas investment, etc.; $800 billion for Government-sponsored home mortgages, farming agencies, etc.; $600 billion for F.H.A. and V.A. housing loans, student loans, and small-business loans, and $200 billion in agriculture and other direct loans.
After the savings and loan debacle, as the Stanford symposium makes clear, it has become crucial to examine and repair the entire Government ''financial safety net.''

HEADLINE: Prices Paid To Farmers Up 2% in May

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 31

 BODY:
Prices farmers get for raw products increased 2 percent in May from April, raising the overall commodity index 3.4 percent above a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today.
Higher prices for hogs, corn, hay, broilers and lettuce fueled the increase over the last month, the department's Agricultural Statistics Board said in its preliminary report.
The average price for all hogs of $60.50 per hundred pounds of live weight was the second highest on record, topped only by $62.10 in August 1986. 
Lower prices were reported for eggs, onions, milk and cattle.
While beef cattle prices showed a slight decline, calf prices increased. Prices for sorghum and soybeans were also up from April levels, but barley, wheat and rice dropped slightly.
Agriculture economists said the climb of 3.4 percent in the index of all commodities over a year earlier was propelled by increases in hogs, cattle, milk and grapefruit.
 
Farm Income Expected to Rise
The economists have been saying that net cash income of farmers in 1990 may be in the range of $55 billion to $59 billion, compared with about $53 billion last year. The record was $57.2 billion in 1988.
Net cash income is the money nationally that farmers have left from gross cash income during a calendar year after deducting cash expenses. It includes Government payments and proceeds from crops grown previously but sold during the year.
Consumer food prices are forecast by the department to rise 3 percent to 5 percent this year after posting an average gain of 5.7 percent in 1989, the sharpest rise since 1981.
Based on the preliminary figures, the May price index for livestock and poultry rose 1.2 percent from April and averaged 10 percent above the level of a year ago.
Milk prices dropped 20 cents from April to an average of $13.20 per 100 pounds. Even so, the preliminary May price remained 90 cents above the level of a year ago.
Crop prices, over all, rose 3.1 percent from April but averaged 4.9 percent below the level a year earlier. Fruit prices fueled by oranges and grapefruit were up 3.6 percent from last month, about the same level as a year ago.
The index for commercial vegetables climbed 3.4 percent from the April level but was down 21 percent from a year earlier. Lettuce and tomatoes were up while carrots and onions were down.

HEADLINE: Factory Orders, Barometer for Output, Fell 2.3% in April

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 31

 BODY:
Orders to United States factories slumped 2.3 percent in April, the Commerce Department said today. Despite increased orders in February and March, the decline in April pushed orders down 2 percent for the year so far.
''Basically, it shows the manufacturing sector is still dead in the water,'' said Evelina Tainer, senior domestic economist with the First National Bank of Chicago. ''It's just not going anywhere.'' 
The department said orders to factories for both durable and nondurable manufactured goods totaled a seasonally adjusted $235.6 billion.
The April slide followed gains of 4 percent in March and 1.8 percent in February and a tumble of 5.5 percent in January; overall factory orders have fallen 2 percent in the year's first four months. The department said orders have been relatively flat since the beginning of 1989.
 
Steepest Drop Since '74
The January decline was the steepest since a 7 percent plunge in December 1974.
Factory orders are an important economic barometer of manufacturers' plans for production. A decrease in orders may forecast an industrial slump with future layoffs.
''The decrease in April new orders was concentrated in the durable goods sector, which declined 4.3 percent, to $123.4 billion,'' the department said, revising the drop in durable orders from the 4.1 percent decline first reported last week.
''The largest decrease was in transportation equipment, down 14.7 percent, to $31.7 billion,'' it added. ''Both motor vehicles and aircraft were down.'' Excluding transportation, orders were unchanged.
Transportation orders rose 24.1 percent in March and 10.1 percent in February.
Also unchanged during April were nondurable orders, which remained at $112.2 billion.
 
Barometer of Investments
In the category of nonmilitary capital goods, a barometer of business investment plans, orders fell 9.8 percent, to $36.9 billion, after a 13.3 percent gain the previous month. Excluding aircraft, they were off two-tenths of a percent in April and 1.1 percent in March.
Michael K. Evans of Evans Economics Inc., a Washington forecasting firm, said the capital goods spending report spelled bad news for industrial production.
''Businesses are starting to pull in their horns,'' Mr. Evans said, because of high interest rates and a 16 percent decline in profits last year. He said profits in the first quarter are ''not getting any better.''
The volatile military category posted a 2 percent gain, to $8 billion, after advances of 4.5 percent in March and 18.3 percent in February. Excluding the military category, orders fell 2.4 percent.

HEADLINE: Panel Seeks to Preserve U.S.-Owned Technology

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 31

 BODY:
A Defense Department panel has recommended that the Government ''actively intervene'' to maintain American ownership of industries critical to national security.
The report, by the Defense Science Board Task Force on Foreign Ownership and Control of U.S. Industry, recommended that the Government obtain better data on industries identified as crucial, take specific steps to encourage them to remain in American hands and improve the oversight process of foreign acquisitions of United States companies.
The document represents the latest broadside in a growing debate between those who believe that the Government should have a clearly defined industrial policy and work to nurture and save industries critical to national security and economic growth, and those who advocate a laissez-faire approach and contend that Washington is ill equipped to save any industry that is doomed by the laws of economics.
 
Cheney to Get Report
The report, approved this week by the Defense Science Board, will be presented to Defense Secretary Dick Cheney for action. 
''The task force believes that the Government should, after it makes appropriate investigations and before weak firms are put up for sale, actively intervene to help negotiate U.S. mergers, provide refinancing, or offer other support to assist the critical industry,'' the report said.
The report noted that early last year the Hitachi Corporation of Japan purchased the Ceraclad Corporation, a small ceramics company based in Long Island. Before the buyout, Ceraclad was chosen as one of two American subcontractors to supply highly specialized ceramic ''bodies'' for a fourth-generation, ceramic single-memory chip carrier. ''Two months after the buyout, Hiatchi shut down Ceraclad,'' the report said.
The report also cited the 1985 Minebea acquisition of New Hampshire Ball Bearings, a manufacturer of miniature ball bearings needed to insure the production of militarily critical parts in the United States.
 
Purchase by Sony
Also, while the Sony Corporation's purchase of the MRC Corporation gave the New York-based company access to needed capital and kept the company in the United States, the report noted, control of the only important American maker of some specialized equipment for the manufacture of semiconductors was transferred to the Japanese.
The report found that a built-in conflict with the panel that monitors foreign acquisitions of American companies from the standpoint of national security, the Interagency Committee on Foreign Investment. The panel's chairman, a Treasury Department assistant secretary, has a primary goal of alleviating the overall budget and foreign trade deficits.
''The main failing'' of the interagency committee, the report said, ''is that it does not take a long-term perspective in dealing with foreign ownership and control.''
In addition, ''reviews of proposed foreign acquisitions are further hampered by a shortage of data with which to assess the effects on national security,'' the report said, noting that at least 16 Government agencies now monitored foreign investment.
The report noted that the increasing interdependence in the world economy made complete self-sufficiency ''almost impossible and undesirable.'' It could be argued that interlocked economies and defense procurements really helped to stabilize world security, the report said.
Nevertheless, dependency on foreign manufacturers ''still must be controlled by D.O.D. to retain necessary freedom from foreign industrial constraints,'' the report said.
The 15 panel members from business, Government and universities represented a spectrum of economic philosophies.
The panel chairman is Deborah Coleman, vice president of the Apple Computer Corporation. Other members included C. Fred Bergsten, president of the Institute for International Econmomics; Prof. George Lodge of the Harvard Business School and Malcolm Lovell of George Washington University; Bernard Schwartz, chairman of the Loral Corporation; Pat Choate, vice president of TRW, and Clyde Prestowitz, president of the Economic Strategy Institute.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Cleaning Up In Europe

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
ENVIRONMENTAL companies in Europe are looking attractive, as a result of dirty water, dirty air, acid rain, hazardous waste, sewage and little room for landfills.
One of the pluses, analysts and executives say, is the growing pressure for central regulation of the environment in a united Europe, which is likely to mean stricter and more uniform standards in different countries so that, for example, a business in France does not have an advantage over a company in Germany.
But these analysts and executives warn that the environmental industry is still fragmented and immature. And they say that investment decisions must be made with caution and a long-term view. (Analysts of environmental stocks in the United States are also cautious now because the prices have already moved too high.) More important, European analysts say the euphoria over the profit potential should not spread to East Germany and the rest of Eastern Europe, where the environment has suffered severely under 40 years of Communist rule. Because of a lack of money, analysts and executives do not expect real environmental business to develop in Eastern Europe until at least the mid-1990's. 
''It's for the very brave,'' said David Owen, senior environmental analyst for Paribas Ltd. in London.
But he also argues that the environment will have to be dealt with. He said the quality of water in Eastern Europe was now so bad that much of it could not be used in regular processing, as in chemical plants.
Jerry Leitman, president of ABB Flakt Industrial Processes, the environmental company in the Swedish and Swiss industrial group of Asea Brown Boveri Inc., said the question is: Will ''these needs translate into demand and how soon will that happen?'' He added that ''there is definitely a shortage of money, especially for transnational solutions.''
Jurgen Jung, director of strategic planning for RWE Entsorgung A.G., said, ''At the moment there is not a big environmental opportunity to earn money in these countries.'' He said the opportunity may be there in several years if the countries move toward market economies. But he said that RWE Entsorgung intended to concentrate its pollution efforts in East Germany. ''Because we have to earn money and we are a small company, we will not go into these countries,'' he said, referring to the rest of Eastern Europe.
RWE Entsorgung, which specializes in incineration, sewage sludge treatment, and energy and resource recovery, is the waste management subsidiary of RWE, the West German power company that, as Mr. Owen said, is ''an environmental poacher turned gamekeeper.''
On the environmental play in Europe, Mr. Owen favors companies that have the wherewithal in earnings elsewhere to wait out the fits and starts of environmental development, which he likens to a staircase. Up, with some new regulations, and then flat for a while before rising again. RWE, with electricity accounting for about 40 percent of sales; Asea Brown Boveri, the world's largest capital goods company, and Waste Management Inc., an American-based concern with a growing presence in Europe, fit this category.
He is also interested in the small niche company. Over the next several years these will include the consulting firms and environmental services companies that will grow up with the newer and more complex environmental regulations. He also looks for companies that do special environmental work that larger concerns are not expected to be interested in.
One of these companies is Powerscreen International P.L.C., which makes equipment used in recycling sewage and demolition waste. The company is based in Northern Ireland and Ireland, with operations also in South Wales and Pennsylvania. The Pennsylvania arm, Royer, makes machinery for soil and waste shredding and separation.
Mr. Owen of Paribas also argues that investment in water treatment will be a major environmental opportunity in the 1990's. In his analysis, he said that the spending on water treatment would be far larger than expected because water quality is far below 1980 directives from the European Community. He said, for example, that in Italy 20 million people drink water that is below World Health Organization standards.
In Britain alone, he notes that estimates for capital investment needed to bring water quality to the levels set by the European Community have leaped from several billion pounds, when the privatization of the water authorities was first considered in 1988, to an official 24.6 billion. And he estimates the cost could be as high as 36 billion.
Among the companies that excite his interest in this area are Simon Engineering of Britian, which is involved in ground water decontamination and sewage treatment; KSB of West Germany, a manufacturer of water and fluid pumps and systems handling toxic effluents, and Compagnie Generale des Eaux of France, which does business in water and waste management and treatment.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries End Narrowly Mixed

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were narrowly mixed in light trading yesterday, as dealers awaited this morning's release of May employment data.
Market participants sold securities early in the session after results of surveys from purchasing managers in Detroit and Chicago showed that manufacturers there experienced an uptick in activity during May.
The reports, which are separate from the national purchasing managers survey that will be released a few hours after the employment numbers today, were not welcome news.
 
A Quick Selloff
''The purchasing managers' reports caused a quick selloff,'' one government-bond trader said, ''but people are still positive about the employment numbers.'' 
Victor Chang, president of the VC Management Company, said, ''I expect the employment numbers will confirm the slower pace of the economy in the second quarter.''
''But the Federal Reserve Board won't budge from their current approach to monetary policy,'' he added, ''and I don't believe they will move until sometime in the summer, when they will ease policy marginally.''
Most analysts are forecasting the job figures will show that non-farm payroll employment rose by around 150,000 last month, excluding temporary workers hired to participate in the 1990 Census.
''By and large, the employment forecasts, if borne out, should be pretty favorable for the credit markets,'' said Robert Chandross, chief economist at Lloyds Bank. ''The bulk of the data suggest an economy that is having very modest growth at best.''
 
Firmer Long-Term Prices
While prices of shorter-term Treasury notes dipped slightly, a drop in oil prices and a firmer dollar helped to buttress prices of long-term notes and bonds during afternoon trading.
The Treasury finished a heavy week of short-term borrowings by auctioning $10 billion of one-year bills. The bills were sold at an average discount rate of 7.65 percent, down from an average rate of 8.05 percent at the last one-year bill auction on May 3.
In addition to sales of three-month and six-month bills on Tuesday, the Treasury sold $12 billion of cash management bills on Wednesday. This flood of new short-term paper had a marginally negative impact on bills and notes yesterday.
In late trading, three-month bill rates were offered at a discount rate of 7.74 percent, up one basis point, or hundredths of a point. Six-month bill rates rose by seven basis points, to a late offered rate of 7.72 percent.
 
Benchmark Issue Up 6/32
In the secondary market for Treasury notes and bonds, the 8 3/4 percent bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 101 7/8 late yesterday, up 6/32, to yield 8.57 percent. Late Wednesday, the benchmark issue was offered at a price to yield 8.58 percent.
Among note issues, the 8 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 101 29/ 32, up 1/8 point, to yield 8.58 percent. And the 8 1/2 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 1/32, down 1/32, to yield 8.48 percent.
Activity in the secondary markets for investment-grade corporate bonds and tax-exempt municipal securities was very light, dealers said. Prices of actively traded issues in both markets were little changed.
In other developments, the Federal Reserve Board reported that two of the three measures of the nation's money supply fell during the week ended May 21. The narrowest measure, M-1, rose by $4 billion. The report had no impact on prices in the credit markets.
Following are the results of yesterday's auction of one-year Treasury bills:

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Gasoline Prices Fall Sharply On Report of Higher Supply

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Prices of unleaded gasoline plunged on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday.
Falling prices are unusual at this time of year because the amount of driving normally rises after Memorial Day. Analysts attributed much of the selloff to an unexpected increase in the nation's stocks of crude oil and gasoline. 
''Given the facts that roughly half the crude oil ends up as gasoline at this time of year and that demand for gasoline has slowed with the economy, the rise in stocks knocked the legs from under the gasoline market.'' said Peter C. Beutel, energy analyst at Elders Futures Inc.
At the close of trading, the spot June unleaded gasoline contract, which expired yesterday, settled at 63.89 cents a gallon, down 2.98 cents on the day.
Unlike the spot contract, which has no daily limits on price movements, the other gasoline contracts for delivery in later months closed down the limit of 2 cents a gallon.
Prices for crude oil and heating oil also fell.
 
Rising Oil Imports
The American Petroleum Institute reported that imports of crude increased almost 800,000 barrels from the previous week and 500,000 from a year ago.
In addition, the nation's crude oil stocks were some 40 million barrels higher than a year ago, when supplies from Alaska were sharply curtailed by the Exxon Valdez oil spill. Crude stocks were up two million barrels from the week before.
But the real surprise, said Bradford H. Hughes, an energy analyst at Cargill Investor Services, was that gasoline stocks were up a million barrels in the latest week, while many traders expected a drop of two million to three million barrels.
''Gasoline prices had been rising for weeks because stocks have been running below year-ago levels,'' Mr. Hughes said.
The latest A.P.I. statistics show gasoline stocks are down about 7.5 million barrels from a year earlier.
Traders were also unnerved after Saudi Arabian officials complained that some members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries were cheating on their export quotas.
''Saudi threats to punish the cheaters by flooding the market with oil shouldn't be taken lightly,'' Mr. Beutel said. ''They have used their huge supplies of low-cost oil to punish other OPEC members before.''
The spot crude oil contract for July delivery dropped 68 cents to settle at $17.40 a barrel for West Texas Intermediate crude.
The prices of heating oil also fell. The spot June contract, which expired yesterday, settled at 50.07 cents a gallon, down 1.08 cents.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Dollar Is Mostly Higher In Speculation on Job Data

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar advanced yesterday against all major currencies except the Canadian dollar in advance of today's release of employment figures for May.
Gold prices gained slightly in the United States after weakening abroad.
The start of the summit meeting between President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union in Washington set the market on edge, particularly because a dispute appeared possible over the future role of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization after German unification. 
Tension elsewhere, including in the Middle East, also helped the dollar, traders said. Dollar investments are typically favored in times of uncertainty.
 
Signs of Health
A strong undercurrent influencing trade in dollars was speculation in foreign exchange markets that the employment figures could indicate economic health. The monthly report will furnish the first information on the economy for May.
The pound tumbled yesterday after remarks by the president of the West German Bundesbank, Karl Otto Pohl, who on Wednesday said the time was not right for British entry into the European Monetary System.
Sterling had been bought aggressively in recent days on the assumption that Britain would soon relent in its opposition to joining the exchange rate mechanism in which many European countries participate.
The pound traded in London at $1.676, compared with $1.693 late Wednesday, and continued to stumble in United States trading. A pound fetched $1.678 late in New York, down from $1.695 Wednesday.
The dollar's trading day began on a strong note in Tokyo. It closed in the Japanese capital at 151.75 yen, a gain of 1 yen from Wednesday. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 152.65 yen. It was quoted at 152.10 yen at the end of New York trading, up from 151.45 yen late Wednesday.
Selected late dollar rates in New York, compared with Wednesday's late quotes, included: 1.6965 West German marks, up from 1.6825; 1.4290 Swiss francs, up from 1.42265; 5.724 French francs, up from 5.6735; 1,248.25 Italian lire, up from 1,237.75, and 1.17285 Canadian dollars, down from 1.17675.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, a troy ounce of gold for June delivery added 20 cents to close at $364.30.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Two Views On Whittle's TV Reports

BYLINE: By Randall Rothenberg

 BODY:
A PLAN by Whittle Communications to put advertiser-supported television programming into doctors' waiting rooms is meeting with widespread interest from advertising agencies. But television executives are questioning the analysis used by the Tennessee company to support its claim that the programming will reach consumers whom network television does not attract.
Whittle said two weeks ago that it was developing an hourlong television news program aimed primarily at young mothers. The program would play continuously on a combination large-screen television and videodisk player to be installed in 20,000 physicians' waiting rooms. The program, called Special Reports Television, will change 24 times a year. Whittle says the program will reach 44 million people. 
Advertisers are being offered $5.5 million packages that will combine two 30-second commercials an hour on all 24 shows with a page of advertising in Whittle's three quarterly Special Reports magazines for doctors' offices.
Whittle argues that its target audience - women between 25 and 54 years old, particularly those in their late 20's and early 30's with children - is barely touched by network television. The company says that the people who watch the most television account for 51 percent of all prime-time viewing but are not a desirable market for most consumer-products companies. Citing data from the Simmons Market Research Bureau, Whittle says that 63 percent of this group are unemployed and 52 percent have household incomes under $20,000.
Whittle says 46 percent of the 38 million women with children in the United States are among the most infrequent television viewers. The waiting rooms of pediatricians, obstetrician-gynecologists and family practitioners, the company says, are the places to reach them.
Marketing executives, having heard that argument before from Whittle, have spent $80 million on advertising during the first two years of the company's Special Reports magazines.
Some advertising executives had been critical of Whittle's projections and research for the magazines, and some advised their clients to reduce their ad expenditures in them. But many of these executives say they have been impressed by the rigor of the research the company has used to support Special Reports Television.
Calling Special Reports Television ''extremely creative,'' John J. Sisk, Jr., the director of network negotiations at J. Walter Thompson U.S.A., said it could turn out to be ''a form of television that can reach potential customers no one else can reach.''
Nevertheless, questions have arisen about Whittle's new project.
The company is basing the marketing of its waiting-room network on what is known in television as a quintile analysis, in which a large market is divided into five groups, from the heaviest to the lightest viewers. Whittle says the networks draw primarily from the heaviest, but least desirable viewers, in quintiles one and two, instead of what it calls the more attractive, light viewers in quintiles four and five.
But television executives say the fifth quintile is of little interest to marketers. Robert Niles, vice president of research at NBC, characterized that quintile as largely ''a downscale audience'' made up of ''second-shift workers, blue-collar and older people who go to bed early.''
Others question the lengths to which Whittle takes its quintile analysis. Willard Hadlock, the head of media services at the Leo Burnett advertising agency, said: ''Quintiles four and five are not necessarily the lightest viewers. In some cases, they're the heaviest viewers. When they're home with a baby, they watch a lot of TV.''
Furthermore, both network and agency executives say that network schedules can be tailored to reach the light viewers, and they question whether even pregnant women or young mothers go to their physicians often enough to give the advertising punch.
''Effective advertising is a combination of reach and frequency,'' said David F. Poltrack, senior vice president of research at CBS. ''With Whittle's program, you don't get frequency. I don't know too many people who go to the doctor's more than once every two weeks.''
Mr. Poltrack compared Special Reports Television to airline advertising, which also reaches a selective, affluent audience, but too infrequently to represent a threat to network television.
Mr. Sisk of J. Walter Thompson, nevertheless, called Whittle's television project ''another form of chipping away at the networks.''

HEADLINE: Kipp Alan Rogers, 32, Entertainment Lawyer

 BODY:
Kipp Alan Rogers, a lawyer who represented entertainment figures and organizations, died of AIDS on Saturday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 32 years old. 
Before moving to Los Angeles last year to become the director of business affairs for Home Box Office, Mr. Rogers was a lawyer at the New York firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison. While there he worked with theater, film and television clients and did legal work on plays, including ''The Phantom of the Opera,'' ''Starlight Express'' and ''Lend Me a Tenor.'' He was also a pro bono counsel for a 1987 benefit at Lincoln Center that raised about $1.3 million for AIDS care, research and education.
Mr. Rogers was born and grew up in Wellington, Kan., and graduated with honors in economics from Harvard College in 1979. He worked for a year for the producer Richard Horner in New York, then returned to Cambridge and graduated with honors from the Harvard Law School in 1983.
He was a corporate lawyer on Wall Street for a year, at Cravath, Swaine & Moore, before joining Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison.
Mr. Rogers's companion was Harold Gunn of Los Angeles.
Surviving are Mr. Rogers's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Rogers, of Wellington; two brothers, Jeffrey, of Wellington, and John, of New Haven, and a sister, Anne, of Belchertown, Mass.

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN WASHINGTON;
Family First, Mrs. Bush Tells Friend and Foe at Wellesley 44

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WELLESLEY, Mass., June 1

 BODY:
Barbara Bush today gently confronted seniors at Wellesley College who had protested her choice as their commencement speaker, telling them that husbands and children are ultimately more important than careers.
''As important as your obligations as a doctor, a lawyer or a business leader may be,'' said Mrs. Bush, with her fellow speaker, Raisa M. Gorbachev, seated behind her, ''your human connections with spouses, with children, with friends, are the most important investment you will ever make.
''At the end of your life, you will never regret not having passed one more test, not winning one more verdict or not closing one more deal,'' said Mrs. Bush, wearing a black academic gown. ''You will regret time not spent with a husband, a child, a friend or a parent.''
 
A Spouse of Another Stripe
But Mrs. Bush softened her lecture on family values with wit. ''Who knows,'' she told the graduating seniors, their family members and professors, ''somewhere out in this audience may even be someone who will one day follow in my footsteps and preside over the White House as the President's spouse.'' 
Then, after a pause, she added, ''And I wish him well.''
The audience of 5,400 people, seated under a huge white tent, roared with laughter and gave Mrs. Bush a ringing ovation.
Her appearance at Wellesley, which started with a seemingly innocuous invitation from the senior class, ignited a debate around the country about women's roles. What Kind of Role Model? The conflict started with a petition by 150 students who said they were outraged by the selection of Mrs. Bush as graduation speaker since she did not represent the career woman they believed Wellesley seeks to educate. Mrs. Bush dropped out of Smith College after two years to marry and has been best known as a supportive wife and mother in the family of a politician.
But as the debate over her appearance here grew more heated, the invitation to Mrs. Bush paid an unexpected dividend when the summit meeting between President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union happened to coincide with Wellesley's commencement and Mrs. Bush asked Mrs. Gorbachev to join her.
''It's a public relations dream for Wellesley,'' said Marshall Goldman, a professor at the college and a specialist on the Soviet economy.
 
Mrs. Bush Triumphs
It was also a triumph for Mrs. Bush, who not only won over most of her audience but to many listeners delivered a more interesting talk than Mrs. Gorbachev, who holds the Soviet equivalent of a Ph.D. and was a university professor before her husband became head of the Soviet Communist Party.
Mrs. Gorbachev, perhaps mindful of earlier criticism of her for sounding too preachy, stuck to safe sentiments about friendship, peace and perestroika, echoing many of her husband's recent themes.
Professor Goldman said later: ''I was disappointed with her. I was really hoping she was going to say something more.''
Mrs. Gorbachev waited until an appearance at Boston's Public Garden to state her own views on the contradictions of the modern woman's role.
Women's careers, she said, have less to do with earning a living than ''expressing themselves as individuals.'' But at the same time, she said, ''I am among those who believe that children and family are very important for a woman and a life without them is one-sided.''
 
A Contradiction Seen
Mrs. Gorbachev said that striking the balance between the two facets of womanhood ''is one of the contradictions of our time.''
''At this juncture, each of us looks for her own solution to the problem,'' she said. ''This is one of the problems society had to deal with.''
While she was willing to discuss a woman's role, she shied away from the use of the word ''feminist,'' which in the Soviet Union carries a strong negative connotation of radical female separatism.
Earlier, as she left the commencement tent at Wellesley, a Russian-speaker asked her, ''Are you a feminist?''
Instead of answering, Mrs. Gorbachev demurred, saying she had to get back to the motorcade.
But a minute later, she was answering the question of another Russian-speaker who wanted to know her feelings about the impasse between Moscow and the independence-minded Lithuanians.
''All of my compatriots are suffering because of the developments there,'' she said. ''There are several nationalities, several opinions there, and we have to take into consideration all their opinions and the will of all the people.
''I do believe on these grounds we shall arrive at the best results.''
 
The Preferred Speaker
Mrs. Bush, in her talk at Wellesley, poked fun at herself. ''Now I know your first choice today was Alice Walker,'' she said of the novelist who had been the students' preference for commencement speaker.
''Alice Walker is known for 'The Color Purple,' '' Mrs. Bush said, referring to the author and her Pulitzer Prize-winning novel. ''Instead you got me, known for the color of my hair.''
''I thought it was wonderful,'' said Meliti Dikeos of Bronxville, N.Y. ''She knew how to direct us. She is very caring.''
Ms. Dikeos, like most of the seniors, was wearing a purple felt armband designed both as a gesture of reconciliation with Mrs. Bush and as a reminder to the First Lady of what the students feel is the unfinished agenda of women's needs.
In a new petition made public today, a group of students said, ''In honoring Barbara Bush as our commencement speaker, we celebrate all the unknown women who have dedicated their lives to the service of others.'' The purple armbands, the petition said, were to honor these unsung heroes among ordinary women.
The petition also asked Mrs. Bush, ''as a concerned mother,'' to ''take a definitive stand'' on a series of issues, including more affordable day care, cuts in welfare funds and the gap in wages between men and women.
 
Some Are Unreconciled
Despite the warm reception for Mrs. Bush, some students stuck to their original position - that they would have preferred a speaker with a record of accomplishment in the working world.
''Wellesley encourages us to make our own niches in life and be our own person,'' said Joyce Anagnos, from Toledo, Ohio. ''Perhaps there are better speakers out there who would exemplify that.''
The college's president, Nan Keohane, told the students that the controversy over the invitation to Mrs. Bush had actually proved beneficial, providing an opportunity for people to re-examine what the proper role for a modern woman should be. The reaction to the dispute around the country had also served as a ''interesting lesson,'' she said, in the importance of free speech.
Many people outside Wellesley had sharply attacked the students, believing that they were criticizing the First Lady, President Keohane said. She reported that she had even received a letter from a sixth-grade class in Jacksonville, Fla., which said ''the Wellesley students must be very dumb to express such views and must not have learned anything at our fancy college.''
President Keohane said she was particularly startled by a warning in the letter, presumably drafted by the class's teacher, ''not to give us any of this First Amendment stuff,'' about the right of free speech.
In any case, she said, this year's commencement will not be like most such exercises, that ''no one remembers very clearly.''

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN WASHINGTON: Reporter's Notebook;
Masters of the Sound Bite Cede Match to Gorbachev

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 1

 BODY:
If a K.G.B. villain in a John Le Carre novel had devised a fiendish torture for American politicians, it could not have been more effective than the one that Mikhail S. Gorbachev inflicted on Congressional leaders this morning.
Mr. Gorbachev invited a dozen Democratic and Republican lawmakers to the Soviet Embassy for a televised question-and-answer session. Then he did all the talking. The legislators were primed to put the Soviet President on the spot with some tart questions that would impress the folks at home. But when Mr. Gorbachev began answering his first question, a query posed by George J. Mitchell, the Senate Majority Leader, about the Soviet economy, the lawmakers around the table watched in growing consternation as the Soviet leader droned on about state property, collective property, comparative property, lease property, private property, shareholders' societies, leaseholds, private initiatives and entrepreneurship.
They knew they were in trouble when Mr. Gorbachev said, ''This is a very important matter and therefore a bit of history is necessary.'' He finished 28 minutes later, half the allotted time for questions. 
For his second question, on Lithuania, the Soviet leader took 10 minutes to lecture on Soviet shipping rights in Klaipeda, a Lithuanian port.
The Senate Minority Leader, Bob Dole, looked on with a tight little smile. Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas rubbed his forehead wearily. Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia offered a glazed stare. Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri and Senator Alan Cranston of California looked like candidates for Mount Rushmore.
 
A Talent for Filibuster
As a closet reformer in the Communist system, Mr. Gorbachev long ago developed a talent for filibuster that would have impressed even that master of the long-winded art, Senator Huey P. Long of Louisiana.
When Mr. Gorbachev met with Congressional leaders during the 1987 summit meeting, even the biggest skeptics came away rhapsodizing about his political finesse, marveling that he was just like them.
This time, the fact that he was just like them, wanting to talk and talk as the cameras rolled, 10,000 words in all, was no longer so charming. In fact, it made the Americans impatient.
''He does have long answers,'' Mr. Dole noted wryly, afterwards. ''He'd fit right in in the Senate.''
Senator Claiborne Pell of Rhode Island agreed: ''He wanted to get across his propaganda points. He did it very ably, but not very briefly.''
The members of Congress were so rattled at being upstaged that they also complained that Mr. Gorbachev outfoxed them by inviting Cable News Network to film the session, without warning them that it was being carried live throughout the world. (Although it was hard to imagine what they thought four cameras and lights were doing there.) Mr. Dole was not pleased when he found out that he had been caught nodding his head in apparent assent as Mr. Gorbachev lambasted Israel for resettling Soviet Jews in the occupied West Bank.
''It would have been nice to have a heads-up,'' sniffed Walt Riker, Mr. Dole's spokesman.
But Mr. Gorbachev found a sympathetic fellow executive in George Bush, who often meets with the same legislators. Greeting the Soviet President at the White House afterward, Mr. Bush told him he had seen the session on television.
''You earned your paycheck,'' Mr. Bush assured Mr. Gorbachev.
 
The Charisma Contest
Chemistry 101: One of the ways Mikhail Gorbachev manages to project confidence, even as he stands on quicksand, is to use President Bush as a foil to convey the impression that he is open and upbeat and daring.
Even though Mr. Bush is taller, older, fitter and possessed of a better gross national product, Mr. Gorbachev seems more the sparkplug when the two are interviewed together.
Mr. Gorbachev always stops to chat longer with reporters, while Mr. Bush keeps trying to move away. Mr. Gorbachev speaks positively about the progress made, while Mr. Bush, when he can get a word in edgewise, speaks more cautiously.
Many Bush Administration officials get edgy and envious when Mr. Gorbachev is in town. They don't like the way he is hailed as a leader of vision while Mr. Bush is criticized as one who replaces vision with pragmatism and boldness with incrementalism.
They whisper insistently that it is really Mr. Bush who has the vision because he pushed early on for a unified Germany and he ''put his chips'' on the Japanese.
''Gorbachev's like Jimmy Carter,'' one Bush adviser said. ''He's a technocrat who can't see the larger patterns.''
 
A Hard Day's Rewards
The Soviet leader was swathed today in the sort of adulation accorded rock stars. In a scene reminiscent of a Beatles concert, one woman wept openly and pulled at her clothes and screamed, ''Gorbachev! Gorbachev!'' as she tried to fight her way past a police officer. Men and women screamed, ''We love you!'' as he passed.
There were times when, like an actor, he seemed almost addicted to the applause and waves of validation. Oblivious to security concerns, he leaned half his body out his limousine window, waving to the Washingtonians lining the streets and hanging from balconies and windows.
His aides had to force the reluctant Mr. Gorbachev back into his limousine after he made another unscheduled stop on Connecticut Avenue, grabbing people by the arm on the same spot where he wowed crowds in 1987.
 
Late Bloomer
Arkady A. Maslennikov did not start off with a bang.
American reporters complained that the new Soviet spokesman was like ''a potted plant'' at the podium, and Soviet reporters and White House officials complained he was nowhere to be found.
Mr. Maslennikov, an earnest fellow, is a far cry from the spokesman Americans are used to, the urbane lover of good brandy, expensive clothes and crackling bon mots, Gennadi I. Gerasimov. When Mr. Gorbachev got his new title of President, he created his own spokesman's job, patterned on the White House model.
Although it would seem on the surface that Mr. Gerasimov was more suited to the sophisticated image that Mr. Gorbachev wants to project to the West, Mr. Gorbachev apparently likes Mr. Maslennikov's less flashy and less sarcastic style.
Mr. Maslennikov, a 59-year-old former correspondent for Pravda, is not the sort to come up with clever formulations like ''the Sinatra doctrine,'' which Mr. Gerasimov coined to describe the Kremlin's agreement to let Eastern European satellites do things their way.
While Mr. Gerasimov's joint briefings with the White House press spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, tended to be good-natured contests, Mr. Maslennikov more often defers to his American counterpart. Asked about Mr. Gorbachev's goals for Germany, the Soviet spokesman replied, ''Mr. Fitzwater very ably speaks for both Presidents.''
Mr. Maslennikov was nearly three hours late for his first American briefing, at the summit press center at George Washington University, and he failed to take his seat in the summit meeting on Thursday at the White House. Mr. Fitzwater scribbled frantic notes to his aides, ''Where's Arkady?'' and the answer came back, ''We don't know.''
But today Mr. Maslennikov began to get some self-confidence.
Evelyn Y. Davis, an American who has made a career of buying small amounts of stock in corporations and then heckling corporate honchos at annual shareholders' meetings, showed up at the briefing to ask a question.
''I'd like to know under this forthcoming trade agreement, what is being done to protect our corporations and stockholders from holding the bag?'' Ms. Davis asked, adding that she might be a gadfly, but she is also a millionaire.
Mr. Fitzwater joked that Ms. Davis was ''one of the fruits of capitalism,'' but Mr. Maslennikov spoke up with a new smoothness.
''Ms. Davis,'' he said, ''if you want to invest in the U.S.S.R., you may be sure your millions will not be expropriated.''
 
Shields and Champagne
Mikhail Gorbachev may not have had any concern for his safety on the streets of Washington, but at the dinner tonight at the Soviet Embassy, he and President Bush were protected by towering bullet proof shields.
The shields were placed between the two Presidents and the windows behind their seats in the ornate embassy dining room.
About 80 guests - a mix of White House officials, Cabinet members, Congressional leaders and industry executives who do business with the Soviet Union - were present as Mr. Gorbachev and Mr. Bush toasted their summit agreements with Zolotoye golden Soviet champagne.
The guests wore business attire, but there was an echo of the splendor of the czars in the menu: baked sevruga fish, roast suckling pig, strawberry parfait, apple puff pastry and renowned 1987 Georgian wines - a dry white Tsinandali and a dry red Mookoozani.
