The New York Times

PUB-DATE: June 2, 1990

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1, Column 6; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1997 words

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN WASHINGTON;
BUSH AND GORBACHEV SIGN MAJOR ACCORDS ON MISSILES, CHEMICAL WEAPONS AND TRADE

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 1

 BODY:
President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today consolidated the gains of their new relationship by signing the broadest Soviet-American understandings in two decades, including commitments to cut stockpiles of long-range nuclear arms and to eliminate most of their chemical weapons.
Mr. Bush unexpectedly signed the trade treaty that Mr. Gorbachev had been hoping to take back to a restive and hungry nation, even though the Soviet Union has not yet carried out a promise to enact emigration laws that are the condition for removing long-standing restrictions on tariffs and loans to Moscow.
To avoid a confrontation with Congress, American officials said, Mr. Bush told Mr. Gorbachev that he would not send the pact to Congress or move to grant preferential tariffs until the emigration law had been enacted. The Soviet President had held up an agreement on long-term grain sales to get the trade pact in his pocket.
 
Lithuania Is an Issue
Mr. Bush apparently set aside his concerns about Lithuania in signing the trade treaty. But Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said tonight that it would be very difficult to get the treaty through Congress or to lift the restrictions on Soviet trade as long as the standoff persisted betweeen Moscow and Lithuania over the Baltic republic's demand for independence. 
At a ceremony replete with the power and majesty of superpower summitry, Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev appeared in the East Room of the White House and sat at a table where treaties have been signed since 1898.
With the hammer-and-sickle flag at Mr. Bush's elbow and the stars-and-stripes flag at Mr. Gorbachev's, and dozens of senior American and Soviet officials seated before them, the two leaders also signed or announced a series of agreements covering topics including nuclear testing, grain sales, student exchanges, scientific and technical cooperation, civil aviation and maritime transportation. [The text of the statement on missiles and summaries of other accords are on page 8.] Strong Flavor of Optimism In some ways, the two Presidents were carrying on work started in an earlier era, a cold-war agenda initiated by Presidents over the past two decades before the emergence of democracy ripped asunder the postwar military and political structures of Europe.
The two leaders infused the event with a strong flavor of optimism, of two nations once adversaries and now striding together into a new era.
''Not long ago, some believed that the weight of history condemned our two great countries, our two great peoples, to permanent confrontation,'' Mr. Bush said. ''Well, you and I must challenge history.''
Mr. Bush declared, ''We may not agree on everything, indeed we don't agree on everything. But we believe in one great truth: the world has waited long enough, the cold war must end.''
Mr. Gorbachev, who quoted from Franklin D. Roosevelt's ''Four Freedoms,'' spoke in his turn of ''building a new civilization.''
Glancing at his formal surroundings, Mr. Gorbachev said, ''This room has seen many important events and agreements signed, but I think that what has happened now represents an event of momentous importance, not only for our two countries but for the rest of the world.''
The first phase of the summit meeting came to a formal end after two days of talks and was remarkable for its sheer numbers: about 15 agreements, protocols and joint statements were signed this evening in the White House.
 
Weekend Talks at Camp David
Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev will continue their talks on Saturday at Camp David, the Presidential retreat in the Catoctin Mountains of Maryland.
Mr. Gorbachev had a chance to revel in the respect of the American President and in the adulation of Americans, receiving a series of awards today at the Soviet Embassy, taking another of his trademark strolls through downtown Washington and spending 90 minutes bantering with the leaders of Congress. The day ended with a dinner at the Soviet Embassy where Mr. Gorbachev paid tribute to Andrei D. Sakharov, the dissident whom Mr. Gorbachev freed from years of internal exile within the Soviet Union. The Soviet President called the late dissident a person ''ahead of his time.''
The two leaders had the chance to carry through on some of the promises they made at their first summit meeting in Malta last year. They signed an agreement outlining a treaty that would reduce by 30 percent the two countries' stockpiles of nuclear missiles that can span the oceans, called on their negotiators to finish the actual treaty by year's end and agreed to a whole new round of nuclear disarmament talks.
 
Vast Cuts in Poison Gas
They also agreed to make vast cuts in their stocks of poison gas weapons, reducing them by about 80 percent, and pledged to work toward a worldwide ban on chemical weapons.
But the pomp was shadowed by the larger problems already testing the new superpower comity - the future of Europe and its shaky military alliances. The signing ceremony today marked only the start of what may be the hardest work, the talks at Camp David, which are expected to focus on Germany and European security issues.
For today, Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev glossed over their differences with a vague commitment to accelerate the effort to conclude a treaty on conventional, or non-nuclear, weapons by the end of the year.
The leaders agreed that the treaty is ''essential to the future stability and security of the continent,'' but they offered no new formulas for resolving their technical differences or their more sweeping disputes over the future of the Germanys and the Continent's military alliances.
Mr. Baker said tonight that the two leaders had made no progress in resolving their differences over Washington's insistence that a united Germany must remain a full member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
 
Some Issues Unresolved
The joint statement on strategic nuclear weapons, those with a range of more than 3,000 miles, suggested that the two sides had not been able to resolve several important issues on which they had been working frantically over the last week, including a last-minute conference this afternoon between Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze and Secretary of State Baker.
These disputes involve American demands for further limits on the production of the Soviet Union's SS-18, its biggest intercontinental missile, questions about the treaty's handling of mobile launchers for intercontinental missiles and on missiles that carry more than one nuclear charge.
The statement outlined the framework of a treaty that would make the first actual cuts in the number of nuclear warheads that each side has put into ballistic missiles, nuclear bombs dropped by aircraft and the jet-propelled, pilotless weapons known as cruise missiles.
Previous agreements simply sought to put caps on the growth in such arsenals. The treaty has been presented as a 50 percent reduction in long-range nuclear arms, but that is somewhat misleading.
It does provide for a roughly 50 percent reduction, to 4,900, in the number of warheads deployed on intercontinental missiles, the weapons that the United States considers to be the most threatening.
 
Rules Are Complex
But the rules for counting and reducing other kinds of weapons are extremely complex and there are a number of uncertainties in the treaty that will provide for smaller reductions than 50 percent.
For example, an aircraft that drops nuclear bombs is counted as having only one charge, or ''warhead,'' aboard even though it actually carries many more weapons. The treaty also does not place any formal limits on cruise missiles launched from ships and submarines.
In the statement on future negotiations on strategic arms, the Americans won a provision speaking of possible steps to further constrain the biggest missiles, a response to conservative critics of the current agreement. Moscow is likely to use the statement to press its demands that American sea-based missiles be subject to further limits.
 
Doubts on Chemical Accord
Some critics have contended that the chemical weapons agreement signed today is flawed, because of verification problems and because the Soviet Union lacks the equipment to actually destroy the weapons. But it is a significant step toward eliminating poison gas from Soviet and American weapons stockpiles.
The agreement calls for the countries to begin destroying chemical weapons in 1992, eliminating half of their stockpiles by the end of 1999. By 2002, stocks are to be no more than 5,000 metric tons, or about 20 percent of the current American stores of poison gas agents. The exact size of the Soviet arsenal is not known.
The document also reaffirms Mr. Bush's previous commitment to cancel production of a new generation of chemical weapons. The Soviet Union says it has stopped producing chemical arms.
 
An 'Agreement,' Not 'Treaty'
The accord was deliberately not cast as a treaty. Under the Constitution, a formal treaty would require the Senate's advice and consent to ratification, with approval by a two-thirds majority. In this case, Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev signed an ''agreement'' that will require only a simple majority in each house.
The only other arms control agreements signed at the summit meeting today were two documents outlining verification for old treaties limiting the size of underground nuclear explosions. Those treaties have not been ratified, but have been observed by both sides.
The final working day of the summit meeting saw Mr. Gorbachev plunge once again into his single-handed public relations campaign.
For the second day, he screeched up to a Washington curbside in his limousine. Diners streamed onto a restaurant balcony. Sirens wailed. Men in business suits ran down the sidewalk as Mr. Gorbachev shook hands on both sides of the street.
 
Some Flashes of Annoyance
But when he seemed to feel pressed, there were flashes, too, of iron will and resentment of what he calls meddling and preaching by the West.
For 90 minutes this morning, in a gilt room in the Soviet Embassy, Mr. Gorbachev lectured leaders of Congress on his country's economy, on his programs for reform and on his policy toward the movement by the Baltic republics to leave the Soviet Union.
When Senator Bob Dole, the minority leader, complained about Moscow's battle with Lithuania, which declared independence March 11. Mr. Gorbachev fired back with a gibe on the invasion of Panama. His smile faded again when Representative Richard Gephardt, the House majority leader, referred to a promised new Soviet law on free emigration and the American desire to link that bill to American-Soviet trade relations.
''When we hear there is a debate in Congress about our affairs, about our legislation, about what we should do, well, then this is resented in our society,'' Mr. Gorbachev said. ''This is a matter of dignity. This is a matter of prestige. This is a matter of sovereignty and national dignity.''
 
Benefit to China Noted
During the discussion about giving the Soviet Union most-favored-nation trade status, Yevgeny M. Primakov, a member of Mr. Gorbachev's Presidential Council, interjected that Mr. Bush had recently recommended extending favored tariff treatment to China for another year, despite the crackdown on political dissent and the violence in Tiananmen Square last year.
''What should we do for you to give us M.F.N.?'' he asked. ''Maybe we should introduce martial rule in the Baltics and at least fire some rounds.''
In the afternoon, Mr. Gorbachev received four awards from American organizations: the Franklin D. Roosevelt International Four Freedoms award from the Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt Institute, the Martin Luther King International Peace Award from Friends World College, the Man of History Award from the Appeal of Conscience Foundation and the award of the Albert Einstein Peace Prize Foundation.

HEADLINE: U.S. Worried Over Safety of Americans in Liberia as Crisis Grows

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 1

 BODY:
Bush Administration officials expressed concern today that the increasing turmoil in Liberia is posing a threat to American lives and property.
The Administration is especially worried that important United States communications installations outside the Liberian capital could be damaged by the escalating violence, the officials said. Relay stations for Voice of America and United States diplomatic communications near Monrovia are each valued at $200 million, and officials say they are virtually unprotected.
Charles Taylor, the guerrilla leader who is challenging the Government of President Samuel K. Doe, has assured Washington that American property and citizens are not targets. But Administration officials remain skeptical. 
''What we're concerned about,'' said Herman J. Cohen, Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, ''is getting caught in a crossfire of combat and the development of uncontrolled, undisciplined military operations. The security situation is deteriorating.''
 
Leery of Both Sides
American officials expressed little sympathy for Mr. Taylor or General Doe. One State Department official characterized the conflict as one for ''power and control'' over the West African nation rather than one of ideology.
Increasingly frustrated by General Doe's human rights record, Washington has steadily reduced assistance to his country. In 1986, the United States provided $53.5 million in economic and military assistance to Liberia; in fiscal 1990, it offered no military aid and just $10 million in food and other humanitarian assistance.
American officials are also leery of Mr. Taylor, whose original force of 60 rebels was armed and trained by Libya. After invading Liberia from the Ivory Coast in January, his movement successfully turned the Gio and Mano tribes in Nimba Province against the central Government, which is dominated by members of the Krahn tribe.
Like most members of the Liberian elite, Mr. Taylor was educated in the United States. While attending Bentley College near Boston, he organized Liberians living in the United States in opposition to President William Tolbert, whose Government was dominated by a minority group of descendants of freed American slaves who migrated to Liberia in the early 19th century.
When General Doe overthrew the Tolbert Government in 1980, Mr. Taylor returned to Liberia to join the new Government as a mid-level manager. Exile in U.S. Mr. Taylor fled Liberia for the United States in 1983 after a falling out with General Doe. The Liberian Government sought his extradition on charges that he diverted $900,000 of Government money, and a Federal court in Boston found the evidence sufficient to detain him in a county prison.
Mr. Taylor broke out of jail with two other prisoners and escaped to Liberia, where he joined in an unsuccessful coup attempt in 1985.
''He's a driven person,'' said Ramsey Clark, the former United States Attorney General who served as Mr. Taylor's lawyer during the extradition proceedings. ''He is single-minded in his determination to liberate his country.''
Mr. Clark said that his former client was a believer in free enterprise and democracy.
The Administration's two immediate policy goals are to ease the way for talks between Mr. Taylor and General Doe and to evacuate as many of the 1,200 American citizens from the West African nation as possible.
The United States Navy has dispatched six ships and 2,300 Marines to positions off the Liberian coast so that they will be available to evacuate American citizens should the Robertsfield International Airport be closed by fighting. Of the 102 American officials stationed in Liberia, all but about 25 will leave within days.
 
Abductions Add to Fears
Mr. Cohen said his fear that violence might spiral increased when undisciplined Doe forces entered a United Nations refugee facility on Wednesday and abducted 40 refugees. Several of them reportedly were killed. ''The development of a chaotic situation concerns everybody,'' he said.
So far one American, a missionary caught in a crossfire two months ago, has been killed in the fighting.

HEADLINE: Test of a Summit

BYLINE: By R.W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 1

 BODY:
President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union have done much better at their second summit conference on the agenda from the past than on the agenda for the future. They have done better on the issues that constitute the legacy of the cold war than on the issues thrown up by its demise.
With two days of formal negotiations complete and a Saturday of informal conversations at Camp David still to come, it is not entirely clear if this meeting has met the test for success that was suggested beforehand by Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh, the new Soviet Ambassador to Washington: Are the leaders ''sincerely convinced that relations are on the right track''?
The two men talk to each other ''sometimes bluntly but never belligerently,'' a participant in the meetings said, and they ''respect each other's perspectives.'' But except in the most basic sense of wishing to avoid war, their goals for the years ahead have not yet meshed. Another participant added, ''So far, on the issues that really drive the relationship, they have not fully engaged.'' 
 
'Toward a New World'
To use a bit of political patois made famous by the former Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill, what has been achieved ''ain't beanbag'': a landmark treaty on chemical weapons; lesser accords on topics like nuclear testing and grain and the environment and cultural exchanges, and an agreement outlining a strategic arms treaty, which came only after eight grinding years of bargaining and a last-minute hitch that for several hours threatened to delay the whole thing.
''We are making steps toward a new world,'' Mr. Gorbachev said at tonight's gala signing ceremony. ''The area of disagreement is being narrowed.''
The strategic arms treaty will be the first ever to require the destruction of any of the weapons that the United States and the Soviet Union have been using for decades to threaten each other with nuclear annihilation. The reductions in the strike forces will amount to about a third, not a half, as originally envisaged. The terms have upset many American conservatives, and some points had to be deferred.
Old questions related to new ones have proved more nettlesome: a trade agreement to which both sides committed themselves 18 years ago remains entangled in the crisis in Lithuania, even though Mr. Gorbachev got the economic trophy that he had lobbied for, and progress in the negotiations on conventional forces in Europe was limited by the issue that undergirds almost all diplomacy these days - the military posture of a unified Germany.
 
Filled With Political Peril
The nationalities question, as epitomized by but not limited to Lithuania and the other Baltic republics, is filled with political peril for Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev.
Still, the package of documents signed by the two presidents late this afternoon represents a body of accomplishment that is unsurpassed in Soviet-American relations since the days of detente almost 20 years ago.
But so far at least, Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev have found it much harder to set out a course for the new Europe, with clearly understood, mutually acceptable roles for the United States, the Soviet Union and a unified Germany, than to undo some of the grosser military excesses of the recent past.
If Dean Acheson was ''Present at the Creation'' of a new world order almost a half-century ago, as the title of his memoirs asserted, Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev have been chosen by history to be present at the re-creation. But they have not reached real agreement on what sort of a world they want to see, and even if they did so, neither has the authority any longer to impose his vision on the rest of the world.
 
Seeking to Preserve Power
Mr. Gorbachev came to Washington seeking to preserve his power and that of his country, apprehensive like every Russian leader from Peter the Great to Nikita S. Khrushchev about whether foreigners would treat his country with sufficient dignity. His wife thanked the audience at the Library of Congress on Thursday for according respect to Soviet art, and Mr. Gorbachev told a Congressional delegation that ''it would be humiliating if we were to ask, to beg for something from you.''
He and Mr. Bush both have a vested interest in stability; incumbents always do. But the real question before them was not, as Mr. Gorbachev framed it, ''Does the United States want a Soviet Union which is weak, torn by complexes and problems and turmoil, or do you want a dynamic Soviet state that is open to the outside world?'' It was: ''How do we get there? Who yields what?'' Like Charles de Gaulle in World War II, Mr. Gorbachev has transformed his weakness into strength at the bargaining table, implicitly warning Mr. Bush that a successor might be less to American liking. But the efficacy of that tactic has been reduced by the emergence of Boris N. Yeltsin, the new President of the Russian republic, as a formidable rival. It now seems to many American policy makers that Mr. Yeltsin is as credible an alternative, apres Gorbachev, as the deluge of neo-Stalinism.
 
Forcing the Pace
Mr. Gorbachev, tired as he is, has worked furiously, appealing to every constituency he can think of, from actors to senators to pedestrians to the television networks, in addition to Mr. Bush.
He has forced the pace. When he said at the White House on Thursday evening that new ideas had been put forward on Germany, surprised Administration officials from the President on down had to scramble to match him, with the result that they contradicted one another.
For his efforts, he appears to have achieved at least one important goal beyond the formal agreements: he has driven home to many American officials, one of them said, the intensity of his country's apprehension about Germany. That has made it more likely that the West will eventually go further to reassure him, through more radical changes in the shape of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization or indirect limits on the size of the German army or a greater role for the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, if not all three, in exchange for his acquiescence to German membership in NATO.
Although the Soviet Union is in trouble and the United States and Western Europe are not - although ''we won and they lost,'' in the political shorthand of American conservatives -there seems no disposition in Washington to ''impose a solution on us,'' as a senior Russian negotiator put it.
Mr. Bush, in the words of a Western European Ambassador here, ''has kept Gorbachev engaged in the search'' for a new European architecture.

LENGTH: 1983 words

HEADLINE: Summit in Washington;
Excerpts From Gorbachev's Remarks at Breakfast With U.S. Lawmakers

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 1

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from remarks by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev at a breakfast with Congressional leaders at the Soviet Embassy this morning, as provided by the Federal News Service, a transcription agency. Mr. Gorbachev spoke through an interpreter.
 
GORBACHEV STATEMENT
I think that this meeting has a kind of set of issues and agreements that makes this summit a very important one. Of course, the central issue is that of 50 percent reductions in nuclear strategic arms. We have done a lot of difficult work - I am frank with you, very difficult work - and we feel that the U.S. side has done a lot of difficult work, too. . . . And I think that as a result, we can say now that the document, and that is the statement on the main provisions of the future treaty, can be signed. And the remaining issues will be worked on by our negotiators. ...
Yesterday we discussed the German question . . . the external matters related to the unification of Germany. And I felt that this rather rigid position of the Administration that the united Germany should absolutely belong to NATO, that position, to a large extent, is because the United States would like to assure its military presence on the European continent and its role on the European continent - strategic role and the role for stability. Those are the two elements of the same strategic situation, of course. 
And I said to the President . . . ''There is not a problem for us. We're not arguing that the United States should not be in Europe, regardless of how we resolve this issue of the membership of the united Germany and the question of European structures. We can say that regardless of those structures, it is necessary at this stage - it is necessary at the stage of rapid change in Europe, very dramatic change in Europe, we would like to have stability.
We want stability. We don't want any turmoil in this central focus of world politics. If we fail to develop this process in Europe and if we have concern on both sides, then it will be very difficult to move forward generally in our relationship.
And that is why I said very directly to the President, and I would like to say that to you, that if we in the Soviet Union feel that we are being squeezed out, that we are - that pressure is being applied on us for a unilateral advantage of the other side, well, it's - that is something that does more than just cause concern. ...
 
The Military Balance
It is a question of imbalance - of a possible imbalance, of a possible disparity. And then, if there is such a disparity, such an imbalance, our side or your side will have to think - to think about what to do next, whether we should continue on the course that we are proceeding now or we should stop and think about what to do about arms reduction, what to do about Vienna, to reconsider our entire position, to reassess our position. ...
Sometimes we hear voices here in America saying, Well, let's see, what is happening in the Soviet Union? Maybe the Soviet Union is so weak that we can defeat him just with one step. That's not serious. Now, Western press and the American press is saying, Gorbachev, compared to any other Soviet leader, has come to Washington very weak and he will not get anything. But I am not going to ask for anything, to beg for anything, even when I for example raise important matters such as trade, and it's important for us now to expand trade because we are moving toward a market economy and it's important for us to have the Americans participating in that process. But certainly we are not asking for a free ride. We will be asking for normal credits and of course we will be paying and paying the interest. For us it would be humiliating if we were to ask for - if we were to beg for something from you, and of course hopeless. ...
 
QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
 
The Soviet Economy
SENATOR GEORGE J. MITCHELL. . . . I wonder if you could tell us what further steps you anticipate taking with respect to the economy and when? . . .
GORBACHEV. . . . We will be replacing the old, command planned system with a new regulated market system. . . . When we began perestroika, we thought that we would be able just to add a certain dynamic to our society, to improve the state of research and development in the Soviet Union, to improve productivity in the Soviet Union, and through that we will be able to get a better Soviet Union.
But we found out that the old economic system rejected any kind of progress, rejected any kind of scientific and technological progress. It really was not receptive to that . . . There was no incentive, there was not motivation for people to work.
People worked really just taking commands from their bosses, no initiative . . . no thinking on the part of every worker was really necessary. He was estranged from this process of economic development and we have seen as a result of analyzing the situation, that we have to change our economic system, to change the format of our economy.
First, we began by introducing some new forms of the economy like leasehold, cooperatives, some others. We tried various approaches but they did not work. . . . Trying to inject those new elements and the new forms of economic life, we continued to retain the entire old superstructure of economic management and we understood that really we were being very naive, because that system, that system which evolved over decades, was really a kind of vice, was really a kind of cramp on our entire economy. And it made impossible any initiative, any decision making at various levels, and therefore we had to try and dismantle that command system. And to dismantle that command system we needed the political reform in order to really dismantle the command and bureaucratic system. . . . In combination with democracy, glasnost, the dismantlement of old management, we were able to open up for the people possiblities of participating, of becoming involved. Now that this is happening . . . we see that really we are lagging behind in the economy. . . .
We have dismantled the old system but we have not yet put in place a working system, a new system, and our ship has lost anchor and therefore we're all a little sick. And looking at this process, we see that if that process of transition from that old dismantled system to the new system, if that process takes too much time, it can create the kind of instability and the kind of implications that will just disorganize our entire society.
So, we decided that we have to radicalize our reform. We have to radicalize that transition to new forms of economic management. So this is how our proposals evolved. . . . We saw that we need a new kind of system of ownership, a new system of property. . . . And we have now adopted a law on property, and we're going to have a system of various forms of property, which will have state property, collective property, comparative property, lease property, and private property. . . . We are discussing now the law on taxes. Anti-monopoly legislation will be discussed because we have the kind of monopoly that exists only in our country. . . .
We need competitiveness in our economy, and that is why we will be adopting laws on entrepreneurship, on small and medium-size business. We do not have a system of markets. We do not have systems of stock exchanges, monetary or labor exchanges. . . . Of course, in order to cover all this gamut, matters such as credit, finance, banks, property, taxes and so on, in order to do that, we also need to address the question of prices, because it is only in our country that we have such a skewed system of prices. . . . They do not reflect real costs. They do not take into account demand. They reflect just the dictates of the producer - the producers who do not want to increase their productivity, they just do not want to increase quality, they are monopolists. ...
 
Changing Directions
We have to begin. We have to begin this change of direction which is very dramatic, and some people are scared. People are scared about price increases. . . . We will introduce social protection measures with regard to pensioners, families with many children, students, all those with fixed incomes. And of course it applies to workers. ...
Certain limits will be introduced. Next year we're going to retain only control over foodstuffs and in industry a little more than that. . . . We are doing that deliberately, not in order to slow down things, but because our people and society at large are not simply prepared in conditions of market economy how to behave themselves. They don't even know that. And also we do this to prevent an explosion of inflation. But the degree or extent of freedom in terms of prices will increase as the mechanism of the market system grows. ...
 
State of the Baltics
SENATOR BOB DOLE. . . . When it comes to trade, there will be certain . . . questions raised in Congress about the Baltic states, about Lithuania, Latvia, Estonia independence if it comes to, say, most favored nation or whatever it might be. . . . So if you can shed any light on that. . . .
GORBACHEV. Well, of course, I have spoken so much on the subject that I must now try to crystalize the most important things. ...
They held an election in Lithuania. Some part of constituencies, about one-third, did not complete the electoral process. In two weeks, they were supposed to hold another round of elections, but, at that time, our Congress was to open, an extraordinary Congress, in order to establish the institute of presidency.
So, the Lithuanians decided to repeal the old decision, moved up the election two days before the Congress, before our Congress, in order to create that artificial situation and confront the entire Congress with that fait accompli. So, they elected their parliament, proclaimed - and they assembled at night to vote for secession from the union.
Well, let me say, this caused very acute reaction in our society. This is kind of a night coup d'etat, a coup, if you wish. Who can be given the right to participate in elections? It takes months and months to discuss a question like that. But here, they met at night, raised their hands, and said, We are now out of the Soviet Union. This is absurd. ..
Recently Ryzhkov and I, myself, met with Prunskiene, and we said, Let us find our way out of the situation by saving our face. . . . I am saying, well, let us decide that this is not rescinded. That it continues to exist, but you just suspend it, and then we will be able to talk, because we will be able to say that there is a return to the old situation, but you will be able to say that you have not rescinded the declaration. . . . Well, we will be trying to use every opportunity in order to find a solution without extreme measures within the framework of the constitutional process. We want to find a solution within the framework of the constitutional process because this is the key to resolving similar issues with other republics. ...
 
Middle East Peace
REPRESENTATIVE ROBERT MICHEL. . . . The Middle East is also a destabilizing thing. Could you help us in any way to solve that particular problem? Is it within your province to assist us in any way?
GORBACHEV. . . . We are ready to cooperate with you, we are ready to use our influence . . . . We are already doing it. ...
We are really in a difficult situation now as a result of certain actions of the Israeli Government. We have democratized our emigration procedures, people are leaving and they settle then on the occupied territories and provoke clashes. They are provoking a problem between us and the Arabs. The Arab Presidents are remonstrating with us. This is something that I think the Israelis are doing on purpose in order to make a solution very difficult.
Now, thank you for this meeting. I'm very pleased.

HEADLINE: Summit in Washington;
Wide Differences Over Germany Are Still Said to Divide the Superpowers

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 1

 BODY:
Despite some vague remarks on Thursday from both President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev about narrowing their differences on Germany, American and Soviet officials said today that the gaps between them on this critical issue still appeared to be wide.
Indeed, Mr. Gorbachev used a meeting today with Congressional leaders at the Soviet Embassy to complain about the Administration's ''rather rigid position'' that ''a united Germany belong to NATO.''
Mr. Bush telephoned the West German Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, first thing today to assure him that he did not diverge from his position that a unified Germany must remain a member of the NATO alliance.
The discussion that took place on Thursday afternoon between the two Presidents on the German question appears to have been a combination of diplomacy and public posturing. On the diplomatic side, an Administration official said, the two men laid out their longstanding positions on the German question, with a new nuance here or there, but no surprises. 
 
Insistence on NATO Role
That American position in short, the official said, is that Germany is going to be united, it is going to be in NATO, and the United States stands ready to make that fact as politically, economically and militarily acceptable to Moscow as possible.
Mr. Gorbachev countered with what one American official described as ''an extremely peculiar'' performance on Germany. In an ''animated, confident and thrusting'' speaking style, the official said, Mr. Gorbachev gave ''an extraordinarily vague presentation - it was elaborate, convuluted and imprecise.''
Through the haze, officials said, he made clear that the Soviet people simply could not accept the idea that their enemy of World War II - a united Germany - and their enemy of the cold war - NATO - should now be joined in one alliance. Germany should be in both alliances, he said, which should eventually give way to some new pan-European security framework.
At the close, however, Mr. Gorbachev asked aloud whether it ''shouldn't be the German people who decide whether or not they are in NATO.'' Mr. Bush, confident that the German people want to remain in the alliance, tried to press the Soviet leader on how they might establish this point, but he could not pin him down, officials said.
 
Gorbachev Seemed Upbeat
Public relations came into play when Mr. Gorbachev left the White House saying ''something emerged'' in their discussions on Germany, and appearing generally quite upbeat. He also said Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, would be holding ''in depth'' talks to work on details, giving rise to speculation that a breakthrough on Germany was imminent.
Mr. Gorbachev's upbeat approach seemed consistent with Soviet efforts to avoid being depicted as the ''spoiler'' standing in the way of a smooth, speedy German unification and to emphasize that Moscow is the one spinning out new ideas for an idyllic Europe free of all military alliances.
Mr. Bush, apparently not wanting to contradict Mr. Gorbachev at the very outset of the summit talks and intrigued by the Soviet leader's closing remark on letting the Germans decide, said he too was ''encouraged'' by their discussion.
 
Nothing Fundamentally New
As the day wore on, though, Administration officials, speaking not for attribution, began letting it be known that Mr. Baker and Mr. Shevardnadze were not planning any more talks on the German question and that nothing fundamentally new had really come up in the Bush-Gorbachev talks on this issue.
Today, the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, tried to get the two Presidents down from the tree they had climbed together by saying: ''I think the confusion just arose over the interpretation of what the word 'new' means, if you can believe that. We had some new - meaning different, is the way I would describe it - different formulations of our positions, but nothing was agreed to.''
Many Administration officials say they believe that if there is going to be any real movement by the Soviets on the German question, it might be foreshadowed in the private meetings between Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev at Camp David on Saturday. But more likely, officials say, is that Mr. Gorbachev will not make any new move on Germany - an explosive domestic political issue for him - until after the Communist Party congress in early July.
 
On Repackaging NATO
President Bush's position, as laid out on Thursday, is that to make a unified Germany in NATO palatable to the Soviets, the United States, West Germany and the NATO allies have agreed to package it in this way:
* After German unification, no NATO troops will be extended to the territory of what is now East Germany, so there will be no increased threat to Soviet forces.
* The 300,000 to 400,000 Soviet troops now in East Germany will be able to remain there for a transitional period of a few years.
* The West German Government will pay the estimated $180 million cost of maintaining the Soviet troops in East Germany for the transition period, and will also pay for the construction of new housing for them back in the Soviet Union.
* NATO will begin revamping its force structure - downgrading readiness of certain units, scaling back its military training programs, developing multi-national fighting units, scraping plans to modernize its short-range nuclear missiles - to respond to the diminished threat from the East and to make NATO less threatening to Moscow.
* As soon as the Soviets agree to conclude the current conventional forces treaty now being negotiated in Vienna - the treaty would sharply reduce Soviet and American troops, armor and artillery forces in Europe - the Germans, in conjunction with NATO, will be prepared to begin immediately discussing limitations on the size of a united Germany's armed forces.
* The United States has offered to begin looking for ways to institutionalize the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe to transform it into some sort of ''club'' that every nation in Europe could belong to, an official said. The Conference could be given a permanent secretariat, hold more frequent meetings and be given responsibilities for everything from crisis management to election monitoring. With the Soviet-led Warsaw pact disintegrating and NATO remaining intact, the idea is to use the Conference as a framework that could give the Soviets a sense of both belonging to and playing a leading role in a pan-European organization - but one that would be a compliment to NATO, not a substitute.

HEADLINE: Summit in Washington;
Trade Accord Holds Many Prizes, But Obstacles to Passage Remain

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 1

 BODY:
The decision by President Bush to sign a trade agreement with the Soviet Union today paved the way for a process that would normalize commercial and economic relations between the two countries for the first time in a half-century.
Just five days ago, the President had said the agreement was ''not on the table'' because Moscow had yet to approve a free-emigration law.
Today's signing suggests that the President has received assurances from Mr. Gorbachev on the emigration issue and on Soviet efforts to resolve the crisis in Lithuania.
But the Soviet Union has been applying leverage as well. Soviet officials said they would not sign a new long-term grain agreement committing the Soviet Union to higher levels of purchases from the United States over the next five years unless the United States signed the trade agreement. Both accords were signed this afternoon. 
 
Lower Tariffs, More Options
The trade pact would clear the way for much lower tariffs on Soviet products, according them ''most favored nation'' treatment, while expanding American business opportunities in the Soviet Union.
While the agreement has now been signed, technical as well as political obstacles could delay its being sent up to Congress for a few weeks.
The President still has to waive restrictions imposed by the Jackson-Vanik amendment to the Trade Act of 1974. The Jackson-Vanik restrictions bar most-favored-nation trade status from countries that place emigration curbs. Congressional experts said the agreement cannot go up until the President issues his waiver, a report declaring that the free-emigration conditions have been met.
Both Governments came to terms on a trade agreement during the 1972-74 period of detente. But that agreement was never implemented because of the Jackson-Vanik restrictions.
''Given the President's long-standing condition that we will not be granting 'M.F.N.' until the Soviets pass their emigration legislation, this agreement will not be sent to the Congress until after such legislation has been enacted,'' Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d told reporters today.
 
Lawmakers Assess Chances
Lawmakers and their aides said the chances of approval appeared good, provided the Soviet Union lifts its economic blockade of Lithuania and continues policies of freer emigration.
Because it could spur not only commerce but the flow of capital and technology, the decision was eagerly sought by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to back his market-oriented economic reforms and help him get more food and other consumer goods on store shelves.
Yet it has been almost as avidly desired by American business leaders, who see huge markets in the Soviet Union but shy away from making deals without the seal of approval from Washington that a trade agreement represents.
''It is the psychological indicator of re-engagement in one of the most important markets of the world,'' said Michael J. Johnson, a vice president at the FMC Corporation, a Chicago manufacturing company.
 
Desire for Soviet Markets
Business people also saw the situation in terms of American competitiveness. ''Without some clear indication that the pending U.S.-Soviet trade agreement will be implemented, American business proposals will get short shrift in the Soviet Union compared with those from Europe and Japan,'' the president of the National Association of Manufacturers, Jerry J. Jasinowski, wrote the President last Wednesday, Should it come into force, the trade agreement would qualify the Soviet Union for the lowest tariffs granted to any other country. The Soviet Union is among only 12 countries that do not get the favored trade status.
 
Cheaper Vodka Is Nearer
Soviet products sold in the United States currently bear duties as much as 10 times higher than imports from other countries. By one estimate the price of Soviet vodka could drop by $1.25 a bottle.
There might not be large short-term increases in trade because the Soviet Union now makes little that Americans want to buy, and has trouble paying for goods it needs from the United States.
However, over the next three to five years, American officials think, the current $5 billion in annual trade between the two countries could double or even triple.
Largely because of Soviet grain-buying, the United States had a $3.5 billion surplus last year.

HEADLINE: Evolution in Europe;
Stunned North Korea Warns Soviets on Meeting With Seoul Leader

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 1

 BODY:
Despite President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's plans to meet in the United States with the South Korean President next week, experts on North Korea say they do not expect the diplomatic opening to dislodge Pyongyang soon from its hard line against any contact with the South.
The North Korean Government expressed incredulity and directed vague warnings at the Soviet Union today in response to Mr. Gorbachev's plans to meet President Roh Tae Woo, which were disclosed by United States officials on Wednesday and confirmed by South Korea the next day. The meeting is expected to take place in San Francisco on Sunday or Monday, after the Soviet leader ends his talks with President Bush in Washington.
Clearly stunned by this recognition of South Korea by one of North Korea's few remaining allies, the official Korean Central News Agency quoted an unnamed Foreign Ministry spokesman as having said: ''If President Gorbachev has a meeting with Roh Tae Woo, which we do not think will take place, it will be a serious political issue.'' 
The spokesman added that such a meeting would ''freeze the division of our country.''
Despite the threatening tone of the report, diplomats and experts on North Korea said there did not appear to be much Pyongyang could do, although the move sharply increases the pressure on North Korea to consider altering its policies. North Korea is believed to receive about 70 percent to 80 percent of its military supplies from the Soviet Union, and they are essential to supporting on a war footing a standing army of more than one million.
The North Koreans have made some modest gestures recently toward better relations with the United States, engaging in some inconclusive discussions in Beijing. On Monday, the North Koreans turned over the remains of five of the several thousand American soldiers still missing from the 1950-53 Korean War.
 
Inflexible Stand on Seoul
But all this has not seemed to ease the North Koreans' inflexible stand against their foes in the South, as hoped by some in Seoul.
''We think this should ease tensions and induce the North Koreans to talk,'' said Chung Jae Moon, a member of South Korea's National Assembly and the ruling party, who has been instrumental in establishing the links with the Soviet Union. ''Otherwise, they will just be more isolated.''
Diplomats who monitor the tightly controlled North Korean press and broadcasting said that the Government had not informed its people of the coming meeting.
''The Soviet Union is emphatically admitting there are two Koreas,'' said a Japanese Foreign Ministry official. ''This proves the whole basis of North Korea's foreign policy is groundless.''
The North Koreans insist that there is only one legitimate Korean Government, their own, and they refuse to refer to Mr. Roh as President.
The Japanese diplomat added, ''I can't say we expect a hardening of their position but we just don't expect this will change their policy, either.''
The North Korean press agency report, monitored here, said North Korea had not been officially informed of a meeting between President Gorbachev and President Roh.
''We consider that the President of the Soviet Union, an ally of ours, is quite able to analyze and judge what a serious political consequence will be entailed by his meeting with Roh Tae Woo, who is seeking only the division of Korea,'' the North Korean official said, South Koreans Took Initiative While hosting the Olympic Games of 1988, South Korea undertook an effective campaign to break the ice with Communist Eastern Europe, offering increased trade and cheap consumer goods as an inducement.
Starting with Hungary in the fall of 1988, Seoul established diplomatic relations with all the East European countries except East Germany and the Soviet Union.
South Korea and the Soviet Union opened consular offices in each other's capitals. The meeting next week is expected to lead toward full embassies.
 
Moscow to Supply Uranium
After a visit by a group of leading Seoul politicians in March, Moscow agreed to a long-term contract to supply uranium for South Korean nuclear energy plants.
The Soviet Union has also agreed to sell advanced technology to Korean companies. On Thursday, the Samsung Group, a leading Korean conglomerate, said it had signed a deal to provide telecommunications equipment to the Soviet Union.
One sign of North Korea's difficulties in responding to the success of South Korea's diplomatic and economic offensive came last year. Kim Pyong Il, the son of North Korea's leader, Kim Il Sung, arrived in Hungary as ambassador shortly before Hungary recognized South Korea.
Western diplomats said Mr. Kim was quickly transferred to Bulgaria, which then followed Hungary's example and moved to open relations with Seoul. Mr. Kim is believed to be still in Bulgaria.

HEADLINE: Critics Say Draft Report on Climate Shift Ignores Urgency of Problem

BYLINE: PHILIP SHABECOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 1

 BODY:
A draft report by an American-led policy group of the United Nations has proposed international measures to cope with global warming caused by pollution, but it calls for no specific goals or timetables for action.
Environmentalists and some European diplomats who have seen a summary of the report, which was prepared by American officials, complained that its recommendations did not reflect the urgency evident in a report on scientific knowledge about global warming.
That report, prepared by a British-led panel and released last week by another United Nations panel, , found that unless the emissions of carbon dioxide and other gases that are trapping heat from the sun are immediately cut by more than 60 percent, global temperatures would rise sharply in the next century with unforeseeable consequences for humans. 
The draft policy report by the American-led panel calls for a general international treaty to address global warming, but none of the signers would be obligated to take specific action. Other recommendations are to use energy more efficiently, to strengthen existing institutions that could address the climate change issue, and to accumulate more information on scientific, technical and economic implications of the problem. #3 Panels Examine Problem Three United Nations-sponsored working groups are gathering information to help nations decide what to do about global warming. The British-led panel completed its report last week. A Soviet-led group studying potential effects of global warming is still working on its report. The American-led group was assigned to examine strategies for dealing with the problem.
The information provided by the three groups is intended to form the basis of further international action to deal with the problem. An international conference will be held in Geneva this November to plan the next steps.
The policy group's recommendations generally parallel the Bush Administration's approach to the problem. The Administration wants to delay specific international action, like mandatory reduction of carbon dioxide and other pollutants, and to focus on more study of the scientific and economic implications of the shift in climate.
European governments are expected to press for a stronger report when the members of the American-led working group meet in Geneva next week to prepare its final report, said an official in the Netherlands Embassy here.
The official said Western European governments were concerned that the policy summary prepared by the United States put more emphasis on uncertainties than was warranted by the findings of subcommittees that did the research for the report. But he said that his government could not comment officially on the report because it was still in draft form. #2 Panels at Odds Daniel Lashof, a global warming expert for the Natural Resources Defense Council, an environmental group, said ''there is a real disconnect'' between the recommendations of the science panel and the draft report by the working group on policy responses. He said the science panel ''made a strong statement about the science and the need for at least a 60 percent reduction in carbon dioxide, while the policy group did not even analyze the policy measures needed to reach that reduction.''
Frederick M. Bernthal, deputy director of the National Science Foundation and chairman of the policy working group, did not respond to several telephone calls over the last two days.
The draft report on policy options was prepared by the Response Strategies Working Group, one of three working groups that make up the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, which was created in 1988 by the United Nations Environmental Program and the World Meteorological Organization, another United Nations organization.
The response strategies working group identified a number of measures that it said would be ''particularly important and feasible in the short term.''
It suggested the development of a ''framework convention,'' or general treaty on climate change, without specifying any particular obligations or deadlines for reducing the pollution that is accumulating in the atmosphere and trapping radiation from the sun in a phenomenon known as the greenhouse effect.
It proposed carrying out measures that ''are already economically and socially justifiable in their own right and which also provide benefits from a climate change standpoint.'' Such measures would include increased energy efficiency and improved use of forests and other natural resources.
It urged increased research into scientific, technical and economic uncertainties about the magnitude, time and regional effects of global warming; potential policies to lessen its impact, and measures to adjust to a warmer earth when and if that happens. it Unlike the Bush Administration, several Western European countries have concluded that enough is known about the potential dangers to warrant substantial countermeasures, including stabilizing and reducing emissions of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Jobless Rate Dips but Economy Is Weak

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 1

 BODY:
In a report signaling further withering of economic growth, the Labor Department said today that business payrolls in May failed to expand for the third consecutive month and that the number of factory jobs dropped by 35,000.
Most analysts had expected moderate growth in jobs. The decline touched off a major rally in the money and bond markets, pushing interest rates down sharply in the expectation that the Federal Reserve Board would have to relax its grip on the money supply to keep the seven-and-a-half-year business expansion intact. Because of these interest rate developments, stocks also posted gains, though less spectacular, reaching new record levels. 
''This shows that the economy has more weak sectors than strengths,'' said Stuart G. Hoffman, chief economist for the Pittsburgh National Bank. He said it was now clear that the economy's rapid pace earlier in the year was an aberration, caused mainly by unusually warm winter weather. ''The forward momentum is now pretty minimal,'' he added.
 
Jobless Rate Down Slightly
Yet today's report, generally regarded as the single best indicator of economic performance, was not uniformly grim. The civilian unemployment rate as measured by the department's survey of households fell by one-tenth of a point in May, to 5.3 percent, helped by the Census Bureau's hiring of temporary workers. A shift of less than two-tenths of a point is not considered to be statistically significant, but the figures did reflect some job gains.
In addition, there was a decline in the ranks of the newly unemployed -those idled for less than five weeks -and, in contrast with April, more industries added workers than shed them.
Jay N. Woolworth of the Bankers Trust Company said that while the overall figures were ''a whole heck of a lot softer'' than expected, ''there are some pieces of strength'' in the nation's economy.
One of the more surprising elements in the report was an increase of four-tenths of an hour in the length of the average factory work week, to 41.1 hours, and an increase of five-tenths of an hour, to 4 hours, in factory overtime work.
 
More Hours for Auto Workers
Such advances sometimes suggest rising economic activity, but this time they mainly reflected activity at 15 automobile plants producing fast-selling models, Labor Department officials said. With overall sales generally lackluster, the auto makers decided to preserve flexibility by adding hours rather than hiring new workers.
W. Van Bussman, an economist for the Chrysler Corporation, said another reason for this was the coming labor negotiations in which job security is expected to be high on the agenda, making companies ''a little wary about adding to the work force.''
In the aggregate, however, the May figures showed an economy probably growing only half as fast, after adjusting for possible inventory buildup, than the rate experienced in the first three months of the year.
''Labor market developments over recent months are now fairly clear,'' Dr. Janet L. Norwood, the Commissioner of Labor Statistics, told the Joint Economic Committee of Congress this morning. ''Employment growth has been very slow, and what growth there has been was concentrated in a very few industries,'' she said, adding that the only real job strength came from the 325,000 people who were hired temporarily as census workers in the last few months.
''The private sector has been stagnant for the past three months, with job losses in construction and manufacturing,'' Dr. Norwood said.
 
Easing of Policy Debated
Despite this evidence of economic weakening, the Federal Reserve is likely to ''sit tight'' for awhile, analysts at Salomon Brothers suggested today, at least until the next readings on consumer and producer inflation, which are to be published in about two weeks. Then, easing of its policy on money supply ''depends more on extending April's favorable price news through May and June,'' the economists said.
Today's report also showed that both hourly and weekly earnings of private production workers rose four-tenths of 1 percent in May, up from an increase of three-tenths of 1 percent in April.
The department's survey of business payrolls for May showed a total increase of 164,000 jobs, but when 145,000 new census workers are subtracted the gain was considered negligible. The latest decline in factory jobs means that 310,000 of these have now been lost since the recovery peak in March 1989.
In addition, business payrolls are now shown as falling 126,000 in April, twice as much as when initially reported a month ago.
 
More Jobs in Health Services
For May, manufacturing jobs fell for the seventh month in the last nine, with construction falling by 20,000 jobs after seasonal adjustment. In services, employment in retail trade has now been weak for four consecutive months, particularly in general merchandise stores, where 55,000 jobs have been lost. Health services, the only sector of the economy that showed a big gain, added 45,000 more jobs; this sector now accounts for one-third of the total increase in private payroll jobs over the last year.
Partly reflecting the exceptionaly long factory hours last month, the index of hours worked remained unchanged at 130, although the figure for May was revised down to that level from 130.2.
The household survey, on which the unemployment rate is based, showed civilian employment up by 234,000, slightly more than April's decline. Half the new jobs went to those who had been jobless, reducing their ranks by 117,000, and the other half went to those who joined the labor force.
Except for an increase of eight-tenths of a point in the teen-age jobless rate, to 15.5 percent, there was little change among the various population groups.
And despite considerable shifting among geographic regions over the last year, with the jobless rate for New England up nearly two points and that for the South showing a moderate decline, few states showed statistically meaningful changes in May. The exceptions among the 11 largest states were Illinois, showing a decline of eight-tenths of a point, to 5.3 percent, and Pennsylvania, also showiing a decline of eight-tenths of a point, to 4.9 percent.
New York's jobless rate was put at 5.1 percent, up from 4.9, while New Jersey's edged down one-tenth of a point, to 4.8.
The overall national jobless rate, which includes the 1,639,000 members of the armed services stationed in the United States, was 5.3 percent, the same as the civilian rate. Enserchd(Pittsburgh National Bank)

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN WASHINGTON;
The Other Agreements, in Brief

 BODY:

SIGNED BY BUSH AND GORBACHEV
 
AGREEMENTS
 
Peaceful Uses of Atomic Energy
Opens the way for increased cooperation by Soviet and American scientists studying subatomic particles and the safety of civilian nuclear reactors. Researchers will work to study health and environmental effects of the 1986 accident at the Chernobyl nuclear power plant.
 
University Exchanges
Establishes a general agreement expanding undergraduate university exchanges by 1,000 full time students in each direction. A mix of private and Government funds is to be used to cover the cost of Soviet participants in the United States, while the Soviet Government will cover all in-country costs for Americans. 
 
Trade
Would normalize trade and economic relations between the United States and the Soviet Union. Clears the way for much lower tarifs on Soviet products in this country and eligibility for the Soviet Union for American Government credit and guarantee programs. American companies would get better copyright protection for computer software in the Soviet Union and an accelerated process for obtaining commercial representation in Moscow. Although Mr. Bush signed the treaty, the White House is saying he will not send it to Congress or apply the most-favored-nation provision until he is satisfied that the Soviet Union has ended restrictions on emigration and resolved the crisis in Lithuania.
 
JOINT STATEMENTS
 
Conventional Forces
Agrees to speed negotiations in Vienna so the U.S. and the Soviet Union can sign an agreement this year reducing non-nuclear military forces in Europe. The 35-nation conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe should not hold a summit meeting until the treaty on conventional forces is ''ready for signature,'' they said.
 
International Park
Announces the intention to create a large park, the Beringian Heritage International Park, along the Bering Strait. Would include land and water in Alaska and Siberia. The Soviets and Americans would cooperate in studying the ecology, archeology and cultural heritage of both sides of the strait, once the site of a land bridge linking North America and Asia.
 
AGREEMENTS CONCLUDED BY OTHERS

 
These were concluded by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d or other Administration officials and by Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze.
 
Maritime Transportation Opens 42 cities in each country to shipping. Permits Soviet vessels to engage in trade between the United States and third countries. Sets annual targets for market share.
 
Ocean Studies Renews previous arrangements. Provitdes for the shared use of research vesels and ports, open publication of joint studies in marine science and oceanography, and scientific exchanges.
 
Expanded Civil Aviation Opens six new Soviet cities and four new American cities to Soviet-American air traffic; Chicago, Miami, San Francisco, Anchorage, Kiev, Tbilisi, Minsk, Riga, Magadan and Khabarovsk. (New York, Washington, Moscow and Leningrad are now served.) Total passenger and cargo flights would increase to 58 per side by April 1, 1992. U.S. airlines are guaranteed that about 9 percent of their seats will be filled by Soviet passengers.
 
Maritime Boundary Resolves differences about jurisdiction over fishing and oil and gas resources. The agreed-to maritime boundary is the ''western limit'' in the 1967 convention ceding Alaska to the United States. The United States transfers to Soviet jurisdiction one ''special area'' inside the American 200-mile limit. The U.S.S.R. transfers to American jurisdiction the three ''special areas'' comprising five Arctic islands, inside the Soviet 200-mile limit.
 
Cultural Centers Would establish reciprocal institutions in Washington and Moscow. The nonprofit centers would be open to the public, and operate libraries and sponsor seminars and other events.
 
Customs Cooperation Provides for cooperation between the United States and Soviet customs services in deterring and detecting narcotics trafficking, in export control and in commercial fraud.
 
Government Publications Memorandum of understanding to increase circulationn of ''America'' and''Soviet Life'' magazines. Would raise the circulation ceilings of the publications to 250,000 in 1991; after that, distribution to be determined by demand.
 
Grains Long-term guarantee for an export market in the Soviet Union for an additional 1 million tons of American wheat, feed grains and soybean a year. Current agreement expires this month.

HEADLINE: Token Thief Shows Millions Are Up Sleeve

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
At the 110th Street IRT subway station, where all the turnstiles were recently broken, an unidentified man held open the fare gate and instructed passengers to place their tokens in a large black fare box.
''Come right this way through the gate; the turnstiles are broken. Put your tokens in the box,'' he said in an official tone, directing the confused subway riders with his hand. And the passengers complied. 
A few minutes later, the 33-year-old man, dressed in jeans and a T-shirt, pulled a homemade metal sleeve from the top of the fare box, emptied it of the tokens, and reinserted it. The man, an unemployed printer who asked to remain anonymous, said that he made about $300 a day that way.
The man demonstrated his new craft in videotaped testimony presented to the New York City Council's Transportation Committee yesterday. The videotape, which was made by city investigators, shows the relative ease with which hundreds of people are jamming turnstiles throughout the subway system and stealing millions of dollars worth of tokens from fare boxes.
The Transit Authority estimates that it loses about $60 million in revenues each year to fare evasion, which includes tokens lost to people who vandalize turnstiles and fare boxes. The agency receives about 2,400 ''trouble turnstile'' calls each week. There are 2,730 turnstiles in the subway system.
''People are so frustrated and confused by the lack of working turnstiles that they respond to anyone who appears to be in control, mainly individuals like the one in the video,'' said Jonathan Drapkin, chief of the City Council's Office of Legislative Oversight and Investigation, which is conducting an investigation into the growing problem of turnstile vandalism.
City investigators made the videotape on Thursday when they discovered the unemployed printer putting tape over the token slots of the turnstiles. The man agreed to demonstrate the scheme provided that his name and face not appear in the video. He also agreed to return all tokens acquired during the videotaping to the token booth clerk. The man was not arrested.
Mr. Drapkin said that while many token thieves jammed turnstiles with paper or metal and sucked the tokens out with their mouths, a growing number of the thieves were using fare-box sleeves, which were more lucrative.
A typical fare-box sleeve is usually made from a beer can and is about the size of a pocket comb. It can be slid through a token slot until it is almost entirely inside the turnstile or fare box. Thin, barely visible metal edges atop the sleeve prevent it from falling all the way inside and enable the thief to pull it out. The sleeves allow thieves to take six to 10 tokens in one swoop.
''I don't like jamming and sucking; it takes extra time. I just put paper and tape over the turnstile slots because people are so used to the turnstiles being jammed that they automatically use the black fare box,'' the man in the videotape said.
Appearing before the Transportation Committee for the first time yesterday, Alan F. Kiepper, who took over as president of the Transit Authority in February, said that the agency was experimenting with a number of programs aimed at ending fare evasion. Mr. Kiepper said that the agency had just completed a successful program that placed unarmed security agents at heavily used stations. He said they had discouraged turnstile vandalism and people who jumped over turnstiles or walked through the fare gates without paying.
 
Thief Discovers Thievery
Transit officials say, however, that the authority cannot assign an officer to monitor each fare box and unlocked gate because they have too few officers and a rising number of other, more serious crimes.
Not all passengers who go through the fare gates pay their fares. In the video, the unemployed printer retrieved the beer-can sleeve from the fare box and found that one passenger had deposited a nickel in the box and another passenger, a penny. ''Some people don't pay,'' the man said. ''Sometimes you find no tokens, just pennies and nickels.''
Mr. Kiepper said the agency had established an internal task force to develop ways to curb fare abuse. The task force, Mr. Kiepper said, is considering changes to fare-control areas, including better lighting and higher railings.
In a trial program to start next week, the Transit Authority will appoint managers to a group of stations to supervise cleaners, maintenance workers, police and operations personnel, Mr. Kiepper said.
Mr. Drapkin of the council's investigation office said the Transit Authority could thwart many fare box thieves by reducing the size of the token slot in the fare box, leaving no extra space to insert the sleeve.
