HEADLINE: Race for Courter's Seat Revives Issues of 1989

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MORRISTOWN, N.J., June 1

 BODY:
After losing the race for governor last year to Representative Jim Florio, the 12th District's own Representative, Jim Courter, decided not to seek re-election to Congress. But the spirited Republican campaign to succeed him has been dominated by the very same issues that were at the center of the statewide campaign.
The sprawling district in the northwestern part of the state meanders through seven counties and includes 79 municipalities.
Its 571,600 residents range from blue collar to silk stocking, and interviews with several Morris and Hunterdon County residents before the primary on Tuesday show they are concerned about economic issues, chiefly the prospect of increased state and Federal taxes, as well as overdevelopment, pollution, automobile-insurance costs and crime. 
The litany of concerns was occasionally recounted with some anger. Donald H. Ort of Neshanic, who retired in December from the marketing division of A.T. & T., said, ''We should have another Boston Tea Party and toss all the politicians into Newark Bay.''
He said taxes were the top issue. ''They're killing us in this state,'' he said. ''When Kean was in, we were told we had a surplus. And now we're told there's a deficit and we have to jack up all the taxes.''
 
'Rampant Uncontrolled Growth'
Mr. Ort, who likes to hunt, also opposes Mr. Florio's successful drive to enact a law banning the sale or possession of assault rifles. ''If the courts and law-enforcement system put the criminals away, we would't be passing laws to disarm law-abiding citizens in the name of keeping guns away from criminals.''
Bruce Brodack, owner of Light Fare, a lighting and decorating store on Main Street in Flemington, said: ''Overdevelopment, rampant uncontrolled growth is one of our most serious problems. It's crazy. It's nuts.''
He said the proliferation of office parks and light industry in the once bucolic western counties had inspired unplanned housing and increased traffic to the point where streets in small towns like Flemington are jammed several hours a day.
''It's also displacing animals,'' he said. ''The number of road kills is up tremendously.''
 
Taxes and Traffic
Richard Huyler, a retired school maintenance worker who was sunning on a bench on South Street in Morristown, said he was worried about trying to live on his pension and Social Security.
''I always looked forward to my retirement and made plans,'' he said. ''But you just can't make it these days without trying to find some work.
''It seems the economy went into a turnover when Bush got in there. They all say they're interested in lowering taxes, but they never do it.''
Valerie Cunningham, a licensed practical nurse who moved here six years ago from Jamaica, said that ''racial problems and traffic congestion,'' which forces her to leave earlier and earlier to catch a bus to her job at Morristown Memorial Hospital, were her chief concerns.
In January 1989, John Jackson, a 22-year-old black, died after being arrested by in connection with a traffic violation here. An autopsy found that he had died of cardiac arryhthmia brought on by cocaine use. But the incident prompted an examination of racial relations in the town.
 
'Job Is Not Being Done'
Thus far, Ms. Cunningham said, the efforts have not been successful. ''One group is meeting behind closed doors, and the other is meeting out in the open,'' she said. ''They're not getting together. They're not hitting the nail on the head.'
Margaret Hyland, owner of Pegeen, a children's-clothing store on South Street, said: ''I'm worried about water pollution, and I'm glad to see the Governor doing something about that. But I'm also worried about drugs and the deterioration it brings, even to small communities. The job is not being done, and Bush has been dancing around the issue with his program.''
She said he was glad to see Mr. Florio's ban on assault weapons become law. ''It's a step in a better direction,'' she said.
Four candidates are vying for the Republican nomination, with two legislators, State Senator Richard A. Zimmer, 45, of Flemington, and Assemblyman Rodney P. Frelinghuysen, 44, of Morristown, leading a field that includes Phil McConkey, 33, a former player for the New York Giants, and Joseph F. Shanahan, 76, president of the Hunterdon County Citizens and Taxpayers Association. Tossup for G.O.P. Marguerite Chandler, 46, an executive, has been endorsed by all the County Democratic organizations in the district and is expected to win her party's nomination. She is opposed by James J. Cleary, 53, a supporter of Lyndon H. LaRouche.
Steven A. Salmore, a professor of political science at the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University, said the Republican race appeared to be a tossup between Mr. Zimmer and Mr. Frelinghuysen.
''Frelinghuysen was better known at the start and was better plugged into established money,'' Professor Salmore said. ''But Zimmer has run before in more of the district and is very strong in Hunterdon and Warren.''
Each man is fiscally conservative and moderate on social issues, and each supports a woman's right to choose an abortion. Each has produced a campaign video that includes warm comments by former Gov. Thomas H. Kean, and each had been going his own way in the campaign until the last two weeks. Former Representative Millicent H. Fenwick has endorsed Mr. Frelinghuysen, and State Senator Wayne Dumont Jr. of Phillipsburg backs Mr. Zimmer.
 
Differences Over Budget
Mr. Frelinghuysen's family includes four United States Senators and a former Representative, his father, Peter H. B. Frelinghuysen. He stresses his record as a Morris County Freeholder and Assemblyman, including chairman of the Appropriations Committee.
Mr. Zimmer, a former head of New Jersey Common Cause, spoke of his sponsorship of legislation to preserve farmland and his leadership in passing a radon-protection bill.
About two weeks ago Mr. Zimmer personalized the campaign by comparing his actions as a member of the Appropriations Committee with those of Mr. Frelinghuysen.
Mr. Zimmer pointed out that as chairman, Mr. Frelinghuysen had helped draft the current budget, which Mr. Florio says is $600 million out of balance. Mr. Zimmer voted against the spending plan, saying it was balanced with gimmicks and smoke and mirrors. He has voted against five of the last eight budgets.
Mr. Frelinghuysen has responded by accusing Mr. Zimmer of mudslinging and waging a negative campaign, but he has decided not to defend his role in drawing up the budget.
Although he has not held elective office, Mr. McConkey's name was known because of his football career, and he has established himself as the most conservative candidate in the race. He is opposed to abortion and has the endorsement of the National Right to Life Political Action Committee. On Thursday, the Housing and Urban Development Secretary, Jack F. Kemp, visited Flemington for a fund-raising event for Mr. McConkey.
The Zimmer and Frelinghuysen camps plan to spend $500,000 each to win a nomination that both sides say will go to the candidate who receives 18,000 votes.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, JUNE 2, 1990

 BODY:

 
 
Companies
 Two judges reopened Manville's bankruptcy proceeding by ordering a Federal bankruptcy judge to overhaul the procedures for compensating victims of asbestos. The extraordinary ruling comes in response to troubles at the trust set up two years ago by Manville, its insurers and a Federal bankruptcy court. The Economy
 Business payrolls in May failed to expand for the third consecutive month and the number of factory jobs dropped by 35,000, the Labor Department said. Most analysts had expected moderate growth in jobs and the decline heightened speculation that the Federal Reserve would have to relax its grip on the money supply to keep the seven-and-a-half-year business expansion intact. The civilian unemployment rate as measured by a household survey fell by one-tenth of a point in May, to 5.3 percent, helped by the Census Bureau's hiring of temporary workers. HEADLINE: Kennedy Still No. 1, but Slipping

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
Kennedy International Airport, long the biggest and most popular United States gateway for international travelers, is seeing its dominant position erode as major American carriers increasingly choose to fly abroad from other cities they use as hubs.
The change has implications not only for the airport but also for its two biggest airlines, Pan American World Airways and Trans World Airlines, and for the metropolitan New York economy.
In just five years, the airport's share of international passengers boarding flights at United States airports fell to 32.2 percent in 1988, the most recent year for which figures are available, from 37.1 percent, and the percentage has continued to drop since then.
 
Slower Traffic Growth
All told, traffic at Kennedy is expected to grow at about 2.5 percent to 3 percent a year in the next decade, a rate slower than at other major airports. International traffic at major hub airports, including Newark, Dallas, Chicago and Atlanta, is growing far faster than at Kennedy. 
''It used to be that when you went to Europe you went to New York first,'' said Donald J. Carty, the senior vice president of planning at the AMR Corporation, parent of American Airlines.
International traffic has grown fast enough that Kennedy has not suffered severely from the loss of market share; it handled 8.95 million international passengers in 1989, down from 9 million in 1988, which was a record. But the airport has clearly lost the momentum that made it the jewel of the Jet Age, with enormous growth in the 1960's and 1970's as the industry converted to jet planes and foreign travel became far more convenient. Kennedy's weakening position affected the recent decision of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which oversees the airport, to postpone a planned $1 billion central terminal and monorail system. That project would have meant thousands of jobs in construction and in airport services. Kennedy handles 11 domestic and 48 foreign carriers, and 40,500 people are employed at the airport.
And because more international flights are leaving from and arriving at other cities, New York City itself will not become as big a gathering place for business and pleasure as it might have. The growth at Newark has softened the impact, however.
The expansion at other airports at the expense of Kennedy is also hurting Pan Am and T.W.A., which together account for 50 percent of the operations at Kennedy.
Many international travelers who once flowed to those two airlines at Kennedy now fly on other airlines, like American, United and Delta, that have recently introduced or expanded overseas service and send passengers through their own hubs.
''As the hubs have became bigger and bigger, there have emerged a lot of connecting points which made more sense than going to Kennedy,'' Mr. Carty said. Since 1982, American Airlines has added seven daily flights to Europe and East Asia from its hub at Dallas-Forth Worth International Airport, and nine flights from O'Hare International Airport in Chicago. But the airline reduced its service from Kennedy earlier this year.
 
Other Hubs Win Flights
When United Airlines began flying to Europe on May 15, the flights to Frankfurt went from United's hubs at O'Hare International and Dulles International Airport near Washington.
''We never even considered Kennedy,'' said John C. Pope, the executive vice president in charge of finance at United's parent, the UAL Corporation. ''Why would we ever start European service to Frankfurt there when we have a powerhouse hub in Chicago?''
Since the industry was deregulated, all leading United States carriers have built domestic hubs at which they collect passengers from many destinations and send them on to other cities. They no longer needed Government permission to fly anywhere within the United States.
Major increases in the range of some of the larger aircraft - like the Boeing 747-400, which can fly about 8,000 miles without refueling - have given major carriers more flexibility on where they originate their flights. (The longer-range planes can also benefit Kennedy, however, putting such flights as New York to Tokyo, which is 6,800 miles, within easy reach.) Foreign carriers have also added United States destinations other than Kennedy, although most have expanded service at Kennedy as well.
 
Overseas Lines Fly to Hubs
British Airways, for example, has added Orlando and Tampa, Fla., Seattle and Pittsburgh during the last decade and in 1988 took on Atlanta, Dallas, Houston and San Diego when it acquired British Caledonian Airlines.
Despite its slowdown in growth, Kennedy might appear to have more than enough business, at least to judge by the rate of flight delays there - among the nation's highest -and the crush of passengers at peak travel times.
But the flight delays occur largely because the airport operates in a heavily congested region. In fact, Kennedy has plenty of extra capacity to handle more flights at times other than the peak hours of the afternoon and early evening, said Donald Z. Plavin, the director of aviation redevelopment programs for the Port Authority.
And the crush of travelers at certain places within the airport has much to do with access roads, parking lots and terminal reception areas in need of expansion and improvement to meet past growth.
 
Catching Up With the Past
Mr. Plavin said the Port Authority planned to spend about $2 billion in the next five years to upgrade. ''We're going to catch up to the growth that we have had in the past,'' he said.
One reason that Kennedy is not growing faster at this point is that no major carrier has solved the problem of how to establish a domestic hub at Kennedy that would feed its international flights while attracting enough domestic travel to make the network profitable, said Mr. Carty of American Airlines. Part of the problem is that New York has two competing major airports, La Guardia and Newark. Another concern is that New York is not well situated as an airline hub.
As a result, Kennedy relies far less than others on domestic traffic.
Even with Kennedy's decline in market share, the airport is still by far the largest international airport in the country and it will maintain that position for a long time.
The airports at Miami and Los Angeles are neck and neck as a distant second, handling a little more than half as many international passengers in 1988. (The world's biggest international airport, Heathrow in London, handles almost twice as many international passengers as Kennedy or any other airport.) New York Still a Favorite James T. Murphy, an aviation consultant who recently advised airlines on the planned expansion at Kennedy, said New York was still the favorite destination among vacationers coming from overseas with Orlando second.
''New York itself is a target destination for people who want to come here and see the Big Apple even as they leave to go elsewhere,'' said Robert Falkner, executive vice president of North America for British Airways.
The airline is spending $80 million to improve its terminal at Kennedy in cooperation with United Airlines, which formed a marketing alliance with British Airways under which they feed each other passengers and jointly market their flights.
Mr. Falkner and Mr. Murphy both believe that Kennedy will continue to see its share of international passengers drop as domestic carriers add foreign flights at their hubs.
Delta, for example, will have four international gates at a new terminal being built at Orlando International Airport, where the airline now has a flight to Frankfurt.
 
Expansion in Atlanta
Delta is also seeking to have a concourse added at Hartsfield International Airport in Atlanta. The carrier began international service there in 1978 with a daily flight to London. It now has eight daily flights to Europe.
Trying to make up for the loss of passengers at Kennedy from other airlines, Pan Am and T.W.A. have tried to build up their own domestic networks to feed passengers to Kennedy. T.W.A. acquired Ozark Airlines and has built a hub at St. Louis. Carl C. Icahn, the chairman of T.W.A., has unsuccessfully sought to strengthen the network by trying to buy carriers like Eastern, most recently last year.
But maintaining domestic networks is becoming more difficult for both carriers as their United States competitors add flights abroad.
Delta Air Lines, for example, now flies directly from Cincinnati to London and Frankfurt and plans to add Paris on July 1. Pan Am flies a Boeing 727 to and from Cincinnati to bring passengers to its international hub at Kennedy. That is highly inefficient because the plane must often lay over at Cincinnati for up to 16 hours before its flight back.
 
Advantage for Domestics
For overseas flights that do connect at Kennedy, the United States airlines count on the ability to bring passengers directly to their terminals, enabling them to board international flights easily. That gives them an advantage over foreign carriers, which cannot operate domestic flights.
The reluctance to give up such an advantage was an important reason that the domestic carriers were unwilling to support the Port Authority plan for a $1 billion central terminal and monorail system. The Port Authority said last month that it would put off the project.
Under the Port Authority plan, passengers on all domestic and international flights would have checked their luggage at the central terminal at Kennedy and then boarded the monorail to terminals operated by the airlines.
Another factor was the financial pressures on Pan Am and T.W.A., which said they could not pay for both the renovations that had to be made at their terminals and the higher user fees at Kennedy to help finance the new central terminal.
Pan Am has been able to keep operating by selling assets. Last month it put its shuttle up for sale to raise enough money to survive the autumn and winter, when traffic declines.
The carrier has also sought to be taken over by a stronger airline. Other carriers have been reluctant, however; Pan Am's valuable international routes are offset by an old fleet and a heavily unionized work force.
At T.W.A., Mr. Icahn has begun to cut back the airline's operations in his struggle with the pilots' union for concessions. Mr. Icahn maintains that unless the pilots' union provides further concessions on wages and benefits he will not invest in more new planes and will shrink the airline.
If both carriers are forced to sell more international routes to keep operating, there will be buyers, most executives and consultants agreed.

HEADLINE: U.S. Reports 0.7% Decline In Construction Spending

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 1

 BODY:
Construction spending fell seven-tenths of 1 percent in April, the Government reported today. Analysts said the report signaled weakening in the building industry.
The Commerce Department said residential, nonresidential and government construction spending totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $432.4 billion in April. The March figure was revised to show a similar decline of seven-tenths of 1 percent, down from the 1.4 percent decrease originally reported. 
The decreases in spending in March and April followed gains of 3.2 percent in February and 2.4 percent in January. The declines resulted in the loss of 159,000 construction jobs.
 
'Quite a Decline'
''We had strong construction employment in the first quarter when we had great weather,'' said David F. Seiders, chief economist for the National Association of Home Builders. ''But if you look at the next two months, that's really quite a decline.''
Along with new employment data, the construction spending report provides ''two more signals of a pretty sluggish economy,'' Mr. Seiders said.
Other reports also indicated further weakening in the economy. Government job data released today showed that although the unemployment rate fell to 5.3 percent in May, virtually no new jobs were created in the private sector. The Labor Department reported 20,000 more construction jobs were lost in the month.
On Wednesday, the F. W. Dodge division of McGraw-Hill Inc. reported that contracts for new construction declined 6 percent in April.
Analysts attribute the construction slump to high interest rates and tighter restrictions on lending.
Residential building edged down three-tenths of 1 percent, to an annual rate of $202.7 billion. It had risen 2 percent in March, higher than the 1.8 percent increase first reported.
 
More Apartment Construction
Single-family building dropped 2.2 percent, to an annual rate of $120 billion, after a 1.2 percent increase in March. But apartment construction rose 6 percent, to $21 billion. It had dropped 4.3 percent in March.
With mortgage rates in the double digits and new-home sales declining, residential construction ''is destined to keep going down,'' Mr. Seiders said. He said the jump in multifamily building was an aberration.
Nonresidential construction, including office and industrial buildings, edged up six-tenths of 1 percent, to $104.2 billion, after rising 2.4 percent in March.
The volatile government sector fell for the second straight month, down 3.5 percent, to $87.6 billion. Spending for highways and streets paced the drop, declining 8.2 percent.
Government construction spending had fallen 4.9 percent in March after gaining 5.2 percent in February.
Overall construction spending in April was 5 percent above that of April 1989, when it was $411.9 billion.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Precious Metals in Plunge; Livestock and Pork Climb

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Precious metals futures plunged yesterday on the New York Commodity Exchange in the wake of weak May employment figures and amid uncertainty on whether a trade agreement will result from the United States-Soviet summit talks.
On other markets, grain and soybean futures fell; livestock and pork futures were higher, and energy futures were mixed.
Peter Caudillo, an analyst with Josephthal & Company in New York, said the precious metals market was monitoring the talks between President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union in Washington. ''If nothing positive comes of out of the summit, there are fears the Soviets will be forced again to sell gold in the open market'' to pay for overseas purchases, Mr. Caudillo said. 
He noted that gold has not been able to rally since mid-May, when heavy cash market selling of the metal sent prices tumbling.
The Labor Department announced yesterday that the nation's unemployment rate fell to 5.3 percent in May, and that a smaller-than-expected 164,000 jobs were created in that month.
''The figures are indicating economic weakness, translating into a downward trend in inflation,'' he said. Gold is seen as a haven during inflationary periods.
Silver futures were battered by gold's plunge, with the day's gains erased when investors liquidated near-month contracts.
Gold settled $5.10 to $5.80 lower, with the contract for delivery in June at $359.20 an ounce; silver was 2.8 cents to 4.4 cents lower, with June at $5.046 an ounce.
 
Soybeans Mostly Down
Grain and soybean futures were mostly lower on the Chicago Board of Trade as improving weather depressed prices. Soybeans dropped sharply when the July support level of $6.05 a bushel was breached and selling set in.
Forecasts called for dry conditions much of next week, which will facilitate planting of soybeans, said William Biedermann, an analyst with Allendale Inc. in Chicago. Soybean plantings had been delayed by soggy fields.
Corn futures were pushed lower by progress made this week in planting the corn crop.
Mr. Biedermann said that sparse export business and a lack of progress in trade talks during the Bush-Gorbachev talks influenced corn futures.
Fairly good weather, allowing for progress in the harvesting of the winter crop, pushed wheat futures lower.
Wheat was 1 cent to 4 1/2 cents lower, with July at $3.29 1/4 a bushel; corn was 1 3/4 cents to 2 1/4 cents lower, with July at $2.75 3/4 a bushel; oats were a 1/2 cent lower to 1 cent higher, with July at $1.44 a bushel, and soybeans were 5 1/4 cents to 7 1/2 cents lower, with July at $6.02 a bushel.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Gains Against Mark But Loses Ground to the Yen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was mixed yesterday, gaining against the West German mark and Swiss franc and losing ground to the Japanese yen and British pound.
The report on the United States labor market in May initially had a negative impact on the dollar. The report indicated continuing sluggish growth, which drove down interest rates in the bond market. Lower interest rates reduce returns on dollar-denominated holdings and can curb demand for dollars.
The unemployment rate dipped to 5.3 percent in May from 5.4 percent in April and non-farm payrolls expanded by an unexpectedly small number.
Sales of other currencies to collect profits from recent advances helped the dollar recover from its lows of the day.
Lingering concerns about various international matters also benefited the dollar. Confidence in the West German currency has been eroded by speculation that German unification could undermine the mark's value.
Trading slowed during the day as currency dealers usually refrain from establishing significant new positions on Fridays because events over the weekend might have an impact on exchange rates.
The dollar's performance against the Japanese yen was mixed. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 152.17 yen, up 0.42 yen from Thursday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 151.45 yen.
The currency was quoted at 151.85 yen near the end of New York trading, down from 152.10 late Thursday.
The British pound rose to $1.6840 in London, from $1.6760 late Thursday. Sterling rose to $1.6810, from $1.6780 late Thursday.
Selected late dollar rates in New York, compared with Thursday's late quotes, included: 1.6985 West German marks, up from 1.6965; 1.4375 Swiss francs, up from 1.4290; 5.7295 French francs, up from 5.724; 1,250.375 Italian lire, up from 1,248.25, and 1.17465 Canadian dollars, up from 1.17285.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER'S WORLD;
A Price War Forces Some Air Fares Down

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE

 BODY:
Travelers who plan to vacation in the United States this year - and already know when and where they are going - can get a very good deal if they buy airline tickets by next Thursday and are willing to put up with restrictions on their flights.
That's because domestic airlines are in another big price war. Some fares are being cut by more than half. The number of seats is limited, some dates are blacked out and the fares are not refundable, but the savings are significant. 
Tickets must be purchased by June 7 and at least seven days in advance of departure, and the trip must be completed by Dec. 13. You must fly on Tuesday, Wednesday or Thursday, both going and coming, and stay over on a Saturday night. The fares are not good over the Thanksgiving holidays.
 
An Unusual Summer
 ''For the consumer who can take advantage of this, it's just wonderful,'' said Raymond P. Kane, the president of Pisa Brothers Travel Service, a New York travel agency.
Why is there a price war? Paul Turk, the publications director of Avmark Inc., an aviation consulting company in Arlington, Va., explained: ''Customarily, airline fares go up in the heavy summer travel season, but this year capacity is about to outstrip demand, as new airplanes are delivered and old ones are not taken out of service. In order to put people in seats, you have to make the seats attractive.''
Relatively few seats on each domestic flight are being sold at the discount fares. That is because airlines are using yield-management techniques to try to make the highest profit by periodically increasing or decreasing the inexpensive seats on a given flight, based on demand.
 
A Few Here, a Few There
 But even though each flight has a small number of discounted seats, they add up over all. Robert B. Cozzi, senior vice president for marketing at Trans World Airlines, said that when his airline began promoting the new prices late in May, ''we had over a million seats a month for sale.''
Samuel C. Buttrick, the airlines analyst at the securities firm of Kidder Peabody & Company, said that ''the vast majority of deep-discount seats are aimed at vacation travelers'' because such travelers ''have the flexibility in their travel plans to meet the restrictions.''
Not every vacationer will find a discounted fare for the preferred destination at the preferred time. But there are major economies for travelers with elastic schedules. The new round-trip fares are $198 or less for flights up to 1,500 miles and $298 for longer flights. That is far less than the lowest regular-price basic fares; on flights of less than 1,500 miles, for example, the regular fare is $426 from Des Moines to San Diego, $364 from Dallas-Fort Worth to Los Angeles and $322 from Chicago to Phoenix.
If the price war forces fares still lower, many airlines say they will give further discounts to people who already have discounted tickets. ''It is really an effort to get some advance traffic on the books,'' said Marilyn Hoppe, the senior director for pricing and revenue management at America West Airlines.
The discounted fares are nonrefundable, so the purchaser must use them or lose them, unless it can be proved that an illness or a death in the family prevented the trip. Lee R. Howard, the chief executive of Airline Economics, a Washington consulting company, put it this way: ''If you have a change in plans, it's going to be very expensive.''
In addition to offering the discounted fares, United Airlines recently advertised coupons - with restrictions - for $35 off its domestic flights costing $175 or more. Many other airlines are accepting those coupons.
 
Some Flights Are Just $29
 What's more, the industry has followed the lead of Eastern Air Lines in offering a restricted one-way summer fare of $29 on flights between the Northeast and Florida for children age 2 through 17 traveling with an adult. While that bargain isn't as good as last summer's - when children could fly free - it is well below the current reduced adult fare of $89.
Are hotel and motel rates in the United States following the lead of the airlines? No. The average room rate is up about 4 1/2 percent this year over the 1989 average level of $56.31, according to the Travel Industry Association of America.
''The lower the air rates are, the more people are going to be traveling,'' said Ronald Evans, chief executive officer of Best Western International. ''They all have to stay somewhere, and that builds demand for our business.''
 
FLYING ABROAD COSTS MORE
Many domestic air fares are being discounted, but international fares will cost more this summer. Tickets for overseas flights are running 5 to 7 percent higher than a year ago, following the usual trend for the summer rush.
Here are some typical round-trip fare increases: New York to Stockholm, up by $46, to $804; New York to Berlin, up $42, to $720, and New York to Rio de Janiero, up $50, to $1,079.
''Demand is very good,'' said Ann Fegan, system director for pricing at Pan American World Airways. ''Fare sales are not likely on international trips.''

HEADLINE: CONSUMER'S WORLD;
Airlines Phasing In Safer Plane Seats

BYLINE: By BARRY MEIER

 BODY:
All the major airlines in the United States are quietly installing new and safer passenger seats on airplanes. But the changeover is so random that the level of seat safety varies from plane to plane and even between sections of the same aircraft.
The change is taking place because the Federal Aviation Administration is expected to adopt a regulation this year that would require airlines to use the new seats throughout all commercial planes by late 1995. Currently, some planes have all seats of the new type, others have none and still others have the new seats only in first and business class or only in economy class, spokesmen for most major airlines said. Typically, the seats are being changed when sections of planes are refurbished. 
The new seats are known as ''16-G'' seats because they can withstand a force about 16 times the force of gravity. Safety experts agree that they are a major improvement over the ''9-G'' seats now in use, because, among other things, they are less likely to break loose in some accidents and hurtle passengers toward serious injury or death.
 
A Question of 'More Safe'
 Industry and Government safety experts say the 9-G seats are not dangerous. ''This is not a question of safe versus unsafe, but safe versus more safe,'' said Thomas McSweeny, the F.A.A.'s deputy director of aircraft certification services.
The airlines have not announced the change to the public, saying it would be impractical to tell travelers what kinds of seats are on a particular flight. But some consumer advocates said such information should be disclosed. ''If I was choosing a flight I would want to know,'' said Edward Perkins, editor of Consumer Reports Travel Letter, a publication of Consumers Union.
Passengers are not likely to notice the difference between the old and new seats, but they differ in several ways. The 16-G legs, for example, are often curved or otherwise designed to absorb force during a crash; the 9-G seat supports are usually straight, making them more vulnerable to snapping. In addition, the 16-G seat, unlike a 9-G unit, must meet Government specifications for protecting a passenger's head, spine and legs.
Some groups, like the flight attendants' union, say airlines should be required to switch to the new 16-G seats sooner than 1995. The F.A.A. proposal of 1995 was based on its estimate that most seats are replaced after about seven years. But the airlines want to delay replacing all their seats beyond 1995, because they say some seats can last longer than seven years and the cost of replacing them early is high.
The F.A.A has estimated that the change will cost about $33 million, though airline officials say it will cost more. ''I think the public would rather have us spending the money on wind-shear detection and other things to prevent accidents,'' said Richard Tobiason, safety director for the Air Transport Association of America, a trade group in Washington.
Mr. Tobiason said that his group supported using the new seats but also that carriers should be allowed to install them at their own pace. To date, about 15 percent of the estimated 600,000 seats on United States airliners have been converted to 16-G seats, according to the Air Transport Association.
The F.A.A. estimates that about 33 lives will be saved annually for every 1 million new seats installed. Several safety experts said a major benefit of the new seats would be the reduction of injuries that disable passengers and thus prevent them from escaping burning planes.
 
Change Long Sought
 Some safety experts and the National Transportation Safety Board have long called for improved seat safety. But it was not until May 1988 that the F.A.A. issued a rule requiring the immediate use of 16-G seats on all newly certified aircraft and a proposed rule requiring the replacement of 9-G seats on all aircraft by 1995. The proposed rule is of greater immediate import because no new passenger aircraft models have been certified since 1988.
A survey of seven major United States carriers this week showed that new airplanes are being delivered with 16-G seats throughout. The airlines also said that they plan to change to 16-G seats whenever they refurbish planes, but for now many planes have both seat types.
Seat strength and fire safety are just two of several factors that affect the ability of passengers to survive accidents. But several air-safety experts are pointing the January 1989 crash of a British Midland Airways Boeing 737-400 north of London as an incident where the new seats may have saved lives.
The aircraft, which was outfitted with 16-G seats throughout, crashed about a quarter-mile short of a runaway, breaking into three sections. Forty-three passengers were killed, but 83 others survived. Where the cabin remined intact, the new seats did not tear loose, Mr. McSweeny of the F.A.A. said.
A crash like the British Midland accident - one near an airport during takeoff or landing - is the type in which the new seats could make the biggest difference, safety experts agree. A 1981 National Transportation Safety Board study of such ''survivable'' crashes, which make up about one-third of all aircraft accidents, found that 9-G seats sometimes tore loose from floor moorings or sheared off upon impact. Passengers were thrown like missiles through a plane, the board reported.
In light of the F.A.A. proposal, most seat manufacturers have phased out 9-G seat production, said R. Rudy Pecoraro, the vice president of marketing and sales for Weber Aircraft Inc. in Fullerton, Calif., a seat maker that is a subsidiary of Hanson Trust P.L.C. But Mr. Pecoraro noted that airlines are with replacing 9-G seats at their own pace.
 
Wide Variation in Use
 The survey of airlines this week found that the use of 16-G seats by major carriers ranged from 3 percent to 40 percent of an airline's total seat capacity.
American Airlines, which had the highest percentage of 16-G seats of the airlines polled, said the situation represented, among other things, a recent influx of new plane deliveries. Delta Air Lines, which ranked lowest in the survey, said its number of 16-G seats should rise with deliveries of new airplanes in coming months.
One surveyed airline, Trans World Airlines, declined to disclose information about its seats.
In the past, some safety experts have suggested another seat-related safety measure, rear-facing seats. But passengers, airlines and Government officials have shown little or no interest in the idea.
Matt Finucane, the air-safety director for the Association of Flight Attendants, said the F.A.A. has repeatedly bowed to industry arguments that 16-G seats are too costly. ''If someone dies in an accident because of a 9-G seat two years from now,'' he said, ''it is going to be a situation where everybody knew better seats were available but for economic reasons did not put them in.''
F.A.A. officials said such charges are unfair because the agency was required to include financial consideration in its decisions about safety.
Foreign governments are expected to follow the F.A.A.'s lead on the seat issue, Mr. McSweeny said.

HEADLINE: Summit in Washington;
2 Leaders Spend Day in Relaxed Talks at Camp David

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 2

 BODY:
 President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev withdrew to the relative informality of Camp David, Md., today and applied their growing rapport to such problems as regional conflicts, Soviet emigration and anti-Semitism.
The Presidential spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said the two leaders doffed their coats and ties and had a ''relaxed give and take'' on a range of regional issues, including Afghanistan, Cambodia, the Middle East, Cuba and Nicaragua. He said they then discussed human rights and anti-Semitism in the Soviet Union before moving into a more ''philosophical'' conversation.
Mr. Fitzwater said the two men did not resume their discussion on the major unresolved issue of the summit talks, the future of Europe after German reunification.
 
Laying the Groundwork
In his most upbeat comments of the week on this issue, the Presidential spokesman said that in their earlier meetings Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev had laid the groundwork for an eventual convergence of views on the German issue. 
American and Soviet officials said the two sides remained far from a breakthrough on the central issue of whether a united Germany will be integrated into the military structure of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, but had come to a much closer understanding on ways to make Germany's future less threatening to the Soviets.
At Camp David, the presidential retreat 50 miles northeast of Washington, the two men spent the morning reviewing the world's hottest trouble spots, then took a short break and cruised the Camp David grounds in a golf cart, with Mr. Gorbachev at the wheel at one point. After lunch they resumed their conversation with no specific agenda. 'Made It a Personal Thing'
American officials today recounted how Mr. Bush tried to cement the kind of personal trust he prizes in his relations with world leaders by responding on Friday to Mr. Gorbachev's appeal for a trade pact, the first surprise of the summit meeting.
Mr. Bush had said before the summit meeting that the Kremlin's harsh resistance to Lithuania's drive for independence could impede a trade agreement, and members of Congress warned today that Congressional approval of the accord would hinge on an end to Moscow's economic crackdown on Lithuania. [Page 10.] In what Soviet and American officials said was an example of the commercial contacts that would prosper under the trade accord, the Chevron Corporation signed an agreement today that could open the way for a major expansion of its activities in the Soviet Union. [Page 13.] Discussing the two leaders' meetings this week, an American official said that Mr. Gorbachev brought up the issue of the trade accord in each of his encounters with Mr. Bush.
''He made it a personal thing between him and the President,'' the official said. ''Chemistry played a big role in it, because Bush is very high on personal diplomacy.''
At the same time, the official said, the Soviet side began dragging its heels on signing a new long-term grain agreement greatly desired by American farmers, implicitly signaling that the grain and trade deals were linked.
''They wanted to show they were bargaining hard too, that they were not groveling too much,'' the American official asserted.
The official said that after sounding out Mr. Gorbachev personally on his willingness to seek a peaceful resolution of the Lithuanian issue, and after having aides check for possible repercussions on Capitol Hill, Mr. Bush agreed to sign the treaty. It is to be sent to Congress as soon as the Soviet Parliament approves a new emigration law, a step which is expected soon.
 
Pressure From Conservatives
''Gorbachev had a track record with us, and we calculated that he was going to need something to take back with him from Washington,'' the American official said. ''That was in our interests too, because we need his acquiescence, at the very least, in Europe and his help on arms control and other issues.''
The Administration's version of this exchange may have been aimed at pre-empting criticism from American conservatives, who have already begun to complain that Mr. Bush failed to extract concessions from the Soviet leader on Lithuania.
Soviet journalists said Mr. Gorbachev could depict the trade agreement at home as a small vote of confidence by the Bush Administration in the Soviet leadership and its prospects for reviving the economy.
After two days of talks in the capital focused on arms accords and on trade and European security, the two Presidents flew by helicopter from the White House lawn to the Presidential retreat in the Maryland mountains this morning.
 
'Most Fruitful Summit'
Yevgeny M. Primakov, a close adviser to Mr. Gorbachev, told reporters in Washington that the rustic setting of Camp David was conducive to reflection on broader philosophical questions ''you cannot talk very well about in tuxedoes.''
''I believe that this is the most fruitful summit in the history of our relations,'' Mr. Primakov added, explaining that the emergence of a more cooperative approach on issues like the future of Europe had given the superpower relationship ''a vertical dimension.''
American officials reported no major progress in the discussion of regional conflicts, although Americans had initially hoped for joint statements on Afghanistan, Ethiopia and Kashmir.
The American side has taken pains to play down the prospect of resolving differences on Germany, especially after optimistic and apparently offhanded comments by the two leaders earlier this week ignited a brushfire of expectations.
A senior American official said that after reviewing the issue at length earlier in the week, the opposing positions seemed clear and not subject to change.
''They spoke about it for two and a half hours,'' the official said. ''They may return to it, but I think we took it as far as we can take it on this trip.''
Today Mr. Fitzwater put a more hopeful spin on the week's discussions.
''I think both leaders feel their discussions a day ago were quite productive on the question of Germany and reunification, that they did reach a better understanding of their positions, that they were closer than they were before they started, that progress has been made that will lead them to converge in the months ahead,'' he said.
''There is a feeling that those understandings can lead to bringing the two sides together as well as the other members of the alliances together on this issue.''
The Soviets contend that a united Germany fully integrated into the NATO military command would be perceived at home as tilting the balance decisively against Soviet security.
As Germany reunifies, Moscow wants the rival military blocs gradually supplanted by a more collective European security structure that would protect existing boundaries, limit the size of the German army, and prevent Germany from becoming a nuclear power.
 
U.S. Argues Inevitability
The United States contends that Germany's membership in NATO is virtually inevitable, and the only issue is how to make that fact politically, economically and militarily palatable for the Soviets.
Mr. Primakov said the issue of Germany's membership in NATO is ''far from being settled,'' but he said the United States ''understands much better than before'' the Soviet desire for international structures to diminish the danger of military confrontation.
When a reporter asked what leverage Moscow had to prevent Germany from reuniting and joining NATO, Mr. Primakov said: ''I don't think for that we would have to send tank divisions to the territory of Germany.
''As for other questions, the Soviet Union, if its security interests are not taken into account, then will have to consider on a unilateral basis a whole series of measures that will enable it to insure its own security,'' he said, without elaborating.

HEADLINE: Door to a Business of One's Own Can Be Good Exit From Welfare

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, June 2

 BODY:
Zoraida Feliciano said she saw no exit from a world bounded by welfare checks and food stamps. Then last year a door in her life opened and now she runs her own business, a party-supply shop here in South Philadelphia.
''I'm dreaming,'' said Ms. Feliciano, standing behind the counter of her shop, Ida's Party Place. She is one of the first graduates of a program to train welfare recipients for self-employment - an approach that is being hailed as one of the best hopes for transforming the nation's welfare system from a cash-dispensing machine into a system that provides education, career counseling and job placement.
Hundreds of other welfare recipients in Pennsylvania and in a handful of other states have started businesses, and a thousand more recipients are working toward that goal in similar demonstration programs started recently by the states. 
The new businesses, nearly all of them run by women, are as diverse as a restaurant with seven employees in Minnesota, a gun shop in West Virginia and a booking agency for male strippers and comedians in Iowa.
Though it will be years before it is clear whether the programs move people permanently off welfare, the short-term verdict is that the approach works. Program officials estimate that it may cost taxpayers $5,000 to $10,000 to start each business, but that the cost can be quickly recovered by savings in welfare expenses and business tax payments. State and Federal governments share the cost.
''I think the programs are a terrific way for some people to achieve independence,'' said David T. Ellwood, professor of public policy at Harvard's John F. Kennedy School of Government. ''Self-employment gives recipients with poor educations a chance to make more than the minimum wage, and it allows them flexibility in the hours they work so they can deal with the daily crises of kids' getting sick, or whatever.''
 
Taking the Initiative
States with fledgling training programs include New Jersey, Maryland, North Carolina, Michigan and Mississippi. West Virginia's one-year program ended last fall and is being evaluated.
Self-employment training is also being offered, with early indications of success, to recipients of unemployment insurance in an experimental program in the State of Washington. But offering an entrepreneur program to welfare recipients is even more ambitious, since they make up that part of the population with the most disadvantages. And, to the surprise of welfare experts, most of those who volunteer for the programs are long-term welfare recipients who have not responded to other initiatives.
The response rate is less surprising, some observers say, in light of the fact that some welfare recipients already have business experience, from running small, one-person enterprises just to make ends meet.
Statistics on the programs' successes and failures are virtually nonexistent at this early stage. Some officials say they hope for a success rate of 60 percent, which would be comparable to the general survival rate of new businesses after the first year.
For some people, the program may break the cycle of poverty. ''I'm training my daughter to help me out because she's got to know that if she wants anything in life she's got to work for it,'' said Brinda Reed, two months after opening her barbecue stand in Canton, Miss.
The 31-year-old single mother said she was born into a welfare family and has been ''just sitting around depending on welfare'' for 13 years. ''I never knew how it felt to make $100 a day,'' she said. ''It feels good.''
 
Beginnings in Europe
The programs are based on successful ones started a decade ago in France and Britain that have since spread across Europe, said Rona F. Feit, a senior fellow at the Corporation for Enterprise Development, a nonprofit organization that is coordinating some of the projects.
''Self-employment has been a route out of poverty for centuries,'' she said, ''but this is the first time public policy-makers in this country have begun to look at ways to make this route more available to poor people through training and access to capital in small amounts.''
She estimated the programs would appeal to 1 percent to 10 percent of the four million adult recipients of welfare, the eight million officially unemployed and the nine million working poor. And she said self employment could become an increasingly important option for millions of people as more jobs require advanced education and specialized skills.
 
Someone to Push Her
Ms. Feliciano, for example, is 49 years old, has four children, a ninth-grade education and a recently earned high school equivalency certificate. For her, the choice was always between welfare or working in a factory for the minimum wage. For most of her adult life she chose welfare. Then last year she applied for the self-employment training program being offered in Philadelphia by the Women's Enterprise Resource Center on a contract with the state.
''To tell you the truth, I didn't think I would make it,'' Ms. Feliciano said. ''They were talking about all these big things in business, and I was afraid to go back to school.'' But she persevered. ''I always wanted to go into business, but I needed somebody to push me,'' she said.
The self-employment programs help people start businesses by providing individual support and training. Those who participate are also exempted from Federal rules, now under review, that are designed to prevent people from living too comfortably on welfare, but also make it difficult for recipients to legally start a business by restricting their savings and assets, such as equipment.
 
Changing Their Thinking
States usually contract with nonprofit business organizations to provide the programs. Courses cover business practices, accounting and taxes. Students develop detailed business plans. The study programs, which generally last three to six months, stress career counseling and assertiveness training. Homework for Mississippi participants, for example, includes the daily repetition of five affirmations, including, ''I like myself as I am.''
After completing training, graduates continue to receive public assistance benefits for a year while they get their businesses on a firm footing.
Obtaining financing for the businesses is one of the biggest obstacles. ''We wouldn't be on welfare if we didn't have financial problems,'' said Beverly A. Baldwin, a 35-year-old mother of two children in Charleston, W. Va. Ms. Baldwin, who had worked as a secretary for 15 years, said she went on welfare about two years ago after a divorce forced her into bankruptcy.
She completed a self-employment training program last year, but her credit history made it impossible to obtain a $4,000 loan, she said. Thanks to two women who lent her $2,000 after reading about her plight in a local paper, Ms. Baldwin opened her business May 1. She decorates baskets, fills them with gourmet goods and then sells them for $20 to $95 from a pushcart in a local mall. She expects to make $15,000 in the next six months and pay back the loan.
 
Loan Funds Set Up
Since obtaining credit is such a big problem, some states incorporate a revolving-loan fund into the programs; Pennsylvania, for example, put aside $100,000. ''We look at it more as an economic development program than a human-resources initiative, but it's both,'' said Raymond Christman, secretary of the State Department of Commerce, which coordinated the project.
The 15-month Pennsylvania program, which cost state and Federal governments a total of $950,000, involved training centers in Philadelphia, Pittsburgh and Scranton. At last count, 189 people had enrolled, 135 had completed training and 61 had started businesses. Two people decided to attend college, and 32 others found permanent employment while working on their business proposals.
''Every business is risky,'' said Cheri Huber, business program coordinator at the Institute for Social and Economic Development, a nonprofit organization that runs a state-sponsored training program in Cedar Rapids, Iowa.
Sara Beth Long is one of Iowa's success stories. In the summer of 1988, she applied for welfare after her husband lost his job selling insurance and after they had lost their new home in Cedar Rapids. The 34-year-old mother of three children knew there was a market for placing nannies with East Coast families, and the training program helped her develop a business plan that priced services, planned advertising and projected sales. With a $5,000 bank loan she started Nannies of Iowa and grossed $60,000 her first year.
''It's really a big load to try to start a business when you're dead broke and have a lot of personal problems,'' Mrs. Long said. ''My faith is a lot stronger than it used to be.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Zoraida Feliciano, a former welfare recipient, now operates Ida's Place, a party-supply shop she opened in South Philadelphia (Bill Cramer for The New York Times); Sara Beth Long, who once applied for welfare, started Nannies of Iowa in 1988 with a $5,000 bank loan. The company, which places nannies with East Coast families, grossed $60,000 in its first year. (Paul Jensen for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN WASHINGTON;
U.S. Lawmakers Tie Soviet Trade Pact to Kremlin Progress on Lithuania

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 2

 BODY:
Members of Congress warned today that Congressional approval of an agreement expanding American trade with the Soviet Union would hinge on President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's willingness to end Moscow's economic crackdown on Lithuania.
The trade agreement, which paves the way for granting the Soviet Union preferential trade terms, was one of the accords signed on Friday by President Bush and Mr. Gorbachev. The agreement is an important symbolic victory for the Soviet leader, who faces mounting political and economic problems at home.
''He desperately wants that trade legislation, and whether or not Congress responds is up to him,'' said Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader. 
Mr. Bush has already told Mr. Gorbachev that the trade legislation would not be submitted to Congress until the Soviet Government wrote into law new polices to ease emigration. American lawmakers who met with Mr. Gorbachev here on Friday said they expected that move to be compeleted quickly.
 
No Agreement on Capitol Hill
The real difficulty is Lithuania, and there is no agreement on Capitol Hill about precisely what steps Mr. Gorbachev would have to take to satisfy enough members of Congress to obtain approval of the trade pact.
''I think it has to be the beginning of some kind of negotiation on Lithuania, but there is really no way to define it,'' said Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House Democratic leader. ''We're going to know it when we see it.''
Mr. Gorbachev has demanded that the Lithuanians follow a new Soviet law on secession that requires approval in a referendum by two-thirds of the people, a transition period and approval of the Congress of People's Deputies. Leaders of the three Baltic republics say that they were illegally annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940, and that they do not have to follow Soviet laws. The United States has never formally recognized the Baltic republics' incorporation into the Soviet Union, but it has also not formally recognized them as independent.
The most difficult obstacle may be the Senate, where members approved a resolution last month saying the Administration should not submit the trade legislation to Congress until Moscow lifts its partial economic embargo on Lithuania and resumes negotiations on Lithuanian independence.
 
Some Signal of Change Sought
Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat whose Finance Committee has jursidiction over trade matters, said that while the Senate resolution on Lithuania was not binding, the 73 senators who voted for it would need some signal by Moscow that policy had changed to justify backing away from it. Mr. Bentsen said he made that clear to both the Administration and Mr. Gorbachev on Friday.
''I told Mr. Gorbachev that I would hold hearings on the most-favored-nation status as soon as the legislation is submitted,'' Mr. Bentsen said. ''But a lot of my colleagues have taken a position on the Lithuania resolution, and I also told him that something has to be done on his side to justify a change in that position.''
In comments to reporters on Friday, Mr. Dole suggested that senators would need ''ironclad assurances'' from Mr. Gorbachev that he would enter negotiations on independence with Lithuania.
But Senator Rudy Boschwitz, Republican of Minnesota, had other criteria. He said that in his view the preferential trade terms were not ''going to be granted as long as they give aid to Cuba and Ethiopia and Cambodia.''
''I think that's a very compelling part of the equation,'' he said.
Leading American business groups, including the United States Chamber of Commerce and the National Association of Manufacturers have been lobbying for approval of the agreement, warning that without it, American companies would be at a disadvantage in trying to gain access to the Soviet market. Conversely, lawmakers noted, it would be months, and perhaps years before the Soviet Union is really able to take much advantage of the reduced trade duties conferred under the pact, given the state of its economy and the poor quality of the goods it produces.
Once Mr. Bush submits the trade legislation to Congress, it is to be considered under special, expedited procedures that limit the amount of time for debate and prohibit amendments.
The signing of the trade accord to some extent overshadowed the long-awaited agreement on cutting long-range nuclear arms as well as a treaty banning production of chemical weapons. Lawmakers expressed satisfaction at the overall results, calling the menu of accords the most substantial to have been approved in many years.
The strategic arms agreement has come under fire from liberals and conservatives, with liberals arguing that it does not sufficiently cut superpower arsenals and conservatives arguing that it gives advantages on the Soviet Union by permitting Moscow to modernize some of its most powerful and accurate long-range weapons.
Senator Joseph Biden, a Delaware Democrat and senior member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, has said that despite these criticisms the treaty will well serve American interests and should be promptly completed.
Mr. Biden made clear last week that even though the agreement does not address defensive weapons systems like the United States ''Star Wars'' program, he intends to raise the issue when the treaty comes before the Senate. The senator is considering a treaty amendment to insure that American and Soviet defensive weapons programs are strictly limited during the term of the missile treaty.

HEADLINE: Summit in Washington;
Meanwhile, Back in Moscow, the News Is Bad

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: MOSCOW, June 2

 BODY:
Domestic issues ranging from economic reform to political opposition have shaped Soviet press coverage of the Bush-Gorbachev summit meeting in Washington.
Only with the signing of arms and trade agreements has Soviet press coverage shifted from the long shadows cast by the turmoil over planned price increases and the election of Mr. Gorbachev's rival, Boris N. Yeltsin, as President of the Russian republic. 
Leading newspapers devoted large portions of their front pages today to the meeting, with most featuring photographs of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, relaxed and smiling, with President Bush.
Central television broadcast long scenes of the ceremonies and tours surrounding the summit meeting. But the main television news on Friday evening also gave ample time to domestic stories and other foreign items, in contrast to past practice of showing nothing but the leader's summit trip.
But many front pages were still focused on domestic crises: the economy, the Russian Parliament and scenes from Armenia, where 24 people were killed this week in clashes between militants and Soviet troops.
The Communist Party daily Pravda, echoing the Lithuanian theme, quoted an American expert on Soviet-American relations as saying that the question of Lithuania, which is seeking independence from the Soviet Union, was an ''uninvited guest'' at the summit talks. It also focused heavily on arms controls agreements signed by the two leaders.
Unlike the central press, Soviet television has given prominent coverage to Raisa M. Gorbachev's activities, including a stop at the Library of Congress.
Earlier in the week, Soviet television dwelled at length on Mr. Gorbachev's remarks in Canada, where he criticized Mr. Yeltsin after his election.
Mr. Gorbachev suggested that Mr. Yeltsin, with whom he broke in 1987 over Mr. Yeltsin's criticisms of the pace of reform, was playing ''political games.''

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN WASHINGTON: The Gorbachev's Will Get a Close Look at the America Beyond Washington;
San Franciscans to Give a Big Party

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, June 2

 BODY:
The T-shirt sellers are out in force, the gossip columnists are wondering why this C.E.O. was invited to meet Mikhail S. Gorbachev and that one wasn't, and the merchants at Fisherman's Wharf are hyperventilating about the boost to a sagging tourist industry.
Everyone here knows - or so it seems - that the Soviet President requested lamb at Monday's Chamber of Commerce luncheon, that a K.G.B. agent had his car towed from the financial district the other day, and that Raisa Gorbachev's sightseeing tour will skirt the homeless encampment near City Hall.
In the affluent Pacific Heights neighborhood where the Gorbachevs will stay, folks like the Gettys and the Zellerbachs are peeking from behind brocade draperies at a forest of antennas going up on the roof of the Soviet Consul General's brick mansion. And 40 miles to the south, at Stanford University in Palo Alto, students who did not get tickets to the Gorbachev events in a random drawing are scanning lists of those who did to see who might sell. 
 
Enthusiasm Without Limits
Washington may have grown blase about the Gorbachevs, but the San Francisco Bay Area is breathless about the Soviet visit on Monday, with these and other spellbinding questions consuming the locals in recent days:
* Why did Mr. Gorbachev ask to visit the Hoover Institution of War, Peace and Revolution, only to jilt the conservative research institute?
* Will Marin County commuters survive rush hour while the Gorbachevs are admiring the view from the Golden Gate Bridge?
* And who on earth decided to give the Soviet leader and his wife an oil painting of kissing dolphins done by an artist who uses recyclable diapers instead of a brush?
While there is much of substance on Mr. Gorbachev's itinerary here - a breakfast talk with Ronald Reagan, a speech at Stanford, a question-and-answer session with 200 West Coast business executives, a meeting with President Roh Tae Woo of South Korea - it's the frothier parts of the visit that have gotten the most attention - the circus and not the bread.
''A matter of priorities,'' said Andrei Sidorin, the San Francisco bureau chief for Tass, the official Soviet press agency, who says he finds the American attitudes a bit unseemly, given the political and economic upheaval going on in his country.
 
A Special Sensibility
San Francisco's chief of protocol, Charlotte Mailliard Swig, said ''feeling badly'' about the hardships in the Soviet Union need not stop the city from throwing a great party. ''People in San Francisco sort of have champagne in their veins,'' she said.
For the planners of this visit, Mrs. Swig among them, these are hectic days, unmatched since Queen Elizabeth II came calling in 1983 and Pope John Paul II passed through in 1987.
Vain about their beautiful city and piqued that it has lately taken a back seat to Los Angeles, local officials see this as a chance to put their best foot forward. And concerned about tourist trade that has yet to rebound from the October earthquake, they are grateful that San Francisco will be back on national television, this time without raging fires or collapsed freeways.
And so Mrs. Swig has been fussing with every detail. Lamb was an easy choice for lunch, once she heard of Mr. Gorbachev's preference. Then she deferred to a Soviet request that the rack be carved into chops. The chef at the Fairmont Hotel strugged all week to get the colors right on marzipan Soviet flags. The project was abandoned when the hues were less than faithful. Meanwhile, the roses for the centerpieces were cut last Wednesday, lest they be bruised by rain.
At the chamber's office downtown, all the while receptionists were being wooed with flowers and poetry by those left off the guest list, which includes executives from the Bank of America, Hewlett-Packard, Chevron, Apple Computer and more than 150 other West Coast enterprises. The companies were selected to further trade with the Soviet Far East.
 
Only the Truly Useful
Harry Orbelian, a native of Armenia and the chamber official who organized the lunch, said he dismissed people who wanted a glimpse of Mr. Gorbachev but had nothing to offer for the restructuring of the Soviet economy. ''This is a serious business lunch,'' he said. ''The people who wanted to bring their wives couldn't do it.''
There was a similar frenzy for tickets at Stanford, where 7,100 students, faculty and staff members were selected to see Mr. Gorbachev at three locations: the main quad, where he will be greeted; the promenade at the Graduate School of Business, where he will meet a few students and teachers, and Memorial Auditorium, where he will give what the Soviet Embassy has billed as a major address.
''The real prize is a ticket to hear him speak,'' said Kurt Johanknecht, a graduate student in electrical engineering, who was not among the 27 columns of lucky winners of the random drawing printed in The Stanford Daily.
Also on the agenda at Stanford is the presentation of two paintings to the Soviet leader, both said to have been selected by consular officials. One, by Cynthia Schuman and called ''Creation of Peace,'' is an abstract enamel on wood. The other, ''The Peacemakers'' by George Sumner, depicts a pair of dolphins nuzzling in outer space.
 
The Ethereal View
''I think of this as a personal hug on behalf of anybody that feels like me,'' said Mr. Sumner, who has a gallery in Sausalito.
In art circles here, there is great lamentation that the Gorbachevs are not being sent home with something a little classier, a Richard Diebenkorn, perhaps, or a Wayne Thiebaud. And at the Stanford Art Gallery, the paintings were hustled into storage last week by staff members who averted their eyes.
''I'm cringing with embarrassment,'' said John M. Wagner, the editor of The Stanford Daily, who, by the way, has slept only a few hours this week but is having the time of his life.

LENGTH: 1044 words

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN WASHINGTON;
Three Decades Ago, Another Visitor

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 2

 BODY:
Much has changed since Nikita S. Khrushchev barnstormed the country three decades ago, meeting American labor leaders in San Francisco, visiting an Iowa corn farm and touring a machine tool plant in Pittsburgh.
When President Mikhail S. Gorbachev sets off Sunday on a trip that will take him to Minneapolis and San Francisco, he is not likely to boast, as Khrushchev did, that Communism is better than capitalism. But some things will be the same.
Mr. Gorbachev, like Khrushchev, will probably be received with a mixture of friendliness and occasional animosity. ''We Butcher Hogs, Not People,'' said a sign greeting Khrushchev in Des Moines in 1959. At several stops, he was booed by refugees from the Hungarian revolution, which was suppressed by Soviet troops and tanks in 1956. 
Mr. Gorbachev, like his predecessor, will probably break away from security guards and reach out to crowds with spontaneous gestures. Like Khrushchev, who visited an I.B.M. factory in San Jose, Calif., Mr. Gorbachev seeks access to American computer technology and desperately wants to increase trade with the United States.
 
A Different Time
But the United States and the Soviet Union stand in different places today than they did when Khrushchev toured the United States in September 1959. Then, the economic and agricultural superiority of the United States was open to debate. Khrushchev and some of his listeners suggested that the United States and the Soviet Union might compete as equals.
Today the sense of rivalry and competition has faded with the collapse of Communism in Eastern Europe and the deterioration of the Soviet economy.
William Taubman, a professor of political science at Amherst College who is writing a biography of Khrushchev, said this week, ''The 1959 visit was for Khrushchev a turning point politically and personally.'' It was, he said, the first visit by a Soviet leader to the United States and the first bilateral summit meeting, after several conferences of the four World War II Allies.
''Being invited to the United States, being wined and dined by Eisenhower and by American businessmen represented acceptance for Khrushchev and his country,'' Mr. Taubman said. ''He took the invitation as recognition of the full political equality of the Soviet Union. He displayed a touchy pride and would fly off the handle at perceived insults. Khrushchev's trip had an edge that this one by Gorbachev doesn't have.''
 
Soviets Were Ahead in Space
A Soviet rocket hit the moon one day before Khrushchev arrived in the United States. It was the first space vehicle to reach the moon from Earth, and it provided tangible evidence, as American officials later said, that the Soviets were far ahead of the United States in space exploration.
''We each believe our system to be better,'' Khrushchev declared in California, and he challenged Iowa to compete in corn production with a fertile region of the Soviet Union.
''Live as you like under capitalism,'' Khrushchev told a collection of Hollywood stars and film studio executives, who organized a display of can-can dancers for his edification. ''But we will live under socialism.''
Indeed, he said, ''we have no doubt that the Soviet Union will be able to stand on its own in this economic competition and will, in time, overtake you.''
In San Francisco, Khrushchev met seven American labor leaders and debated philosophical questions for more than three hours. Walter P. Reuther, then president of the United Auto Workers, reported that their positions were irreconcilable. Khrushchev denounced the union leaders as ''capitalist lackeys.'' Mr. Reuther reported that Khrushchev ''defended their system and we defended ours.''
 
He Preferred Businessmen
Khrushchev said he got along better with American businessmen than with American trade union leaders. ''You have charmed me,'' he said in San Francisco. ''But you have charmed my heart, not my mind. I still think that our system is a good system.''
He was ready for disagreements over economic philosophy. What most annoyed him was that he could not visit Disneyland. Security officials said they could not guarantee his safety. His temper tantrum over that disappointment threw a cloud over the first days of his tour. At one point, after exchanging sharp words with the Mayor of Los Angeles, Khrushchev threatened to return home.
The tension became so conspicuous that the White House urged Americans to be more courteous to Khrushchev. He received a warm welcome in San Francisco and in Iowa, where he had his first hot dog and inspected the cornfields of Roswell Garst, a hybrid corn breeder who had done business with the Soviets. Khrushchev ate fried chicken and barbecued ribs while talking with Adlai E. Stevenson, the two-time Presidential candidate, about arms control and trade.
Khrushchev patted the stomach of a 240-pound Iowa farmer, whom he called ''a good advertisement for America.'' And he singled out two big, healthy-looking blond women, saying, ''I want to meet these slaves of capitalism.''
In Pittsburgh, he basked in the warmest reception of his American tour and, as a token of gratitude, gave his wristwatch to a factory worker.
 
Khrushchev Was Impressed
At the end of the trip, Khrushchev's escort, Henry Cabot Lodge, said the Soviet leader was deeply impressed with ''our roads, our automobiles, our factories'' and ''the vitality of our people.'' Khrushchev himself said: ''I have come here to see how the slaves of capitalism are living. I see that the way they live is not bad at all.''
By contrast, the trip to the United States in 1973 by Leonid I. Brezhnev was bland. The Soviet leader visited President Nixon at San Clemente for two and a half days. In Orange County, Calif., a stronghold of anti-Communism, Mr. Brezhnev supped with conservatives like Ronald Reagan, who was then Governor.
On that visit, which came just as the Watergate scandal broke wide open, Mr. Brezhnev stayed in Mr. Nixon's Spanish-style house overlooking the Pacific. They saw movie stars, business magnates and millionaire contributors to the Republican Party.
Mr. Brezhnev seemed so at ease among the American celebrities that Red Skelton, the comedian, asked him if he was a card-carrying Communist.
