HEADLINE: Centralized Immigration Control Urged

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 2

 BODY:
Over objections from the Bush Administration, a Federal advisory committee will recommend creation of an independent Government agency to formulate immigration policy and to enforce laws now administered separately by three Cabinet departments.
In a report to be submitted to President Bush and Congress in July, the panel will also recommend a new strategy to curtail illegal immigration: using foreign aid to promote economic growth in those areas of Mexico, Central America and the Caribbean that have sent the most migrants to the United States.
''Greater economic opportunity at home will reduce the pressure to emigrate,'' said the report, which calls for a free-trade agreement between the United States and Mexico, like the one signed in 1988 by the United States and Canada. ''Only sustained economic growth will reduce emigration over the long term.'' 
 
A Major Shift in Thinking
The report signals a major shift in thinking, to the view long advocated by Hispanic groups in the United States. The 12-member panel is headed by Diego C. Asencio, a former Ambassador to Brazil and Colombia, who served as Assistant Secretary of State for Consular Affairs from 1980 to 1983.
The advisory panel, the Commission for the Study of International Migration and Cooperative Economic Development, was established by Congress under the Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986. The members were appointed by Democratic and Republican leaders of the Senate and the House of Representatives.
Their recommendations are based on public hearings in the United States, consultations with the presidents of seven Latin American countries and research done for the commission by more than 70 scholars.
The panel said there was a stark choice for many Latin American countries: ''They either export goods and services to create jobs at home, or they export people,'' many of whom come to the United States illegally.
Under the 1986 immigration law, employers in this country can be punished for hiring illegal aliens. But the report says such employer sanctions must be supplemented with economic incentives to keep would-be emigres from leaving their home countries.
 
Enforcement 'Less Necessary'
''Enforcement measures should become less necessary over time as economic development succeeds'' in Latin America, the report said.
The bipartisan panel said immigration must be given much higher priority in decisions about foreign policy and trade policy. For this reason, the panel proposes creation of an independent Agency for Migration Affairs, to consolidate responsibilities now divided among the Departments of Justice, State and Labor. The new agency would not be under the control of a Cabinet department and would be able to set policy independently of the President.
The panel said, ''The development and administration of immigration policy is far too important to be relegated to a stepchild agency such as the Immigration and Naturalization Service, which falls uncomfortably within the Department of Justice and which historically has been beset with serious management and resource problems.''
 
Opposition From White House
Officials at the White House, the State Department and the Justice Department said they opposed creation of an independent agency. They said such an agency would undermine the President's ability to control immigration policy.
Under the panel's proposal, the Border Patrol would remain in the Justice Department. The new agency would take over most I.N.S. activities, including reviewing petitions for citizenship, asylum and other benefits under the immigration law. The new agency would also take over two tasks performed by the State Department: the admission of refugees and the issuance of visas to million of visitors and immigrants.
The panel said immigration policy had historically been neglected by the White House and the State Department. ''The Secretary of State does not spend his waking hours concerned about immigration policy,'' said Mr. Asencio.
Nine of the 12 panel members met this week with Ivan Selin, the Under Secretary of State for Management, who supervises the State Department's work on immigration and refugee issues.
 
State Department Objects
Mr. Asencio said State Department officials did not like the recommendation for an independent immigration agency and did not agree that immigration would get more attention if responsibilities were centralized. Moreover, he said, Mr. Selin asserted that the commission had ''exceeded its mandate.''
An aide to Mr. Selin said the Under Secretary did not want to discuss his concerns publicly.
In an interview, Mr. Asencio said, ''The real reason State Department officials dislike our proposal is that it would eliminate a substantial part of their budget and many entry-level jobs in the department.''
Duke Austin, a spokesman for the immigration service, said officials there had no immediate comment.
In its report, the panel said some United States trade policies had the unintended effect of encouraging illegal immigration. For example, it said, United States quotas on imports of textiles, clothing, steel, sugar, coffee and other products retard economic growth in Latin America, and as a result many Latin Americans come here to get jobs they cannot find at home.
 
More Foreign Trade Urged
''Expanded trade between the sending countries and the United States is the single most effective remedy to the problem'' of illegal immigration, the panel concluded.
The panel also said the Federal Government and private banks should help emigres send money home and channel money into ''productive small business investments.'' Such investments could generate jobs, raise incomes and reduce the pressure for people to migrate to the United States, the panel said.
Besides Mr. Asencio, these are the panel members:
Donna M. Alvarado, former director of Action, the Federal volunteer agency.
Toney Anaya, a former Governor of New Mexico.
Eric H. Biddle Jr., a Virginia lawyer.
Representative John Bryant, Democrat of Texas.
Garner J. Cline, former staff director of the House Judiciary Committee.
Dale S. de Haan, former United Nations Deputy High Commissioner for Refugees.
The Rev. Theodore E. McCarrick, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Newark.
Edward C. Rivera, a California businessman Michael S. Teitelbaum, a demographer Art Torres, a California State Senator Esther Lee Yao, an educational psychologist at the University of Houston.

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1, Page 22, Column 4; National Desk

HEADLINE: To Farmers, Saving Rails Means Saving Livelihood

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TEKOA, Wash., May 31

 BODY:
The last operating railroad in this community of lentil farmers passes a sign that advertises a special on horse-wormers for $9.95, and drops under a crumbling overpass with the faded expression, ''Mad-dog loves Tracy.''
But it is more than romance and small commerce that ties this eastern Washington farm country here in Whitman County to its train tracks. Without the railroad, the farmers here, who grow 98 percent of the nation's lentils, say there is no profitable way to get their product to market - and ultimately, to Ethiopia and Somalia as part of the Government's Food for Peace program.
That relationship makes the railroad track dear to farmers in farm hamlets in the green hills south of Spokane, and they are fighting the Union Pacific Railroad's plan to abandon 71 miles of it. Since 1980, when the railroads were deregulated, more than 30,000 miles of track has been abandoned nationwide. Now Federal agriculture officials, alarmed at how the loss of trains is hurting farm communities, have joined the lentil growers in taking a stand. 
 
Where's the 'Public Service?'
''The railroads used to be viewed as a utility, but now that they can operate as any other free enterprise they are taking full advantage of deregulation,'' said Paul Kepler, a top official with the Agriculture Department. ''Somewhere along the line, they need to take more of a public service attitude.''
Last year, Union Pacific, the nation's second-biggest railroad after Burlington Northern, made a $547 million profit on revenue of $4.6 billion. But the company says its branch lines, the small feeder tracks to distant farm communities, continue to lose money.
''They say the loss of the railroad is another nail in the coffin of rural America, and there's no question those communities are changing,'' said John Bromley, a spokesman for Union Pacific, which is based in Omaha. ''But we don't have to subsidize those lines. Our business strategy is that if the line isn't making a profit, we abandon, sell or lease it out.''
At the urging of Representative Thomas S. Foley, the Speaker of the House, whose district includes this county, the Interstate Commerce Commission held a hearing last week on the abandonment plan. By law, the railroads can leave a community only if they can prove the operation is unprofitable. Other concerns, like whether there is alternative transportation for farmers, can also be considered.
 
Some Ignore Regulation
At the hearing, doubts were raised by farmers and shippers about whether the line to the lentil growers was in fact losing money; their analysis showed the line actually made a small profit. A decision by Paul J. Clerman, the administrative law judge in the case, is expected by the end of June.
While the railroad needs the Commerce Commission's approval to shut down the line legally, some train operators have merely abandoned lines without being penalized by the Government, Federal officials say.
For the farmers in this area who grow peas and lentils and haul the food to train terminals in towns like Fairfield, Tekoa and Farmington, the train cars that arrive about three times a week are their main link to distant markets.
Restrictions on pock-marked and outdated county roads keep trucks from hauling the food to bigger rail depots in Spokane at certain times of the year. Even when they can use the roads, farmers say, it costs them about $830 more to ship a rail-car load by truck.
If Union Pacific pulls out ''it will be devastating to us,'' said Dan Bruce, a shipper in Farmington whose family grows lentils. ''We're just a little town - 150 people - and we've only got one option. With the higher transportation costs, we would lose 94 percent of our business, which is shipping lentils overseas.''
 
Year-Round Shipping
Farmington, on the Washington-Idaho border, is where lentil-growing was pioneered in this country. Although Americans have yet to take to the high-fiber bean, it is a staple in many African countries and parts of South America as well.
Lentils are harvested in August, then dried, stored and shipped year-round. The farmers say that without the Union Pacific, 4.5 million pounds of lentils would not reach the ports in the Gulf of Mexico from which they are shipped abroad.
In surrounding counties, wheat is a thriving crop that is shipped to different ports, mainly by barge, than are the lentils. If the train line is abandoned, the smaller farmers, who have been growing lentils for three generations, could theoretically switch crops, but they say it would take years to recoup the investment in equipment and irrigation systems needed to make the shift.
Mr. Bruce said the railroad could make a profit on the run to the lentil-growing country if the railroad tried to develop more business in the area. But Union Pacific officials say they have looked at the numbers and cannot make the line profitable.
 
No Buyers, Line Says
If the Government allows the abandonment, the railroad plans to rip out the tracks and sell the ties and iron for scrap. They have offered to sell the line, but no buyers with sufficient capital have come forward.
Many people here say the railroads owe something to the communities here, which they helped build up. Tekoa, a town of 650 people, used to have a population of nearly 3,000, and three rail lines came through town. Its broad-shouldered stone buildings on Main Street are a testimony to another, more prosperous era.
''All the towns are struggling to stay afloat, to keep what business they have,'' said Gary Heaton of Tekoa, a food processor and shipper. ''You start losing just one or two families who have to move because the railroad left town, and you're in trouble.''
Federal officials say economic diversification in many of the dying small towns is dependent on keeping at least one rail line in the area. That may be true, Union Pacific says, but the railroad should not have to carry the load of those towns.
''Our obligation is to our stockholders,'' said Mr. Bromley. ''We don't enjoy going into a community and wearing a black hat. But we're used to it.''

HEADLINE: E.P.A. Drops Waste Case in North Carolina

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: RALEIGH, N.C., June 2

 BODY:
In a case watched closely by environmentalists and waste treatment companies, the Federal Environmental Protection Agency has abandoned an earlier effort to revoke North Carolina's authority to regulate hazardous waste.
This turn in the longstanding dispute came Friday in a ruling by Daniel W. McGovern, the agency's regional administrator in San Francisco. It was immediately hailed by environmentalists as having nationwide implications for a state's right to adopt environmental laws more stringent than Federal standards. It could also scuttle the project that was immediately at issue: the plans by the Laidlaw Environmental Services Company, formerly the GSX Chemical Services Company, to build a vast plant near the town of Laurinburg, 100 miles south of Raleigh, to treat hazardous waste from the entire region. 
The dispute centered on GSX's argument that a law enacted by North Carolina in 1987 effectively prevented hazardous-waste treatment plants from operating in the state. In essence, the law required such plants to dilute each gallon of treated wastewater with at least 1,000 gallons of pure water before discharge into rivers and streams. That requirement would be particularly difficult to meet at the Laurinburg site, partly because of the enormous amount of waste to be treated there and partly because the stream that would supply the diluting water frequently runs too low to do so. After the law had been passed, GSX contended that it was arbitrary and was primarily aimed at preventing the company from building its Laurinburg plant. Appeal to E.P.A. GSX and the Hazardous Waste Treatment Council, an industry group, then asked the Environmental Protection Agency to revoke the state's authority to manage hazardous wastes. Among their arguments was that if the law was upheld, other states would be encouraged to devise their own programs to keep such treatment plants, often politically unpopular, outside their borders.
State and local officials responded by saying that the law was intended only to protect drinking water. The GSX plant would discharge as much as 500,000 gallons of treated waste daily into the Lumber River, the main water supply for much of Robeson County, near Laurinburg.
E.P.A. officials initially sided with GSX, saying that the states should not be allowed to impose regulations effectively barring unpopular but environmentally necessary plants. But when William K. Reilly took office as the agency's Administrator last year, he decided on a full airing of the issue.
After a series of hearings last year, an administrative law judge backed North Carolina. The final such decision is usually made by the Administrator himself, but environmental groups complained that Mr. Reilly had engaged in improper contacts with officials of the waste treatment industry at a breakfast meeting. In the meantime, the agency's Southeastern regional administrator had also been criticized as partial to the industry, and so the decision was delegated to Mr. McGovern, the regional administrator in San Francisco.
In his decision Friday, he said that although a plant of the Laurinburg facility's planned scale might be unfeasible at that site because of the law, the measure would not keep such a plant from being built elsewhere. In addition, he said, GSX could have decided to build a smaller plant at Laurinburg.
''Therefore,'' the decision said, ''the law cannot be said to act as a prohibition on the treatment, storage or disposal of hazardous waste.''
The company, based in Columbia, S.C., said it had not decided whether to appeal to the courts. Roger E. Davis, a spokesman, said that the judgment did not rule out a plant at Laurinburg but that it would force the company to build a much smaller version that might not be economically feasible.
''If we can't get permits to build these facilities, there is insufficient and inadequate treatment of the waste,'' he said. ''Since we're not going to shut off the production of hazardous waste totally, the environment is going to suffer.''

HEADLINE: Florio's School Plan Angers Bergen

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ENGLEWOOD, N.J., June 1

 BODY:
Gov. Jim Florio's proposed law redistributing state school aid to local districts, and slashing $97 million from Bergen County's aid by the mid-1990's, has left Bergen's superintendents incredulous, indignant and gloomy.
While the Governor's proclaimed intent is to equalize education spending statewide by shifting tens of millions from prosperous suburbs to poorer urban and rural districts, suburban Bergen's losses would be the deepest in the state. Seventy-one of its 78 school districts would lose money.
The losing districts cut across all Bergen's social and economic lines, from its richest northern suburbs to the largely black and Hispanic middle-class districts here and in neighboring Hackensack and Teaneck, to the working-class towns in the shadow of the Meadowlands Sports Complex in southern Bergen. 
From all, the superintendents' outcry is the same - that an autocratic and devastating plan has emerged from the Governor's staff. And that his aides have not directly given local school officials - or the Bergen County Superintendent of Schools, who is the state's usual conduit of official information - any of the plan's figures or asked their opinions. They complain that the policy will leave districts facing severe program cuts or seeking sharply higher property taxes from homeowners already in revolt about school taxes.
 
'Dire Fiscal Constraints'
Here and elsewhere across Bergen, resentment and anxiety in school offices run deep. Englewood's schools, which have an enrollment that is 62 percent black and 23 percent Hispanic, stand to lose $3.6 million of their current state aid of $5.9 million, or roughly 15 percent of the current budget of $24 million, between fall 1992 and mid-1996.
''There's no educationally sound and sensible way for a community of this type to handle that size cut without decimating our public schools,'' said Englewood's Superintendent, Larry Leverett. ''We've never faced such dire fiscal constraints.''
He was echoed by Vincent Doyle, school business administrator in Teaneck, which would lose $5.7 million of its $9.4 million in state money. ''The Governor's proposing the most radical restructuring of education ever in New Jersey and he wants the Legislature to blow it through by June 15. It's absolutely ridiculous; it's absolutely nuts.''
Alan Sugarman, Superintendent in Fort Lee, a district of wealthy high-rise apartment buildings and modest homes next to the George Washington Bridge, said, ''We find the whole concept is absolutely impossible.'' Fort Lee stands to lose about $3.4 million of $4.5 million in aid, or about 15 percent of its current budget of $23 million.
''It's almost a kinetic effort by Trenton - like a dictum from on high -rather than a carefully analyzed, carefully discussed, prudent effort,'' Dr. Sugarman said. ''I just cannot, cannot, cannot believe this will fly.''
The seven Democrats in Bergen's 15-member legislative delegation have broken ranks with Mr. Florio over the depth of the county's cuts and are seeking amendments to restore funds. Democratic caucuses on changing the cuts started Friday in Trenton and are expected to continue until Monday.
''No Bergen County legislator can vote for this plan,'' said Senator Gabriel M. Ambrosio, a Democrat of Lyndhurst, whose blue-collar district near the Meadowlands faces an aid cut of $8.7 million. ''There will absolutely and positively be changes that will lessen the impact on Bergen County and restore all or most of the lost aid.'' Bergen's two other Democratic Senators, Matthew Feldman of Teaneck, the powerful head of the Senate Education Committee, and Paul J. Contillo of Paramus, are also involved in the struggle for changes in the Governor's bill. Their districts would lose $19 million and $22.1 million in school aid, respectively.
 
Poorer Districts to Benefit
Because the proposed cuts, which were announced May 24, are so new and so deep, Bergen school officials say they have not started planning how to absorb them. They talk about impact only in the broadest and most drastic terms.
''We're looking at having to come up with $6 million over four years,'' Dr. Doyle, Teaneck's business administrator, said. ''To make that kind of cut without putting it on the backs of taxpayers, we're looking at cutting a quarter of our staff of 550. We wouldn't be able to afford busing for integration or raises for teachers.''
The $97 million in aid that Bergen stands to lose over 4 years is about 35 percent of the total $277 million state-aid cutback facing 222 of the wealthiest school districts in New Jersey's 21 counties. Under the Governor's plan, state aid in 1991-92, the plan's first year, will be frozen at the level of the 1990-91 school year for all 222 districts. The plan also calls for the wealthiest 151 of the 222 districts to pay all pension and Social Security costs of their staff starting in 1991-92. This expense, now fully paid by the state, will drain money from local school programs or require higher property taxes.
In mid-1996, under the plan, all state aid for the 222 districts will end, except for money for transportation and special education programs.
The beneficiaries of Mr. Florio's plan will be 356 districts, mostly poor inner-city systems in North Jersey or sprawling rural ones in South Jersey. Starting in 1991-92, they will share $970 million in new state education aid, to come from the Governor's proposed income tax increase.
Nearly 42 percent of it, or about $402 million, will go to the state's 20 poorest cities. Camden's schools will get the most, $44.6 million, followed by Newark, $37.6 million; Paterson, where the state Education Department has taken a first step toward a state takeover of the district, $36.3 million; and Jersey City, whose schools were taken over by the state last October, $32.3 million.
 
Wealthy Face Double Impact
Which districts will get increases and which will face cutbacks is determined by two criteria - property values per pupil and per capita income per pupil. Districts below the state averages in those categories would benefit; those above the averages would lose.
Residents of the wealthiest districts facing aid cutbacks would bear the brunt of the proposed income tax increase. That means they face a double financial burden under the Governor's plan - potentially higher property taxes to offset losses in their state aid and higher income taxes to finance increases for poorer districts.
Critics of the plan's reliance on property values and per-capita income say it would leave northern counties like Bergen at a disadvantage because its property values and personal incomes have always exceeded South Jersey's. They say South Jersey districts, where teachers' salaries and other educational costs lag behind those in Bergen and other northern counties, will enjoy a windfall under the Governor's plan.
For instance, nearly $310 million of the $970 million in new state aid is earmarked for five adjacent southern counties: Camden, Burlington, Cumberland, Gloucester, and Salem.
About $6 million of the new aid will go to seven districts in Bergen County: Garfield, Bergenfield, Fairview, Bogota, Dumont, Waldwick and Midland Park.

HEADLINE: CAMPUS LIFE: Southern Methodist;
Admissions Rule For Top Athletes Stirs Old Fears

DATELINE: DALLAS

 BODY:
Southern Methodist University's admissions procedures for athletes were tightened after a scandal that led to the cancellation of the 1987 and 1988 football seasons. Now those procedures are loosening, and that has some faculty members worried.
The changes, announced recently by President A. Kenneth Pye, would allow athletes with substandard admissions test scores and high school grade point averages to have their cases argued by coaches directly with admissions personnel.
Last month, Mr. Pye also removed from the admissions process Cynthia Patterson, who had been hired away from Northwestern University in 1987 and named associate athletic director for compliance and academic affairs in the wake of the scandal. 
Many faculty members, students and alumni consider Ms. Patterson a staunch supporter of strict academic standards for athletes. She has been the athletic department's sole liaison with admissions officials at the university for the last three years. She will now focus on tracking athletes already attending the university to insure that they maintain their academic standing.
Mr. Pye and the newly appointed athletic director, Forrest Gregg, said in a recent news conference and in later interviews that the changes were made to speed recruiting of admissable high school athletes who might otherwise be lost to competing universities.
 
Fine Tuning, President Says
''There are no major changes coming,'' Mr. Pye said in an interview. ''We will just fine-tune the system. We are just going to be getting rid of some paperwork and have people look at the admissions office as a resource rather than a regulator.''
He added that coaches could bring to the admissions process a personal perspective on athletes who wished to attend S.M.U.
Some faculty members, however, voiced strong skepticism that the changes would result in admissions officers' getting a more balanced perspective from the coaches.
''I think that's a lot of hogwash,'' said J. Carter Murphy, a recently retired economics professor who is a former faculty senate president and a frequently vocal watchdog over the athletic department. ''When coaches have found a strong prospect, they want to insure that he gets in.''
Paying football players was only a part of the athletic department's problems in 1987, Mr. Murphy said, adding that the most important problem was that ''the university was viewed as the home of an excellent athletic team, not as an academic institution.''
 
Shakeup After 1987 Scandal
Mr. Pye tightened the admissions standards for all students in 1987, when the National Collegiate Athletic Association put the university on three years probation after disclosures that some S.M.U. football players continued receiving money from alumni, even though the athletic program was already on probation for similar violations.
The scandal led to the resignations of the university's president, athletic director and football coach. The remaining sanctions, which include greater scrutiny of athletes' finances, are to expire in September.
An applicant must now have a combined score of at least 700 on the Scholastic Aptitude Test and must have completed 11 academic units in high school with a grade point average of at least 2. Those are the same standards set by the N.C.A.A. for athletes applying to any colleges.
Now, if a high school athlete recruited by the athletic department has a combined Scholastic Aptitude Test score of less than 900, or less than 450 on the verbal portion of that exam, or if he has less than a 2.7 grade point average or is in the lower half of his graduating class, his file is flagged.
In the past, the coaches would send any flagged files to the recruiting coordinator, who would review them and pass them on to Ms. Patterson. She, in turn, would argue the case for or against admissions with a special four-member faculty admissions committee. The committee would make a recommendation to the university's admissions director.
 
Concern Over Alumni Pressure
Under the new procedures, coaches can send flagged files directly to the faculty committee and can argue an athlete's case face-to-face with the admissions director.
In an interview last week, Mr. Gregg said he did not understand why anyone found the changes worrisome.
''Number one, S.M.U.'s admission standards will not change,'' he said. ''Our number-one priority is for every athlete to graduate. A person who can't graduate won't get in.''
But Mr. Murphy said there was concern that with the new procedures ''if we are unable to field winning teams, then there will be pressure from alumni to get star athletes'' who are academically weak.

HEADLINE: Visa Rules for Performers Are Disputed

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN

 BODY:
New Federal regulations intended to reduce the number of work visas granted on the basis of ''distinguished merit or ability'' are making it more difficult for new and less well-established performers from abroad to perform in the United States, music industry spokesmen contend.
Government authorities deny this is so and say the new regulations just clarify existing policy. But the French Culture Minister, Jack Lang, has spoken out on the issue on the side of the musicians, calling the new regulations an example of ''cultural protectionism.''
Speaking at a press conference in Paris recently, Mr. Lang said: ''It's a fact that today Moscow is more accessible than Washington. We want artists to be at home wherever they go.'' He said he had protested the new regulations to the cultural attache at the United States Embassy in Paris. 
Char Eberly, an agent at Third World Agency in New York, which specializes in managing musicians from Africa, South America and the Caribbean, said she had to cancel two tours because she feared that under the new regulations the musicians ''didn't have good enough financial records to get visas.''
 
Evidence Required
The new Immigration and Naturalization Service regulations, which became effective on Feb. 25, require that performers seeking H-1 visas, the most desirable category, must demonstrate their ''distinguished merit or ability'' with evidence like ''a record of major commercial or critically acclaimed success.'' This record may include box-office receipts or record sales, reviews, advertisements, publicity releases and prizes.
Examples of performers holding H-1 visas range from Kurt Masur, the East German conductor who was recently named to lead the New York Philharmonic, to lesser-known but distinctive bands and performers like Linton Kwesi Johnson, a Jamaican-style poet from England who recently completed a United States tour. Mr. Johnson qualifies because he can document his eminence in his field and because no American can duplicate what he does.
Under previous regulations, the criteria for establishing ''distinguished merit or ability'' were vague and were therefore regarded as easier to meet.
''The new regulations are a cause for alarm for new and less-established foreign musicians because they will make it more difficult for them to get in,'' said James R. Mayock, a San Francisco lawyer who specializes in immigration law. ''But it's with them that new music is happening.''
 
Time and Trouble
For those who do not qualify for the H-1 visa, the H-2-B visa is available for all nonagricultural workers. However, the H-2-B requires certification from the Department of Labor that no American worker will be displaced by the petitioner. Certification takes at least a month and is sometimes difficult to obtain.
Steve Sprague, executive assistant to the president of the American Federation of Musicians, who is frequently consulted by the Immigration and Naturalization Service, said that he commonly submits ''negative advisory opinions'' in response to H-2-B applications in cases where ''a producer wants to import particular musicians to cities where those same kinds of musicians are unemployed.''
In such cases, Mr. Sprague said, the union also gives the Immigration and Naturalization Service a list of names of available union members who could handle the performance.
Richard L. Kenney, a public-affairs specialist for the Immigration and Naturalization Service, which is a branch of the Department of Justice, said that it would be ''more difficult than in the past'' for petitioners to meet the present specific criteria and that the agency anticipated fewer petitioners for the H-1 visa as a result.
 
Against 'Spirit of the Law'
The reason for the change in the regulations, Mr. Kenney said, is that the service found it was receiving more applications for H-1 visas than for H-2-B visas. ''It's against the spirit of the law,'' he said. ''The H-1's are supposed to be more the exception than the rule because the H-1 is for distinguished merit and ability, whereas the H-2-B covers the mainstream of temporary workers.''
Mr. Kenney also said the French Culture Minister was ''overreacting.''
Mr. Mayock said the Government does not understand that music-industry petitioners for H-1 visas will always outnumber H-2-B applicants because producers naturally want to import artists of the highest merit and ability, since they are the ones who attract audiences.
Furthermore, he said, ''They don't understand the fast-paced manner of the music business. When a group gets hot, people start to grab for them to make them available to the public. It doesn't happen with six months of advance notice.''
 
Spontaneity Is Necessary
The music business also must react quickly to news developments, Mr. Mayock said. ''All of a sudden, Nelson Mandela was released from prison,'' he said, ''and promoters wanted to do a celebration with Miriam Makeba at the Apollo Theater in Harlem. Negotiations began in January, but things didn't really come together until late March, after the new regulations took effect. She got in, but one of her backup musicians had to be replaced.''
Ms. Eberly said: ''It's a Catch-22 situation. You get visas for your clients by telling Immigration what gigs you've signed, but then you must wait to see if they're going to allow you to honor your commitments.''
Mr. Maycock said: ''The big problem is not that people on the fringe are not going to become popular and world-famous. It's that people in the music business in Europe are going to snap them up long before our people can get to them because they can't get into the United States. The Immigration Service is hurting American business.''
The Immigration and Naturalization Service is not alone in creating more stringent requirements for visas. Under the Immigration and Nationality Act, the Immigration and Naturalization Service must consult with the Department of Labor before granting an H-2-B visa.
''Our responsibility is to protect American workers,'' said Thomas Bruening, chief of the Division of Foreign Labor Certifications.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: June 3, 1990

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1, Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 2706 words

HEADLINE: STAGE VIEW;
Broadway's Bounty: Dramas Brimming With Life

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH

 BODY:
''What kind of day has it been?'' That was the question with which William Goldman closed ''The Season,'' his classic journalistic study of one season (1967-68) in the life of the Broadway theater just as it slid into its most precipitous period of decline. Two decades later no one can say whether that decline has yet halted, but the 1989-90 New York theater season, on and off Broadway, has been one unexpectedly, perhaps inexplicably, bright day. Theater art, show biz glamour and, best of all, American plays about lives that intersect with the audiences' own have been in high supply during the 12 months that will be celebrated tonight, as tradition has it, at the Tony Awards show.
For theater fans in the habit of laughing at the Tonys as a collapsing industry's campy effort to paint a happy veneer on disaster, tonight's TV broadcast may come as a culture shock. This will be the first Tony ceremony in years in which the legitimate nominees vastly overwhelm the wince-inducing turkeys needed to fill out the ballot. (And even the turkeys are slightly less scrawny, as a comparison of this year's ''Meet Me in St. Louis'' to last year's ''Starmites'' will attest.) Then again, all sorts of surprises have been happening in the theater since the last Tony night of a year ago. 
This was the season framed by the departures of the two longest-running shows in Broadway history, ''Oh! Calcutta!'' and ''A Chorus Line,'' yet the closings did not prompt a funereal sense of loss so much as confirm the passing of one chapter in that history and the arrival of the next. It was the season in which character actors with New York theater careers dating back to the 1950's returned to Broadway in triumph: Robert Morse (''Tru''), Charles Durning (''Cat on a Hot Tin Roof''), Lois Smith (''The Grapes of Wrath''). It was the season in which Tyne Daly didn't settle for cruising through in the rickety vehicle usually favored by the stars of canceled television series but instead pulled off the unlikely feat of exorcising Ethel Merman's ghost from ''Gypsy.'' It was a season in which Tennessee Williams had two hits on Broadway and Shakespeare had one, while the presumed sure things, ''Annie 2'' and Neil Simon's new play, ''Jake's Women,'' closed during their pre-Broadway tryouts. So large was the profusion of native talent this season that such English superstars as Tom Stoppard, Vanessa Redgrave and Rex Harrison could be overlooked in the Tony nominations and not really be missed.
The season's best new plays all point to an American theater whose artistic vital signs are good even as the malevolent forces of AIDS, censorship and economic calamity threaten at every turn. In contrast to most seasons of the 1980's, in which there would usually be only one serious contender for Best Play and that contender as likely as not would be a London import, there are three outstanding nominees this season, all American: ''The Grapes of Wrath'' as adapted from John Steinbeck by Frank Galati, ''Prelude to a Kiss'' by Craig Lucas and ''The Piano Lesson'' by August Wilson. The one English nominee - Peter Shaffer's boulevard comedy, ''Lettice and Lovage'' - seems merely dusty by comparison, though there is nothing mere about its riveting star, Maggie Smith.
 
The Old Boys' Network Comes Unraveled
 While the three American Best Play nominees have little in common in style, their similar origins dramatize the broad base of the American theater right now. None of the three was created by or for Broadway. The plays were booked into Broadway theaters only after they had appeared at nonprofit institutional theaters, at least three in each production's case, across the map, from South Coast Repertory, Berkeley Rep and Mark Taper Forum in California to the Steppenwolf Theater Company in Chicago to the Yale Repertory Theater and Circle Repertory Company back East. The old boys' network of New York producers that used to choose and mount new American plays has been almost completely supplanted by the national network of resident companies that carry out the old producers' role in a far more enlightened way, sometimes with the aid of at least nominal grants from the National Endowment for the Arts. The nonprofit theater Off Broadway, whether in New York or beyond, is what now keeps Broadway in business as a disseminator of new American plays.
Reflecting the fact that they were not conceived as potential Broadway cash cows, the three American Tony nominees are adventurous works more in touch with what audiences and artists care about than with what theater owners regard as merchandisable product. Like them or not, these plays do not insult an audience's intelligence. Nor are they humorless problem dramas in the earnest, hand-wringing, pseudo-documentary manner that has now been appropriated by television. They dra matize the world of the moment in the poetic, nonliteral terms of the stage.
 
'Grapes of Wrath' In Present Tense
 In ''The Grapes of Wrath,'' Mr. Galati, both as director and as writer, uses the simplest elements (his palette is literally air, water, fire, earth) to levitate Steinbeck's dust bowl from the remote historical specificity of the Depression and into an intimate present tense. The homeless cease to be a faceless abstraction that can be ignored or wished away by the audience and become instead a vivid, courageous constituency within the mainstream democratic family. As acted by a Steppenwolf ensemble full of nervy, idiosyncratic individuals and designed with a hallucinatory simplicity that is closer to Georgia O'Keeffe and Edward Hopper than the Walker Evans-like iconography of the 1939 John Ford film, ''The Grapes of Wrath'' is a transporting epic whose final destination is the society of economic extremes the audience revisits as soon as it steps back on to a mean New York street. That the evening leaves one feeling energized, not enervated, by the unfinished struggle against injustice and hunger is a tribute to the show's dramatic sweep and unsentimental populist zeal.
 
'Prelude' Teaches Lessons in Compassion
''Prelude to a Kiss,'' seemingly the most conventional of the American Best Play contenders, is a romantic adult fairy tale about an ordinary young urban man who finds that the soul of the woman he loves has become trapped in the body of a figurative frog - an elderly man racked by lung cancer. Even without knowing that Mr. Lucas is also the author of ''Longtime Companion,'' a feature film about the devastation of the gay community by AIDS, it isn't hard to see that ''Prelude'' is a response to the epidemic. The play demands of its hero a love that endures even when the body of his beloved is rotting and dying.
By enclosing that hero's journey to selflessness within a fantasy that is funny, magical and moving, rather than somber, clinical and earthbound, ''Prelude to a Kiss'' teaches a broad lesson in compassion applicable to anyone - which is to say everyone - who must face a loved one's death. Since Mr. Lucas never mentions AIDS and his characters are not in the disease's high-risk groups, ''Prelude'' doesn't even have to be read as an AIDS play. But the youth of its stricken heroine makes that extra dimension clear to those who wish to see it. Those who do so will also appreciate the beauty with which Mr. Lucas has dequarantined the tragedy of AIDS to place it squarely within the universal, and universally terminal, human condition.
 
'Piano Lesson' Sings In a Black Key
 In ''The Piano Lesson,'' Mr. Wilson continues his saga of black America in the 20th century, this time focusing on the 1930's. As acted by another extraordinary ensemble, headed by Charles S. Dutton and S. Epatha Merkerson and directed by Lloyd Richards, the play has the invigorating, and at times unruly, vitality of a voluminous folk tapestry. Song, tall genealogical tales, history, family drama, poetry, ritual and sexual passion are all part of the by turns garrulous and cathartic mix.
Mr. Wilson doesn't write according to the white man's rules, and ''The Piano Lesson'' is unlikely to be confused by anyone with ''Driving Miss Daisy.'' With its free use of the supernatural, the play intertwines African and American esthetics, just as the two continents are mixed in the blood of the characters, who must achieve freedom from both slavery's repressive social legacy and its deep psychological scars. ''The Piano Lesson,'' like most Wilson plays, demands that white audiences adjust to a voice that sings in a genuinely black key and that they meet black people as they are rather than as many whites imagine them to be.
It's an essential leap, for what is going on in the parlor and kitchen of the play's Pittsburgh, 1936, household is another, equally crucial chapter of the American saga of dispossession found in the contemporaneous ''Grapes of Wrath'' and continuing to the present day. Like Spike Lee in the movies, Mr. Wilson is introducing white audiences to black America without patronizing either whites or blacks. Whatever the flaws of ''The Piano Lesson,'' or, for that matter, of Mr. Lee's ''Do the Right Thing,'' they are essential dramas (and entertaining ones at that) for a city playing out its own drama of racial division in its neighborhoods.
 
Richness of Words And Music
 One of the more exhilarating treats of the theater season has been to see so much fine American writing in free-floating repertory. The themes of ''The Piano Lesson'' overlap those of Tennessee Williams's ''Orpheus Descending,'' which ends with a vigilante murder motivated by bigotry, much as Williams's ''Cat on a Hot Tin Roof'' addresses issues of intimacy, tolerance, familial and sexual love and mortality that complement those of ''Prelude to a Kiss.'' When one takes in the season's Tony-ineligible productions, which is to say those that confined their runs to Off Broadway, the repertory becomes richer still: ''Spunk,'' George C. Wolfe's adaptation of Zora Neale Hurston tales, and ''Sex, Drugs, Rock-and-Roll,'' Eric Bogosian's latest and most extensive tour of excess in the upper echelons and lower depths of contemporary urban America, respectively anticipate and continue the anguished vernacular storytelling of ''The Piano Lesson'' and ''The Grapes of Wrath.''
There was even an informal repertory of musicals available to the New York theatergoer this year. The revival of Stephen Sondheim's 1979 ''Sweeney Todd'' stood in fascinating counterpoint to that of ''Gypsy,'' the Arthur Laurents-Jule Styne-Sondheim masterpiece of 20 seasons earlier. As directed by Susan H. Schulman (''Sweeney'') and Mr. Laurents (''Gypsy''), these two intense productions emphasized personal drama over show biz spectacle, revealing both works as searing tales of women pushed by emotional and socioeconomic circumstance into either figuratively or literally devouring their young.
 
Awakening of The American Musical
 The big news events in the musical theater, however, were the new works that pointed to an awakening of the American musical. ''City of Angels,'' the stylish Hollywood satire written by Larry Gelbart (book), Cy Coleman (music) and David Zippel (lyrics), is a welcome throwback to the bright, unpretentious musical-comedy cartoons of the immediate post-''Gypsy'' era on Broadway - indeed, to the early shows of its own authors. (Mr. Gelbart was co-author of the book of ''A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum,'' and Mr. Coleman composed the score for ''Little Me,'' both in 1962.) Just as the season ended, Off Broadway's Playwrights Horizons introduced a jubilant musical fantasy, ''Once on This Island,'' whose young authors, Lynn Ahrens and Stephen Flaherty, promise more good times for the American musical; they and their show, one suspects, will be competing for Tony Awards this time next year.
In the other notable new musical of the season, that nonstop whirl of dramatic movement known as ''Grand Hotel,'' Tommy Tune again proves that he is the most imaginative director and choreographer of musicals on Broadway. Why he insists on lavishing his gifts mainly on lackluster material is the mystery that haunts and inhibits his career. As ''Forbidden Broadway 1990'' has most hilariously pointed out in its ''Grim Hotel'' sketch, ''Grand Hotel'' is a warmed-over recycling of themes and techniques from Harold Prince's ''Cabaret,'' now almost a quarter of a century old.
 
English Musicals: End of an Affair?
 Though ''City of Angels'' and ''Grand Hotel'' are each brilliantly designed (by Robin Wagner and Tony Walton), neither depends on the kind of overwhelming hardware that has been the stock-in-trade of English musical spectaculars. As if on cue, Andrew Lloyd Webber and Trevor Nunn brought to town their latest and most inert example of the genre, ''Aspects of Love,'' whose elephantine emptiness seems particularly conspicuous next to its American competition of the season. Should the show fail with the public - as seems to be the case - the Broadway audience's love affair with English musicals may unravel. It could be a sign of the times that New York theatergoers are laughing at the mindless theatrical Anglophilia of American tourists visiting London in Richard Nelson's smart comedy, ''Some Americans Abroad.''
The colossal box-office failure of ''Jerome Robbins's Broadway,'' which has announced a September closing with what its producers say will be a $4 million deficit, is another watershed, but one that says more about the economic crises of Broadway than it does about the quality of the show or the state of the musical theater. When a Tony Award-winning musical can run nearly as many performances as such Robbins shows as ''Gypsy,'' ''High Button Shoes'' and ''West Side Story'' did in their original Broadway engagements, play to large audiences most of the time and still have red ink to rival that of ''Annie 2,'' it means that production costs are out of control. And high production costs mean high ticket prices with which the producers attempt to recoup them. ''Jerome Robbins's Broadway'' was the first musical to have a $60 top ticket, extending from the orchestra into the rear mezzanine, but the public wasn't necessarily buying. The $60 tickets were frequently marked down through discount coupons and at the half-price ticket booth in Duffy Square.
As always, there were other ominous signs for the theater this season - whether in the battles over government arts financing, or in the obituary pages. Less ominous was the closing of ''A Chorus Line.'' It was a pivotal event of the season, and one that aroused the most mixed emotions. Surely no production had come to represent Broadway more, or at least the Broadway myth we know from old movies and present daydreams. Yet ''A Chorus Line'' was also the foremost symbol of the nonprofit theater's successful annexation of Broadway, since this production had, after all, begun its life Off Broadway, at the New York Shakespeare Festival.
 
Darkness Falls On a Beloved Icon
 Perhaps no one wanted to see such a beloved icon - and musical - die, even after 15 years. But there also seemed to be a feeling of release, however melancholy, at the final performance. The theater community could at last end its period of mourning for Michael Bennett, the show's most influential collaborator and the man whose death at age 44 in 1987 has clouded Broadway ever since. Meanwhile, there was little doubt that the revolution Mr. Bennett had helped win both on stage and behind the scenes, at the very heart of the process by which theater is created in this country, would not be turned back.
Leaving the Shubert on that closing night in late April, one looked at the lighted neighboring marquees and realized that most of the best plays surrounding ''A Chorus Line'' had reached Broadway as it had, by a long trail that began in workshops at artistically-minded theaters where Broadway, or even New York, was not necessarily the goal. The theater did not go dark when ''A Chorus Line'' did. Tony show viewers will discover tonight that New York's stages are, for the moment at least, teeming with new plays, some important and some just fun, demanding to be seen.

LENGTH: 1400 words

HEADLINE: TV VIEW;
'Yes - and No - Prime Minister!'

BYLINE: By Walter Goodman

 BODY:
For the past three months, Anglophiles have had reason to switch at 9 P.M. Sundays from ''Masterpiece Theater'' on PBS to C-Span, in order to catch ''Prime Minister's Question Time'' from the House of Commons.
Twice a week for 15 minutes each Tuesday and Thursday, Margaret Thatcher submits herself to the slings and arrows of the Opposition and to the caresses of Conservatives. (Because Parliament was in recess last week, the time slot will be given over tonight to a BBC call-in program with Mrs. Thatcher. Coverage will resume next Sunday through the middle of August, or as long as Parliament is in session.) The cameras began covering the proceedings of the House last November for British audiences, and C-Span has become the exclusive importer to America of a consistently diverting if occasionally perplexing half-hour. If America's House of Representatives comes across on television like a sophomore debating society, ''Prime Minister's Question Time'' is a vaudeville show. 
The drill is simple enough. Each session, the Speaker of the House of Commons, the splendidly bewigged Bernard Weatherill, calls on Members who have risen in hope of catching his eye - first from the party on one side of the aisle, then from the other. Mr. Weatherill, who has become something of a video star at home, has the manner of an indulgent headmaster given to shaking his head over his unruly charges. He is constantly forced to call, ''Order! Order!'' as the Laborites jeer the Prime Minister or the Tories hoot the Opposition. He has been heard to mutter, ''Very disorderly.'' Last Sunday his rebuke was ''We can't have this conversation across the chamber.'' A week earlier he was driven to an uncharacteristic touch of personal criticism by a Member who was slogging through a particularly unenthralling question. ''Please come on,'' the Speaker chided. ''A very long question.'' Now and then he reprimands Members with the reminder that their interruptions ''take a lot of time out of other honorable gentlemen who wish to be called.'' No one seems to pay much attention, but order invariably manages to restore itself in under a minute.
It is reported that since the question times have gone on screen, the sartorial quality of the Members has picked up. Most do seem to be smartly turned out these days, in well-cut dark suits with handkerchiefs flashing from breast pockets; even the backbench radicals without Oxbridge credentials or accents seem to have found their way to Savile Row or a facsimile. Still, there are mismatched outfits to enliven the proceedings, and one recent Sunday the tie of a Conservative from Eastbourne hung almost to his knees, where its swing distracted attention from his question.
Questions have bounced about among such matters as the poll tax that brought protesters into the streets of London, the high inflation rate, the reluctance of the Irish Republic to extradite people suspected of terrorist acts, and Lithuania's independence movement. A Labor Member rose at one session to take the Tories to task for not doing something to stop pedophiles from posing as social workers.
The players are predominantly white and male, the atmosphere clubbily partisan. Neil Kinnock, the Labor Party leader, can be counted on at almost every session to attack the Government for its solicitude for the rich at the expense of the poor. The exchanges are indirect; one addresses the Speaker, asking Mr. Weatherill, for example, whether it is not true that the Government economic policy is a disaster for the nation. Other Laborites use their time to bash what one called ''this wretched Administration'' and to suggest sacking the whole Cabinet. From their side of the aisle comes a chorus of ''No, Prime Minister!''
Mrs. Thatcher, who seems to have softened her appearance if not her personality for the cameras, responds with spirit. ''Nonsense, Mr. Speaker!'' she may exclaim, referring, of course, not to Mr. Weatherill but to some Laborite. She shrugged off the remonstrance about those disguised pedophiles with ''Cheap politics!'' Last week she dismissed a Labor backbencher as follows: ''The honorable Member brings out all sorts of tittle-tattle which is just not worthy of reply.'' The silver-haired man on her front bench who nods his agreement with everything she says is Geoffrey Howe, the Tory leader of the House.
The Prime Minister is generally prepared with statistics of some sort to counter criticism or to buttress the compliments heaped upon her Government by Members of her own party. When figures don't quite do the job, she is ready to remind the Speaker of how much worse things were under the Laborites. The Members cry ''Hear! Hear!'' or ''Humbug!'' according to their party allegiance.
Now and then Mrs. Thatcher is caught off guard by an eccentric on her own side of the aisle. A Member named Peter Lloyd recently got tangled up in the technology of the motor vehicle. When he paused in his obscure disquisition to say, ''And if she is with me this far . . .'' he brought down the House. Mrs. Thatcher did not pretend in her answer that she had the foggiest notion of what the honorable gentleman was going on about. On the other hand or side, a Laborite was subjected to a burst of genial derision when he began his question with the observation, ''Nineteen-ninety started in January.'' As the glee seemed to be subsiding, he proceeded to announce, ''This is May,'' and started things up again.
Americans, unfamiliar with the personalities on show, no doubt miss some of the fun. The very appearance in one session of a backbench Laborite named Frank Haynes brought anticipatory chuckles from his side of the House. ''Go on, give her a kiss,'' one Member was heard to urge. The gaunt Mr. Haynes, who looks a bit like the actor Alastair Sim, took the occasion to remind the Speaker that the Prime Minister had not had a very good time in her question sessions during the past few weeks. Then, leaning toward Mrs. Thatcher, he asked, ''Have you, duckie?'' When her turn came, she pointed out that since all comments in the House are directed at the Speaker, the gentleman's remark seemed unusually endearing.
One of the mysteries of the proceedings to the outsider is a piece of protocol that requires the Prime Minister to rise to respond to a question, sit down and rise again at once as though she were doing a knee exercise, to say, ''I refer the honorable gentleman to the reply which I gave some moments ago.'' What honorable gentleman? What reply? This viewer is content not to know, to have it remain one of the Old Country's mysteries, like cricket. On this side of the ocean, the pleasures of the show lie more in the ceremony than in the substance, more in manner than matter. Add ''Prime Minister's Question Time'' to cucumber sandwiches and bubble and squeak, under the category, There'll always be an England.
 
 
 
HEARD IN THE HOUSE: HIGHLIGHTS OF 'QUESTION TIME'
Sir Anthony Grant: Will the research into noise at work include the House of Commons? The noise here and the audibility of the system are such as to make work almost impossible sometimes.
 
Mr. Patrick Nicholls: The powers of Government may be great, but they are not sufficient to take care of the level or quality of the noise in the House. I am afraid that both may defeat us.

Mr. Evans: Does she not think that it would be a good idea if we had a flag day to commemorate a day that is important to the Conservative party, such as the day on which Winston Churchill became Prime Minister - 10 May 1940 - or perhaps the day on which the task force set off for the Falklands to show the world that sovereignty and freedom came before everything else, or perhaps even the day that my right Honorable Friend became Prime Minister? On the other hand, she might agree with me that the most significant day for the Conservative party was 1 Oct. 1983, when the Leader of the Opposition became leader of the Labor Party, went to Brighton beach and fell flat on his face. He has done just that every Tuesday and Thursday ever since.
 
The Prime Minister: I congratulate my Honorable Friend on his ingenuity and clarity of expression.

HEADLINE: Currency;
Gaining Ground on the Mark

 BODY:
The dollar rose against the West German mark again last week, topping 1.70 marks to the dollar briefly on Friday before slipping back to 1.6985. The dollar is now up more than 4 percent against the mark since the beginning of May. Some foreign exchange traders say that part of the mark's weakness stems from the belief that the West German Bundesbank is having more disagreements than usual over economic policy with the West German Government. In addition, there may be more dissension within the Bundesbank itself. Both strains, if true, could hamper the Bundesbank's efforts to make the economic unification of the two Germanys as smooth as possible. Meanwhile, the dollar also rose against the Japanese yen, finishing the week above the key 150 level.

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
Investing Goldman's New Money

BYLINE: By Anise C. Wallace

 BODY:
Until recently, an investor needed $5 million to open an account at Goldman Sachs & Company. But times are tough on Wall Street. This prestigious investment bank has established a mutual fund and now welcomes smaller accounts.
So far the fund, which opened in April, has attracted more than $400 million, of which about $140 million came from Goldman employees' savings. How Goldman intends to use this money provides an interesting view of current investment strategies. 
Fund executives said they are not eager to invest in stocks. Goldman's philosophy is to keep clients out of securities when they are overpriced, said Leon G. Cooperman, who last fall became chairman of Goldman's asset management group. He has invested $2 million of his own assets in the fund.
''I don't see the overwhelming compelling case for the stock market,'' Mr. Cooperman said. Consequently only about 35 percent of the GS Capital Growth Fund is invested in stocks.
But there are still some bargains available, Mr. Cooperman said, if investors consider stocks that analysts and other investors consider controversial. One of his picks for the fund is American Express, which has had management problems with its subsidiary Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc.''You cannot make a lot of money in the stock market at today's level without taking on a certain amount of controversy,'' Mr. Coopermansaid.
So it should come as no surprise that 5 percent of the fund is in the battered ''junk bonds'' of companies like McCaw Cellular Communications and ACF Industries.
''What's happening now is that the equity players like myself are sifting through the rubble,'' he said. ''Some of our best investments have been junk.'' Junk bonds are securities issued by companies that are too young or have too much debt to earn an investment-grade from the rating agencies.
But because many junk bonds offer potential returns of 17 or 18 percent, bargain hunters have driven their prices up sharply in recent weeks. Now, Mr. Cooperman said, it is difficult to buy them at prices he likes.
The balance of the Goldman Sachs fund, almost $250 million, will remain in short-term investments like Treasury bills until the firm's analysts and portfolio managers find securities they like at lower levels. The fund has an extremely broad charter and can invest in a wide a variety of financial instruments, including stock-index futures and foreign currencies.
Goldman's new fund reflects a change in strategy. Last year, the firm decided to expand its $21 billion investment management division that invested money-market funds for bank trust departments. (The last time Goldman offered a mutual fund was, perhaps inauspiciously, in 1929.) Before taking charge of the expanded investment department, Mr. Cooperman was portfolio strategist and head of the firm's research department for 12 years. From 1977 to 1985, he was rated the No. 1 portfolio strategist in a survey by the magazine Institutional Investor.
For now, Mr. Cooperman is wary of the overall stock and bond markets because he sees little opportunity for gains. Goldman's economists expect only modest economic growth this year and a further decline in corporate profits. And they are not looking for a significant drop in long-term interest rates.
One exception in this overpriced market is Sotheby's, the art auction house, Mr. Cooperman said. There is evidence of a weakening in the art market, and sellers have pushed the stock down from its peak of 37 to 17 3/4 at Friday's close. Mr. Cooperman does not expect the company to enjoy the rapid growth of recent years. But cash flow should remain strong because ''it is a world-class franchise,'' he said, and it dominates the world auction market.
Mr. Cooperman does see room for growth in the cellular telephone business and has invested in Motorola and McCaw Cellular. From his briefcase he pulls a Motorola cellular phone, a gift from colleagues. ''I never would have paid $3,000 for a telephone, because I'm so cheap,'' he said. ''But it has had an important impact on productivity. I call London every morning before I go through the Holland Tunnel.'' Although McCaw has a heavy debt load, Mr. Cooperman said he is impressed that the McCaw family has a large stake in the cellular franchise company, that British Telecommunications invested $1.5 billion in cash in the company and that J. P. Morgan & Company acted as the lead bank on raising funds for the company's acquisition of Lin Broadcasting. Less than 2 percent of the population in the United States owns a cellular telephone, a figure he thinks will increase in coming years. ''This is like the razor business, and they own the blades,'' he said.
Goldman's fund is also betting on some of what Wall Street calls ''defensive'' companies, which do well in weak or poor economic environments. These includes American Home Products, American Cyanamid, Glaxo and SmithKline Beecham. ''We wanted to avoid companies that were dependent on strong economic growth,'' Mr. Cooperman said. ''We wanted decent balance sheet and above-average growth because I don't see the case for a strong economy.''
Nor does he see the case for a sharp decline or a bear market. There is no evidence of a recession, he said, and investors have not been wildly enthusiastic about the stock market, often a sign of a peak in prices.
''If I were an individual investor,'' Mr. Cooperman said, ''I would be taking money out of the market and maintaining cash reserves.''

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
A Lot's Amiss, But the Indexes Could Care Less

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
Just as all of Washington was celebrating the victory of capitalism over Communism, a symbol of capitalist excess surfaced last week at the most symbolic of places, where Monopoly is made.
Always polite, Mikhail S. Gorbachev evidently did not mention the problems of the Tonka Corporation to President Bush as they met last week. Soviet leaders no longer look for evidence that their economic system is superior; they just want to find painless ways to get the benefits of ours without sacrificing political control. 
But the problems at Tonka, whose shares plunged $2.875 last week, to $7.325, nonetheless stand as a reminder of the excesses of this system in the last decade. Tonka simply can't make enough money to pay the interest on the more than $400 million in debt it piled up when it bought the maker of the Monopoly board game in 1987. It says losses in this quarter may leave it in violation of bank loan agreements. Monopoly, it seems, just isn't profitable enough to pay off the banks. Tonka's problems served as a reminder, too, that many companies find themselves in financial distress because of varying combinations of the weak economy and borrowing excesses of the past. Only 110 companies raised their dividends in May, Standard & Poor's reported, the lowest such figure for any May since 1971, while the number eliminating payouts is running at the highest level since the last recession ended in 1982.
But those problems haven't bothered the stock market as a whole. The unemployment report on Friday, showing that the Census Bureau created 90 percent of the new jobs in May while manufacturers continue to shed workers, renewed the bond market rally. The yield on 30-year Treasury bonds, above 9 percent only a month ago, fell to 8.44 percent.
In the stock market, one might expect that the continued reports of weakness in the manufacturing sector would put a damper on share prices. Instead, industrial stocks have led the market up, while financial, utility and transportation stocks have lagged. The Dow Jones, Standard & Poor's and Nasdaq industrial averages are all at record levels, with the Dow last week advancing 80.05 points, to 2,900.97.
The Dow rose 8.3 percent in May, but it was a laggard next to the more broadly based industrial indexes. The S.&P. industrial index rose 9.5 percent and the Nasdaq version added 11.3 percent. While many have been claiming that this rally has been for large stocks only, it appears that many of the smaller ones have quietly begun their own celebration.
It has been so long since the last recession, and there have been so many incorrect forecasts of another one, that many stock buyers have decided to bet that the economy will forever muddle through. A Tonka or an L.A. Gear - the maker of trendy tennies and other shoes that lost 38 percent of its market value last week when it forecast lower profits - may be dumped, but the money is promptly put into other stocks.
For now, the lure of profits is greater than the fear of losses.
