HEADLINE: Stop the World, Mexico Is Getting On

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY

 BODY:
As usual, Carlos Salinas de Gortari is a man in a hurry - and with some tough decisions to make.
Next week, Mexico's 42-year-old President heads to the United States again, his third visit in less than a year. While it took the United States and Canada three years to shape a free-trade agreement, Mr. Salinas is convinced a similar accord between his country and the United States must be reached more quickly, and believes Washington is ready to start dealing. ''I think it would be advantageous for both economies if it were a shorter time,'' he said during an interview in late May at Los Pinos, the Mexican equivalent of the White House. 
For Mr. Salinas, time is a commodity not to be wasted. Since taking office in December 1988, the Harvard-educated economist has routinely taken dramatic steps to open and modernize the Mexican economy, long one of the most closed and protected in the world. He has put state enterprises like airlines, mines, steel mills and the telephone company on the block; permitted imports to surge to pressure Mexican producers to become more efficient; liberalized foreign investment regulations; overhauled the tax system, and cut the deficit to its lowest level in a quarter-century. In doing so, he has won the applause of the World Bank, George Bush and leaders of other industrialized nations, who now hold Mexico up as a textbook example of modernization for the rest of the world to follow.
But the more Mr. Salinas does, the more he needs to do. The problem is that the rest of world is now changing at an even more rapid pace, and Mr. Salinas finds himself scrambling not to fall behind. Mexico's Minister of Finance, Pedro Aspe, may be receiving invitations from the new leaders of Eastern Europe to deliver tutorials on how to dismantle a state-dominated economy and make it competitive, but Western investors seem more impressed by what is occurring in East Germany, Hungary and Czechoslovakia than by events in Mexico.
 
At the Crossroads
 As a result Mr. Salinas faces a difficult choice: either further accelerate the pace of reform, which is already intense by Mexican standards, or risk losing the gains he has promised the Mexican people. A lot is on the line, especially for Mr. Salinas's Institutional Revolutionary Party. After six decades of unbroken rule, the party's hold over Mexico weakened in recent years and Mr. Salinas barely squeaked into office amid widespread allegations of election fraud. If Mr. Salinas and his economic program stumble, the party would likely face further erosion.
''Salinas has followed the recipe and done everything the way you are supposed to do it,'' said Rogelio Ramirez de la O, a leading private-sector economist here who is sympathetic to the President's objectives. ''But his situation reminds me of that Bunuel movie in which every time they sit down to eat, something happens and they have to get up from the table. As a result, he and his people are finding that much of what they thought would not be necessary has become necessary.''
Just last month, Mr. Salinas delivered a most heretical message to the one million workers who marched by the balcony of the National Palace expecting the ritual stroking that comes each May 1, Mexico's Labor Day. They must, he told them, ''increase productivity, lower costs and help win markets inside and out of the country.'' A day later, he announced that he intended to privatize the country's banking system, nationalized in 1982. And by the end of May, he obtained approval from Mexico's Congress for the proposal that promises to be the most important of his administration: negotiation of a free-trade agreement.
As a candidate for President early in 1988, Mr. Salinas had ruled out such an accord, citing ''such a different economic level'' between Mexico and the United States. That statement was in keeping with the traditional values of his party, which during the four decades ending in 1980 delivered 6 percent average annual growth by keeping foreign competition out and subsidizing domestic producers, so as not to be swallowed by United States interests.
But Mr. Salinas ''is nothing if not pragmatic,'' one diplomat here said, and the President now contends that an agreement is essential not only to attract investment but also to guarantee access to American markets. The steps that led him to discard a policy in place since the Mexican Revolution of 1910 say much about the flexibility he will need to demonstrate during the rest of his six-year term.
''At least we have someone who reacts quickly to changed conditions, rather than governing on assumptions that no longer hold up,'' said Gabriel Szekely, a Mexican scholar who is associate director of the Center for United States-Mexican Studies at the University of California at San Diego.
 
Promises, Promises
 One major assumption has already been undermined: When Mexico concluded an historic debt-reduction agreement with its 500 commercial bank creditors last July, cutting its $100 billion foreign debt by more than 10 percent, Mr. Salinas and his economic team predicted that a burst of growth was imminent, fueled both by a surge of foreign investment and the return of Mexican capital that had gone abroad. The National Development Plan sent to the Mexican Congress shortly afterward predicted that the $26.5 billion that foreigners have invested in Mexico would double by 1994, the end of Mr. Salinas's term.
What Mr. Salinas could not anticipate, however, was that Communism would collapse in Eastern Europe and present Mexico with a whole new set of rivals. Overnight, state-owned companies were on the block around the world, offering the foreign investor attractive new possibilities.
''Suddenly, there were more players in the piece,'' said Claudio X. Gonzalez, chairman of Kimberly-Clark de Mexico and an adviser to Mr. Salinas on foreign investment matters. ''There is no question but that a diversion is going on.''
The implications for Mexico became clear in January, when Mr. Salinas addressed top European business executives at a conference in Davos, Switzerland, and met with the leaders of the European Community, Britain, Portugal, East Germany and Poland. Interest in investing money in Mexico or buying up Mexican state companies was minimal, and Mr. Salinas returned to Mexico sobered by his experience, according to Mexican officials and foreign diplomats here.
''Here you are at Davos, and your President is there, and he gives the keynote address and is extremely good and is well-received, and the next day, meetings on Hungary and Poland and East Germany started, and zoom, everybody was off listening to those meetings and what those other people had to say,'' an adviser to Mr. Salinas recalled. ''It was a real eye opener.''
As a result, while Mexico is still looking to foreign investment to play an important role in the country's growth, the Government's emphasis is now clearly on the domestic sector. The decision to privatize the banks, which are highly profitable, is expected to bring home as much as $7 billion in capital that had been sent abroad in the early 1980's. Similarly, the mere prospect of a free-trade agreement with the United States is expected to encourage Mexican investors to take advantage of new opportunities at home instead of buying real estate in California and Texas.
 
'An Ossified System'
 Still, even if a free-trade agreement is reached, it will not be a panacea. Mexico faces a gamut of structural problems that will test Mr. Salinas's political resolve and his reputation as an innovator and reformer.
''The problem is not Salinas or his 10 top people,'' said one foreign official. ''But in an ossified system like this one or the Soviet Union or any other place where there has been one-party rule for a long time, you run into tremendous problems the deeper you go into the society.''
Mr. Salinas's biggest challenge probably lies in Mexico's agricultural system, which has suffered a dramatic deterioration in recent years and is described by one Eastern European diplomat here as ''even more backward than that of the Soviet Union.'' More than half the country's arable land is held as ejidos, a pre-Columbian form of land tenure in which a peasant community collectively owns a piece of land and the natural resources and houses on it. As Mexico's population has grown, the parcels worked by individual peasants have shrunk in many cases to an acre or less, thus making economies of scale impossible.
Combined with a tradition of low prices for agricultural producers and large subsidies for consumers, the result is a disaster in the countryside that contributes heavily to Mexico's widening trade gap. In 1989, Mexico imported more than 10 million tons of grains, mostly from the United States. Mr. Salinas acknowledges that ''this year we are going to have to import another 10 million tons of food,'' a trend the United States thinks is likely to continue through the end of the century.
 
Mystical Attachment
 On purely economic grounds, a complete overhaul of the ejido system would therefore appear to be in order. But official recognition of ejido ownership was one of the principal issues over which more than a million people lost their lives during the Mexican Revolution, and to this day many Mexicans maintain a mystical attachment to the institution. In addition, Mexican law states that ejidos are ''inalienable, nontransferable and nonattachable,'' conditions that drive away investment that might otherwise flow into agriculture.
Thus, the steps Mr. Salinas can take to modernize the countryside are limited unless he wishes to risk a long, emotional and politically costly battle to change the Mexican Constitution. At the moment, with the free-trade issue already generating enormous controversy, he appears unwilling to do so.
A similar situation prevails at Pemex, the state oil company, which is also viewed as ''untouchable'' because of the profound nationalist sentiments associated with it. The corrupt labor leaders who manipulated those feelings to their own profit at the height of the oil boom a decade ago have been jailed or squeezed out since Mr. Salinas came to power, but Pemex continues to be notoriously overstaffed and unproductive: with proven oil reserves of more than 50 billion barrels, Mexico is importing gasoline.
The company was starved for investment through much of the 80's, a result of Mexico's economic crisis, but to pump large amounts of state money into it now would undermine Mr. Salinas's drive to reduce the public sector. Some limited activities have been opened to private participation through new decrees that are paragons of bureaucratic legerdemain, but foreigners are largely unimpressed: before rushing in, they want new laws passed to make investments more secure.
Complaints that Mexico has not done enough to provide foreign investors with the protection they require are common in other areas as well, especially among the Japanese business executives Mr. Salinas will be meeting during a 10-day Asian trip that starts June 17 in Tokyo.
 
What Investors Want
 Potential foreign investors are quick to note that Mr. Salinas changed only the administrative regulations governing their activities, shying away from rewriting a restrictive 1973 foreign investment law that remains on the books. They say that the country's labor regulations, traditionally staunchly pro-union, are increasingly being interpreted in favor of corporations, but argue that the entire labor code needs to be replaced. They point out that they can now buy preferred stock that allows them to share in the profits of companies formerly closed to foreign investment, but complain that they are still denied a voice in management.
''Mexico needs to do away with a lot of regulations that are highly politicized,'' said Dr. Szekely of the University of California. ''Mexico is full of rules with hidden understandings and 25 exceptions, and that's no way to run a country.''
When asked about the complaints, Mr. Salinas chose to focus on one of the problem areas. ''The changes we have made in our investment regulations to stimulate foreign investment are very recent,'' he said, adding that critics must ''give us time to make them work.''
Mexican investors also want ''greater stability, and that means single-digit inflation,'' said Jorge Ocejo Moreno, president of the Mexican Employers' Federation, a leading business group. But after bringing inflation down dramatically from a record high of 160 percent in 1987 to 19.7 percent last year, the Government effort has stalled, at least momentarily. The Government had set a target of 15 percent for 1990, but most economists in the private sector now foresee a rate of 25 percent.
That, however, has not stopped Mr. Salinas from implementing a $1.3 billion social works effort. Spending to install electricity, water, schools and health clinics in poor areas may not be inherently inflationary, since Mr. Salinas has repeatedly emphasized that he is using only the money gained from the privatization of state companies. But critics of the effort point out that this money could just as easily have been used to diminish the $50 billion domestic debt, thus driving down interest rates as well as inflation.
''In order for the economic program to advance, there has to be a social consensus, and you build that consensus by responding to the most urgent demands of the community,'' Mr. Salinas said in response.
''It's a question of political management and equilibrium, no?'' asked Jesus Silva Herzog, a former Minister of Finance who believes Mr. Salinas has pointed Mexico in the right direction but is moving too fast. ''There are political and social necessities that must be attended to.''
But whatever the political realities, the economic realities are making their own demands. The surge of inflation has placed renewed pressure on the exchange rate. That has slowed the growth of exports.
And fears are growing that the foreign debt could re-emerge as a crippling factor. The Government's strategy ''is highly dependent on the success of capital repatriation and foreign investment,'' said Mr. Silva Herzog. ''If they don't come, then we are going to have serious problems again with the service of the debt in 1991 or 1992.''
With such dire possibilities on the horizon, Mr. Salinas is not likely to be slowing down any time soon.
 
THE NORTHERN CONNECTION
If President Salinas and his economic team are carrying out the restructuring of Mexico ''by the book,'' as both critics and supporters acknowledge, it may be because they devoted their formative years to poring over Keynes, Schumpeter and Samuelson under the tutelage of professors in the United States.
Mr. Salinas spent much of the mid-1970's at Harvard University, where he was awarded master's degrees in both public administration and political economy before earning a Ph.D. in political economy and government.
Mr. Salinas's most trusted adviser is probably Jose Maria Cordoba Montoya, whose nondescript official title is chief of the office of coordination of the presidency.
''Cordoba is the closest thing Salinas has to an alter ego,'' one diplomat said. ''When they are together, you find Salinas saying things like, 'Isn't that what we think, Pepe?' ''
Born in France of parents who were Spanish Republican exiles, Mr. Cordoba, who celebrated his 40th birthday on Friday, studied at the Ecole Polytechnique and the Sorbonne in Paris before moving on to Stanford University, where friendships with Mexican students led him to develop an interest in the country. He became a Mexican citizen in 1985.
Rounding out Mr. Salinas's economic cabinet are three key ministers, all of them under 40 and with doctorates earned at universities in the United States.
The Minister of Finance, Pedro Aspe (39, Massachusetts Institute of Technology), has overall authority for management of the economy.
As Minister of Commerce and Industry, Jaime Serra Puche (39, Yale), is, along with Mr. Cordoba, most closely identified with the push for a free-trade agreement.
And the Minister of Budget and Planning, Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon (38, Yale), occupies the post that has produced Mexico's last two Presidents, but is viewed more as a number cruncher than a politician.
 
INCREASING THE FLOW OF FOREIGN CAPITAL
Though a flood of foreign investment has yet to materialize as a result of last summer's debt-reduction agreement, a steady flow of capital is on its way, Mexican officials say.
The largest single investment announced thus far is that of the Nissan Motor Company, which is expected to pump nearly $1 billion into a new automobile plant in the central state of Aguascalientes. Volkswagen A.G. and the Ford Motor Company have also said they would raise their profiles here, by about $500 million and $300 million respectively.
Beyond the automotive industry, the largest new commitment, some $300 million for general expansion, has come from Nestle S.A. Another major European multinational, Rhone-Poulenc S.A., heads a group that will invest more than $100 million in a hydrofluoric acid plant near the American border.
Of the large American corporations that traditionally have accounted for the bulk of foreign investment in Mexico, one of the most bullish appears to be the General Electric Company, which is spending about $200 million in a joint venture with a Mexican appliance maker, aimed at producing cooking stoves for consumers in both countries. ''It is a very big leap forward for us,'' said Jim Allen, a G.E. spokesman. ''This plant will be our only gas-range facility and is very critical to our whole North American strategy.''
In addition, ''at least $500 million of activity has taken place through the stock market,'' said Claudio X. Gonzalez, a foreign investment adviser to President Salinas.
According to Government figures, nearly half that flow has gone to a pair of companies: the Alfa group, an industrial conglomerate, and Telefonos de Mexico, the state-owned telecommunications company that is being privatized.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2, Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1668 words

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIARY

BYLINE: By Allen R. Myerson

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
Greenwald Shifts His Bets From Chrysler to UAL
 
Gerald Greenwald would rather bet his career on an employee buyout of UAL Inc. than the prompt retirement of Lee Iacocca. Last Wednesday, he resigned as the Chrysler Corporation's vice chairman and Mr. Iacocca's likely successor to become chief-executive-in-waiting for UAL. Mr. Greenwald's wait will end if he can arrange financing for the unions' $4.36 billion offer by the board's Aug. 9 deadline. At Chrysler, he helped keep the company out of bankruptcy a decade ago and led a cost-cutting campaign more recently. Analysts say his participation improves the chances of a deal at UAL. ''It moves the entire transaction off dead center,'' said Helane Becker of Shearson Lehman Hutton. ''The employees should be congratulated for going out and getting someone so good.'' UAL stock jumped 4 5/8 to 155 1/2 on Thursday, still well below the unions' $201-a-share offer. 
 
*
 
Chrysler, meanwhile, rushed to reassure investors that the loss of three senior executives in about two weeks has been coincidental, and unrelated to sagging sales. Mr. Greenwald's duties, and his prospects for succeeding Mr. Iacocca, were immediately divided between the new vice chairman, Robert S. Miller Jr., and Robert A. Lutz, president of Chrysler's automotive operations. Scott F. Merlis, an analyst at Morgan Stanley, says that the company has deep ranks of sound managers. He added that, ''if my computer is correct in extrapolating his energy and commitment,'' Mr. Iacocca is unlikely to leave when his contract runs out in 1991.
 
Tubeside Revisionism
 
If the new fall lineup doesn't produce more viewers, the statistical adjustments will. On Thursday, ABC announced a plan to come up with ratings more to its taste. CBS and NBC are likely to follow. The networks have suffered from broad declines in television viewing reported by the A.C. Nielsen Company. Failing to deliver a guaranteed audience to advertisers can become costly, forcing the networks to dole out free commercials. So ABC, disputing Nielsen's reliability, plans to adjust its audience counts. ''Totally fair,'' an ABC executive said. ''Totally unacceptable,'' a leading advertising executive responded.
 
One Bum Quarter, You're Out
 
Barbarians in the bullpen: They say that baseball teams take on the character of their cities. So it's no wonder that the New York Mets changed managers the way Wall Street restructures a corporation. Davey Johnson had a peerless record for six years. But his bottom-line, won-lost performance for the most recent quarter disappointed sports analysts and the team's investors. Met attendance passed 2.9 million in a winning season last year; fewer fans would watch losers. The investors decided that they could improve their returns with a tough new manager, Derrel McKinley Harrelson. A former Met shortstop, he is called scrappy as often as he is called Bud. Employees fear that the company will become more like boot camp than the corner bar, with layoffs possible. Mr. Johnson, meanwhile, floats off under a golden parachute that gives him the rest of his $350,000 salary this year and $500,000 the next.
 
Harcourt Changes Covers
 
One more publishing house executive is gone after failing to mind the right set of books. William I. Jovanovich resigned as chairman of Harcourt Brace Jovanich after a career of publishing the likes of T. S. Eliot and E. M. Forster. His successor, John S. Herrington, a former Secretary of Energy, needs to slash the $1.6 billion in debts that Mr. Jovanovich piled up in fighting off a takeover attempt. In this he will work with Peter Jovanovich, the chief executive and William's son. Harcourt Brace stock, which reached 63 3/4 in 1987 during the battle for control, has recentlybeen trading at about 3. Bert L. Boksen, an analyst at Raymond James & Associates, said that teachers who are impressed with the company's textbooks ask him whether toinvest. Mr. Boksen is neutral, but says that the sale of some could pull the company through.
 
Manville's Bankrutpcy, Again
 
Two judges in New York reopened the Manville Corporation's bankruptcy proceedings on Friday. The extraordinary ruling came in response to the deteriorating financial condition of a trust handling thousands of asbestos claims.
 
Banking's Into Insurance
 
Banks are all ready to storm into the insurance business. Delaware passed laws on Wednesday allowing the banks, many of which have credit card operations in the state, to sell insurance across the nation. Analysts expect the banks to sell home and automobile insurance but avoid underwriting. ''They have their hands full with credit risk,'' said G. Alan Zimmerman, an analyst at Smith Barney. ''They don't need underwriting risk.'' Their greatest risk now is that insurance agents will convince the Federal Reserve Board to keep the banks out of the business.
 
In Brief
 
The trustee for Eastern Airlines said on Friday that he had offered to aid a Federal investigation of allegedly falsified maintenance records.
 
*
 
A Federal grand jury accused the Nynex Corporation of violating a restriction on selling computerized information that was imposed in the 1982 break-up of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.
 
* Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. hopes to rise from the indebted and the dead. The brokerage firm sought bankruptcy protection last week in an attempt to reorganize. Frederick H. Joseph resigned as the firm's chief executive while continuing as president of the parent company, which filed for bankruptcy in February.
 
COMPANIES
 
Japan's New Women
 
Don't discount the efforts of Japanese women in the workplace, says the new editor-in-chief of the prestigious Asahi Journal magazine. When Mitsuko Shimomura joined the affiliated Asahi Shimbun newspaper 18 years ago, she was one of just 10 female journalists there. Today there are 200, out of 3,000 in all. And women now account for nearly 40 percent of the Japanese workforce, up from 32 percent in 1975. American feminists are more visible, Mrs. Shimomura says, while their Japanese counterparts are quiter, more subtle and less confrontational, in accordance with their culture. ''The American way, whenever you find anything wrong, you do surgery, no matter how much blood comes out,'' she said on a visit to the United States last week. ''The Japanese way, you take a pill every day, and six months or a year later you feel better.'' Mrs. Shimomura, apparently the highest-ranking woman in Japanese print journalism, says women are still scarce in management - as if the medicine, while working, has yet to have its full effect. One of her first actions as editor was urging her five deputies, all male, to take more time off to spend with their wives and children.
 
Spirited Touch to Russian Trade
 
President Mikhail S. Gorbachev arrived in the United States last week in search of expanded trade. He admitted that his economic reforms have yet to show results. ''Our ship has lost anchor and therefore we're all a little sick,'' he said. In talks with Congressional leaders, he backed away from his commitment to a referendum on higher food prices. Vodka makers, meanwhile, capitalized on the summit spirit. Smirnoff is running advertisements showing weaponry X-ed out and Smirnoff bottles, unmarked. Liquor stores in Minneapolis celebrated Mr. Gorbachev's planned visit today with rebates on Stolichnaya, a Soviet vodka.
 
THE ECONOMY
 
Jobs Scarce, Market's Up
 
Dreary employment figures caused delirium on Wall Street. Private payrolls rose by only 19,000 in May, after economists had expected at least 100,000 additional jobs. The unemployment rate reported on Friday fell a tenth of a point to 5.3 percent in May, but economists said the employment figures were far more significant. Excluding government, which has been temporarily hiring hordes of census workers, the economy has lost 105,000 jobs over the last three months. ''It's a sluggish economy. No doubt about it,'' said Stephen S. Roach, senior economist at Morgan Stanley. He expects the economy to grow less than 2 percent this quarter. Investors who said they foresee lower interest rates helped push the Dow to its first close above 2,900 on Friday, while bond prices soared. But Federal Reserve Board members are bound to be calmer than Wall Street's manic traders. Mr. Roach, a former Fed economist himself, says that with no apparent threat of a recession, the board is unlikely to ease up on rate pressures.
 
Economic Clouds Ahead . . .
 
The leading economic indicators are leading downward. For April, the index fell two-tenths of 1 percent, reflecting the third straight decline in building permits. Real estate appears to be in a recession; sales of new single-family homes fell 1.6 percent in April. The decline, the fifth in a row, brought sales to the lowest level since 1982.
 
. . . But the Texas K.B.I. Soars
 
The surest sign of a reviving Texas economy: The closely watched Kreuz Barbecue Index, released last week, showed a healthy annualized gain of 5 percent. Because this is a preliminary estimate, industry analysts are reacting with caution. ''I haven't sat down and figured it out exactly,'' said Don Schmidt, co-owner with his brother Rick of the Kreuz Market in Lockhart, Tex. For the year so far, he said, he is serving at least 5 percent more beef brisket, beef shoulder, pork loin and hot sausage links, with more Shiner beer. The K.B.I. had been as flat as the state's Panhandle for about three years. Not that it takes much prosperity to buy a thick slice of beef on brown butcher paper - $1.50 does it. But since Kreuz is in the hill country of Texas, many customers also have the expense of driving over from Houston, San Antonio, Austin or the oil fields to the south. ''People don't travel unless they have money,'' Don Schmidt said. ''Overall, Texas is picking up.''

HEADLINE: Civvies for the American Military Economy?

BYLINE: By JOEL KURTZMAN

 BODY:
As the cold war fades into history, policy makers are beginning work on trimming the military budget. But how easily can companies that serve the military convert their operations to civilian use? Seymour Melman, professor emeritus of industrial engineering at Columbia University and chairman of the National Commission for Economic Conversion and Disarmament, and Lawrence Klein, Benjamin Franklin Professor of Economics at the University of Pennsylvania and a Nobel laureate, discussed the economic consequences of smaller military budgets with Joel Kurtzman of The New York Times.
 
Q.: Will companies that produce for the military be able to convert their factories to civilian use as the military budget is trimmed?
 
Mr. Melman: Companies that supply the military are operating in a cost maximizing mode. Based on the available evidence, it is not prudent to assume that these same firms could satisfy the demand for civilian products. Military-industry managers have what Thorsten Veblen once called a ''trained incapacity.'' They can't function in a civilian market. They can't design products for the civilian consumer market like tape recorders, VCRs, etc. 
 
Q.: If these companies can't produce for the civilian market, then will cutbacks in the military mean more imports and higher unemployment? :cw0> Not necessarily. Too few military contractors that I know of have been able to shift to civilian production. But some did. I did some computer work, for instance, with Boeing Computer Services.
 
Mr. Melman:: Pardon me, but were you referring to Boeing Computer Services as a military contractor?
 
Mr. Klein:: No. It is a civilian company. But it is a civilian alternative for Boeing after cutbacks in military spending.
 
Mr. Melman:: Ah, but you see, this is a very important matter. We have to make some differentiations here. The larger companies typically have a variety of divisions, some serving the military and some serving the civilian sector. In the case of Boeing, the military contractors are notably different in their internal modus operandi from the civilian facilities. Even the plants and management systems are different.
 
Q.: Can't military managers learn from civilian managers?
 
Mr. Melman:: There was a very important attempt made by Boeing's Vertol division outside Philadelphia. Boeing attempted to go from making helicopters for the military to producing electric trolleys, trams, light rail vehicles and subway cars.
It failed. The reason it failed is because Boeing did nothing but operate by methods that were well accepted on the military side. In fact, of the 80 or so engineers that worked on this project, all but one had come out of military aerospace. The other engineers had no training in cost-minimizing design.
They also operated in the standard Pentagon fashion called ''concurrency,'' meaning they did the design, testing, evaluation and production all at the same time instead of dealing with each of these operations sequentially. As a result, the items they produced and delivered to customers were not properly tested. One unfortunate customer was the Massachussetts Bay Transportation Authority. The cars it received suffered from extreme unreliability and unacceptable breakdown rates. There was a parade of lawsuits and then Boeing abandoned the whole affair.
 
Q.: What is required for a company to make a smooth transition from the military to civilian sector?
 
Mr. Melman: Preparation.
 
Q.: What kind and over how long a period?
 
Mr. Melman: It takes two years to do serious blueprinting for changing a military factory to a civilian one. That's the planning time. That's well-established. We also must change the occupational skills of managers and engineers and some production workers. We have to train them into designing for cost minimizing. We have to train managers to deal with Sears, Roebuck rather than with Pentagon divisions. That requires, again, about a two-year period. Part-time participation in retraining work is a perfectly conceivable.
 
Q. So it would take about two years overall if these actions were undertaken at the same time?
 
Mr. Melman: Yes. About two years.
 
Mr. Klein: It is not just a question of retraining engineers. Retraining is important with military personnel also. Some of the suggestions that have been made include demobilizing 100,000 troops - and that is the low end of the estimate.
 
Mr. Melman: In April of 1962, President Kennedy announced a comprehensive plan for achieving general and complete disarmament in 10 years on a three-stage basis. It was formally submitted for negotiations. The proposals were never negotiated because of the Cuban missile crisis, and the ideas were put aside. But it was a serious formulation. The plan should be re-examined.
The military budget today is about $300 billion a year. If we implemented the Kennedy plan over a 10-year period and reduced the budget by 10 percent a year to just enough to support an international police force, we would save a total of about $1.5 trillion over that period.
 
Mr. Klein: Well, what's being talked about is not disarmament. There's talk of some disengagement, mutual arms reductions, stopping the cold war, stopping some of the arms race. But there is also talk about being ready for situations that may develop in other parts of the world. That's not disarmament.
 
Q. Under the Kennedy plan, would these resources become available if there were arms cutbacks?
 
Mr. Melman: Yes.
 
Mr. Klein: Another route to getting the resources would be to reduce capital costs in this country by getting interest rates down, which would come from a smaller budget deficit.
 
Mr. Melman: That's one perspective. The United States and the Soviet Union have both suffered badly domestically in the course of the cold war. The probable economic winners of the cold war are West Germany and Japan. The United States has been made into a second-class industrial economy with worse yet to come.
 
Mr. Klein: I don't agree with that at all. The United States has not become a second-class economy.
 
Mr. Melman: I take it as a reasonable conclusion from a set of independently checkable phenomena - the ability to produce comparable products at a competitive price. Then there's the decay in quality of life. You have only to walk out of into the streets of New York to see the evidence of it: broken streets, broken people. It's a disaster.
 
Mr. Klein: That's anecdotal. It is true that there's homelessness in America. It's true that we have a poor, degraded infrastructure. But, if you travel all over America, you get a very different picture depending on where you are. What's crucial is this: We have spent less relative to some other nations, but we have gained in the last three or four years and we will probably continue to gain. Our trade balance will improve - it has improved. It will continue to improve. We will eventually get down the budget deficit.
There is much to be done, but I think it is highly premature to say that we are a second-class nation.
 
Q. Are you arguing that the degraded infrastructure you refer to is a result of military spending?
 
Mr. Melman: Yes. From 1947 to 1989, the Department of Defense spent $8.2 trillion in 1982 dollar value on behalf of the military. That is an immense figure since in 1982 the combined value of American industry and infrastructure was $7.3 trillion.
So we have put into the military, cumulatively, a quantity of resources more than enough to rebuild what is man-made in the United States. There's no wonder that we show a deterioration in many civilian spheres.
And take the little matter of the quantity of machines that are held by the Pentagon. The money value of those machines - including such things as airplanes, cannons, factories and so on - is somewhat more than 40 percent of the money value of all the machinery held by all of American industry.
That means that the 6 to 7 percent of gross national product spent on the military each year has had a set of current and cumulative effects that weigh heavily on the competence of the industrial system as a whole.
 
Q. What have been the practical consequences of these expenditures?
 
Mr. Melman: A major part of American industry has disappeared from the United States. It was put abroad by the owners.
 
Q. But won't those firms come back once it's attractive again for them to relocate in the United States? Isn't that what capitalism is about?
 
Mr. Melman: One crucial point here. If this decay proceeds to the point where there is no longer a capacity to design and manufacture products, there's no coming back.
We spoke earlier of Boeing and its attempt to make electric trolleys. Electric trolleys and electric transportation are now in increasing demand in the United States. But the cities and states looking for these goods are looking abroad because there are no factories in the United States. One example: the locomotives on the Amtrak line are made in Sweden. Where are electric locomotives being made in the United States?
 
Mr. Klein: That's only temporary.
 
Mr. Melman: But soon there won't be any labor force to make those things.
 
Mr. Klein: The labor force changes in the sense that people can be trained. But things are becoming much more automated.
 
Mr. Melman: A number of states are now asking for bids for making high-speed rail transportation: Texas, Florida, California. But the bids are all coming from West Germany and Japan because they have a competent staff and the facilities to produce high-speed electric power.
 
Mr. Klein: Things change in the world. We don't live in a static world. And we're moving ahead, we're moving ahead in some lines. We're falling back in others. But on the whole, we're not losing ground. That is, on the whole, we're not a No. 2 nation, and on the whole, we can gain back whatever we have lost.
 
Mr. Melman: If your baseline is the competence of the basic capital goods producing industries of the United States, then the data of the last decade as now reported in the census of manufacturers show a definite, persistent and large decline in production capacity. Now, that can't be reproduced in a day.
 
Mr. Klein: Of course not in a day. But the way in which certain nations got into a position of pre-eminence in certain markets is through their relatively low military burden and the devotion of their own forces to civilian business. That will come if we cut back here. But it could take one or two decades.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Lawrence Klein, left, and Seymour Melman discuss how to wage a peace economy. (Don Hogan Charles/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The Great New Drive to Rescue Wang's Computers

BYLINE: By STUART MIEHER; Stuart Mieher, a financial journalist, will receive his M.B.A. from the Harvard Business School on Thursday.

DATELINE: LOWELL, Mass.

 BODY:
Richard W. Miller wasn't frightened by difficult business situations. After all, his first job after finishing business school in 1970 had been at the Penn Central Corporation, which was going through what was then the largest bankruptcy proceeding in the nation's history.
But Wang Laboratories Inc., the computer maker that Mr. Miller was tapped to lead last August, was another story. Management was feuding with the banks. Cash was bleeding out, and Wang had just reported a $424 million loss for the fiscal year. Customers were holding back on orders, concerned over whether Wang would survive.
Even these clouds had a silver lining, however. ''One of the good things about finding the company as I found it was that people were ready for change,'' said Mr. Miller. And change he has delivered. More than 5,000 of the company's 25,600 jobs have gone; so have $400 million in annual expense and nearly 85 percent of the Wang's debt. Procedures for serving customers and developing new applications have been revamped. 
Now Mr. Miller is refocusing the company around new products, particularly in an embryonic field known as image processing. His goal: to regain profitability, and quickly.
''Turnarounds usually take two or three years,'' he said. ''We're doing this in half the time. Frankly, it's because we have to.''
Wang is far from healed. For the quarter ended March 31, it reported a loss of $147 million and a 19 percent decline in revenue. But for the first time since the onset of Wang's financial crisis early last year, a number of analysts give the company a better-than-even chance of survival. ''I think they'll make the cut,'' said Robert Cameron of Dataquest Inc., a market research firm. ''I believe Rick Miller understands what it takes to make the transition.'' Mr. Miller, a lanky, 49-year-old Harvard M.B.A., now chief executive officer, is only the second to hold that job in the company's history. The first, of course, was An Wang, the Shanghai-born computer scientist who founded the company in 1951 and remained C.E.O. until his death in March. Known as The Doctor, Mr. Wang steered the company out of troublesome areas and into profitable products with exquisite timing. The company got out of the calculator business just before competition became heated. In the 70's, it won the hearts of secretaries around the world with easy-to-use word-processing systems.
But in the 1980's, Wang's word processors - built around expensive minicomputers - became dinosaurs as personal computers took over. When Wang began making PC's, they were priced too high and weren't compatible with the products from the International Business Machines Corporation that were dominating the industry. Furthermore, service was often poor and expensive.
By 1988, sales were slumping and profits were erratic. Mr. Wang apparently began to lose confidence in his son, Frederick, who had been president and chief operating officer since 1987, and, in 1989, dismissed him. After a hectic 10-day search, The Doctor hired Mr. Miller. Though the Wang family still controls the company through special Class C stock, it shows no signs of opposing the new management.
Mr. Miller came to the job with no experience in the business of making computers. After leaving Penn Central, he had managed the consumer electronics business for the General Electric Company - also a turnaround situation - but left when the operation was sold to Thomson, the French conglomerate, and worked in industrial investment after that.
At Wang, he began with some ostentatious belt-tightening. Out were the reserved parking places for executives and the executive dining room. In was new discipline. ''Under The Doctor, 9 A.M. meetings usually kicked off at about 10:15,'' said one former executive. ''Now they get started at 8:55.''
Mr. Miller attacked the bank debt by selling a range of assets outside Wang's core businesses, such as a financial-data service, thus raising around $600 million. He also brought in consultants who told him that customer service was dreadful, and energy was expended to correct that.
But insuring long-term survival is more complicated. First, Wang has to convince customers that it will stay around. Mr. Miller said he started by answering personally every letter of customer mail on his desk - some 30 per day. And when results for the quarter ended March 31 came in worse than expected, he said he made sure that major customers received his upbeat interpretation of the results by phone or electronic mail before they appeared in the newspapers.
Mr. Miller thinks such efforts have turned the tide: ''It used to be that every phone call I had from a customer, asked me if Wang would survive. In the last 60 days, nobody's asked that question.'' Still, some are doubtful. ''A lot of upper managements wouldn't approve a purchase of Wang at this juncture, and it wouldn't be prudent to propose one,'' said Chris Richard, manager of information services for Johnson & Johnson Hospital Services, a Wang customer.
Wang also has to come up with new products and new applications to reverse its slide in sales. In the past, the organization was great at developing new technologies, but competitors were beating the company by selling solutions to problems. Mr. Miller ordained seven applications groups to focus on customer industries, such as banking and manufacturing. Reorganization isn't complete, but the group already has rediscovered scores of potentially salable applications that had once been developed for individual customers but then set aside.
At one point, Mr. Miller told staffers to get close to the customer, listen to his needs. One engineer replied: ''Just how are you going to get me closer to the customer?'' ''Pack your bags!'' There was silence, then applause. Finally, Wang is focusing product development around its advanced image processing technology. Its Integrated Image System allows a user to enter an image of a document into computer memory. Users can then summon the image and compose a response. One variation, Freestyle, lets executives annotate the document with handwritten or voice messages.
Such technology promises a host of applications. Insurers could use it to process claims more quickly, since they wouldn't have to coordinate flows of paper. One registry of deeds installed a Wang system last year to cut down on the costs of storing the million pages of records to make deed searches easier. Wang isn't the only company in the imaging market; heavyweights including I.B.M. and the Digital Equipment Corporation are also entering the field. Mr. Miller said that eventually imaging ''will drive the demand for all our products.
Wang's critics wonder if change has come too late. ''There's not enough to turn around,'' said Dale Kutnick, president of the Meta Group, a market research firm. Wang, he said, ''is too big to be a niche player, and imaging is a niche market.'' Mr. Kutnick estimates Wang's imaging sales for calendar 1989 at around $150 million, for a market share of 20 percent to 25 percent. Others point to the incompatibility of Wang's traditional products, notably the VS minicomputer, to industry-standard equipment. But there, too, it has been changing. Imaging equipment will be compatible with Unix, one of the industry's major operating systems, and a new line of microcomputers is I.B.M. compatible.
The move toward compatibility does pose tricky problems for Wang, however. The incompatible VS and related equipment account for sales of nearly $1 billion a year, or half Wang's revenue from products. The company does not disclose details on overall revenue, but microcomputers, networking equipment, operations now discontinued and new technology have made up much of the other half.
''They have to satisfy their existing customers by supporting the VS, but from a growth standpoint they have to move to open systems,'' said Michael Howard, program director for office systems for the Gartner Group, market researchers. The dual role strains Wang's research and development budget of roughly $250 million annually. Mr. Miller recognizes the problem. ''When I came, we had 800 projects in R. & D., and only 72 had had feasibility studies,'' he said. The company has whittled the list of R. & D. projects to around 150, with a third of the dollars going to VS development.
''We're committed to doing what we have to do to make the company profitable,'' Mr. Miller said - including, if necessary, additional staff cuts.
 
REVIVING CUSTOMER SERVICE
Wang Laboratories Inc.'s new management brought in Ira C. Magaziner of Providence, R.I., a consultant, to help with its revitalization, and he and his analysts set about to quiz 100 major customers on Wang's strengths and weaknesses. Here, he said, is what customers were saying:
'' 'This company has excellent products, but boy, are they hard to do business with.' ''
Rather than fixing problems, the old management, under founder An Wang, would simply ''create another department to do what the first department was supposed to do, '' Mr. Magaziner said.
The new chief executive, Richard W. Miller, regards Mr. Magaziner's principal value to Wang as having been his complete frankness.
''I could tell you lots of stories'' Mr. Magaziner said recently of what he found at the company. ''Forty percent of orders were late. Of orders entered in the factory, 58 percent were wrong. . . . One of the things about coming into a company that's been very poorly run is you can improve so many things.''
Now that Wang has installed a computerized system connecting salespeople directly to the factories that fill their orders, the consultant said, mistakes on orders have dropped to 10 percent.
Service also appears to be better. ''The number of man-hours we spent reconciling service invoices used to be a problem, and that's been rectified,'' said Chris Richard, manager of information services for Johnson & Johnson Hospital Services, a Wang customer.
The variety of staff and operational changes that have been made appear to have worked. ''We're running better with fewer people,'' Mr. Miller said.

HEADLINE: All About/Platinum;
A Thriving Market Guaranteed By Both Vanity and Pollution

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
When the Ford Motor Company announced in December 1988 that it had developed a catalytic converter that would not require platinum, the metal's price plunged. Platinum producers feared that demand would evaporate. But Ford's new converter is still in testing, and platinum demand is near an all-time high.
Platinum prices have been sustained at about $500 an ounce this year by environmentally conscious governments in the United States and Europe, and by status-conscious Japanese. The metal's leading uses are in jewelry and catalytic converters.
Jewelry accounted for 38 percent of the 3.4 million ounces sold outside Communist (or formerly Communist) nations in 1989. A record 1.15 million ounces of platinum went for jewelry in Japan, almost 20 times the amount used by American jewelers. 
Another 37 percent of the non-Communist world's demand came from producers of catalytic converters. Slightly more than half of this amount went into converters in the United States, the first country whose air pollution standards made the devices necessary. Tougher American pollution laws will require a new generation of converters that will use even more platinum.
The likelihood of tighter environmental standards is making the converters more common in Europe as well, especially in West Germany, where stricter anti-pollution regulations are already in place.
Platinum is also an important chemical catalyst, used in making many products worth far less per ounce than the pure metal: gasoline, fiberglass, optical glass, certain types of rubber, some electrical equipment, even plastic seat covers and nylon carpeting. But the metal's chemical use has diminished as manufacturers seek ways of doing without this costly ingredient.
Investors, too, are becoming less likely to buy platinum as they become disenchanted with the financial returns.
And the music industry's platinum records? They are usually made of nickel, with shiny foil or paint, and not a single gram of platinum.
 
Of Metal and Politics
South Africa, Soviets Are Main Suppliers
For all the economic sanctions the United States has invoked against South African apartheid, trade in platinum continues undisturbed. The non-Communist world depended on South Africa last year for 77 percent of its platinum, and the United States was no exception, buying in about the same proportion.
The only other major source, the Soviet Union, produced about 16 percent of international supplies - up from about 10 percent in previous years, as the Soviet Union tried to earn more Western currencies.
The worldwide stock of platinum is close to meeting demand, but turmoil in either country could disrupt shipments.
Some analysts suggest that political reforms in the Soviet Union and South Africa could bring new militancy among mine workers looking for improved conditions. News of unrest in either country regularly sends platinum prices climbing; calm sends them back down. While jewelry makers could easily turn to gold and silver, automobile makers cannot.
Jeremy S. Croombes, an analyst at Johnson, Matthey P.L.C., the London-based corporation that is the world's largest trader in the metal, said he is especially worried about unrest among black miners in South Africa.
''The black population might want to sit back and let various leaders negotiate on their behalf,'' Mr. Croombs said. ''Or they may want to make their voices heard through strikes and industrial disruption.''
 
Investment Ups and Downs
Once-Healthy Market Collapsed Last Year
For a while, platinum appeared likely to join silver and gold as a mainstay in any precious-metal portfolio. Investment demand, virtually nil until the early 1980's, grew to 155,000 ounces in 1983, 490,000 ounces in 1985 and 630,000 in 1988. A range of bars and coins was proliferating.
But last year, as gold and silver prices stagnated, investors decided they needed only 160,000 more ounces of platinum. The Japanese, the world's most active platinum investors, turned away abruptly, cutting their demand from 415,000 ounces in 1988 to 65,000 in 1989.
''The demand for platinum as an investment tool has been dragged down by gold and silver prices, which have performed more poorly than platinum,'' said Bruce Kaplan, a precious metals consultant in Los Angeles. Last year, platinum prices fell from about $560 an ounce to about $500. Investors are less interested in using platinum as a hedge against inflation, Mr. Kaplan said.
Higher demand from jewelry and industry sources has kept platinum prices relatively stable this year - which might be making the metal less attractive to investors.
Common wisdom in the platinum business is that the metal seems brighter when its price is moving, no matter which way. The Japanese are said to buy when the price is falling, while Europeans and Americans jump in on the way up.
 
New Technology
It Isn't Likely To Curb Demand
For a while, it seemed that Michigan had more to say about platinum prices than producers or investors. In December 1988, Ford announced ambitious tests of a catalytic converter made without platinum. About 40,000 Cougars and Thunderbirds in California were to be equipped with the new devices. On the day of Ford's announcement, platinum prices plunged $71 per ounce. Ask the company how things are going with its platinum-free converters now, and the response is a copy of the 1988 press release.
Platinum assists in converting nitrogen oxide pollutants in automobile exhaust into carbon dioxide and water. Few still believe that pollution control equipment can dispense with platinum entirely.
Ford says that even if converters without platinum are practical now, tighter emissions standards might require platinum to be reintroduced.
Ford contends that its new converters will at least enable the company, and the nation, to lessen its reliance on South Africa and the Soviet Union.
Some auto makers are increasing their use of rhodium, another precious metal that is often found in platinum ores. ''Rhodium will undoubtedly be an essential component of auto catalysts used in Europe,'' Mr. Croombs said. Its use in catalytic converters increased 16 percent worldwide in 1989. At $1,600 an ounce, rhodium is far more costly and rare than platinum, but also more efficient for use in converters.
But even as some turn to other metals, the demand for platinum in converters increased 9 percent in 1989 and is likely to grow more quickly this year. The growth is likely to be greatest in Western Europe, where only three of every 10 cars already have the converters.
 
WHEN PRICE IS NO OBJECT
Where price is no object, platinum fuel cells are fine. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has used the exotic batteries to power its space shuttles.
Now the developers of these cells need to make the giant leap back to earth and find less expensive, everyday applications.
The cells, which look somewhat like stacks of car batteries, use platinum to catalyze a chemical combination of hydrogen and oxygen, generating electricity. Lee Marino, a spokesman for Johnson Matthey P.L.C., said that the fuel cells waste 10 percent less of their power than do standard utility engines.
Major corporations are eager to pursue this new technology. International Fuel Cells, a division of the United Technologies Corporation, is already selling platinum fuel-cell generators that can heat and provide emergency power for small apartment buildings.
A Japanese joint venture between International Fuel Cells and the Toshiba Corporation developed the cells for the space shuttle.
In the longer range, scientists say that the power cells can propel buses and delivery trucks. ''There are a variety of potential applications for the future that we're only beginning to explore,'' Mr. Morino said.

HEADLINE: FORUM;
U.S. Is the Leader in Decentralization

BYLINE: By STEVEN SCHLOSSSTEIN; Steven Schlossstein, a business consultant based in Princeton, N.J., is author of ''The End of the American Century.''

 BODY:
We are now entering an era in which our political allies - Germany and Japan - are our most formidable economic adversaries, and we do not know how to manage these changing circumstances yet, least of all in Washington.
The new era is marked by the end of the American half-century, with the United States no longer the dominant player. But while the conventional wisdom suggests we look first to the Federal Government for leadership, a contrarian view, more in tune with the changing reality, says Washington should be the last place we look. 
Why? Because the information revolution has rendered centralized, inflexible bureaucracies - public or private - obsolete and inoperative. Decentralization, individual autonomy and choice have become the watchwords of this new era, and America - not Japan, not Germany - has emerged as the clear leader.
A brief glance at innovative reforms in public education and at new private-sector strategies provides the evidence of this powerful shift away from centrally controlled models.
In Dade County, Fla., experiments in shared decision-making are creating a new managerial model called school-basing autonomy. It began two years ago when 32 public schools chose to be managed by teams of teachers and parents, not bureaucrats.
In Minnesota, a new law lets parents anywhere in the state choose their child's school, eliminating residence requirements and forcing schools to compete. A dozen states have emulated this model.
The point is, these pockets of experimentation, restructuring and reform are in place now, and others are sure to follow. They are all being created by pressures unique to their environments, not by fiat from Washington.
In the private sector, imaginative forms of what I call complementary strategic alliances are emerging to create new decentralized business strategies for this new era.
''Tiering'' is a cross-border concept that merges strength with weakness in a cooperative way. The Intel Corporation, a first-tier American microprocessor maker, has set up an alliance with NMB Semiconductors, a second-tier Japanese memory-chip maker. The purpose is to develop a new generation of D-RAM's for Intel's market.
Non-Japanese Asian alliances are an innovative way for American companies to compete with Japanese companies in the home market. The General Electric Company has joined Korea's Samsung to make medical equipment, and is exporting its systems back to America to blunt Hitachi Ltd.'s market-penetration moves.
For all the talk about the need for Washington to provide new leadership for the new era, we ought to be looking instead to the places where America's leadership is being forged.
With the collapse of the central command economies and the death of Communism, Japan's politically authoritarian brand of capitalism will probably move into this vacuum to compete against American-style capitalism. But the new American variant, based on the decentralized, autonomous leadership examples cited, will not be the centrally controlled welfare-state capitalist model dominated by bureaucracy and linked to the pessimism of decline. It will be a more vigorous and vibrant entrepreneurial capitalism, driven by a spirit of American optimism and renewal, much more appropriate to the demands of a new age.

HEADLINE: The Bank of Tokyo Responds

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''Japan's Stubborn Overseas Bank'' (April 29) fails to appreciate that the Bank of Tokyo is a unique institution and analyze it on that basis. Instead, it tries to force it into the mold of Japanese city banks. There are crucial distinctions:
* From its origins as the Yokohama Specie Bank in 1880, Bank of Tokyo has been specifically designed to provide financial leadership for the internationalization of Japan. It has pioneered overseas markets since it began business in New York in 1880 and in London in 1881. Today, it exercises its leading role in the private sector for Japan's newly assumed responsibilities as the major creditor nation and one of the largest providers of development aid. 
* In the past 110 years, the bank has built an unparalleled international financial system with more than 300 offices in 42 nations.
* The bank has such deep roots in the key markets of Asia, Europe and the Americas that it has long since diversified from entirely Japanese business to handling a large volume of indigenous business of the host countries and of multinational corporations.
The article missed the synergies between this powerful international system and our strengthening domestic operations. As more Japanese companies become internationalized, more have become Bank of Tokyo customers in Japan. The bank has benefited significantly from this trend by, as you stated, ''simply doing what it was designed to do: focus on overseas business.''
The bank's domestic business is also benefiting from the shift to transactional banking, where the bank has great expertise, especially in foreign exchange-related areas, in developing new products and in putting together complex deals.
Finally, the article asserts that ''adding more pressure for a merger is deregulation of Japanese bank deposits.'' As of March 1989, the ratio of regulated interest-rate deposits to total domestic yen-denominated deposits for the top five city banks was 30.5 percent, compared with 10.3 percent for the Bank of Tokyo. Logically, then, the adverse impact of deregulated deposits should be three times greater on other banks than on the Bank of Tokyo.
We in ''this proud institution'' believe we are going to do very well in the increasingly global world economy. It seems we were made for each other.
 
KENJI YOSHIZAWA
Resident Senior Managing Director
Bank of Tokyo Ltd.
New York, May 16

HEADLINE: The Nation;
In Moscow, Yeltsin Has A Summit To Himself

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
IT truly was the far side of the summit here last week as Boris N. Yeltsin could be found leaning back in the Kremlin and waxing presidential, using some of the cold war bromide language about ''mutual understanding'' to talk of mercy toward his antagonist, who was in Washington. ''I am prepared to go a good part of the distance towards Gorbachev,'' Mr. Yeltsin said, delighting the nation's groundlings as he ascended to presidential office - President of Russia, the nation's heartland republic - and immediately began talking as Mikhail S. Gorbachev's equal.
''There would be no big, no small presidents,'' Mr. Yeltsin declared, expanding still another proposal to decentralize authority away from Moscow and Mr. Gorbachev's national presidency. ''They would be equal,'' he suggested, offering if not a seriously promising plan at least some Orwellian amusement in a battered land where the people hoard food as the main way of taking the future seriously. 
Mr. Yeltsin could be savored every day here last week making some such statement, calling - in his first 100 hours in office - for the central government's resignation, for a blitzkrieg declaration of Russian republic sovereignty, and then making a point of personally befriending the rebellious Baltic leaders who have been such a cross for Mr. Gorbachev. And all this while the Soviet leader paced far off through the summit meeting's planned panoply, partnered in a slow fox trot with President Bush in comparison with Mr. Yeltsin's ragtime solo back home.
Maybe people elsewhere were absorbed in the latest news from Washington about chemical demilitarization and most-favored-nation status, but for sheer demonstration of political throw weight, the Soviet public was relishing Boris Nikolayevich back in center ring. He was crinkly smiled, thunder voiced and unfawning as ever, offering scathing complaint about Mr. Gorbachev's dalliance over promises of economic rebirth and true political opposition. Even the media here, normally so enamored of meetings at the top, paid more attention to the local news than to the doings from afar.
''This pyramid must be turned upside down,'' the husky street politician advised. Mr. Yeltsin carefully withheld critical details of his own prescriptions for reviving the economy. He preferred to focus on the easier populist demands to have Russia profit more directly from its oil reserves and to have the people somehow protected from price rises if socialist controls ever yield to free markets.
In real political terms, Mr. Yeltsin's immediate prospects may be limited beyond a fresh shower of celebrity. The Russian parliament is deeply divided and will not likely be a passive vehicle for his career. There also is no mechanism for national opposition politics on the horizon. But at the very least, Mr. Yeltsin's national franchise as a dominant talker has been renewed and in a showcase setting for him to continue his complaints about Mr. Gorbachev that so refresh the tired Russian people.
 
Stepping on Gorbachev's Coattails
Mr. Gorbachev could not mask heartfelt disappointment as he offered a tight, thin smile and bitter words at the news of the resurrection of Mr. Yeltsin, the onetime protege he sought to banish politically from the Kremlin in 1987. Mr. Yeltsin survived by going, unlike Mr. Gorbachev, directly to the people in popular election, then winning a parliamentary free-for-all by bucking the party monolith that still underpins Mr. Gorbachev's power in the national legislature. The Soviet leader's dark reaction was beamed back here as part of the summit coverage and it was hardly perceived as a demonstration of self-confidence among a Soviet audience that, so dispirited in this shopworn country, managed a collective leer of appreciation for the spectacle of Yeltsin redux.
President Gorbachev was probably more bruised than he admitted, for he had personally led a stop-Yeltsin drive while he might have been expected to be doing his pre-summit cramming, only to see the Russian parliament reject his wishes once the public began heavily pressuring lawmakers for Mr. Yeltsin's election. Even though it took three votes by the parlia-ment to elect him, and even though his victory margin was small, Mr. Yeltsin has been the nation's most popular politician, in the measure of raw street enthusiasm, ever since he made a name by bluntly criticizing Communism's shoddiness, in everything from the bare Moscow shops to the inflated promises of Mr. Gorbachev's early renewal promises. That latter outburst cost him his future as a party careerist in 1987 and it may account for Mr. Yeltsin's ever-more-beaming smile since then, for Mr. Gorbachev's attempts to discredit him have only increased the public's support of Mr. Yeltsin's new career as an insurgent.
When he comes down from the summit, President Gorbachev will find other fresh symptoms of the continuing de facto decentralization of Soviet authority. Last week, militant Armenians and Soviet troops once again clashed, with 24 fatalities. The Moldavian republic was recognizing rebellious Lithuania. The Byelorussian parliament was joining the rebellion against the food price increases. And the Ukrainian parliament was debating its own path toward sovereignty.
Amid all this growing dissent in the republics' debating halls, Mr. Yeltsin clearly was hurrying to fashion himself as the Soviet version of Mr. Republican, calling for bilateral agreements and market freedoms between republics as one of an array of methods to bypass the Kremlin's traditional central dictate.
Mr. Yeltsin claims he is a creatively, if haphazardly, evolving politician rather than the model of bombast his critics claim to see. In breaking from the Communist system, he is almost poignantly fatalistic at times, as he imagines plots to do him in and even sees Mr. Gorbachev's hand in his own success. ''If Gorbachev didn't have a Yeltsin he would have had to invent one,'' Mr. Yeltsin has written, saying for Mr. Gorbachev to play ''the wise, omniscient hero'' he needs Yeltsin ''the bully-boy, the madcap radical.''
When he comes home President Gorbachev will likely find the omniscient hero's role to have been easier up on the summit than in the heart of Russia. Now President Gorbachev will find President Yeltsin presiding most nights on one of the TV channels, leading a debating hall full of legislators, with a little bell for keeping order and interrupting for his own grand asides, just like Mr. Gorbachev does in the national debating hall. As ancient Rome offered bread and circuses in its most threadbare days, Moscow more and more is making do with the sound bites and clashing egos of modern democratic campaigning, an ever more necessary entertainment relief, perhaps, as real executive programs prove so slow in arriving.

HEADLINE: The Work Week Grows;
Tales From The Digital Treadmill

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN

 BODY:
ON Wall Street in the 1960's, there was the theory of the paddling duck. An employee would slip into the office at daybreak, do a couple of hours' hard work and then go out for breakfast. He would amble back as his colleagues arrived and would glide through the day, impressing everyone with his effortless mastery of his chores. Today the worker would have nothing on anyone else. The executive suite and a lot of humbler domains beyond Wall Street have become seas of paddling ducks, among them Clark Evans Downs.
On a misty Friday evening in Chevy Chase, Md., Mr. Downs, his wife, Emilie, and their daughters, Morgan and Julia, have finished supper and are watching a videotape of ''Cold Sassy Tree.'' As he watches, Mr. Downs flips through briefs and contracts that he has brought home from the Washington office of a leading international law firm where he is a partner. ''My firm has a word-processing crew that is available 24 hours a day,'' he says. ''I can work at the office to midnight, hand something to them and say I want it at eight the next morning, and by God it's there.''
Mrs. Downs says: ''At 7 P.M. on a Saturday night, he left something at the office. We went to a concert and he went back at 10 P.M. He reviewed it. Then he faxed it somewhere.'' 
Among 88 million people with full-time jobs last year, nearly 24 percent - largely executives, professionals, self-employed people, journalists, bureaucrats, and the secretaries and clerks who toil alongside them - spent 49 or more hours a week on the job, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Ten years ago only 18 percent worked so much.
A management training concern, Priority Management Systems Inc. in Vancouver, British Columbia, recently surveyed 1,344 American and foreign business executives and found that 57 percent of them worked 6 to 20 hours beyond the 40-hour week - 20 percent longer on average than a decade ago. ''The leisure society in America is a myth,'' said Jerome M. Rossow, president of the Work in America Institute in Scarsdale, N.Y. Last year in the United States the sales of the Filofax company, whose elaborate notebooks help people navigate through the clutter of their lives, hit $4.2 million, more than double the amount in 1987.
The American work ethic seems to have become an obsession. Part of the problem is that salary increases continue to lag behind inflation, so workers have to run harder each year just to stay even. At the same time, fewer people are entering the work force now that the baby boomers are grown up and employed; with fewer new workers for hire, companies try to squeeze more out of the ones they already have.
Students of the psyches of hard-toiling workers say that many people thrive on 60- and 70-hour weeks and the fast-pace of the electronic workplace. But others find it a sweatshop. One result is a surge in early retirement among men, who have been in the work force longer than most women. In the end, some economists say, it is not even clear that the economy is benefiting from all the frenetic activity.
The Government says more workers than ever held both a regular job last year and at least one part-time job - 6.2 percent of all working people. The moonlighting among men hasn't changed very much over two decades, but among women, it has soared. For many factory workers, store clerks and others with more menial jobs, the 35- to 40-hour, five-day week remains entrenched and protected by law and the unions. But in factories people are working almost four hours of overtime a week, at time-and-a-half pay, the most in nearly 20 years.
Some managers say that even in a conventional eight-hour day they work much harder, thanks in part to their arsenals of technological gimmickry. They have fax machines, cellular telephones, paging devices, laptop computers that they use on planes and desktop computers that let them send electronic letters, orders and contracts in seconds, across oceans. An employee at the American Telephone and Telegraph Company can dispatch messages he composes on his computer to someone else's faraway fax machine. ''I type 'ATT MAIL!' then 'FAX!' then the phone number and hit the 'execute,' key,'' he said. ''I send stuff that way to Hong Kong, Singapore, Brussels.''
Peter A. Hoffman is the partner in charge of litigation consulting at the accounting firm of Deloitte & Touche in New York. He recently spent three or four days a week for 14 weeks in Denver advising a company that the Securities and Exchange Commission was investigating.
''During that time I was asked to work on a lawsuit relating to a hostile takeover attempt,'' Mr. Hoffman said. ''From Denver, I was able to put together a team in New York, and material they produced in the day was faxed to me so I could work on it at the hotel at night. Some nights it came to 200 pages.''
Sheila Griffin, the corporate advertising director for Motorola Inc., clicks on her cellular phone at 5:30 A.M. as she sets off from home in St. Charles, Ill., for the hour drive to work. First she checks her ''voice mail,'' the recorded messages people leave on her phone. ''Then I make calls to Europe,'' she said. ''I get to the office and check the faxes. I get Europe out of the way and then work on things in our own time zone.'' Ms. Griffin gets home to her husband, a civil engineer, and two young children 13 hours after she left and spends three hours with them. ''Then at about 9:30 the phone rings,'' she said, ''and it's Japan.''
People give many reasons for working harder or longer. Most say they must to make ends meet. Some say they also relish the bustle. Some think that if they don't work harder, the competition will. An executive at Chase Manhattan Bank said that when he stays on at the office and takes the 8:10 train home to Old Greenwich, or the 8:40 or 9:10, ''I see a lot more Japanese. They're working late. You can't help but notice.''
Some people are running scared, not from the Japanese but from their own bosses. In the 1980's, hundreds of American companies eliminated whole layers of middle management to cut costs. Those remaining fear they will be next. ''They feel they have to work harder,'' Marylin Puder-York, a clinical psychologist in New York, said. ''They want to prove to their bosses that what they are doing is very important.'' They work harder, too, Mr. Rosow said, ''because the companies no longer have back-up people to pass on the work during peak loads or crises.''
Some people are getting nudged in subtler ways. Gil Gordon, a communications consultant, said many employers arrange generous discounts for their workers to buy computers for their personal use. ''But part of me wonders if that just makes it easier for them to extend the work day,'' Mr. Gordon said. ''You can get creeping expectations on the part of managers that it should be the norm for people to put in two or three extra hours a day on home computers.''
Maureen Pearce, a 50-year-old secretary in the Third Avenue offices of the New York law firm of Debevoise & Plimpton, said that when she started there nine years ago she had an I.B.M. Selectric typewriter on her desk, a Dictaphone and a telephone. Today she has a Canon memory typewriter-printer, a Compaq computer, an Amdek monitor, a Hewlett-Packard laser printer, a Dictaphone and a multiple function telephone.
''I didn't like the change,'' she said. But Debevoise & Plimpton helped her along. ''They gave wonderful training, and then refresher courses, and they paid me overtime to attend them,'' she said. Thoroughly hooked on the hardware, she has become hooked as well on working overtime with her boss, Christopher Smeall. ''My hours are 9:30 to 5:30,'' she said, ''but we schedule most mornings to get in at 8. I get a kick out of doing even what he is not sure I can handle.''
But others find that the quickening pace of the volley is burning them out. ''They're in a time-compressed state,'' said Joseph Ruffin, a psychiatrist in Oklahoma City. ''They've got more bellyaches and more headaches. They've got more diarrhea. I ask my patients: 'What if you were an automobile? What shape would you be in?' They say, 'I wouldn't last three weeks.' ''
Boris Rifkin, a psychiatrist in New Haven, said anxiety disorders have mushroomed. ''I tell these people: 'Change your behavior pattern. Go to the supermarket and wait in the longest line. Do the relaxing things. Come into work late and don't be uptight about it.' ''
Many analysts suspect that the extra work does no more good for the economy than it does for the health. Indeed, they ask, if people are producing more with their labor, why is the economy so sluggish? And why is American productivity - the value of goods and services workers produce - growing so much more slowly than in Asia and Europe?
One explanation might be that many people are just spinning their wheels. Executives hustle from meeting to meeting and make calls to disembodied voices on answering machines because those people, too, are in meetings. Michael V. Fortino, a management consultant in Pittsburgh, says the average professional worker will spend three years of his life in meetings and two playing telephone tag.
''Working longer and harder is not the same as working smarter,'' Mr. Rosow said.
Ronald E. Kutscher, associate commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, said, ''We may be getting more throughput but no more output.'' Or perhaps, he said, people really are producing more but no one has figured out how to gauge their production. Mr. Kutscher said he can write seven drafts of an economic analysis with his computer now in the same time it took to write two or three a few years ago. ''Can I argue that the article is better?'' he said. ''I don't know. It isn't being measured.''
