HEADLINE: The World;
Voting Isn't Helping in Guatemala

BYLINE: By LINDSEY GRUSON

DATELINE: GUATEMALA

 BODY:
MORE often than not, President Vinicio Cerezo packs a pistol under his custom-made suits - a sign, he says, that he will defend his Government with his life. But for many Guatemalans, the gun is a bitter symbol of the carnage plaguing this country, and of the Government's failure to uproot the military's regimented control.
''Elections are merely a note in the song of democracy,'' Msgr. Ricardo Urioeste, a Salvadoran critic of rightist repression in the region, often says in criticizing the United States' reliance on voting as the barometer of democracy. ''Washington keeps playing the note and expecting us to hear the tune.'' 
When Mr. Cerezo was elected five years ago as the first civilian president in almost two decades, Guatemalans heard the song. His inauguration in 1986 was greeted with national jubilation. After a generation of often bloody military rule, many equated elections with democracy, and democracy with a better life.
But far less changed than these Guatemalans expected. Mutilated bodies are still dumped by the sides of roads. Once again people are avoiding political discussions and fleeing the country. Military commanders remain regional warlords, with absolute power over their subjects and impunity from civilian prosecution. And the armed forces retain a de facto veto over almost all important Government decisions. As Guatemalans prepare for presidential elections this year, this has brought deep disillusionment, not just with the President but also with democracy.
When he took office, Mr. Cerezo tried to make changes, starting by trying to integrate the Army into the democratic process. He sought to raise the minimum wage and rework the tax code. But the oligarchy eviscerated the tax code and ended up reducing the already low payments made by the rich. Inflation effectively cut the minimum wage.
The turning point for him came during a May 1988 coup attempt, the first of two. The high command suppressed the uprising, but in return Mr. Cerezo was forced to give the military a free hand in security policies, break off talks with Marxist guerrillas and give command of the National Police and the Treasury Police to the military. He seemed to give up on governing, preferring to spend his time yachting and partying.
 
The Army Controls
So today, civilian government exists largely in name. The armed forces build the roads, provide services in rural areas, and run the government television station. ''The Army is much more efficient,'' said Edmond Mulet, an opposition deputy in the National Assembly. ''We civilians don't know how to run the Government.''
Mr. Cerezo's defenders say he would quickly have been overthrown if he had challenged the Army's institutional prerogatives. His critics say he was never up to the job and failed to demand systematic changes. ''The big success is that there were two coup attempts and both failed,'' a European diplomat said. ''That's a real success, but perhaps the only success.''
Even the United States has all but given up on the present Government. Washington used to point to Mr. Cerezo as an example of success in its effort to foster democracy. After his election, it renewed military aid and increased economic support. For the last two years, however, the United States has been increasingly critical, and this year recalled its ambassador to protest a failure to prosecute human rights abuses. The criticism may in part be pique for Mr. Cerezo's insistence on trying to become a bridge to the Sandinistas when they were in power.
The United States has also been disappointed by Mr. Cerezo's inability - some diplomats and Guatemalans say refusal - to combat an increase in drug trafficking. Since his election, the United States says, Guatemala has become the world's sixth largest producer of opium poppies and a major transshipment point for cocaine.
 
Yearning for the Old Days
Since the election four years ago was so closely equated with hopes for fundamental change, there is a growing backlash today against the whole system in Guatemala. Increasingly, it is viewed as incapable of solving the country's deep-rooted problems, which have been aggravated by the collapse in the last several years of the international prices for coffee and cotton, the two principal exports. ''People say to themselves, if this is a democracy, let's go to a military government,'' Mr. Mulet lamented.
In response to the corruption and rising urban crime, many long for the stability of authoritarian government. Opinion polls indicate a surge in support for the presidential campaign of the former dictator Efrain Rios Montt, whose 16-month rule in the early 1980's was marked by repression in which thousands died.
The Constitution appears to forbid the general, as a former president who came to power through a coup, from taking office. But law has a narrow base here, and little tradition. A waiter at a fine restaurant said he planned to vote for the general despite the Constitution. ''We need a strongman!'' the waiter said.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 6, Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1006 words

HEADLINE: The Region;
It's Grand And Old But It's No Party

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
THERE were 2,620,288 enrolled Republicans in New York State at last count. Last week, the Republican State Committee couldn't find one to run against Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.
Not that Republican leaders solicited every party member, of course. But they failed to impress at least 19 potential candidates into their seemingly hopeless cause before finally enlisting a Manhattan economist, Pierre A. Rinfret, a lapsed Republican whose enrollment card lists no party affiliation. 
What has the party of Roosevelt (Theodore), Dewey and Rockefeller (Nelson) come to? Why did the Reagan revolution, which helped revitalize the Republican Party in many other states, leave New York Republicans adrift beyond the national mainstream in their own political backwater? Republicans have won five of the last six Presidential elections, but they last elected a Governor of New York in 1970. New York's Republican United States Senator, Alfonse M. D'Amato, was elected in 1980 only after defeating the venerable incumbent, Jacob K. Javits, for the nomination.
In New York today, the G.O.P. is neither grand nor much of a party. Arguably, it is old, though. The youngest recruit to the statewide ticket designated last week is George F. T. Yancy Jr., a cheese company executive who is 42 years old and is the former Wayne County party chairman. The party's third new face on the ticket is Bernard C. Smith, a former Suffolk County District Attorney who, like Mr. Rinfret, is 66 years old.
National and New York Republicans have often been estranged since Barry Goldwater defeated Nelson A. Rockefeller for the Presidential nomination in 1964, although the alienation began years earlier. ''New York has been out of step with the national Republican Party since the party derived its strength from the Sunbelt,'' says John Buckley, a Washington-based Republican political consultant whose uncle James was elected a United States Senator from New York on the Conservative Party line in 1970. ''Nelson Rockefeller's dominance of the party right up to the rise of Reagan,'' Mr. Buckley said, was emblematic of the divergence between Goldwater and Reagan conservatism and a more moderate brand of Republicanism tailored to a largely urban state punctuated by Democratic power bases.
 
Antidote to Rockefeller
''The New York State Republican Party,'' says Roger Stone, another Republican consultant, ''was never part of the Reagan revolution.'' But the New York Conservative Party was. It was created as an antidote to what was described disdainfully as Rockefeller Republicanism. The same philosphical tensions that led to its formation resonated last week in the Conservatives' refusal to endorse Mr. Rinfret because he - and, for the first time, the Republican Party platform - endorsed abortion rights, another apparent concession to political realities in New York.
Mr. Rockefeller's resignation to fill a vacancy for Vice President in 1973, after 15 years as Governor, triggered the decline of a state party that had become dependent on his personal largesse. ''The New York Republican Party,'' Mr. Buckley said, ''is the paradigm of welfare dependency.''
Even so, said Richard Rosenbaum, the Republican state chairman at the time, ''there is nothing so important to a political party in any state than the governorship.'' In 1974, the Republicans lost that, too. Malcolm Wilson, Mr. Rockefeller's lieutenant governor, succeeded him briefly, but failed to win the governorship in his own right. Mr. Rockefeller had bred no other political heirs.
But that was 16 years ago. Since then the party has wandered in a political desert, befriended periodically by outsiders for its rubric, but unceremoniously dumped thereafter to fend for itself. The 1982 gubernatorial nominee, Lewis E. Lehrman, a political neophyte, came close to winning. Like Mr. Rockefeller, he financed his own campaign. Like Mr. D'Amato, he capitalized on early support from the Conservatives to wag the Republican dog. ''Lew Lehrman created a new party for the sake of a campaign,'' said John Buckley. ''When Lew lost interest in being the leading Republican in the state, the myth of party fell apart.''
Mr. Stone suggests the Republican slump is cyclical. ''Had Lehrman gotten 51 percent of the vote instead of 49 percent,'' Mr. Stone said, then this story might be about the deprivation of the Democratic Party. What Mr. Lehrman's near miss proved, he said, was that ''if you've got the money, the coalition can be put together in this state.''
Mr. Rinfret, who is a multimillionaire, may give Governor Cuomo a run for his money, but that would still leave Mr. Cuomo with plenty. He already has raised $7 million in his campaign for a third term.
 
Keeping the Senate
Perhaps all Mr. Rinfret can realistically hope for is to deny Mr. Cuomo the record vote he piled up in 1986. What concerns Republican leaders more is retaining control of the State Senate, without which they could be virtually excluded from reshaping congressional and legislative districts on the basis of the 1990 Census.
State Senator Roy M. Goodman, the Manhattan Republican leader who recruited Mr. Rinfret, argued that the selection process itself had galvanized the party out of complacency and had given it new vitality. (It was Mr. Goodman who recruited Mr. Rinfret after a mutual friend, Lawrence C. Leeds Jr., stumbled upon his name as he and Mr. Goodman were rummaging through their personal telephone directories in search of a candidate.) What emerged from last week's convention, Mr. Goodman maintained, was a ''Tiffany-quality ticket'' and a party that, to accommodate divergent views, had pitched its tent as broadly as it had cast its net for a candidate. Whether what happens under the Republican tent between now and November is more akin to a circus or to a revival meeting remains to be seen. What has happened so far is ''terribly embarrassing,'' said Guy V. Molinari, the Republican Staten Island Borough President. ''Anyone who suggests it's not isn't being honest.''

HEADLINE: The Region;
When Welfare Pays the Rent

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
CAN a family of three survive in New York City on $286 a month for rent? The city and state maintain that it can. That is how much they give to the typical welfare family, a single mother with two children, for basic shelter.
But most housing experts say the grants given to the 287,000 families living on welfare in New York City bear little relation to the marketplace. The grants, called shelter allowances, are far below rents for vacant apartments in even the meanest of New York's neighborhoods. Welfare mothers often end up using money earmarked for food and clothing to pay rent, or living doubled- and tripled-up in cramped quarters with friends and relatives. The low level of the grants has also contributed significantly to evictions and, thus, to homelessness, housing experts say. 
The adequacy of the housing grant - which is set by the state and paid by the city, state and Federal governments - is seldom questioned in Albany or City Hall because of fiscal constraints and because the poor wield little political power. The question is about to be debated, though, in the courts. Twenty welfare mothers have sued the State Department of Social Services, asserting that the grant is inadequate and asking the courts to order an increase.
Numbers tell much of the story. Welfare recipients typically are single mothers with two or three children. A mother with three children receives a $312 monthly shelter allowance. Recipients also get about $200 in food stamps and another check for food, clothing, utilities and other expenses. This second check is $291 a month for a mother with two children and $375 for a mother with three.
Periodic surveys of New York's housing market have shown a growing gap between the welfare housing check and rents, particularly in privately owned buildings, where most of the poor live. There were virtually no apartments available for less than $400 a month, according to the most recent survey, in 1987.
Vacant, habitable apartments with two bedrooms, the minimum space sought by most families, start at about $550 a month and go as high as $700 and $800 a month in the city's poor neighborhoods, say social workers who help homeless families find permanent housing. In such a tight market, the $286 or $312 allowance can be a ticket to a homeless shelter.
''Nobody can live on that in New York, they just can't,'' said George Sternlieb, the University Professor of Urban Affairs at Rutgers University. ''You're seeing doubling up. You're seeing a whole subterranean world of people coping to get by, because the numbers really do not make sense.''
State officials would not discuss the housing grants because of the pending lawsuit.
Many welfare families do manage to survive on the shelter allowance. Generally they have lived for a long time in the same apartment. If their home is in a privately owned building, rent increases have likely been limited by rent stabilization. If they live in public housing projects or older, city-owned apartment buildings, their housing grant is accepted as the rent.
 
Squeezed by the Cost
But welfare families who have entered the system recently, and many if not most who have been in it for a while, are squeezed extraordinarily by the cost of housing. Christopher Lamb, one of three lawyers for the Legal Aid Society who are representing the welfare mothers in their suit, said poor families often must spend 60 percent to 70 percent of their income on housing. They use food money to help pay the rent, and they fall behind on their electrical bill. Often, they also fall behind on the rent, and many wind up in housing court, facing eviction. ''We see people all the time who are about to lose apartments that rent for $400 a month or $450 a month,'' Mr. Lamb said. ''And they have no reasonable chance of finding another $400 or $450 apartment.''
Many families who are evicted find themselves in city shelters and in welfare hotels - often at the cost of $1,500 and $2,000 a month for cramped, decrepit rooms. Mr. Lamb and Bonnie Brower, executive director of the Association of Neighborhood and Housing Development, a citywide coalition of community groups, contend that it would be less expensive, and more humane, for government to pay higher rent subsidies to keep welfare families in their homes.
Some conservative housing economists, like Peter D. Salins, chairman of the Department of Urban Affairs and Planning at Hunter College, agree that the shelter allowance is too low and has contributed to homelessness. Mr. Salins said the state should eliminate the housing grant altogether, consolidating all welfare payments into a single check ''to let welfare families decide how to allocate their resources.''
He added, though, that the courts should not be deciding welfare policy, including the level of the shelter allowance. ''I don't think that this involves a sufficient constitutional issue to warrant court involvement,'' Mr. Salins said.
But many housing experts want the courts to confront the question head-on. The state's highest court, the Court of Appeals, ruled in April that the shelter allowance must bear a reasonable relation to the cost of housing. The court returned the welfare mothers' case to State Supreme Court in Manhattan, where a trial is expected by the fall on the grant's adequacy.
''New York is finally catching up to reality,'' Mr. Sternlieb said. ''One would hope that, if there is an increase, New York will also reconsider code enhancement and enforcement, to make sure this doesn't turn out to be a giveaway to building owners.''

HEADLINE: Alabama Bound

BYLINE: By Howell Raines; Howell Raines, the Washington editor of The New York Times, was born in Alabama in 1943 and lived there until 1971.

 BODY:
During a recent visit to the Alabama Archives in Montgomery, I felt a heavy hand on my shoulder and turned to find the bearish figure of Clarke Stallworth, who was my first city editor 25 years ago at The Birmingham Post-Herald. Stallworth, now 64 years old, had been one of my early journalistic heroes for his crusade against the inequities of a tax system that soaked wage-earners so that United States Steel and other out-of-state corporations could pay token taxes on their vast acreage in Alabama. It seemed coincidence of a rare sort to run into this old fire-eater while I was visiting my native state to report on the post-Wallace era in Alabama politics. Serendipity piled atop coincidence when Stallworth revealed that he was on his way to join a panel discussion on the same subject. 
As Stallworth and his fellow panelists spoke in the auditorium of the archives building, I felt as if I - or rather, my native state - had been caught in a time warp. For years, Stallworth observed, the Legislature's fame rested on the fact that it included ''more crooks per capita'' than any other location in the state. Prof. William D. Barnard of the University of Alabama, the leading authority on the history of the state's Democratic Party, added that Alabama's resistance to political change and its dependence on outside capital had kept it in ''the shady part of the Sun Belt.'' Anne Permaloff of Auburn University at Montgomery, a biographer of the failed populist giant ''Big Jim'' Folsom, added that the problems of education, public corruption and tax equity that are being discussed in the 1990 gubernatorial campaign are precisely those that were debated in Folsom's 1946 campaign. ''They haven't changed,'' she said.
Of course, panel discussions on politics often produce hyperbolic statements. But what I found in a series of visits to Alabama was an astonishing unanimity of shame and rage that while the New South awakening has energized every other state in the region, Alabama remains in what one statewide magazine called ''a sleeper hold.'' And in a historic shift of public opinion, many conservatives and a few business leaders are joining scholars, journalists and political liberals in denouncing outside corporations for their historical failure to pay their civic rent.
As Ray Scott, a millionaire fishing entrepreneur and George Bush's campaign chairman in the state, put it: ''We do everything but kiss them all over their body from the bottom of their you-know-what to the top of the whatchamacallit trying to get these people to come in here and bring another industry in, and in one way we allow them to rape us.
They rape our streams. They rape our resources, and they bring a small payday in,'' while paying property taxes that are ''an absolute joke.'' As a result, says Scott, who is known nationally as founder of the Bass Anglers Sportsman Society and as President Bush's fishing partner, ''we're sucking the hind tit of poverty in this state in almost every count.''
Such comments represent a great leap forward in Alabama's political consciousness. Rage against corporate exploitation has always been a submerged theme in Alabama's political psychology. But to protest the state's status as an economic colony of the Northeast was to risk being branded a ''radical.'' In the 1990 campaign, that has changed.
''Alabama is to the rest of the nation almost as this country was to England 200 or 250 years ago,'' says Paul Hubbert, a leading candidate in the Democratic gubernatorial primary on Tuesday. ''We are a supplier of raw products. The gas coming out of Mobile Bay will be piped to Chesapeake Bay to turn the wheels of other people's industry. We'll buy back the finished product from them, and then to add insult to injury, they'll pay us 22 bucks a ton and they'll ship poison in here and bury it in our soil. And I think that makes us the equivalent of a third world nation.''
Scott's and Hubbert's comments are reminders that colorful characters speaking a language rich in images of sex, violence and aggrievement are part of Alabama's political tradition. In the early 1800's, the land rush known as Alabama Fever peopled the state's mineral-rich hills and fertile coastal plain with a rough mix of planters, horse-traders, horny-handed woodsmen and enslaved blacks. The state's love of confrontation and shady dealing - and the outsider mentality that was marketed as a national political attitude by George C. Wallace - are rooted in that period. Its feelings of aggrievement intensified after the turn of the century, when J. P. Morgan and other capitalists used Alabama iron and coal to fatten bank accounts in Pittsburgh and New York.
These corporations probably deserve as much credit as the Ku Klux Klan for institutionalizing violence as a way of settling social disputes. They used their political influence to convert the Alabama National Guard into a union-busting army. Having watched bullets, dynamite and horsewhips used against whites eager to claim their economic rights during the 1920's, the state had a model for deadly behavior when its black citizens tried to claim their Constitutional rights in the 50's and 60's.
It is impossible to understand what Professor Barnard calls the ''retardation of Alabama politics'' without mastering this capsule history. Against this backdrop, two other forces come in to play - bad luck and an astonishing tolerance for corruption. Montgomery is a town where, in serious conversation, one can hear a person's profession described as that of ''hereditary bagman.''
Shakedowns were a favorite ploy of the Wallace crowd, although Alabamians insist that the Governor was too busy with national politics to pay attention to what was being done in his name. Whatever the case, the setup was that some ally of his would get a friendly legislator to draft a bill that would hurt a given economic interest - say dog tracks, or coal miners, or electric utilities - and then offer to have the bill killed in exchange for a fee. From time to time, a Federal prosecutor will go after a politician on bribery or tax-evasion charges like those used to nail George Wallace's acquisitive brother Gerald, a Montgomery lawyer whose name became synonymous with chicanery. But no Alabama prosecutor has ever initiated any comprehensive sting operation in Birmingham or Montgomery, the major transfer points of political money.
State Senator Charles D. Bishop, one of five principal candidates for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination, says no systematic cleanup can occur until there is a governor willing to staunch the unregulated flow of corporate money into the Legislature.
''I don't know whether you want to call it corrupt money or not, because we have a very gray line in this state,'' Bishop said. ''What is corrupt? It's legal in Alabama, for instance, if there is a bill on the floor to address an envelope [to me], and I'm walking out of the Senate floor, and one of these people can walk up to me and hand me a check for $10,000 and say to me: 'Senator, now this is for your next campaign. This is not for anything to do with trying to sway your vote on the bill.' And I can simply say, 'Well, look, I'm going to tell you, I'm going to take your money and I appreciate it, but this has nothing to do with the way I vote because I was going to vote for the bill before you gave me this check.' That's legal in Alabama. It's rotten.''
This brings us to Alabama's phenomenal streak of bad luck. Every time the Alabama electorate has risen up and voted for change, something has happened to thwart the process of reform that began more than 20 years ago in the bellwether states of the New South transformation - North Carolina, Georgia and Florida - and then spread throughout the region, skipping Alabama as if its wells had been poisoned.
Alabama's ship of state ''is dead in the water, sort of rocking back and forth, while the flagships of our sister states are steaming just steadily past us,'' says Attorney General Don Siegelman, another Democratic gubernatorial candidate. ''Every other state in the South has elected at least one New South governor.''
Alabamians appeared ready to vote for a New South progressive in 1966 when Ryan deGraffenried, a racial moderate from Tuscaloosa, was leading the race for governor. His death in a plane crash cleared the way for Wallace, who was barred by law from seeking a second consecutive term, to run his wife, Lurleen, for governor.
In 1970, another progressive, Albert P. Brewer, was leading George Wallace in the polls. Then the Wallace claque unleashed the dirtiest campaign in Alabama history, using the Klan to paper the state with leaflets falsely depicting the clean-living Brewer and his family as sexual deviants, alcoholics and miscegenists.
But the biggest disappointment for Alabama voters came in 1978, when Fob James, an Auburn University football hero, was elected on a promise to improve the schools and rewrite the 1901 Constitution that shields the corporations against reasonable property taxes. Not since 1946 had Alabamians voted so clearly for clean government, fair taxes and good schools. But James, a religious fundamentalist, devoted his term to a feckless crusade for school prayer.
For years, Alabamians comforted themselves by making fun of their backward neighbors. But Louisiana and Arkansas elected polished young Ivy Leaguers as governors while Alabama wallowed along with Gov. Guy Hunt, a former Amway salesman, who is running for another term. Now, even the habit of scoffing at Mississippi, the regional scapegoat, is threatened. Ray Mabus, that state's Harvard-educated governor, has begun an education program that seems likely to lift his state, currently 49th in spending on schools, past Alabama, which is 47th.
The big question in the 1990 election is whether corrupt money, dirty campaign tactics or weak candidates will once again conspire to keep Alabama, in Ray Scott's phrase, ''down below the salt in the pickel barrel.''
So far, the gubernatorial campaign has featured a brutal accounting of the state's problems, but that is not entirely the candidates' doing. It began on Jan. 10 when Governor Hunt, a Primitive Baptist preacher, showed up at a Montgomery hotel for the annual Alabama Legislative Prayer Luncheon. Preceding him was Wayne Flynt, a Baptist deacon and author of ''Poor but Proud,'' a history of poverty in Alabama.
Dismissing Hunt's boosterism, Flynt told the legislators that ''God will judge us, as will history'' on the conditions that exist in Alabama today. Almost a fifth of the citizens have no basic health insurance and 4 percent have no running water. Birmingham, home of the state's only medical school and its best hospital, has an infant mortality rate ''rivaling that of many third world countries,'' Flynt said. Alabama ranks 43d among the states in per capita income, and 21 percent of its citizens exist below the Federal poverty level of $12,700 for a family of four.
The Governor was angry, and his rejoinder did nothing to allay his reputation for foot-in-mouth disease: ''We need to remember in many countries that would be called a rich life,'' he was reported as saying in newspaper accounts.
The Speaker of the House passed out copies of Flynt's speech. This sparked open discussion of the state's tax system, the most regressive in the country. While the Federal income tax kicks in at $12,700, in Alabama a family can start paying at $4,500. This, plus an unusually large sales tax, means that Alabama taxes the poor more heavily than any other state.
In this way, it squeezes out the revenue to maintain the nation's lowest property taxes for the companies and wealthy individuals who use Alabama as a vast tree farm. Thirteen out-of-state corporations - including International Paper, Kimberly-Clark, Scott Paper, Union Camp, Tenneco and USX, the successor to United States Steel - hold more than 11 percent of the state's land.
In 1982, the Alabama Legislature memorialized its thralldom to big timber, the state's major industry, by making it illegal to tax this land on its market value. As a result, in one large holding that straddles the state line, Kimberly-Clark pays 93 cents an acre on the Alabama side and $4.36 an acre in Georgia.
Clearly, economic progress in Alabama amounts to this: From 1901 until the decline of the iron furnaces in the mid-1970's, Alabama property taxes were tailored for United States Steel. Now they are tailored for companies that own pine trees. It comes to the same thing. Property taxes are so low that it is more economical for the big firms to sit on their land than to develop it or sell it to someone who will.
Here's a footnote for students of irony. The 1901 Constitution was written to deprive blacks of the vote and, by mandating equal tax rates for all individuals and corporations, to assure that wealthy farmers and industrialists could not be taxed for programs to help blacks. The idea was, as the saying goes, ''to keep the niggers down.'' But, as, Flynt, who teaches history at Auburn, documented, the result was to keep everybody down.
Governor hunt, it is fair to say, is no student of such matters. A self-described ''dumb farm boy,'' he was a part-time preacher and a county probate judge when he became chairman of the 1976 Reagan campaign in Alabama. Ten years later, the Republicans turned to him as a sacrificial candidate in the 1986 governor's race, but a feud among the Democrats soured the voters and suddenly Alabama found itself with its first Republican governor since 1874. Behind his back, Alabama's educators and lawyers laugh at his table manners and grammar.
But Hunt has the advantage of having at his side the single most influential man in Alabama politics these days, a polished Louisiana-born lawyer named John E. Grenier. ''Put it like this,'' says James H. Horn, a Democrat and a former state insurance director. ''Grenier eats the watermelon, Hunt spits out the seeds.'' Grenier, who took a law degree at New York University, drives a Range Rover and rides to hounds. He is said by friends to have no illusions about Hunt's bumpkin ways or his abilities. But Grenier, who was elected G.O.P. state chairman in 1962 when the Republicans were trying to out-seg George Wallace, sees Hunt as the instrument by which he can install a true two-party system in Alabama.
Grenier speaks openly of an institutionalized political segregation - ''the racial separation of the parties'' - in which Republicans would become the party of the white majority. Racial antagonisms, in his view, will enable Hunt to withstand the Democrats' charge that he is the puppet of the banks and insurance, oil, steel and forest-products companies represented by Grenier's Birmingham law firm.
''The problem with the property tax, of course, like everything, goes back to race in Alabama,'' Grenier said in an interview at the Governor's mansion. ''I think probably whites feel like they own the property, and the property tax goes up, and the proceeds will go to blacks.''
This is the 1990 version of the oldest theme in Alabama politics: the corporations and the plantation owners appeal for the votes of working-class whites by convincing them that blacks hunger for their jobs and a disproportionate share of government benefits. In order to meet the demand for more taxes from outside businesses, Hunt has proposed legislation to raise the tax on out-of-state waste dumped in an unpopular site in Emelle from $22 a ton to $112. To divert heat from the timber companies, Hunt has resorted to a political version of blame-the-victim, singling out the state's teachers, rather than a century-old tradition of underfunding, as the root of Alabama's education problem. Hunt argues that his political allies in the timber companies, long notorious for starving the school systems in poor rural counties where they own up to 60 percent of the land, have agreed to ante up, if only they can be convinced that incompetent teachers are not wasting their money. ''So all that it's waiting on now,'' Hunt says, ''is for education leaders to come in and be a part of the solution instead of being a part of the problem.''
Hunt clings doggedly to his vision of Alabama as a low-tax, low-wage haven for big corporations. ''I think that's the thing that has helped us,'' Hunt says in arguing that he has led the state into a new era of prosperity. ''These corporate heads understand a pro-business attitude.''
''Well, Governor Hunt is just dead wrong,'' says Representative Ronnie G. Flippo. ''Pure and simple, there is no substantiation for his position.
''Our job growth in Alabama has been approximately two-thirds of the job growth of our sister states in the Southeast for a number of years,'' adds Flippo, who is leaving Congress to run for governor. ''The gap between income earned in Alabama and the national average is getting broader. In 1982, the gap was $2,600. In '88, it was $3,600.'' Moreover, Flippo says, three out of four of the new jobs created during Hunt's tenure ''have paid less than the state average.''
Most public-policy experts and all of Flippo's opponents for the Democratic nomination agree. But their problem is that Alabama's sad statistics are George Wallace's legacy. Their task is to condemn the problem without attacking its author, who at age 70 lies deaf and bedridden in his suburban Montgomery home. Even so, the Democratic campaign has an inescapable theme that Wallace's most enduring damage to the state was not the harm he did to its reputation for race relations, but the poor schools, bad health care and low wages of its people.
The most candid in promulgating this view is Paul Hubbert, a former teacher and school administrator, who is in a tight race with Flippo, Siegelman, Bishop and Fob James for a spot in the inevitable June 26 runoff for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination. Without explicitly blaming the former governor, Hubbert speaks candidly of the searing experience of trying to bring black children into white classrooms while ''Wallace was railing against the desegregation of schools.''
Hubbert has introduced a new tactic into Alabama politics by driving a wedge into the business community. The extractive industries - timber, mining, petroleum - are solidly with Governor Hunt as the protector of their favored tax status. But the bankers, retailers and service corporations headquartered in Birmingham are tired of having prospective employees and investors shun them because of the state's poor schools, hospitals and cultural facilities and its troglodyte reputation. For the first time there is a chance that a few members of Birmingham's white-collar establishment could play the progressive political role played by their counterparts in Atlanta, Charlotte and Miami for the past two decades.
In this effort, Hubbert has a powerful ally in Tom Coker, former head of the Alabama Business Council and one of the most influential lobbyists in Montgomery, who says he has become convinced that ''business in Alabama has been more the problem than part of the solution.''
As his campaign media strategist, Hubbert has hired Frank Greer, a Tuscaloosa native who specializes in packaging progressive Democrats for conservative Southern electorates. Last year Greer managed the media campaign of L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia as the South's first elected black governor. This year, he is advising Andrew Young in his campaign to become the first black governor of Georgia. But Alabama represents a chance for an equally dramatic, if less obvious, break with the past. A victory for Hubbert would represent an internal revolution against power alignments that have prevailed since 1890, when the plantation masters stole the governorship from Reuben F. Kolb, a dirt-road populist elected by the white yeomanry and poor blacks.
It is clear that Siegelman and Flippo, as well as Hubbert, could provide worthy leadership on the New South model. These three men may represent Alabama's only chance to escape a long siege of dynastic politics. Lurking in the wings are Lieut. Gov. James E. Folsom Jr, now 41, and State Treasurer George C. Wallace Jr., now 38. Both are affable parochialists and law-school dropouts who got their undergraduate degrees at second-tier schools. Unless the Democratic nominee wins the governorship this time and has four years to entrench himself, either Folsom or Wallace seems certain to enter the 1996 gubernatorial race as the Democratic front-runner. Of the two, only Wallace has a fire in his gut. At the moment ''Little George'' is cagily promoting the idea that ''Little Jim'' ought to run for Congress and leave the State House to him.
''George Jr. is just eaten up with following in his father's footsteps,'' Tom Coker observes. Specifically, young Wallace wants to break the iron link forged by his father between racism and the Wallace name. ''Knowing him as his only son,'' young Wallace says, he is convinced that his father never believed in the racial policies he espoused. ''It was a political position he took.'' Then he added: ''But he was never a member of the Klan as Hugo Black was or he didn't run in the white primaries as Lyndon Johnson did.''
At this point, young Wallace's high-pitched voice rises with passion as he warms to the comparison between his father and the late Justice Black, who joined the Klan in 1923 to secure election to the Senate. ''I don't know why Dad has difficulty being rehabilitated when he finally said, 'I was wrong and I'm sorry.' What more can a man do? But Hugo Black is considered this great progressive liberal, yet he was a member of the Klan and made some of the most outlandish statements about black people that have ever been made.''
At such moments, one sees the father shining through. In part it is the physical aspect, the bulging eyes and bushy brows; in part, it is that vintage Alabama rhetorical trick, the excuse-by-comparison.
But this new Wallace is very different. He is twice divorced, dogged by rumors of rowdy living in the company of another Alabama princeling, the country and western singer Hank Williams Jr., yet essentially a loner. The elder Wallace was a compulsive socializer and, until the death of his first wife, too caught up with politics to have much libido left over for scandal. ''I'm not as outgoing,'' young George says almost apologetically. ''I don't have'' - he pauses and realigns the sentence - ''although I am very competitive, I don't think I appear as combative as he did one time.''
He is different in another way. While holding down a patronage job at Troy State University, young George was in charge of financial aid for working students. Many of his clients were black, young parents who brought their children to his office. The experience moved him. I found no one in Alabama who believed George Wallace Jr. to be a racist, in his private heart or his public positions. In that regard, he is a vast improvement over the original model.
He may be in another way, too. Everyone agrees that the elder Wallace went into office after his election in 1962 with the intention - inherited from Folsom, his political mentor - of breaking the power of the corporations and the Black Belt planters. But when Potomac fever struck him, he found he needed two things - large amounts of money and an obedient Legislature. So he lined up with the old grandees in the Legislature.
Young Wallace has been tutored by the same University of Alabama public-policy experts who are guiding Paul Hubbert. ''The data I've seen in terms of tax equity and reinvesting in Alabama is that many of our large landowners, who may not even be developing their property, paid 30 cents an acre per year. If they would pay, for example, what Georgia pays, that would generate another half-billion dollars a year for education and other state services.''
To hear George Wallace Jr. speak of the problems his father failed to address inevitably calls to mind Flynt's warning to Alabama's leaders that God would hold them accountable for the conditions they left behind them.
I thought of this when George Jr. told of riding away from the State Capitol on the day in 1986 when his father announced his retirement from office: ''With tears in his eyes, he turned to me and said, 'Son, I hope they will not let the rich and powerful take over.' ''
Was this real regret for a career blighted by demagogy or just more Wallace bloviation? It is impossible to know. But if ''Little George'' had been in an argumentative mood, he might have pointed out to his father that he had 23 years to tackle the retrograde forces that have kept Alabama in the ditch.
When George Wallace pledged to preserve ''segregation forever,'' he was a little off the mark. It was poverty and tax breaks for pine trees that he preserved. So now on Tuesday, Alabama, the hard-luck state in the heart of Dixie, must try yet again to start down the path taken by its sister states many years ago.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: June 3, 1990

SECTION: Section 6; Page 39, Column 2; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 3859 words

HEADLINE: Laureate in the Land of the Pharoahs

BYLINE: By Brad Kessler; Brad Kessler is a former associate editor of Interview magazine.

 BODY:
The Aly Baba Cafe in downtown Cairo is a cheerless place with yellowing walls and soiled soapbox-sized tables. By day, couples rendezvous in its dark corners, and at night it is mostly empty. But the cafe on Tahrir Square has two things to recommend it.
The second-floor window looks out over the monuments that have come to symbolize modern Egypt: the Nasser-era Mugamma building, the bureaucratic hub of the country; the Arab League headquarters, unused since Egypt signed the Camp David accords; the Nile Hilton, and the Egyptian Museum. And in the early morning, another monument of modern Egypt is on view at the Aly Baba: Naguib Mahfouz, the 78-year-old author who is the first Arab to win the Nobel Prize in Literature.
At 7 o'clock each morning, Mahfouz arrives for his coffee, taking his window seat upstairs. For weeks after he won the prize in October 1988, journalists, tourists and assorted Mahfouz seekers hung around the Aly Baba waiting for the writer to open his newspapers and then receive visitors like a nobleman holding court. Mahfouz's face appeared on television, magazine covers and signs all over the city. A tourist restaurant was named the Naguib Mahfouz Cafe, and the author's publishers at the American University in Cairo Press were overwhelmed by requests for permission to translate his works into languages from Serbo-Croatian to Faeroese. 
By January, the burst of excitement had died down, and only one person in the Aly Baba seemed to care that Mahfouz was a bit late. It was a cold morning; newspaper vendors on the square wore scarves and keffiyahs around their heads as a damp breeze blew off the Nile. ''He'll come,'' the waiter said. Then, almost on cue, Mahfouz appeared, picking his way across the square, cars swerving around him, a small figure wearing his trademark wraparound sunglasses and a gray overcoat several sizes too big. He seemed relieved that he could have his privacy again.
The nobel committee's selection of Mahfouz was met with little enthusiasm in literary circles. Publishers and critics who had gathered in Stockholm for the occasion dispersed quickly and quietly. Reporters had a hard time finding any of his books, a not unusual ritual when the literature winners are disclosed. Even the Nobel judges admitted that little was known about Mahfouz because he was a private man and gave few interviews. After the announcement, Mahfouz's face appeared on the front pages of newspapers around the world, but it wasn't long before he disappeared again into the obscurity of a third world writer.
In Egypt, however, Mahfouz was a national landmark well before he won the Nobel. A prolific master of both popular and literary fiction, he has averaged a book a year for some 40 years, not to mention dozens of screenplays, several plays and a weekly political column in the Egyptian daily newspaper Al-Ahram. His novels, most of which deal with the life of Cairo's lower and middle classes, are more widely read and translated than those of any other author in the Arab world. Both the highly educated and barely literate read his works, and even the illiterate know his stories from the dozens of movies made from his novels and screenplays.
''You cannot picture Egypt without the Pyramids,'' says Sonallah Ibrahim, another Egyptian writer, ''and neither can you conceive of Arabic literature without Naguib Mahfouz.''
Although there had been attempts at writing novels in Arabic before Mahfouz, he was the first of his generation to write successful Arabic novels; but he didn't stop there. For more than 50 years, he duplicated in Arabic the history of the European novel - writing at first in the romantic style of Victor Hugo, then working his way through the social realism of Dickens, the internal monologue of Joyce and Woolf, and finally landing Arabic literature in the lap of the modern age.
For all this, Mahfouz is a modest man. His office at Al-Ahram, the semiofficial Government paper where he has worked for the last 20 years, is spartan, with a couple of green leather couches and one potted plant pushed into a corner. A few paintings of Mahfouz by admirers hang on the wall, along with a framed arabesque of Koranic verse.
Late on a January morning, he sat on one of his couches, a king-sized Kent in his mouth, an undisturbed cup of Turkish coffee on a small table in front of him. He was frail, slightly stooped, and wore a hearing aid; he always wears sunglasses because his eyes are sensitive to light. ''You see,'' he said, in slow, precise English, only half-joking, ''I am a very old man, an introvert. So winning the Nobel was really terrible for me. I won the prize, yes, but I lost everything else.''
He went on to explain that he was unable to write for a year after he had won the Nobel. The prize had thrown his orderly life into disarray, forcing him to face television crews and cameras and a lot of unbidden questions. For such a private man, he bore it well. But it seemed as if Mahfouz did not consider the Nobel a prize so much as some prolonged sentence of public service he had to perform.
In a sense, he was performing a public service. Ever since an Israeli writer, S. Y. Agnon, won the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1966, Arab writers had waited for the prize to fall to their camp. They believed that the Nobel committee, often an equal-opportunity donor, had ignored their literature, confirming the view of Arab intellectuals that the West was inherently hostile to their culture. The choice of an Arab, then, was considered long overdue, and it was clear that Mahfouz was selected somehow to represent Arabic literature. And in Mahfouz, the Nobel panelists found a safe bet: a humanist who called for peace with Israel and would be palatable to the Western press.
In his office, with the midmorning sun slicing through the Venetian blinds, he was being a perfect public servant, saying that the real winner of the prize was in fact Arabic literature. He had once said that his work, along with the rest of Arabic letters, was fourth- or fifth-rate, a statement he now regrets. ''The new forms of literature like the novel are only 50 years old in our culture, so we are still developing,'' Mahfouz said. ''Conditions of life in Egypt are very hard at the moment. Our cultural environment would be a lot better if it wasn't for our economic crisis and if our democracy was complete.''
But Mahfouz did not want to talk about Egypt's dismal economy or incomplete democracy. He is far too cautious for that. Instead, he smiled and discussed the virtues of the country's younger writers. He sounded like a Government official, but, then, he has had plenty of experience as a civil servant. He has supported himself and his family by working for various Government ministries, as an aide to the head of the centrist Wafd Party and as a state adviser on the arts. He has also served as a Government film censor, a role for which he has been criticized. Indeed, many Cairo intellectuals regard him as an obedient functionary of the state who has tread lightly and caused as little friction as possible. While many fellow authors were being thrown into jail by Gamal Abdel Nasser in the 1960's, and later by Anwar el-Sadat, Mahfouz managed to befriend the right people, they say, and stay out of prison.
Even today there is a prudence and economy about him. He leads a middle-class existence, spending his summers in Alexandria and the rest of the time in a two-bedroom flat overlooking the Nile in a comfortable neighborhood, Agouza. He is married, with two daughters, and keeps his personal life strictly private. He hates to travel and has left Egypt only twice, on ''cultural missions'' to Yemen and Yugoslavia, and declined to go to Stockholm to pick up his prize. He is a shy man who measures his daily life down to the minute: awake at 5 A.M., a cup of Nescafe, a light breakfast, out of the apartment by 6 for a walk along the Nile - always the same route - along Um Kalthoum Street, past the Gezira Club, over the Tahrir Bridge, and to the Aly Baba by 7. He writes in the afternoon for a few hours, and is in bed by 10:30.
The world he creates in his novels, by contrast, is unsettled and difficult. His characters are lower- and middle-class Cairenes, civil servants and bureaucrats, brutish grocers, shopkeepers, pensioners, petty thieves, prostitutes and peasant women who try, but often fail, to better themselves in the big city. In his books, women are brutalized, abandoned or kept secreted away in their silent households. Men must choose between a stifling traditional past and an uncertain ''modern'' future. Either way, they are usually doomed.
''Palace Walk,'' the first book in his more than 1,200-page ''Cairo Trilogy,'' is one of Mahfouz's most popular. It was written in the early 1950's and published a few years later. Though its style is not as accessible as that of his later works, the novel, in French translation, was ultimately what swayed the Nobel committee, its panelists said. It has all the elements of a typical Mahfouz novel: an urban family ravaged by economic attrition and war, the sexual tensions of a society where men and women are kept strictly apart; mistreated women, and the struggle against the stubborn hold of tradition.
The author once described his literary career as a journey from Sir Walter Scott to Nathalie Sarraute. Though his voice may have changed along the way, the road he has traveled has always been a distinctly Egyptian one. Modern Egypt is Mahfouz's stage and Egyptian history - whether it's the Hyksos invasion some 1,500 years before Christ or Sadat's assassination in 1981 - is the backdrop for his fiction. In ''The Cairo Trilogy,'' Mahfouz traces one family through three generations, from 1917 to 1944, using as crucial events the 1919 revolution that overthrew the monarchy, World War II and the uprisings that drove out the British and eventually brought Nasser to power.
History informs his stories, and a sense of loss runs through them, coming to the surface occasionally in the form of old men who sit around hotels or tea houses longing for the hopeful and happier days of the revolution, before Nasser's socialism soured or Sadat came to power. All his novels can be read as commentaries on the national condition. In ''Only an Hour Is Left,'' the matriarch of an old Cairene family, torn apart by the Arab-Israeli wars of 1948, '56, '67 and '73, looks at her children, the children of Egypt, on the eve of the Camp David accords in 1979 and laments: ''They are all skinny, they have all aged prematurely. What has happened to them?'' And of her garden, a metaphor for Egypt itself, she observes wearily: ''When is it going to be tilled? And when will the seedlings arrive? When will the rain stop, and the workmen resume their work?''
Western readers may not immediately recognize this Egypt. There are no camel caravans, desert sandscapes or Alexandrian excess. The Western writers on Egypt - T. E. Lawrence, Lawrence Durrell, Flaubert, E. M. Forster - presented an exotic country, pulsating with sexual possibilities and Oriental naughtiness. They had the luxury of romanticizing Egypt and turning it into an oasis for their own fantasies. Nothing is ''exotic'' about Mahfouz's Egypt. It is simply a place where the yearly per capita income is about $700, where half the population is illiterate, where due process, democracy and job opportunities do not exist.
The problem for English readers comes with the language. Arabic is hard to render into English or the Romance languages. Some scholars even talk about a ''linguistic Iron Curtain'' separating Arabic literature from that of the West.
Mahfouz writes in the florid classical Arabic, which is roughly the equivalent of Shakespearean English, and his earlier novels like ''Palace Walk'' tend to be overwrought. To read him in English translation requires a little imagination and a lot of charity. In the Doubleday translation of ''Palace Walk,'' for example, Mahfouz writes: ''The young man's vital forces were so powerful that they dominated him if he was otherwise at liberty. At no time did they grant him any relief from their proddings.'' In ''The Beginning and the End,'' the protagonist, Hussein, tells his older brother, on learning of their father's death, ''Your sangfroid is amazing . . . whoever yields to fate encourages it to impose further tyranny.'' Despite passages like these, the characterizations and craftsmanship of Mahfouz's storytelling come through.
The Cairo where Mahfouz grew up was a much smaller place than today's metastatic city of 14 million people. Born in 1911 to a low-ranking civil servant, Mahfouz spent his youth in Gamaliya, a neighborhood in the heart of Islamic Cairo. His childhood was unremarkable, if a little lonely. His mother was his closest companion, taking him on trips to the Giza Pyramids and to the mummy rooms of the Egyptian Museum.
Gamaliya was and still is one of Cairo's more traditional neighborhoods, full of small alleyways, large mosques, towering minarets and noisy tea houses. There, Mahfouz learned Egyptian folk tales and culled the characters for his later works of fiction; there, he witnessed the uprisings against the British. Later, after his family moved to Abbasiya, a Cairo suburb, he studied philosophy at the University of Cairo. He read Darwin, Freud, Marx and Nietzsche, and had what he later described as a ''crisis of faith'' - the unraveling of the old Islamic pieties he had picked up in Gamaliya.
Books always figured prominently in his life. Though he was never a devout Muslim, he learned lengthy sections of the Koran by heart in school (as all children must). As a teen-ager, he translated cheap English romances into Arabic. At 25, he abandoned philosophy for writing.
With an old copy of ''Outlines of Literature'' by John Drinkwater as his guide, he diligently set about reading the correct books for a literary vocation. He studied Shakespeare, Balzac, Tolstoy and Scott, then moved his way through Melville (whom he didn't much care for), Dostoyevsky (whom he could never finish), Proust, Joyce and Mann. His first novels, written in the early 1940's, were historical romances set in Pharaonic Egypt. They were thinly veiled allegories for Egypt's struggle against British occupation based, paradoxically, on the novels of Sir Walter Scott. These early novels were mildly successful, and, with the publication of ''Midaq Alley'' in 1947, Mahfouz gained wide renown in Egypt. But it wasn't until the publicaton of his magnum opus, ''The Cairo Trilogy,'' in 1956-57, that Mahfouz became the leading writer in the Arab world.
Mahfouz today is painfully aware of his position as de facto spokesman for Arabic literature. The Nobel has generated jealousy among several Egyptian writers, and some of his peers do not think he represents them or Arab concerns. His chief critic is Youssef Idris, a respected Egyptian writer who many thought would win the Nobel himself. Shortly after Mahfouz was awarded the prize, Idris created a small tempest by claiming Mahfouz had won because of his conciliatory politics toward Israel and because he was the only type of Arab the Nobel committee would ever choose.
Idris also has an office at Al-Ahram, only a few doors down from Mahfouz's. But the two men are far apart, both politically and personally. Idris, in his early 60's, is a blustery man who has traveled widely, fought alongside the Algerian resistance against the French and spent time in prison during Nasser's reign.
In his office in January, more than a year after the Nobel went to Mahfouz, Idris was clearly still annoyed with the decision. ''We have in Egypt what I call an Amon-Ra tendency,'' he said, referring to the Pharaonic sun god. ''It's the tendency to worship one god, to pray behind one imam and obey one emir. Now there's Mahfouz, and everyone's praying to him.'' Between puffs of his Cleopatra cigarette, Idris said that Mahfouz's winning the prize was not a victory at all for Egypt or Arabic literature, but a victory for one man.
Didn't he think Mahfouz was a worthy writer nonetheless? ''Yes,'' Idris said, ''Mahfouz is a great novelist, but he's not an inventor. He borrowed the novel from Europe; he imitated it. It's not an Egyptian art form. Europeans - and Swedes - like it very much because it is their own form.''
Idris, apparently, is not the only Egyptian author who has reservations about the role of the novel in Arab culture. Writers in general, and novelists in particular, have not had an easy time of it anywhere in the Arab world. Buffeted by politics and religion, they are often at the mercy of unfriendly regimes.
Even a moderate man like Mahfouz has found himself at the center of controversy. In 1959, his allegorical novel ''The Children of Gebelawi'' caused an uproar in some Islamic circles because it portrayed the prophet Mohammed as a living man and had exactly as many chapters as there are suras, or sections, in the Koran.
The conflict was similar to the attacks on Salman Rushdie early in 1989. Mahfouz too was the target of protests and death threats. After appearing in serialized form in Al-Ahram, ''Children of Gebelawi'' was banned in Egypt.
When Mahfouz wrote in one of his political columns in 1975 that Arabs must learn to live peacefully with Israel, his books and movies were banned again, this time not in Egypt but in several other Arab countries. Even as late as a year ago, Mahfouz was denounced and given a death sentence by a fundamentalist sheik in Egypt emboldened by the Rushdie affair. Mahfouz was luckier than Rushdie: the sheik was locked up by Egyptian authorities, and Mahfouz was left alone. Yet Mahfouz is impatient when he is compared with Rushdie. While the Nobel winner accused the Ayatollah Khomeini of ''intellectual terrorism,'' he dislikes what he describes as Rushdie's ''enmity toward Islam.''
If Arab writers have had a hard time staying out of trouble in their own countries, they have had a difficult time even getting noticed abroad. Arabic literature has never been greeted in the West with the kind of enthusiasm that has welcomed works from, say, Latin America or Eastern Europe.
It was hoped in Egypt that the Nobel Prize would confer a new status on Arab writers. Novelists hoped their works would break through the linguistic iron curtain into the catalogues of Western publishing houses. But a year and half later, no visible flowering in Arabic literature has taken place, and writers in the Arab world seem as embattled as ever. In Cairo, authors complain of a literary malaise, a disinterested public, a hostile state and a lingering censorship that prohibits frank discussion of sex, religion and politics. A few years ago, copies of ''A Thousand and One Nights'' were seized in Cairo because the classic's bawdiness hadn't been eliminated in a new edition.
Earlier this year, an Egyptian writer, Alaa Hamed, was jailed for writing a novel about an imaginary journey to paradise, where he meets some prophets. Hamed's novel was deemed blasphemous by the religious authorities, and he has been in a Cairo prison ever since. The newest threat, of course, comes from the religious right and the fundamentalists, many of whom regard fiction itself as a profane, Western practice and who now have, in the form of Salman Rushdie and Hamed, living examples of the writer-heretic.
Just getting published is difficult enough in the Arab world. In Cairo, the cultural capital of the ArabJU world, the publishing industry has shrunk to one-fourth the size of what it was during the 1950's. Most writers, no matter how talented, must bankroll the publication of their own books.
''The real talent can't even get published here,'' says Denys Johnson-Davies, a well-known British translator who lives in Cairo and who has translated a collection of Mahfouz's stories. ''The Government, which owns the public presses, is not really interested in literature at all. It was happy when this man won the Nobel, but it would have been much happier had Egypt won the World Cup.''
Every Friday afternoon, Mahfouz meets with a group of friends over coffee at the Kasr el Nil Casino, a restaurant on the west bank of the Nile. They read from the Egyptian dailies - Al-Ahram, Al-Akhbar, Al-Wafd. They talk about politics or literature, or just share in one another's company. Mahfouz has had these meetings for years with his old boys' network. But ever since he won the Nobel, his small circle of friends has grown to include younger writers, journalists, engineers and poets who make weekly pilgrimages from all over Cairo and further afield to be in his presence.
On a chilly January afternoon, in a dimly lighted room by the Nile, 30 men and a few women sat in the empty casino waiting for Mahfouz. The men wore tweed; the women, long elegant dresses. When Mahfouz arrived, conversation stopped and everyone stood up as if a high priest had come to preside over the assembly and bestow upon them his blessings. Mahfouz, wearing his gray overcoat, bowing slightly and beaming from ear to ear, walked around the long table shaking hands, and not until he had found a seat at a far corner of the table did the gathering sit down again.
A Cairo critic had once said: ''Naguib Mahfouz is like the sphinx: silent but expressive.'' That afternoon, Mahfouz was being sphinxlike. All eyes were on him. He occasionally uttered a ''yes'' or a ''no,'' or nodded, letting the others do the talking and sometimes seeming to lose the trend of the conversation altogether. When he did speak, the room became hushed with people straining to hear what morsel of Mahfouzian wisdom was being imparted.
Critics say that Mahfouz has not produced any important books in decades and that he has passed on the literary baton to the next generation of Arab writers. Arguably, there are better Arab writers around today - Youssef Idris, the Sudanese author Tayeb Salih or the Lebanese poet Adonis. Mahfouz himself has said he can no longer find themes that interest him. Yet, to watch him at the Kasr el Nil Casino was to realize in what high regard he was still held as the custodian of Arabic letters.
As the afternoon wore on, the conversation wandered. A Kuwaiti novelist complained about fundamentalists in her country who were trying to ban her books, even though they had been published years ago. An Egyptian journalist described the elections in Jordan, and a literature professor talked about the 50th anniversary of ''Lady Chatterley's Lover.''
A few hours later, after the wind had picked up on the Nile, and the lights on the Tahrir Bridge had been turned on for the night, Mahfouz called over the waiter to pay his bill and the room suddenly fell silent. Mahfouz looked tired.
Earlier that afternoon, he had been at the funeral of a writer, Abdel Qaddous, who had died that morning, and now it was getting late. Mahfouz got up to go, with several apologies and handshakes and bows. After he shuffled out of the cold casino, everyone was left standing, in complete silence, with no more reason to stay.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Writer Naguib Mahfouz is a familiar figure at the Aly Baba cafe in Cairo. (JOANNA PINNEO) ;Mafouz, right, sits with a shopkeeper in a Cairo shoe-repair store. The writer's novels often deal with the lower and middle classes, and their struggles between a stifling traditional past and an uncertain future. (JOANNA PINNEO)
