The New York Times

PUB-DATE: June 3, 1990

SECTION: Section 6; Page 34, Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 4160 words

HEADLINE: NOTHING BUT CURVE BALLS

BYLINE: By Roger Cohn; Roger Cohn is a former reporter for The Philadelphia Inquirer.

 BODY:
Nothing has come easy for Fay Vincent. Not even his ceremonial appearance at the belated opening day at Yankee Stadium.
He had arrived on the field before game time, holding court behind home plate for the sportswriters who huddled around him. It was a glorious spring afternoon, and the new commissioner of baseball, finally ready to begin his first full season, was in high spirits. He recalled his first visit to the stadium, in 1952 (the Yanks vs. the Philadelphia A's), and his trip with President Bush to Toronto two days earlier for the Blue Jays' opener. The writers listened respectfully. Then they got down to business.
Did he think the fans still resented the owners' 32-day lockout that had wiped out this season's first week? Was he conducting an investigation of the Yankee owner George Steinbrenner's relationship with a man accused of extortion? And how would he rule if Pete Rose, banished from baseball for gambling, applied to be reinstated? 
''Did you notice no one asked me about the game on the field?'' Vincent said the next day, en route to Seattle for yet another opening day. There, he would be asked the same questions, after enduring such indignities as shaking hands with a team mascot dressed as a moose.
It has been that kind of initiation for the 52-year-old chief executive of the national pastime. ''Fay Vincent's really had a baptism by fire,'' says Fred Wilpon, president of the New York Mets. ''He's had to deal with more serious problems in his first months than other commissioners have dealt with in a full term in office.''
Francis T. (Fay) Vincent Jr. came to Major League Baseball at the start of last season - following a career as a securities lawyer, president of Columbia Pictures Industries Inc.and a Coca-Cola Company executive - to serve as deputy to his close friend, Commissioner A. Bartlett Giamatti. Five months later, Giamatti was dead, and Vincent was chosen as his successor. The following month, he presided over a World Series that was upstaged, delayed and rendered largely inconsequential by the earthquake that shook San Francisco's Candlestick Park and the Bay Area. And before he had even settled into the commissioner's office on Park Avenue in New York, he was embroiled in the labor conflict that jeopardized the 1990 season.
''It has been a bit tumultuous,'' Vincent says, allowing just the trace of a smile. ''The big issue for me is, what is the steady state in this job? Is it just one major crisis after another, the way it's been since I got here? I'm coming to the conclusion that's just the way it's going to be.''
That may prove true, given the difficult issues looming ahead for Vincent, as he oversees the $1.1 billion-a-year business of Major League Baseball. He must improve the abysmal state of labor relations between players and owners, which has led to four strikes and two lockouts in less than two decades. He must deal with the growing complaints from owners in cities like Milwaukee and Cleveland who contend they cannot compete for players and profits with fat-cat teams in major media markets like Los Angeles and New York. He must guide baseball through its first expansion since 1977, as the National League prepares to add two new cities as early as 1993.
And in what may be his most thorny problem, the George Steinbrenner investigation, Vincent will have to decide whether to discipline a powerful owner who had been one of his most outspoken supporters during the spring-training lockout.
For ultimately, the commissioner of baseball - an oddly public-sounding title for a private-sector job - must play the at-times conflicting roles of chief executive officer of Major League Baseball and trusted caretaker of the game. Elected by the 26 club owners, the commissioner is empowered to act in the ''best interests'' of baseball, with broad authority over both the owners and the players. But balancing the owners' profits and baseball's best interests can prove tricky, as Vincent discovered during the recent lockout.
''It's obvious I'm part of the owners' side,'' he said at the time. ''But I'm also the fans' representative, and I have to try to do what I can to make sure the games are played and the season is not impaired. So I'm sort of groping along, trying to figure out what approach is best for me, and ultimately what's best for the institution.''
Certainly, Vincent's unassuming, soft-spoken style differs from that of his recent predecessors. He lacks the eloquence of Giamatti, the cocky, take-charge attitude of Peter V. Ueberroth and the imperiousness of Bowie Kuhn. Indeed, Vincent would appear to be a rather drab successor to the charismatic Giamatti. He is a husky, rather ungainly man who walks with difficulty and uses a cane because of a severe back injury he suffered in his college days. In television interviews, he comes across as a mild-mannered Main Street merchant.
But in person, Vincent is far more engaging - a thoughtful, gentle, often charming man, with a wry sense of humor, who likes to quote both Dizzy Dean and the English romantic poets and managed to finish reading biographies of Wordsworth and Henry Adams during the lockout. He has a boyish enthusiasm and can get truly annoyed with himself for slipping and calling his old friend George Bush by his first name or, worse yet, Poppy. ''I've got to be more careful about that,'' he says reprovingly. And he has an intense, old-fashioned sense of loyalty, whether to his home state of Connecticut; his alma mater, Williams College, or to his friends, each of whom is inevitably described as a ''great guy'' or a ''terrific fella.'' Indeed, Vincent appears to be utterly without guile or pretense. During the labor talks, he kept saying he was trying to follow the old adage: ''When in doubt, do the right thing.'' And when he told this to a group of jaded sportswriters gathered for an evening briefing, no one snickered. Clearly, after two decades of arcane law and corporate politics, Vincent is relishing being a part of baseball. Unlike Ueberroth, who seemed more comfortable marketing the game than watching it, Vincent has pledged to try to get to all 26 major-league ball parks this season. During the marathon labor talks, he had Scott Sanderson, the Oakland Athletics pitcher and one of the players' representatives, show him the grip for a split-fingered fastball. And before a settlement was reached, he asked all the players present to sign a ball that now is displayed in his office next to the one autographed by Babe Ruth. ''This job is not like running a manufacturing business or a car dealership or a movie company,'' Vincent says, swiveling about in his leather office chair and plucking a cigar from a box behind him. ''Part of the marvel of baseball is its very special relationship with the American soul. And I'm very conscious of that.
''You know, I've had friends who were chief executives of big companies say to me, 'I'd love your job. I'd drop everything to have it.' '' He chuckles, then clicks a lighter to his cigar. ''If you love baseball, this is the ultimate fantasy.''
The office of commissioner of baseball surely was not on Fay Vincent's career track. Two years ago, he quit Coca-Cola, having amassed a major block of company stock, now valued at more than $20 million. He was thinking about practicing law again, maybe teaching a college course, and spending more time with his wife, Valerie, and their three children at their home in Greenwich, Conn. But then his friend Bart Giamatti, the former Yale University president, asked him to come work for baseball. The two had met 10 years earlier at a dinner party and had developed a close friendship. Giamatti was about to be named baseball commissioner, and he wanted Vincent, with his business and legal experience, to join him as his deputy. ''I could think of nothing nicer than to get up in the morning and work for baseball and be with Bart,'' Vincent says. ''To me that was very close to nirvana. I remember telling him the only thing I knew a lot about from my years practicing law and running Columbia Pictures was trouble. And no sooner did we get here, when we realized we had the Pete Rose problem. Boy, that sure was trouble.'' Even before taking office, he and Giamatti were confronted with mounting accusations that the former hitting star, Rose, by then the manager of the Cincinnati Reds, had bet on baseball games. Vincent coordinated legal matters for Giamatti on the Rose case, ultimately drafting the formal agreement banning Rose, which he modeled on consent decrees he had once routinely prepared as a securities lawyer. Because he will decide on Rose's possible request for reinstatement, which could be made under baseball rules as early as this August, Vincent refuses to discuss the case. (With Rose's recent guilty plea stemming from income-tax charges, such an early request now seems unlikely.) But Vincent describes his first meeting with Rose, in February 1989:
''We asked him point-blank, had he bet on baseball? And he said, no, he was too smart for that. And I told him that was a very significant answer, that it was ground zero for our investigation, because it was an on-the-record denial before the commissioner. And if that was a lie, that was going to be a very important fact.'' On Sept. 1, eight days after banishing Rose, Giamatti died of a heart attack. The owners quickly named Vincent to complete Giamatti's five-year term, at an annual salary of $650,000, despite the reservations of a few who felt the game might have found a more dynamic chief executive. The following month, he was in the commissioner's box at Candlestick Park when the earth moved just before the third game of the World Series.
''That whole first month, right up to the World Series was absolutely a blur,'' Vincent says softly. ''I had never intended to be in baseball without Bart. We came here joined at the waist. I don't think I got my arms around the fact that Bart was dead and I was commissioner for quite a while. I suppose I'm still adjusting to it.''
He pauses to collect himself. ''The World Series itself was almost surrealistic. I found myself going to a press conference, with only candles and no lights. There was an ethereal quality to it all, as if I was floating through it.''
But he remembers distinctly the return to the ball park 10 days later. ''I sat out on the field before the game,'' he says, ''and talked to people about how good it was to finally be back seeing baseball. It was a lovely evening, the players were ready, and all the drama and turmoil, I thought, finally was behind us. I tell you, some of those moments are as fine as I've ever experienced in my life.''
The exhilaration was short-lived, as Vincent was soon beset by the winterlong contract hassles that led to the lockout. And on March 19, the morning after the owners and players finally reached an agreement, the commissioner was back at his desk. Sorting through a stack of paper work and listening to an aria from ''La Traviata,'' he looked haggard. His mood was uncharacteristically grim. ''I think baseball deserves better than what we've just been through,'' he said, frowning. ''I think the game should be better run.
It should be able to manage itself without this sort of major confrontation every four years.'' When he became commissioner, Vincent had said he hoped to end the acrimonious contract battles that have become almost as much a part of the rites of spring as the game itself. He worked behind the scenes last fall to replace management's chief negotiator, Barry Rona -an antagonistic presence because of arbitrators' findings that the owners had colluded to keep down player salaries - with the courtly Charles P. O'Connor. And when negotiations stalled and a lockout appeared imminent, Vincent himself joined the talks - an unprecedented move that a few hard-line owners thought unseemly for the commissioner, but that did not go unnoticed by the other side. As Marvin Miller, the legendary former union chief, observes: ''This was not a man who was putting on a lot of airs of being management on high. That's a refreshing change from past commissioners.''
''I got involved because nothing was happening,'' Vincent says. ''I knew I couldn't just sit there and watch baseball head over a cliff. Whoever holds this office can't just stand by while the season is placed in jeopardy. There's a public trust involved here.''
Traditionally, there have have been two ways of viewing the office of commissioner of baseball - either as the omnipotent protector of the national pastime or as a flunky who ultimately must do the bidding of the club owners who hired him. Those views have varied, depending upon the occupant of the office. But every commissioner - Vincent is the eighth - has been measured against the first, Kenesaw Mountain Landis.
Seeking to forestall Federal regulation and restore public confidence in the face of the 1919 Chicago Black Sox betting scandal, baseball's owners created the post for Landis in 1920. He was a crusty, autocratic Federal judge who insisted upon sweeping unilateral powers to govern the sport and frequently overruled the owners during his 23-year tenure.
While Landis's successors retained those powers, none exercised them so freely. In 1976, when the owners imposed a spring-training lockout, Bowie Kuhn ordered the camps opened, earning the enmity of several owners, a festering rift that helped lead to his ouster eight years later. Kuhn's successor, Peter Ueberroth, fresh from his success in selling the 1984 Los Angeles Olympics, was able to insist on increased independence. By leading baseball into a new era of commercialism, collusion and profits - capped by the astounding $1.5 billion four-year national television package that began this season - Ueberroth reclaimed the commissioner's authority.
During his brief tenure, Giamatti dealt with no major issue that pitted the commissioner's office against the owners. And the jury is still out on how Fay Vincent will use his powers. ''This office carries with it a very strong authority,'' he says. ''It's like having a 16-inch cannon. You ought to polish it regularly, trot it out on ceremonial occasions and let everyone know you have it. But you should never fire it.''
Indeed, during the lockout, Vincent fired no booming salvos, resisting media pressure to order the owners to open the camps. He abandoned the pretenses of previous commissioners who had contended they acted independently of the owners; in fact, Vincent became a key management player, persuading hard-line owners to drop their insistence on a revenue-participation scheme for determining salaries. ''Short of breaking the union and shutting down baseball for a year, you weren't going to win on that point,'' he says.
It was this kind of common-sense conciliation and his up-front approach that gained Vincent the respect of the players' negotiators and won the praise of Donald M. Fehr, the union's executive director. But Vincent's new relationship with the union was nearly undermined by his proposal, announced at a press conference midway through the negotiations, that the owners open the camps in exchange for a union pledge not to strike during the season. Fehr denounced the plan as a publicity stunt, insisting Vincent knew the union would not relinquish its right to strike and was simply trying to put the onus for a delayed season on the players.
It was a grueling period for Vincent. The talks were held in his office, rather than the traditional neutral site, in deference to his difficulty in walking. When he managed to get home, he spent most of his time fielding calls from owners, union officials and reporters. ''What do you mean, what are we going to do, Howard?'' he told Howard Cosell. ''We'll keep at it, until we get this thing settled.''
When a settlement finally was reached, Vincent said he felt vindicated in not having broken with the owners and ordering an end to the lockout. ''If I'd done that, there would not have been a contract agreement,'' he said. ''We'd have started the season, but we'd be waiting for June and July with a strike threat hanging over our heads. At least now, the fans know we're going to have a full season of baseball.''
On Saturdays, Fay Vincent sometimes drives from Greenwich to tour the Connecticut towns he remembers from his youth - usually New Haven, where he was raised and was graduated from Yale Law School; occasionally Waterbury, the old mill city where he was born and where his Irish-American family was rooted.
Vincent was born in 1938, and five years later, the family moved to New Haven, where his father worked for the telephone company and his mother taught kindergarten. He remembers his boyhood as a wholesome slice of 1940's Americana, with the emphasis on sports. The senior Vincent, also known by the Irish-American nickname of Fay, had been captain of the Yale football team and was a college and professional football referee and amateur baseball umpire. And so his son grew up immersed in both sports, tagging along when his father refereed games and rooting for the Yankee baseball teams of DiMaggio and Mantle.
At the Hotchkiss School in Lakeville, Conn., young Fay played guard on the football team, excelled at Latin and French and was remembered by classmates for his witty parodies of the poetry of Keats and Coleridge. ''He was a moose of a guy, with short legs and big shoulders,'' recalls his Hotchkiss football linemate, William H. T. (Bucky) Bush. ''Half the plays we'd run would be over Vincent.'' After graduation, the two linemates spent a summer working in the Texas oilfields of Bucky Bush's older brother, George, and they stayed briefly with George and Barbara Bush. ''The President tells me we used to leave a layer of grease in his pool every time we went swimming,'' Vincent says. While a freshman at Williams College, Vincent suffered the back injury that still plagues him. As a prank, his roommate locked him in their dormitory room, and Vincent climbed on the roof to try to escape. He slipped on an icy ledge and fell four stories, smashing two vertebrae and crushing his spine. His legs were paralyzed, and Vincent spent three months strapped to a frame contraption that his sister Barbara recalls ''looked like something out of the Middle Ages.'' Despite doctors' pessimistic warnings to his family, he learned to walk again.
''No one ever told me I wasn't going to be able to walk, and it never occurred to me I wouldn't,'' Vincent says. His physical rehabilitation proceeded so well - ''largely by his own sheer will power,'' Barbara says - that by the time he graduated from Williams, he no longer needed a cane. He only began using it again about five years ago, when he developed arthritis, and now, when he goes to a ball park, he uses a golf cart to get around the field. ''Walking for me is like doing push-ups,'' he says.
After Yale Law School, Vincent practiced law in New York and Washington, then worked briefly for the Securities and Exchange Commission. In 1978, Herbert A. Allen, whose family's investment banking firm controlled Columbia Pictures, asked Vincent to head the scandal-plagued company, which had been shaken by disclosures that its studio chief, David Begelman, had forged checks and misappropriated company funds. Vincent, whom Allen had known from Williams, was an odd choice; he had never run a business and knew nothing about the film industry. But Allen believed Vincent, with his impeccable S.E.C. and legal credentials, could help restore Columbia's credibility. ''I thought Fay could come in and make it a major-league company,'' Allen says. ''And that's exactly what he did.''
''Going from the S.E.C. on a Friday, as a $47,000-a-year bureaucrat, to running one of the world's seven major movie companies on Monday was absolutely astonishing,'' Vincent recalls, adding the story of one studio executive who ''told me my biggest problem was I wasn't paranoid enough. I said to him, 'You know, where I come from that's a compliment.' ''
As Columbia's president and chief executive officer, Vincent initiated new management and accounting procedures (''There was a lot of chiseling going on,'' he says), fought off a hostile takeover by the corporate raider Kirk Kerkorian and was credited with expanding the company's profitable television and videocassette operations. The movie studio's record during Vincent's tenure was more mixed, as early successes such as ''Kramer vs. Kramer'' and ''Ghostbusters'' were followed by the infamous ''Ishtar'' and other box-office bombs. When the Coca-Cola Company purchased Columbia Pictures in 1982, Vincent was placed in charge of Coke's entertainment sector. Five years later, as the division's once impressive earnings began to decline, he was offered a senior post running Coke's international soft-drink joint ventures. Coca-Cola officials deny they sought to nudge him out of the company. But, Vincent says: ''If they were, I got the hint. It was time to go.''
The Seattle Kingdome, a domed concrete barn of a stadium, is not Fay Vincent's kind of park. ''Indoor baseball is not the preferred version of the game,'' he says. But he had flown across the country to show the flag of his office before what was to be the first sellout crowd in the 13-year history of the Seattle Mariners.
It was opening night, and Vincent's appearance in Seattle was intended as a public-relations boost to what has been one of baseball's least successful franchises. Before the game, he dutifully toured the field, rolling along the Kingdome carpet in a golf cart and stopping along the stands to sign autographs. When his big moment arrived, the throwing of the first ball, he was given the cue too soon and had to stage a repeat toss for the cameras after the Mariners' catcher had returned to the dugout.
''This is all part of marketing,'' Vincent quipped, after being greeted by the Mariner moose. ''I know my role in this game.'' There was baseball played in the Kingdome that night. But there were also fireworks, machine-churned smoke streaming from the outfield wall, blaring rock videos on the DiamondVision screen and a laser-light show beaming onto the Kingdome ceiling.
''That's show biz,'' he said. ''I don't really mind it. Now, if it gets too carried away, that's another thing. I don't like parachute shows or guys getting shot out of cannons. But for opening day, well, it's an entertainment device.''
Clearly, Vincent, with his decade in the entertainment business, understands the value of marketing. But he is also a lifelong fan who concedes he is ''basically a traditionalist.'' He is not a fan of domes or artificial turf and plans to ask club owners to restore natural grass fields wherever possible. He opposes the American League's designated-hitter rule and intends to ''lobby tastefully'' for its abolition. Yet when he lists his priorities, Vincent sounds less like a baseball purist and more like baseball's C.E.O. He has launched programs to expand the sales of licensed products and to promote the game and its television rights internationally. He stresses the need to improve labor relations, to establish a more aggressive affirmative-action program for hiring from minorities as managers and executives. And later this season, Vincent will approve a joint labor-management commission to study the game's economic status and consider the financial inequities among franchises, a contentious issue among owners that has been recently exacerbated by the widely varying revenues from local television rights. In the coming weeks, Vincent is expected to rule on the touchiest issue facing him - the investigation of the accused extortionist Howard Spira's claims that the Yankee owner George Steinbrenner paid him for information to discredit the outfielder Dave Winfield. For now, Vincent will not comment. But ultimately he must decide whether Steinbrenner should be fined, or even suspended, actions that would not necessarily displease other owners who have long resented the bellicose, free-spending Yankee boss. As for his own plans, Vincent says he does not look beyond his term as commissioner, which expires at the start of the 1994 season. ''One of the advantages I have is I don't have to work anymore if I don't want to,'' he says, back in his office, where he seems delighted to find the first All-Star baseballs bearing his signature have just arrived. ''Financially, I think I have greater resources than some of the owners. That gives me a certain independence other commissioners didn't have. I'm not here looking for the next job.
''When I was at Columbia and Coca-Cola, I wasn't passionately devoted to movies and television. That was not my life. Here, my passion and my job overlap almost completely.'' He leans back in his chair and smiles. ''You simply can not wear me out with baseball.''

AND BEAR IN MIND
(Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)
 
FIVE O'CLOCK ANGEL: Letters of Tennessee Williams to Maria St. Just, 1948-1982. (Knopf, $24.95.) Williams's letters to the Russian-born Englishwoman Maria St. Just reveal a cheerful, tender, civilized man far different from what has become the drugged, drunken, despondent received version of the playwright.
 
LETTERS OF KATHERINE ANNE PORTER, edited by Isabel Bayley. (Atlantic Monthly, $29.95.) Letters of astonishing clarity, keenness and vigor showing the author of ''Pale Horse, Pale Rider'' as a solid critic of life and a good help to her friends.
 
FRANCOIS TRUFFAUT: CORRESPONDENCE 1945-1984, edited by Gilles Jacob and Claude de Givray. (Noonday/Farrar, Straus & Giroux, Cloth, $50; Paper, $19.95.) A hefty, well-annotated collection of the great French director's almost compulsive correspondence - often joking, always self-revealing.
 
WRITERS IN HOLLYWOOD: 1915-1951, by Ian Hamilton. (Edward Burlingame/Harper & Row, $25.) An ably researched and entertaining account of the literati who condescended to, and profited by, the movie industry during its infant and golden years.
 
A HIGHER KIND OF LOYALTY: A Memoir by China's Foremost Journalist, by Liu Binyan. (Pantheon, $22.95.) Repeatedly Mr. Liu wrote the truth; repeatedly he was punished for it, but never gave up faith in the party until Tiananmen Square. Strange and sad.
 
THEN SHE FOUND ME, by Elinor Lipman. (Pocket Books, $18.95.) A deft, amusing first novel, full of entertaining mysteries, about an adopted daughter awkwardly reunited with her birth mother.
 
THE KING, by Donald Barthelme. (Edward Burlingame/Harper & Row, $16.95.) The author, who died last year, left us one more wild, parodic metafiction; in this one, King Arthur meets World War II.

The New York Times

SECTION: Section 7; Page 14, Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1147 words

HEADLINE: THE DEFICIT: A LOOK AT THE BRIGHT SIDE

BYLINE: By NORMAN J. ORNSTEIN; Norman J. Ornstein, a resident scholar at the American Enterprise Institute, is co-writing a book on American fiscal policy to be called ''Debt and Taxes.''

 BODY:

THE DEFICIT AND THE PUBLIC INTEREST
The Search for Responsible Budgeting in the 1980s.
By Joseph White and Aaron Wildavsky.
671 pp. Berkeley, Calif.:
University of California Press/
Russell Sage Foundation. $45.
If it's spring, it must be budget season - although, come to think of it, in the past decade summer, fall and winter have been budget season, too. Our political and economic systems have become at one and the same time consumed with and overwhelmed by budget politics and deficits. We are not only obsessed with our budget process, endlessly analyzing and arguing over it; we are also engaged in systematic self-flagellation over our failure to master it. 
Books about the deficit - by scholars, Reagan Administration insiders, businessmen and economic journalists - are everywhere, explaining, interpreting, blaming, defending, castigating. And even as legions of lawmakers and private citizens from Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union make respectful pilgrimages to Washington to learn how our political process works, our politicians and journalists continue to disparage it, pointing to the deficit as Exhibit A in the case against Congress and the President.
It would be easy to conclude that nothing more can be said about the subject: after all, everybody knows about our obvious failures and, besides, the basic elements of the political struggle are stultifyingly similar year after year, including this one. But it would be wrong. ''The Deficit and the Public Interest'' should be required reading for anyone who has followed the deficit debate, in particular all those, including politicians and pundits, who have made a career out of bashing and belittling our institutions because of our deficits.
Frankly, on the surface, this task won't look too easy. Joseph White and Aaron Wildavsky's book is a hefty 671 pages, including notes, and contains page after page of meticulous detail from an impressive array of sources about how budget decisions were made and not made from 1979 to 1989. To read it fully takes some discipline, and some basic knowledge of legislative procedures and jargon. Fortunately, the writing style is felicitous, lively and clear. That, along with both the careful, honest, straightforward marshaling of argument and data and the power of the thesis, makes the effort worthwhile.
The thesis is neither liberal nor conservative, neither Keynesian nor supply-side. In a nutshell it is this: The decisions our policy makers have made have been neither irrational nor irresponsible. ''The deficit is high because reducing it will have serious adverse consequences for virtually everybody, and therefore for the country as a whole. Until that fact is faced; until politicians, the media, and the public admit that the difficulty is not a lack of courage or insidious 'special' interests dominating the 'public' interest, debate will remain distorted and unproductive.''
As that quotation suggests, Mr. White, a research associate at the Brookings Institution, and Mr. Wildavsky, a professor of political science at the University of California, Berkeley, begin with a startling and - sadly - unconventional assumption: that politicians are neither driven by evil or weak motives, nor are they all, beneath the surface, conniving and dishonest. From there, without defending the indefensible, they make their case for the rationality of the budget process by carefully recounting and explaining the events, from Jimmy Carter's struggles with an increasingly uncontrollable economy, through the budget and tax cuts of Reagan's first year, to the efforts in Washington to cope with the aftermath of huge deficits.
The case Mr. White and Mr. Wildavsky make will annoy or even infuriate lots of people - not the least because their evidence is strong and persuasive. Democrats will be irked because the authors portray Ronald Reagan (in the best argument yet made) as a strong, rational and purposeful leader, not as a doddering and confused ideologue. Republicans will be uneasy because Mr. White and Mr. Wildavsky show Congress as an institution making reasonable and understandable decisions, as its members struggle in good faith to balance legitimate competing views. Liberals will be furious over the argument that big deficits were not caused by Mr. Reagan - that, in considerable part, they were inevitable, given policy choices made in the early 1970's and an economy that did not perform up to expectations or projections.
The most upset of all will be those purveyors of conventional wisdom who are convinced that the persistence of deficits shows our system is in shameful tatters and in dire need of sweeping constitutional reform. To Mr. White and Mr. Wildavsky, the evidence shows other things. First, an awful lot has been done to reduce deficits, something very easy to forget until it is recounted to us in detail. They note that Congress ''stopped the defense buildup, passed two substantial tax hikes (mostly on businesses), created a growing Social Security surplus, cut Medicare providers, squeezed and then Gramm-Rudmaned the domestic discretionary budget.'' EVEN so, big deficits persisted. Why? Basically because bigger questions overshadowed them. ''You might say that the participants in budgeting agree on everything except how much revenue should be raised and who should pay, how much should be spent and which programs should benefit. Whether balance is achieved at low or high levels of spending would determine the future shape of our government, and our politicians quite reasonably act as if that is as important as the deficit itself.''
Mr. White and Mr. Wildavsky would like to see deficits reduced, although they are not hysterical about their size (relative to our gross national product). Mostly they are worried about the continuing legitimacy and strength of our governing institutions. They believe - correctly, I think - that our obsession with deficits has more to do with our perception of them as a metaphor for governing than with evidence of their effect on the economy.
''Politicians of the center,'' they say, ''have come to see the deficit as a symbol of their own inadequacy. Having made elimination of the deficit the test of their ability to govern, they have come to see the deficit as a crisis because they cannot solve it, not because of any harm it causes.'' Be cool, the authors advise. Set a modest and achievable deficit-reduction goal, achieve it, declare victory and move on to more productive things. As President Bush, White House budget director Richard G. Darman, Speaker of the House Thomas S. Foley, Senate Majority Leader George J. Mitchell and their colleagues proceed to do battle again this year, and as the usual kibitzers prepare to second-guess them, they would all be well served to take time out to read this book and heed its advice.

LENGTH: 1611 words

HEADLINE: WHAT THEY KNEW AND WHEN THEY KNEW IT

BYLINE: By J. ANTHONY LUKAS; J. Anthony Lukas is the author of ''Nightmare: The Underside of the Nixon Years.''

 BODY:

THE WARS OF WATERGATE
The Last Crisis of Richard Nixon.
By Stanley I. Kutler.
Illustrated. 733 pp. New York:
Alfred A. Knopf. $24.95.
Shortly after Richard Nixon resigned the Presidency in August 1974, his son-in-law David Eisenhower predicted that in 15 years Watergate would ''look pretty small.'' Some while later, the former President himself told reporters, ''History will treat me fairly.'' 
Today, a decade and a half after that apocalyptic time, one must say: wrong, Mr. Eisenhower; right, Mr. President.
''The Wars of Watergate'' is the first major work by a professional historian to focus on the scandal and the investigations that felled the Nixon Presidency. Stanley I. Kutler, who teaches at the University of Wisconsin, clearly does not regard Watergate as a small thing. He treats it at 733-page length, and by and large he gives Mr. Nixon just what he deserves.
An able historian, Mr. Kutler has made his long march through the original sources, including materials in the Nixon papers, the records of the Watergate special prosecution force and those of the Senate Select Committee. Moreover, he has interviewed 63 people who had some connection with the Watergate events, among them former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew, former Attorney General John Mitchell, the former White House counsel John Dean and Richard M. Helms, the former Director of Central Intelligence.
Given the depth of Mr. Kutler's research and his impressive access to major participants, his volume is something of a disappointment. If it contains no thunderous revelations, that should be no surprise: Watergate has been pretty thoroughly raked over by news-hungry journalists and other investigators. But that the book is also short on fresh insights and thoughtful analysis is more puzzling.
Recognizing that the territory has been well trod, Mr. Kutler eschews a step-by-step recital. But for those who may not know the full story, his elisions can be troublesome. The germ of the Watergate break-ins - G. Gordon Liddy's Gemstone plan - is treated so casually that many readers may not be able to make sense of it. Nor does Mr. Kutler spend much time on the two Watergate burglaries themselves. And he gives short shrift to such ancillary subjects as Mr. Nixon's tax troubles, the illegalities of his campaign fund raising and the use of public monies on his California and Florida houses.
Indeed, ''The Wars of Watergate'' focuses much less on the Administration's high crimes and misdemeanors than on the subsequent investigations, particularly the work of the United States Attorney's office, the Justice Department, the special prosecution force, the Senate Select Committee and the House Judiciary Committee. This produces some portraiture etched in acid: a scathing description of the way Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., the leading Republican on the Senate committee, played both sides of the fence; the picture of a weak, procrastinating Peter W. Rodino Jr., chairman of the House committee; some back-of-the-hand swipes at the House Judiciary Committee's bumbling special counsel, John M. Doar, and at the ''honest but incompetent'' White House special counsel, J. Fred Buzhardt.
The major themes Mr. Kutler advances - that Watergate was rooted in Mr. Nixon's lifelong political personality, that he was at all times in full charge of his Administration - are scarcely fresh. But there is another, more surprising theme lurking here just beneath the ambling surface: in brief, that the system worked. Mr. Kutler contends that once the Watergate burglars were arrested, the men entrusted with uncovering the wrongdoing - notably the assistant United States attorney Earl J. Silbert and his staff - did their jobs well and deserve most of the credit for breaking the case.
This runs counter to the main thrust of the reporting at the time, which tended to be critical of Mr. Silbert and his superiors at the Justice Department for ignoring some important leads, for bypassing several major aspects of the case, for failing to offer immunity to one of the burglars in order to get information on the others and for showing undue deference to the White House.
Mr. Kutler does not grapple seriously with the argument that Mr. Silbert's office and the Justice Department cooperated with the White House to limit the investigation, at least initially. He merely asserts the contrary: that ''the U.S. Attorney's office had in fact discovered the cover-up conspiracy and had broken the case by the time [the special prosecutor Archibald] Cox took control, and before Senator [Sam] Ervin's committee provided a public venting of what the prosecutors had learned.''
But there is a still larger implication in Mr. Kutler's implicit theory, namely, that all the Watergate hoopla, the big splashy Congressional investigations and especially the press's ballyhooed investigative reporting did not play a central role in what happened. This stance is particularly evident in Mr. Kutler's treatment of Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein, The Washington Post's celebrated reporters, for whom he seems to harbor an ill-disguised disdain.
He says The Post built its Watergate stories ''primarily on raw [F.B.I.] reports.'' Again, he offers no evidence for this; he merely asserts it. The raw bureau reports are presumably the 302's, summaries of unevaluated, unsubstantiated material, replete with fourth-hand information and suspicions. Mr. Bernstein has said that ''using a 302 as the sole basis for a story was unthinkable.'' Mr. Woodward has flatly denied that the pair used 302's.
In discussing Mr. Woodward and Mr. Bernstein's first Watergate book, ''All the President's Men,'' Mr. Kutler writes that some critics questioned their ''failure to address any of the ethical deficiencies of their investigative reporting, including offering of bribes, illegally gaining access to telephone numbers, and talking to members of the grand jury.'' In fact, Mr. Woodward and Mr. Bernstein do own up to, and express some misgivings about, the last two charges. As for their ''offering of bribes,'' neither I nor anyone I consulted has ever heard of it.
Mr. Kutler provides no direct evidence for the accusation, but he footnotes two reviews, one by Richard H. Rovere in The New Yorker, the other by Doris Kearns in The New York Times Book Review. The only mention made of bribes in either is Ms. Kearns's statement that ''Woodward refused a bribe for an interview.'' In the incident in question, as related in ''All the President's Men,'' Mr. Woodward and his editor, Ben Bradlee, indignantly declined to pay thousands of dollars for an interview with a former F.B.I. man. (The only other episode in the book mentioning ''bribery'' is one in which Mr. Woodward rejects an implied deal by the attorney for the Presidential assistant Charles W. Colson to supply some memos if The Post agrees not to pursue a more explosive matter.) How does Mr. Woodward's refusal of a bribe become ''offering of bribes''? Mr. Kutler has done Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein a disservice.
The role of the press in Watergate is much-disputed ground. Surely there is ample room to doubt the simple-minded notion that Mr. Woodward and Mr. Bernstein ''brought down'' a President. But while this subject may deserve tough-minded analysis - such as that offered by Edward Jay Epstein in his cogent 1975 essay, ''Did the Press Uncover Watergate?'' - Mr. Kutler presents scarcely half a dozen paragraphs, with his harshest criticism inaccurately attributed to book reviewers.
For a scholar so dismissive of reporters' work, Mr. Kutler has some difficulty establishing his own factual base. His book is heavily speckled with evasive adverbs: ''reportedly,'' ''supposedly,'' ''doubtless,'' ''undoubtedly.'' Consider the following sentence: ''Nixon doubtless considered McGovern dangerous to national security and the economy.'' Certainly Mr. Nixon found it convenient to portray George McGovern as dangerous, but what he believed on this score remains unproven. Mr. Kutler's ''doubtless'' could have been omitted if he had any evidence. Here, as elsewhere, the word signals exactly the opposite of what it says.
Wrong, Mr. Eisenhower. Right, Mr. President. Fair to middling, Mr. Kutler.
 
 
 
HE WILL GET HIS DUE
 Nixon certainly will be remembered for his role in world affairs. He will receive heavy measures of both praise and criticism, and historians of both the Right and the Left probably will cross sides in unpredictable ways. It might never have occurred to Richard Nixon that so-called leftist historians helped rehabilitate Herbert Hoover. Whatever historians do, however, no ''fair'' history of the Nixon era can overlook the centrality of Watergate. Textbooks a century from now will inevitably speak of Richard Nixon as the first president to resign because of scandals. His achievements will get their due, as different generations weigh them, favorably or unfavorably, but they probably will not rival Watergate for historical attention. . . .
Not every president has stood in danger of impeachment. Neither Nixon nor we can escape Watergate. . . . It was neither trivial nor insignificant. It raised important, painful questions about American political behavior and the American political system, questions that speak to the traditions and structure of American life. Whether the actors in the drama of Watergate confronted those questions successfully or unsuccessfully, directly or passively, honestly or conveniently, will be the subject for history. That is the significant, inescapable importance of Watergate.
 
From ''The Wars of Watergate.''

HEADLINE: Waterfront Renewal Turns to Greenpoint

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER

 BODY:
A developer who built his reputation in Manhattan high-rise construction is embarking on the first major effort to redevelop the long-neglected East River waterfront in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn.
The developer, Ian Bruce Eichner, envisions a 13-building, 3,324-unit co-op and rental apartment complex rising from the site of the rundown Greenpoint Terminal Warehouse and other factory buildings that have sat vacant for 20 years. Total construction cost for the project, called Greenpoint Common on the River, is estimated at $350 million to $400 million, with an average unit price of $200,000.
Although construction is at least two years away, Mr. Eichner's plans have already set off a sharp debate in the mostly blue-collar community about how best to revitalize the area's valuable waterfront. 
To Marsilia Boyle, a third-generation resident and member of Community Board 1, the project is ''too tall, too dense and too expensive.''
Like Ms. Boyle, many feel that towers as high as 38 stories represent not only an unacceptable change in character for the low-rise neighborhood, but also a missed opportunity for a more varied use of the property.
''His project has no relation whatsoever to the communty in which he intends to put it,'' said Ms. Boyle. ''It's like sticking something from another planet on Earth.''
But Mr. Eichner considers his proposal an ideal project at an ideal time. After a decade of developing such major Manhattan projects as Cityspire, a 72-story residential and office complex on West 56th Street east of Seventh Avenue, and the 44-story, One Broadway Place office and retail complex at Broadway and 45th Street, astronomical land prices turned his attention to the other boroughs, where he began his career.
The reason, he said, is the city is encouraging development - possibly with tax abatements - outside of Manhattan and on the waterfront, especially in dilapidated areas with few jobs and many vacant buildings.
''New York has the most underdeveloped waterfront of any city in the United States,'' Mr. Eichner said, noting that he had spent six months studying the Queens and Brooklyn waterfronts. ''What we are dealing with I think is just a wonderful opportunity for a private initiative that is consistent with public policy.''
After considering a number of sites - including one in Hunters Point in Queens - last summer Mr. Eichner found the 14-acre riverfront plot in Greenpoint between Greenpoint Avenue to the north, Franklin Street to the east and Oak Street to the south. All but one of the site's 10 buildings - which served mostly as distribution centers for textiles, grains, rope and other goods - were vacant.
With a two-year option to lease the land - most of it owned by the estate of Sol Goldman and the rest by Irving Goldman, the late Mr. Goldman's brother - he hopes to have the site rezoned from manufacturing to residential. His environmental consultants, Alee King Rosen & Fleming of Manhattan, will soon begin the required environmental impact statement, one of the first in many steps that, if all goes as planned, will take the rezoning issue before the City Council by the end of next year.
Then he intends to demolish the old warehouses, and, over the next five to seven years, build a 3.7-million-square-foot complex, his largest residential project to date. The new structures, mostly arranged around a grassy park, would start at two stories near the existing homes and step up toward the river to 38 floors - a height that frightens even strong advocates of the project. One-third of the site would be open space and there would be an esplanade, 100 feet at its widest, along the river.
The architect, Alexander Cooper of Cooper Robertson & Partners, said the priority for the project was to ''open and ventilate the site in a way that it gives not only visual access but physical access through the site.''
Mr. Cooper, who designed guidelines for Battery Park City, said he is striving to create buildings of differing sizes and shapes that will mix with both the industrial waterfront and the inland residential area.
But no matter how the project may look on paper, many in the community feel it could not be more foreign - in size, design and use.
David Sweeny, director of economic development for the North Brooklyn Development Corporation, said Mr. Eichner's project reflects a ''cookie cutter'' mentality of development that seeks to place in Brooklyn a project more suited to Manhattan. ''When you have a site like this you want to go for bulk,'' he said. ''You want to cram as much as you can in there.''
While stressing that his nonprofit community development organization has not taken a formal position on the project, he said: ''From my point of view personally, it's bad planning. It's a mass-produced, pie-in-the-sky plan.''
Beyond the esthetics, the size and its relationship with the community, some also argue with the idea of a fully private, market-rate residential use of waterfront land in Greenpoint-Williamsburg.
Ms. Boyle of Community Board 1 said that as a result of meetings with community groups last summer, the board drafted a list of six priorities for development on the waterfront. In addition to height restrictions and low density, the list calls for leisure and recreational facilities, affordable housing and mixed uses that could include some commercial or even light industrial space. Under provisions of the new City Charter, the board is working on its own waterfront master plan.
Mr. Eichner contended that his project addresses many of those issues. He repeatedly called the project ''affordable,'' in that the target buyers are families with two wage earners who together earn between $70,000 and $100,000 but cannot afford to live in Manhattan.
Moreover, the developer asserted, the project will open to the public a rundown waterfront that has been closed off for at least five years.
His supporters add that the development offers the best hope to renew an area with increasing blight and crime. And some feel that by negotiating with Mr. Eichner now, when the project is just starting, they can gain such concessions as housing for the elderly within the project and parking for the surrounding neighborhood.
The cost of such improvements may be a willingness to live with a project that, to turn a profit, is more dense than even they would prefer.
''I personally would like to see a smaller-scale development, some small buildings, some retail shops, a theater on the waterfront,'' said Thomas Diffley, 35 years old, of Milton Street, who considers himself a ''cautious'' supporter of the project. ''But I don't think its going to work. The numbers aren't there.''

HEADLINE: Reaching for the Sky to Add a Room

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
 STANDING atop the Plaza Hotel, with the leafy carpet of Central Park laid out 19 stories below, Lee Harris Pomeroy finds irony in the project he is about to begin - a $20 million reconstruction of the 83-year-old hotel's roof and top two floors into 14 penthouse suites.
''The irony,'' said Mr. Pomeroy, a Manhattan architect who has already restored its interior, ''is that the most valuable space in a city where buildings meet the sky has been relegated to water tanks, paint sheds, equipment storage and maids' rooms.''
Although not many New Yorkers can afford to think as expansively as Mr. Pomeroy - or spend as much money as the Plaza's owner, Donald Trump - people across the city have reached similar conclusions. Hundreds of roofs on older buildings, some of them offering views of the city, its parks and rivers, have gone underutilized for decades.
Now, even with the city's economy slumping and new construction slowing to a trickle, some people are striving to add space and value to their residences by building penthouses, greenhouses, decks and other additions on their roofs. 
''Generally speaking, older residential buildings in the city were not built to the maximum density allowed, and we have an ability to add at least a small area on top,'' said Douglas Korves, a Manhattan architect who has designed several roof additions. He added that zoning laws and the strength of the steel beams used to support roofs before World War II are creating incentives for rooftop construction.
At the Plaza, where Mr. Pomeroy said the penthouses might each fetch as much as $1 million a year in rent, the roof and upper floors are now a neglected eyesore, hidden from view at street level by a phalanx of cornice work. Ornate pavilions at the corners of the roof are used to conceal a paint shed and water tank.
The hotel's elevator shafts erupt skyward in rusting metal cages. Beneath the cornices and rooftop eaves, an entire floor is littered with telephone equipment, industrial pallets and musty storerooms.
''Historically in New York, people lived close to the ground and regarded the tops of buildings as decorative,'' Mr. Pomeroy said. ''That means we have an underutilized asset.'' But those who have completed roof additions, even on a tiny scale compared to what is planned for the Plaza, warn that disputes with neighbors and regulatory snarls can delay or derail the projects. And those planning to build on top of their buildings should be prepared for months, if not years, of difficulties.
''To people who can build on to their roofs, I would definitely say do it, but be prepared for a long arduous process,'' said Fausto Hilario, a New York City psychologist who, with 10 other apartment owners on the top floor of a loft building on East 21st Street in Manhattan, last year completed work on small rooms on the roofs above each apartment. The minipenthouses open on to decks and terraces. ''The work seemed to go on forever,'' he added. Indeed, according to architects and builders, what might appear to homeowners as a simple addition to the roof - a hole to install a stairway, one or two small rooms and a pretty little terrace with flowers - is much easier to imagine than to build.
Logistical problems abound. How do you get building materials up an elevator without creating havoc among fellow tenants? Could they be hoisted up the side of the building? Legal questions can be murky. If you have the right to build on a roof, exactly what part of it can you claim?
''If people have roof rights, they tend to think that they can build the Taj Mahal,'' said Marc Luxemburg, the president of the Council of New York Cooperatives and a lawyer who has represented several parties on both sides of disputes over roof additions.
Mr. Luxemburg and other experts said one of the uncertainties facing people with apartments on the top floors of co-op or condominium buildings is the meaning of the term ''roof rights'' - a widely used but poorly defined concept. Many prospectuses or sales agreements assign such rights to apartment owners.
But rarely do the legal papers spell out what, if any, construction is allowed.
''Nobody should buy an apartment expecting to add space without getting something in writing from the board that says, given city approval, you will be permitted to do it,'' said Mr. Korves. Prospective buyers who hope to build on a roof, he added, should also hire an engineer or architect to make sure the building's roof is capable of carrying the additional weight.
Even those who have received consent from their boards must negotiate other agreements in detail, the experts said. People responsible for building on a roof are almost always liable for leaks or other structural damage that affects other apartments. Any changes in wiring, plumbing or drainage pipes must be approved, and the details of how building materials are to be taken up to the roof must be negotiated in advance.
In most cases, since people adding to their apartments are adding to the size and value of a co-op or condominium building, they are also assessed additional monthly payments for maintenance.
In co-ops, that usually means assigning additional shares to the expanded apartment, and the number of shares or amount of monthly payments must also be negotiated in advance.
Mr. Luxemburg said many suits have been won by co-op boards or neighbors of those who have begun roof construction without the necessary approvals.
In some cases, people have been forced to remove partially completed rooftop additions. In others, they have faced the wrath of their neighbors later, when they tried to sell their apartments, and the boards of their buildings refused to approve the sale without changes in the additions or increased maintenance charges.
In recent years, city approvals have sometimes proven easier than negotiations with co-op and condominium boards. Architects say small greenhouses and other small roof structures have been built across New York City over the last 10 years simply on the basis of a ''building notice.''
In a building notice, architects or engineers file a statement with the Buildings Department attesting that zoning and building code restrictions are not being violated. City inspectors need not come to the site for detailed review of the project.
The type of construction approved under building notices has been the simplest kind - decks, terraces or small structures that the city considers in a broad category as temporary greenhouses. Some of the greenhouses contain other furnishings besides plants and have been erected as long-term, if not permanent, additions.
In most large old residential buildings, the city has approved building notices for roof additions that add up to 1 percent of the total square footage of the building.
But the city's rules changed this year, and approvals could become more difficult to get. In an administrative revision, the Buildings Department now considers greenhouses permanent additions to roofs. A visit is required by a city inspector, and those adding up to 1 percent or more of the building's square footage can no longer assume that their applications will be approved.
Nonetheless, Vahe Tiryakian, the spokesman for the Buildings Department, said that the change was ''only a matter of nomenclature'' and that standards for approving roof construction have not been altered.
To be sure, not all residential buildings are suitable for roof construction. Most built since World War II - and almost all that went up since the early 60's - were built to the maximum height and density allowable under zoning laws.
Although developers are sometimes able to find ways around the zoning laws by buying the air rights from neighboring structures, such complex and expensive legal maneuvers rarely make sense for the owners of apartments or small residential structures.
But in older buildings, experts say, there is an advantage. Few of the apartment buildings erected more than 45 years ago were designed to their maximum size.
An added incentive in some large prewar buildings is that their roofs were supported by networks of steel beams capable of supporting more stress than is dictated by current safety standards, and therefore provide ample strength for a roof addition, according to architects who specialize in the field.
Still, those considering a project on the roof should take into account the frustrations they may encounter. One case that illustrates the difficulties, as well as rewards, is Mr. Hilario's building on East 21st Street.
The 1920 building, a former factory, was converted to co-ops in 1980. At the time, those who bought the 12 apartments on the top floor were assigned roof rights, and the prospectus on the building even delineated in a rough way what part of the roof each was entitled to claim.
Almost immediately after the conversion, one of the top-floor owners built a greenhouse above his apartment. But when the others planned their additions, things quickly became complicated.
''The building code is always subject to interpretation, and we agonized over approvals for this building,'' said Jack Suben, a Manhattan architect who was hired by the apartment owners in 1985. By that time, he said, other architects and engineers had been consulted and either advised against building on the roof or told the apartment owners that the most the city would approve was tiny additions of about 8 feet by 8 feet over each apartment.
Meanwhile, even though their sales agreements had given them roof rights, Mr. Hilario, who bought his apartment in 1985, said internal negotiations were not going smoothly. The building's board wavered, he said, at first saying it would not challenge plans to build on the roof, then saying it would fight the project. In the end, he added, the board approved the plan, but assessed each of the top-floor owners additional monthly maintenance charges.
The owners on the top floor also squabbled. ''It is hard enough to get two neighbors to agree on something like this, and we had 11,'' Mr. Hilario said.
The first step after Mr. Suben was hired in 1985 was to get city approvals, which proved more difficult than in many other applications for rooftop additions. It took a full year and required arbitration by a Buildings Department expediter. The architect said he was determined to win approval for greenhouses that would measure 150 square feet to 250 square feet, and in the end prevailed by citing the city's policy of allowing roof additions of 1 percent of a building's total floor area.
Once the plan was approved, the apartment owners sought a bid from a contractor, who came back with an estimate far higher than they expected or were willing to pay - $200,000 for each of the additions.
Mr. Suben said that disappointment aggravated tensions already building within the group, which could not agree on working together with a single architect and builder. ''I couldn't get these people to sit down together in the same room for 20 minutes,'' he added. Each owner decided to go it alone. One problem confronted by many other roof builders was resolved at the East 21st Street building when contractors agreed to use materials that could fit into an elevator and be carried by hand up a fire escape to the roof.
But another common problem - leaking water - became a disaster when a subcontractor cut a hole in the roof to install a stairway and left the opening uncovered overnight. Heavy rain poured into the apartment below and seriously damaged two others on a lower floor.
''Fortunately, the general contractor stuck by the job,'' said Mr. Suben, adding that all costs of repairing the damage were paid by the contractor.
He said that experience provided a lesson for others - check the references of all contractors and make sure their work is bonded and insured.
Despite the problems, Mr. Suben said the costs of additions were far lower than early estimates had suggested. Each apartment owner paid between $30,000 and $45,000, he said, not including the ongoing expense of their increased monthly maintenance payments to the co-op.
Mr. Hilario, whose apartment before the addition was a 450-square-foot studio, now has a spiral staircase leading to his room on the roof. The little penthouse measures 10 feet by 15 feet and has four windows and a sliding glass door leading to his own terrace and garden.
''It gives the apartment an expansive feeling,'' he said, adding that the project, despite its frustrations, was ''well worth the effort.''

HEADLINE: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester;
Rental Apartments Thriving in Stamford

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
RENTAL apartments are popular in Stamford, where housing now lingers unsold for an average of 163 days. In the boom days several years ago it took only 30 days to sell a home, and prices have dropped 20 to 24 percent since then.
''Rentals thrive in an economy like this, when people won't buy for fear of further depreciation,'' said Alan Schap, who heads the rental division of William Raveis Realty in Stamford. ''We are having the strongest season ever, running 20 to 30 percent ahead of last year.'' 
New downtown buildings have done well. ''We haven't had anything like them in a long time,'' said Jon Smith, the city planner. ''This is a reaction to the all-condo market. For anybody on the housing ladder, rentals are a necessary interim place.''
The Trammell Crow Group, the giant developer from Dallas, has stepped onto this fertile ground with Town Glen, a four-story, 197-unit complex being built on 3.6 acres of Glenbrook Road off Main Street, a residential neighborhood a quarter of a mile from the center of town. Scheduled to open early in 1991, it provides a startling contrast to Stamford's urbane, multistoried downtown buildings like Canterbury Green on Main Street, the Biltmore on Greyrock Place and the Classic on Forest Avenue.
Resembling a country inn, the white clapboard structure designed by Niles Bolton, an Atlanta architect, forms a square around a landscaped courtyard with a heated swimming pool. The complex will provide a smorgasbord of free amenities for tenants, including an indoor racquetball court, Nautilus and aerobics rooms, a clubhouse and a 373-space underground garage. A concierge will have myriad duties, including arranging for dry cleaning and car repairs.
Entrances will be controlled by punch cards and there will be four tenant and two service elevators. Prices range from $900 for a 705-square-foot, one-bedroom apartment to $1,400 for a 1,236-square-foot, two-bedroom-and-den layout.
Forty percent of the units will have gas fireplaces, lofts, washer-dryers and one or two decks. Washer-dryer hookups and a laundry room will also be available. Kitchen appliances and wallpaper, carpeting and mini-blinds are in all units. The ground floor will have 7,800 square feet of professional offices along an old-fashioned porch.
Trammell Crow's foray into Stamford was preceded by two successful rental projects in Middletown and Manchester, where some 1,350 apartments were promptly leased on completion and 500 more are being built.
THE company keeps prices down through its enormous buying power. Its popularity is generated by attention to details focusing on creature comforts. Before construction plans are approved they are sent for suggestions to local interior designers, families of Trammell Crow employees and residents of the area.
The research in Stamford, for example, produced ''more storage than anything we've ever built,'' said Charles Berman, head of the Connecticut operations, headquartered in New Canaan. ''We made sure that two supermarkets were nearby. Some bedrooms are side by side for parents with babies, or at opposite ends for roommates who want privacy. A homelike setting was preferred to a skyscraper, and gas was preferred for cooking and heating.''
The substantially lower cost of such low-rise frame construction has not been lost on other developers. Warwick Malkin, which built Metro Center, an office building south of the railroad station, is including a four-story complex of 400 units which will rent for about $1,000 in its plans for Metro II, a mixed-use project with high-rise offices and some retail.
If their application is accepted by the zoning board this month, the complex could open a year later on part of Metro Center's seven-acre tract between Atantic and Henry Streets. A delay might result from a recommended denial of a zoning change by the planning board last month because of the height and density of the two 275-foot-high office towers.
Milton Mann, another local developer, has city approval for 263 low-rise units on four acres at Hoyt and Morgan Streets, north of Main Street. Studios and one- to three-bedroom units ''would be moderately priced for singles, empty-nesters and families moving into the community,'' said Mr. Mann. ''We are working on the financing.''
ACCORDING to Tom Purcell, director of the Stamford Board of Realtors, ''out of 375 listed rentals, 50 percent are investor-owned condos, the rest are houses, old apartment buildings and summer rentals. We don't get the new buildings, they rent their own.''
Canterbury Green's 106 units are fully leased at $875 for a 530-square-foot studio to $1,300 for an 1,100-square-foot two-bedroom unit, plus $62 a month for parking. There are no recreational facilities.
The Biltmore has rented all but 30 of its 161 units since it opened last September. Rents range from $800 for 547 square feet with one bedroom to $1,700 for 1,003 square feet with two. Parking costs $55 a month. There is a coin-laundry on the fourth floor; an exercise room, roof deck and clubhouse under construction will be free to tenants.
The Classic, which started out as 143 condominium units priced from $152,000 to $545,000, was converted by the developer, Caspi Development Company of Armonk, N.Y., to rentals in March, when only 12 units were under contract in the incomplete building. Contracts were canceled and 30 of 48 finished units are rented, at $1,100 to $1,850 a month. Caspi and the Marine Midland Bank are jointly seeking a buyer.
''The bank will not release the remaining construction funds until it has a buyer,'' said Barbara Zuckerman, manager of the building. Consequently an indoor pool, exercise room and clubroom remain unbuilt, along with the remaining apartments, which will range up to $2,400 for 2,300 square feet. Tenants get one free garage space. All three buildings have ground-floor retail space. The construction loan for Town Glen, a joint venture with the Prudential Insurance Company, was provided by Fuji Bank of Tokyo. Final approvals are being sought in Hamden for another Trammell Crow joint venture, with Blue Cross-Blue Shield of Connecticut. The project will have 1,400 units of mixed rental apartments, condominiums, single-family homes and housing for the elderly.
''We have options on several other sites in the state,'' said Mr. Berman, but he declined to say where.

HEADLINE: Talking: Rate Shock;
Remedies For High Payments

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
Many people who stretched their incomes wafer-thin to buy the best possible home at the height of the real estate boom two or three years ago are likely to be caught in an excruciating bind this summer.
The payments on their adjustable-rate mortgage, taken at a special one-year low introductory rate of 7 or 8 percent, have probably risen relentlessly.
''We figure payments can go up as much as 40 percent in the first two years,'' said David J. Totaro, first senior vice president at the Dime Savings Bank of New York.
In addition, real estate taxes, maintenance costs or even common charges have probably risen too. However, values and income may not have gone up as anticipated - as happened, for example, to Keith and Carla Leland, who bought a two-bedroom Cape Cod home in Danbury, Conn., for $173,000 in 1988. 
They started with an 80 percent loan carrying monthly payments of $1,100, now pay $1,500 and may soon pay even more. They recently had a son and Mrs. Leland's income of $23,000 a year has been temporarily lost. The septic system needs immediate repair, at a cost of $20,000, and they cannot qualify for an equity loan because the value of their home has not gone up.
''It's tough,'' said Mr. Leland, general sales manager for a local radio station.
There are ways out, but not without pain. They include refinancing for more favorable terms, moving to a less expensive property, selling and renting for a while, cutting expenses (if feasible) or moonlighting to augment income.
Before taking any steps it is advisable to visit the lender of the original mortgage. ''Bankers are telling me they will do anything to avoid getting stuck with a delinquent loan in this sort of market,'' said Paul Havemann, vice president of HSH Associates, a mortgage monitoring service in Butler, N.J.
''Whenever we see a real potential for a default, or even a chance that someone will start falling way behind, we will do everything we can to work with that person,'' said Walter Henderson, senior vice president at Mechanics and Farmers Savings Banks of Bridgeport, Conn. And right now, he insisted, that could mean eliminating all or some of the normal conversion fees.
In other instances charges can usually be folded into the new loan amount and an even better deal worked out. Len Druger, vice chairman of sales for Citicorp Mortgage, headquartered in St. Louis, gives as an example a couple struggling after two years with payments of $1,254 on a $120,000, 30-year adjustable loan.
These could be immediately be lowered to $1,161, he said, by changing to ''Homeowner's Key,'' a Citicorp hybrid program for people with rising incomes. It combines artifically low early payments with a brief 15-year fixed-rate amortization schedule - especially useful in a stagnant or falling market. Payments rise with time but it will take two years before they reach $1,254 again. Further, the amount of each year's rise can be clearly spelled out in advance since, unlike an adjustable-rate mortgage, the changes do not depend on fluctuating market rates. The refinancing costs, about $1,200, can normally also be included in the new loan.
Other alternatives include changing to an interest-only payment schedule for a while, negotiating a ''forebearance,'' as bankers call it when they let a borrower make smaller payments for a brief period of financial stress, or stretching the mortgage term, which should also bring down payments. Several of these options can often be combined.
A further alternative is to refinance to a new adjustable-rate mortgage, starting once again at the low introductory rate. This should provide at least two years of relief before payments again reach today's level, by which time income may have risen.
Anyone going to such an expense might also want to consider combining that option with what brokers dub ''buying down'' - selling an expensive home and buying a cheaper one.
''I've been in real estate for 15 years but this is a totally new kind of buyer,'' said Ruth Brewster, president of Brewster Realtors of Elizabeth, N.J. ''All they seem to want is to get out whole, without losing their down payment.''
The idea of living as fully indebted as one is allowed, she said, seems to be losing its allure, especially when values are falling and living costs rising.
Mrs. Brewster gives as an example a couple who might sell their two-bedroom town house for net proceeds of $150,000, getting back the $30,000 they may have invested as a down payment. They then buy a small apartment for $100,000, possibly in an nearby area where values have fallen further or property is cheaper. Doing so instantly releases $10,000 in cash, since they will need only $20,000 (20 percent of $100,000) as a down payment. If they start again with a new variable-rate mortgage their monthly payments should immediately drop from $1,189 ($120,000 at 11.5 percent) to $587 ($80,000 at 8 percent). The danger of having to paying a capital gains tax - which is normally incurred when trading down - is unlikely since there was probably little or no gain.
''A lot of them don't even go out and buy something else in a hurry,'' added Mrs. Brewster. ''They decide it's better to rent for a while.'' Those who seem best served by this idea, she said, are more flexible, such as younger singles or childless couples.
If moving is not a realistic option then most mortgage distress situations require multiple changes in living patterns to make things work, according to David Sledge, president of the Consumer Credit Counseling Service of Baton Rouge, La., who has seen many such families. ''You must look carefully at income too,'' he said. ''Can you lower your withholding? Can you eliminate some employee benefits to increase take-home pay? What about an added job?''
Other expenses also need to be examined. ''Can you substitute expensive child care for a family member, even temporarily?'' continued Mr. Sledge. ''Can other debts be renegotiated?''
The CCCS in Baton Rouge is one of a network of more than 500 affiliated nonprofit credit counseling agencies supported by the business community. There is normally no charge and the counselors can also act as an intermediary between lender and borrower. For a referral to the nearest branch call the CCCS national hot-line at (800) 388-2227.
