HEADLINE: LONG ISLAND OPINION;
Today's 3 R's: Reduce, Reuse and Recycle

BYLINE: By Arthur P. Copley and Ralph B. Maust; The authors of the following article, Arthur P. Capley, Ralph B. Maust and Nanette Essel, are active in environmental organizations.

 BODY:
THE time-honored adage of waste not, want not was heeded by many of our grandparents. Not being wasteful to them was economical and virtuous.
If citizens and government officials today would practice what was preached in times past, our waste-management dilemma could be solved in a less costly and environmentally safer way. In our grandparents' time the three R's meant reading, 'riting and 'rithmetic. In the garbage crisis today it means reduce, reuse and recycle. 
New York State has adopted a waste not, want not solid-waste philosophy by giving the new three R's the highest priorities in the Solid Waste Management Act of 1983 and in the regulations of the Department of Environmental Conservation. They mandate significant reductions in creating trash, increasing reuse materials and making recycling a household byword and practice.
If the state is going to obey the law, it needs a plan that maximizes them. To do that it has to approve a local solid-waste management plan that does not call for incineration, because incinerator contracts use the very few tax dollars that are needed to reduce, reuse or recycle waste.
Thus far all approved solid waste-plans in the Nassau-Suffolk region have included incineration. The state has to find the courage to approve a non-incinerator plan. Brookhaven Town is an excellent place to start. Why not experiment? What is there to lose? If after three to five years, the techniques have not reduced waste sufficiently, then consider an incinerator. In the meantime, the state will have experimented with an approach mandated by law and that, economic analysis says, saves tax dollars.
This kind of proposal has been adopted in such places as Seattle, Wash. Surely prudent citizens would want all the cheaper techniques developed before using their tax dollars for the most expensive remedy.
Although some communities delay decisions on incinerators and promoting the three R's, New York is busy considering additional incinerators despite clear signals that the region is amply supplied. If, according to its plan, the state expects to recycle 50 percent of its trash by 1997, a more modest level than some think is achievable, then it has to limit incinerator capacity to no more than 50 percent of the solid-waste stream.
The Nassau-Suffolk region already exceeds that limit. Seven incinerators - Babylon, Glen Cove, Hempstead, Huntington-Smithtown, Islip, Long Beach and Oyster Bay - have a total capacity of 5,650 tons a day. Calculations for 1997 show that figure is 53 percent of the projected waste stream.
If the additional capacity of 2,340 tons a day for North Hempstead, Brookhaven and an expansion at Huntington-Smithtown are approved, the region will be burning 75 percent of its solid waste by 1997, effectively precluding a 50 percent recycling rate. Does the state's three-R hand know what the incinerator hand is doing?
The incinerator hand is larger, richer and had more influence on governmental decision makers. The environmental department is pro-incineration. Certain advisers to the Governor and State Senate advocate incineration.
The state has excessively financed incinerators over the three R's. Many in the incinerator business seek understandable self-interest remuneration. That does not make them evil. But the three-R businesses are just beginning to develop and need nurturing and a chance to gain an equal opportunity against years of prejudicial funding by government in favor of incineration.
The three R's are economically and environmentally sound. Reducing the amount of trash we create prevents a problem before it starts. Who has not bought a small item in a hardware store wrapped in plastic and cardboard? Who has not bought packages triply wrapped only to be given a paper bag to take it home in? Each of us can think of many too many examples of excessive packaging. In our grandparents' day reuse was common. Rubber bands were stored on the door knob, used string in the drawer next to the sink and the Sears and Roebuck catalogue went to the outhouse. And recycling was an every day occurrence. Kitchen wastes went to the compost, grass clippings stayed on the lawn as fertilizer and old rags were made into rugs. Society is just beginning to revisit the 3 R's and the savings will be significant if incinerator contracts do not remove the incentives for their adoption.
It is time that the state and the Town of Brookhaven break through these inequities and give the three R's an unfettered chance to succeed. The taxpayer will benefit by cheaper alternatives, the environment will benefit by smaller amounts of hazardous materials being created as ash and emissions from incinerators and the state will have for the first time obeyed both the spirit and the letter of its own recent solid waste laws.
Our grandparents understood and practiced the new three R's but it is yet unclear whether the state has learned the same lesson. Brookhaven Town leaders have the opportunity to relearn the wisdom of our grandparents by developing a solid waste management plan without relying upon incineration. However, they need additional time, encouragement and approval from the State and diligent pressure from their citizen-taxpayers before they can make the new three R's the focal point of a non-incineration plan. It is up to the grandchildren to convince government of the wisdom of their grandparents.

HEADLINE: Jill C. Luftig Marries Michael Mendelsohn

 BODY:
Jill C. Luftig, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mark D. Luftig of New York, and Dr. Michael G. Mendelsohn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Mendelsohn of Dix Hills, L.I., were married last evening. The bride's cousin, Rabbi Dennis Math, assisted by his wife, Cantor Ellen Math, officiated at the Equitable Tower in New York. 
Mrs. Mendelsohn, 24 years old, a graduate of Boston University, expects to receive a Master of Arts degree in counseling psychology at New York University next year. Her father is a vice president of National Economic Research Associates, a consulting firm in White Plains.
Dr. Mendelsohn, also 24, a resident in ear, nose and throat surgery at the Long Island Jewish Medical Center, completed a six-year combined college and medical school program at B.U. His father, who is retired, was an English teacher at Thompson Junior High School in Syosset, L.I.

SECTION: Section 12NJ; Page 1, Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1832 words

HEADLINE: Ranks of 'Reverse Commuters' Expected to Grow

BYLINE: By BARBARA STURKEN

 BODY:
To live in New York City and spend one's days working in a suburban office complex in New Jersey is still regarded as an unusual way of life. But if predictions by transportation analysts come to pass, by the end of the decade reverse commuters may have plenty of company as they cross the Hudson River against the traffic flow.
One reason that reverse commuting is expected to rise is the exodus of businesses from New York to New Jersey, which picked up in the mid-80's. Three hundred fifty companies made the move or added offices or plants in New Jersey from 1984 through 1989, according to the New Jersey Commerce Department, and although the pace has slowed, the trend is likely to continue.
Although some of the companies that moved lost employees as a result, other workers have been persuaded to try reverse commuting. 
 
Changes in Region's Economy
In the future, experts say, commuting trends will be shaped by changes in the New York metropolitan region's economy and by the estimated growth in new jobs in northern New Jersey, which is expected to greatly outpace the growth in the state's population.
''We definitely expect to see an increase in reverse commuters,'' said Christine Johnson, an assistant commissioner for policy and planning at the New Jersey Department of Transportation ''A good half of new jobs in the metropolitan area will be located in northern New Jersey, and that is more than the expected population increase. Those employers will need to draw labor from beyond the borders of New Jersey. We are seeing a structural change in the region's economy as we pass the crest of the baby boom.''
Banking, finance and other traditional New York businesses hit a peak in the 80's but are now slowing, while New Jersey has drawn businesses in other industries, she said.
If reverse commuters are to avoid the traffic jams and other headaches that are the lot of traditional suburb-to-city commuters, more alternatives to the automobile must be developed, planners say. Already, as more New Yorkers have found across state lines, a variety of transportation alternatives have cropped up: new bus routes have opened, van pools have formed under the encouragement of private New Jersey companies, and ferry services have caught on.
 
Study of Rush Hour Conducted
The ranks of reverse commuters are still dwarfed by the throngs taking the more familiar direction. In a study conducted during rush hour one day last fall, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey found that about 18,000 people used public transportation to travel from New York to New Jersey in a three-hour period, using buses from the George Washington Bridge and midtown Port Authority bus terminals, PATH and train service out of New York's Pennsylvania Station.
In another study, N. J. Transit determined that an additional several thousand riders were taking private bus services that did not use either terminal. Those who commute by car are harder to measure, because westbound commuters in the morning are not stopped by toll booths, but the Port Authority has estimated that they represent two-thirds of all reverse commuters, or about 40,000, daily.
By contrast, roughly 200,000 take the more traditional commuting route across the river to jobs in Manhattan, according to the Port Authority study of major Hudson River crossings.
 
Taking Staten Island Route
The statistics do not give a complete picture, however, since there are other ways to commute to New Jersey, like via Staten Island. The number is probably closer to 100,000, said the New Jersey Division of Taxation, which counts the number of employees who live in New York State but have taxes withheld by a New Jersey employer.
Reverse commuting has drawn the attention of city and state planners on both sides of the river in recent years as companies started fleeing New York City for lower-cost office space elsewhere. Various agencies and companies like N. J. Transit are now evaluating ways to make the reverse commuting by public transportation more attractive, as automobile traffic threatens to create backups in both directions during rush hours.
One proposal under consideration at N. J. Transit, for example, would set up a ferry operation between Staten Island and Jersey City, where the Exchange Place development now draws 7 percent of its workers from the New York City borough.
N. J. Transit has done a study of workers at the waterfront complexes that have sprung up along the New Jersey side of the Hudson, where major employers include the Paine Webber brokerage concern, which moved a number of divisions from Manhattan to New Jersey several years ago. The transportation company estimates that the number of workers employed there will grow from the current 11,000 to 60,000 by the year 2000.
In a survey of companies that moved to Jersey City's office developments during the mid-80's, N. . Transit found that right after the move two-thirds of the employees affected were living in New York City and commuting to New Jersey. But three years later the percentages were reversed: just one-third were making the reverse commuting trip.
The analysts conducting the survey believe that while some of the employees might have moved to New Jersey, a larger number may have decided to find other employment in New York.
''Many stayed initially because they were given inducements like free transportation, typically for the first year,'' said Anthony Grazioso, director of public affairs for the N. J. Transit Waterfront Transportation Office in Jersey City. ''But after a while many found other employment in the same field in New York City.''
Reverse commuting is for some people a less stressful alternative to the New York City transit system, and theoretically it should involve less time sitting in traffic jams as well. But for some it can be time-consuming and exasperating. And companies that try to ease the burden for reverse commuters sometimes encounter unexpected problems.
 
Having to Learn to Drive
At Inter-Continental Hotels, which moved from midtown Manhattan to Montvale a few years ago, one hitch was that some of its employees did not know how to drive, said Deborah Bernstein, a director of public relations for the hotel chain.
''That is really the first thing that happened: a lot of people had to get their licenses,'' Ms. Bernstein said, because the company's new offices were not convenient to public transportation. She said car pools were formed and the company gave workers allowances to compensate for higher commuting costs.
Some employees, daunted by the expense of buying a car, insuring it and finding parking space in the city, decided it was simply easier to change jobs, she said.
From New York City, commuting is often unpredictable because of traffic. ''I used to get up at 5:30 A.M. so I could be in my office at 8:30,'' said Bob Garnet, a resident of the Upper West Side of Manhattan, who until recently worked at the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's Basking Ridge headquarters.
He joined a van pool with several other city dwellers. The van made several stops before crossing the George Washington Bridge. In the morning, traffic was often light, but in the evening the van would sometimes take detours to avoid backed-up toll plazas.
''We'd always tune into the radio to find out if a truck had turned over,'' Mr. Garnet said. ''Once we heard there was an hour and a half wait at the bridge, but we got through it in 15 minutes by taking a shortcut.''
 
Left With Less Time and Energy
Nevertheless, he said, he tired of the commuting life because it robbed him of free time in the evening and also left him with less energy. ''Getting up at 5:30 A.M. means you're tired at 10 at night,'' he said. He now works at A.T. & T. in Manhattan.
A.T. & T., New Jersey's largest employer with a work force of 51,000, says that 800 to 900 of its workers live in New York City and work in New Jersey. The company has tried to ease the trip for New Yorkers by helping to set up van pools because many of the telecommunication giant's offices are miles from the nearest bus stop, making commuting by public transportation nearly impossible.
Although N. J. Transit and private bus operators have added bus service where new offices created demand, commuters often complain about inconvenient schedules and long waits. William Cooper, a video film maker who lives in Manhattan, said he gave up his job at a production company in Fairfield, in part because he was tired of the 28-mile bus ride.
''My least favorite four words in the English language are Port Authority Bus Terminal,'' he said, explaining his frustration with having to push through the crowds exiting the terminal on the West Side during morning rush hour.
Mr. Cooper also said that in New Jersey he felt isolated from others in his field and missed the cultural life of the city. That is a sentiment echoed by other New Yorkers who do reverse commuting.
''If you want to take a client to lunch out here, you don't have a choice of 400 restaurants to go to,'' Ms. Bernstein said. ''It is a bit of a cultural abyss.''
But not all reverse commuters feel that a suburban office is a drawback. Deborah Wright, who lives in the Riverdale section of the Bronx, drives across the George Washington Bridge every day to her job at Trans World Airlines' Secaucus sales office. She used to work in Manhattan but spent almost twice as much time commuting, and prefers to work in New Jersey.
 
Crossing the Hudson Twice
One of Ms. Wright's co-workers does what might be described as double reverse commuting, and her predicament illustrates some of the difficulties on the public transportation side.
Linda Malizia lives in Union City, a five- or 10-minute drive from her Secaucus office. But because she does not own a car, and the bus links within New Jersey are ''terrible,'' she said, she must board a bus at her corner in the morning and make the trip into New York, wait at the bus terminal for 20 minutes and then take the same bus back across the Hudson. The total travel time each way is almost an hour.
A few reverse commuters have had the unlikely experience of having their companies move back to New York City. Susan Buchanan of Knight-Ridder Commodities Research was just getting used to commuting to Jersey City, a trip that required a subway ride from the Upper West Side to the World Trade Center and then a change to PATH. Then the company decided to move back to New York's financial district.
But Ms. Buchanan's experience is the exception. Paul Rosengren, a spokesman for the New Jersey Department of Commerce, said that more New York-based companies were considering a move to New Jersey to save on rent and other expenses. That trend, coupled with the creation of more jobs on the New Jersey side of the river, will induce more workers to job hunt across the river and will eventually lead to better transportation, Mr. Rosengren said.

SECTION: Section 12WC; Page 14, Column 3; Westchester Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1119 words

HEADLINE: Who's That Behind the SUNY Curtains?

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

DATELINE: PURCHASE

 BODY:
WHEN the Flying Karamazov Brothers appeared at the Performing Arts Center at the State University of New York at Purchase, among the things they found in their dressing rooms were boxes of tea, both Earl Grey and English Breakfast; bottles of fruit juices, assorted sandwich and salad makings, flowers and good wishes. All supplied by the theater's volunteer group, the Prompters.
Although such treatment has won plaudits for the Performing Arts Center from artists who play there, the Prompters do more than fill special requests for food and drink, pointed out Dr. Lee Katz, vice president for external affairs and development at the campus.
''Frankly, it would be hard for us to operate without them, especially in today's economic climate,'' Dr. Katz said. ''We couldn't afford to pay for all their services.'' 
Offering a rough estimate, Dr. Katz said that if all the tasks performed by the Prompters were paid for, the yearly dollar value would be about $200,000.
The group, started 10 years ago by five theater buffs, has grown to 170 members. They work on a dozen or more committees, from marketing to organizing music and dance and drama programs for schoolchildren.
 
'A Businesslike Footing'
''We're very conscious that the deep cuts in funds for the arts from the state can be devastating, so we work with a small paid staff to try to fill the gap,'' said Gail C. Conway, who is completing her second year as the Prompters' president. ''My goal was to try to put the Prompters on a businesslike footing by making the best use of our members' considerable abilities.''
Mrs. Conway, a former physical therapist, gives three days a week to the Prompters business.
J. Norton Dunn, 67 years old, a former director of manpower and development at Dunn & Bradstreet, joined the Prompters nine years ago. He is now a consultant, teaching sales and management techniques to business groups nationwide, but managed to devote about 157 volunteer hours to the Prompters this year.
Most recently, for example, using techniques learned at Dunn & Bradstreet, Mr. Dunn organized and ran a successful four-night subscription telethon. It netted the center's theaters more than $6,000 in ticket orders. He also produces and edits the Prompter newsletter, which comes out four times a year.
 
Prompted by His Wife
''My wife got me involved as a volunteer,'' he said. ''She is a docent at the Neuberger Museum next door, and she thought I'd like the Prompters. She was right. I enjoy being in the center of things, and that's the feeling you get here. I was an actor in my youth, and I still love all the excite ment that surrounds the theater.''
Mr. Dunn also goes on the road, selling the attractions of the Performing Arts Theater to Rotary, Kiwanis and other groups in Westchester and Fairfield Counties.
''I also worked as a bartender during the subscription-drive parties we held this spring,'' he said. ''My wife was an usher that same evening.''
A lot of volunteers are husband-and-wife couples, said Bernice Jutkowitz, the group's director of publicity.
She added that Prompter ushers have been working harder than ever this spring, trying to keep up with the demand for their services during the May 1 through June 24 run of ''The Kiss of the Spider Woman,'' the first performance in the New Musicals premiere season.
 
But There Are Perks, Too
''There are perks,'' Mrs. Jutkowitz said. ''The ushers get to see all the shows gratis.'' Members are required to give the Prompters a minimum of 25 hours of service each year but most give many more hours, she said.
''We're becoming the Lincoln Center of Westchester, a hub for the arts,'' said Shirley Axelrod, the group's new president-elect. She said that Christopher Beach, the new director of the Performing Arts Center, wanted to go out into the community to find out what people wanted to see, so Prompter volunteers held a series of coffee hours in their homes, where Mr. Beach was able to meet and speak to people.
Taking their cue from budget cutbacks, Mrs. Axelrod said, the Prompter marketing committee has embarked on an all-out drive with the goal of filling all the seats in all the theaters.
''We've been holding gala evenings at the theater, and we've been meeting with corporations and organizations to get them interested in the Performing Arts Center,'' she said. ''And we've been making special mailings in order to create the kind of interest in the theater that it deserves.''
Carol Saltzman, the staff-liaison member of the Performing Arts Center and the Prompters, estimated that $100,000 in subscriptions hadbeen generated by the Prompters' ''Festival Renewal Evenings,'' gala theater evenings for which the Prompters were the hosts for both past and future subscribers.
 
Attractive Gift Shop
''The Prompters, through their own marketing efforts, finance their own activities,'' Mrs. Saltzman pointed out. ''They use the income they derive from the very attractive gift shop they run in the lobby, and income from selling a very successful cookbook, to fund their activities.''
Commenting on the diverse talents of Prompter members, Mrs. Saltzman said: ''The arts and education program, for instance, which includes a performing-arts workshop for more than 300 high school students, is outstanding. They also lead tours of the theater and their speakers bureau sets up programs on and off campus.''
The Prompters recently received national recognition, winning a silver medal award for volunteers programs from the Council for Advancement and Support of Education, in Washington. The council honors the ''best programs and communications contributing significantly to the advancement of education in the nation.''
 
A View From the Director
Mr. Beach, who served as the interim director of the center since last October, was responsible for the programming for the 1990-1991 season and was instrumental in bringing New Musicals, the company devoted to the development and production of new American musicals, to Purchase.
He pointed out that when the theater complex was originally designed, provisions were made for offices for a working staff of 45 to 48 people.
''But the reality is that we're working with a paid staff of only 24, yet we're planning 250 more performances this year,'' Mr. Beach said. ''That shows how much we need volunteers. ''It's hard to put a pricetag on what the Prompters are worth to us, but beyond dollar value they provide good will, and everyone in business knows that when a company is sold, it's good will that commands the highest price.''
For information about joining the Prompters, call the group's office at the Performing Arts Center at 251-6272.

HEADLINE: THE VIEW FROM: MONTVILLE;
As Layoffs Loom, Defense Workers Mount a Battle for Jobs

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
HAROLD E. MOSS worked for a paper mill in Maine until 15 months ago, when he returned to southeastern Connecticut to take a job at the UNC Naval Products plant in Montville. ''I wanted to get back to my friends and family,'' Mr. Moss said. ''And I figured at UNC I had a job for many years to come. Until December I was working 60 or 70 hours a week.''
But now Mr. Moss is on a list of almost 100 UNC workers to be laid off on Friday. The company, which makes nuclear reactors for Navy submarines, is trying to cope with a cost-cutting decision by the Department of Energy to give all future marine reactor work to a single contractor, UNC's competitor, Babcock & Wilcox of Lynchburg, Va.
The UNC employees will meet with members of the Connecticut Congressional delegation on Thursday at Montville's high school, to seek support for continued Federal contracts for the plant. The workers have also formed the S.O.S. Committee - for Save Our State - that is urging Federal officials to help find Government contracts to replace the defense work at UNC and other Connecticut companies. 
 
'Far From Given Up'
''The mood is kind of upbeat right now,'' said James B. Rusiecki, an electronics supervisor at UNC and a member of S.O.S. ''We've far from given up.''
But so far, the employees' petitions, protests and phone calls seem to have done little good. While a few small Federal contracts are being negotiated that might allow for the rehiring of a handful of workers - including one for training Coast Guard personnel and another for machining work on the Government's Superconducting Supercollider project - nothing has developed to stave off the impending layoffs, company officials have said.
Another 80 to 100 workers will be laid off over the next three months, employees have been told. And over the next two years, the rest of work force, which numbered almost 1,100 at the beginning of this year, will be laid off, the company has said.
Many of the employees said they will not apply to work for any other defense contractors. ''I don't want to live through something like this again,'' said Cheryl A. Martel, an electronics technologist at UNC who was told on April 12 that she would be laid off this week.
Mrs. Martel, who has worked at UNC for seven years, said she has been so bewildered by the suddenness of the decision to close the plant that she has been unable to try to look for another job. ''Once I get out, maybe I'll have a clear head, and I'll be able to decide which direction I want to take now,'' she said.
Defense work has become important to southeastern Connecticut. In addition to large companies like UNC and Electric Boat, the shipbuilder in Groton, the area has dozens of small subcontractors like Analysis and Technology in New London, Sonalysts in Waterford, Mystech in Mystic and Tracor in Groton. Now people in the region worry that the loss of UNC's Navy contract will be the first of many setbacks.
Montville's First Selectman, Wayne D. Scott, said the decision to close the plant over the next two years will have a substantial impact on the town. Not only is UNC the largest employer in the town of 17,000 people, but with almost $50 million of property in town, UNC is Montville's biggest taxpayer, accounting for 10 percent of the taxes collected there. Among the town's top 10 taxpayers, four others are UNC suppliers.
''As far as helping UNC stay open, I don't think the town can have much of an impact,'' Mr. Scott said. ''The movement is going to have to come at the Federal level.''
The S.O.S. committee said the impact of the plant closing will go well beyond Montville's borders. The company spends $2 million a year on electricity and $320,000 a year on natural gas; it pays $80,000 a year to the water and sewer company in neighboring Norwich and $60,000 a year to local oil companies.
The plant's $42 million-a-year payroll has an impact throughout eastern Connecticut. A recent S.O.S. meeting about the shutdown attracted the chief elected officials of Norwich, Ledyard, Waterford, Stonington, Groton, Lisbon, Voluntown, Windham, Preston, Old Saybrook and Sprague.
Company officials did not return repeated calls asking for comment, but in interviews in March, they said that unless significant work is found soon, there will be no company to save. As the laid-off workers scatter to other companies, the officials said, they cannot be brought back easily.
S.O.S. members contend the decision to give the reactor-building work to Babcock & Wilcox had more to do with politics than price. They pointed out that the House Armed Services Committee subcommittee on sea power has three members from Virgina. Connecticut has one, Representative John G. Rowland.
''This is the other side of the peace dividend,'' said Mr. Rowland, a Republican of Waterbury, who is working with UNC workers to find contracts to replace the Navy reactor business.
Some employees said they had had other job opportunities but turned them down, because, even as recently as a few months ago, defense worked seemed secure.
David D. Carey, a senior manufacturing engineer who was laid off last month after 17 years, said that when he got his master's degree in manufacturing engineering three years ago, he was offered a job with another company but turned it down. ''In the back of my mind was this loyalty thing,'' he said. ''I figured if I stayed with UNC, they'd take care of me.''
 
'I Don't Want to Drive'
Mr. Carey said he is talking with Westinghouse about a job in either Hanford, Wash., or Savannah, Ga. But other employees said the southeastern Connecticut economy cannot absorb the UNC workers who are not ready to relocate. Several companies, including those that have no defense contracts, have announced closings, they noted.
''If I wanted to work in Hartford, I could probably be back to work by now, but I don't want to drive that much,'' said Gwen R. McTigue, who said the commute would take two hours more each day that she would prefer to spend with her family.
Ms. McTigue started at UNC as a secretary and advanced to information-management systems project leader. She said that her experience in computer programming would easily translate into another industry but that it has been 14 years since she looked for a job. ''I know I'm a very good employee, but how do you get that across in a resume?'' she said.
The company is trying to help with her resume. UNC Naval Products has opened an outplacement center in a warehouse owned by UNC Aerospace, a related division that was shut down earlier this year. A couple of secretaries take messages at the center, which also has telephones to make calls, newspapers and magazines that list job openings and classes on job-hunting skills.
Mr. Rusiecki said the S.O.S. committee members are continuing to seek contracts, particularly for non-defense work, that could help keep UNC open. Committee members are scheduled to meet with Gov. William A. O'Neill in two weeks, when he returns from a trip to Europe, where he is seeking foreign trade for companies in the state, including UNC.
Mr. Rusiecki said that Senator Joseph I. Lieberman has agreed to talk with the Department of Energy about contracts for UNC and that other committee members are talking with the Department of Defense and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration about possible work. ''Our goal is to become a model for how people can handle defense cutbacks,'' he said. ''But we need help. We need the Federal Government to invest the peace dividend in diversification efforts.''

HEADLINE: Mall Builders See Growth Continuing

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
DESPITE falling retail sales, rising vacancy rates and problems at a number of major department store chains, a mall building boom is still under way in Connecticut.
A major mall recently opened in Manchester. At least two more are planned, one on the Cheshire-Southington line and another in the Watertown area. And expansions are being built or planned at malls in Stamford, Danbury, Meriden, Hamden and Naugatuck. But James Rogers, president of the Connecticut Retail Merchants Association, said he is not sure how much longer the boom can last. 
''There are just so many consumer dollars out there,'' Mr. Rogers said. ''And if you look at a map of the malls in the state, you see there's one that's convenient to most people. With the recent opening of Buckland Hills in Manchester, I would have thought that was all the mall building you were going to see in Connecticut for a while.''
Mall owners, developers and managers, however, say Connecticut is far from overserved by the centers. Michael S. Fenley, general manager of Stamford Town Center, said average sales in its shops exceed $400 a square foot per year, compared with a national average of well under $200 a square foot.
In some Town Center stores, the yearly average is more than $1,200 per square foot, he said. ''Clearly, that makes an expansion of Stamford Town Center a wise business decision,'' Mr. Fenley said. The mall is seeking permits for a 440,000- square-foot addition to its existing 900,000 square feet. The addition would be connected to the mall by a pedestrian walkway over Grey Rock Place.
Despite the economic slowdown in the Northeast, per-capita income in Connecticut remain the highest in the country; and with so many two-income families, many shoppers seek the one-stop shopping convenience of a mall, merchants said.
''Retailers are very optimistic about New England, and about Connecticut in particular,'' said Allan Hutensky of Bronson and Hutensky, a development company based in Hartford. ''What we're seeing is the one-store, local operations are putting a new outlet on hold for now, but the national and regional tenants still want very badly to expand.
''Discount chains are looking for locations here. The national specialty stores are looking for locations. The big supermarkets are looking for locations.''
''I'm not an economist, and I'm not a retailer, but I think there is a perception that things are bad, and the perception is worse than things really are,'' said Mr. Hutensky, whose company is a partner in the 900,000-square-foot Buckland Hills Mall, which opened last month in Manchester. The company also owns or manages about 9 million square feet of retail space in malls and strip shopping centers in New England and the Middle West.
''If people read and hear enough times that the economy is bad, they'll believe it, no matter how much they've got in their checkbook,'' Mr. Hutensky said. But sooner or later, he said, people will want to spend the money in their checkbooks, and mall developers want to have stores ready when those consumers come calling.
Sales seem to be off to a slow start for retailers generally this year in Connecticut. Mr. Rogers said that after posting a 0.8 percent gain in January compared with the same month a year earlier, retail sales in the state dropped 1 percent in February and 2.8 percent in March compared with the same months in 1989.
''If the sales figures are down, the profits are down,'' Mr. Rogers said. ''And if the profits go down any more, these retailers are in trouble.
''I think the problems you're seeing in the major stores are a reflection of these figures. There's an economic slowdown. Housing starts are down, so people are not buying furniture, appliances and all the other things you need for a new house.''
 
Tightening of Credit
Another problem, he said, is that banks in the Northeast have tightened credit in response to failed real-estate loans, so less money is available for major purchases.
''But what has really kicked us in the butt is how all of this has affected consumer confidence,'' Mr. Rogers said. ''It's the lowest in the Northeast that it has been since the mid-1970's, and that tells you people are going to hold onto their bucks.''
Retail vacancies in the state have also doubled in the last year. A recent study by the real-estate concern Coldwell Banker found that retail vacancies in Connecticut increased to 6 percent from 3 percent in 1989.
The Danbury Fair Mall, which opened in October 1986, was fully occupied within 18 months, said the general manager, Patricia A. Frisaro. But that the occupancy rate has slipped to 94 percent, she said.
''We may not immediately go back to 100 percent as we have enjoyed,'' Ms. Frisaro said. ''But we do expect to be there by the holidays.'' The tenants that have stayed on are doing well, she said, and one anchor store, G. Fox & Company, recently added 40,000 square feet of selling space, for a total of 180,000 square feet.
Ms. Frisaro said the mall is so confident of the economy and consumer demand it has begun construction of a 130,000-square-foot addition to its 1.3 million square feet. The addition will house its fifth anchor tenant - Lord & Taylor - and almost 25 new smaller stores, bringing the total number to 250.
Also under construction on the north side of the mall is a 1,500-car garage, she said.
''In this particular area, there was a real thirst for a major retail complex before we opened,'' Ms. Frisaro said. ''It was a 45-minute drive in any direction for an enclosed mall.''
Increasingly, consumers want to drive the shortest possible distance to spend their money. That was why Buckland Hills opened off Interstate 84, only 15 minutes from the successful Westfarms Mall in West Hartford.
''One mall for a population base of more than 1 million people just wasn't enough,'' Mr. Hutensky said. ''Even now, what do we have? About two square feet per person.''
 
Unconcerned by Problems
Mall developers do not seem daunted by the well-publicized problems of a few stores, like Bloomingdale's and Macy's. Mr. Fenley said that while occupancy at Stamford Town Center has ranged from 93 to 98 percent recently, the mall has attracted a number of upscale boutiques that are bringing in many customers. Among those boutiques are Fendi, the Italian leather deigner; Mondi, a German-Italian boutique, and Westminster Lace, a specialty retailer based in the Pacific Northwest.
''We want to maintain some vacant space, so we can take advantage of new opportunities,'' Mr. Fenley said. ''We're really at as high an occupancy as we would want to see.''

LENGTH: 1151 words

HEADLINE: Parents Learn to Accent the Positive

BYLINE: By Cheryl P. Weinstock

 BODY:
A hush came over the crowded room of parents when the psychologist asked them to remember their best and worst bosses.
''What made your best boss so great and your worst one so intolerable?'' David Pelcovitz asked the parents. He is chief psychologist in the division of child and adolescent psychiatry at North Shore University Hospital in Manahsset.
A few people in the audience raised their hands and offered that their best boss praised them a lot and was rarely critical of their work. 
''Precisely,'' smiled Dr. Pelcovitz. ''I asked you this to illustrate a point: The power of praise is all too forgotten when dealing with kids. Praise is a far more effective technique of dealing with your children than criticizing them.''
''Positive Parenting'' is what the North Shore hospital calls its program for developing realistic and effective strategies and techniques for parents and providing information about rearing children from infancy through the teen-age years. It is one of many such programs offered by local hospitals on Long Island.
Many of these programs are working toward the same goals, using the guidelines of the Pre- and Postnatal Parent Education Hospital Program of the New York State Task Force on Child Abuse and Neglect.
Matilda R. Cuomo, a co-chairwoman of the Task Force, said in an interview, ''The more parents know about how to take care of their babies, the less child abuse and neglect you'll see. It's like nurturing a little kitty. No one wants to hurt the kitty but they do because they don't know how to take care of it.''
Magda Stayton, program director of North Shore's Positive Parenting Program, said, ''We want to help parents understand what to expect from their children so that taking care of them will be more rewarding.''
Beyond preventing child abuse and neglect, the parenting programs offer other opportunities.
Lawrence Balter, who is a professor of educational psychology at New York University and the author of several books on child rearing, said:
''These programs take the place of talking over the back fence, which is what our parents and grandparents did. Parenting is a lonely job. Parenting programs give you a chance to be among your peers, who can be wonderfully creative and helpful.''
When a couple at a group meeting at North Shore asked the moderator how to help their child stay in bed all night, one woman said that after months of her son's walking around his room all night, she took him downstairs and asked him to draw what was bothering him.
She learned that he was frightened of monsters coming into his bed. She decided to take him on a tour of the house, opening all the closets and checking for monsters. Reassured that there were none, he slept soundly that night and every one thereafter.
''The biggest need for parents is to share their concerns without being judged,'' said Lois Fink, a registered nurse who is coordinator of parent-child education at Long island Jewish Medical Center. The center sponsors parent support groups for all first-time parents and for those needing a refresher course.
Beth Epstein of Port Washington, 31 years old, recently shared some of her thoughts with other new mothers at a parent support group at the center. 'I wouldn't be comfortable talking over my problems with my mother-in-law or my mother. I'd be afraid they'd hold it against me or my husband.''
Ladonna Sanchez, 27, of Bayside, Queens, who was also at the support group, said she was overwhelmed when her son, Robby, now 8 months old, was born. ''I was devastated from the lack of sleep I was getting. I began thinking things that my friends and family would have been suprised about. For instance, I kept thinking to myself; When are this baby's parents going to come and take him home?''
''It was great to find out that other mothers thought the same thing at times,' she said. ''I learned from them how to handle Robby. Now, I'm just winging it.''
These groups also give parents a chance to decide if their child has a developing psychiatric or emotional problem.
Cory and Albert Yim of Searingtown have a 4 1/2-year-old boy and a 9-month-old girl. They came to the parenting program at North Shore with a purpose. ''We wanted to make sure we weren't missing anything,'' said Mr. Yim. He and his wife thought their son ''was too crazy, perhaps even hyperactive.''
''Now we doubt it,'' he said. ''The more we learn about hyperactivity, the more we think our child is normal.''
Mrs. Yim said, ''I think we expected too much from such a young child. Now, when he gets frustrated, we give our son time off to play.''
Julie Economou, program coordinator in social work at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center in Manhattan, said, ''There are so many complexities to being a parent. Most of us don't prepare for it in a systematic way. We usually do like our parents did or others do.''
Mr. Yim said, ''We're living in a different time than our parents. We can't compare what we should do with what they did. I'm glad we came to the parenting program.''
 
Normal Problems
The programs also offer ways to deal with the normal problems of growing up.
Mark and Hillary Spector of Briarwood, Queens, have a 2-year-old daughter and a 1-year-old boy. Mrs. Spector said, ''We were really looking to learn how better to deal with them. That's why I came to a parenting program. Because the kids are so close in age it can be frustrating. A lot of times I can't give my daughter the attention she needs because I'm taking care of our son.''
After one evening in a parenting class, Mrs. Spector said, they ''began to understand how our kids see the world and where the problems originate from.''
''I realized it wasn't appropriate to tell my daughter to be a big girl if she whined for me,'' said Mrs. Spector. ''She has needs too, so I plan to set aside private time just for her.''
Laurie Brancaleone, a social worker at Mercy Hospital in Rockville Centre, said; ''A lot of us grew up in an environment where if we did something wrong we got spanked. In our responsive parenting program we try to show parents that there are more positive methods of discipline that won't be detrimental to their child. A child who gets hit all the time will grow up without self-esteem.''
Dr. Pelcovitz at North Shore said some of the more effective techniques of controlling aggression in small children were praise, ignoring the behavior or punishment.
Praise, he said, works best if it is not placed as a caboose. For example, he told the support group, ''Don't tell your child, 'I'm so proud of you - Why can't you do that all the time?'''
Cathy DeMarco, the mother of girls ages 2 1/2 and 4 1/2, said later that she had liked Dr. Pelcovitz's suggestion to ignore undesirable behavior, so when she went home that evening, she tried it out.
''It's awfully hard to keep calm and cool. But it works,'' she said.

LENGTH: 675 words

HEADLINE: Cold War Mentality: Alive and Well

BYLINE: By Gene Guerrero and Jeanne M. Woods; Gene Guerrero is field coordinator for the American Civil Liberties Union's national office. Jeanne M. Woods is a legislative counsel there.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The cold war is dead and has been buried by George Bush and Mikhail Gorbachev. But the cold war mentality, and undemocratic policies and practices designed to limit Americans' thoughts and associations that it engendered, live on. They, too, should be given a funeral. 
Ask Dan Snow, a Texas fisherman. On April 6, he was fined $5,000 and sentenced to 90 days in prison for organizing groups of fishermen to travel to Cuba ''for the purpose of pleasure fishing.''
Absurdly, the Government will not let ABC televise the 1991 Pan American Games in Cuba, even though U.S. athletes will participate.
Americans take pride in their freedom of movement, considering it a right of citizenship. Our Government seeks to have other nations equal our standard of free movement. Yet, paradoxically, the Government curtails this right, declaring certain countries off limits on foreign policy grounds. At present, there are restrictions on travel to Cuba, Cambodia, Libya, North Korea and Vietnam.
Under the Trading With the Enemy Act and International Emergency Economic Powers Act, the Treasury Department can bar Americans from spending money for personal travel-related expenses. This bans travel to lands the Government views unfavorably. For example, with a few exceptions, Americans cannot travel to Cuba at their own expense.
The U.S. permits individuals to travel to Vietnam and Cambodia, but has made it illegal to ''organize, arrange or facilitate'' group travel.
Groups of Vietnam vets have been warned to stop arranging nonprofit trips to battlefields for psychological healing, universities have been denied permission to take students on academic studies, and travel agencies have been prosecuted and fined.
President Bush recently signed a law that prohibits the refusal of visas to visitors to the U.S. because of ''past, current or expected beliefs, statements or associations.'' Good. But the Administration still insists that people belonging to ''proscribed organizations'' are excludable. It asks visa applicants if they have ever belonged to a Communist organization; if the answer is yes, the visitor must apply for a waiver of excludability to be admitted.
The Government still claims broad power to exclude individuals on foreign policy grounds. The State Department last month denied a visa to the Cambodian Minister of Culture, Cheng Pon, saying admittance would convey recognition of his Government. Last year it denied a visa to Khieu Kanharith, a prominent Cambodian journalist invited to the U.S. by individuals and groups concerned about his country's political transition.
The Administration is imposing new and expanded security-clearance procedures, approved by the Reagan Administration, on thousands of Federal workers who do not hold jobs with real national security responsibilities.
Even though the Civil Service Commission ruled in 1977 that inquiries about personal and political associations ''might infringe on rights guaranteed by the Constitution,'' the Government is requiring Federal employees in ''sensitive'' positions to divulge information about their associations, including Communist Party membership.
Almost all Federal employees are obliged to provide detailed medical, psychiatric and criminal histories and must permit unlimited access to records held by third parties such as health insurance companies.
Such inquiries are justified, the Government says, for ''background investigations'' required by a 1953 executive order. Such invasions of privacy have no place in today's world.
Representative Howard Berman has introduced legislation to give Americans back the right to travel freely throughout the world. Representative Don Edwards, a former F.B.I. agent, and John Conyers have sponsored legislation to forbid political surveillance by the F.B.I.
The Administration should support these measures and, on its own initiative, institute new security and classification systems that safeguard legitimate national security interests without undue infringement of the rights of Americans.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-ed

TICKER: PANASONIC (NSE) (71%); 

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (99%); CUBA (94%); CAMBODIA (94%); KOREA, DEMOCRATIC PEOPLE'S REPUBLIC OF (79%);

PUB-DATE: June 4, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 4; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1407 words

HEADLINE: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK;
Gorbachev Passes Up Stunts But Dazzles the Heartland

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., June 3

 BODY:
Mikhail S. Gorbachev took a pass on Cher, who offered to fly into Minnesota today after her Chicago concert appearance to meet with the Soviet President.
He also shrugged off the Minnesota farmer who wanted to bring an 850-pound pig to any spot along the motorcade where Mr. Gorbachev, a farm worker in his youth and a former Agriculture Secretary, might be able to admire such a prize American porker.
He declined to stop by the wedding reception of a Minneapolis bride who wanted to save him a dance. Nor did Mr. Gorbachev get together with the northern Minnesota horse breeder who was thinking of emigrating to Leningrad.
 
Skips Farm Visit
Running behind schedule, he canceled his trip to the dairy farm of Richard and Cecilia Brand, who had been painting their house and planting flowers and brushing their herd of 250 Holsteins, among them 80 milking cows with an annual production of 20,000 pounds per cow. 
But none of that mattered. Mr. Gorbachev did not need Cher or super-pigs or any other gimmicks to help him dazzle the heartland. Braving 49-degree gray, drizzling weather that people here called ''a Siberian cold front,'' Mikhail and Raisa Gorbachev created a sensation on their whirlwind trip to the Twin Cities.
 
Proving Himself to Soviets
''We were supposed to maintain our composure and not become complete babbling idiots,'' apologized one excited television commentator. ''But this really is something to see.''
Surrounded everywhere by screaming, adoring crowds with cameras and video cameras who chanted ''Gorby, Gorby,'' including a man on stilts dressed as Uncle Sam and waving a Soviet flag, he accomplished exactly what he needed to.
He promoted his country to a high-powered group of chief executives and waded into the crowd several times, producing shots for the evening news that will show Soviet audiences that he is able to thrill the Midwest as easily as he did the East.
''All the best to you,'' the Soviet President said through a translator. Mr. Gorbachev wore a fedora and overcoat as he stopped to wave to thousands of people gathered near the Governor's Mansion, where the Gorbachevs had lunch.
Continuing to show a softer side -remarkable when one recalled that only a few years ago Americans knew nothing about Soviet leaders' families - Mr. Gorbachev stopped to talk for two minutes with an 11-year-old boy named Brandon Peterson.
''You're almost as old as my granddaughter,'' he told the little boy through his interpreter.
At an evening meeting at the headquarters of Control Data Corporation, Mr. Gorbachev teased employees that he was, not so long ago, ''your archenemy.''
''See how fast things are changing?'' he said, smiling.
Mr. Gorbachev was so energetic during his seven-hour visit that the Soviet film crew ran out of film and batteries. The movement was so frantic, the crew even lost a camera.
Nick Hayes, a professor of Soviet affairs at Hamline University in St. Paul, noted that Mr. Gorbachev, who has acted on stage, knew how to make his act play in Peoria and throughout the heartland.
''He's here not with the big-timers in Washington and New York, but with the sort of common people Russians identify with,'' Mr. Hayes said. ''Hence, he's played it to the extreme.''
 
In Search of the Average
What tempts a Soviet First Lady on a shopping spree in South Minneapolis?
Orange nail polish, French perfume, suntan lotion, Snickers candy bars and plastic Nintendo figures containing gum.
While her husband met with business leaders, Raisa Gorbachev checked out an average Midwestern drugstore and an average Midwestern Mexican delicatessen.
Taking a page from her husband's book, Mrs. Gorbachev ordered her limousine driver to halt suddenly at the deli, Pepito's, where she chatted with two customers. Then she walked around the corner to Snyder Drug Store, where she questioned Carey Kilbo, the stunned merchandise manager, about what kinds of goods he sold and how much was imported.
There were cookies from Denmark and sardines from Norway, Ms. Kilbo told the Soviet visitor, but nothing from the Soviet Union.
Then Mrs. Gorbachev browsed, trailed by Lola Perpich, the Minnesota Governor's wife. Mrs. Gorbachev picked up some ''Tantra'' orange nail polish, asked the price ($3) and wondered if that was considered expensive or inexpensive. She asked whether the drug store carried French perfumes. She passed by some earrings, stopped at a lipstick display, picked up a bottle of suntan lotion and then put it back.
In the end, she bought only two three-inch plastic Nintendo figures that contained gum.
 
In Pursuit of the Average
Mrs. Gorbachev moved on to put some questions to the Watson family in South Minneapolis, the ''typical'' American family that was chosen because the 13-year old daughter, Lisa, toured Moscow with the Minneapolis-based Children's Theater Company.
When Mrs. Gorbachev arrived at about 6:30, she sat at the dining room table talking with Steve Watson, 39, an art teacher at an elementary school in Eden Prairie, a suburb of Minneapolis; Karen Watson, 38, a part-time obstetrics nurse, Lisa, Stephanie, 11, Thomas, 7, William, 6, and Bonnie, the family's golden retriever-Irish setter.
She asked the Watsons how they were paying for their house and how many years it would take to pay off their mortgage.
Staying more than an hour, twice as long as scheduled, she leafed through Lisa's scrapbooks from her Moscow trip and examined the dolls she had brought back.
Mrs. Gorbachev gave the family a pop-up Russian fairy-tale book, and received a teapot. Just a Game? To help him recall the moment when President Bush finally managed to loosen him up, Mr. Gorbachev will have a framed lucky horseshoe to hang on his wall.
When he took a break from talking to Mr. Bush at Camp David on Saturday and tossed a few, Mr. Gorbachev threw a ringer on his first try - a feat that mightily impressed the supremely competitive President Bush.
''I pride myself as a horseshoe player,'' Mr. Bush told reporters on Saturday evening, a new note of respect in his voice. ''And then President Gorbachev picked up a horseshoe, never having played the game to my knowledge, and literally, literally - all you horseshoe players out there - threw a ringer the first time.''
After the joint news conference in the East Room this morning, Mr. Gorbachev was asked by Helen Thomas of United Press International, the dean of White House correspondents, if he was going to take his horseshoe home and throw it at his pesky rival, Boris N. Yeltsin, who was just elected President of the Russian republic.
Mr. Gorbachev smiled mischievously, enjoying the image. ''No, I'm going to leave it at home,'' he said. (Soviets also hang horseshoes for luck.) ''But just remember this,'' he warned. ''I got a ringer on my first try, so I'm a pretty good shot.''
 
Legend in a Can
Like Malta, Minneapolis was drenched and blown when it was trying to show its prettiest face for the summit visit. The Gorbachevs, who are used to cold, misty Junes, seemed unfazed as they emerged from their plane without overcoats.
But Minnesota tried to make the most of its moment in the shade.
State promoters showered visiting reporters with story suggestions, including an intriguing item on ''The Universal Popularity of Spam.''
This pork and shoulder ham luncheon meat, produced by the Hormel Company of Minnesota, has achieved ''legendary status,'' according to the press release.
''Its popularity is such that even former Soviet leader Nikita Khrushchev had something to say about it,'' the Hormel release said. ''In his memoirs, 'Khrushchev Remembers,' he wrote: 'There were many jokes going around the Army, some of them off-color, about American Spam. It tastes good nonetheless.' ''
 
A Long Goodbye
As the time arrived for him to leave Minneapolis, Mr. Gorbachev seemed reluctant to go.
He said goodbye to a row of Minneapolis state troopers - an unusual move for a head of state - and, holding hands with Raisa, slowly climbed the stairs of his plane as the Greater Twin Cities' Youth Symphonies serenaded the couple with ''Moscow Nights.''
The crowd waved their ''Gorby-chiefs'' - commemorative handerchiefs - and cheered as the plane's engines warmed up.
When Mr. Gorbachev's face appeared in the small porthole, there was a roar in the crowd. The final sight for the Minnesotans was four hands pressed against the two windows.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: June 4, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 6; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1911 words

HEADLINE: SUMMIT TALKS END WITH WARMTH BUT FAIL TO RESOLVE KEY ISSUES;
WORDS OF RESPECT

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 3

 BODY:
President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev concluded their second summit conference today with warm talk of amity, but with little progress toward resolving their most divisive disputes over Germany and Lithuania.
A possible new difficulty emerged at a final joint news conference in the White House when Mr. Gorbachev nettled the Bush Administration with a warning that he might consider holding up Jewish emigration unless Israel guaranteed that Soviet Jews would not be resettled in the occupied territories. [Key sections from the news conference, pages A14 and A15.] American officials said such action would further complicate what already promised to be a tough fight over approval of the trade treaty signed just two days ago, which is predicated on legal codification of changes in Soviet emigration policy. 
 
Reaction From Israelis
The seriousness of Mr. Gorbachev's threat remains to be seen. Israeli officials said today that they were not encouraging Soviet Jews to settle in occupied areas, and that only a very small number of the 10,000 Soviet Jews arriving monthly had sought to live there. But Israel has shown no sign so far that it would be willing to prevent immigrants from going there. [Page A11.] Despite their words of mutual respect, Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev said they remained at odds over the Kremlin's test of wills with leaders of the Baltic republics, who have declared independence from the Soviet Union. But before Mr. Gorbachev left Washington for stops in Minnesota and San Francisco, Mr. Bush did offer a gesture to the Kremlin by saying he was not formally linking the issue of Lithuanian independence with the decision on when to submit the newly signed trade agreement for Senate consideration.
The only linkage, he said, was to Soviet passage of a law permitting unfettered emigration. But other American officials have said there is little chance for approval of the trade pact while Moscow maintains its oil and natural gas blockade of Lithuania.
After three days of intensive talks the two Presidents said they had made no movement toward an understanding on the future alignment of the two Germanys, which are headed for unification. The United States and other Western countries say a united Germany should be part of NATO, while the Soviet side wants Germany's future to be overseen by an all-Europe council.
Today, as throughout the summit meeting, there were frequent reminders of Mr. Gorbachev's domestic political and economic problems, which have shown a tendency to intrude into Soviet-American relations.
But the two Presidents' final hours together before Mr. Gorbachev's departure were marked by repeated expressions of confidence in their ability to resolve problems. They issued two additional joint statements, one about joint efforts to end the civil war in Ethiopia and the other about cooperation on environmental questions.
 
Plans to Meet More Often
They announced plans to meet more frequently, perhaps in annual working meetings that lack the ceremony and political expectations of a formal summit conference, which is usually arranged for signing major agreements.
''We're now at the stage in the U.S.-Soviet relationship and, indeed, in world history where we should miss no opportunity to complete the extraordinary tasks before us,'' Mr. Bush said.
Mr. Gorbachev, who seemed to revel in Mr. Bush's respect and in the applause of the American public, spoke of a ''qualitatively new relationship.'' He offered extraordinary praise to Mr. Bush ''as a political leader who is able, in a very human way, and in a politically responsible way, to engage in dialogue and cooperation.''
The summit conference ended this morning much as it began on Thursday, with ceremonies that dramatized the different tone of the meeting itself and of Soviet-American relations.
At the North Portico of the White House, the Presidents' wives, Raisa Gorbachev and Barbara Bush, embraced as their husbands went through the formalities of a departure ceremony before the Gorbachevs left on a trip to Minneapolis and San Francisco. Mr. Gorbachev paused for a moment before a cheering crowd, his hands clasped like a victorious boxer, before sweeping off in his Zil limousine.
An hour earlier, the two leaders had walked together down a red-carpeted hallway to the East Room. They sat before reporters, certainly not as allies, but as friendly rivals talking about banishing suspicion and emphasizing the importance of the documents signed here on Friday, including commitments to reduce their long-range nuclear arms and to make deep cuts in stockpiles of poison gas.
 
Taking Risks to Help Gorbachev
Mr. Bush's position on Lithuania seemed to symbolize the change. Having moved from a policy of support for Soviet reform to one of backing Mr. Gorbachev personally, Mr. Bush has now demonstrated himself willing not only to have a new kind of dialogue with Mr. Gorbachev, but also to take political risks to help him.
After days of saying it would be difficult to improve commercial ties when the Kremlin was squeezing Lithuania with economic sanctions, Mr. Bush said today that the Lithuanian situation would not keep him from offering the new trade treaty to the Senate.
Although this position seemed certain to inflame members of Congress who have already expressed doubts about the treaty, Mr. Bush said he would send the document to the Senate and recommend removing tariff and credit restrictions as soon as the Soviet Union enacted a promised new emigration law.
Mr. Bush said he did not ''want to mislead the American people and say that I have lessened my concern over the Baltic states,'' Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia. He said the Soviet Union's actions in Lithuania were ''thorns in the side of an overall relationship.''
But he said the only ''linkage'' between other issues and the granting of trade concessions to Moscow was the United States' insistence that the more liberal Soviet emigration policies be codified into law. Once the Soviet Union fulfills its promise to enact a new emigration bill, Mr. Bush said, ''we go forward'' on the trade agreement.
Although American officials remain confident that the Soviet Union will enact the new law, Mr. Gorbachev added a new wrinkle to the issue when he was asked how the Soviet Union and United States could guarantee that Soviet Jews who emigrated to Israel would not settle on occupied land in the West Bank.
Arab leaders say they fear that if Soviet Jews move to the West Bank in massive numbers, they will inevitably displace Palestinian Arabs, making impossible their goal of an independent Palestinian entity.
Mr. Gorbachev said he had been ''bombarded by criticism'' from Arab governments on this issue. He said that if Israel did not offer assurances that Soviet Jews would not settle on occupied territory, ''we must give further thought to it in terms of what we can do with issuing permits for exit.''
 
Seeks Israeli Assurances
Using a formula that he employs when he wants to suggest that his options are limited, Mr. Gorbachev said, ''Some people are raising the matter in these terms in the Soviet Union, namely, as long as there are no assurances from the Israelis that this is not going to be done by them, postpone issuing permits for exit.''
American Jewish groups immediately protested Mr. Gorbachev's comments. The president of the American Jewish Committee, Sholom D. Comay, said, ''Only a tiny fraction of the tens of thousands of Soviet Jews who have arrived in Israel recently have settled in the occupied areas.''
Mr. Bush said, ''The United States policy on settlement in the occupied territories is unchanged and it is clear, and that is, we oppose new settlements.'' But he did not comment directly on Mr. Gorbachev's remarks.
Brent Scowcroft, the President's national security adviser, said in an interview: ''The Soviets are under enormous pressure from the Arab world. I'm presuming that this is a reaction to it on his part in hopes of getting the Israelis to restrict where immigrants will settle.''
He said any Soviet action delaying emigration visas for Jews would complicate the fate of the trade treaty.
The seriousness of Mr. Gorbachev's warning clearly depends on Israel's response. Today, Israeli officials, already under pressure from the United States, said they would assure Mr. Gorbachev that they did not encourage Jewish settlement in the occupied territories. The Government does not include East Jerusalem, where many Soviet Jews have settled, in its definition of occupied land.
Mr. Bush said he and Mr. Gorbachev had had ''intensive discussions on the transforming events in Europe.'' He said he had told Mr. Gorbachev that he and other members of the Western alliance believed that a united Germany should be a full member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
 
'For the Germans to Decide'
''President Gorbachev, frankly, does not hold that view,'' Mr. Bush said. ''But we are in full agreement that the matter of alliance membership is, in accordance with the Helsinki Final Act, a matter for the Germans to decide.''
The Helsinki document, which was signed by the Soviet Union, the United States and 33 other governments in 1975, recognizes the right to national self-determination. Administration officials said they did not read much significance into the comment, saying it seemed to reflect a general Soviet affirmation of the Helsinki agreement rather than a specific sign that Moscow is ready to accept German membership in NATO.
Mr. Bush said he and Mr. Gorbachev had a clearer understanding of their differences on this issue. ''But I'm not sure we narrowed them,'' he said.
Mr. Bush demurred when asked if he thought the two countries were closer to being allies than adversaries. ''We've moved a long, long way from the depths of the cold war,'' he said. ''I don't quite know how to quantify it for you, but we could never have had the discussions at Camp David yesterday, or as we sat in the Oval Office a couple of days before with President Gorbachev, 20 years ago.''
 
Germany, NATO and Rapport
But Mr. Bush spoke passionately of his effort to persuade Mr. Gorbachev to acquiesce in the membership of a united Germany in NATO. ''The threat is unpredictability and instability,'' he said. ''We feel that a continued U.S. presence in Europe should not be seen as hostile to Soviet interests.''
Mr. Gorbachev, who has said he does not oppose an American military presence in Europe but does not want NATO to be the pre-eminent security force in Europe, did not press the issue. Instead, he focused on the personal rapport between him and Mr. Bush.
''I don't know whether anyone will ever be able to say that we know each other totally well or completely,'' he said. ''I think that would take many, many years. But now we have a good human relationship and, I think, a good human atmosphere between us.''
He spoke with obvious enthusiasm about the reception he had received in Washington. He said, ''I would like to say both to the Americans and to the Soviet people that here we, the Soviet delegation, have felt very good feelings of the American people, feelings of solidarity and a lot of interest from the Americans toward what we are doing in the Soviet Union for perestroika.''
''I would like to thank all Americans for that,'' he said, ''and they certainly can expect reciprocity from the Soviet Union.''

Members of the United States Army honor guard held onto the red carpet and their hats. (Jose R. Lopez/The New York Times) (pg. A11)

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: June 4, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 3; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1280 words

HEADLINE: SUMMIT TALKS END WITH WARMTH BUT FAIL TO RESOLVE KEY ISSUES;
The Doubts That Linger

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 3

 BODY:
For months, senior American officials have expressed confidence that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev would give way, if offered enough inducements, and agree to NATO membership for a united Germany, thus settling the most intractable issue facing Moscow and Washington.
But that confidence is fading fast. After three days of talks between President Bush and the Soviet leader, which produced no real progress on the German question and the shape of post-cold war Europe, top United States policy-makers say they are beginning to believe that Mr. Gorbachev's domestic political situation may be too delicate for him to make such a concession at any time soon, and that a protracted period of ambiguity may result.
''It may well be that the only way he can resolve his dilemma is to string the process out, let Germany go ahead with political and economic reunification and stall on the military side,'' said an American official who played a significant role in the Bush-Gorbachev summit conference here. ''West Germany would stay in NATO and the Soviet troops would stay in East Germany. 
''Unfortunately, with so many security questions undecided, the situation might prove dangerous.''
 
Fewer Cheers at Home
In domestic political terms, Mr. Bush emerged from last week's events with Germany in doubt, Lithuania unresolved and perhaps a few political problems on the trade agreement. But he will find that easy enough to live with, given his broad popularity. For Mr. Gorbachev, on the other hand, the acclaim he won in the streets of Washington is unlikely to be repeated at home. His public-relations triumph here is not likely to ease his struggle for survival.
At their news conference this morning, the two Presidents made much of the relationship they have built, and a few White House officials say they believe that personal chemistry will eventually dissolve the policy stalemate. Mr. Gorbachev promised not to ''put spokes in the wheels'' and said negotiations on Germany would continue. The two pledged to meet on a regular basis.
No doubt things have come ''a long, long way from the depths of the cold war,'' as President Bush commented. But there are limits on personal diplomacy, even in an era of good feelings. Between May 1972 and November 1974 four summit meetings took place, and after the fourth one, in Siberia, Gerald R. Ford spoke hopefully of ''the spirit of Vladivostok.''
But that proved inadequate to overcome fundamental disagreements -the next summit conference did not come until 1979 - and the ''constructive spirit'' of which Mr. Gorbachev spoke may not suffice in the weeks and months ahead.
 
Debate Could Be Protracted
A protracted debate about the rival visions of the new Europe now seems highly likely, with a substantial possibility that progress in the negotiations in Vienna on conventional forces will prove impossible to achieve and that the summit meeting of the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, now scheduled to take place late this year in Paris, will be delayed.
The United States is ready to see that rather inchoate organization gain a more formal structure and a larger role. But the Soviet Union, which belongs to no other important pan-European organization, wants to make it the centerpiece of the new Europe, which is an entirely different matter.
''We are talking about building an all-European security system and casting the issue of German unification, its external aspects, within the context of that larger European security framework,'' Vitaly Churkin, a senior adviser to the Soviet Foreign Ministry, said in an interview over the weekend.
Many Western European officials, as well as many here, see that idea as ''a trap that would give the Soviets a veto like the one they have in the United Nations, in fact if not in law,'' as a ranking Italian official argued recently. A British diplomat said that an organization with 35 members ''would quickly become a talking shop, incapable of making decisions.''
But there is some support, among politicians as well as policy experts, for the Soviet idea, or some modified version of it. Hans-Dietrich Genscher, the West German Foreign Minister, has called for a pan-European ''conflict-resolution center,'' and President Francois Mitterrand of France supports a loose European confederation.
 
U.S. Role in Europe
Leaders of the newly democratic East European countries see the Conference on Security and Cooperation as their only chance for a link to Western Europe, so they too support the idea that something new, beyond NATO and the moribund Warsaw Pact, must be created to handle European security.
In the current issue of World Policy Journal, Malcolm Chalmers of Stanford University argues for the creation of a European Security Organization, based on the Conference on Security and Cooperation, with only a residual, transitional role for NATO and the Warsaw Pact. Only such an organization, he says, would reassure the Soviet Union, buttress German sovereignty and guarantee a United States role in Europe.
Nearly everything about the debate remains murky. One of the things the United States has promised the Soviet Union, to combat Moscow's fear that a unified Germany would be joining an alliance hostile to Soviet interests, is that NATO will be transformed into a more political organization.
Revivifying NATO - giving it some reason for being other than defense against a threat from the East that is rapidly vanishing - is a crucial matter for the United States, Mr. Bush believes, because NATO gives Washington its sole institutional voice in Europe.
But every time in the past that NATO has tried to agree on something other than the common defense against the Soviet Union and the Warsaw Pact, things have gone wrong - whether the question was the Suez invasion in the 1950's or the overflight of United States planes on the way to Libya in the 1980's.
 
The Perils of a Deadlock
The danger lurking down the road, in the American view, is not the application of a new Soviet noose to Berlin, or even a rancorous Soviet decision to break off negotiations on the German question. The positive tenor of the conversations here seems to make those two eventualities unlikely, at least for as long as Mr. Gorbachev or another reformer remains in power.
But a prolonged deadlock would carry its own sorts of perils.
''If Moscow should refuse to leave Germany,'' says Michael Mandelbaum of the Council on Foreign Relations, ''and its refusal became a major point of conflict with the West, this would, in effect, re-create the political conflict on which the great East-West rivalry of the postwar period was based.''
For Moscow, the stakes are immense. In the century since 1890, Russia and Germany, the two largest and strongest European countries, have been almost constantly at odds. Now the Soviet Union, already economically weakened, faces the prospect of losing its military power in central Europe, with no compensating increase in political power, at the very moment when Germany, already economically powerful, stands on the verge of reunification and greatly augmented political influence.
''It's going to require tremendous finesse on our part to manage this kind of unsettled situation,'' said Robert D. Hormats, a former official of the State Department and the National Security Council. ''The analogy to Germany, post-World War I, is very close. We can't afford to isolate them, leave them to brood about losing the cold war, let their economy collapse. If we do, as a last resort, they'll play on neutralist emotions in Germany, which are already too widespread for comfort.''
