HEADLINE: Japanese Panel Urges More Help for Poor Nations

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 3

 BODY:
For the first time, the Japanese Government has begun to spell out its strategy for directing more of Japan's huge private investments overseas to the developing world and Eastern Europe.
Since the mid-1980's, Japan has been the world's largest exporter of capital, but it has been criticized by the United States and others for having the wealth of a world leader but not the vision.
The Japanese are now taking steps to answer those critics with programs that hew to broader Japanese policy goals. Some aspects of their plans were contained in a report released last week by a Finance Ministry advisory group.
 
Source of Tension
The most notable provision was a recommendation that Japan reverse its stated policy of eliminating its huge trade surpluses. Those surpluses have been shrinking in the last three years, but they are still large and a source of tension with the United States. 
The group proposed that Japan's official assistance to developing countries be used increasingly as a magnet to help attract private Japanese capital. Japan is the world's largest donor of aid to developing countries.
The Government could spur private investment, the report said, by encouraging countries receiving aid to foster political stability, change economic policies to make them more oriented toward growth and trade, put more industries in private rather than governmental hands, deregulate financial systems to make them more open to foreign investment and improve their financial markets.
 
Dependent on Capital
Such a shift in Japanese investment could have a significant effect on the United States, which has grown critically dependent on Japanese capital during the last five years.
The nascent and more independent Japanese strategy could also exert influence over economic policies in the developing world. The traditionally strong influence of the United States might be weakened, and Japan's approach to development, emphasizing the creation of business-governmental partnerships to spur selected industries, may supplant American models, which rely more on the private sector and free markets.
The advisory panel's report has already stirred controversy, particularly for its recommendation that Japan reverse its stated policy of eliminating its huge trade surpluses. The group recommended - and immediately afterward a number of Japan's top economic officials agreed - that the surpluses should be maintained at a moderate level to finance Japan's international goals. The existence of the surpluses would enable Japan to make overseas investments without impinging on the capital it uses at home.
Even within Japan there is bound to be resistance to such changes. Takao Akabane, an adviser to the Economic Planning Agency and formerly its top bureaucrat, said in an interview: ''What seems to be making people uneasy is the speed of the reduction of Japan's current account surpluses over the past few years. But it's just not right that Japan must have surpluses to maintain foreign assistance. I don't ascribe to those arguments.'' The public release of the report, which was prepared largely by the staff of the Finance Ministry, suggests that the process of building a consensus is well advanced.
 
Shift in Financial Power
In the 1980's, the huge budget and trade deficits of the United States transformed it into the largest debtor country, while Japan's bountiful trade surpluses vaulted it ahead of other countries to become the largest creditor nation. It was a dramatic shift in financial power.
Most of Japan's savings rests in private and corporate hands, and the the money has been used to acquire everything from huge amounts of United States Treasury securities and real estate to Columbia Pictures, the big movie studio; Rockefeller Center and rare Van Goghs and Picassos.
The amount the Japanese are spending abroad continues to grow. The Government announced over the weekend that direct investment by Japanese companies in foreign factories, real estate and corporate acquisitions soared by 44 percent in the fiscal year that ended in March, to a record $67.5 billion.
 
Widest Gauge of Surpluses
The broadest measure of a country's annual surpluses of capital is known as the current account, which reflects a country's trade balance in manufactured goods, as well as services, earnings from investments and other international flows of capital.
Japan's current account jumped to a peak surplus of $87 billion in 1987, from a $10.7 billion deficit in 1980. The current account surplus was $57 billion last year, reflecting concerted American and Japanese Government attempts to reduce it, and it is expected to be about $55 billion this year.
The report by the Finance Ministry advisory committee had two parts, one of which examined the current pattern of Japan's foreign investment, and another that discussed the future.
Thus far, media attention has focused on the portion that declared that Japan should not eliminate its current account surpluses, which now total slightly less than 2 percent of the size of Japan's gross national product, down from 4.5 percent in 1987.
 
Support of Stability Seen
The advisory panel, made up of leading business executives, academicians and journalists, was headed by Tomomistu Oba, a former vice minister of finance. It said ''the nation's current account surplus is serving to support stable world economic growth rather than causing confusion in the global economy.''
It also sought to discourage Japanese companies from acquiring highly visible landmark assets abroad, because of the resentment against Japan they engender - a reference to such transactions as Mitsubishi Estate's purchase last year of a major interest in Rockefeller Center.
The Finance Ministry is also resisting a concession the Japanese made to the United States in recent trade talks and may use this report as a means of watering down the commitment to increase domestic spending on such projects as roads, bridges and sewage treatment plants.
 
Viewed as Threat to Trade
The investment was intended to reduce Japan's capital surpluses, which the United States has described as an imbalance threatening free trade.
On Friday, for instance, Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto said at a news conference that ''the time has come for Japan to seriously consider what level is appropriate for its current account surplus.'' The premise of his comment was that surpluses of some size would continue.
''I don't see any need to bring it down further,'' Hideyuki Aizawa, director general of the Economic Planning Agency, said of the surplus while in Paris on Friday.
Japanese officials have argued that since Japan is now being called upon to make greater contributions to help finance the reconstruction of Eastern Europe, as well as to finance the American budget deficits through purchases of United States Treasury securities, the country must continue to sell more to the world than it buys.
But Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said in Paris on Thursday that new capital demands in Europe ''should not be confused with the need for surplus countries to continue to bring down their external surpluses by increasing investment relative to savings'' at home.
 
Position Called Paradoxical
Richard Koo, senior economist at the Nomura Research Institute in Tokyo, said many Japanese found it paradoxical that the Government seemed more concerned about using Japan's surpluses to strengthen the competitiveness of Japanese companies abroad, and contributing to the development of the third world, than improving the life style of the Japanese.
One reason Japan agreed in the recent trade talks to increase domestic investment was to bring the nation's standard of living to a level commensurate with the wealth it has accumulated.
''The attitude sometimes seems to be that the Japanese can live in their rabbit hutches and that this capital will be used in Eastern Europe,'' Mr. Koo said. ''The main problem with this new theme is that it maintains the status quo. That's what this is all about. And remember, the status quo is the source of so many trade problems today.''
 
Redirection of Capital Flows
In another indication of the sweep of the new proposals, a senior Finance Ministry official said, ''We must consider all factors surrounding all of Japan's international relations.'' That was a reference to the question of redirecting the flow of Japanese capital away from the United States.
In its recommendations, the panel also proposed the creation of more ''country funds,'' or mutual fund-type investments that take private capital and invest in a diversified basket of securities in those foreign countries. Japanese securities houses have developed numerous country funds for investing in Southeast Asia, for instance.
As the Finance Ministry official indicated, there is still a lengthy review process before the proposals are adapted. But his pointed comments and those of other Japanese financial leaders make clear that Japan is preparing to take on the greater international responsibilities that the United States and others have urged on it.

HEADLINE: Cuomo to Run; Won't Promise A 4-Year Term

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 3

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo formally announced today that he would seek a third term, but he refused to commit himself to serving a full four-year term and seemed almost to be encouraging speculation about a possible Presidential bid.
Mr. Cuomo said before the last gubernatorial campaign that if he ran for a second term, it would be a signal that he would not seek the Presidency in 1988. But when asked today whether there was any signal about 1992 to be discerned from his current re-election bid, he said, ''None that I can see.''
In a letter announcing his intention to run for re-election, the 57-year-old Governor said today that despite the ''significant progress'' made in his seven and half years in office, ''clearly a great deal of work still lies ahead.'' 
 
Day Before State Convention
''I intend to ask the people of New York to again give me the privilege of serving as Governor,'' he said.
Mr. Cuomo's widely anticipated announcement came one day before the state's Democratic convention is to begin in Albany. His announcement signals the beginning of a test on how much this year's fiscal problems have damaged his sheen as Governor and any national political aspirations he may have. [Page B2.] Mr. Cuomo has said he waited to announce his plans until after the state budget was resolved, a process that lasted until the middle of last month. But his advisers said another reason that the announcement came so late was to avoid triggering the Federal law that requires broadcast stations to give political candidates the opportunity for equal air time in a campaign.
Addressing convention volunteers this afternoon, Mr. Cuomo appeared relaxed and confident. He was dressed in uncharacteristically casual attire, sporting a dark jacket and light blue pants.
''I hope nobody was surprised that we announced that we were going to run again,'' he said jokingly. ''I never took the question very seriously when people said, 'What are you going to do?' I'm not sure I'm qualified for anything else, frankly.''
Speaking to reporters later, Mr. Cuomo insisted that he did not want to engage in the cagey circumlocutions about the Presidency that were a theme of his second term. But he nevertheless declined to answer reporters' questions about his intentions, saying they would not believe his responses anyway.
 
'Semantic Carousel'
''The last thing in the world I would want to do, if we're nominated and if we succeed, is to get involved in the kind of semantic carousel that we were on last time,'' he said. ''I'll try to figure out how to avoid that. I don't know how to do it, but I'll try.''
Asked why he did not simply say he intended to serve out his full four-year term in Albany, Mr. Cuomo said, ''That wouldn't work at all because what would make you believe it?''
Historically, Mr. Cuomo has always benefited from the speculation that he might run for President. When the speculation was at its most feverish in 1987, the Governor's approval rating jumped to more than 70 percent. Since then, it has hovered around 60 percent.
In 1986, when the Presidential fever was already high, Mr. Cuomo won re-election to the governorship by the largest margin in state history, defeating his Republican opponent, Andrew P. O'Rourke, the Westchester County Executive, by more than two to one.
But this year, aides to the Governor have been trying to lower expectations about the campaign, saying that even though Mr. Cuomo's Republican challenger, Pierre A. Rinfret, is a political neophyte, they do not expect Mr. Cuomo to win again by such a large margin.
Mr. Cuomo himself has taken to talking about his opponent in a clearly exaggerated, often even comical tone of fear. Asked about Mr. Rinfret today, Mr. Cuomo said he thought he would be ''formidable.''
 
Starting With Advantages
The Governor has overwhelming advantages as he enters the race against Mr. Rinfret, an economist who won the Republican nomination after 19 other people declined it. Not only does he have eight years of incumbency but he also has a campaign fund of more than $6 million. Mr. Rinfret has no campaign fund to speak of yet, though he has said he plans to spend $500,000 of his own money on the campaign.
Although Mr. Cuomo has frequently been at odds with the Liberal Party, he also comes to the campaign enjoying the Liberal Party endorsement. Mr. Rinfret, in contrast, will face an opponent, Herbert London, a dean at New York University, on the Conselrvative Party line.
But Mr. Cuomo also comes to the campaign bruised by the state's continuing fiscal problems, which resulted last month in the largest tax increase in New York history. He acknowledged the damage from the budget indirectly, saying: ''We never went through a time quite like the last budget, but that's O.K. We'll deal with that too.''
 
'Tired of Negativism'
Mr. Cuomo, whose campaign four years ago became bogged down in an exchange of unsubstantiated assertions by both sides about ethical improprieties, said today he was ''tired of negativism'' and pledged to conduct a positive race.
''You can't build a society on a foundation of mud,'' he said.
Mr. Cuomo , who was criticized in the 1986 race for conducting an aloof and unengaged campaign, vowed today to crisscross the state with his running mate, Lieut. Gov. Stan Lundine.
''I will be with Stan all over this state,'' he said. ''We're going to work harder than we ever have before.''

HEADLINE: Japanese-U.S. Relations Undergoing a Redesign

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, May 30

 BODY:
Thirty years ago, leftist protesters mobbed the streets of Tokyo to denounce a new security treaty with the United States. The turmoil toppled the Government and forced President Dwight D. Eisenhower to cancel a trip to Japan.
Today, the collapse of the cold war and Japan's coming of age as an economic and technological superpower -a rival as well as a friend - have brought a quiet redefinition of some basic assumptions of the 30-year-old partnership, including the rationale for the presence of 51,000 troops on Japanese soil.
''Japan and the United States need a new map to define our interests,'' said Terumasa Nakanishi, professor of international relations at Shizuoka University. ''The question is whether we have the intellectual vitality to face a new era of history.'' 
In a report in April on the American presence in East Asia, the Defense Department acknowledged that ''traditional threat perceptions are changing'' and that ''our presence in the region is now seen as less relevant'' because of the Soviet decline.
Defense officials cite such developments as the Soviet Union's troop withdrawals from its border with China and Mongolia, its reduction in naval forces at Cam Ranh Bay, Vietnam, and the general preoccupation of Moscow with domestic economic problems.
 
U.S. Pullback Upsets Japanese
Such factors helped persuade the Bush Administration to withdraw 14,000 to 15,000 of the 135,000 troops currently stationed in Japan, South Korea and the Philippines over the next three years, a decision that has unsettled Tokyo.
Soviet intentions in Asia are still widely viewed as uncertain and its armed power remains potent. Military experts say that Russian naval and air forces are undergoing rapid modernization even as they are being nominally reduced. Japan is especially skeptical of Moscow because of a lingering bitter territorial dispute over several islands north of the country that were seized by the Soviet Union in the final days of World War II.
Beyond these military concerns, officials note that trans-Pacific trade is now about $300 billion a year, or about 50 percent more than trans-Atlantic trade, and that instability in Asia, such as China or North Korea, could disrupt vital American interests.
''Even if the Russians withdrew completely, you'd still have a host of security problems,'' said Lieut. Gen. James B. Davis, commander of United States forces in Japan. ''You've got unstable situations in North Korea, China, Cambodia and a lot of other places. We are here because it is in our interest, not just Japan's.''
Like many others, General Davis said he saw Japanese economic power - as the No. 1 investor, trade partner and aid donor in Asia - as a force for stability perhaps equal to the presence of American troops.
 
U.S. Urges Japanese On
In light of this has come American encouragement for Japan to involve itself in Asian problems, which Tokyo has been wary of since the war. For the first time, Japan has begun to respond.
For example, beginning on Monday, Japan will play host to talks on Cambodia between Prince Sihanouk and Prime Minister Hun Sen. Japan's moves came after it warned members of the United Nations Security Council that if they expect Japanese aid to be a part of a Cambodian settlement, this country would have to be involved in the political discussions along the way.
In general, economic cooperation between Japan and the United States is now no longer advertised as crucial to stem Communism in Asia, but to cope with a new generation of problems -from aid to Eastern Europe to third world debt, refugees, terrorism, drugs and the environment.
Perhaps the most sensitive rationale for the Japanese-American partnership is one that has been less widely discussed until recently, but now considered central since the Soviet Union has receded as a threat.
This is the perception that American troops are needed to reassure Asian neighbors about Tokyo's intentions. Like Germany in Europe, an economically powerful Japan continues to generate wariness 45 years after its defeat in World War II.
Accordingly, Japanese officials increasingly argue that Tokyo's spreading trade, investments and economic aid in Asia are actually made possible by an American military presence in Japan that effectively blocks any chance of Japan's rearming.
In addition, Japan has taken a supportive role on the negotiations to renew the lease on American bases in the Philippines. Indeed, at American urging, Japan has committed about $1 billion in aid to the Philippines in the last year.
Opinion surveys show that in spite of well-publicized economic friction, the Japanese-American partnership has broad popular support in both countries. Like Americans, Japanese are yearning for a ''peace dividend'' growing out of the declining Soviet threat, some polls say.
American policy makers say it ought to be obvious that two countries accounting for 40 percent of the world's economic output and 40 percent of aid to poor nations must work together.
Japanese and American economic interdependence is also at an all-time high. Not only does military technology now flow both ways, but Japan has $66 billion in direct investment in United States companies and property and Japanese investors have been essential in financing the United States budget deficit.
The United States estimates, for instance, that Japanese institutions own perhaps $100 billion worth of government securities and that they buy perhaps 30 to 40 percent of the debt offerings of the Treasury Department.
 
When Closeness Hurts
But specialists in Japanese-American relations are also nervous that just this interdependent relationship is causing concern and eroding support for the relationship.
On the American side, a recent Japanese-sponsored survey showed sharp increases in the number of people who view Japan as less than reliable. Most Americans now seem to feel more threatened by Japanese economic power than by Soviet military power.
In Japan, officials note that many leading advocates of Japanese-American friendship were defeated for re-election this year, and Japanese politicians are increasingly inclined to criticize the United States.
Aides to Mr. Kaifu said that Ichiro Ozawa, secretary general of the governing Liberal Democratic Party and the Prime Minister's chief political official, spoke for many when he accused Washington of ''self-righteousness and arrogance'' in recent trade negotiations.
By far the greatest concern among those seeking to preserve Japanese-American cooperation stems from the economic friction surrounding the persistent $50 billion American trade deficit with Japan.
Thus the United States Ambassador, Michael H. Armacost, has repeatedly warned Japan of ''an erosion of public support in the United States for our relationship'' because of a perception of unfair Japanese trade and investment practices. Accords Without Much Effect? A flurry of trade accords were negotiated in April, the centerpiece of which was an agreement that Japan curb some of its deep-rooted ''structural impediments'' to American imports, including monopolistic business practices and regulations that bar competition in crucial areas.
But Japanese and American specialists agree that these agreements are unlikely to have a significant effect on the trade imbalance. For one thing, the accords are expected to change Japanese practices marginally, if at all, with many people uncertain that a rise in American exports would result.
Another cause of tension, specialists in both countries say, is the rapid growth of Japanese investment in the United States and the perception that certain crucial industries, like automobiles, computers and semiconductors, are endangered by Japanese competition.
Worst of all, in the view of American and Japanese policy makers, is a growth in the feeling in Japan that the United States is blaming Tokyo for its own shortcomings and unwilling to address deep-seated problems at home.
There is also tension surrounding the United States desire for Japanese military technology, coupled with fear that this technology could spur Japan into new commercial areas like commercial aircraft, undercutting American business.

HEADLINE: HONG KONG HONORS BEIJING'S VICTIMS

BYLINE: By BARBARA BASLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HONG KONG, June 3

 BODY:
More than 100,000 people, most of them dressed in the mourning colors of white and black, took part today in a march to honor pro-democracy demonstrators who were killed in the army crackdown in Beijing last June 4.
The march, under gray, rainy skies, drew the largest turnout here since the huge demonstrations in support of democracy in China last summer. The police estimated the crowd at 100,000, while organizers claimed 250,000.
The size of the crowd, which stretched for more than two miles past the skyscrapers of Hong Kong's central business district, surprised even its organizers, whose original estimate of a turnout of 30,000 people was widely thought to be optimistic. Hong Kong, a British colony, reverts to Chinese control in 1997. 
''The vast numbers show that in spite of fears here - and many people do fear that the Chinese photograph these demonstrations and will later seek to punish those who took part - despite those fears, almost a quarter of a million people came out,'' said Martin Lee, a liberal lawyer and a leader of today's march.
 
Intimidation Said to Fail
Mr. Lee said the huge crowd ''proves that the Chinese policy of trying to intimidate Hong Kong over the past year has failed.'' He added, ''They need to recognize that fact and try to win us over, not frighten us.''
The crowds today, generally sad and solemn, followed a hearse, and where the Chinese traditionally place a picture of the dead, it carried pictures of the violence in Tiananmen Square last June.
A Chinese father marching behind the hearse and carrying his young son on his shoulders said: ''I want him to remember this. I want him to understand we must never forget.''
Thousands of small white penants proclaimed, ''People Will Not Forget.'' The marchers, who sang ''China Shall Be Free'' to the American protest tune ''We Shall Overcome,'' also chanted for the downfall of Prime Minister Li Peng, and demanded the release of democracy advocates still in prison in China.
The river of demonstrators was led by Mr. Lee and Szeto Wah, and a number of Hong Kong's most popular entertainers. The march was organized by the Hong Kong Alliance in Support of the Patriotic Democratic Movement in China, a group Beijing has labeled subversive.
The march ended at the New China News Agency, China's de facto embassy here, and then dispersed quietly. The press agency's headquarters has traditionally been the focus of protests against China, and all day, passers-by had stopped to pay tribute to those who died in Beijing last June.
 
Makeshift Altar Set Up
Some bowed reverently before a makeshift altar that had been set up by student protesters outside the big marble and tile New China News Agency headquarters. Others lighted joss sticks, and still others brought small offerings of apples, oranges and biscuits they placed before the alter. The headquarters was heavily guarded by the police, its front door locked and barred.
The crowds today were no match for the hundreds of thousands - some said up to a million - who took to the streets here last summer in support of the democracy movement in China. But today's turnout was nevertheless impressive for a colony that has grown increasingly reticent and fearful of China.
One sign of the change of heart from summer to summer is the large Goddess of Democracy statue, put up by Beijing demonstrators, and copied here by local artists. The replica was displayed last summer in parks here, but was absent from today's tribute.
The Goddess, stored for months by its creators, was finally buried in a garbage landfill after the Hong Kong Government refused to give it a permanent public home. Today, there was a smaller copy strapped to a bus, and there were a number of cardboard cutouts of the Goddess.
Since last June, the Hong Kong government and political leaders here have taken pains to avoid angering or even displeasing the Chinese authorities, whose attitude toward the colony has been seen by many as intrusive and threatening.
The military crackdown last year shook Hong Kong's very foundations, destroying in days the colony's essential confidence in itself, in its future under China. A local newspaper recently quoted expert psychologists as saying the level of stress in Hong Kong ranks behind only Beirut and Belfast. #1,000 Leave Each Week While China has promised to leave Hong Kong's social and economic systems largely intact and to maintain a policy of ''one country, two systems'' after 1997, few have faith in those pledges anymore.
More than 1,000 people - educated, talented entrepreneurs and professionals - are leaving Hong Kong each week, creating serious shortages in key occupations.
Economic performance has been lackluster, and more local companies here have moved their bases to Bermuda, and are looking for investments outside the colony.
A Hong Kong Chinese banker said recently that political reforms here were no longer the answer. ''The only hope for us,'' he said, ''is a change of power in Beijing.''
 
Rallies in the U.S.
 
By The Associated Press
Demonstrations commemorating the first anniversary of the suppression of the democracy movement in China were held yesterday in New York, Washington, Chicago, Boston and Buffalo, among other cities.
The rally in New York City drew about 1,500 people across the street from the Chinese Consulate in Manhattan. People inside the consulate's building at 45th Street and 12th Avenue were seen videotaping the rally from windows, and an older Chinese man yelled up several times in Chinese, ''Come Down! Come Down!''

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN WASHINGTON;
Gorbachev May Be a Prophet Without Honor at Home

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 3

 BODY:
The most telling moment of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's appearance at the post-summit press conference today came when the man from Izvestia, the Soviet Government daily, was recognized for a question.
While the Americans were peppering the Soviet leader with questions on Germany, the Izvestia writer, Stanislav N. Kondrashev, drily noted ''a cooling of interest'' back home in international affairs.
''Everybody's concerned with internal matters at home,'' he told the Soviet leader, who was startled that this splash of cold water should come from the once-predictable hometown press. ''Taking advantage of this opportunity, I'd like to ask you, what do you think of your relationship with Yeltsin?''
 
Problems Back Home
For Mr. Gorbachev, the street-corner adulation and shirtsleeve summitry of this American visit have been a pleasant reprieve from his domestic troubles, and have shored up for a time his position on the world stage. But when the presidential bonding was over, Mr. Gorbachev had found no escape, and little relief, from the problems awaiting him at home. 
What Mr. Gorbachev takes back, by way of the Middle West and California, is an American vote of confidence.
Time and again during his meetings here, the Soviet leader sought to refute the impression that he is a man enfeebled by economic and political crises, and his American counterpart graciously played along.
President Bush, putting the relationship above the agenda, bolstered Mr. Gorbachev with public affirmations of respect and trust. Most notably, Mr. Bush announced that he would not make the liberation of Lithuania a precondition for the normal trade relations Moscow wants so desperately.
''Bush had all the trump cards, and he didn't play them,'' said Aleksandr Bovin, the well-connected Soviet newspaper and television commentator, pleased that in America, at least, there is still faith in perestroika.
But in practical terms, it is hard to see how the summit in any way arrests the Soviet Union's steady retreat from world influence or the inexorable unraveling of the domestic order.
 
Competition From Yeltsin
For Mr. Gorbachev's anxious citizenry, this summit meeting has not even performed the service that statesmen in trouble expect from such events: a distraction from what ails them.
In the formerly obedient Soviet press, the White House signing ceremony and Camp David golf-cart driving competed for front-page attention with stripped grocery shelves, death in Armenia and the leader of a budding Russian mutiny, Boris N. Yeltsin.
Mr. Yeltsin, now the President of the Russian republic, conducted his own summitry with the Baltic secessionists of Lithuania and Estonia. The Lithuanian President, Vytautas Landsbergis, declared that an inter-republic trade deal was in the works that might circumvent Moscow's economic sanctions against his Baltic state.
Thus, while Mr. Gorbachev was trying to explain in Washington his plan for a rebuilt Soviet federation that would allow various degrees of freedom to the 15 constituent republics, the unruly republics seemed to be negotiating their own new federation in the Soviet President's absence.
The most tangible trophy Mr. Gorbachev takes home for his consumers is a trade agreement, which is a symbol of momentum in his quest for Western economic help. Transforming that symbol into sausage, however, will not be easy.
First, to get the agreement through Congress, Mr. Gorbachev must see an emigration law through his own Parliament.
 
The Costs of Emigration
The emigration measure is considered a sure thing, but the costs have just recently begun sinking in. The free emigration envisioned by the law is expected to accelerate a drain of Soviet talent and of foreign currency. That is one reason the Government was unable to deliver the bill before the summit meeting and is not expected to do so until the fall.
Second, though Mr. Bush no longer links trade relations to the fate of Lithuania, Congress may.
And third, enactment of the law will not remove the biggest barrier to increased Soviet-American trade: the fact that the Soviets produce little that Americans want to buy, and cannot afford what America sells.
After five years of unkept economic promises, it will take more than signatures on a trade pact to improve the moods of skeptical Soviet consumers.
On the most contentious outstanding issues of Soviet foreign policy - arms control, regional issues and the critical question of Germany's future - the two leaders seem to have found the personal rapport that Mr. Bush prizes so highly in his dealings with foreign leaders, but they did not close any of the great gaps that remain on points of substance.
In effect, Mr. Gorbachev was reconfirmed in his role as a man the West likes to do business with - in other words, the man best qualified to preside over the ebb of Soviet power.
 
Stalemates Remain Unbroken
The stalemates on the treaties to cut long-range nuclear weapons and conventional forces in Europe remained unbroken.
On arms control, Mr. Gorbachev found himself up against a resurgence of the American conservatives, who have pressed Mr. Bush to insist on further concessions regarding Soviet heavy missiles and bombers. Mr. Bush insisted.
The one foreign-policy area where the summit may ultimately pay off big for Mr. Gorbachev is in the design of the post-Cold War order of Europe, especially the question of whether a united Germany will be integrated militarily into the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
The Bush Administration seems to understand how badly Mr. Gorbachev needs assurances that the new Europe does not leave the Soviet Union feeling isolated and threatened. Mr. Gorbachev seemed, at the end of his visit to Washington, to feel that the Americans appreciate his predicament. That kind of mutual trust could ultimately prove vital in working out a solution that accommodates Soviet psychology and saves Mr. Gorbachev face.
Asked on the eve of the summit what Mr. Gorbachev most wanted from America, one presidential confidant, Yevgeny M. Primakov, replied without hesitation, ''Understanding.''
In Washington, Mr. Gorbachev got what he wanted. The question is whether he can take it home.

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN WASHINGTON;
Meetings on Food Will Examine Soviet Shortages

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 3

 BODY:
The United States and the Soviet Union will undertake their most ambitious efforts ever this week to deal with one of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's greatest problems - finding more and better food for Soviet consumers.
Representatives of the two country's food sectors are gathering in Washington at what is being described as a ''food summit'' to promote food trade and joint ventures after Mr. Gorbachev's meeting with President Bush, in which promise was held out for greater economic cooperation,.
The Soviet Agriculture Minister, V. V. Nikitin, and two American Cabinet members, Agriculture Secretary Clayton K. Yeutter and Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher, will use the occasion to sign an accord on the exchange of food data between the two countries. 
The meeting, to be held from Monday thru Wednesday, is being sponsored by the Food Industries International Trade Council, an association of major food processors and food machinery producers organized to promote trade with the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe.
 
Trade Agreement Signed
The decision by Mr. Bush Friday to sign a Soviet trade agreement - starting a process that could end four decades of trade discrimination against Moscow - has increased chances of positive results from the food meeting, American officials said.
While the trade agreement would cut American tariffs on Soviet goods, it would also improve conditions for Americans doing business in the Soviet Union, providing, among other things, better intellectual property protection.
But other obstacles, chiefly related to problems in repatriating profits, will remain even if Congress approves the new trade agreement. The outlook for freer repatriation depends on moves to restructure the Soviet economy along market-oriented lines, establish more realistic pricing, and make the ruble convertible into hard currencies.
''Unless we see more full-scale reforms occurring, you won't see much real increase in business activity,'' said Dr. George Melnykovich, President of the Food Processing Machinery & Supplies Association, a trade association of 530 companies.
 
Signing Set for Wednesday
The information exchange pact, to be signed Wednesday, sets up a clearing house in Moscow that would give American companies information on specific manufacturing and other needs and possible joint venture partners.
The information would be disseminated by Commerce Department offices throughout the United States.
For their part, Soviet enterprises would have direct access to constantly updated lists of American food companies, their specialties, production areas and capabilities.
There have been casual, ad hoc data exchange programs in the past. The new accord gives the effort a higher visibility and broader base.
 
'Deepest Cooperation' Seen
According to one of its negotiators, Michael P. Skarzynski, Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Trade Development, it sets up ''the deepest cooperation ever undertaken by the United States with the Soviet Union in any industrial sector.''
Such companies as FMC Corporation, Archer Daniels Midland, Land O'Lakes, H. J. Heinz, Pepsico, Philip Morris/Kraft General Foods, Stokely and RJR Nabisco are among leading backers of the meeting.
Soviet participants include representatives of the State Commission of the Council of Ministers on Food and Procurement, Ministries of Finance, Trade and Foreign Economic Relations, and other government agencies.

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN WASHINGTON;
Israel Answers Soviets, Denies Plans for Settlers

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, June 3

 BODY:
Israel reiterated tonight that it has no plans to settle Soviet Jewish immigrants in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.
The Israeli statement was issued tonight by Avi Pazner, a senior adviser to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, in response to an apparent threat by the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, to stop the flow of Soviet Jews to Israel unless the Soviet Union was assured that they will not be settled in the occupied territories.
Discussing Israeli immigration at a news conference with President Bush in Washington today, Mr. Gorbachev said:
''We are facing the following situation: Either after these meetings and exchanges with the President of the United States of America on this particular issue, our concern will be heeded in Israel and they will make certain conclusions, or else we must give further thought to it in terms of what we can do with issuing permits for exit.''
Mr. Pazner said, ''We will make clear to Gorbachev our policy that we are not sending, not encouraging, and not giving incentives to Soviet Jews to settle in the areas of Judea, Samaria and Gaza.'' Judea and Samaria are the biblical names for the West Bank. 
 
Incentives Are Offered
All Jews immigrating to Israel are given help in resettling there, and those who choose to settle in the occupied territories are given extra incentives by the Government.
''The Jews arriving here have complete freedom of choice and can choose where to live, and it is a fact that very few, until now, have chosen to live in these areas,'' Mr. Pazner said in a telephone interview.
He added that only 135 Jewish emigrants from the Soviet Union had chosen to live in settlements established by Israel in the occupied territories. ''This year less than one half of one percent have expressed their choice to do so,'' Mr. Pazner said.
About 70,000 Jewish settlers live in the occupied territories amid 1.7 million Palestinians.
Another Israeli official, who asked not to be identified, dismissed the Soviet threat as a bluff, saying the Soviet Union would face severe economic penalties from the United States and Western European nations if it tried to carry out such a threat or acted to slow the flow of Soviet Jewish emigration to Israel.
''I think the comments were meant for Arab consumption,'' the official said. He added that the Soviets, who are seeking urgent financial and economic cooperation in the West, are ''too vulnerable on this issue to act on it.''
At their summit meeting in Baghdad last week, Arab nations asserted that the flow of tens of thousands of Soviet Jews to Israel threatened the peace process in the region by diminishing the chances of negotiating the establishment of an independent Palestinian state in the occupied territories.
 
Soviets Ban Direct Flights
It was partly in response to previous expressions of Arab alarm that the Soviet Union banned direct flights to Israel, but several countries, including Poland, Cyprus, Austria and Italy, are allowing Soviet Jews transit rights to Israel.
The issue has become so sensitive, particularly in view of threats by some Palestinian extremist groups to attack countries that allow Soviet migrants to travel to Israel, that Israeli officials have been forbidden to discuss any matters dealing with Soviet immigration here.
Israeli officials have repeatedly asserted that the number of Soviet Jews who have moved into settlements in the occupied territories is too small to be considered a problem. But Western diplomats here say that if new settlements that have been built in East Jerusalem are taken into consideration, the number could be as high as 10 percent.
Israel has also been upset about assertions by the United States that it objects to any new settlements in the occupied territories and to a recent declaration that the United States may increase its own quota of Soviet Jews allowed to settle there.
Today, Uri Gordon, head of the absorption department of the Jewish Agency, said the United States' declared intention to increase its quota of Soviet immigrants reflected what he described as an erosion of the United States position toward Israel, according to a report broadcast on Israel's radio today.
Israeli officials say the United States, which allows about 50,000 Soviet Jews to come in every year as immigrants, is considering increasing the quota to 70,000.
The last monthly figure on immigration from the Soviet Union to Israel was 10,500 for April. Israeli officials would not say how many immigrants arrived in May.
But a senior Israeli Government official said: ''We still expect higher numbers to come, regardless of what the Soviets are saying. They have done nothing to slow the movement, and there are many things they could do if they really meant it.'' ----Gorbachev Is Criticized American Jewish groups condemned Mr. Gorbachev's comments on Jewish emigration yesterday.
Sholom D. Comay of New York, president of the American Jewish Committee, said his group was ''distressed'' at the remark that the flow of Soviet Jews to Israel might be curtailed. In a statement, Mr. Comay said he hoped ''that President Bush's silence on hearing the Soviet leader's threat does not mean any weakening of the Administration's resolve, and that it will now once more make clear its determination that Soviet Jewish immigration must continue.''
Another New York-based group, The Student Struggle for Soviet Jewry, said Mr. Gorbachev had made ''intemperate threats'' and given ''tragic confirmation'' of his ''underlying hostility to Israel.''
Malcolm Hoenlein, executive director of the Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations, said in a statement in New York that ''even to suggest a restriction of Jewish emigration to Israel is unacceptable.''

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN WASHINGTON;
Gorbachev, in U.S. Heartland, Dangles Visions of Fortunes in Soviet Trade

BYLINE: By ERIC N. BERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MINNEAPOLIS, June 3

 BODY:
Mikhail S. Gorbachev told America's business and agricultural leaders today that they need not fear investing in the Soviet Union while that country undergoes economic reform.
In a speech to executives and heads of farm groups from across the country, Mr. Gorbachev acknowledged that perestroika, his program of economic liberalization, had produced difficulties.
But the Soviet leader seemed to suggest that these problems were only a short-term result of the liberalization process and that American companies would be wise not to wait to invest in the Soviet Union.
He provided a checklist of business sectors in which he said the Soviet Union hoped to receive United States investment - in everything from auto making to computer design to railroad modernization. 
''Those who are with us now have a good chance - have good prospects -of participating in our great country,'' Mr. Gorbachev said. Those companies that remain on the sidelines, he said, ''will remain observers for years to come - we will see to it.''
 
'We Are Just Beginning'
Mr. Gorbachev urged his audience to be patient while the Soviets developed financial and legal systems, and added that the Soviet Union hoped to develop stock exchanges and a modern banking system. ''When you pass judgment on us, please understand that certain things you have had for decades - centuries perhaps - are new for us,'' Mr. Gorbachev said. ''We are just beginning.''
Mr. Gorbachev's remarks on economic matters were the highlight of a day that blended pageantry, sightseeing and public relations. After ending his summit talks in Washington with President Bush, Mr. Gorbachev flew to Minneapolis-St. Paul, where he settled into a one-hour meeting with the business and agricultural leaders after a brief sightseeing tour.
Protesters were out in force along the route. They carried signs criticizing Mr. Gorbachev's handling of the Baltic republics' independence movements and the Soviets' involvement in Afghanistan.
On his arrival, as soon as the University of Minnesota's Symphonic Wind Ensemble struck up Dmitri Shostakovich's ''Festive Overture,'' Mr. Gorbachev plunged into the crowd, pumping hands.
He did not even permit his motorcade to arrive at its first destination, the Governor's Mansion in St. Paul, before he was working the crowds a second time. After greeting well-wishers a block from the mansion and even gesturing to protesters, Mr. Gorbachev clasped his wife's hand and, with a handbell choir performing in the background, walked to the mansion.
 
Veal and Walleye Pike
There, he dined on breaded walleye pike, Wisconsin Provimi veal, a compote of wild rice and corn and minted sweet biscuits filled with whipped cream and served with early-summer berries and caramel sauce.
From an economic perspective, Mr. Gorbachev's visit to Control Data Corporation could yield immediate results, including a stop he made to observe a demonstration of computer work stations being built under contract to improve nuclear power-plant safety in the Soviet Union.
A delegation of scientists arranged meetings with Control Data scientists, discussing topics ranging from computer-to-computer communications to computer-aided design.
''Gorbachev understands that to get into the modern world it will take automation and advancement in electronics,'' said Lawrence Perlman, Control Data's president and chief executive.
Realizing that no amount of money could generate as much favorable publicity as the Gorbachev visit, Mr. Perlman and other Control Data officials decided to turn the event into a party.
They had huge tents erected on the company's front lawn, supplied truckloads of hot dogs, cotton candy, popcorn and corn on the cob and invited all Control Data employees and their families. More than 15,000 tickets were handed out.
The celebration was paid for by Control Data. Indeed, except for the overtime pay that St. Paul and Minneapolis will have to pay employees who were involved, virtually the entire Soviet visit was financed by businesses, providing cash, goods and services.
International Business Machines Corporation, for instance, lent personal computers. U.S. West Communications Inc. donated telephones. The Carlson Companies Inc., owner of the Radisson lodging chain, provided rooms. And Northwest Airlines gave free travel.
 
Volunteers Save the Day
An army of local lawyers, accountants and public-relations executives offered their services. It was a demonstration of volunteerism that made local officials proud.
''If they wouldn't help me I don't know what I would have done,'' said Roger Parkinson, publisher of The Star Tribune, who was chosen by Governor Rudy Perpich to head the committee organizing for the visit.
Minnesota officials had less than three weeks to prepare.
Early in the planning, Soviet officials emphasized that President Gorbachev would want to meet with business and farm leaders. Indeed, one reason Minnesota was chosen is that Minnesota has well-developed agricultural and industrial sectors.
But what began as an intimate gathering of prominent Minnesotans evolved into a congress of industrialists from across the country, with hundreds of companies jockeying for an invitation.
When Soviet officials made clear that Mr. Gorbachev hoped to meet with leaders of American business and finance no matter what their home base, the list of invited guests swelled to 145.
'We received many, many requests from individual companies,'' said Ray Bohn, Governor Perpich's press secretary. ''And various business groups forwarded invitation lists.''
Security along the entire route was extremely tight. Major roads were closed to all but official traffic.

PUB-DATE: June 4, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 13, Column 3; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 843 words

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN WASHINGTON;
U.S. and Soviets Will Seek to Prevent Ethiopia Famine

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 3

 BODY:
The United States and the Soviet Union said today that they will work together to avert a famine in Ethiopia and announced that the Ethiopian Government has removed a major obstacle to the delivery of relief supplies.
President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union, in a statement on Ethiopia issued at the conclusion of their four days of talks, said that joint diplomatic efforts had succeeded in persuading the Government of Lieut. Col. Mengistu Haile Mariam to stop bombing Massawa, the Eritrean guerrilla-held port, in order to enable food to enter the country.
''This is a major advance over where the United States and the Soviet Union were a year ago in cooperation on African issues,'' said Herman J. Cohen, Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs. ''I'm very pleased because the port of Massawa is the highest priority for saving potential victims.'' 
 
Port Bombing to Cease
Mr. Cohen said the Soviet-allied Ethiopian Government had made its decision to stop bombing Massawa two days ago and estimated that one million people could be fed from supplies delivered to the Red Sea port.
But before food shipments begin to come through Massawa, United Nations technicians will have to survey the port to examine war damage and see if there are adequate facilities for docking and unloading. Delays could take weeks at least.
Today's announcement was the first indication that American-Soviet cooperation to end the Ethiopian war was producing results. The struggle between the Ethiopian Government and separatist guerrillas from Eritrea province has raged since 1962. Fighting has intensified in the last few months as the Eritrean People's Liberation Front has taken Massawa and encircled the provincial capital, Asmara.
The war, compounded by a second separatist war in Tigre province, immediately south of Eritrea, has exacerbated the effects of drought and collectivist economic policies to bring a series of famines to Ethiopia in recent years. Currently 3 million people, of a total population of 50 million, are at risk of starving.
Peace negotiations mediated by former President Jimmy Carter broke off in December, when Addis Ababa refused to go along with an Eritrean proposal to include a United Nations observer in the talks.
The three-paragraph American-Soviet statement issued today indicated that the Ethiopian Government has now removed that obstacle by agreeing to include a United Nations representative in the process.
But a top Administration policymaker said Addis Ababa's decision may have come too late to resume a dialogue because the military situation has deteriorated so far in so short a time. The Eritreans are expected to mount a large-scale offensive this month to take Asmara - an action that would effectively slice off Eritrea from the rest of the country - as the rainy season grounds the Ethiopian Air Force.
 
Food Will Be Delivered
In their statement, the Soviet and American Presidents announced an agreement to cooperate on delivering food aid to 100,000 people living in regions isolated by the war. Soviet AN-24 transport planes, now used to deploy Ethiopian military units and supplies, will soon be used to supply American-supplied sorghum and rice. Before the airlifts can go into high gear, the Soviets must repair or replace four planes sabotaged by guerrillas last month.
The statement said the two Governments will support a United Nations conference to consider how to resolve the Ethiopian conflict. Mr. Gorbachev proposed the idea to Mr. Bush at Camp David. ''Nothing is planned yet on that,'' Mr. Cohen said, ''We'll have to flesh that out now.''
Mr. Cohen expressed hope that efforts by the United States and the Soviet Union to resolve the conflict in Ethiopia would soon expand to similar efforts to negotiate a conclusion to the guerrilla war in Angola.
Washington has been urging the Soviet Union to press Ethiopia to negotiate a settlement of its war for two years. About a year ago, Administration officials say, Moscow came to the conclusion that President Mengistu could not win. In the last few weeks, Moscow put Ethiopia on notice that it would significantly cut military aid next year as a pressure point to negotiate.
The United States effort to enlist Moscow's cooperation in ending the conflict and relieving the Ethiopian food shortage reached a high point last month during Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d's visit to Moscow, when the Soviets agreed in principle to work together on airlifting supplies.
Since then the Soviets and Americans have coordinated efforts, with Moscow explicitly telling Addis Ababa to negotiate an end to the fighting and Washington offering to upgrade relations in return for reopening the port.
President Mengistu's problems were compounded two weeks ago when 12 senior military officers accused of involvement in an attempted coup were executed.
Representative Tony P. Hall, Democrat of Ohio, chairman of the House Committee on Hunger, hailed today's statement as a ''mighty victory.''
