HEADLINE: Massachusetts Democrats Back Veteran as Silber Wins Ballot Spot

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, June 3

 BODY:
John R. Silber, the president of Boston University, narrowly captured a place on the Democratic primary ballot for governor this weekend as the state Democratic Party endorsed Francis X. Bellotti, a veteran politician, as its favored candidate.
The outcome allows Mr. Silber to continue his challenge for the nomination for governor in the September primary. It also averts a potential embarrassment for the Democrats. The maverick educator leads in the public opinion polls, but he had few state convention delegates; the convention tends to be more liberal than the voters at large. 
Mr. Silber, an eclectic mixture of traditional New Deal Democrat and Ronald Reagan conservative, has injected fresh energy and uncertainty into the campaign. Many voters have been outraged by his barbed remarks; others say he has the toughness to rescue Massachusetts from an economic and political slump.
 
Setback for Lieutenant Governor
The balloting at the Democrats' state convention in Springfield on Saturday was a sharp setback to Lieut. Gov. Evelyn F. Murphy, who campaigned as the only liberal in the contest but was hurt by her close identification with Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, the Democratic candidate for President in 1988. Ms. Murphy finished with 40.1 percent of the 5,000 delegates on the second ballot, to 51.4 percent for Mr. Bellotti. Mr. Silber won 15.4 percent on the first ballot, barely more than the 15 percent necessary to secure a place on the September primary ballot. He withdrew his name before the second vote, but that did not affect his being on the primary ballot. Ms. Murphy also remains in the primary race.
Mr. Bellotti, 67 years old, first ran for governor, and lost, in 1963, and has been a regular candidate for state office. He served for several terms as Attorney General. But at a time when voters talk about wanting and outsider for governor, he seems an unlikely candidate.
The convention turned into an embarrassment for the Democrats, already staggering under voter anger about the state's unresolved fiscal problems and the likelihood of sharply higher taxes. The start of the convention was delayed for four hours when the Springfield police union picketed the city's Civic Center in a contract dispute with the Mayor Mary Hurley, a Democrat.
The Democratic delegates, forced to stand in the hot sunshine as they faced a difficult choice over whether to cross a picket line, were not made happier knowing that the police union had endorsed George Bush against Mr. Dukakis.
 
Scuffles With Picketers
James Roosevelt, the general counsel to the state Democratic Party, said the Republicans were responsible for the officers' action. He noted that Ronald Kauffman, a White House political aide, and Alexander Tennant, the executive director of the Massachusetts Republican Party, were seen driving around the convention site. Mr. Kauffman and Mr. Tennant denied any responsibility.
The picketers, chanting ''Four more years'' in an evident reference to Mr. Bush, scuffled with several delegates who tried to enter the Civic Center, hitting several of them.
The picketing ended only after the Democrats obtained a restraining order from a local judge.
But former United States Senator Paul E. Tsongas worried that the picketing and the way it was handled would hurt the party.
 
Harsh Words for Party
''This is everybody's worst caricature of the Democratic Party, sitting out there for hours captive of a union that never supported us,'' Mr. Tsongas said. ''I think it would have been appropriate for someone to say we have to get through that line and show some leadership.''
Despite public anger against the Democrats, the outcome of the governor's race is far from certain. Stephen Pierce, the minority leader in the State House of Representatives who is the leading Republican candidate, is best known for his strong stand against new taxes and opposition to a woman's right to abortion. He is regarded as an uninspiring speaker and has offered few new programs.
He is opposed by William F. Weld, a former United States Attorney in Boston and former Assistant Attorney General who resigned his position in 1988 to protest the ethical problems of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d.
Mr. Silber would seem to have violated all the rules in the political book by his outspokenness, offending, at one time or another, blacks, women, homosexuals, immigrants and union members, the core members of the Democratic Party. But by refusing to tone down his campaign speeches and by calling for policies like cutting off welfare benefits to teen-age mothers who have a second child, Mr. Silber has struck a responsive chord with many disgruntled voters.

HEADLINE: CHRONICLE

BYLINE: By Susan Heller Anderson

 BODY:
Over the years, KARL ELLER has given generously to the University of Arizona, his alma mater. The grateful Tucson school has, in return, named parts of itself in his honor: the Karl Eller Graduate School of Management and the Karl Eller Center for the Study of the Private Market Economy, both in its College of Business and Public Administration. 
Recently, Mr. Eller, 62 years old, quit as chairman of the Circle K Corporation, a convenience store chain. Now, the troubled company has filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy code. Is the Eller name still one you wound want on the door of a business school?
''Mr. Eller is a typical entrepreneur - they fall on good times and hard times,'' said Susan Wong, assistant dean in the graduate school of management. ''And he's just going through a bad time.''

HEADLINE: Re-creating a Musical Event of 1927

BYLINE: By JOHN ROCKWELL

 BODY:
Since 1987, Stephen Rogers Radcliffe and his New York Chamber Ensemble have been presenting some of New York's friskiest programming - and performances, one hastens to add, since intention without follow-through equals mere conceit.
Mr. Radcliffe has an interest in the music of the early 20th century, meaning the earliest and best years of modernism. He looks at music with a historian's eye, re-creating important musical events with modern forces. For those forces he unites smaller chamber groups under his ''Chamber Ensemble'' banner, the current components being the Chester String Quartet and the piano and wind sextet Hexagon, with additional freelance forces added as necessary. 
Friday night's program at Gould Hall, which enlisted 22 instrumentalists and 7 singers, counted as one of the ensemble's best. In 1927 the prestigious, composer-organized summer festival at Donaueschingen, in what is now West Germany, moved over to Baden-Baden, which had a bigger hall. The central program, on July 17, presented staged performances of four new chamber operas by Ernst Toch, Darius Milhaud, Kurt Weill and Paul Hindemith, ranging in length -the timings are those from Friday -from 11 minutes to 33 minutes.
Mr. Radcliffe re-created that program with a few variations. The most important was that in Baden-Baden the operas were staged with proper sets and costumes; in New York, despite some effective hints of characterization, they were given in concert form. The order was juggled, too, ending with the longest piece, the Toch. Musical interludes were omitted, most piquantly Milhaud's jazzy ''Creation du Monde,'' which received its first performance in Baden-Baden.
Friday's program was rather grandly entitled ''The Birth of Chamber Opera.'' That does a disservice to more than 300 years of earlier chamber operas. It also suggests that these 1927 scores had a profound impact on music to come. Since some pessimists count 1925 as the year the operatic canon stopped admitting new entries, and since Nazism and World War II disrupted artistic evolution of all kinds, that is hard to sustain. Certainly there were all manner of theatrical ''actions'' in the 1960's, but they were generally closer to today's performance art than 1927's operatic compressions.
That said, the 1927 evening was clearly an event, and given the quality of at least three of the scores and of the performances, Friday was also something of an event. The music sounded urgent, amusing and ingenious, full of a spirit of adventure and even an optimism that was soon to be dashed by larger political events.
Far and away the most famous and influential of the four scores was Weill's ''Mahagonny Songspiel,'' a 27-minute song sequence that soon grew into the full-dress ''Rise and Fall of the City of Mahagonny,'' which the Metropolitan Opera has done with success.
The ''Songspiel'' crops up fairly often, but few performances have matched Friday's in the crispness and spunky clarity of the instrumental playing. Hearing the music so performed, one could appreciate anew the brilliance with which Weill synthesized Bertolt Brecht's cabaret obsessions, jazz and modernist formalism. The singing - all night - was by no means bad, either.
The program opened with Hindemith's ''There and Back,'' Marion J. Farquhar's English version of ''Hin und Zuruck.'' This 11-minute score depicts a jealous husband's murder of his wife, the intercession of an angel and then the filmic rewinding of the events back to the opening marital bliss, the second half being an exact musical reversal of the first half. More a cute joke than evocative music, the opera succeeds because it is a joke and is most definitely cute.
The most successful mix of musical economy and invention was Milhaud's ''Abduction of Europa,'' heard in an Eric Smith translation. Here, more than in any of the other three operas, one feels that the composer has made a complete, ingenious and fully satisfying statement within the limits set by the festival's commissioners.
Finally, Toch's ''Princess and the Pea'' (again in a Farquhar translation) emerged as not only the longest but also the most operatically and musically conventional of the lot. Posterity is not as dumb as is sometimes asserted; there's a reason Toch is now less famous than the other three composers on this bill.
Singers for the evening were Katherine Johnson, Margaret Bishop, Nancy Ortez, Mark Bleeke, Michael Brown, Richard Holmes and Robert Osborne.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

International
The Japanese Government wants to redirect the country's huge flow of private investments overseas from the industrialized Western countries to the third world and Eastern Europe. Tokyo, the world's largest exporter of capital since the mid-1980's, seems to be responding to criticisms that it has not had a world vision to watch its wealth. [Page A1.] 
A year after China violently suppressed the democracy movement, the optimism of foreign businesses about the potential of a vast market is gone. [D1.] Throughout Beijing and the rest of the country, hundreds of families are remembering their loved ones who were killed on June 4 last year when the Government moved against protesters. [A1.]
The war on cocaine trafficking in Colombia is costing Bogota dearly and officials there are growing impatient with what they feel has been a lack of aid from the U.S. [D1.]
East Germany's 3,400 industrial companies are scrambling to stay alive after the country's monetary, economic and social policies are melded with West Germany's. [D6.]
 
 
 
The Economy
Robert N. Noyce, a co-inventor of the microchip that revolutionized the eletronics industry and gave rise to Silicon Valley and the high-technology era, died after suffering a heart attack. [A1.]
Many credit market analysts do not expect the Federal Reserve to begin efforts to stimulate growth until later in the summer, despite mounting evidence that the economy is expanding at a sluggish pace. Credit Markets. [D1.]
 
 
 
Companies
Landmark Land is being forced to sell some of the country's best-known golf resorts and developed communities because it owns its real estate assets through a savings and loan institution. The subsidiary must comply with the tougher restrictions imposed on savings institutions by the Government. [D1.]
 
The Media Business
At Time magazine, the editorial direction and managerial practices are being transformed. The distinctive Olympian voice has disappeared from its pages and group journalism is being replaced by stories written in the field by reporters, and the editor in chief has ceded much control in a decentralization move. [D1.]
Book sales in Las Vegas, the gambling mecca where American booksellers are holding their annual convention and trade exhibit, are above the national average. Residents, not tourists, do most of the book buying in the town, bookstore owners say, but the city still has three shops devoted to books on gambling. [D7.]
One tradition in the book business has resisted dizzying change in an industry that has become glitzy and global: the publishing lunch. Between 12:30 and 2:30 in the afternoon, in posh restaurants in Manhattan, publishers, agents and occasionally authors do business over their midday meals. [D7.]
NBC will have to fend off questions from its affiliates about its leadership in the industry at network's annual convention of station managers. NBC became unexpectedly vulnerable in prime time toward the end of the recent television season. [D7.]
When Romann & Tannenholz won a $3 million account to promote a set of Time-Life cookbooks through direct-response advertising, the small agency saw visions of growth and glory. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [D8.]

Labor costs of American companies are rising again. Not since the early 1980's have they gone up so fast. This time, the problem is the rising cost of benefits. Louis Uchitelle: Business Scene. [D2.]
International Minerals and Chemical, once the biggest fertilizer company in the world, has spun off several major components and bought back a substantial piece of its stock in the last five years to the applause of institutional investors. Market Place. [D4.]

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;
High Cost of Fighting Drugs Strains U.S.-Colombian Ties

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOGOTA, Colombia, June 1

 BODY:
As the cost of Colombia's war on cocaine trafficking rises, officials here are growing more impatient with the United States.
''In trade and financial matters related to the drug war, there have been more words than results,'' President Virgilio Barco Vargas said in an interview here, as he prepared to lead an economic mission to the United States.
Mr. Barco estimated that the war with the traffickers was costing Colombia $1 billion a year. The figure includes money to support army and police operations, the loss of tourism and foreign investment and the cost of repairing buildings bombed by drug traffickers. 
To offset the cost, the Colombians want better prices and better access to the American market for their chief exports: coffee, cut flowers, bananas and textiles.
On Tuesday, Mr. Barco is scheduled to meet with President Bush, largely to discuss economic issues. Colombia's Finance Minister, Luis Fernando Alarcon Mantilla, will meet with Barber B. Conable Jr., president of the World Bank.
On Monday, Colombia's Minister of Economic Development, Maria Mercedes Cuellar de Martinez, is to meet with Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative.
Many officials in this nation of 32 million people have become bitter toward the United States.
''If President Bush is offering cooperation, why doesn't it filter down to the bureaucracy?'' the economic minister asked in an interview before she left for Washington on Thursday.
Referring to a recent move by the United States trade representative to place Colombia on ''a watch list'' of unfair traders, another senior Government official said, ''Carla Hills is becoming one of the most difficult foes of the drug war.''
Colombia would like to join a group of about eight countries that use the framework of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade to resolve export-subsidy disputes with the United States. Colombia is also seeking American guarantees for a $1 billion bond issue that would ease budget problems caused by the drug war.
This week, an agreement is expected that would give Colombia a portion of the assets seized in drug raids in the United States that result from information furnished by Colombia.
 
Exports to U.S. on Rise
American diplomats here note that this year the duties on imports of Colombian flowers have been reduced, barriers to Colombian textiles have been removed and imports of Colombian tropical fruits have been promoted. Later this year, the United States is expected to increase Colombia's sugar export quota by 30 percent.
''Last year, Colombia's exports to the United States increased by 17 percent,'' one American official said. ''We think Colombia should keep an eye on the results, and not on the debate and anxiety surrounding the process. We are Colombia's best and fastest-growing market.''
On the Colombian side, anxiety is fueled by a growing sense that the drug war is proving longer and more costly than many Colombians bargained for.
''Colombia is paying a high cost,'' Cesar Gaviria, the nation's president-elect, said in his victory speech on May 27.
Without international aid and foreign reduction in cocaine consumption, Mr. Gaviria warned, ''It will be increasingly difficult for the Colombian people to understand that their sacrifice is not being matched and could be in vain.''
Tourism to Colombia's Caribbean beaches has been hit hard, said Oscar Rueda Garcia, president of the National Association of Tourism.
Since traffickers began a campaign of assassination and bombing last August, 100,000 fewer tourists have visited Colombia, costing the country $80 million, Mr. Rueda Garcia said.
Domestic air traffic is running 15 percent below normal since last August. Avianca, the state airline, has lost $15 million since last August.
In May, the Government announced a $10 million low-interest credit line to help the hundreds of bombed-out shopkeepers and homeowners. In the coastal city of Cartagena alone, a bomb at a shopping center in mid-May heavily damaged 100 stores, causing at least $2 million in losses.
In Cali, the city government recently said it would create a $300,000 ''family support fund'' to aid victims of a series of drug-related bombings.
The violence has frightened away an unknown amount of foreign investment from an economy that is considered one of the best managed in the region. With an average growth rate of 4 percent since 1986, Colombia has never skipped a payment on its foreign debt in recent years. Mr. Gaviria, an economist and former Finance Minister, has promised to continue the nation's tradition of honoring its foreign obligations.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Immediate Move by Fed Not Expected

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Despite mounting evidence that the economy is expanding at an even more sluggish pace than the tepid 1.3 percent rate in the first quarter, many credit market analysts do not expect the Federal Reserve Board to begin efforts to stimulate growth until later in the summer.
Even though the Federal Reserve runs the risk of tipping the economy into recession if it waits too long to act, analysts said the central bank is primarily concerned about inflation. Consequently, Fed governors will want to see additional confirmation that inflationary pressures are ebbing from the first quarter before they move to help shore up the economy, the analysts said.
 
Economist Sees No Action
''The Fed ought to be concerned about the economy,'' said Alan Sinai, the chief economist at the Boston Company, ''but I don't think they will do anything about it yet.'' 
The most recent - and for many, conclusive - signs of a significant slowdown were contained in the employment figures for May, which were released on Friday.
Some analysts saw some hints of modest strength in the report, including a marked uptick in the factory workweek, an indication that activity in the manufacturing sector may be picking up.
But the small positives were outweighed by the third straight month of weak overall employment growth. Excluding temporary census workers, nonfarm payroll employment rose by just 17,000 last month. Even more sobering, revised figures for March and April show that nonfarm employment for the three months actually fell by 34,000 jobs after the census workers hired during that period were excluded.
The analysts are particularly concerned with the slowdown in employment in the service sector, which has served as the wellspring of activity in the economy for much of the last decade.
Excluding census workers, service-sector employment has increased an average of about 65,000 jobs, said John R. Williams, a managing director at Bankers Trust, down from an average increase of 275,000 in the first two months of the year. For all of 1989, the service sector added an average of 200,000 jobs a month.
 
'Demands Are Waning'
''The thing that has kept us out of recession for much of the last decade has been a strong service sector,'' Mr. Williams said. ''Now, for the first time, we are seeing that those demands are waning a bit.''
Douglas Schindewolf, an economist at Smith Barney, Harris, Upham & Company, suggests in the firm's weekly credit market commentary that the slowdown in service-sector employment growth may be a ''symptom of the recently tightened credit standards for smaller businesses, which would disproportionately impact the service sector.''
With service businesses growing less rapidly and manufacturing activity remaining weak, Mr. Williams said growth in the current quarter was likely to be less than 1 percent.
Credit market participants, who thrive on signs of weakness in the economy because they usually lead to an easing in inflationary pressures, responded to the release of the employment report by sending bond yields below 8.50 percent, to their lowest levels since mid-February.
By late Friday, the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent bonds of 2020 were offered at a price to yield 8.44 percent.
With the fear of a Fed tightening all but obliterated by the employment numbers, short-term interest rates moved closer to the 8 1/4 percent rate that has been the target for the overnight rate on bank loans in the Federal funds market since mid-December.
 
Current Rate Levels Seen
With no significant economic reports to be released this week, interest rates are likely to trade around current levels for the near term, barring an unforeseen policy change by the Fed.
The next test is likely to come in the middle of the month, when key inflation reports will be released.
''We continue to feel that a continuation of the current sluggish pace of economic activity allows for bond yields to test the 8 percent level in the months ahead,'' Mr. Schindewolf said, ''particularly if the Fed is patient on the policy trigger.''
In the wake of last week's rally, the Treasury's 8 1/2 percent two-year notes were offered at a price to yield 8.30 percent.
The sharp drop in interest rates could well prompt a flood of corporate bond issues in coming weeks, corporate finance specialists said.
But the decline may also signal a slowdown in the issuance of ''put'' bonds, a financing vehicle favored by corporations during periods of interest rate volatility.
Put bonds allow investors to cash in the securities with the issuing company at 100 cents on the dollar at a specified time.
For issuers, offering the put option to investors means that issuers can shave 25 to 40 basis points off their borrowing costs, depending on the credit of the issuer, said Robert Schwartz, a financial market economist at Merrill Lynch.
Last month a total of $1.3 billion worth of put bonds were issued, a figure that just about matches the total issued during the first four months of the year, Mr. Schwartz said.
While put bonds are not new, investment bankers have added a wrinkle by tacking on additional put dates.
''Securities with multiple puts are very unusual,'' Mr. Schwartz said. ''And investors place much more importance on the secondary puts than the issuer does, because if the first put isn't exercised, the probability that the second or third will be increases exponentially. But the issuer, who is basically paying for the first put, doesn't really care.''
With participants looking - and expecting - further declines in interest rates, corporations may be far less interested in issuing put bonds in the weeks ahead.
''With this rally we have had in the market, there might not be so many,'' Mr. Schwartz said, ''because absolute rate levels for borrowers are very attractive.''

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;
Pessimism on Chinese Trade

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, June 3

 BODY:
Ever since they sailed their clipper ships to China two centuries ago with cargoes of opium, foreign traders have brimmed with optimism about the potential of the vast China market. These days, however, on the first anniversary of the bloody suppression of the democracy movement, the flush of optimism is gone, along with much of the business.
While only a handful of American corporations have closed their doors and left China since the crackdown last June 4, and a few newcomers have set up shop, many companies say business is more difficult than ever, and in some cases slower than they had expected it would be.
For most traders with sales offices in China, business is in a deep slump. 
''We feel that things just have to get better,'' said a foreign business executive in Beijing. ''But I can't say we're past the bottom of the cycle.''
 
Curbs on Imports and Credit
Executives say these hard times stem from the austerity program China began in the fall of 1988 and intensified last summer, with the Government clamping down on imports and on credit to local companies.
But beyond that, they say the violent crackdown last year and the mixed signals about economic liberalization since then have made it nearly impossible to assess China's political risk with any confidence.
Doing business in China has always been difficult, particularly because China's bureaucracy often requires myriad steps and approvals before any agreement can be signed. Collecting and confirming seemingly simple information, like the amount of a new tariff, can often lead a company through a maze of bureacratic red tape without a definitive answer.
 
Sales Have Decreased
Now China has tightened credit, cutting off funds to many Government entities and industrial enterprises that would otherwise purchase from American companies, and so sales of American products are down.
For many foreign companies, this year has been marked by other obstacles, further tainting the business climate. Some obstacles, like martial law, are being removed. But in the meantime China has recentralized its decision-making process, so that the central Government and not just the local authority must agree to certain investment and trade proposals. This has created a more difficult and confusing investment environment.
It is also unclear how long China's leaders will stall decisions on economic changes, especially in such areas as freeing prices and expanding stock ownership. Many foreign companies had pinned their hopes on a more market-oriented business environment in China. Now, greater uncertainty about the direction of economic policy and about political stability has led many companies to cancel or postpone plans for expansion in China.
 
Expansion Ruled Out
''We didn't set up any expansion plans before June 4,'' one executive said. ''But of course after June 4, we wouldn't even consider it.''
The freeze on lending by the World Bank has also meant that loans from foreign institutions are few and far between, and business for bankers has slowed so much that two of the four American bank representatives in Beijing have been reassigned outside China. For many foreign bankers who remain here, much of their time is absorbed with loan problems, primarily hotel loans that need to be renegotiated because the debtors have not been able to meet their obligations.
''I guess I was wrong because I thought things would have picked up,'' one foreign banker said. ''I've been disappointed too many times this year.''
 
Optimistic, but Restrained, Talk
Traders and corporate executives prospecting for lucrative investment possibilities have returned to China, and they fill the hotel coffee shops with optimistic, if restrained, talk of business. But the current economic recession in China has made prospects grim for new business and investment in the future.
''We're not seeing any new ideas in the pipeline,'' said John T. Frisbie, director of the United States-China Business Council in Beijing. ''For traders, it'll be lean business years unless there is a significant change in trade policy.''
In the first quarter of this year, American companies signed 65 investment contracts worth $48 million, according to statistics from China's Ministry of Foreign Economic Relations and Trade. The ministry has not publicized comparable quarterly figures for previous years, but other statistics show that the latest figure is far below the level in the past.
In the first six months of last year, for example, American corporations signed contracts worth $382 million. That was nearly three times the new investment for the same period in 1988. At the end of 1989, the total amount of American contracts for investment projects was about $4 billion, an increase of about 20 percent over the amount at the end of 1988.
 
Investing Smaller Amounts
Industry executives say there are isolated cases of American and Japanese companies that are considering large investment projects of about $100 million. But in general, companies are investing smaller amounts -an average of $700,000 in the first quarter - and negotiations on contracts sometimes have become more cumbersome and protracted during the last year.
''The Chinese are generally strapped for money, so negotiating is as hard as it ever was before, and they are trying to extract as many concessions as they can,'' said Timothy A. Steinert, an American lawyer in Beijing who helps negotiate some deals.
Mr. Steinert added that there seemed to be a rising number of commercial disputes, as American companies become more willing to go to arbitration instead of turning a blind eye to what they believe are contract violations. ''Problems that were swept under the rug before are now becoming conflicts,'' he said.
 
American Exports Down
United States trade statistics show that American exports to China had been on the rise, jumping 16 percent, to $5.7 billion, in 1989. The exports fell a percentage point during the first two months of 1990, to $876 million, compared with the same period a year ago.
Some companies say they expect the rest of the year to bring more business, and most companies in industries that China is strategically encouraging, including energy, telecommunications and transportation, say they are still closing sales. But most trade representatives say the last year has been a struggle, and they are cutting costs where they can to offset reductions in revenues.
The IBM China Corporation, for example, one of the most visible foreign companies in China, now has 100 employees in its office, compared with 127 a year ago. Many other companies have reduced their sales staffs and representatives. And most joint-venture hotels have cut down their expatriate staffing and electricity costs.
''The double whammy of economic retrenchment and political shock took the romance out of China,'' a Western diplomat said. ''It takes a lot of vision and staying power to remain here.''

HEADLINE: Business Scene;
Offsetting the Rise Of Labor Costs

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
DESPITE years of concessions from workers, the labor costs of American companies are rising again. Not since the early 1980's have they gone up so fast. But the increases do not reflect labor militancy. The problem this time isn't escalating wages, but the escalating cost of benefits - and they are not easily controlled by labor or management. That makes the impact on the nation anyone's guess.
Today's labor costs are hard to deal with at the bargaining table. The big collective-bargaining issue is wages, but they are rising only mildly, failing even to keep up with inflation. The growing burden for corporate America is in non-wage items -particularly big jumps in health insurance premiums, imposed by the insurers, and higher Social Security taxes, imposed by the Government. 
''You are really hard pressed, when you look at the numbers, to talk of wage explosion going on there,'' said Daniel J. B. Mitchell, a labor economist at the University of California at Los Angeles. ''When you back out the benefits, nothing is really going on in labor costs.''
That does not make the problem less painful, from several viewpoints. One is inflation. When economists talk of the ''inflation threat'' these days, the chief concern is that companies will raise prices to recover their higher outlays for labor. But in a sluggishly growing economy, price increases are hard to come by, even when the Labor Department's Employment Cost Index, measuring the cost of wages and benefits, goes up alarmingly. (The index for the private sector rose 5.2 percent in the year ended March 31, compared with increases of 4.6 percent and 3.8 percent, respectively, in the two previous years.) Without the option of price increases, many companies are paying for the higher labor costs out of profits. The Labor Department measures the profit from the sale of each unit produced in the nation, whether the unit is in the service sector (a newly cleaned suit, a haircut) or in manufacturing (a toy, a computer, a car). This index plunged to 112.5 last year from 128.8 in 1988. Not since 1983, a year in which the nation was emerging from a recession, have unit profits been so low.
Another alternative is to obtain more production from each worker. That increases profits by spreading the labor cost over more units; a presser is pushed to iron more suits, and the 10 workers in a toy factory to make more toys, for the same wages and benefits. This exercise in greater productivity is particularly noticeable among companies competing with foreigners - a competition that often forces them to hold down prices.
Thus, the Bank of America, with headquarters in California, where Japanese banks have a huge presence, is relying on incentives. Loan officers, for instance, get extra pay to negotiate more loans and the bank's real estate appraisers to churn out more appraisals. ''We are moving from traditional merit increases to this sort of incentive payment,'' said Norman Snell, a vice president.
Similarly, with its health insurance premiums rising 16 percent a year, the Union Camp Corporation is spending millions on machinery to increase output at mills making liner board, a material used in shipping containers. In addition, the mill workers, whose wages are rising only 2.5 percent a year, have agreed to rules changes that increase their output. Production and maintenance people, for example, now do each other's tasks.
But in a sluggish economy, productivity has its ceiling. Fewer people are taking out loans, no matter how motivated Bank of America's loan officers are. And while liner board demand is rising, it is not rising as fast as the capacity to produce it.
American corporations are trying two other routes around the labor cost burden. One is to reduce the outlay for benefits, particularly company-paid health insurance. Many companies are pushing employees toward less expensive doctors and hospitals. Some are also lobbying Congress to help bear the cost of some health care.
But if none of this slows the rise in labor costs, American companies could return to more drastic measures. The early 1980's were a period of wage givebacks and layoffs that fell heaviest on blue-collar workers. And the early 1990's could become a similar period, but this time focused on white-collar employees. White-collar wages and benefits are rising more rapidly than blue-collar compensation (10.2 percent over the last two years, versus 8.4 percent) and their average income is higher ($18.50 versus $14 an hour).
Already, reports of layoffs or hiring freezes for white-collar employees are appearing regularly -involving such giants as Caterpillar, I.B.M., Lockheed, Chrysler and H. J. Heinz. ''You don't necessarily cut functions, but you cut the number of people who do each function,'' said Donald Hilty, a Chrysler economist. ''One way to do this is to reduce the layers of white-collar management.''

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Book Industry Meets in Land of the Bookmaker

BYLINE: By EDWIN MCDOWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS, Nev., June 3

 BODY:
''Sports books'' and ''race books'' are by far the best sellers in this desert gambling mecca. Gross revenues from those ubiquitous betting parlors, and from the other legal games of chance, add more than $3 billion a year to the local economy.
By contrast, sales of books - the kind that are read - were only $16.1 million in Las Vegas bookstores in 1987, the latest year for which figures are available. But according to the Commerce Department, per-capita book sales in Las Vegas are above the national average. 
''The national average was $57.15 in 1987,'' said William Lofquist, the specialist in book sales for the Commerce Department, ''and the Las Vegas average was $64.84.''
In this town, book talk is unlikely to replace talk of jackpots, of hot hands or bad luck, but book talk has been plentiful here since Saturday, when the 90th annual convention and trade exhibit of the American Booksellers Association opened at the Las Vegas Convention Center, with 24,000 booksellers, publishers and vendors registering for the four-day event.
 
Pleased to Have Event
Las Vegas booksellers say they are happy to have the convention here, but only the half-dozen or so adult bookshops on or near Las Vegas Boulevard (the casino-lined ''Strip'') cater to the convention trade or the city's 17 million annual visitors. In fact, the only traditional bookstore on the Strip, a Waldenbooks outlet, is tucked away on the second floor of a fashionable shopping mall, far from the madding gambling crowd.
''There's a tremendous amount of cash in this town, left behind by visitors, and there are people with money to spend on books,'' said Danny Greenspun. Gambling that they will spend some of it in an independent bookstore about 15 minutes from the Strip, Mr. Greenspun and his wife, Robin, recently opened The Culture Dog, a literary bookstore and gallery in Green Valley, just outside the Las Vegas city limits.
''I was annoyed there wasn't a Rizzoli, Brentano's or Scribner's here, so I opened one,'' Mr. Greenspun said. His father, the late Hank Greenspun, founded The Las Vegas Sun, one of the town's two daily newspapers.
The Culture Dog is not yet a Rizzoli, Brentano's or Scribner's, nor does it have the selection equal to Waldenbooks & More, one of that chain's superstores a couple of miles away. But the Culture Dog carries an impressive list of fiction, including fiction from small literary presses, and a good selection of children's books and books on art and architecture.
While Mr. Greenspun plans to expand, Dana McKay, another Las Vegas bookseller, has gradually retrenched - to just one store, from five stores in the 1970's.
''Once the national chains came in,'' she said, referring to the two B. Dalton stores and four Waldenbooks, ''we couldn't compete with their discounts.''
Ms. McKay opened her first bookstore here in 1955, with $500 worth of books given on credit by a wholesaler. ''I started my store because I couldn't find anything to read,'' she said. ''There was no bookstore in town and the only library was in the basement of our City Hall.''
The biggest of the city's three stores devoted to books on gambling, Gamblers Book Shop, carries thousands of new titles and about 2,000 used. ''We also carry novels if they have even a slight gambling theme or if they're about the Mafia,'' said Howard Schwartz, the store's marketing director.
Housed in a red-brick building at a busy intersection a few miles north of most of the gaming action, Gamblers Book Shop consists of two plain rooms filled with books arranged in dozens of categories - poker to casino management to sports betting. The latter category is growing so fast that the store carries more than 60 titles just about betting on football.
''We're 80 percent mail order, only 20 percent walk-in traffic,'' Mr. Schwartz said. ''We publish our own books and we mail up to 75,000 catalogues all over the world.''
The store was started in 1964 by John Luckman, a former dealer and manager at casinos on the Strip, and his wife, Edna. (Mr. Luckman died in 1987.) Asked if she gambles, Mrs. Luckman wrinkled her nose in disapproval. ''No, and we don't encourage others to gamble,'' she said. ''But if they do, that's their business. And we hope the books in here will help them.''
Las Vegas has many religious bookstores - at least seven Christian evangelical stores, five catering to members of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints and one that sells Jewish books.
''Our clientele is families who live here,'' said Glen Hales, owner of two of the Mormon bookstores. ''As far as I know, we've never had a gambler, repentent or not, come into our stores.''
Gray Crampton, an owner of the two Christian Supply Center book stores, said his stores carry a selection similar to that of other evangelical Christian stores: Bibles, religious self-help, even novels with Christian themes. While it does not carry books about gambling, it does sell books about overcoming various addictions.
While sales in Mr. Campton's stores are largely unaffected by tourism, it seemed certain that sales would surge last summer, when more than 18,000 members of the Southern Baptist Convention held their annual meeting here.
But the bonanza never occurred. Mr. Crampton said the delegates brought their own books and set up a bookstore in the convention center. K Martd(Waldenbooks)

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
For NBC, 'Party's Over' at Its Affiliates Meeting

BYLINE: By BILL CARTER

 BODY:
For the first time in five years, NBC is facing questions about its leadership in the industry at the annual convention of the managers of its affiliated stations.
''We all know the party's over,'' said Betty Hudson, senior vice president of corporate communications for NBC. ''But that doesn't mean we can't still have some good parties.'' 
NBC became unexpectedly vulnerable in prime time toward the end of the recent television season, after dominating it for five years.
Pier Mapes, the president of NBC's network division, said the affiliate managers, who begin three days of meetings in Washington today, would probably raise questions about the May ratings sweep period, in which NBC came close to losing its lead to CBS.
He said the affiliates, ''accustomed to our hitting home runs in May,'' were likely to express concerns about the trend in prime time. NBC hopes to reassure them with buoyant descriptions oif its schedule for next fall.
 
Deflecting Criticism
During the last five years, NBC executives were able to depend on their prime-time dominance to deflect potential criticism from affiliates in other areas, most prominently the continuing weak performance of the netwrok news division. Affiliate managers have questioned the leadership of Michael Gartner, the news division's president, at previous meetings.
This year the questions about news may be more intense, Mr. Mapes said, because of the news division's ragged performance on the night of the Northern California earthquake, the inability of NBC evening newscast to escape last place in the national ratings and, most pointedly, the ratings collapse of the ''Today'' program.
''There is be a lot of emotion about 'Today,' mostly because of the economics,'' Mr. Mapes said. More than half of the commercial time in ''Today'' is sold by the local stations. When ratings for ''Today'' plunge, local stations are hurt just as badly as the network. 24-Hour News Service Mr. Mapes said Mr. Gartner would concede that the network had made errors in its handling of ''Today'' and the earthquake. But these concessions will be balanced by praise for the network's performance at the Berline wall and by outlines of changes on ''Today,'' including the addition of three cast members.
NBC News will also disclose plans for a 24-hour news service for broadcast stations. Mr. Mapes said the proposed news service should eventually be a serious competitor to the services that stations currently buy from CNN and other satellite news systems.
In addition, he said, Mr. Gartner will disucss plans to use Jane Pauley more extensively on the ''Nightly News,'' a move that many affiliates have urged.
NBC's affiliate convention, usually held on the West Coast, has been moved to Washington to underscore legislative issues affecting broadcasters.
The two main issues, Mr. Mapes said, will be what the stations consider to be unfair opportunities granted to cable operators, at the expense of broadcasters, and Federal restrictions on the networks' financial ownership of programs.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
A New Formula in Hungary: Speed Service and Grow Rich

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

DATELINE: BUDAPEST

 BODY:
The road to riches in Eastern Europe? A former Hungarian rock musician, Gabor J. Varszegi, found an answer: hire young people untainted by Communist work experience, pay them four times the going rate and then offer customers a one-hour film-developing service instead of the usual monthlong wait.
In Hungary, like other Eastern European nations, where service has traditionally ranged from sullen to nonexistent, Mr. Varszegi's formula has proved to be both revolutionary and highly profitable.
Today the trim, bearded 44-year-old entrepreneur is one of Hungary's richest men, worth an estimated $10 million or more. His fortune might not make him John Paul Getty, but in a nation just emerging from Communism, where the average annual salary is $1,800 at current exchange rates, he is surely a tycoon.
He drives a large black Mercedes and the walls of his office in a mansion overlooking Budapest are bedecked with Chagall and Dali lithographs. 
Envying his success, many Hungarian businesses are seeking to copy his bold, unorthodox style. And some Western observers say Eastern Europe could lift itself out of its economic morass in a year, instead of a decade, if it had a few thousand executives with the skills and market instincts of Mr. Varszegi (pronounced var-SAY-gee).
But in Hungary, he is resented as well as praised. In fact, he refused to have his picture taken for fear that his family might become targets for criminals.
''In Eastern Europe, the people don't like rich people,'' he said. ''They were taught for 40 years that wealth is bad.''
Mr. Varszegi picked up many of his business ideas in the United States, where he traded diamonds and machinery in the early 1980's. Returning to Hungary in 1985, he and two partners invested $200,000 to set up Eastern Europe's first one-hour photo minilab. The business was an instant hit, earning $200,000 in the first year.
Since then, his empire has grown steadily and branched into new fields. Today it includes seven photo-developing shops, two contact lens stores, and factories that make contact lenses, leaded glass, picture frames and commemorative coins. Now he dreams of someday becoming the first Eastern European to take his company public through a share offering in the United States. He said his company, Fotex Ltd., earned $4 million last year on sales of $10 million.
Impressed by Mr. Varszegi's business skills, several American corporations have asked him to be their man in Hungary. He is Eastman Kodak's exclusive distributor here, and he is negotiating with the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company to distribute its Scotch-Brite scouring pads and Post-It notes.
 
'A Western-Minded Hungarian'
Mr. Varszegi, a millionaire who often wears faded blue jeans, does not hesitate to give advice to budding entrepreneurs or foreign investors.
''To succeed in business in Hungary you have to be a Western-minded Hungarian,'' he said in his roomy office. ''You have to understand the people here, their way of life, and the day-to-day changes, but you also have to be a Western-style entrepreneur.''
For his part, Mr. Varszegi has transplanted American business ideas to Hungary's badly neglected service sector. He saw that it took six months for Hungarians to obtain contact lenses. So last year he invested more than $1 million in computer-controlled, precision cutting machines - Hungary's first contact-lens equipment. Now customers can have their eyes examined in the morning and pick up lenses in the afternoon.
''What makes him so successful is he knows what the customer wants,'' said Horst Escher, Kodak's assistant general manager for Eastern Europe.
When Kodak was searching for a distributor in Hungary three years ago it chose Mr. Varszegi because he seemed the most entrepreneurial of the candidates. He was buying huge sheets of Fuji film wholesale, cutting and processing them into rolls and selling them under the name Tokyocolor. It quickly became Hungary's most popular film made outside of the Soviet bloc.
 
A Boon for Kodak
Thanks to him, sales of Kodak film jumped from 30,000 rolls in 1987 to more than a million last year. He has made Kodak far more popular than Fuji or Agfa even though he charges 60 percent more than Kodak's competitors. He has also made Kodak batteries the best seller among Western brands.
''If you start to sell a product that is unknown here and you advertise it well, you have a good chance of building up a market,'' he said. Kodak is now talking to him about assembling its cameras in Hungary.
Mr. Varszegi's approach may be old hat to Westerners but it is welcome in Eastern Europe: fast and friendly service, convenient locations and emphasis on quality. Fotex shops, often on main streets and in subway stations, are among the few places in Budapest, other than at McDonald's, where service comes with a smile. Unlike the many dingy brown and gray stores of Budapest, Fotex shops are spick-and-span, vibrant yellow and brightly lighted. Some are open round the clock.
''It's great that there is a store like Fotex close by,'' said Zsuzsa Zsiga, a law student. ''It might charge a little more than other places, but it's good that we can have our pictures back in a few hours.'' The stores also sell wooden picture frames that Mr. Varszegi manufactures.
 
The Pay Is Good
He is known for unorthodox personnel policies as well. To win loyalty and instill motivation, Mr. Varszegi pays his employees more than $550 a month on average. Hungary's average wage is $150.
His employees say they work hard for their money. ''To work here, you have to be young, pretty and quick on your feet,'' said Victoria Szomolanyi, a 24-year-old manager in a photo development shop. ''You have to smile and be polite. You also have to be able to think independently. Sometimes there are large lines out the door, and you have to make a lot of quick decisions.''
The average age of his work force is 23. He refuses to hire people who held jobs under Communism, which he said encouraged slacking off. ''I hire young people because they haven't inherited the bad habits of older workers,'' he said.
Mr. Varszegi said he developed his knack for business as a rock musician in the mid-1960's. He was bass guitarist as well as business manager for Gemini, one of Hungary's most popular groups, and bargained with Communist apparatchiks about fees.
''Back then, the only private businessmen in Eastern Europe were rock musicians,'' he said.
A traditional business education will not guarantee success in Eastern Europe, he said, adding: ''It's not possible to learn in Harvard Business School how to do business in Czechoslovakia, Bulgaria, Romania or Hungary today. In Czechoslovakia they don't even know what rules will exist two weeks from now.'' Even so, Mr. Varszegi is looking to open Fotex shops in Prague.
 
'Find the Right Partner'
His advice for Western executives interested in Eastern Europe is ''find the right partner, someone who is able to do what you do.'' 3M seems to have followed his advice. Mr. Varszegi will soon begin processing, packaging and marketing Scotch-Brite.
Horst Flemming, head of 3M's Eastern European operations, said: ''You just don't go into Hungary tomorrow and identify distributors. You have to find a person who you think has the talent, whatever it takes to get you good distribution. You gamble on him and trust him to distribute your product. We chose Mr. Varszegi because he has a track record.''
One big problem for Mr. Varszegi has been the limits that the Hungarian Government, worried about trade deficits, has placed on imports of consumer goods. Mr. Varszegi has navigated around this obstacle by exporting picture frames to reduce his company's trade deficit.
As part of that effort, he acquired control late last year of an export-oriented glass company, Ajka, which supplies fine pieces to Cartier and Tiffany. Mr. Varszegi has introduced more modern designs and opened several Ajka stores so the company can sell directly to the consumer, bypassing the middleman.
''We've earned as much in the first quarter as the company did all last year,'' he said.
He has one final piece of advice for Western investors: ''Now is the time to build up in Hungary; there are marvelous opportunities,'' he said.

HEADLINE: After the Summit;
GORBACHEV, ENDING U.S. TRIP, MEETS SOUTH KOREA LEADER, WHO SEES A RENEWAL OF TIES

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, June 4

 BODY:
President Roh Tae Woo of South Korea met here today with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union and said later that the two nations would establish diplomatic relations in the future.
Mr. Gorbachev who left for the Soviet Union shortly after the meeting with the South Korean leader, told reporters as he got into his car that it was important to improve relations with all countries in the region but did not say anything specifically about establishing formal diplomatic relations.
Mr. Roh said at a news conference, ''The cold-war ice on the Korean peninsula has now begun to crack.'' He said he expected his conversations with Mr. Gorbachev ultimately to lead to Korean reunification.
Mr. Roh provided no details on the timetable for diplomatic recognition but said Mr. Gorbachev had told him that ''the meeting signified that progress has already been made along those lines.'' 
Asked after the meeting whether the Soviet Union and Korea had agreed to normalize relations, Mr. Gorbachev answered: ''Let the fruit grow ripe, and when it grows ripe, we shall eat it.''
At a news conference after the meeting, Mr. Roh said through an interpreter that ''normal bilateral relations will be restored after 86 years,'' a reference to the period before the Russo-Japanese War of 1904-5, when czarist Russia had relations with a unified Korea. After Russia's defeat in that war, Korea became a virtual protectorate of Japan, which eventually annexed it in 1910.
 
Step to Reunification, Roh Says
The South Korean leader said that he and Mr. Gorbachev had discussed the future of the peninsula and military and economic relations and that they ''didn't find any basic difference in views about these matters.''
Citing imminent German reunification, Mr. Roh said that Korea was ''the only nation on earth still divided by cold-war policy.'' But after the meeting with Mr. Gorbachev, he said, ''We expect this to be the first major step toward a peaceful and unified Korea.''
It was the first face-to-face meeting between leaders of the Soviet Union and South Korea, which have been ideological and military adversaries since the division of the Korean peninsula after World War II.
Any improvement of relations between Moscow and Seoul is sure to further anger North Korea, the Soviet ally, which has expressed concern even over the initial report of Mr. Gorbachev's plan to meet with Mr. Roh.
The news conference in the Fairmont Hotel, at which Mr. Roh's remarks were read in English by an interpreter from a prepared statement, was attended not only by scores of reporters but also by Donald Gregg, the United States Ambassador to South Korea.
 
Achievement for Roh
For Mr. Roh, the meeting with Mr. Gorbachev was a significant achievement. The South Korean President's prestige has been battered in recent months by student strikes and a slowdown of the economy.
But the meeting here, a product of a two-year-old policy of reaching out to Eastern European nations, put Mr. Roh at the center of the world's stage - a player, along with Mr. Gorbachev and Mr. Bush, in this week of high-level meetings.
The South Korean delegation arrived here ready to offer the Soviets a quid pro quo: Let us help you rebuild your collapsed economy as a trade partner in exchange for your help reunifying our divided country.
 
Hoping to Isolate the North
If the Soviet Union establishes formal ties with South Korea, senior Government officials said, then North Korea may feel hopelessly isolated and forced to reckon with its neighbor on the other side of the 38th parallel.
A senior South Korean Government official said the North Korean Government's refusal to recognize Seoul was one of the final vestiges of the cold war - ''the last island in a sea of change.'' A warming of relations between Seoul and Moscow ''would give North Korea a chance to rethink their position and become more reasonable in accepting change,'' the official said.
Mr. Roh made the same point in a statement to the South Korean people before his departure for San Francisco. ''The waves of reform now reshaping the world have started rushing toward northeast Asia as well,'' he said. ''I am confident that the cultivation of Republic of Korea-Soviet Union relations will contribute not only to the common prosperity of both countries but also to peace in Asia, especially on the Korean peninsula.''
Mr. Roh set out to establish ties with Warsaw Pact countries at the time of the 1988 Summer Olympic Games in Seoul, when South Korea came out onto the world stage as a nascent economic power. The North Korean Government called for a boycott of the Games, but only Cuba and Albania stayed away -a victory for the Seoul Government that eased the way for diplomatic relationships with a half-dozen Eastern European nations.
Seoul and Moscow have not had an official relationship since the division of Korea after World War II, but even these ideological and military adversaries began moving closer after the Games. Trade offices and consular relations were established, and cultural exchanges grew. Last year, bilateral trade reached $600 million, more than a 100 percent increase from 1988, South Korean officials said.
The prospect of formal relations between South Korea and the Soviet Union is also expected to put pressure on Japan to rush to Mr. Gorbachev's side as a trade partner.
''There is the thorny issue of the four northern territories,'' a senior South Korean official said, referring to the islands north of Japan that the Soviet Union has occupied since the end of World War II. ''But after seeing what Korea is doing, I am sure Japan will not want to miss the bus.''
The South Korean President arrived here on Sunday morning, about 12 hours before his Soviet counterpart, and was greeted at the airport by Mayor Art Agnos and George P. Shultz, the former Secretary of State, who is now a professor of international economics at Stanford University.
Mr. Shultz, who worked with Soviet officials during the Reagan years, was said to have been instrumental in both Mr. Gorbachev's visit to the Bay Area and his meeting with Mr. Roh. Mr. Roh met later on Sunday with Mr. Shultz and also with former President Ronald Reagan, here for a breakfast today with the Gorbachevs.
While South Korea and the Soviet Union have been steadily moving toward each other, the meeting between the two leaders was hastily planned, announced last Thursday as Mr. Gorbachev was beginning three days of talks with President Bush in Washington. By then, Mr. Gorbachev's itinerary here was already crowded, but Mr. Roh was shoehorned in.
 
City Officials Scramble
When San Francisco officials learned that Mr. Roh was coming, they scrambled to accommodate another high-level visitor and entourage. Quickly, a third national flag was hung outside the Fairmont Hotel here, where Mr. Roh would join the Soviet traveling party and Ronald and Nancy Reagan.
Dozens of South Korean journalists also flocked to San Francisco. By the time the South Korean Government had set up a press room for them at the hotel, separate from the room used by Soviet and American journalists, the telephone company had run out of equipment. Telephones were rented and connected to A.T.&T. lines.
Now that his meeting with Mr. Gorbachev has ended, Mr. Roh is scheduled to travel to Washington to brief President Bush.

HEADLINE: After the Summit;
Gorbachev Urges Major Changes In the World's System of Alliances

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, June 4

 BODY:
President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union ended an exhausting transcontinental visit to the United States today with an appeal for a radically changed system of global alliances.
''Alliances have been built on a selective and in fact discriminatory basis,'' Mr. Gorbachev said in a speech at Stanford University, referring to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the Warsaw Pact, which arose from the cold war.
''They were based on setting countries against each other,'' he continued. ''They divided countries and peoples much more than they united them.'' [Excerpts from the speech are on page A16.] Non-Military Roles Stressed Rather than strengthening defense, he asserted, alliances of the future should be designed to foster an international unity that would ''protect the environment, combat hunger, diseases, drug addiction and ignorance.'' 
The Soviet leader seemed to be underlining once more his insistence that NATO be supplanted by a new pan-European security organization. Rejecting that idea, the West contends that a unified Germany should belong to a redesigned NATO. Neither side budged from its stand during three days of detailed talks between Mr. Gorbachev and President Bush last week.
''The cold war is now behind us,'' Mr. Gorbachev told 1,700 students, teachers and administrators in Stanford's Memorial Auditorium. ''Let us not wrangle over who won it.''
 
Running Behind Schedule
He appealed, in a state that is heavily dependent on military contracts, for the demilitarization of the Soviet and American economies.
Mr. Gorbachev and his wife, Raisa, departed for the Soviet Union late tonight. The Soviet leader's schedule had been running behind ever since he decided to sleep in this morning to recover from the grueling schedule that took him from Washington to Minneapolis and then to San Francisco on Sunday.
After the speech at Stanford, he sped back to San Francisco for a late lunch with West Coast business leaders, including computer makers and the manufacturer of Levi's, a status symbol among Soviet young people. Soviet officials said they hoped the meeting would produce investments to help their staggering economy.
A reunion for the Gorbachevs with former President Ronald Reagan and a precedent-shattering meeting with President Roh Tae Woo of South Korea were also accomplished before their departure.
''I always wanted to come here, and I never had the chance,'' Mr. Gorbachev said to reporters just before he flew out of San Francisco. ''You're fortunate to live here. If I were President Bush, I would levy a tax on you. Fantastic!''
Although he and Mr. Bush failed to resolve their differences over the place of a reunified Germany in a restructured Europe or to settle their dispute over Lithuania, Mr. Gorbachev took home with him a package of major agreements, including a trade deal that he had avidly sought, as well as what he termed a ''qualitatively different relationship'' with Mr. Bush.
In addition, the Soviet leader took with him enough cheers, hugs, medals, handshakes, honors and congratulations to last several lifetimes. Beleaguered at home, he was hailed here by President Donald Kennedy of Stanford as ''the architect of a great world transformation.''
Mr. Gorbachev responded with generous praise for Stanford, for the work of its scientists on disarmament and, indeed, for the whole state of California. He noted that the United Nations was founded in this city 45 years ago, said that ''the ideas and technologies of tomorrow are born here in California'' and quoted the 19th-century Russian writer Aleksandr I. Herzen as describing the Pacific Ocean as ''the Mediterranean of the future.''
The Soviet leader said his second summit conference with Mr. Bush had helped move the United States and the Soviet Union ''toward a new world,'' but he also sounded a note of caution about the relationship.
''I am under no illusions as to the possibility of a faster rapprochement or convergence of our two societies,'' he said. ''They are quite different. For many years, they were developing in different directions. They will probably never be fully alike. Indeed, there is no need for that.''
 
'Everyone Must Change'
''For a new type of progress throughout the world to become a reality, everyone must change,'' Mr. Gorbachev added. ''Tolerance is the alpha and omega of a new world order.''
In San Francisco, Mr. Gorbachev conceded that he had made mistakes in the early stages of Soviet economic reform, and he told the business leaders that there were ample opportunities for Soviet-American economic cooperation, including the use of heavy Soviet rockets to launch American satellites and joint efforts to search for oil and other materials. He said:
''You are wondering: Could investment in the Soviet Union be a trap? Could you lose money? I think risk is good both in business and politics, but adventurism is bad. The Soviet leadership seeks change in a careful way, a balanced way.''
 
Many Foul-Ups in Bay Area
The Gorbachev visit to the Bay Area, which was conceived only a few weeks ago, was marred by many technological and logistical foul-ups. Schedules and itineraries were changed repeatedly, without notice, and the Soviet leader ran late all day.
At the request of the Gorbachevs, Mr. and Mrs. Reagan arrived at the residence of the Soviet Consul General, Valentin Kamenev, a half-hour late. After an exhausting Sunday, which began with a White House news conference, ended here almost 17 hours later and included a tumultuous stop in Minnesota, the Soviet leader and his wife decided to sleep in, according to Joseph V. Reed, the American chief of protocol.
Mr. Reagan and Mr. Gorbachev spent about 45 minutes together in the consular residence, a red-brick building with roses climbing up its facade. Their wives, whose relationship seemed distinctly frosty when the Reagans were in the White House, seemed to get on better this time, standing on a balcony overlooking the earthquake-damaged Marina district and the Golden Gate Bridge for about five minutes, drinking in the magnificent view and holding hands.
 
'A Great Misunderstanding'
Afterward, Mrs. Reagan spoke of ''a great misunderstanding'' about her earlier relationship with Mrs. Gorbachev and said their meeting here had been ''just fine.''
''When we first met,'' Mrs. Reagan said, ''it was a very difficult time. We were plowing new ground.''
Asked whether he approved of the trade agreement that Mr. Bush signed with Mr. Gorbachev on Friday, which has engendered some Congressional criticism, the former President replied: ''I'm not going to discuss any of those things, but President Bush was a major part of what we were doing during those eight years. He wants the same solution we want to these problems.''
Mr. and Mrs. Gorbachev gave no appraisal of the occasion, climbing immediately into their black ZIL limousine for the drive to Stanford, about 40 miles south of San Francisco.
 
Shouts of 'Gorby! Gorby!'
As they had in Washington and in Minneapolis, crowds shouted ''Gorby! Gorby!'' as the Soviet leader strolled across the Stanford campus, pausing now and then to study its low-lying neo-Romanesque and Mission buildings with flat, red-tile roofs.
He stopped to speak with and to embrace several people, including a woman in a vividly striped dress and a man in a workman's flat cloth cap. They and thousands of others had waited for hours in the shade of eucalyptus trees, and he plunged several times into crowds to shake hands.
At the Stanford Business School, Mr. Gorbachev met with a group of students and faculty members to discuss management techniques. On his left sat former Secretary of State George P. Shultz, a professor at the school who played a major role in persuading Mr. Gorbachev to visit Stanford and also helped set up the Soviet leader's meeting with Mr. Roh of South Korea.
After his speech, Mr. Shultz gave Mr. Gorbachev a 1921 Soviet poster, from the collection of revolutionary documents and memorabilia at the Hoover Institution at Stanford. For reasons that have not been fully explained, the Soviet leader canceled plans to visit the institution.
Small groups of anti-Gorbachev demonstrators - Armenian-Americans, supporters of the Baltic republics, Korean-Americans in traditional dress and others - turned up at every stop, but the police kept them at a considerable distance from the official party.

HEADLINE: Congress Looks Anew at Ties With Vietnam

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 4

 BODY:
Pushed by Vietnam War veterans, Congress is reopening a debate on normalizing economic and diplomatic relations with Hanoi.
The opening salvo is a piece of legislation introduced by Representative Howard L. Berman, Democrat of California, that would remove legal restrictions on travel to Vietnam and four other nations - Cambodia, Cuba, Libya and North Korea.
Veterans groups around the country have testified in favor of the legislation and have begun to urge their members to write supporting letters to their representatives in Congress. The legislation is expected to be considered by the House Foreign Affairs Committee before the July 4 recess. 
''This is the first step towards Congress's getting over its trauma over Vietnam,'' said Representative Sam Gejdenson, Democrat of Connecticut, chairman of the House Subcommittee on International Economic Policy and Trade. ''There is no reason we can't review our relationship. Veterans groups are leading the charge.''
Mr. Gejdenson's subcommittee, which is handling the travel legislation, is at the forefront of Congressional efforts to normalize relations. In a small gesture toward that end, the subcommittee recently removed language in PL-480 Food for Peace legislation that prohibited the sale of American food and other commodities to Vietnam.
Since losing the Vietnam War 15 years ago, the United States has not pursued normal diplomatic relations with Hanoi. The Bush Administration has said it is not opposed to normalizing ties once a complete removal of Vietnamese military forces from Cambodia can be verified.
The Vietnamese invaded Cambodia, then ruled by the Khmer Rouge, in 1978 and installed the Hun Sen Government. Vietnam announced the withdrawal of its troops last September, but persistent reports have indicated that elite Vietnamese combat units still back the Hun Sen Government in its war against a guerrilla insurgency consisting mainly of the Khmer Rouge.
A State Department official who deals with East Asian affairs said that now would be a bad time to send friendly signals to Hanoi, given the stepped-up diplomatic activity to resolve the Cambodian conflict.
''We need leverage'' to make sure Vietnamese forces leave Cambodia, he said. ''It would be unwise to act unilaterally to satisfy Vietnamese demands.'' The United States would like to see a coalition, backed by an international peacekeeping force, replace the Hun Sen Government.
Currently, under the Trading With the Enemy Act, it is illegal for commercial or non-profit tour groups to organize or advertise trips to Vietnam. Individuals may travel legally to Vietnam on their own. But without the help of people experienced in dealing with the Vietnamese, they often have trouble arranging visas and hotels.
Allied with the Bush Administration opposing the Berman bill, which is called the Free Trade in Ideas Act, are Cuban exile groups opposed to liberalizing travel to Cuba.
A growing number of legislators disagree with the Administration position. Senator Mark O. Hatfield, Republican of Oregon, said that liberalizing travel and trade with Vietnam made sense ''from every angle'' because it would not only help moderate Hanoi's foreign and domestic policies but would also enable relatives of Americans missing in action to visit Vietnam to press their search for information.
Mr. Hatfield said the Berman bill ''could be a triggering action toward normalizing relationships because it does have the support of those who in previous times were against normalization, like the veterans groups.''
Don Mills, from Akron, Ohio, told the committee: ''Twenty years ago, if I didn't go to Vietnam I was threatened with jail, and now if I want to go to Vietnam I am threatened with jail.''
Mr. Mills has helped organize tours of Vietnam for more than 200 veterans. The Treasury Department has warned him that he may be prosecuted unless he halts his activity. A letter sent to Mr. Mills from the Treasury Department said he could face up to 10 years' imprisonment and a fine of up to $50,000.

HEADLINE: Debt-Burdened Zambians Find Life Costly

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KASAMA, Zambia

 BODY:
Judith Chileshe was looking forward to outfitting her children for school on a rare shopping pilgrimage to this provincial capital more than 100 miles from her village. But when she arrived with her $20-a-month salary from a part-time teaching job, she was confronted by New York City prices.
Notebooks of inferior quality cost $1 and folding umbrellas - the kind found for $2 on Times Square - are $5. Blankets, which boarding students must provide for sleeping on the floor, are $32; towels are $15. 
Mrs. Chileshe, who is 35 years old, shook her head in disbelief. Her teen-age daughter would have to make do with her threadbare blanket. After persevering on the towel shelf in the Government store, she found a skimpy one for $7.
Mrs. Chileshe's cheerless shopping expedition is a reflection of Zambia's state-run economy, one of Africa's most mismanaged. Once buttressed by copper and considered one of post-colonial Africa's most promising economies, Zambia has been going downhill fast for the last decade.
As copper prices fell and production dropped, President Kenneth D. Kaunda piled up enormous international debts and heavily subsidized food for urban dwellers at the expense of farmers who grew it.
Now, as the Government has been forced to remove subsidies on food, Zambians find urban life impossibly expensive. Many are retreating to their home villages to grow crops; once there, they find that the most basic standard of living has also regressed.
A bus to Kasama once ran regularly from Mrs. Chileshe's village, Chakombe. But the Government cut the service, and now, unless villagers are lucky enough to get a ride with the local missionaries, they must walk for four days. Even for the 20-mile journey to Chinsali, a fleck on the map with several stores and an unsanitary hospital - but at least a doctor - the bus was abandoned. Chakombe village, never wired for electricity, is now virtually isolated in the northeastern corner of Zambia, in Mr. Kaunda's home district.
Zambians are beginning to grumble ever more loudly about the price they are having to pay for Mr. Kaunda's economic policies in the 26 years he has been President.
Last year, Mr. Kaunda finally agreed to impose austerity measures approved by the International Monetary Fund. Among them, devaluations of the kwacha in the last nine months have made everyday items prohibitive for most. Last year, the inflation rate topped 100 percent.
Some $1.2 billion in arrears to the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund and with only eight million people, Zambia has one of the highest debt per population ratios in the world. Because of the arrears, the country is not eligible for badly needed capital from either institution.
Economic mismanagement affects even the smallest things. Mrs. Chileshe's teen-age daughter Peggy did not take exams last semester: there was no paper in the school for the exams to be written on. The absence of exam results was understood but not helpful when Peggy wanted to prove herself to the local missionaries as a worthwhile candidate for further study.
Spending on education dropped in Zambia from 19 percent of the budget in 1972 to 8 percent in 1987, even though the number of students has doubled. Statistics like those are prompting many Zambians to remark that life has deteriorated since independence in 1964.
It is hard for the villagers of Chakombe to see how foreign aid from well-meaning Western sources has made much difference. At the main provincial hospital in Kasama, there has been no water for three years. Patients usually sleep two to a bed, with others on the floor. They must arrange with relatives or friends to have water brought to them.
Despite the difficulties in Chakombe, the village headman, Henry Chakobe, is both resigned and philosophical. ''It is cheaper than in towns,'' he said, referring to life in his village. ''I have enough land to grow the things I want. I've got things to help us: firewood for cooking and grass for thatching our houses. And we live in peace.''
