HEADLINE: After the Summit;
Gorbachev at Stanford: Excerpts From Address

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's address at Stanford University yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of Cable News Network. Mr. Gorbachev spoke through an interpreter.
 
Imagining Destiny
It is appropriate now to ponder the destinies of the world since it was here in San Francisco that the United Nations was founded 45 years ago. I think it is very symbolic that it is this sunny city that was selected as the place to proclaim the foundation, the establishment of this organization, whose efficiency we need very much.
Let us look at the conclusions drawn at that time right after a horrible war. The United Nations was set up to, I quote, ''maintain peace and security and remove the political, economic and social causes of war; to settle disputes in conformity with the principles of justice and international law; to promote relations among nations based on the principle of equal rights and self-determination of peoples; a respect for human rights and for fundamental freedoms without distinction as to race, sex, language or religion.'' Marvelous words, a marvelous appeal, but, alas, it is only now that we have come closer to addressing the tasks in practical terms. 
It is only now that international politics is really starting to adjust itself to these ideas and principles. And all of us have felt how much we need the United Nations if we really are to move toward a new world, and new kind of relationships in the world in the interest of all countries. . . .
 
New Winds in Asia
For a long time, the Pacific was a theater of confrontations and the arms race. Located on its opposite shores, our two nations found themselves on the opposite sides of the barricades of Asian revolutions. But new winds are now blowing in Asia. It has been developing dynamically according to its own logic, setting impressive examples of economic efficiency and international interaction.
The Japanese, the Koreans, the Chinese and other Asian peoples have lessons for the entire world to learn, including lessons for us. And for you. And to avoid finding ourselves on the sidelines in the Pacific as well as, of course, in Europe, we ought to think about the speediest way to abolish political-military rivalry.
Let us think about the future. Our two countries have more than enough reasons to be partners in building it, in shaping new security structures in Europe and in the Asian Pacific region. And also in the making of a truly global economy, indeed, and the creation of a new civilization. . . .
 
War Without Winners
It is important to see the thrust of what is happening as we move toward a world without wars; a world of equality and freedom. In our cooperation to build a better future, I will take, as a point of departure, the fact that the cold war is now behind us.
And let us not wrangle over who won it - who won the cold war.
There can be no winners in the cold war, just like in a nuclear war. This truth has already been established. Both our countries know that. So any kind of talk about the cold war being useful to some countries, I think, is just political cheating and irresponsibility. Our two countries, who know the burden of the arms race during the cold war, know that particularly well. The cold war was nurturing our political thinking, our political approaches, our political analysis and the whole of the political choice. . . .
 
A Novel Alliance
Each of our two countries bears its share of responsibility for the fact that the postwar period in the history of mankind took on the character of an exhausting and dangerous confrontation. It is now, and it is quite logical to say that, that it is now our common responsibility to make sure that the mechanisms of East-West military confrontation are dismantled as soon as possible. . . .
We are witnessing a revolution of international relations toward increasingly open and mass-scale communication. And this greatly increases the role of creative and positive policies. But equally, it raises the price of mistakes - the price we must pay for adherence to outdated dogmas, routine and old thinking. . . .
I'm convinced that we stand on the threshold of revising the concept of alliance building. Until now, alliances have been built on a selective, and in fact discriminatory, basis.
 
The Common Interest
They were based on setting countries against each other. They divided countries and peoples much more than they united them. This system was perfected during the years of the cold war, producing the twin antipodes of the North Atlantic Alliance and the Warsaw Pact. But we are approaching a time when the very principle of alliance-building should become different. It should mean unity to create conditions for a life worthy of a human being, protect the environment, combat hunger, diseases, drug addiction and ignorance.
It is in the common interest of our two countries and nations not to fight this trend toward new cooperation, but rather to promote it, and I think that both the United States and the Soviet Union, if they understand the need for this, and if they really work together, can contribute in a decisive way to moving our entire, placing our entire civilization on the road of genuinely peaceful development. . . .

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: After the Summit: Reporter's Notebook;
A Communist at Home With the Capitalist Elite

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: STANFORD, Calif., June 4

 BODY:
When Nikita S. Khrushchev visited California in 1959, he made a point of declaring his sympathies in the class struggle by including leaders of the longshoremen's and auto workers unions in his wide-ranging itinerary.
President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who prizes investment over solidarity, left little doubt here that he feels more comfortable on the other side of the barricades. His stop in the San Francisco Bay area was a day of rampant, unabashed, big-money, high-tech, brand-name California capitalism.
At Stanford University, the Soviet leader shunned an exhibit on Soviet history in favor of a chat with students and faculty at the business school. The subjects ranged from economics to earthquake-proof engineering and included a brief presentation by the arch-ideologist of capitalism, the economist Milton Friedman. 
Then it was back to San Francisco for lunch with the corporate elite of the Bay area, a guest list made up largely of the kind of capitalists who used to be caricatured in Pravda wearing top hats and squatting on the backs of the downtrodden.
Before leaving for home, Mr. Gorbachev met with the South Korean President, Roh Tae Woo.
Appropriately for a leader now bent on Western sponsorship, Mr. Gorbachev's visit here was underwritten in large part by corporations mindful of the Soviet leader's marketable aura. City officials said the press center, the luncheon, transportation, and everything else except for police time, were paid for by an array of newspaper executives, oil men, bankers and industrialists ranging from A.T.&T. down to the Wallaroo Juice Company.
Khrushchev, by contrast, ended his meeting with a labor delegation headed by Walter Reuther of the United Auto Workers by calling his host ''a capitalist lackey.''
 
Red-Hot Tickets
The most marketable commodity in the Bay area this week was, of course, Mr. Gorbachev.
Stanford University used a lottery to distribute 7,100 tickets to various events among the school's students and faculty, including 1,700 seats for the Soviet leader's speech in Memorial Auditorium.
This morning, scalpers outside the university's security perimeter were asking prices from $250 for an upper-balcony seat to more than twice that for a place front and center.
''It's a great opportunity to see one of the great leaders of the world, a charismatic guy, who is changing the face of at least two countries,'' said Matt McLeod, a senior from Los Angeles who is studying product design, offering a 10th row center seat for sale. ''So from my point of view I couldn't possibly go below $350.''
Local entrepreneurs were quick to exploit the hysteria that was described in a column by Rob Morse, a columnist for The San Francisco Examiner, as ''a Gorbasm.'' In San Francisco, Tsangares Silk Screen Company exploited Gorbymania with the inevitable T-shirt design contest. The winner depicted Mr. Gorbachev as the cartoon brat Bart Simpson aiming a slingshot. Underneath was the slogan, ''I killed Laura Palmer,'' and down the side the exclamation ''Yo, Dude.''
 
A Snub at Stanford?
The mystery this week at Stanford was why Mr. Gorbachev had backed out at the last minute from a planned tour of one of the Western world's greatest archives of Soviet history, at the Hoover Institution on campus.
The institution, known both for its wealth of expertise on Soviet affairs and for its strong anti-Communist orientation, had laid on a special exhibit of Soviet historical treasures, including a handwritten letter from Lenin, the abdication letter of Czar Nicholas II, turn-of-the-century photos from czarist secret police files and a copy of the first issue of Pravda. A visit to the exhibit, called ''A Century of Revolutions: Lenin to Gorbachev,'' was on Mr. Gorbachev's tentative agenda, but was abruptly scratched without explanation.
One theory was that Mr. Gorbachev was put off when he learned of the center's historic hostility to Communism and the abiding pessimism of some of its scholars about Mr. Gorbachev's prospects for reforming his country. Perhaps, some campus analysts said, Mr. Gorbachev's schedulers reviewed the book list of Hoover Institution writers - titles include ''The Coming Soviet Crash'' and ''The Arms Control Delusion'' - and wondered if this was an appropriate stop for a man touting the end of the cold war.
A related and more prevalent theory was that Hoover scholars had inadvertently scotched the visit by boasting in American newspaper interviews that Mr. Gorbachev was coming to them for lessons in democracy and capitalism.
''The tenor of the comments was that by coming here Gorbachev would be admitting that he was wrong and our guys were right,'' said John B. Dunlop, a Hoover Fellow and specialist on Russian culture.
''Of course, there is no hard evidence that the snub was intended at all,'' Mr. Dunlop added.
 
'I Saw Her Hand!'
Raisa M. Gorbachev stood up the press and public all over town today. Scheduled stops at city showplaces like the War Memorial Opera House and Davies Symphony Hall were jettisoned without explanation. Instead of taking in the view of the city from the oak-paneled Carnelian Room on the 52d floor of the Bank of America, Mrs. Gorbachev visited the tiny New Terrace Market on Twin Peaks, where she checked out the frozen dinners and questioned a young clerk about her customers' shopping habits.
Later, a crowd of 500 people mobbed an intersection in the Fisherman's Wharf area as she drove by, only to be disappointed when her car slowed but did not stop. ''I saw her hand! I saw her hand!'' fans shrieked.
But two hours earlier, a mysterious fake Mr. and Mrs. Gorbachev toured the city in a black limousine, allowing tourists a photo opportunity with a realistic substitute.
 
Glory to Spare
When Khrushchev was here, he was so smitten by San Francisco that he sometimes leaned precariously out the window of his speeding limousine, prompting the Mayor of that time to worry that the Soviet leader would topple from the car - and that the public would think the Mayor had pushed him. With Mr. Gorbachev, it was the city that adored the leader, and the local politicians chased along eagerly to bask in the glory.
The state's two United States Senators, Alan Cranston, a Democrat, and Pete Wilson, a Republican, trailed Mr. Gorbachev enviously this morning through the throngs of screaming young voters at Stanford, one of whom waved a sign proclaiming ''Gorby for President.'' Presumably he meant President of the United States.

HEADLINE: After the Summit;
U.S. Will Press the Soviets To Accept Plan on Germany

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 4

 BODY:
Bush Administration officials say they have given the Soviet leadership a nine-point plan designed to induce Moscow to accept the presence of a united Germany in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
The program, which brings together many different elements related to the future of NATO and German-Soviet relations, was largely designed by Washington and Bonn and first presented to the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, in Moscow in mid-May and then reiterated for President Mikhail S. Gorbachev last week, the officials said.
While virtually all elements of the plan have been discussed in public, the Administration wanted to package them in one document to be presented to the Soviets as part of the American strategy for convincing Moscow that the West is seriously trying to address Soviet concerns on German membership in NATO.
 
West Will Push On, Anyway
Despite Mr. Gorbachev's suggestion that the Soviet Union may delay withdrawing its troops from Eastern Europe if a united Germany joins NATO, Bush Administration officials say they intend to press ahead with their plans to integrate Germany into the Western alliance. 
Indeed, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d left today for a gathering of European foreign ministers in Copenhagen, the first of a series of high-level meetings that Administration officials see as critical for putting their German strategy into effect.
The carrot in that strategy, officials say, is to keep offering Moscow this package of nine military and political points designed to make a united Germany's membership in NATO so nonthreatening in military terms and so economically beneficial to the Soviet Union that it will eventually acquiesce.
''We have presented to the Soviets nine points that summarize how we propose to deal with their legitimate interests,'' a senior Administration official said. ''The message of these nine points is that we really want to deal with your concerns on Germany sensitively.''
 
Onus of the Spoiler
The stick, officials say, is to use the gathering momentum of German unification and the broad European support for German membership in NATO, to make prohibitive the diplomatic costs for Moscow of seeking to block German unification. These would involve alienating the German nation whose economic support will be badly needed in the coming years and generally playing the role of ''spoiler.''
''We basically said that if you want to engage on these nine points, fine,'' the senior official said. ''Otherwise, you are going to be isolating yourself and antagonizing the Germans. But if you're serious about having your concerns addressed, then we are ready to go a long way.''
These are the nine points:
* A united Germany will reaffirm its commitment not to develop nuclear, chemical or biological weapons.
* After conclusion of a conventional arms reduction treaty now being negotiated in Vienna, the NATO allies will be prepared to immediately conclude a follow-up manpower accord that would limit the size of a united Germany's armed forces.
* NATO is prepared to advance the date of negotiations to limit short-range nuclear weapons in Europe.
* NATO will radically revamp its military strategy and structure of forces to make them far less threatening to Moscow.
* Germany will renounce claims not only to Polish territory, but also to former German territory now in the Soviet Union, such as East Prussia.
* No NATO forces will be stationed in what is now East Germany.
* Soviet troops will be allowed to remain in East Germany for a transition period, with expenses paid by the German Government.
* The 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe will be institutionalized and expanded, as Moscow has insisted, to make it a pan-European organization in which the Soviets can play a leading role as the Warsaw Pact disintegrates and NATO remains intact.
* Germany will offer Moscow a variety of trade, lending and commercial arrangements to help the Soviet Union in its transition to a market economy.
 
Described as Appreciative
''The nine points are concrete things, and Gorbachev clearly appreciated them,'' a State Department official who took part in the summit meeting said. But ''I think what we learned from him at the summit is that he may also need some intangible things.
''Gorbachev's remarks on Germany were never very clear, but what he seemed to be saying was that the very political nature of NATO causes him problems,'' the official said.
''The nine points are telling him that NATO will eventually change, but that's a pig in a poke for him. He wants to see something now, have something to point to, to prove that NATO is no longer the cold war menace but just a grouping of Western states which want constructive relations with the East. He also want to see more specifics on some of the nine points.''
In Copenhagen on Wednesday, Mr. Baker is to give an address to the European security conference foreign ministers, laying out some American ideas on the roles that this all-European organization might play. From there, Mr. Baker will continue to Turnberry, Scotland, for a meeting of NATO foreign ministers that will lay the basis for a NATO summit meeting early next month focusing on ways to make NATO, as it absorbs a united Germany, a less dangerous alliance to Moscow.
 
Baker to See Shevardnadze
While in Copenhagen, Mr. Baker will meet with Mr. Shevardnadze and try to develop with him some of the ideas floated at the summit for quickly transforming NATO's political image in Soviet eyes. These include more frequent visits by Soviet diplomats and generals to NATO, possibly giving NATO forces a non-American commander, and possibly even drafting an agreement between NATO and the Warsaw Pact for new principles of relations.
On July 1, the two Germanys will put into effect complete monetary, economic and social union, meaning that they will have one currency, one set of labor laws and, effectively, one economy. By autumn, all East and West German political parties will be merged and by sometime between December and next April, all-German elections will be held.
By then, the only thing holding up German unification will be the completion of the so-called ''two-plus-four'' negotiations, in which the two Germanys and the four World War II Allies - the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France - are supposed to dissolve their rights and responsibilities over Germany, making final Germany's borders and concluding a treaty that would be approved at a summit meeting of the European security conference.
To be sure, Administration officials say, Mr. Gorbachev can simply refuse to withdraw Soviet troops from East Germany and hold up the whole matter, but for how long and at what price?
''What are they going to do the day the representative of a united Germany walks into NATO headquarters in Brussels and presents his credentials and it is done?'' an American official asked. ''What happens when the three Western powers say they are going to terminate their rights and responsibilities in Germany and the Soviets say no? What do you think that is going to do for Soviet-German relations?''

HEADLINE: After the Summit;
Japanese Feel Ready for a Visit From Gorbachev

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 4

 BODY:
After years of frigid relations with the Soviet Union, Japan today greeted President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's affirmation that he would soon visit Tokyo with relief and with a glimmer of hope that superpower summit meetings would no longer be something that this country's leadership watches on television.
Though a Japanese-Soviet summit meeting has been in the works for months, Mr. Gorbachev's comment in Washington on Sunday that he would travel to Japan next year to ''open that area for discussion'' was his first public reference to the trip. The statement was welcome here, in a country that in recent months has felt slighted by the focusing of superpower attention on Europe.
But there was a clear if unspoken message to the Japanese public, a senior Japanese computer executive said today. ''The rest of world is rushing to Moscow,'' he said. ''And we are going no place.'' 
For Japan, the images of the last few days - from Mr. Gorbachev's signing of trade accords with the United States to South Korea's President, Roh Tae Woo, arriving in San Francisco for his country's first leader-to-leader talks with a Soviet chief - have been acutely uncomfortable.
 
Territorial Dispute
A succession of failed efforts to resolve a territorial dispute dating back to the last days of World War II keep Tokyo's diplomatic relations with the Soviets in an uneasy freeze, shaking Japan's faith that the lure of loans and the whir of Walkmans would soon bring Soviet concessions. Recently, even Japan's modest business relationship with the Soviet Union - what really counts to many here - has shown signs of souring over delays in Soviet payments for goods.
Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu told the Parliament today that he looked forward to a ''major opportunity'' to mend differences between two of the world's three largest economies. Misoji Sakamoto, the chief Cabinet secretary, said it would be a moment to ''radically improve'' relations.
Privately, though, no one is quite so sure that Mr. Gorbachev's appearance next year will end the 40-year chill. Among government officials, there is widespread speculation that Mr. Gorbachev, with a finely tuned sense of the political power of Japan's business leaders, plans to use the broadening of trade ties with the United States and South Korea - two of this country's biggest economic rivals - to gain leverage in negotiations with Japan.
''I don't think it is a strategy with much substance,'' a senior Japanese diplomat said today. ''But it is possible that over time it could have a significant psychological effect here.''
 
A Sluggish Time
What Mr. Gorbachev may have working on his side is the guiding rule of Japanese foreign policy for the last 40 years: the Government usually avoids taking positions that are conspicuously out of step with those of the United States. But as once fiercely anti-Soviet countries like South Korea begin to warm to the Soviets, and companies like I.B.M. sign agreements to put computers in the Soviet schools, such a divergence is exactly what is developing.
''In Japanese-Soviet relations, we have seen comparatively little movement in the last half-year,'' said Kazuhiko Togo, the head of the Soviet division of the Japanese Foreign Ministry. In contrast, he said, ''There has been steady growth and development in the momentum of building a relationship'' between the Soviet Union and South Korea.
The biggest obstacle to a similar thaw with Japan, which has far more sophisticated technology and far bigger financial resources to offer the Soviets, is the perpetual debate over four sparsely populated and often-frozen islands north of Hokkaido, which the Soviet Union calls the Kurile Islands and the Japanese call the Northern Territories.
Japanese officials consider the islands part of Japan's natural territory, and say that the islands must be returned if the Soviet Union wants Honda plants and video-cassette-player factories - to say nothing of a peace treaty formally ending World War II. President Bush urged Mr. Gorbachev to address the issue when the men discussed regional problems over the weekend, saying that resolving the problem of the islands was important to developing solid East-West ties.
 
'No Land to Spare'
At times in the last 30 years the Soviets have shown interest in discussing the topic, but not recently. With Lithuania and other territories annexed during the war seeking independence, a Japanese diplomat said dryly a few weeks ago, ''This may not be the best time for Mr. Gorbachev to be seen returning land.'' When Mr. Gorbachev told workers in the Urals not long ago that the Soviet Union has ''no land to spare,'' the comment received huge headlines here.
Like protecting the rice market, insistence on the return of the islands has long been an article of faith in Japan. But in recent months that faith has been tested by a latent movement questioning whether a group of islands with little practical value to modern Japan is worth jeopardizing the country's chance to invest in perestroika.
The issue got a rare airing in late April, when a powerful former Deputy Prime Minister, Shin Kanemaru, broke ranks and said Japan should be more flexible about the issue, perhaps considering the return of only two of the four islands, Habomai and Shikotan, as a starting point. The Soviet Union floated a similar offer in 1956, but it was rejected by Japan and later repudiated by the Soviet Government. The other two islands are called Kunashiri and Etorofu.
Mr. Kanemaru's comment started a small sensation here, and he was so heavily criticized by the press and the Foreign Ministry that he was quickly forced to ''correct'' his statement. Gold in the Future? The Japanese are betting that as his economy collapses, Mr. Gorbachev will conclude that he needs Japanese investment and technology more than he needs the islands. To achieve that goal, Japan has been gradually trying to increase its exports, much as South Korea has done.
But in recent months, even the slow growth has appeared threatened. The Japanese Association for Trade with the Soviet Union and the Socialist Countries of Europe estimates that the Soviets, once known for paying cash on delivery, are suddenly $200 million in arrears to Japanese firms. Increasingly worried, Japanese businesses cut their exports by 26 percent in April.
''We think it is a short-term problem,'' Itaru Otawa, a senior economist at the association, said today. ''Over the long term we think the Soviets will come in with loans from Western countries and bigger sales of gold.''

HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
Split at Top On Tactics For Talks On Budget

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 4

 BODY:
Richard G. Darman and John H. Sununu, the twin towers of the Bush Administration's domestic and economic policy, are at odds. Not over substance or personalities, but over tactics.
Budget talks with Congress are to resume Wednesday, and Mr. Darman, the budget director, and Mr. Sununu, President Bush's chief of staff, disagree over the chances of striking a favorable deficit-reduction deal with the lawmakers.
Mr. Darman is confident it can be pulled off. Patience is crucial, he has said in top councils, and he expects the Administration to win big concessions on spending cuts and tightening the budget-making process without unacceptable tax increases. 
If that happens, he maintains, the Federal Reserve would lower interest rates, the economy would strengthen and President Bush's re-election in 1992 would be assured.
Mr. Sununu, on the other hand, is skeptical about the motives of Congress and afraid the White House cannot produce support among Republican back-benchers for an agreement that includes any new taxes. He has repeatedly told his colleagues that the Administration must be prepared to walk out of the talks abruptly if they start going badly.
An official who has met often with both men put it this way: ''Darman believes Congress can be manipulated. Sununu is not sure. Deep down, he doesn't trust Congress.''
Although they hardly knew each other when they took office 16 months ago, the budget director and the chief of staff have become fast friends.
In many respects, they are cut from the same bolt. Mr. Darman is said to have had perfect scores on his S.A.T.'s. Mr. Sununu is said to have an I.Q. of 180. They tend to be impatient with lesser minds.
They have joined forces against Government regulations, trade restrictions, industrial policy and environmental measures that they maintain would retard economic growth.
But their backgrounds are different. And this seems to be the source of their views on Congress.
Mr. Darman, who has worked in Washington most of his career, is an old hand at cutting complicated deals with the legislators. In the Reagan Administration, he was instrumental in negotiating the 1983 Social Security legislation and the Tax Reform Act of 1986, two of the most politically sensitive measures of the 1980's.
In private, colleagues say, Mr. Darman sometimes expresses exasperation over the legislative process, even contempt for it. But he has mastered it like few others off Capitol Hill. A secret of his success has been his ability to strike alliances with key Democrats. He did it with Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey at a crucial point in the tax reform talks. In recent weeks he has been cultivating Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, and Representative Leon E. Panetta of California, chairman of the Budget Committee.
Mr. Sununu cut his teeth in New Hampshire, where politics is dominated by a phobia against taxes and where the Legislature, the largest in the country, is more often the butt of jokes than the subject of respect. As Governor, he stood against all new taxes for three terms, and he found he was more successful bullying the Legislature than working with it.
He has made few Democratic friends here. The strategy he developed for Mr. Bush in the New Hampshire primary two years ago - having Mr. Bush forswear new taxes while calling Bob Dole of Kansas ''Senator Straddle'' - may have won Mr. Bush the Presidential nomination. But it left deep scars in Mr. Sununu's relationship with Senator Dole, the Republican leader.
If Mr. Darman and Mr. Sununu disagree over tactics at a crucial stage in the negotiations, the President will probably turn to his close friend, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, who has stayed in the background in the budget talks so far.
''We're happy with our second-tier visibility,'' said a Brady aide. ''He thinks he's more effective that way as an adviser to the boss. He likes not to be Darmanesque or Sununu-like.''

HEADLINE: No Church, No Ministry, No Pulpit, He Is Called Religious Right's Star

BYLINE: By PETER STEINFELS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: POMONA, Calif.

 BODY:
James Dobson is a radio psychologist, not a television evangelist. He heads no church. His professional training is in the field of child development.
But millions of Americans now look to him for spiritual and, sometimes, political guidance. He has emerged as one of the country's most influential religious figures, a man the Rev. Jerry Falwell has called ''the rising star'' and future leader of the religious right.
How the 55-year-old Mr. Dobson came to acquire such status is the story not of his calling sinners to repentance but of his counseling parents on toilet-training and spouses on mid-life crises. 
Like an old-fashioned machine politician who earned immigrants' votes by responding to their economic needs, Mr. Dobson gets his followers' religious, political and cultural loyalty by responding to their anxieties and offering advice. For him, the machine is the radio - his programs are heard on 1,450 stations in the United States and overseas - and a staff of 700 people who answer the phones and deluge of mail seeking advice.
 
Machine Works for Him
So well has this machine served Mr. Dobson, a former professor of pediatrics at the University of Southern California School of Medicine, that only the Rev. Billy Graham was ranked higher among influential conservative church leaders in a survey last year of Protestant denominational clerics.
With such momentum behind him, there is repeated speculation that Mr. Dobson might run for office one day. But he denies all political ambitions. ''I have no qualification for political life,'' he said in an interview. ''I will never be a candidate for any public office. I do not want a political appointment. I am not seeking political power.''
He says he does care passionately about the future of the family, a passion that has led him to promote what he calls traditional family values. These include the permanence of marriage and opposition to anything that might condone or encourage sexual activity outside marriage, from soap opera love affairs to public acceptance of homosexuality.
 
Interview With Bundy
In January 1989 he made national news with a videotaped interview in which the murderer Theodore Bundy, hours before going to the electric chair, said ''hard-core pornography'' had started him on the road to violent crime.
Mr. Dobson is a determined opponent of abortion and was a featured speaker at the anti-abortion rally in Washington on April 28.
But his following does not stem from these widely publicized events. Instead, it centers on the efforts of Focus on the Family, the organization he heads here in Pomona that has an annual budget of nearly $60 million.
''I love radio,'' the tall, sandy-haired psychologist said as he showed off the organization's offices, where antique radios as well as paintings of family scenes decorate the halls.
''Radio is very intimate, more intimate than television,'' he said. ''Television is performance. Radio is a conversation. People write you like a brother, uncle or friend.''
 
Thousands Seek Advice
In fact, listeners send him 200,000 letters a month, and make more than 1,200 telephone calls daily to his organization's toll-free phone number. Many are looking for further advice on the down-to-earth topics discussed in the broadcasts. Among these topics are eating disorders, learning disabilities, midlife crisis, spouse beating, child abuse, workaholism, family finances and sex education.
In response to these requests, Focus on the Family ships out 52 million pieces of literature and more than a million cassettes a year. The organization's two main-frame computers contain information on two million correspondents.
Mr. Dobson has also fashioned a sophisticated apparatus to provide emergency help or special computerized responses to writers who demand more individual attention: an average of 10,000 often heart-wrenching letters a month.
''Through this department we are watching the unraveling of a social order,'' Mr. Dobson said. ''Five years ago people wrote us about thumb-sucking and bed-wetting. Now they're writing about wife beating, child abuse, manic depression, suicide and satanic cults.''
 
Beginnings in 60's
Mr. Dobson has been worrying about the unraveling of the social order since the 1960's, when he said he was appalled by what he viewed as the impact of sexual and cultural permissiveness on people he was treating in family counseling.
In 1970, he wrote a manual on child rearing, ''Dare to Discipline,'' and earned a reputation as a kind of evangelical antithesis to Dr. Benjamin Spock.
Mr. Dobson's father was a minister in the Church of the Nazarene, a denomination that has retained the revivalist fervor of its Pentecostal origins while dropping the practice of speaking in tongues. ''I grew up in the church and I never left it,'' Mr. Dobson said. ''When I talk about traditional values, I'm talking about those that go back to Jesus Christ.''
Mr. Dobson can sound like a pillar of conservatism when he defends traditional roles for men and women, or he can sound like a radical social critic when he criticizes society for making children see themselves as winners or losers on the basis of beauty or brains.
 
Repackaging Scripture
What may ultimately bind Mr. Dobson to his audience, however, is not this personal brand of psychology but a conviction he shares with his audiences that he is simply ''repackaging'' scriptural messages.
He does not separate secular and religious wisdom into different compartments, and he does not expect others to do so. A psychological discussion of guilt merges into a theological one of God and Satan.
Mr. Dobson recounted how, by the mid-1970's, a flood of speaking engagements and a burgeoning career in medical research was turning his own family life into a pressure cooker. He had been married since 1960 to Shirley Deere, and they had two children.
''The pace at which we run is probably the biggest threat to marital relationships,'' the psychologist said. ''Everybody I know is exhausted, living on the edge. You don't have time for sex; you're worn out by the time you fall into bed.'' #1,000 Emergencies a Month He decided to leave academia and to substitute radio and videotapes for personal appearances. A few years later, drowning in mail from his broadcasts and books, he started composing prototype responses to common problems. It was another step in creating Focus on the Family's mixture of personal teamwork with impersonal technology.
Today, of the 10,000 letters a month that require special treatment, about 1,000 are emergency cases, containing threats of suicide, fears of violence or marital breakups. Nineteen California-licensed family counselors try to phone these people immediately. They are equipped with computerized lists of therapists and other sources of assistance throughout the nation.
Mail that is special but less urgent goes to 60 staff members familiar with more than 1,000 prototype letters approved by Mr. Dobson. The topics begin with aging, abuse and abortion and run to the end of the alphabet.
Using words like ''rejection,'' ''infidelity'' and ''custody,'' a correspondence assistant can also frame a more complicated reply, picking out pertinent paragraphs from different prototypes and sending or recommending books, tapes or other resources from an index of materials.
 
A Flood of 'Pain Mail'
The organization tries not to schedule several broadcasts on topics like incest or child abuse close to one another because staff members' morale drops and they fall behind in replies.
''The pain mail will be so great that you can tell the impact on the whole department,'' said Kurt Bruner, who oversees the correspondence staff.
Besides the half-hour weekday program featuring Mr. Dobson, Focus on the Family produces a daily 15-minute family news analysis, a weekly one-hour program, a radio drama series for children and a brief daily program in Spanish.
Mr. Dobson draws no salary, relying instead on royalties from his 11 books and compensating the organization for the help his broadcasts give in promoting their sales.
Focus on the Family publishes six magazines for different age groups. A monthly political publication tells 267,000 subscribers what they can do to combat gay rights, abortion and sexually suggestive advertising.
 
Pro-Family Organizing
The organization is forming coalitions of ''pro-family organizations'' for lobbying and public education at the state level. Coalitions are now in place in 18 states and are being organized in seven others.
In November 1988, the organization began sponsoring the Family Research Council, a Washington-based research center headed by Gary L. Bauer, who was a domestic policy adviser to President Ronald Reagan.
Mr. Dobson says he keeps his conservative views private unless they touch on the family. ''I don't talk about South Africa,'' he said, ''and you'll never hear me endorse a political candidate.''
Asked why the problems are so much worse nearly a decade after a conservative President and his Administration began backing much of Mr. Dobson's agenda, staff members of Focus on the Family said the society is still suffering the cultural consequences of 1960's permissiveness.
''There's a moral drift to society, and families are caught in a river with a rapid current,'' Mr. Dobson said. ''Nobody floats upstream without a lot of energy.''

HEADLINE: COMMENCEMENTS;
M.I.T. Is Told Latin Nations Deserve Help

 BODY:
In what he described as ''one of the last major speeches'' of his presidency, President Virgilio Barco of Colombia today urged graduates of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, his alma mater, to look beyond East-West relations and support economic development in Latin America.
''Almost a whole contintent has moved from military rule to legitimately elected leaders,'' said Mr. Barco, whose four-year term ends in August. ''Still, as evidence of North America's bias to the Cold War ideology, this dramatic change so close to your own borders receives relatively little attention.
''It is your responsibility, and those in other wealthy countries, to insure the fostering of global economic growth,'' Mr. Barco told the 1,712 graduates and about 8,000 and guests in Cambridge, Mass. ''In this way you can help these fledgling democracies as they struggle to spread their wings.'' 
Mr. Barco, who earned his undergraduate degree in civil engineering from M.I.T. in 1943, also reiterated his plea for help in the struggle to overcome the powerful drug groups and organized crime that have terrorized Colombia.
Also giving his last commencement remarks was Paul E. Gray, who is retiring after 10 years as the university's president to become chairman of the M.I.T. Corporation, the university's board of trustees. Dr. Gray's resignation, announced in March 1989, will become effective as soon as a new president is chosen - a process that has taken longer than university officials expected.
''Since March of 1989, I had planned to follow your example and graduate myself later this month,'' Dr. Gray said. ''However, as the search for M.I.T.'s 15th president continues, I now expect to carry on for a few more months. And I hope that you will forgive me some envy at the apparent ease with which you got it all together and got it right.''
In February, Philip Sharp, a professor of molecular biology at the university, was recommended for president by a search committee. He first accepted and then declined the job, citing his commitment to science.
The board met today and reportedly discussed the search, but university officials denied that a new president had been selected, saying the board routinely meets on commencement day.
 
Swarthmore College
Robert D. Putnam, the dean of the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University, told the graduates of Swarthmore College yesterday that world events in their senior year would have been unthinkable in the early 1960's, when he was a student there.
''Yours is the class that witnessed the fall of the Berlin Wall,'' Mr. Putnam said to 330 new graduates at the school's 118th commencement, at its campus in Swarthmore, Pa. ''Mine was the class that was marked by the Cuban missile crisis.''
Mr. Putnam, who graduated from Swarthmore in 1963, said he sensed a new curiosity about democracy among people in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union.
''Just last Monday I sat until 2 in the morning at a kitchen table in Moscow, talking with two ebullient Russian reformers, eager to exchange ideas about how to create a democracy,'' he said. ''To anyone who came of age in the Cold War and endured that fearsome nuclear confrontation of 1962, the very thought of sharing in the democratization of the Soviet Union is awe-inspiring, indeed almost unimaginable.''
The college gave honorary degrees to Mr. Putnam; Mary Patterson McPherson, president of Bryn Mawr College; Heywood Hale Broun, a television and radio commentator who graduated from Swarthmore in 1940; David Montgomery, a social historian who graduated from the college in 1950, and Robert Whitman, an expert on earthquake engineering who graduated from the college in 1948.

HEADLINE: White House Must Back HDTV Research

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Tom Wicker shows up the shortsightedness, indeed the ultimate danger to American interests, in the failure of the White House to support high-technology electronics (''The High-Tech Future,'' column, May 24).
The retreat from supporting private-sector research and development of high-definition television, or HDTV, affects far more than military research and development. HDTV represents the next stage in electronic development. It will provide not only clearer pictures on a home television tube but also the capability to detect cancer at a far earlier stage and countless other economic and social uses; not to mention enlarging the market share we are rapidly losing abroad and will lose dramatically if the United States cannot compete in the era of HDTV.
The White House should strengthen the office of science adviser to the President, add a deputy for international communications to the National Security Council and listen to Secretary of Commerce Robert Mosbacher, who understands HDTV's crucial role in America's future.
More than that, extensive tax freedom should be provided for private research and development and antitrust restrictions should be relaxed to permit consortiums of United States companies to cooperate in high-tech development. The White House should clearly signal this policy supportive of America's eminence in a high-tech world. This is not ''industrial policy.'' It is simply a recognition of national security.
 
LEONARD R. SUSSMAN
New York, May 25, 1990
 The writer is senior scholar in international communications at Freedom House.

HEADLINE: Shelter Syndrome Theory Has Dangerous Flaw

 BODY:
To the Editor:
A historical note on the newly rediscovered phenomenon of ''shelterization,'' which allegedly afflicts homeless men in New York City's Fort Washington armory (''Shelter Life: Why It's Hard to Get Out,'' Health page, May 24), preventing ''their return to another way of living'':
On two other occasions, once in the Progressive Era and again during the Great Depression, the same specter of iatrogenic disability - shelter-generated dependency - was raised. In the first period, Alice Solenberger in Chicago and Charles Barnes in New York City railed against municipal lodging houses for habituating men to ''idleness and uncertainty,'' rendering them virtually useless should the labor market need them again.
In the 1930's Nels Anderson in New York and, in Chicago, Edwin Sutherland and Harvey Locke (who coined the term ''shelterization'' in 1936) traced the stages by which a man loses contact with old friends, gives up ambition, becomes indifferent to time and slowly sinks into that collective ''waiting for nothing'' (Tom Kromer's phrase) that defined life on the skids. For all the hand wringing, however, lasting damage was never documented. In both decades, when the American war machine was cranked up, the ranks of skid row were depleted of all but the elderly and severely disabled. Shelterized men apparently had no trouble returning to life as soldiers or factory hands. 
Like the ''culture of poverty'' thesis to which it is related, ''shelterization'' risks mistaking for an indelible trait behavior that is better seen as adaptation. Bitter experience suggests that the real danger of such a thesis is that it will be used to justify restricting ''rehabilitation'' efforts to men, rather than buildings and labor markets, which play the crucial role in ''another way of life'' to return to. It isn't bad habits, but affordable housing and jobs that matter most in leaving the shelters. And while housing and jobs may be plentiful in the artificial economies and dispersed habitats of wartime, they are in perilously short supply today.
 
KIM HOPPER
New York, May 24, 1990
 The writer is a visiting assistant professor of anthropology at the new School for Social Research.

HEADLINE: A Workmanlike Summit

BYLINE: By David K. Shipler; David K. Shipler, author of ''Russia: Broken Idols, Solemn Dreams,'' is a senior associate at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
If all goes well in Soviet-American relations, the summit just ended may be the last one in which mere gestures of friendliness between the leaders are enough to stir the emotions of the world. For if the two Presidents fail to bring more imagination to their next couple of meetings, they are likely to find themselves with diminished ability to manage the historic upheaval now taking place.
The handshake, the smile, the courteous word, the informal talk and the modest agreement may no longer stand out as dramatic counterpoints to the hostility between the two countries, the two systems, the two ideologies. With the collapse of Communism and the erosion of enmity, the Soviet and American Presidents will need more creative thinking to excite hopes for solving human problems. 
Ideally, summit meetings will cease to be isolated pageants of accord or encounters of great moment. They will become more frequent, more businesslike and blessedly routine. Their success will be measured not by the warmth of the visual images but by the substantive vision they apply to world affairs.
It may be too early to employ this standard, for as Mikhail Gorbachev and George Bush just demonstrated, we still need symbols to nourish our yearnings. The pictures of recent days were uplifting, inspiring confidence in the possibilities of Soviet-American harmony.
But the revolution that Mr. Gorbachev unleashed, and now cannot control, has given rise to soaring expectations of a new world order, which he and Mr. Bush failed to satisfy in their discussions.
These higher goals, especially in a post-postwar Europe with a united Germany, test both leaders to think differently about their countries' roles than they have in the past. The Soviet Union and the United States have every reason to become allies, or at least partners, in economic, diplomatic, cultural and social spheres.
Potentially, our economies are complementary: vast natural resources in the Soviet Union and technologically advanced industry in the United States. If the Soviet system is transformed, there will be fertile ground for extensive American investment and cooperation.
Our diplomatic interests overlap increasingly, with both sides having less to gain from igniting regional conflicts than from dampening them, which cries out for mutual restrictions on global arms sales.
And if the Soviets overcome their domestic difficulties, we may be able to cooperate in turning our attention from East-West competition to North-South issues - famine, disease, illiteracy and poverty in the third world.
This summit meeting, which operated on four distinct levels, was more complex than those before. First came the symbolism of a Soviet leader being welcomed with military fanfare at the White House, plunging happily into street corner crowds, making his first toss of a horseshoe a ringer at Camp David. This was a resounding success.
Then came the personal rapport, with Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev achieving what seemed to be a frank and trusting relationship. At their joint news conference Sunday, they praised each other effusively. This was an important but transitory success. No leader is in power forever, and hard international problems rarely succumb to the force of personal friendships.
The third level was the conventional agenda: arms control, human rights, trade, aviation agreements, cultural exchanges and the like. The results were mixed.
The notable accomplishment in arms control was the accord to stop producing and start destroying chemical weapons. But its full value will be realized only if Washington and Moscow press hard on their clients and allies to join the band.
Obstacles remain to a treaty reducing long-range nuclear weapons, despite promises to try to sign an accord by the end of the year. Little evident progress was made on conventional military reductions in Europe, despite the unilateral Soviet withdrawals that are under way.
The trade issue got snagged by human rights concerns over Jewish emigration and Lithuanian independence - issues that reawaken old American fears about the Soviet Union as an authoritarian state. President Bush signed a trade agreement and is poised to grant the Soviet Union most-favored-nation status, but has properly waited until a new law liberalizing emigration procedures is passed by the Supreme Soviet. The U.S. Senate also wants a resolution of Lithuania's problems.
The fourth level of the summit, the need to redefine the relationship in concrete strategic terms, turned out to be the least fruitful. There were few new ideas, and the leaders were unable to narrow their differences over Washington's proposal for a united Germany in NATO.
As Gregory Flynn of the Carnegie Endowment observes, the issue is less about Germany than about the power of the Soviet Union, and the Soviet Union's role in Europe. This requires some new thinking in Washington about how to welcome the Soviets into Europe rather than exclude them.
Significantly, President Bush was unable to describe this transition period in Soviet-American relations. He fumbled a question on where he would now place the Soviet Union along a scale between adversary and ally. ''We've moved towards a - I don't quite know how to quantify it for you,'' he said.
Next summit, Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev will have to give us something more.

HEADLINE: U.S. Puerto Ricans Debate Right to Vote on Island's Future

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO

 BODY:
In 34 years as a New Yorker, Reinaldo Pacheco has not voted in New York City. But his apathy turns to indignation at the thought of being prevented from choosing, by ballot, the political future of his native Puerto Rico.
Mr. Pacheco is one of an estimated 2.5 million Puerto Ricans living in the United States. The group is now at the center of an emotional debate about who should vote on whether Puerto Rico becomes the 51st state, an independent country or a United States commonwealth, as it is now, but in a modified form.
Mr. Pacheco, a 49-year-old native of Puerto Rico and a hospital maintenance worker in East Harlem, said he is entitled to vote on the island's status as much as any resident of Puerto Rico. 
 
No Poll in Puerto Rico
''Just because we left we don't stop being Puerto Rican,'' he said. ''We shouldn't be denied the right to vote.''
Support in Puerto Rico is less clear-cut. The three major political parties in favor of the vote are said to agree with some form of participation. Puerto Ricans on the island have not been polled on the issue, even though they are believed to be as divided as Puerto Ricans in the United States.
The vote, a plebiscite, is being sought by the three major political parties in Puerto Rico for some time before the gubernatorial election in 1992. It has the support of President Bush, who favors statehood for the Caribbean island of about 3.5 million people.
It would be authorized under bills pending in the House and Senate that are still the subject of discussion at committee level. Among the discussions is not only who would participate but also whether the outcome of the plebiscite would be binding on the United States.
But already Puerto Ricans on the mainland are forming organizations, lobbying politicians both in the United States and Puerto Rico and exploring legal options to insure that they are not left out if the plebiscite is held. Those Puerto Ricans would not normally vote in an island election because they do not live there.
But many Puerto Ricans who live here argue that ethnicity should be as valid a criterion of eligibility to vote on something as crucial as a change in the political status of their native country. Since 1952, that status has been as a commonwealth of the United States. (Puerto Rico was ceded to the United States by Spain after the Spanish-American War in 1898.) While residents of Puerto Rico are United States citizens, they cannot vote in Federal elections or have a voting member in Congress, and they pay no Federal income taxes.
Many Puerto Ricans who came to the United States note that they own property in Puerto Rico and most of their families remain there. Many also say that they left because of economic reasons and hope to return someday.
Still others defend their right to participate based on cultural identity. Manuel del Valle, a Puerto Rican lawyer who practices in Manhattan, said international principles on self-determination would call for the participation of all Puerto Ricans regardless of home address.
 
Not All Want to Vote
''This issue will affect us directly and indirectly.'' said Jose Luis Rodriguez, chairman of the Committee Pro-Puerto Rican Participation, which was formed in New York late last year.
But the sentiment is not universal. The Institute for Puerto Rican Policy, a research and advocacy group in New York, found in an opinion poll last summer that of the 615 Puerto Rican community workers surveyed in 18 states, Washington and Puerto Rico, 59 percent favored allowing Puerto Ricans living in the United States to vote while 38 percent did not.
Ramon Daubon, vice president of the National Puerto Rican Coalition in Washington, which represents 105 community-based service organizations, said he has found that many Puerto Ricans living here are more concerned with problems in their communities, like drugs and AIDS, than with the plebiscite.
One resident of Puerto Rico who opposes the idea is Manuel Casiano, publisher of Caribbean Business, a business weekly. ''You want to be part of Puerto Rico?'' he asked. ''Come on back, and help solve the problems. Why should we be allowed to vote in New Jersey and have a voice and vote on their problems?''
 
A New York City Effort
The voting-right efforts come mostly from New York City, which is home to about 900,000 people from Puerto Rico or of Puerto Rican descent. The interest led the House Subcommittee on Insular and International Affairs to plan a hearing in Manhattan on the plebiscite. The focus is expected to be on a proposed amendment to the House bill that would allow all United States citizens born in Puerto Rico living overseas to vote by absentee ballot.
The provision was offered last month by Representative Jose E. Serrano, Democrat of the Bronx. Mr. Serrano, a native of Mayaguez in the island's Northwest, moved to New York with his family when he was 7 years old.
''I have yet to meet a Puerto Rican who left Puerto Rico in the 30's, 40's, 50's and 60's because they didn't like the weather, or the beaches, or the food or their neighbors,'' Mr. Serrano said. ''It was the social and economic conditions that caused them to leave, and those conditions were the result of the relationship with the United States. Now that that relationship will be decided forever, those of us who were forced out of the island should be allowed to participate.''
The issue has shown the attachments some Puerto Ricans in the United States have toward the island. At a forum sponsored by the Institute for Puerto Rican Policy on Saturday at Columbia University, City Councilman Jose Rivera unexpectedly began a version of a patriotic song about a Puerto Rican peasant's inability to survive economically on the island.
He changed the words, to the audience's delight, to sing, ''Even though I'm far from Puerto Rico, I will vote on this plebiscite.''
 
A Question of 'Empowerment'
The vote is also viewed as a way to raise the political conscience of Puerto Ricans in the United States at the grass-roots level.
''By focusing on the referendum we can begin an entire educational process and discuss fundamental questions of political organization and empowerment,'' said Pedro A. Caban, a political science professor at Fordham University.
Most Puerto Rican elected officials in New York have publicly endorsed participation in the plebiscite and many, like Councilman Rivera, are enlisting backers. Some, like Borough President Fernando Ferrer of the Bronx, support participation but question the plebiscite itself. If Congress refused to pass legislation binding the United States to accept the outcome of the plebiscite, he said, ''then who cares who participates?''
In deciding who will participate in the plebiscite, logistics and costs are two considerations. Would proof of voter eligibility for offshore Puerto Ricans be a birth certificate or an affidavit? How would they register and vote? Would the offspring of Puerto Rican parents also participate?
If allowed to participate, however, Puerto Ricans in the United States are expected to vote in much higher numbers than they have in any election in the United States, and to split along the same lines found in Puerto Rico, where the electorate is divided mainly between commonwealth and statehood, experts said.
While debate in Puerto Rico about the plebiscite has revolved around issues like the fate of Federal aid, United States military installations on the island or Spanish as the official language, random interviews with Puerto Ricans in East Harlem revealed other concerns. Many worried whether independence would result in restrictions that would limit travel between the island and New York. Many also wondered whether a new status would worsen the conditions that made them or their parents leave in the first place.
Fernando Onativia was born and raised in Brooklyn, and by his own admission hardly speaks Spanish. His only memories of Puerto Rico - sitting with his grandfather in a porch with ''chickens all around'' - stems from a visit 17 years ago. But he, too, wants to vote. ''That's my heritage, where I come from,'' said the 22-year-old radiology student at Hostos Community College in the Bronx. ''Even though I've never lived over there I feel that Puerto Rico would always be there for me, as I'm here for them.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: ''That's my heritage,'' said Fernando Onativia, who was born in Brooklyn, but considers Puerto Rico ''where I come from.'' (Angel Franco/The New York Times) (pg. B4)

HEADLINE: Top New Jersey Court to Issue Crucial School Ruling Today

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, June 4

 BODY:
The State Supreme Court announced today that it would issue its long-awaited ruling on the constitutionality of the education-financing system on Tuesday. The announcement was made as Gov. Jim Florio's proposal to revise the formula to shift aid to poor communities suffered a second round of attacks in legislative hearings.
The court made its announcement as a lawyer who filed the challenge against the formula argued before a joint hearing of the State Senate and Assembly Education Committees that Mr. Florio's plan would perpetuate illegal spending disparities between affluent and poor districts and lead to additional suits.
''What is being offered is, as it was in 1976, a single year's influx of money in some districts, with absolutely no plan to insure long-term equity,'' the lawyer, Marilyn J. Morheuser, head of the Education Law Center in Newark, testified. ''No attempt has been made in the proposed legislation to assure an end to the long history of discrimination against New Jersey's poor and minority public school children. My plea is that you refrain from enacting into law that which will have to be challenged.'' 
The timing of the court ruling appears to disrupt the administration's plan, sharply criticized in two days of hearings by the Education Committees, for quick enactment of the formula.
 
'Abide by That Decision'
The head of the Senate panel, Matthew Feldman, Democrat of Teaneck, said at the opening hearing last Wednesday that he planned to release the formula to the full Senate on Thursday. That timetable will have to be delayed until after the committee studies the court decision and determines whether the ruling requires minor changes in the Governor's proposal or a major overhaul, Mr. Feldman said.
''Whatever the court does we will accept,'' he said. ''We will abide by that decision.''
He also said he would delay two major amendments he had planned for the Governor's plan. One would have lengthened the four-year phase-out of all aid, except transportation and special-education money, for 151 of the 578 districts covered by the new formula.
Another amendment would have revised the plan to have all districts absorb some or all their staff's pension and Social Security costs. The state now pays 100 percent of those costs.
 
Hope for Court Ruling
Mr. Florio issued a statement after the court announcement saying: ''The court's ruling has been anticipated for months. Everyone who cares about quality education in New Jersey expects the court's decision will reflect the need to offer the same high level of education to all of our children wherever they live in our state.''
The ruling could have broad implications for Mr. Florio's budget and education plans. If the court upholds the formula that was enacted in 1976, along with the income tax as its financing, and orders additional aid to the districts, the administration would be forced to find a major new revenue source for the 1991 budget, which has to be approved by July 1.
The existing formula calls for $500 million more than the state is providing the districts for the 1990-91 school year. In the past the court has suggested that the formula was constitutional if it was fully financed. Mr. Florio is providing 83 percent. If the court orders 100 percent financing, $500 million in new money would have to be found by the end of the month.
 
Caps on Spending
Invalidating the formula could undercut a basic tenet of the proposed formula. Mr. Florio's plan sets no cap on spending per pupil and allows using property taxes to pay for whatever a board wants to spend.
The Education Law Center contends that the reliance on property taxes has led to unconstitutional spending disparities and, consequently, unequal educational opportunities affluent and poor districts.
To eliminate inequities, Ms. Morheuser has urged the court to set a statewide spending level for each pupil and allow each district, no matter how affluent, to exceed it by just 5 percent.
Mr. Florio's plan does not incorporate that restriction and gives districts unlimited spending freedom. His aides said imposing curbs on affluent districts could, over time, diminish the quality of their schools and ultimately harm the economy of their regions.
 
Possible New Challenges
Ms. Morheuser sharply criticized the lack of spending caps today. She said that educational quality would remain a function of local property wealth and that new constitutional challenges were inevitable if Mr. Florio's formula were enacted.
The legislative panels also heard criticism from the New Jersey Association of School Administrators, which represents superintendents; the New Jersey Principals and Supervisors Association, and the New Jersey Association of School Business Officials, which represents business administrators.
They join the New Jersey School Boards Association and the New Jersey Education Association, the union representing 130,000 teachers, in voicing major misgivings over the bill, including what they consider the plan for its hasty enactment.

HEADLINE: Bush Decision Expected on Whether to Delay Offshore Oil Drilling

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHABECOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 4

 BODY:
President Bush can be expected to announce in a few weeks his decision on whether to delay any oil drilling off the coasts of Florida and California until more environmental studies can be done, Administration officials said today.
Stephen Hart, a White House spokesman, said the President had not yet made up his mind about whether to let oil companies drill off the coasts of southwestern Florida, Southern California and Northern California. But officials said that given the facts available to Mr. Bush, he was likely to choose a delay. 
The officials said a panel appointed by the President to study the three areas found that the lease sales could cause ''unacceptable changes to local environments'' and recommended additional study before they proceed.
Moreover, a decision to proceed with drilling could be damaging to Republican candidates for governor in the two states: Gov. Bob Martinez of Florida and Senator Pete Wilson of California.
 
Opposition Along Coast
Offshore oil activity is strongly opposed by coastal communities and their political representatives in those two states.
By denying the appropriations necessary for the Interior Department to carry out its sale of leases to oil companies, Congress has effectively blocked oil and gas activity on areas of the outer continental shelf off California, Florida and other areas for nearly a decade. Even if Mr. Bush decided to move forward in the three areas at issue, Congress would almost certainly impose another moratorium on drilling in those areas.
Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr., frustrated with the continuing delay in offshore oil leasing activities, recently announced a new plan to ''jump-start'' the program.
In the department's next five-year plan for the outer continental shelf, scheduled to begin in 1992, Mr. Lujan plans to scrap the policy, instituted in 1981 by former Interior Secretary James G. Watt, of making the entire 1.4-billion-acre outer continental shelf available for drilling. Instead, Mr. Lujan plans to exclude environmentally sensitive areas from the leasing program and offer only those tracts shown to have a high potential for producing large areas of oil and gas.
If Mr. Bush were to order the lease sales off California and Florida to move forward immediately, it could jeopardize the entire five-year plan, one official said.
 
Lease Cancellation Unlikely
But the President is unlikely to permanently cancel the Florida and California leases.
Mr. Bush, an oil industry entrepreneur before he entered public life, is concerned about having adequate supplies of energy to assure economic growth and to minimize dependence on foreign sources. The United States is already importing over 40 percent of its oil, much of it from politically volatile countries in the Middle East.
But simply delaying leasing off Florida and California is likely to be regarded as an inadequate solution by man in the affected areas and others who worry about the potential effects on the marine environment and related economic activities like fishing and tourism.
''Any decision that doesn't incorporate permanent protection will be viewed with disappointment and skepticism by environmentalists,'' said Lisa Speer, a scientist and expert on offshore oil issues for the Natural Resources Defense Council, a national environmental group.
''Secretary Lujan talks about a bold stroke to jump-start the offshore program, but token delays are not a bold stroke,'' Ms. Speer insisted.
Mr. Hart said today that the documents needed for the President to reach a decision on the offshore leases had not yet reached his desk.
