HEADLINE: Beginning Scientists Face a Research Fund Drought

BYLINE: By GINA KOLATA

 BODY:
DR. KATHERINE WILSON joined the Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine recently with high hopes. The university had hired her as an assistant professor of cell biology and anatomy and invested $350,000 in her laboratory equipment and salary.
But there was one problem. She had to bring in grant money to run the laboratory. Dr. Wilson applied to the National Institutes of Health, the largest source of funds for biomedical research. She asked for a million dollars to pay for her research and overhead expenses for five years to study cell division. In a letter from N.I.H., she was informed that her proposal was ''highly worthwhile'' and ''likely to yield new and important information.'' The proposal was rated in the top 25 percent of those submitted.
But she was turned down. There was not enough money in the N.I.H. budget to finance all the high-quality proposals for new research. The financing squeeze occurred even though the N.I.H. budget has been rising rapidly for many years - from $3.2 billion in the fiscal year 1980 to $7.5 billion in 1990 - and even though biomedical research has been very generously financed compared with most other areas of research. But amid this overall abundance, administrative choices and other factors have limited the money available for new grants. 
Dr. Wilson squeaked by with a two-year grant from the American Cancer Society for a total of $250,000 and she is applying to the N.I.H. again. But like her fellow young biomedical researchers, she is deeply worried about her future.
''We love what we do,'' Dr. Wilson said. ''It is basic research, but we have seen all the spinoffs and we know it is valuable.'' But, she added, ''If we apply again and we don't get grants, there is a very good chance that many of us will just call in the chips.''
Scientists of all ranks, from Nobel laureates to graduate students, say stories like Dr. Wilson's have become common. They and administrators at the National Institutes of Health say the reasons for the sudden money drought include soaring costs of doing research, more money than ever tied up in long-term grants and more scientists applying.
The fund problem has caused leading scientists to speak out with alarm.
''It's the most important problem facing us today,'' said Dr. Philip Leder, a member of the National Academy of Sciences, who is head of the genetics department at Harvard University's School of Medicine. ''It is having a devastating impact on the morale and enthusiasm of young people.''
The Institute of Medicine is studying what long- and short-term solutions might be feasible, said Dr. Samuel Thier, the institute's president, who said a meeting with the National Academy of Sciences would be held June 27 to discuss ''what can be done to buffer the effect.''
Some administrators have asked, however, whether the pitch of hysteria in the scientific community has become too fevered.
''Some of the anxiety relates to the perception of the good old days that aren't here anymore,'' said Dr. James Wyngaarden, a former N.I.H. director. His remarks, published in a recent issue of The Journal of N.I.H. Research, indicated that he thinks there is a problem with funds for basic research but that the most important research is done by a small cadre of elite scientists, so that it may not be so harmful to cut out good, but not stellar scientists.
 
Loss of Young Researchers
''The dilemma becomes whether we protect the largest number of scientists or make certain that the most productive scientists are adequately funded,'' he wrote.
Scientists and administrators say that if more money does not become available to young researchers, they will be driven out of basic research, irrevocably damaging the next generation of American research.
N.I.H. research grants account for about 75 percent of all biomedical research funds provided by the Federal Government and private nonprofit sources, the N.I.H. says.
The number of N.I.H. grants awarded for new research projects and continuing ones that must compete again for approval has dropped sharply, from 6,446 in fiscal year 1987 to an estimated4,633 in the current fiscal year. So few new grants are available that the percentage of worthy applicants who are able to obtain funds has dropped to a record low. In recent years, N.I.H. has typically received about 19,000 applications for grants. The vast majority are approved as worthy of financing by peer review panels. But the percentage of the approved proposals that actually received funds fell from 38.3 percent in 1987 to an estimated 24.1 percent in this fiscal year.
For young scientists submitting their first grant application, the figure is even worse. Dr. Marvin Cassman, deputy director of the National Institute of General Medical Sciences, reports that just 11 to 16 percent of those whose grant applications are approved for financing actually receive any funds.
 
Slamming a Door Shut
''We've never had a time in which the field is better equipped,'' said Dr. Keith Yamamoto, a microbiologist who reviews N.I.H. grant proposals in his specialty. But Dr. Yamamoto, a member of the National Academy of Sciences and a professor at the University of California at San Francisco added: ''The system now appears to be slamming the door in the face of young people. We have a real crisis on our hands.''
The research is the sort that can lead to new drugs and diagnostic techniques and new understanding of questions like why a cell becomes cancerous or why brain cells die in diseases like Alzheimer's.
The financing problem has several sources, researchers and administrators say. The major one, some administrators and senior scientists say, is that the N.I.H. has become more heavily committed to grants it has already financed, leaving less money for new grant applications. Starting in 1987, in response to demands from leaders of biomedical research, N.I.H. began extending the duration of its grants so scientists would not be forced to return as often to seek more money. Whereas previously it financed projects for an average of three years, it began financing many grants for five years or more.
Although scientists had clamored for just such a system, they had not anticipated living with the consequences. The money that would ordinarily be availble for new grants is now being used in part to pay for the added years of the old grants. The leadership of N.I.H. had made no provision to assure that there would be enough money to pay for both the old and the new grants.
''It's like someone who bought a house with very large interest payments,'' said Dr. David Korn, dean of Stanford University's School of Medicine. ''Your income isn't big enough to pay the mortgage, buy gas for the car and feed your family.'' One way to deal with it, he said, is ''to make fewer obligations.'' In the case of the N.I.H. budget, that means fewer grants, he said.
One factor exacerbating the problem, many researchers say, is that science research costs more than ever. Increasingly advanced equipment and methodology have put the research inflation rate above 10 percent a year, whereas the N.I.H. budget has increased only a few percent a year, Dr. Cassman said.
Another reason, some scientists say, is that special projects, like the human genome and AIDS, are competing for funds with other basic research. The most recent budget increase was 4.7 percent, from 1989 to 1990, but if the money set aside for AIDS and the project for mapping all human genes is excluded, the budget increase was 3.7 percent for the past fiscal year, Dr. Cassman said.
Dr. Yamamoto said even though AIDS and the genome project may not be major contributors to the fund problem, many researchers are resentful of what they perceive as a laxity in awarding those project funds. ''These are big ticket items that have gotten a pat on the head from the bureaucracy, but there is a perception that the research is not as good,'' he said. ''I think it's a perception that is widely felt in the community and I share it.''
Another reason, some scientists say, is that more scientists are seeking grants than in the past.
Uncommitted money is now so tight that reviewers cannot discriminate on objective grounds between grants that are financed and many of those that are not, scientists on review committees said. ''The ranking system falls apart,'' Dr. Leder said.
 
End of a Career
For a young scientist, not getting an N.I.H. grant can end a career in academic science. Dr. Ponzy Lu, a chemistry professor at the University of Pennsylvania, said that he has repeatedly warned a young faculty member in his department, Dr. David Christianson, ''that if he wants to get tenure, he has to get an N.I.H. grant.''
Although there are no national data to indicate how students and scientists are affected by the difficulty in getting research money, anecdotal data abound.
Dr. J. Michael Bishop, a professor of microbiology and immunology at the University of California in San Francisco and the recipient of the 1989 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine, said that even some high school students who are interested in science are growing leery because of the financing situation.
Dr. Bishop said he recently spoke toa group of elite high school students who were interested in science. But he was dismayed when, ''One after another, they said, 'We heard that scientists can't get the money they need to do research so we're thinking of other careers.' ''

HEADLINE: A Haze of Debt Clouds The Plaza Hotel's Gleam

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
Donald J. Trump is fond of calling the Plaza Hotel, which he bought two years ago, ''the ultimate trophy in the world.'' But the famed Manhattan luxury hotel has proved to be a costly trophy.
Under Mr. Trump's stewardship, the Plaza is filling more of its rooms and charging more for them. Yet because he borrowed heavily to buy the Plaza and spruce it up, the improved profits are still not high enough to cover the interest payments on his bank loans. So the Plaza drains cash from other Trump Organization businesses, consuming more money than it generates.
That cash-flow problem is similar to the pinch Mr. Trump faces with other properties, including the Trump Shuttle airline. Mr. Trump's cash bind is a key reason he has been forced to open talks with bankers in what is apparently an effort to restructure some of his loans. 
For his part, Mr. Trump still exudes confidence. He says he remains optimistic and appears to believe that the Plaza will not be hurt by the sluggish New York City economy.
Real estate analysts contend that he paid too much for the Plaza, at $390 million, not to mention the $50 million he says he has spent on renovations. But Mr. Trump seems to hold no such qualms. He asserts that if he chose to sell the grand old hotel he would have little trouble finding a buyer willing to pay substantially more than the $440 million he invested.
''There is always somebody to pay more,'' Mr. Trump said in a recent interview, recalling his $100 million profit on the sale of another Manhattan hotel, the San Moritz, to Alan Bond, the Australian financier whose empire has since collapsed under a mountain of debt.
The Plaza, by some accounts, is a much improved hotel from the one Mr. Trump bought. ''They really have done a spectacular job of renovating the property,'' said Arthur Adler, a partner with the accounting firm of Laventhol & Horwath who specializes in New York hotels.
Indeed, the Plaza's new chandeliers gleam, conference rooms are bright and inviting, and ballrooms are restored to the grandeur that made the Plaza New York's premier hotel when it opened in 1907 just south of Central Park and just off Fifth Avenue.
By aggressively courting both foreign travelers and corporate executives, the Plaza has managed to fill more rooms than it did when it was run by Westin Hotels and Resorts, and to charge sharply higher rates. This year, it hopes to average $280 a night in room charges, up from $249 last year and $233 in 1988.
 
Financial Reports Disclosed
Over all, the hotel's operating performance has improved substantially. Angered by reports of large losses at the Plaza, Mr. Trump and his aides, including Richard R. Wilhelm, the Plaza's vice president and general manager, provided monthly profit-and-loss reports dating from the fall of 1987, along with projections for the rest of 1990, on the condition that many of the exact numbers not be printed. These financial statements had been reviewed by independent auditors.
The reports show that the hotel's operating profit - before interest payments and income taxes, and ignoring such non-cash charges as depreciation - rose to $20 million in 1989, from $16 million in 1988, when the hotel was under Mr. Trump's ownership for less than half the year. In this year's first quarter, traditionally a weak period, the profit came to $4.3 million, up from $1.6 million in the 1989 period.
Still, operating profits do not tell the entire story of a hotel. Because Mr. Trump borrowed the money to buy the Plaza, paying interest of about 10 percent a year, with much of the debt floating at around the prime rate, the hotel must show an operating profit of more than $40 million a year just to break even. Last year, the Plaza fell almost $24 million short of that goal. Add in the renovation expenses, and the hotel consumed $74 million more in cash than it earned.
 
Pressing Need for Cash
Financially, the Plaza resembles another recent Trump acquisition, the Trump Shuttle. Mr. Trump calls the airline ''an esthetic success,'' but it, too, is not throwing off any cash.
While both may yet prove to be financial successes, Mr. Trump needs to find cash to support them. In an interview, he refused to discuss cash flow for his empire, but with some loans on his Atlantic City casino operations coming due soon, he may have to rely on bank loans. While some bankers say privately that they are comfortable with their loans to Trump operations, and are willing to make more, others say they are nervous.
The Plaza management is hoping the hotel will stop being a cash drain for Mr. Trump in 1990 - that is, break even after the interest payments. But to do so, the hotel will have to improve substantially on last year's results at a time when the New York economy is weakening.
''Basically, our goal is to break even, to give Donald $1 after all the expenses,'' said Ivana Trump, the hotel's president and Mr. Trump's wife. Even, she was asked, after extensive publicity of their marital troubles? ''I still want to give him the dollar,'' she responded.
 
Bathrobes and Gift Items
Part of the success that the Plaza has enjoyed under Mr. Trump has come from a resolute desire to leave no potential source of profit untapped. The hotel is more aggressively marketing items like Plaza towels and bathrobes, and Mr. Wilhelm said it had managed to persude many suppliers to provide substantial discounts in return for the privilege of advertising that they are suppliers to the Plaza. That, he said, is part of ''the Trump factor.''
In addition, the hotel has embarked on a drive to find extra space to rent out. The catering and marketing staffs were ousted from rooms with a nice view of Fifth Avenue, creating more banquet and meeting rooms. The employees were moved into offices carved out of what Mr. Wilhelm calls ''the largest ladies' room in the history of mankind.''
The Plaza also embarked on a drive to get more of the revenue from various spaces that had been leased out. The newsstand and gift shop, which had produced $120,000 a year in rent, was taken away from the lessee and is now operated by the hotel. Mr. Wilhelm estimates that it could add $850,000 a year to the hotel's profits.
 
Recycling Beer and Soda Cans
Upset by big increases in the cost of trash removal, the hotel has begun sorting all of its trash, separating newspapers for recycling and beer and soda cans for the five-cent deposit. The outside contractor that used to clean the chandeliers was dismissed. Hotel workers now do the job.
In an effort to trim expenses, Mrs. Trump said she monitors weekly reports on revenues versus labor costs, the highest single expense for a hotel. In June 1989, she said, labor costs came to 29 percent of the Plaza's $8.6 million in revenues, but this month the plan calls for them to account for only 25 percent of the expected $10.2 million in revenues.
The immediate problem for the hotel is getting through the summer. Last July and August, burdened by the renovation, the hotel lost about $150,000, even before interest costs. This year, projections call for operating profits of more than $2 million, even without additional occupancy, assuming it can charge more for rooms.
Still, a slowing New York economy could make those anticipated profits elusive. ''I think there is a big decline in the hotel industry,'' Mrs. Trump said. ''The people are discounting like crazy.'' Nonetheless, she expressed confidence that the hotel will meet its profit targets.
Just how large a role Mrs. Trump plays at the Plaza is a source of much speculation outside the hotel, in part because Mr. Trump played down her contribution when talking to reporters about a possible divorce. (He now says she has done ''a nice job.'') In an interview, Mrs. Trump expressed irritation at the speculation. ''They talk like I make the beds or something,'' she said, without specifying whom she was referring to. ''I know what they are saying.''
In fact, she said, she is active both in marketing the Plaza internationally and in keeping a close watch on operations. ''They say I don't know the business or the numbers,'' she said. ''I know the numbers. I always did.'' Certainly, in the interview, she seemed familiar with a wealth of operating figures.
 
Effect of Higher Room Tax
But the success or failure of the Plaza as an investment for Mr. Trump now probably hinges more on the future of the New York economy than on his wife's management skills. Mr. Trump, along with most other observers, sees signs of a slowing, and there are some worries that the local convention business may be damaged by New York State's decision to raise the tax on hotel rooms.
The tax will soon rise to 18.25 percent of the room rate, plus $2, an increase of five percentage points. If the Plaza does average $280 in rent for its rooms, as it plans, the customer will end up paying $333.
Despite the uncertainties, Mr. Wilhelm said he hopes operating profits will rise to $46 million in 1991 and $51 million in 1992, providing a profit after interest payments of about $10 million in 1992, and perhaps enabling Mr. Trump to begin paying down the debt on the Plaza.

HEADLINE: Bank Talks Confirmed By Trump

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES

 BODY:
Donald J. Trump confirmed yesterday that he was holding discussions with representatives of the banks that have helped finance his far-flung business ventures. On the news, the prices of the publicly traded bonds issued to finance Mr. Trump's three casinos in Atlantic City plummeted, reflecting the market's increasing nervousness about the Trump financial condition.
In a terse statement released in response to a report in The Wall Street Journal, the Trump Organization said that Trump aides were ''meeting with major banks and are having cooperative and constructive discussions.'' It added, ''Based upon the excellent asset values and their long-term earnings potential, we are confident we will arrive at a mutually beneficial solution.'' 
The negotiations continued into last evening, with Trump executives being advised by their lawyers and by senior officers of Kenneth Leventhal & Company, an accounting firm based in Los Angeles that specializes in real estate valuations and transactions.
 
'In a Bit of a Jam'
A banker who has been briefed on the talks and who asked not to be identified, said: ''The situation is manageable, but he is in a bit of a jam. There are no defaults yet, but the cash-flow situation is difficult.''
The ''jam'' apparently arises because Mr. Trump faces repayment deadlines on portions of his bank debt at a time when many properties for which he borrowed the money, like the Plaza Hotel and the Trump Shuttle, are not yet producing the cash necessary to service those loans.
Several bankers informed about the talks said the negotiations were initiated about 10 days ago by Mr. Trump with Bankers Trust, Chase Manhattan, Citicorp and Manufacturers Hanover, all of which have been involved in providing credit to Trump projects for nearly a decade.
None of the banks would comment either about the talks or about the amount of credit they have extended to Mr. Trump. But one financial executive dismissed the suggestion that bankers were seeking to prevent Mr. Trump from meeting his debt service obligations to his casino bondholders.
The bonds sold to finance the casinos are secured by the casino properties themselves, this executive pointed out, and any default on debt service would give bondholders the right to seize that collateral. ''If you're a banker, the last thing you would want would be a default on a publicly traded bond that held a mortgage on the property,'' he said.
Despite the security that collateral offers, however, the bond market was clearly unnerved by the reports that bankers were putting pressure on Mr. Trump. ''This is a barometer of the market's faith in this situation,'' said Raymond E. Neidl, a analyst with Dillon, Read & Company.
The bonds sold to finance the new Taj Mahal casino, which opened in April and has not yet shown whether it can sustain its initial revenue levels, were being offered at about $560 for each $1,000 in par value, a decline of roughly $90 from Friday's bids. The bonds sold to finance Trump Castle, where recent capital projects have consumed a hefty slice of the available cash flow, took a sharper dive, falling $110 to close at about $590.
The Trump Plaza bonds fared better yesterday, closing at $800, off about $50 from Friday. ''The Plaza's cash flow is so strong that they should be cash-sufficient through at least the next 12 months,'' Mr. Neidl said.
The fall in bond prices does not directly affect Mr. Trump, several analysts agreed. Indeed, the decline would theoretically make it less expensive for him to repurchase the bonds in the public market, thereby reducing the debt burden on the casinos.
 
Questions Raised on Debts
But yesterday's reaction does illustrate how nervous the market has become about Mr. Trump's financial health in recent months, as various reports have raised questions about whether the developer can service the debts he has run up as he assembled his extensive empire.
It did not help, a bond trader said, that Mr. Trump himself had not disclosed the bank talks. ''If something like this is going on,'' he added, ''you're much better off getting it all out front.''
Much of the brief Trump statement yesterday was devoted to praising the quality of the Trump holdings. Mr. Trump, through various private entities, owns properties that include the Plaza Hotel, the Trump Shuttle, the retail and commercial space in the Trump Tower, half of the Grand Hyatt Hotel, an undeveloped 76-acre site on New York's Upper West Side, and a controlling share of Alexander's, the retail chain.
 
Tied to Weakening Economy
But most of those properties are harnessed, in one way or another, to the weakening economy in the New York area, which makes it more difficult for businesses like the Shuttle and the Plaza Hotel to operate profitably. That, in turn, makes it harder for Mr. Trump to sell his holdings for more than he has invested.
Moreover, bankers have grown increasingly cautious about real estate loans, and the market for high-yield ''junk bonds'' is no longer a ready source of borrowed cash. That affects Mr. Trump as well as those who might wish to borrow to buy some of his assets.
Associates point out that Mr. Trump is an experienced and cautious developer who has weathered real estate cycles, tight credit and depressed property values. It was in just such an environment that he made his first foray into New York real estate in the late 1970's, the transformation of the decrepit Commodore Hotel, next to Grand Central Station, into the Grand Hyatt Hotel, which became the linchpin of East 42d Street's renewal.
It was on that base that he assembled his empire during the 1980's, relying increasingly on borrowed funds and junk bonds as that debt-driven decade progressed.
 
No Details on Net Worth
In a recent interview, without disclosing that he was holding talks with his bankers, Mr. Trump said he was confident he could weather any change in the New York real estate climate. He would not provide any details of his net worth, pointing out that there were numerous strategic and tax-related reasons why he might wish to minimize his wealth.
Several recent news reports have estimated Mr. Trump's total debt at $2.3 billion and measured the annual debt service at roughly $255 million. Estimates of the cash his properties are producing each year fall considerably short of that debt service, although bankers report that Mr. Trump is still current on all his loan repayments.
What is not clear, of course, is how much of a cash cushion Mr. Trump has assembled.

HEADLINE: New Research Group Wary Of U.S. Global Enterprises

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
A new research organization, the Economic Strategy Institute, built on the prestige of Clyde V. Prestowitz Jr., opens in Washington today, dedicated to the proposition that American corporations should not be lured into becoming ''stateless'' global enterprises.
Through studies and Congressional testimony, the new institute will push the Prestowitz view that in the long run, the profitablity of American-owned companies depends on maintaining the United States as the center for their best manufacturing and research operations.
''Given that most Americans work in American-owned companies, I don't believe that you can have highly skilled people turning out sophisticated products unless most of this is done in American companies right here at home,'' said Mr. Prestowitz, the institute's founder and president. 
Mr. Prestowitz popularized his America-first approach in his book ''Trading Places,'' an account of the nationalistic corporate practices that made Japan a world leader in automobiles, semiconductors and other industries once dominated by the United States. Drawing on his experience as a businessman in Japan and as a Japan specialist for the Commerce Department, he argues that the Federal Government must similarly help American industry to sustain the nation's standard of living.
The new research institute presents itself as the capital's first such group set up specifically to counter the global tendency of American corporations. The argument of such companies is that their profits - and often their best technologies - come increasingly from European and Asian subsidiaries. Indeed, the overseas subsidiaries of America-owned companies now sell products worth more than $700 billion abroad, twice the nation's annual exports.
One forthcoming institute study, for example, is likely to conclude that the recent United States-Japan trade negotiations, in which the Japanese agreed to purchase more American satellites, supercomputers and wood products, probably will not achieve the promised trade breakthroughs.
Other studies are likely to argue for Federal subsidies for high-technology research and for national planning to promote American-owned high-technology industries. Still others, assessing the boom in foreign investment in the United States, will probably find that foreign companies, European and Japanese, hold back their best technologies from their American operations.
''They start out using foreign components, and while they eventually do substantial research and value-added manufacturing in this country, the general history is that it does not happen that quickly,'' Mr. Prestowitz said.
 
Corporate Sponsors
Ten corporations supplied most of the nonprofit institute's $1.4 million in first-year financing. The list of donors includes Motorola Inc. and the Ford Motor Company, both in the forefront of the global movement, The North American Philips Corporation, the Dutch-owned electronics company, is also a donor.
The Motorola and Philips support illustrates contradictions in the global trend. One goal at Philips, for example, is to make its United States subsidiary as American as possible.
''Our relationship with the Economic Strategy Institute demonstrates, if you will, our commitment to being an American company,'' said Daniel F. Minahan, the executive vice president.
Motorola, on the other hand, has set up a research facility in Japan to develop a new highway technology that signals traffic jams and other road problems to drivers on dashboard computers. Japanese Government support has made Japan a leader in this technology, which is why Motorola set up shop in Japan. The problem is that the Japanese are likely to be the first customers for a home-grown technology and ''they aren't likely to buy from an American company,'' said Richard Heimlich, a Motorola vice president.
Motorola seeks Federal support for similar American technology. ''We look to the Economic Strategy Institute to bring these issues out into the open,'' Mr. Heimlich said.

HEADLINE: Dow Up 34.22 Points, to a High of 2,935.19

BYLINE: By DANIEL F. CUFF

 BODY:
Without looking back, the stock market advanced into uncharted territory yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average pushing well past 2,900. With an apparent clear horizon for inflation and interest rates, the Dow gained 34.22 points as buying surged in the afternoon.
The Dow closed at 2,935.19, setting a record high again after it reached the 2,900 mark Friday, ending a week that saw the average increase 80 points. Other indexes were strong. The S.&P. 500 posted a fifth straight high at 367.40, up 4.24. The Dow Jones transportation index reached a high for the year, gaining 18.43 points, and the utility index rose 3.71 points. 
Trading volume reached 175.5 million shares, down from Friday's 187.9 million. Advancing issues numbered 1,105, while only 477 declined. Financial issues were strong.
The Dow hugged the 2,900 mark most of the morning as blue chips traded in a narrow range. In the final hours, stocks surged as more money managers bought in and selling abated.
''It's still a case of some newly converted optimists flush with cash and undercommitted to the equity market,'' said Michael Metz, chief market analyst for Oppenheimer & Company.
''There's really been no radical change in the external world,'' Mr. Metz said. ''But it looks like we are having a slowdown without a recession. And if the Fed is going to change it will be toward easing interest rates. All of this is a recipe for higher stock prices.''
 
Transportation Index Advances
Some analysts saw confirmation of broad market strength in the Dow transportation and utility indexes. The transportation index surpassed its high for 1990 as it rose to 1,207.85. The 12-month top of 1,532.01 is much higher, but was distorted by earlier merger and buyout activity, analysts said.
''A lot of analysts are saying that the market is being narrowly led by blue chips,'' said Robert H. Stovall of Stovall/Twenty-First Advisers. ''There was confirmation that it was not a true-blue market in the form of the S.&P. 500 index. Now today we have a transporation new high for the year and the recently dormant utilities are beginning to move up in response to lower interest rates.''
Also helped by the outlook for lower interest rates were financial issues. American Express gained 1 7/8, to 31 5/8. BankAmerica, rose 1 1/4, to 32 5/8, and Federal National Mortgage was up 2, to 43 5/8.
First Interstate added 6 1/4, to 44 7/8, with a 500,000-share block traded at 41 1/4, and Wells Fargo jumped 3 5/8, to 84 1/2.
First Interstate said it knew of no corporate developments for the rise in its stock. A Wells Fargo spokesman told Reuters that there has been speculation about a matchup for six months or more but declined to confirm or deny Wells Fargo's interest.
Corroon & Black, a United States insurance broker that plans to merge with Willis Faber, a London insurance broker, fell 2 1/4, to 34 1/4. The deal valued Corroon & Black shares at $38.15, traders said.
L.A. Gear, the athletic footwear maker that was hit hard last week on its outlook, fell 1/8, to 30 5/8, leading the most active list.
Wal-Mart Stores gained 2 1/4, to 60 5/8, as the company told of plans to double the number of stores by the end of the decade.
Compaq Computer jumped 5 3/8, to 124 3/4. Michele Preston, an analyst with Cowen & Company, reiterated a buy recommendation.
Philip Morris continued active and strong, at 44 1/2, up 1 1/4.
The Amex market value index closed up 0.57, to 364.40. The Nasdaq composite rose 3.48, to 465.61.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
U.S. Securities Rise in Light Day

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The rally in the credit markets continued yesterday, as prices of Treasury securities rose in light trading.
The gains represented a reversal from early in the session, when traders took profits in the wake of Friday's big rally. But the selling did not last long.
''The fundamental situation is pretty bullish and the fact that the market is not going to see any new paper for awhile means that the technicals are getting better every day,'' one government bond trader said. ''At times like these, the market moves up faster and easier than it does down. And it stood the test that it had to stand on a Monday following a big week-ending rally.'' 
Bond prices rallied sharply on Friday after the Labor Department reported that employment growth in May was far weaker than most analysts had anticipated.
The fifth straight daily decline in the Commodity Research Bureau's index of major commodity futures prices and a further drop in gold prices also provided some support to the market yesterday.
''There is a firm bid underneath the market,'' said Ward McCarthy, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, a Princeton, N.J., firm that provides research and commentary on developments in the fixed-income and foreign exchange markets.
''That firm bid is symptomatic of a people who are afraid they will miss something if they stay out.''
Even though employment data have been weak for three straight months, a trend that strongly suggests the economy is losing steam, the prevailing view among credit market analysts is that the Federal Reserve will delay any easing of monetary policy until sometime in July, after it has seen further evidence that inflation is slowing.
Mr. McCarthy does not share that view.
''I think the Fed will ease in June, after the May producer price and consumer price figures come out,'' he said. ''That easing, which will push the funds rate to 8 percent from its current level of 8 1/4 percent, will be nicely timed in advance of Alan Greenspan's Humphrey-Hawkins testimony to Congress in July, and will take some political heat off of him.''
The Federal Reserve, which is headed by Mr. Greenspan, gave no indication yesterday that it had initiated a change in policy, as the rate for overnight bank loans in the Federal funds market traded in a narrow range around 8 1/4 percent throughout the session.
At the weekly bill auction, the Treasury sold three-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.69 percent, down sharply from an average rate of 7.80 percent at last week's sale.
Bids on the six-month bills sold yesterday produced an average discount rate of 7.62 percent, compared with an average rate of 7.74 percent a week ago.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 3/4 percent bonds of 2020 were offered in late trading at a price of 103 19/32, up 7/32, to yield 8.41 percent. Late Friday the benchmark issue was offered at a price to yield 8.44 percent.
Among note issues, the 8 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 102 30/ 32, up 1/8 point, to yield 8.43 percent. And the 8 1/2 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 3/8, up 1/32, to yield 8.29 percent.
Activity in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds was light yesterday, dealers said. Prices of most widely quoted issues were little changed on the day.
In the tax-exempt municipal bond market, traders said that prices of most issues were unchanged in dull trading.
Following are the results of yesterday's auction of three-month and six-month Treasury bills:

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Brady's Remarks on Rates Send Dollar Down at Close

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
After a mixed performance overseas, the dollar declined yesterday in domestic trading against most currencies except the British pound and Japanese yen.
Trading volume was light because most European markets were closed for the Whitmonday holiday.
Comments by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, implying that United States interest rates could be heading lower, knocked the dollar down as trading ended in New York. As a result, the dollar closed near its lowest levels of the session. 
Mr. Brady, speaking at the International Monetary Conference luncheon in San Francisco, expressed optimism that a budget agreement could be reached between Congress and the Bush Adminstration that would reduce interest rates.
Currency dealers said the effect of Mr. Brady's remarks was exaggerated because of the market's low liquidity. Markets in continental Europe were closed; of the European markets, only those in London were open.
''For the most part, it was a very quiet, dull day, with the dollar stuck in a narrow range,'' said Bob Morrissey, senior currency trader at the Bank of Boston's office in New York.
Attention was generally focused on trading between the dollar and West German mark. Speculation about possible intervention by West Germany's central bank to prop up the mark restrained the dollar. In New York, the dollar closed at 1.6905 marks, down from 1.6985.
The dollar rose against the Japanese yen. But dealers in New York and London said the gains reflected momentum from Asian buying rather than a fundamental improvement in sentiment toward the dollar. In New York, the dollar ended at 152.65 yen, up from 151.85 on Friday.
The dollar's trading day began in Tokyo with a gain of 0.25 Japanese yen, to a closing level of 152.42 yen. Later, in London, the dollar was quoted at 152.65 yen.
Weakness in the British pound favored the dollar. A pound fetched $1.6745 late in the day in London, down from $1.6840 late Friday. The pound lost strength in New York, falling to $1.6770, from $1.6810 on Friday.
Selected late dollar rates in New York, compared with those of late Friday, included: 1.4340 Swiss francs, down from 1.4375; 5.696 French francs, down from 5.7295; 1,243.00 Italian lire, down from 1,250.375, and 1.17475 Canadian dollars, up from 1.17465.
Other late dollar rates in London, compared with late Friday's levels were: 1.6940 West German marks, unchanged; 1.4390 Swiss francs, up from 1.4358; 5.7080 French francs, down from 5.7180; 1,245.50 Italian lire, down from 1,247.25; 1.9068 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9073, and 1.1763 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1728.
Gold prices declined. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, an ounce of gold for June delivery edged down 60 cents, to $358.60. The Republic National Bank quoted a late bid of $357.40 for gold bullion, $1.35 lower than on Friday.

HEADLINE: Confidence Index Slips

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Consumers were slightly less confident about the economy in May than in the previous month, according to a monthly survey released yesterday by the Conference Board.
The business research group's index of consumer confidence stood at 106.7 in May, down from 107.3 in April. Consumers' opinions of current conditions fell slightly, while expectations for the future were virtually the same.
The index is considered an important barometer of spending behavior; consumer spending accounts for much of the economic activity in the United States.
About 23 percent of the survey participants believed business conditions were good, while 20 percent said they were bad. The percentages are down slightly from April, as is consumer opinion on the availability of jobs.
More than 18 percent expect business conditions to improve in the next six months, while 10 percent fear they will worsen. The figures are virtually the same as those for April.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Booksellers Mixed on Fall Outlook

BYLINE: By EDWIN MCDOWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS, Nev., June 4

 BODY:
The annual convention of the American Booksellers Association is as much a pep rally for publishers as an occasion to show off their wares for the fall. So it is understandable that many publishers exude optimism despite what others say are troubling times.
''Our industry is still sluggish, and the consumer doesn't seem to be coming into the stores the way we would like,'' said Alberto Vitale, the chairman and chief executive of Random House Inc.
But Mr. Vitale predicted that Random House's fall book list, including the works of its subsidiaries and imprints, would bring buyers into the stores. Other publishers and booksellers agree that this fall's lineup of books by name authors is one of the strongest in memory. 
 
Many Noted Authors
From just Alfred A. Knopf, a Random House subsidiary, those authors include John Updike, Anne Rice, Gabriel Garcia Marquez, Tom Peters and Jacobo Timerman.
The Random House imprint includes a long-awaited novel from Norman Mailer; nonfiction from William Styron, and another book from Donald J. Trump, the New York developer, as well as a novel and a nonfiction work by William F. Buckley Jr. And Crown, another Random imprint, plans a first printing of at least a million copies of ''The Plains of Passage,'' a novel by Jean Auel.
Works will also be published this fall by Stephen King for Viking; Sidney Sheldon for William Morrow & Company; Larry McMurtry and Jackie Collins, each for Simon & Schuster; Dick Francis and Dean R. Koontz, both for G. P. Putnam; Mario Vargas Llosa for Farrar, Straus & Giroux; Cleveland Amory for Little, Brown; Elmore Leonard and Belva Plain, each for Delacorte; Len Deighton for Bessie/HarperCollins; James Herriot for St. Martin's Press; Victoria Holt for Doubleday, and Andrew Greeley for Warner Books.
Gary P. DelVecchio, president of Doubleday's 41 book shops, agrees that the lists are impressive. ''But the big uncertainty is the national economy,'' he warned. He said he was nervous that many of the novels would cost $22.95, up to $3 more than current prices for fiction.
But the immediate outlook for booksellers is for continued good health, with retail sales being projected at $7.2 billion this year, up from $6.6 billion in 1989, according to William Lofquist, a specialist in book sales for the Commerce Department.
Bernard Rath, the association's executive director, said during the four-day event that so many people wanted to open bookstores that the association's 4,700 membership could double during the 1990's.
More than 6,200 booksellers are attending the convention, the largest book event in the English language, which ends on Tuesday night.
Many delegates who were apprehensive about coming to Las Vegas, in part because they regard its get-rich-quick values as fundamentally antithetical to those of the book industry, quickly came to terms with this desert city.
''I was opposed to holding the convention here, but I've changed my mind,'' said Liv Blumer, the director of subsidiary rights for Warner Books. ''The city is tacky, but it's magnificently tacky.'' 606,000 Square Feet Most exhibitors are also happy with the Convention Center and its 606,000-square-foot exhibit hall. ''With almost all the exhibits on one floor, it's a good place for a convention,'' said Steven J. Mason, the president of the Ingram Book Company, a large book distributor based in Nashville.
The 1,400 exhibitors include suppliers to the book industry, as well as companies that sell books on audio tape and videocassette. Also registered are many representatives of television, radio and film, who prowl the aisles looking for authors and for books to option.
Foreign publishers are here in greater numbers than ever. More than 100 booths display books from Spain, France, Argentina, Hungary, Colombia, Mexico and other nations. British, Canadian and Australian publishers are here in force, while three Soviet publishers and two Soviet booksellers are guests of the booksellers association and the Association of American Publishers, another industry group.
''The overall costs of attending have increased astronomically,'' said Morton Mint, the chief executive of Penguin U.S.A. ''But we still find it very valuable from a corporate point of view.''

HEADLINE: Jack Gilford, Actor, Dead at 81; Veteran of Stage, Screen and TV

BYLINE: By PETER B. FLINT

 BODY:
Jack Gilford, the actor and comedian whose malleable face, rapier wit and buoyant manner energized scores of plays, films and television shows, died of stomach cancer yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 81 years old.
Mr. Gilford grew up in Brooklyn, learned acting by studying silent films and entering amateur contests, and gained stamina and staying power in nightclubs.
On the stage and screen, he matched barbs with a fellow Roman slave (Zero Mostel) and neatly executed a turn in drag in ''A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum.'' Also on Broadway, he slyly and elegantly romanced Lotte Lenya in ''Cabaret.'' He was nominated for Tony Awards for those two plays. 
Other stage roles were in ''Meet the People'' (1940), ''The Diary of Anne Frank'' (1955), ''Romanoff and Juliet'' (1957), ''Once Upon a Mattress'' (1959), ''The Tenth Man'' (1959), ''No, No, Nanette'' (1971) and ''Sly Fox'' (1976).
In films, he battled American materialism with Jack Lemmon in ''Save the Tiger'' in 1973, receiving an Oscar nomination as best supporting actor. His other films included ''Enter Laughing'' (1967), ''Catch 22'' (1970), ''Harry and Walter Go to New York'' (1976) and ''Cocoon'' (1985).
Television appearances included ''The Defenders,'' ''All in the Family,'' ''Rhoda,'' ''Soap,'' ''The Love Boat'' and, on cable in 1982, ''The Very Special Jack Gilford Special.''
 
From Commercials to Opera
The actor was also a long-trusted television guest in American households as a purveyor of Cracker Jack and a frequent favorite of opera devotees for his nonsinging appearances as Frosch, the besotted jailer, in the Metropolitan Opera's widely popular ''Fledermaus.''
He made his Met debut in 1950 and also played a solo act at the Palace Theater the same year, observing that ''there are not many people who played the Met and the Palace in the same year.''
Cabaret ''is the most difficult performing art,'' he tolf an interviewer. ''Audiences drink, chat and dance. You may become an intrusion. It's a constant struggle, and if you're rejected, you're standing there all alone.''
The actor, whose original name was Jacob Gellman, was born on July 25, 1907, on the Lower East Side of Manhattan to an immigrant Jewish couple, Aaron, a furrier, and the former Sophie Jackness. They divorced when he was a child, and his mother moved to the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn and made a living by bootlegging.
''She made whisky in the kitchen and sold it by the gallon,'' Mr. Gilford said. ''It probably wasn't too bad because even after repeal, customers still came to buy because they trusted it. She got arrested a couple of times and told us it wasn't she, but Prohibition, that was bad.''
Mr. Gilford's acting career began with mimicry. ''I would do people of my time, John D. Rockefeller Sr., Jimmy Walker, Calvin Coolidge,'' he said. ''I was very influenced by silent movies, particularly Laurel and Hardy, even before they were partners.''
In 1939, Barney Josephson invited him to perform in his new Manhattan club, Cafe Society, which soon became a legend. ''You could stand at the bar, nurse a beer all night and see the best talents in town,'' he recalled.
''It was the first place to let Negroes sit down at tables below 110th Street. Hazel Scott was the lull pianist between acts. A young girl named Helena Horne was the singer before she changed her name to Lena. Billie Holiday was there, too.''
 
Unemployed in the Blacklist
The low point in Mr. Gilford's career occurred in the blacklisting period after World War II. ''One day the phone just stopped ringing,'' he said, ''and I wasn't able to do films or TV for 10 years.'' He generally refused to discuss that period, though in 1956, in a hearing before a subcomittee of the House Committee on Un-American Activities, he invoked the Fifth Amendment in refusing to answer questions as to whether he had ever been a Communist. As late as 1967, he said, ''Some performers still can't get jobs.''
His first dramatic role, in ''The World of Sholom Aleichem'' in 1953, which was revived on Broadway in 1982, had a single line, which stunned audiences and became associated with him for years. His long-suffering, silent character, told in heaven that he can ask for anything, replies, ''In that case, if it's true, could I have, please, every day, a hot roll with butter?''
The actor's routines include a day in the life of a golf ball, an impression of a surrealistic movie, pea soup coming to a slow boil, a conductor afflicted by an errant clarinetist and a drowsy subway rider struggling not to sleep past his station. His performances consistently earned acclaim, with Frank Rich of The New York Times concluding in 1982 that ''no Broadway season should lack Jack Gilford.''
Surviving are his wife, Madeline Lee, a producer and actress; a daughter, Lisa, of Denver, who is the Colorado state chairman of films; two sons, Sam, an actor and jazz anthologist, of Montague, Mass., and Joe, an actor and director, of Manhattan, and two grandchildren.
A funeral service will be private, and a memorial service will be scheduled later.

CORRECTION-DATE: June 6, 1990, Wednesday, Late Edition - Final

An obituary yesterday about Jack Gilford, the actor and comedian, misstated his age. He was 82, not 81.

HEADLINE: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;
BUSH GAINS TIME AS MOSCOW DELAYS LAW ON EMIGRATION

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 5

 BODY:
A conflict between the White House and Congress over the trade accord signed at the Washington summit meeting was averted today when the Soviet Parliament said it would probably not take up a new law permitting unfettered emigration until September.
Because passage of the Soviet law is a condition for expanding trade ties with Moscow, the White House said today that President Bush would not submit the accord that he signed on Friday with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to the Senate until September at the earliest, assuming that the Soviet legislature, the Supreme Soviet, acted then.
 
Political Breathing Space
The likely delay will give the White House political breathing space to shore up support for the trade agreement. Presidential aides greeted the news from Moscow with obvious relief. 
As the results of the summit meeting were tallied, Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union announced today at a meeting of foreign ministers in Copenhagen that the Soviet Union would withdraw a small number of its short-range nuclear weapons from Central Europe. Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d lost little time in dismissing the military significance of the Shevardnadze announcement. [Page A10.] Soviet officials said the decision to postpone the vote on the emigration bill could conceivably be changed, but the legislation was not on the agenda of the Parliament's current session, which ends on June 14. The Parliament does not convene again until September.
On the trade treaty, some American officials said the Administration was aware before it signed the accord that the Soviet Union, which delayed passage of the emigration bill before, could well do so again. That would give Mr. Bush time to deal with Congressional opposition to the treaty.
But Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said this consideration ''didn't have any influence'' on Mr. Bush, who he said had ''no idea'' beforehand that the vote would be delayed until September. ''We didn't have any indication of a timetable,'' he said. ''We assumed it was totally unpredictable, just like our own Congress.''
At a meeting today with Congressional leaders, Mr. Bush defended his decision to sign the trade treaty. He has been criticized by some lawmakers for not linking the signing of the treaty to a resolution of Moscow's struggle with Lithuania over its declaration of independence. Senator George J. Mitchell, the majority leader, accused Mr. Bush of ''abandoning Lithuania.''
Several of the lawmakers who met with Mr. Bush said they warned him that the treaty would not go through the Senate as long as Moscow's dispute with Lithuania was in a stalemate.
''Even after they codify their emigration practices, if the Lithuania or Baltic problem is not resolved, then I think it will become a matter of great concern in the Congress,'' said Senator Bob Dole, the minority leader.
Administration officials said they saw the Soviet Parliament's action today as a temporary reprieve from the political battle over the trade agreement and expressed hope that Mr. Gorbachev might be able to make progress toward resolving the Baltic dispute by the time the Soviet Parliament votes on the new emigration law.
The news today from Moscow on the Parliament's agenda was the latest twist in the tortuous history of the treaty, which sets rules for Soviet-American commerce, establishes protections for American companies doing business in Moscow and would increase the volume of trade by leading to the lifting of longstanding barriers, including higher tariffs and restrictions on Soviet access to American financial markets.
Officials said that Mr. Bush warned Mr. Gorbachev five weeks ago in a letter that the proposed treaty was a political land mine because Congress was unlikely to approve it without a resolution of the Lithuanian situation or at least a lifting of Moscow's economic sanctions against the Baltic republic and the start of negotiations. The sanctions were imposed after Lithuania declared independence on March 11.
 
An Implied Warning
The letter's implied warning that no trade agreement would be signed at the Washington summit meeting was made explicit just before Mr. Gorbachev arrived, the officials said. Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh, the Soviet Ambassador to Washington, was told last Wednesday that the treaty would not be among the documents Mr. Bush was willing to approve at a signing ceremony with Mr. Gorbachev that was scheduled for Friday, an official said.
But there were sentiments within the Administration that the treaty should be signed, and even as Mr. Bessmertnykh was given the warning, the Administration was considering the option that was finally adopted - signing the treaty but holding up Senate consideration until the new emigration law was adopted, officials said.
''There was a sense that not to sign it at all would be a rebuke to Gorbachev at a time when we are trying not to show a loss of support for perestroika,'' an official said. Then, over two days of talks with Mr. Bush, Mr. Gorbachev made the trade agreement a personal issue between the Presidents, officials said.
Members of the Soviet delegation threatened, meanwhile, to scuttle a long-term grain agreement if the overall trade accord were not signed, officials said.
Mr. Fitzwater said of the delay of the emigration law: ''That may not be bad in the sense of it gives them a little time'' to work out the Lithuanian dispute and issues related to emigration. These include Mr. Gorbachev's suggestion that he might consider delaying Soviet Jews' emigration visas unless Israel guarantees that they will not settle in the occupied territories.
Mr. Fitzwater said Mr. Gorbachev's warning is ''contrary to our policy'' and added that Mr. Bush told Mr. Gorbachev that the United States wanted to see unfettered Jewish emigration.
During a discussion on human rights, Mr. Bush also expressed concern about what he perceived as rising anti-Semitism in the Soviet Union, officials said. He suggested that both leaders ''speak out against it,'' Mr. Fitzwater said.
''President Gorbachev said he would look for an opportunity to do that, but that was it,'' he said.

HEADLINE: THE SAVINGS DEBACLE: A SPECIAL REPORT:
A Financial Disaster With Many Culprits

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 5

 BODY:
The cost, which seems to mount daily, will stretch out for decades. By one current measurement, paying for the collapse of the savings and loan industry could cost American taxpayers as much as $500 billion, or about $5,000 for every household.
It is easily the biggest disaster in public finance since the Depression. Yet even though billions of dollars in precious resources were squandered in the last decade and even though the money required to undo the damage will make less available for schools, drug control and other services, the political cost of the savings crisis seems to be slight. So many politicians are to blame that few are left to point fingers.
 
Warnings Ignored
The warnings from this growing disaster were ignored in Washington for more than a decade. Yet today, polls show, most Americans do not seem to hold the Government responsible. 
Many experts believe that vigorous Government action as late as six or seven years ago might have held the savings and loan losses to $25 billion or less, an enormous sum but tiny compared with the current projections. Instead, the Government played down the problem and the losses grew and grew.
Unlike Watergate, which cost Richard M. Nixon his presidency, or Iran-contra, which shook the Reagan Administration, the collapse of the savings and loans was not the product of adventurers operating outside normal bounds. The huge debacle was rooted in politics as usual and nourished by the prevailing political and economic philosophies of the 1980's.
''This is a huge scandal,'' said Charles A. Bowsher, the Comptroller General, ''and to a large extent it was allowed to grow because of the way this town does business.''
The Carter, Reagan and Bush Administrations, eager to avoid bad economic news or measures that would throw budgets further out of balance, ignored the problem or vastly underestimated the expense of solving it. They were never taken to task by their opponents. The savings crisis was too complicated for a catchy slogan or a television sound bite.
Many of the most powerful people in Congress were blinded by friendships with savings and loan executives at home and their quest for campaign donations from an industry that had deep pockets.
Government regulatory agencies were understaffed and ill equipped. Little pressure was put on the examiners to get tough, the notion being in vogue that the Government should let the free market take its course. Yet free market principles did not apply. The Government bore most of the financial risk.
The savings and loan industry, established more than a century ago to provide home mortgages, could not cope with the relaxed regulation and the high finance of the 1980's.
Many savings and loans used the new freedoms to offer high interest rates to attract deposits and then tried to earn hefty profits with risky loans and investments, especially in real estate. Some savings and loans were run by rogues, others by incompetents. Their deals - sometimes shady, sometimes merely chancy - often went sour. Yet the savings and loan executives were not at risk. The Government was because the deposits were federally insured. So the taxpayers were left holding the bag.
Because so much money was poured into bad loans and worthless property, the United States economy has grown less, interest rates are higher, fewer people are employed, tax revenues are lower and the prospect of recession is greater. And in the years ahead, the Government will have to borrow heavily to make good on its promise to depositors.
In the end, nearly half the savings and loans may fail, and the industry itself may be extinct by the turn of the century.
How big is the problem? How did it come about? Who is at fault? What follows, in broad terms, are the answers to those questions.
 
The Cost
 
Rapid Increases In the Estimates
Last month, Nicholas F. Brady, the Secretary of the Treasury, testified that based on new projections, more than 1,000 savings associations, about 40 percent of the industry, might eventually have to be seized, at a cost to the Government of at least $89 billion and possibly as much as $130 billion. That is calculated at ''present value'' - the cost if a check were written today. It comes to roughly $1,300 for each American household.
An outside expert, Prof. Edwin W. Hill of Cleveland State University, puts the present value between $159 billion and $203 billion.
But the bill will be paid with borrowed funds. Mr. Bowsher told Congress this spring that including interest payments, the bailout would cost at least $325 billion, probably much more and possibly as much as $500 billion in the next 40 years, or $5,000 for each American household.
The projections have grown rapidly. Estimates of how many savings and loans will fail increase almost daily. The interest payments the Government must make on bonds to finance the bailout keeps rising. The value of the assets the Government can sell continues to fall. And the income the Government receives in deposit insurance premiums from healthy institutions is lagging.
Economists who have studied the savings and loan debacle say three points must be kept in mind:
* The Government has no choice but to pay what it takes to clean up the situation. Every penny will go to pay off insured depositors or to reduce what must be paid to them. Nothing will be paid to the investors.
* The biggest cost to the economy has already taken place. ''The money has already gone out the window,'' said Benjamin M. Friedman, professor of political economy at Harvard. ''It went into fraud and graft and empty office buildings.''
* The large amount of borrowing the Government must now assume to meet the savings and loan obligations is less damaging to the economy than other kinds of borrowing would be. Borrowing to build bombers or finance education reduces the amount of national savings dollar for dollar. That money is spent, and raises interest rates by reducing the amount available for lending. Almost all of the money borrowed to pay off the savings depositors will go right back into savings accounts in other institutions.
How the bailout will affect the budget deficit as measured by the Gramm-Rudman- Hollings law on balancing the budget is more complicated.
That is because the liquidation of failed savings institutions and the sale of their assets do not necessarily occur in the same fiscal year, making the deficit artificially high some in years and artificially low in others. President Bush and Congress are talking now about removing these transactions from the Gramm-Rudman calculations.
 
Fraud
 
Phony Appraisals And Kickbacks
Some savings and loans were swept under by an economic tide not of their making. But many were drowned by greedy, unscrupulous and sometimes fraudulent operators.
L. William Seidman, who is in charge of the day-to-day management of the cleanup, said that fraud had been found in 60 percent of the failed savings institutions and that in half of those, it had been the main element in the institution's demise. Phony appraisals, self-dealing, loans to family and associates, kickbacks and payoffs were rife.
The Bush Administration wants to prosecute such operators aggressively, but fraud is difficult to prove in court. ''Often truckloads of documents are involved,'' William S. Sessions, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, told Congress in April.
Even worse, ''there is a difficult dividing line between what is mismanagement and what is criminal fraud,'' said Laurence A. Urgenson, head of the fraud section of the criminal division of the Justice Department. ''Merely proving someone is acting imprudently and improperly is not enough to get a conviction.''
 
The Origins
 
Simple Business, Low in Risks
One direct cause of the crisis was the Government deposit insurance that has been part of the American social contract since the New Deal.
It permitted depositors to seek the highest possible interest rates without worrying about the soundness of the institutions and it enabled savings institutions, no matter how sick, to pull in deposits and risk that money with long odds against them, knowing that the Government stood to be the big loser.
But the roots of the savings and loan associations themselves, and their first cousins, mutual savings banks and building and loan societies, go back to the 19th century. Commercial banks had little desire for small deposits and even less for long-term loans. But Americans wanted to own their homes. Savings institutions - small businesses, sometimes little more than storefronts, often family-owned or owned mutually by the depositors themselves - accepted modest deposits and lent the money out in long-term home mortgages.
Nearly 40 percent of the nation's commercial banks failed in the Depression, wiping out millions of depositors. Savings and loan associations, with their conservative lending practices and close ties to their communities, weathered the storm. Of the 12,000 in 1930, fewer than 5 percent failed.
Franklin D. Roosevelt, who opposed to deposit insurance lest it ''put a premium on unsound banking,'' was powerless against the prevailing view that deposit insurance alone could prevent runs on banks. Early in his Presidency, he signed laws guaranteeing that Government insurance would cover up to $5,000 in bank and savings deposits. The ceiling was increased periodically over the years to keep pace with inflation.
By 1960, nearly two-thirds of American families owned their homes, the highest percentage of any large country. To encourage deposits, the rate of interest savings institutions paid was fixed by Washington at a quarter of a percentage point or a half-point above what banks were permitted to pay.
The savings associations were as much an element of a social policy to encourage home ownership as they were a commercial enterprise, and they were nutured by the American dream. It was a simple, low-risk business. The Federal Home Loan Bank Board had a dual statutory purpose: to regulate the industry and to promote it. Savings and loan executives lived by the 3-6-3 rule - pay 3 percent on deposits, charge 6 percent on mortgage loans and tee off on the golf course at 3 o'clock.
 
The Squeeze
 
A Sudden Bulge In Interest Rates
In the late 1970's, the Federal Reserve's action to curb runaway inflation pushed short-term interest rates as high as 20 percent. Tens of billions of dollars were withdrawn from savings institutions and placed in Treasury securities, the new money market funds and other financial instruments that paid much higher rates of interest.
By the early 1980's, more than two-thirds of the savings industry, stuck with long-term, low-rate mortgages and a shrinking deposit base, was technically insolvent. Nearly all savings institutions were unprofitable.
A 1980 law increased the ceiling on deposit insurance to $100,000 from $40,000, expanded the savings and loans' authority to make consumer loans and started to phase out the limit on interest rates that could paid. But the flow of money out of savings accounts persisted.
In 1982, Congress permitted savings institutions to make unsecured business loans and to invest large amounts in commercial real estate.
By 1983 a recession brought inflation and so interest rates back to a relatively normal level. At this point, in the view of many scholars, the savings industry could have regained its health - had most executives been prudent and the Federal regulators tough.
 
Bad Loans
 
A Recipe For Disaster
But the oil boom in Texas, the get-rich-quick atmosphere on Wall Street, the Reagan Administration's philosophy of keeping business free of government intrusion and lawmakers' need for money to run their ever-more-expensive campaigns laid the groundwork for disaster.
Deposit insurance permitted brokers to take $1 million of investments, divide it into blocks of $100,000, and put the money wherever they could get the highest interest rate. New computer and telecommunications technology allowed this money to be moved around the country readily.
Street-corner institutions with no experience in big-time finance competed for jumbo deposits. Many doubled and tripled their deposits in months.
''Someone at the time should have said this is ludicrous; no one in finance has ever been able to grow like this and stay alive,'' said William Taylor, the chief banking regulator at the Federal Reserve, who is in line to take over management of the Government's bailout effort from Mr. Seidman.
With little of their own capital invested, savings and loan owners speculated in risky investments like ''junk bonds,'' office buildings and land development seeking the high returns they needed to pay the high rates they offered on deposits. Some were honest gamblers. But many cooked their books, made insider deals with friends and family members and paid and took kickbacks. Some used the new deposits to support opulent living.
In 1986, the bottom fell out of the oil market, and land and real estate prices, especially in the Southwest, began to plunge. The junk bond market turned sour. Many owners of savings and loan associations quickly lost their own stake in the business.
''They were like guys who had lost all their chips in a poker game and were desperate to recoup their losses,'' said Mr. Bowsher, the Government's chief auditor. The difference, Mr. Bowsher added, was that it was the Government that bore the risk of losing the pot because it was responsible for the deposits.
By 1987, the savings and loan industry had a net loss of $6 billion. The figure rose to $11 billion in 1988 and $20 billion in 1989.
 
The Blame
 
A Wide Range Of Choices
In the savings and loan scandal, there is no Richard M. Nixon or John N. Mitchell, no Ivan F. Boesky or Michael R. Milken, no Oliver L. North or John M. Poindexter. No single person bears the brunt of the blame. Many people and groups of people were at fault. Here are some of them: Congress As the crisis developed, Congress seemed to be in the pocket of the savings and loan industry, passing laws the lobbyists wanted, tying up bills they opposed, and hectoring regulators relentlessly to ease up.
How did the savings industry gain so much political influence?
Partly, no doubt, because of campaign contributions and personal favors.
The so-called Keating Five - Senators Alan Cranston of California, Dennis DeConcini of Arizona, John Glenn or Ohio and Donald W. Riegle of Michigan, all Democrats, and John McCain of Arizona, a Republican -intervened with regulators on behalf of Charles H. Keating Jr. after he gave them $1.3 million in contributions.
Representatives Jim Wright of Texas, the Speaker of the House, and Tony Coelho of California, the majority whip, were forced from office last year in part because of questionable dealings with savings officials. Fernand J. St Germain, the Rhode Island Democrat who had been chairman of the House Banking Committee, lost his seat in 1988 largely because of gifts from industry lobbyists.
But money was only a small part of the close relationship.
Senator David H. Pryor, an Arkansas Democrat who sits on the Ethics Committee, explained it this way: ''You've got to remember that each community has a savings and loan; some have two; some have four, and each of them has seven or eight board members. They own the Chevy dealership and the shoe store. And when we saw these people, we said, gosh, these are the people who are building the homes for people, these are the people who represent a dream that has worked in this country.''
 
The Reagan Administration
In eight years in office Ronald Reagan never addressed the growing savings and loan crisis publicly. David A. Stockman, his first budget director, and Donald T. Regan, first Treasury Secretary and later White House chief of staff, pressed for less Government supervision, repeatedly rejecting requests to give the savings examiners more money and staff.
''I think the Administration played ostrich right through 1988,'' said Mr. Bowsher, who was nominated by President Reagan to be Comptroller General in 1981 and confirmed by the Senate for a 15-year term. ''They didn't want the problem to be recognized until after Reagan left town.''
 
The Regulators
The Federal Home Loan Bank Board, the regulator of the savings and loan associations in the 1980's, was not up to the job.
That was in part because the industry had not required much supervision until then, and in part because they were hamstrung by the politicians. But for the most part, it was because they were tied so closely to the industry they were also responsible for promoting.
''The regulators were closer to the regulated than in any other industry in America,'' said John G. Heimann, vice chairman of Merrill Lynch Capital Markets and a former Comptroller of the Currency.
As late as 1987, officials at the bank board accepted the industry position that the problem could be grown out of. Savings banks, supervised by independent commercial bank regulators, had limits placed on their growth and strict requirements for capital reserves and accounting. They survived mostly intact.
 
Lobbyists
Within industry circles, people content with the familar business of making mortgage loans were overwhelmed by the high-rollers.
The chief lobby, the United States League of Savings Institutions, fought for ''forbearance,'' meaning waivers of normal supervisory rules that might have protected much of the industry.
The league, said Herbert M. Sandler, chairman of the highly profitable World Savings and Loan Association in Oakland, Calif., and an advocate of stricter regulatory procedures, ''was willing to risk 80 percent of the industry to save 20 percent from going under.''
 
The Future
 
Dismantling An Industry
The new regulatory structure provided by last year's Financial Institutions Reform, Recovery and Enforcement Act has had a rocky start, with policy mistakes and personnel conflicts, and the cleanup's ambitious plans are fraught with danger. It is not clear how many investors are prepared to take over the failed institutions or how much the Government will have to pay them to do so. The Government is also being pressed by real estate interests and some lawmakers to keep the asking price of its real estate high to prevent local markets from being driven down.
In any case, hundreds of institutions remain to be liquidated and many billions of dollars of property remain to be disposed of. Most Government officials and industry executives agree that a distinct savings and loan industry will not exist 10 years from now.

CORRECTION-DATE: June 25, 1990, Monday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day last Wednesday about the savings and loan failures misstated the political setting in which Congress increased deposit insurance for each account to $100,000, from $40,000. The change was made in 1980, when both houses of Congress were controlled by Democrats, not just the House of Representatives.
