HEADLINE: $85 Million for New York City Homeless Unspent

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
Two years after the New York State Legislature set aside $85 million to build permanent housing for homeless families in New York City, the Cuomo administration says it has grown impatient because the money has not been spent, and it is threatening to give some of it to suburban counties.
State and city housing officials blame one another for delays that have kept the money tied up. The state says the city was slow to provide abandoned buildings and vacant land on which to create new housing. Municipal housing officials say that they did offer sites but that state officials were not satisfied with the properties.
Now Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has proposed a change in state law that would make as much as $50 million of the $85 million available to Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester and Rockland Counties. City housing officials and some lawmakers vow to block the plan, which some officials said would make the housing agency headed by the Governor's son Andrew the main beneficiary. 
The dispute comes as the city is struggling to remove homeless families from emergency quarters in rundown welfare hotels and city shelters and when Federal subsidies for permanent, low-income housing have all but vanished. While the loss of some of the state money would not cripple the city's efforts, the angry debate between the city and state underscores the fierce competition for housing dollars and for political recognition.
Assemblyman Alexander B. Grannis, a Manhattan Democrat who is chairman of the Assembly Housing Committee, said Andrew Cuomo, through a nonprofit housing agency called HELP, which he operates, would be able to use some of the money that had been reserved for the city. Mr. Cuomo could finance housing projects for the homeless in Westchester and Suffolk Counties, the lawmaker said.
Mr. Grannis said his chief aide had been lobbied by an aide to Andrew Cuomo to support the change in the law proposed by the Cuomo administration.
Andrew Cuomo said he supported the effort to shift some of the money to the suburbs, but along with state housing officials, he denied that the state was motivated by a desire to aid his group.
''I happen to think the bill makes sense,'' he said. ''The money has been available for the homeless for two years, and it has not been utilized. The suburbs have a tremendous housing problem. If you have money appropriated and you have people sleeping on the streets in the suburbs, why not use it in the suburbs?''
He also noted that there were many more housing renovation and construction programs for the homeless in the city than in the suburbs.
 
Commitment to City Noted
Assemblyman Grannis, as committee chairman, introduced the bill for the Cuomo administration. But he said it ''is not going anywhere,'' because the money has been set aside solely for the city under a complex legislative agreement in 1988.
''This money was committed to the city,'' he said. ''It is going to stay in the city.''
Richard L. Higgins, Commissioner of the State Department of Housing and Community Renewal, said the state wanted to offer some of the money to the suburbs because of the city's ''general unwillingness to proceed expeditiously.''
''We made this money available,'' he said. ''If it wasn't going to be spent and buildings weren't going to be made available, there were other areas of the state where it was desperately needed.''
Mr. Higgins called Mr. Grannis's remarks about Andrew Cuomo ''a smokescreen for the city's problems on spending the money.''
The dispute centers on a compromise reached two years ago over how to spend $326 million in state surplus money on housing. The $85 million was reserved for the city under the legislative agreement, and $241 million was made available statewide for other low- and moderate-income housing programs.
 
One Project Approved
Only one organization has been approved so far to use the state money for permanent housing in the city - Mr. Cuomo's HELP. Construction is scheduled to begin next month on 150 new apartments in the East New York section of Brooklyn.
Another nonprofit group, the Coalition for the Homeless, has received preliminary approval to rebuild an abandoned building in East Harlem with 15 apartments. The state agency overseeing the housing program for the homeless, the Housing Finance Agency, has not yet approved this project, however.
In addition, bids were received last month for a contract to build housing on five different sites in the South Bronx and Harlem. A total of 320 apartments are to be built.
Together the first three projects would use $35 million of the $85 million state pool. The city matches each dollar spent by the state.
Mr. Higgins said the program had not moved more quickly because the city was slow to provide vacant land and abandoned buildings. He also said the city had prolonged the process by insisting that the sites be reviewed by local community boards.
 
Mix of Tenants Approved
There was also a lengthy debate over whether all of the apartments should go to the homeless, or whether the new buildings would remain more stable in the long run if they contained a mix of homeless and other families. The state, which insisted on a mix, ultimately prevailed.
Such difficulties ''highlight some things that just slowed down the program from our point of view,'' Mr. Higgins said.
But Mr. Grannis said state officials had insisted that the 1988 law required the city to provide sites to the state and to obtain approval from community boards and the Board of Estimate.
''It was written to make sure the city took all the heat for the siting decisions,'' Mr. Grannis said.
City officials said they had warned the state that most of the larger abandoned buildings in the city's inventory had already been assigned to developers and nonprofit groups under the city's own housing plans.
Only smaller buildings at less desirable locations were left, said city officials, who asserted that state officials were slow to understand that the city was not withholding more desirable sites from them.
 
State Inexperience Cited
Some municipal officials said another reason for delays was that the State Housing Finance Agency had never before developed low-income housing.
''We built thousands of units during that time, thousands,'' said Felice Michetti, Commissioner of the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development. ''That's why to say that the delays were our fault makes no sense.''
The city has overseen the completion of 4,300 new apartments in formerly abandoned buildings over the last four years, said Roz Post, a spokeswoman for the city housing department. A total of 15,000 more apartments are being built. About a third are for the homeless.
Mayor David N. Dinkins has said he will continue the city's housing efforts, which were begun by his predecessor, Edward I. Koch. As Manhattan Borough President and a member of the Board of Estimate, Mr. Dinkins voted to approve most housing initiatives undertaken by the Koch administration.
The state's development efforts have been modest by comparison. The most successful state effort, called the ''turnkey'' program, has spent $128 million of the surplus money in the last two years to build or completely renovate low- and moderate-income housing. Eleven projects are being built, with 121 units completed. Construction is scheduled to start by September on 11 projects. Overall, nearly 1,200 apartments are to be created.

HEADLINE: SIHANOUK WIDENS KHMER ROUGE RIFT

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 5

 BODY:
Responding to the concerns of his Western backers, Prince Norodom Sihanouk distanced himself further from the Communist Khmer Rouge today, signing a communique with Hun Sen, the Prime Minister of Cambodia, that the Khmer Rouge refused to support.
Speaking alongside his non-Communist ally, Son Sann, Prince Sihanouk said the two men and their followers would abide by the terms of the communique, even though their allies, the Khmer Rouge, would not do so.
The statement calls for the establishment of a Supreme National Council by the end of July to embody Cambodian sovereignty until new elections can be held and a new government formed.
The communique says the council will be made up of equal numbers of representatives from the two rival governments, as Mr. Hun Sen wishes - not of equal numbers from the four Cambodian factions, as the Khmer Rouge demands. 
 
'Voluntary Self-Restraint'
The communique also calls for ''voluntary self-restraint on the use of force'' - diplomatic language for a cease-fire that cannot be enforced -beginning on the first day that the Supreme National Council meets.
But Prince Sihanouk admitted at a news conference tonight that no cease-fire or lasting peace in Cambodia could be reached until the Khmer Rouge agreed to take part.
He also said the Supreme National Council would not truly be representative of Cambodian sovereignty until the Khmer Rouge took part.
''There will be no Khmer Rouge -they do not want to participate in the Supreme National Council at all,'' the Prince said. ''But in my opinion, the Supreme National Council will really be a symbol of sovereignty only on the day the Khmer Rouge join as full members. In order to have peace in Cambodia, we need to make peace with the Khmer Rouge. We must persuade the Khmer Rouge to join us inside the Supreme Council.''
 
Pressure Off Western Nations
But if the Prince and Mr. Son Sann do what they have now promised to do -form a Supreme National Council with Mr. Hun Sen even without the participation of the Khmer Rouge - it will enable the United Nations this fall to give Cambodia's seat there to the council, thereby further legitimizing Mr. Hun Sen and isolating the Khmer Rouge.
It would also take some of the pressure off the Bush Administration and other Western governments that have been increasingly criticized for indirectly supporting the Khmer Rouge by their support for the Prince and Mr. Son Sann.
Cambodia's seat is currently held by the Sihanouk coalition, which includes the Khmer Rouge, who were driven out of power when the Vietnamese invaded Cambodia in 1978. Under the Khmer Rouge, more than a million Cambodians were killed or died of starvation and disease during a brutal campaign of restructuring.
But as the Prince implied tonight, such an pact is likely to do little to end the war in Cambodia, the brunt of which is carried by the Khmer Rouge, and may intensify the fighting.
If they are cut out of any settlement, they will have little incentive to stop fighting, and Asian and European diplomats make clear that no country will agree to put international peacekeeping troops into Cambodia as long as the Khmer Rouge have not agreed in principle, at least, to lay down their arms.
 
Talks Turn Sour
Japanese officials started the two days of talks confidently, working from a draft text that the Thai Defense Minister, Gen. Chavalit Yongchaiyudh, had gotten all four factions to sign.
Japanese officials spoke of the meeting as a first venture into regional peacemaking since the end of World War II, and as a diplomatic exercise more commensurate with Japan's standing as a world economic power.
But what was envisaged as two days of negotiation between Mr. Hun Sen and Prince Sihanouk as the two leaders of rival sides quickly turned sour. The Khmer Rouge, scheduled to attend as part of the Prince's delegation, boycotted the first meeting on Monday, which adjourned after 25 minutes.
The bipartite negotiations never resumed. Although General Chavalit and Japanese officials shuttled among the factions, they spent most of their time in conversation with the Khmer Rouge and the Sihanouk side. Officials with Mr. Hun Sen said there was little for them to do but wait.
 
Japanese 'Very Annoyed'
A joint Hun Sen-Sihanouk news conference turned into separate ones, and then it was announced that Mr. Hun Sen would not speak this evening after all. Throughout, Japanese officials tried to keep smiles on their faces, although one official said the Japanese were ''very annoyed'' with the Cambodians, the Khmer Rouge in particular.
In the end, what Prince Sihanouk and Mr. Hun Sen signed tonight was a communique little different from the one that the four factions initialed last month.
But the real importance of the meeting here is likely to be the growing isolation of the Khmer Rouge within a diplomatic process that is accelerating, and that is treating Mr. Hun Sen with much more respect than before.

HEADLINE: No Rush on Ties to Seoul, Moscow Says

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, June 5

 BODY:
The Soviet Union reacted with reserve today to suggestions that it might soon establish diplomatic relations with South Korea in the wake of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's meeting with President Roh Tae Woo.
After the meeting on Monday in San Francisco, at the end of Mr. Gorbachev's trip to the United States, Mr. Roh said at a news conference that ''normal bilateral relations will be restored,'' but did not give a timetable.
Soviet news reports did not contradict his assertion but put the possibility of formal relations in the context of a general improvement in the region and between the two Koreas.
Mr. Gorbachev was quoted by Tass, the official press agency, as saying that diplomatic relations ''may arise as bilateral ties develop and in the context of the general improvement of the political situation in the region and on the Korean Peninsula.'' 
The meeting with the Korean leader was reported in a brief front-page article today in Izvestia, the Government newspaper. The article said the question of diplomatic relations can be raised as ties develop and the political situation improves on the Korean Peninsula.
 
No Abandonment of North Korea
A later analysis by Tass stressed that ''political dialogue with other countries in no way means that we give up our principled positions and priorities or forgo the interests of third parties,'' a clear allusion to North Korea.
North Korea, which expressed concern when reports of the scheduled meeting first appeared, has not issued any official reaction to Mr. Gorbachev's meeting with Mr. Roh.
South Korean officials have hailed the meeting, with some predicting that diplomatic ties might be established in the second half of this year.
In his own comments after the meeting, Mr. Gorbachev did not refer to diplomatic ties, saying, ''We have commercial ties and that is why we decided to meet with him.''
The Tass analysis took a skeptical tone toward Western news reports, saying they portrayed the San Francisco meeting as a ''political sensation'' that ''supposedly marks 'drastic changes' in the U.S.S.R.'s Asian policy.''
While stressing Moscow's sensitivity to relations with North Korea, the Tass analysis also conceded ''the removal of ideological blinkers from our foreign policy'' in Mr.Gorbachev's search for help for the troubled Soviet economy.
 
Reaction in South Korea
SEOUL, South Korea, June 5 (Special to The New York Times) - South Korean political leaders expressed satisfaction today over President Roh's meeting with President Gorbachev.
Choi Woon Sang, a senior foreign policy adviser to the opposition leader, Kim Dae Jung, said he hoped that the meeting would lead to the restoration of diplomatic relations between the two countries.
''But achievements in foreign affairs,'' he warned, ''will not affect in any way the problems we have here, such as labor problems and economic problems.''
Leftist dissident groups accused Mr. Roh and Mr. Gorbachev of helping permanently to divide the peninsula by effectively extending Soviet recognition to two independent Koreas. The dissident groups criticized the summit meeting as failing to present ''substantial measures'' for peace between South and North Korea. Radical students staged a few small, scattered demonstrations denouncing Roh's diplomacy.
The talks have also raised hopes of increased Soviet-South Korean trade. During the last week, the Soviets have announced nearly $30 million in new contracts with South Korean companies. Two-way trade between the countries doubled to $600 million last year and is expected to reach $1.1 billion this year. A report from a private economic institute released today said that trade is expected to reach $2 billion in two or three years.
The Soviets want increased trade and investment from the South Koreans while Seoul wants full diplomatic relations as a way to press the North Korean Government to lessen tensions in the region.

HEADLINE: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;
Gorbachev Returns to Duty As the Soviet Master of Spin

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, June 5

 BODY:
President Mikhail S. Gorbachev returned home today from his dual summit labors as chief Soviet negotiator and the nation's principal journalistic analyst of his own performance.
On nightly television news broadcasts, the Soviet leader indulged himself fully in the role of analyst and reviewer, enjoying one of the lingering perks of the old dictatorial order of the Kremlin.
There was none of the point-counterpoint coverage more familiar in Western news reports, as Mr. Gorbachev served as the nation's sole spin doctor, calmly and happily presenting glowing summaries of summit events at special televised interviews on Saturday and Sunday with the press feature syndicate Novosti and with the state television, broadcast in addition to the day's questions and answers.
He dominated the Saturday and Sunday night television reports on the main state-controlled evening news show, ''Vremya,'' with long monologue answers to reporters' questions, setting the tone and filtering the substance of most of the Soviet public's impression of the event. 
 
Gorbachev's Last Say
The printed press has followed suit, presenting dispatches loyal to his view, confirming that while democratization and dissent have begun in some parts of the nation's life, Mr. Gorbachev continues to have the last say in coloring major events.
''You have raised absolutely the right question,'' was a typical preamble of one of his answers to a question in a state television interview.
''Maybe you heard my speculations on this subject and that prompted your question,'' he said to the beaming state reporter as he began a drawn-out description of achievement that faced no danger of being shrunk on the air by sound-bite-minded news editors.
''I would call what happened in Camp David a big day,'' he began in answer to another night's stretch of virtually uninterrupted news time on ''Vremya.'' ''What was discussed there was discussed profoundly by all.''
There were a few new wrinkles in the Soviet coverage of this summit meeting, like the appearance with Mr. Gorbachev in one long interview of his Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze. Mr. Shevardnadze's main point to the respectfully delving questioner was to declare, ''I find it hard to add anything to what Mikhail Sergeyevich has said.''
The coverage included more conventionally objective summaries of events, including a brief account of Mr. Gorbachev's meeting on Monday night with President Roh Tae Woo of South Korea and the hopes for further progress. There were scant allusions by Soviet reporters to the economic and political problems on the boil here at home.
But one American diplomat whose duties included monitoring the full array of Soviet news accounts presented here concluded: ''Writing about international relations is still one of the final taboos of the Soviet media. The reporters still think with one brain.''
Even a rare touch of individual analysis that appeared amid the blanket of universally uncritical coverage was that of a combination cheerleader and patriot who wrote in the Soviet Government daily newspaper Izvestia, ''We all sighed with relief when it became clear the trade agreement was signed.''
 
'We Love You Gorby!'
''This time, Mikhail Sergeyevich reached President Bush with his sincerity, passion, drive and honesty,'' the Izvestia reporter confided to the reader back home.
The television-monitoring diplomat said that since Mr. Gorbachev always had the dominant say on the news, the public may be inured to the propaganda effects of his soliloquies.
In any case, the official said, ''Gorbachev's public image does not really matter as much for him here as President Bush's does back home, simply because the public does not matter as much here.'' Even so, the Soviet public could hardly resist the coverage of the crowd scenes in America, replete with shouts of ''We love you Gorby!''
In contrast to the television pictures, Soviet newspapers generally took a muted tone and avoided presenting the color of events as large separate stories in the manner of the Western press. Most front-page space, in fact, was devoted to summary dispatches and the texts of the Presidents' news conference on Sunday and to Mr. Gorbachev's separate showcase interviews on Saturday and Sunday nights.

HEADLINE: Minnesota Journal;
Savoring the Afterglow Of a World-Class Visit

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ST. PAUL, June 5

 BODY:
Gov. Rudy Perpich sat in the Governor's mansion here today and recalled the exact moment Sunday when he asked Mikhail S. Gorbachev the question that every journalist, civic leader and politician in the state had been wondering about.
Why had the Soviet leader chosen to visit Minnesota, among all the states, after his summit meeting with President Bush?
''We had just gone into the drawing room for a family picture, and he went like this,'' said the Governor, jabbing his thumb toward his chest, in imitation of the Soviet President.
''My decision,'' was how Mr. Perpich interpreted the gesture. ''President Gorbachev said he was the one who chose to come, because he had always had such warm feelings about the state, as a result of business contacts over the years.'' 
This state is still basking in the afterglow left from Mr. Gorbachev's seven-hour sojourn, which brought out thousands of local residents in cold, rainy weather to catch a glimpse of his motorcade.
Everyone here has spent the last two days proclaiming the visit a boon to the state's future, even though the weather seemed only to underscore the old saw that Minnesota is a state with nine months of winter and three months of poor sledding.
But for all the civic pride, it is still not clear what tangible benefits, what new economic opportunities and business openings this state of four million people will reap.
''You know, perceptions are 90 percent of the game,'' the Governor said today. ''And I think a lot of people all over the world now have some pretty good impressions of Minnesota. Who knows what effect that might have on an executive thinking of relocating his staff?''
William H. Whyte, an urban sociologist from New York University, said events like the Gorbachev visit provided a kind of ''seal of certification'' to a lesser-known city or state, proof that it could play on a larger stage.
Among the nation's second tier of cities, places like Atlanta and Minneapolis-St. Paul and Denver, there is especially intense interest in being perceived as someplace other than just another provincial capital.
Roger Parkinson, publisher of The Star Tribune in Minneapolis, the man who led the volunteer committee that organized the Gorbachev visit, says the Twin Cities do not usually come to mind when people rattle off a list of great American cities.
But he thinks Minneapolis is now on the way. In July the city will be host to the United States Olympic Sports Festival, which will draw more than 3,000 athletes from around the country to compete in 37 events. And in January 1992 Minneapolis will be the site for the Super Bowl, making it just the second cold-weather city, after Detroit, to have the event.
Al Eisele, a former St. Paul journalist and Washington public relations specialist credited with a key role in arranging the Gorbachev visit, said the impressions from the trip would pay economic benefits back to the state over the long erm.
Not only does he believe that the visit brought many Minnesota companies ''near the front of the line'' in doing business with the Soviets, but he said Mr. Gorbachev had also helped to mold a new, world-class image for the state, by helping to emphasize its economic diversity and high technology.
''I'd like to think we have put Lake Wobegon behind us now,'' said Mr. Eisele, recalling the humorist Garrison Keillor's tales of the mythical and modest Minnesota village.
''In some ways, Garrison Keillor did more damage to the image of Minnesota than Stalin did to the Soviet Union,'' Mr. Eisele said. ''We are more than a bunch of dumb Swedish farmers wandering around telling corny jokes.''
For now, the biggest winner is the man in the Governor's mansion.
They laughed when Governor Perpich sent the invitation to President Gorbachev several months ago. Now Republicans and rivals in his own Democratic Farmer Labor Party are trying to play down the significance of the visit.
Mr. Perpich's aides, meanwhile, are editing yards of videotape that they took while the Governor traveled around with Mr. Gorbachev. By November, said one political consultant here, the two men will have been seen together so often in political ads, voters might think they were running together on the statewide ticket.

HEADLINE: The Capital Gains Promise: Still False

 BODY:
When Washington's budget negotiators get to the dicey question of which taxes to raise, it will be no surprise if the Administration comes out for tax reduction. President Bush still wants a special break for capital gains. It's still a bad idea. 
Since 1986, capital gains - income from the appreciated value of an investment - have been taxed at the same rates as ordinary income, mostly at 28 percent. The previous lower rate was eliminated by a key compromise in the 1986 reform package. That's reason No. 1 to maintain the status quo: a deal is a deal.
The Reagan Administration wasn't happy with the agreement on capital gains, however, and President Bush campaigned on a promise to repeal it. He insists that a preferential rate stimulates investment. But it's unproven that a lower tax would stimulate much new investment. It might even stimulate consumption if people didn't reinvest their gains.
Reason No. 2 is the familiar but correct argument that a capital gains tax favors the rich. A 15 percent tax, which Mr. Bush has advocated, would shower two-thirds of its benefits on people with incomes over $200,000. Politically, this may be the opposition's best rallying point. But there are solid economic negatives as well.
Besides overturning the deal sealed in 1986, tax preference for capital gains violates the sound philosophy behind President Reagan's original proposal for reform. The economy functions best if people invest, save or spend their money according to the merit of the options, not because one or the other saves more taxes. With a special rate for gains, the Government would be saying invest in stocks and bonds - and timber and real estate, if they're included - rather than in money market mutual funds or other ways taxed as ordinary income. The special rate would also revive tax shelter abuses as taxpayers converted ordinary income into gains that would be taxed less.
Capital gains aren't treated as badly as Mr. Bush implies. Gains are not taxed until an investor decides to sell; as long as an investment is held, the taxpayer gets the compounding benefit of untaxed growth. And gains are not taxed at all if the investment is passed on to heirs and beneficiaries when the investor dies. This loophole amounts to $5 billion a year in potential taxes not collected.
In Washington's desperation for ways to shrink the deficit, a capital gains tax cut offers one mighty temptation in the short term: higher revenue from a lower tax. A reduced tax for past as well as future investments would immediately boost revenues as investors unloaded investments they held onto when the tax was higher.
The Treasury says this revenue boost would continue in years to come, but other authorities say it would soon become a revenue drain. Congress's Joint Committee on Taxation, which has the final word in evaluating tax bills, has estimated that over five years, a 15 percent tax on gains would cut revenue by $11 billion.
The fairest way to treat gains is to index them so investors pay tax only on real, not paper gains. And if Congress wanted a real increase in revenue, it would tax gains at death.

HEADLINE: Asian Romance in San Francisco

 BODY:
There's far more than post-cold-war symbolism in the courtship between Moscow and Seoul, further nurtured by Monday's meeting of Presidents Gorbachev and Roh Tae Woo in San Francisco. A consummated relationship could bring real gains to both countries. America, too, would benefit from a wider peace in Northeast Asia. 
South Korea was born anti-Communist when the Korean Peninsula was partitioned along ideological lines after World War II. It fought a bitter war against Soviet- and Chinese-backed invaders from the North, succeeded by a tense and dangerous armed peace.
But under President Roh, a newly confident and economically successful South Korea has reached out to former foes. Moscow and Beijing both came to the 1988 Seoul Olympics. South Korea opened embassies in Eastern Europe even before Communism's collapse.
Diplomatic ties with Moscow remain at the consular level for now but economic relations are booming. Bilateral trade doubled last year to $600 million. The Soviets seek further trade growth, especially in low-cost imports of Korean ships, vehicles and machinery. Moscow also hopes for Korean loans and investments in Siberian development. This, in turn, could entice investment from Japan, to prevent Korea from locking in a head start.
South Korea's anticipated gains are mostly political. Mr. Roh is eager to defuse the danger from the North. If he can persuade Moscow and perhaps Beijing to press moderation on Kim Il Sung, South Korea can have greater security at lower cost. A peace dividend would release funds to respond to the social demands democracy has awakened.
Achieving full relations with Moscow and detente with Pyongyang could also brighten South Korea's political mood. President Roh's standing has abruptly declined in recent months amid political maneuvers, strikes and crude repression.
Washington can only gain from a relationship that promotes Soviet economic reform and reinforces South Korean security. A warmer strategic climate would also allow further American troop withdrawals.
For years, South Korean nationalists have demonized Washington as the main obstacle to better North-South Korean ties. By meeting Mr. Gorbachev on U.S. soil, Mr. Roh refutes their argument while honoring their goal.

HEADLINE: U.S. Sellout at the Summit

BYLINE: By Richard Perle; Richard Perle was Assistant Secretary of Defense in the Reagan Administration.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The most poignant words spoken during the summit talks came from a nonparticipant, Lithuanian spokesman Algimantis Cekuolis. Shortly after agreements on strategic weapons and trade were signed last Friday, he said of his beleaguered homeland: ''Today we were all alone.''
Unlike Mikhail Gorbachev, who won several concessions on trade and arms, the Lithuanians didn't ask for much - a sign, a gesture, an indication that, in its zeal to shore up the Soviet President, the U.S. would, half a century after refusing to recognize the Soviet incorporation of Lithuania, remain true to its belief in democracy and self-determination.
The Administration relegated its concern for Lithuania to sotto voce murmurings amid the pomp of a largely symbolic occasion, because it considers Lithuania a fly speck on the scales of the U.S.-Soviet relationship. 
In pretending to manage the process of change in the Soviet Union -even as Mr. Gorbachev was busy in Washington managing his agenda at the expense of ours - a self-satisfied Administration has conjured the conceit of a ''pragmatic'' approach to issues of power and principle, a self-censoring refuge in which it is now comfortably entombed. No room in there for a hapless little Baltic nation.
It was a symbolic summit meeting because the agreements signed had been largely negotiated beforehand. The principal U.S. concessions concerning strategic arms were made by Secretary of State James Baker in Moscow a fortnight earlier.
One concession opens the way to Soviet deployment of heavy missiles that are twice as capable as the ones they replace. This will largely vitiate the 50 percent reduction in the ceiling for heavy missiles agreed to at Reykjavik in 1986. Another concession limits the range of cruise missiles in a way so favorable to the Soviets that it was resisted by administrations for nearly 20 years.
In his rush to sign an agreement on strategic arms, President Bush set aside, at least temporarily, two important demands: that Soviet ''Backfire'' bombers be included in the treaty and that Soviet heavy-missile tests be limited to two a year, presumably to encumber the development of yet another generation of new heavy missiles.
Like the statement on Start, the trade agreement signed in the White House had been negotiated before Mr. Gorbachev touched down in Washington. For now, it too has only symbolic value, since the Soviets have not yet met the test of the Jackson-Vanik amendment. That law conditions the concessions the treaty promises -most-favored-nation status and access to Government credits - on movement toward free emigration.
Yet, Mr. Gorbachev's implied threat to curtail emigration to Israel in deference to Arab objections again raised the issue of the reliability and permanence of any assurances on emigration that might be given to allow the trade agreement to go forward.
There is one issue on which the Administration deserves favorable mention. Mr. Bush, with the steadfast backing of Secretary Baker, wisely rejected Mr. Gorbachev's demand that a unified Germany should change its status within NATO to something less than full membership. A neutralized, non-nuclear Germany would imperil the stability of post-cold war Europe without in any way enhancing Soviet security.
The cold war may be over, but the two Presidents will still take the measure of each other as they contemplate future policies. Mr. Gorbachev saw a President eager to keep him in power and willing to make concessions to do so.
What he heard from the White House was an unidentified (but almost certainly authorized) adviser derisively critical of Boris Yeltsin, the newly elected, reform-minded president of the Russian republic. In fact, Mr. Yeltsin is far more tractable on Lithuania, bolder on economic reform and more amenable to the American agenda than the Soviet leader. What Mr. Gorbachev read in the statements he signed was American political and economic largesse that is more likely to whet than satisfy an ambitious appetite.
In a summit meeting of symbols, where the measure of the men who made it may have been its only significant product, the plaintive cry of a lone Lithuanian rings still.

HEADLINE: Executive Director to Leave Port Authority

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
Stephen Berger, executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, said yesterday that he planned to leave his post in July after five years with the agency to take a job in the private sector.
His departure was widely expected in government and local transit agency circles since the appointment in April of Richard C. Leone as the authority's new chairman. People familiar with the authority said Mr. Leone, a former New Jersey State Treasurer, wanted a new executive director.
Mr. Berger will become president and chief executive of the Financial Guaranty Insurance Company, a leading insurer of municipal bonds, where he is expected to make considerably more than his current salary of $170,000 a year. 
His departure comes at a time when the Port Authority is dealing with several growing problems. Revenues are sliding, traffic at the airports run by the authority is declining, its marine terminals are losing customers and traffic across its Hudson River bridges and tunnels is at a lull. And the region is facing weak economic conditions.
In the last year, Mr. Berger found himself at sharp odds with Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York and Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey, each of whom can veto the authority's actions. Mr. Berger's proposal for sharp increases in tolls on bridges, tunnels and the PATH train service was abandoned in April after both Governors resisted the plan.
Mr. Berger is credited with generating support among officials in New York and New Jersey to finance a $6 billion capital plan for overhauling the Port Authority's immense operations, which include airports, river crossings, docks, container ports and terminals, and reducing the sprawling bureaucracy of the organization.
But Mr. Berger will be leaving his post before most of those plans are carried out.
''While the past five years have been among the most rewarding of my professional life,'' Mr. Berger said, ''the opportunity that has been presented to me is, from a professional and personal standpoint, one I could not turn down.''
Financial Guaranty, which is owned by G.E. Capital, a division of the General Electric Company, insured more than $2 billion in securities in the first quarter of 1990.
Several potential candidates are said to be under consideration to replace Mr. Berger, with the leading ones being Stanley Brezenoff, a former first deputy mayor now with the Commonwealth Fund, and Vincent Tese, head of the State Urban Development Corporation and a close personal friend of Governor Cuomo.
At a news conference yesterday at the World Trade Center, Mr. Berger, a balding man with a pointed beard, said that among his major accomplishments at the Port Authority were a privately operated ferry service from Hoboken, N.J., to Manhattan, the refurbishing of the PATH system and stations, the overhaul of La Guardia Airport and increased cooperation by management and labor.
Mitchel Moss, director of the Urban Research Center at New York University, applauded Mr. Berger for having reduced the size of the Port Authority's bureaucracy and appointing ''quality people'' in its middle ranks.
Mayor David N. Dinkins said Mr. Berger's years at the had been ''characterized by fiscal discipline and a visionary commitment to bringing the region's transportation infrastructure into the 21st century.''
But Mr. Moss criticized Mr. Berger for his strained relationships with the two Governors and for not finding funds to continue the renovation of Kennedy International Airport, which has been scaled back. ''He forgot that his authority was derived from the Governors and not his title,'' he said.
Mr. Berger's successor will inherit an agency facing some major problems. Shipping at the Port of New York is lagging far behind many other ports in major cities on both the East and West Coasts. In 1989, the value of cargo shipped through New York was exceeded for the first time by the value of imports and exports shipped through the Port of Los Angeles.
At the same time, fewer people are traveling through the region's airports and using the Port Authority Trans-Hudson system known as PATH.

HEADLINE: Cuomo Takes 55 Minutes To Accept

BYLINE: By FRANK LYNN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 5

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo accepted the Democratic nomination for a third term today and responded with a 55-minute speech that often sounded as though he was running for the White House rather than the Statehouse.
While insisting that he was not ''Washington bashing,'' Mr. Cuomo declared that the state's slipping economy and its growing crime and drug problems - the major Republican issues against him - were national problems that affect most states.
But he did not forget his political roots as he devoted one segment of what was to have been a 35-minute speech to hopscotching around the state from Horseheads to the North Country and from Shoreham to Buffalo detailing projects planned by his administration.
 
A Favorite Target
Nor did he forget the State Senate's Republican majority, a favorite target and the main Republican power base in the state. He castigated the Republican Senators for failing to enact laws forcing drug dealers to forfeit property and banning assault weapons. He also criticized them for not accepting his proposal to impose life sentences without parole instead of the death penalty and for failing to enact a bias-related crime bill. 
While he frequently referred to Ronald Reagan and George Bush, he never mentioned Pierre A. Rinfret, the Republican candidate for governor.
When someone from the enthusiastic audience of Democrats shouted ''92,'' an obvious reference to the next Presidential election year, Mr. Cuomo adopted his ''aw shucks'' pose and replied: ''That's all. Now I'll never talk about Washington again.''
 
Ignored His Opponent
But in a vintage Cuomo speech in which he recited his record, he blamed the Republicans in the State Senate and in Washington for what problems there are, and provided a general glimpse toward the future and '' a whole new shining century.''
It was a blueprint for his campaign, which he said would be actively waged throughout the state. That approach would be in sharp contrast with 1986, when the Governor generally ignored his opponent and did not formally campaign until fall.
Lieut. Gov. Stan Lundine said in an earlier interview that ''after eight years, it's important to go out and say I need your vote.''
Mr. Cuomo put it more colorfully today. ''In this business, if you don't blow your own horn,'' he said, ''there's no music.''
Seated to his left, as he roused a full house of 600 Democrats at the Empire State Plaza Convention Hall, across from the capitol, was his wife, Matilda, and other Cuomo family members.
The Governor added to the family theme he likes to sound by having his younger son, Christopher, who is 19 years old, introduce him as ''the man you know as Governor and I know as Pop.''
Mr. Cuomo repeatedly tried to turn a major Republican issue, the state's economy, spending and taxes, on the G.O.P. by blaming Washington.
''The sluggishness of the national economy has dragged down the state economy,'' Mr. Cuomo said. ''This is not some failing of New York State, New York City and local governments.'' He predicted that 37 states would face budget difficulties this year.
 
The Flow of Drugs
Mr. Cuomo also tried to shift responsibility for the state's drug crisis. ''The problem of drugs is not a state failure,'' he said. ''It is a national failure.'' He cited what he said were futile efforts to stop the flow of drugs into the country.
He criticized major defense spending, arguing that even a small diversion of defense funds could produce billions for social-welfare programs.
He drew perhaps the loudest applause of the two-day convention when he sarcastically referred to ''these geniuses, these conservatives'' who deregulated savings-and-loan associations. ''The bankers, what did they do?'' he asked. ''They stole everything in sight.''
He also tried to counter the Republican labeling of him as a big spender and taxer by saying that he presided over ''the largest tax cut in the state's history'' - without mentioning that this year he also recommended the largest tax increase in the state's history as the state's credit rating dropped to a historic low.
 
More College Scholarships
Mr. Cuomo said his administration was responsible for one million more people employed, 100,000 people removed from the welfare rolls, more college scholarships for the poor, an ethics law, a rebuilding of the state's bridges and roads, a near doubling of the state's prison population, and the first full-term appointments of a black and a woman to the New York State Court of Appeals.
The Governor's acceptance speech and an on-stage fireworks display ended a relatively tranquil state convention that left only one piece of unfinished business: a primary battle for the comptroller nomination between Carol Bellamy, the former New York City Council President, and the convention designee, Andrew J. Spano, the Westchester County Clerk.
Also nominated were Mr. Lundine and Attorney General Robert Abrams.

HEADLINE: New 'Witness' Recants Her Bensonhurst Story

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES

 BODY:
The woman who recently claimed that she saw the slaying of Yusuf K. Hawkins in Bensonhurst recanted her story yesterday, the Brooklyn District Attorney, Charles J. Hynes, said.
''It is now clear that she was not a witness to events of that tragic night as she claimed,'' Mr. Hynes said in a statement.
The woman had said in television and newspapaer interviews at the end of the Bensonhurst murder trials that she had watched about 40 white youths surround the 16-year-old Mr. Hawkins on the night of Aug. 23. 
She said she had seen Joseph Fama shoot Mr. Hawkins in the chest while Keith Mondello urged him on.
 
'Set Back' to Federal Case
The woman, accompanied by her husband, issued a statement yesterday at the District Attorney's office, retracting all her previous accounts, including a version she said she wrote in Spanish a day after Mr. Hawkins was killed. Yesterday was the second time she had met with prosecutors.
Andrew J. Maloney, the United States Attorney in Brooklyn who is considering civil-rights charges against Mr. Mondello, called the retraction a setback.
''This is another blow to any potential successful prosecution of any Federal civil-rights violation,'' he said.
Officials at Channel 47, the Spanish language television station that played a large role in promoting the woman to other media organizations, expressed regret over the incident.
''I feel we have been used,'' said Helga Silva, the station's news director, ''but worst of all it makes a mockery of our justice system. It makes a mockery of civic duty when you are talking about life and death.''
 
Woman Won't Be Charged
The woman had identifed herself as ''Iris'' and ''Maria'' in the interviews. Mr. Hynes's office did not release her real name.
Her lawyer, Kenneth Pearson, said through his office that he was no longer representing the woman and had ''no comment'' on the retraction.
Mr. Hynes said he would not seek charges against the woman. ''I am saddened by her actions,'' he said. ''However, I have decided not to file charges against her. The interests of justice would not be served by criminal action.'' He added that the woman's motives ''remained unclear.''
The existence of a possible mystery witness was considered important because she was the only person who said she had heard Mr. Mondello, who was accused of being the ringleader, tell Mr. Fama, who was accused of being the gunman, to shoot Mr. Hawkins.
 
Would Have Been Called
If she had been a credible witness prosecutors said they would have called her in a possible civil-rights case against Mr. Mondello, who was aquitted on May 18 of murder and manslaughter charges but was convicted on several lesser charges.
Mr. Fama was convicted of second-degree murder on May 17. Both will be sentenced on Monday.
The 50-year-old woman, an unemployed cleaning woman, had said she had been in Bensonhurst for the day with a real-estate salesman when she saw the murder.
She had said she went home and wrote down an account of the murder to a friend, but had refused to talk to the police because she was afraid of repercussions and feared that her husband would not understand what she was doing in the neighborhood with the real-estate broker.

HEADLINE: Excerpts From New Jersey Court Ruling on School Financing

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, June 5

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the unanimous New Jersey Supreme Court decision today ordering the state to insure that the poorest cities spend as much on education as wealthy suburbs.
Chief Justice Robert N. Wilentz wrote the opinion.
 
FROM THE OPINION
We find that under the present system the evidence compels but one conclusion: the poorer the district and the greater its need, the less the money available, and the worse the education. . . . We hold that the Act must be amended to assure funding of education in poorer urban districts at the level of property-rich districts; that such funding cannot be allowed to depend on the ability of local school districts to tax; that such funding must be guaranteed and mandated by the State.
We reject the argument, however, that funding should not be supplied because it may be mismanaged and wasted. Money can make a difference if effectively used, it can provide the students with an equal educational opportunity, a chance to succeed. They are entitled to that chance, constitutionally entitled. They have the right to the same educational opportunity that money buys for others. . . . Our decision deals not with optimum educational policy but with constitutional compliance. 
These state constitutional claims, the underlying contentions and facts, although presenting great variety of detail, are remarkably similar to those facing us: an educational funding system that depends on a combination of state and local taxes producing disparity of expenditures in the face of inverse disparity of need. Fourteen of the states have rejected both constitutional claims; six, including New Jersey, have held the state system of financing education invalid under the state education article, while rejecting or declining to reach equal protection claims; four determined that the existing system violated state equal protection clauses.
Very few of the cases have a factual record that even begins to approach that before us. None has the unique attribute of this case: an educational funding system specifically designed to conform to a prior court decision, having been declared constitutional by the Court but now attacked as having failed to achieve the constitutional goal. In short, we are the only state involved in a second round on this issue.
The constitutional command does not require relief every time the slightest deviation from a thorough and efficient education is found, or any time that deviation, though proven, is likely to be corrected soon. . . .
Nevertheless, we reject the State's claim that in these poorer urban districts a thorough and efficient education has been or will be achieved. The extent of failure is so deep, its causes so embedded in the present system, as to persuade us that there is no likelihood of achieving a decent education tomorrow, in the reasonable future, or ever. The State's argument is strong on paper: districts can raise all the money they want, districts must raise all the money they need to provide a thorough and efficient education. . . . But for 10 years and more there has been no thorough and efficient education in these districts. The factors that lead to this failure are described later, but the simplest is that these districts are just too poor to raise the money they theoretically are empowered to. . . . They can, and as we view it, constitutionally they must, be treated differently. Judicial deference can go just so far. $4,029 a Pupil vs. $2,861 The impact of this disparity, solely in dollar terms, is that on the average, in 1984-85, a group of richer districts with 189,484 students spent 40 percent more per pupil than a group of poorer districts with 355,612 students; one provides an education worth $4,029 per pupil, the other, $2,861. For instance, a 3,000-pupil district in a poorer area has a budget of $8.6 million, while a relatively wealthy suburban district with 3,000 pupils has a budget of $12.1 million. The disparity is not as pronounced in the middle, which covers 339 districts and 575,181 students.
We have decided this case on the premise that the children of poorer urban districts are as capable as all others; that their deficiences stem from their socioeconomic status; and that through effective education and changes in that socioeconomic status, they can perform as well as others. Our constitutional mandate does not allow us to consign poorer children permanently to an inferior education on the theory that they cannot afford a better one or that they would not benefit from it.
The 28 poorer urban districts (excluding Atlantic City . . .) have an average per pupil expenditure in 1984-85 of $2,880 and an average equalized valuation per pupil in 1984-85 of $63,066. . . . No sophisticated analysis can destroy the conclusion: the richer districts spend more than the poorer, and their ability to do so is strongly correlated to their wealth.
However, the level of education offered to students in some of the poorer urban districts is tragically inadequate. Many opportunities offered to students in richer suburban districts are denied to them. For instance, exposure to computers is necessary to acquire skills to compete in the workplace. In South Orange-Maplewood school district, kindergarteners are introduced to computers; children learn word processing in elementary school. . . .
 
Computers From Other Funds
By contrast, many poorer urban districts cannot offer such variety of computer-science courses. While Princeton has one computer per eight children, East Orange has one computer per 43 children, and Camden has one computer per 58 children. Camden can offer formal computer instruction to only 3.4 percent of its students. In many poorer urban districts, computers are purchased with Federal or state categorical funds for use in remedial-education programs. Paterson offers no computer education other than computer-assisted basic-skills programs. Further, many of these districts do not have sufficient space to accommodate computer labs. In Jersey City, computer classes are being taught in storage closets.
Science education is deficient in some poorer urban districts. Princeton has seven laboratories in its high school, each with built-in equipment. South Brunswick elementary and middle schools stress hands-on investigative-science programs. However, many poorer urban districts offer science classes in labs built in the 1920's and 1930's, where sinks do not work, equipment such as microscopes is not available, supplies for chemistry or biology classes are insufficient, and hands-on investigative techniques cannot be taught. In Jersey City and Irvington middle-school science classes are taught without provision for laboratory experience.
 
Importance of Foreign Languages
The disparity in foreign-language programs is dramatic. Montclair's students begin instruction in French or Spanish at the preschool level. In Princeton's middle school, fifth-grade students must take a half-year of French and a half-year of Spanish. Most sixth graders continue with one of these languages. Many begin a second langauge in the ninth grade, where four-year programs in German, Italian, Russian and Latin are offered. French and Spanish are offered on two tracks, one for students who began instruction in middle school and the other for those who begin in the ninth grade. Advanced-placement courses are available. In contrast, many of the poorer urban schools do not offer upper-level foreign-language courses, and only begin insstruction in high school. Jersey City starts its foreign-language program in the ninth grade; Paterson begins it at the 10th grade. Most Jersey City high schools offer only two languages.
 
Crumbling Endangers Safety
Many poorer urban districts operate schools that, due to their age and lack of maintenance, are crumbling. . . . Indeed, the safety of children in these schools is threatened. . . .
In contrast, most schools in richer suburban districts are newer, cleaner, and safer. They provide an environment conducive to learning.
Thorough and efficient means more than teaching the skills needed to compete in the labor market, as critically important as that may be. It means being able to fulfill one's role as a citizen, a role that encompasses far more than merely registering to vote. It means the ability to participate fully in society, in the life of one's community, the ability to appreciate music, art and literature, and the ability to share all of that with friends.
We realize our remedy here may fail to achieve the constitutional object, that no amount of money may be able to erase the impact of the socioeconomic factors that define and cause these pupils' disadvantages. We realize that perhaps nothing short of substantial social and economic change affecting housing, employment, child care, taxation, welfare will make the difference for these students; and that this kind of change is far beyond the power or responsiblity of school districts. We have concluded, however, that even if not a cure, money will help, and that these students are constitutionally entitled to that help.
If the claim is that these students simply cannot make it, the constitutional answer is, give them a chance.
We stress that it is state aid only that we are discussing here. The fundamental inequality of local funding through the property tax and the funding disparities it produces are asserted to have a justification in its assurance of local control and its encouragement of citizens' participation in their local school system. . . .
From this record we find that certain poorer urban districts do not provide a thorough and efficient education to their students. The Constitution is being violated. These students in poorer urban districts have not been able to participate fully as citizens and workers in our society. They have not been able to achieve any level of equality in that society with their peers from the affluent suburban districts. We find the consitutional failure clear, severe, extensive and of long duration.

HEADLINE: Uphill Struggle to Adapt Wine to the World's Taste

SERIES: FUTURE ARTICLES WILL DISCUSS PORTUGAL, GERMANY AND THE NAPA VALLEY OF CALIFORNIA.

BYLINE: By FRANK J. PRIAL

DATELINE: MENDOZA, Argentina

 BODY:
A WINE-BOTTLING line is noisy. As the bottles bump along the metal belt waiting their turn to be filled, they clank, rattle and crash into one another, setting up a terrible din.
On the major bottling line here at the Penaflor winery, Argentina's largest and one of the largest in the world, there is hardly any noise: the wine is being packed in one-liter cardboard boxes called tetrapacks.
That particular bottling line says a lot about wine in Argentina. Of course, no one, not even here in the wine capital of the Southern Hemisphere, would put good wine in a plastic box. The Argentines are among the world's leading wine consumers but, for the most part, they have not been overly concerned about quality. 
Or at least, not until recently. For several years now, the Argentine wine business has been adapting - painfully - to the overworked adage that less is more.
Here in this handsome city at the foot of the Andes, 600 miles west of Buenos Aires, wine production has always been described in gargantuan terms: three quarters of a million acres of grapes, an annual output of a half billion gallons of wine, and individual fermenting tanks with the capacity of 10 medium-size California wineries. ''I think we have 40,000 growers,'' said Domenico LoVecchio, the director of the San Telmo winery, ''but nobody knows for sure.''
Most of the growers sell their production, either grapes or wine, to one of about a half-dozen huge wineries where it is blended and shipped.
Much of this wine, probably 70 percent, even today is little more than vin ordinaire, simple table wine. But until recently, it was wine ideally suited to its principal market: Argentina itself. Argentina is the fifth-largest wine producer in the world after Italy, France, the Soviet Union and Spain, and, four years ago was fourth in wine consumption, with per capita consumption at more than 17 gallons a year.
That figure has been dropping, partly because of the disastrous state of Argentina's economy - many people now cannot afford even the cheapest wine - and because, like elsewhere in the world, tastes are changing. Millions of Argentines, it appears, would rather consume soft drinks and beer than the indifferent wine of the criolla grape sold in five-gallon demijohns or in the nondescript tetrapacks. As a result, wineries have been closing and the industry is worried.
But 10 years ago, a handful of farsighted wine makers, mostly based here in Mendoza, decided that the future was in exports. They began to develop the vineyards and the wine-making techniques that would gain them entry into the world's fine wine markets.
There is no reason why Argentina should not be among the world's premium wine producers. Wine has been made here since the Jesuit missionaries arrived in the country in 1556. The criolla grape they brought with them is the basic wine grape of the country. Other Spanish missionaries took the grape into Mexico and the United States, where it is known as the mission grape.
A hundred years ago, Italian immigrants who had grown grapes and made wine in Italy discovered the fertility of the high plains stretching away from this city in every direction. Within a few years, it was Argentina's favorite land for vineyards.
Only now is the long effort beginning to show some success, many years after Chile, which went through many of the same problems, began to make its mark beyond its borders.
Some of Argentina's problems are unique to Argentina. For 40 years, this potentially rich land has been a closed society; closed to innovation, cut off from modern technology and from contemporary political and economic ideas. For example, by law, Argentine products, if available, must be used in preference to better imports. And Penaflor labels its fine wine bottles by hand rather than to use a virtually unworkable domestic machine.
Only after prolonged and costly battles with the bureaucracy were the big wineries here finally permitted to buy European or American presses and oak barrels for aging wine. Still the ravages of inflation are everywhere. What was meant to be one of the most beautiful wineries in the world, San Telmo, here in Mendoza, is a half-built monument to fiscal ineptitude, a partly finished architectural marvel sitting in a sea of mud, surrounded by rusting piles of building materials with which it was to have been finished 10 years ago.
And yet, even San Telmo produces good wines, some of which can be found in the United States. ''We do the best we can,'' Sigifredo Alonso, San Telmo's president, said, ''and we look to the future.''
The future looms large in the lives of Argentines, partly because the present has been bleak for so long. ''Argentina is a nation of unfinished dreams,'' someone once said.
Carlos Pulenta is a director of Penaflor and president of Bodegas Trapiche, Penaflor's fine-wine subsidiary. ''The future for us is in export,'' he said. ''We must export or we will die.'' Dramatic stuff, but Mr. Pulenta, whose grandfather came from Ancona, Italy, to found Penaflor, seems to mean what he says.
He has opened an importing company in New York and plans to do the same soon in London. He has invested heavily in the equipment needed to make and age fine wine and is converting thousands of acres of dull criolla and Pedro Ximenez grapes to chardonnay, malbec and cabernet sauvignon.
For the moment, Trapiche fine wines are only a part of Penaflor's export mix. Bulk wine, millions of gallons of it, are sold to the wine and spirits government monopolies in Finland and other Scandinavian countries. Even major wine producers like France and Spain buy bulk wine from Penaflor. Grape juice concentrate by the shipload goes to Japan where it is made into wine. The country also exports other fruit juices and bottled water. In fact, olive oil brings in more hard currency than wine.
Exporting wine is an uphill fight. The severely taxed Government has no money to spare for promotion, unlike neighboring Chile, where the Government has for almost a decade paid for a sophisticated marketing program for its wine and fruit exports.
Argentina is also hampered by its unfamiliarity with the world wine market. One evening, in the Trapiche tasting room, someone opened a half-bottle of a 1983 cabernet sauvignon from Beaulieau Vineyards in California. The Argentine tasters were delighted. ''One day we will make a wine like this,'' one said. The one American present found the wine faded and oxidized.
Until recently the preferred wine making style in both Chile and Argentina called for many years of aging in large oak casks, just the formula for producing heavy, oxidized wines. Here was a well-known American wine that seemed to conform to that style. Old traditions die hard.
When the Italian wine makers came to Mendoza in the 19th century, they brought the best European grape varieties with them, including cabernet sauvignon. For some reason, malbec, which is the principal variety in Cahors but mostly a blending variety in Bordeaux, in Argentina makes a wine as good as and often better than cabernet sauvignon. Perhaps it resists oxidation more.
In any event, Trapiche makes a malbec that is quite delicious, as does Navarro Correas, one of the most prestigious of the wineries here in Mendoza. Vilma Gutierrez, the chief wine maker at Navarro Correas studied for a time under Zelma Long, for many years the wine maker and now president of the Simi Winery in California.
Two varieties that appear to have considerable promise are merlot and chardonnay. The best merlots seem softer and more harmonious, certainly more so than the cabernets, and avoid what tasters call the ''hotness'' associated with oxidation. The best chardonnays, Trapiche's among them, are fresh and clean. There seems to be no overwhelming need to age them in oak.
Chenin blanc, produced in considerable quantity in Argentina is no better than it should be, and pinot noir is still pretty much in the experimental stage.
In spite of the county's chaotic economic condition, progress continues here. Old vineyards are torn out and new grapes planted. New growing areas are opening up at higher elevations like Tupungato and in cooler climes like Rio Negro, 500 miles to the south. Techniques continue to be refined, better clones of grapes are developed, wine makers go abroad to study. The wines now in export markets show this improvement, particularly the whites. Excellent sparkling wines are being made here; wines that could compete with any other than champagne itself, if they were to be exported in some quantity.
But there is a long way to go. Until the economy is brought into line, there is little likelihood that outside investors - or the Argentines who squirrel most of their income in Swiss banks - will put up the kind of capital needed to modernize the Argentine wine industry. And, given the current downturn in the world wine market, who can say it would be a wise investment if they did?
For the wine fan, however, the Argentine wines are a whole new world to explore. And, given their remarkably low prices at the moment - mostly under $10 for the good wines - it can be a rather reasonable trip.
 
Buying Them
THE best endorsement for the Argentine wine may be the fact that Argentines drink almost all of it themselves.
Argentine wines may not be readily available in your corner liquor store yet, but with a little effort you will find them.
The best-known name is Bodegas Trapiche, the prestige export label of the huge Penaflor. The Trapiche Reserva line includes cabernet sauvignon, malbec, chardonnay and pinot noir, all costing about $5.99. San Telmo includes a cabernet sauvignon and a chardonnay at about $7.99. Navarro Correas offers a malbec, a syrah and a pinot noir in its Collecion Privada group, all at $8.99. Navarro's sauvignon blanc sells for about $7.50.
Other labels to look for include Clos du Moulin, Fond de Cave, Comte de Valmont and Palmero, whose 1984 merlot, for about $6 is a solid bargain.
Worth sampling, too, are the wines of Humberto Canale, which come from Rio Negro. The Canale Reserva line includes a semillon, a cabernet sauvignon and a merlot. Some stores may still have the 1978 cabernet for under $10, a wine well worth trying.

HEADLINE: U.S. Bars A Soviet Phone Deal

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
The Commerce Department told U S West Inc. yesterday that the Government opposed a project to build a fiber-optic cable communications system across the Soviet Union, linking Japan and Europe.
The move signals that despite the reforms sweeping Eastern Europe, the Administration remains wary of exporting high technology to the Soviet Union.
U S West, one of seven regional Bell operating companies, said the department had expressed concern that building the $500 million system could threaten the national security. The department said it would oppose the release of any high-speed telecommunications transmission technology to the Soviet Union by any country, said H. Laird Walker, the company's vice president for Federal Government relations. 
An official of the Commerce Department confirmed that the Administration opposed building the system. ''After careful analysis of the strategic and international factors, it was determined by the Administration that the transfer of such sophisticated technology would be contrary to U.S. national security interests,'' said the official, who asked not to be identified.
 
Reaction of Diplomat
When told of the U S West announcement, Vitaliy Verzhbitskiy, an economic affairs officer of the Soviet Embassy in Washington, criticized the Administration's decision. ''Following the success of the summit, I think that the timing of this negative response is very bad,'' he said.
Mr. Verzhbitskiy said he hoped the Administration would change its position. ''Communications these days are the key element of many of our bilateral relations,'' he said, mentioning cultural, economic and scientific exchanges with the West as examples.
U S West, based in Englewood, Colo., is leading an international consortium that planned to build the system to carry international calls and computer data between Europe and Japan, as well as long-distance calls within the Soviet Union.
Mr. Walker of U S West said the consortium had agreed on safeguards to prevent the use of the project for military or intelligence purposes. He criticized the Administration's decision and said the company would ask the Commerce Department to review its decision.
Commerce Department rules provide for such a review, he said, adding, ''It's a major lost opportunity if the project does not go forward.''
The House of Representatives is scheduled to vote today on a bill that would liberalize rules governing the export of advanced telecommunications and computer equipment to the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. And Cocom, the 17-nation export review agency, is scheduled to meet today in Paris to begin negotiations on whether to relax its rules.
 
Criticism From Lawmaker
Sam Gejdenson, the Connecticut Democrat who co-sponsored the House bill with Toby Roth, Republican of Wisconsin, strongly criticized the Administration's decision. ''It's a serious blow to American high-technology exports,'' he said. ''If anything, the information age works to destroy dictatorship.''
Yesterday's move also came a day after Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev concluded a visit to the United States that was intended, in part, to encourage Western investment in the Soviet Union.
Cocom, or the Coordinating Committee on Multilateral Export Controls, consists of most NATO members, plus Australia and Japan. It has placed embargoes on the export of fiber-optic technology by its members out of concern that it could be used for military purposes.
 
Approval Was Indicated
The Commerce Secretary, Robert A. Mosbacher, told reporters on Dec. 19 that the United States would approve the U S West fiber-optic system provided that the technology involved 5- to 10-year-old technology and not the latest equipment available.
Optical fibers are hair-thin strands of glass that carry conversations and computer data on beams of laser light.
The proposed system would use technology that was first installed in the American telephone network in late 1983, and has been routinely installed nationwide since 1985, said R. Edward Mattix, a spokesman for U S West.
An Administration official said yesterday that military and intelligence officials had blocked the deal because it would impair the ability of the United States to monitor Soviet communications.
 
Reliance on Microwaves
The Soviet Union's communications system now relies heavily on the beaming of microwaves, which can be tapped by satellites and other means. By contrast, fiber-optic cables are typically buried in the ground and are virtually impossible to tap without physical access to the system.

HEADLINE: Sales of U.S.-Made Autos Down 6% in May

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, June 5

 BODY:
Sales of domestically produced cars fell 6 percent in May, as seven months of sluggish consumer demand showed a faint sign of revival during the last 10 days of the month. Sales of domestically produced light trucks rose nine-tenths of 1 percent for the 10-day period.
The seasonally adjusted annual rate for the period was 7.3 million, the highest sales rate since late January, but below the 7.8 million rate registered in the period last year.
Together, sales of domestically made cars and trucks fell 3.7 percent, to 457,565, in the May 21-30 period, compared with 422,134 a year earlier. There were nine selling days this year and eight a year earlier. 
May car sales, including domestics and imports, were 885,279, down 8.6 percent from last May's 968,897. For the month the seasonally adjusted annual rate of car sales was 6.6 million, compared with 7.5 million last May.
Tom Webb, chief economist for the National Association of Automobile Dealers, said, ''I would not label overall demand as strong,'' despite the relative uptick from last year. Of domestically built vehicles, Mr. Webb said, ''The only units that are really moving are the totally redesigned models and the niche markets such as sports-utilities and luxury cars.''
Joel Pitcoff, a sales analyst for the Ford Motor Company, said: ''We were encouraged by the last couple of days of the month. The middle of the month was very slow. There were no bodies'' in the showrooms.
The Big Three also lost market share in May, declining 3.7 points from a year ago, to 69.1 percent, while the leading Japanese producers gained market share. Year-to-year comparisons of market-share penetration showed that the General Motors Corporation slipped to 36.2 percent, from 37 percent, Ford Motor slipped to 22.6 percent from 24.3 percent and the Chrysler Corporation slipped to 12.9 percent from 14.3 percent.
Toyota, however, rose to 8 percent from 5.6 percent, Honda rose to 6.4 percent from 5.8 percent, and Nissan rose to 4.2 percent from 3.9 percent.
In the last 10 days of May, G.M. was off 7 percent in car sales, including imports sold under the brand names of G.M. divisions. The company reported a 1.8 percent increase in truck sales. Total vehicle sales for the period were down 4.4 percent.
For the month, G.M.'s car sales were down 12.2 percent, including imports, and truck sales were down 3.5 percent. Total vehicle sales in May were off 9.5 percent from a year ago.
Chrysler, which has been holding a nationwide publicity tour since February to revive sales, reported a 10.8 percent drop in total vehicle sales in late May, including imported cars and trucks sold as Chrysler-brand vehicles. For all of May, Chrysler's car and truck sales were off about 17 percent, to 168,080, from 202,161 a year ago.
Ford suffered an 8.2 percent decline in total vehicle sales in late May to 130,379 cars and trucks, including imports, from 126,262 a year ago. For the month, total vehicle sales were down 14.1 percent, to 299,318 from 348,553 a year ago.
Light-truck sales were a bright spot for Ford, rising 1.4 percent in late May, to 55,712 from 48,856 a year ago. For the month light-truck sales were off 4.9 percent, to 128,550, from 135,154 a year ago.
The United States sales branch of the Honda Motor Company said sales of domestically produced Hondas fell 9.3 percent in late May, to 24,523, from 24,038 a year ago. But total Honda sales for May, including those of the company's Acura luxury division, were 84,203, a 2.3 percent increase from sales of 82,327 a year ago.
Toyota said United States sales of Toyota brand cars and trucks in May set a record, 99,193 cars, or 24.8 percent higher than a year ago. Toyota's Lexus division posted sales of 5,102 for the month; Lexus began selling cars only last November.
