HEADLINE: Citicorp Ratings: Jarring Reminders

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Citicorp is accustomed to superlatives.
It is the nation's largest banking company, operates the largest and most profitable credit card business, controls the biggest share of the New York market, makes more home mortgages than any other company, and spends more than any other bank on computer technology.
But one superlative Citicorp lacks is ''top rated,'' as in triple-A, the rating assigned to bonds of the safest, highest-quality companies. Citicorp lost its triple-A luster in the early 1980's, and in the last seven weeks has been hit by a spate of fresh reductions by three rating agencies.
The lower ratings have only a minor effect on the amount of interest Citicorp pays to borrow money. But they are a reminder that not all of the company's activities are as profitable as its consumer banking business, which is likely to make more than $1 billion this year. 
With more than 5 percent of its loans either not earning interest or about to go into default, Citicorp's profits have declined, making it difficult for the company to rebuild its weakened capital base to a level that satisfies rating agencies.
''While Citibank probably is the world's most technologically advanced financial institution, at the same time it is just one more undercapitalized bank with a large collection of borrowers who can't pay it back,'' said Peter Treadway, an analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.
Citicorp's chairman, John S. Reed, rose to the top on the strength of his management of the consumer banking business and highly computerized back-office operations. Although Mr. Reed inherited Citicorp's troubled loans to less developed countries, problems with loans for commercial real estate and for financing leveraged buyouts developed during his watch.
Like many other banking companies, Citicorp has recently suffered from losses on commercial real estate loans, a business where it is the leading bank lender. It is also the leading bank lender for leveraged buyouts and other deals for heavily indebted companies, which expose it to additional losses if more of those borrowers go the way of the Campeau Corporation, whose American retailing units filed for bankruptcy protection this year.
The risks of these two lending segments were apparent in the first quarter, when Citicorp said its nonperforming loans - those that are not earning interest or that face other troubles - rose by $548 million, to $8.2 billion.
About half of the increase was in loans for leveraged buyouts. Troubled loans for commercial real estate projects rose $119 million, to a total of $1.3 billion, out of the $12 billion of all such loans.
Last month, Thomas E. Jones, Citicorp's chief financial officer, told analysts that the weak American economy and the rocky real estate market would cause the amount of troubled loans to rise by another $500 million or $600 million before the end of the year. Such an increase would make 1990 the second consecutive year in which nonperforming loans increased by more than $1 billion.
As a percent of total loans and real estate owned, Citicorp's nonperforming loans are higher than 40 of the nation's 50 largest banking companies.
 
Lending Problems Overseas
The rising tide of troubled loans in the United States comes while Citibank is still feeling the ill effects of its lending to less developed countries - another category where it has been the industry leader.
As it became clearer that some of these countries could not repay their loans - or even, in some cases, meet interest payments - Citibank was the first bank to set aside a significant amount to cover possible losses. A reserve provision of $3 billion in 1987 and another of $1 billion in the fourth quarter of 1989 eliminated profits in those periods and cut into capital.
Now, reserves equal only about 38 percent of Citicorp's remaining long-term loans to less developed countries, less than at many other large banks. Many analysts expect Citicorp will be forced to set aside additional funds to cover possible future losses, hurting profits again.
 
Less Cushion
With capital of $8.3 billion as of March 31, or roughly 3.5 percent of assets, Citicorp has a smaller cushion available to absorb future losses than other large banking companies have. Mr. Reed, the company's chairman, said earlier this year that Citicorp would not raise capital by issuing more stock unless it was for an acquisition. He said the bank's capital position would be strengthened by profits from regular operations; by the sale of some businesses, including the Ambac Indemnity Corporation, a municipal bond insurer, and by restraining future growth of assets.
The harshest judgment of Citicorp came from Moody's Investors Service. Moody's, which has cut ratings on more than 40 banks and savings associations this year, cut Citicorp's long-term senior bond rating in late May to A-3 from A-1. The new rating is about average for these bonds for all banking companies Moody's rates.
 
Short-Term Ratings
Citicorp's problems are severe enough, Moody's said, to also justify cuts in short-term ratings, which are changed far less frequently than long-term ratings. Citicorp's commercial paper was dropped from the P-1 rating desired by many investors to P-2. Citibank's certificates of deposit due in less than a year were unchanged at P-1, but C.D.'s due in more than a year were cut to a medium grade of A-1 from a high grade of Aa-2.
All of the Moody's ratings remain well within the range earned by investment-quality companies that face no imminent threat of default. But the declines mean, in the view of Moody's analysts, that negative forces like Citicorp's ''deteriorating asset quality'' and its vulnerability to the weakening real estate market outweigh the benefits of ''a successful consumer franchise,'' ready access to cash, strong management and the diversity of its businesses over both the short and long term.
Two other rating agencies, the Standard & Poor's Corporation and Fitch Investors Service, were kinder than Moody's, but agreed that the ratings trend for Citicorp is lower.
Fitch, a New York rating firm, cut Citicorp's long-term debt ratings slightly last week, to AA- from AA, but left the commercial paper rating unchanged at the top-notch F-1+ level.
''We expect Citicorp will handle its problems and improve its condition,'' said Joseph L. Labriola of Fitch. ''Its consumer business is very strong and it has the most diverse sources of profits from wholesale banking and consumer finance businesses around the world, of any banking company.''
Standard & Poor's, the first company to reduce Citicorp's ratings this year, cut its long-term rating on senior debt in late April to AA-, from AA, and left short-term commercial paper and certificate of deposit ratings unchanged at the top A-1+ level.
Analysts and Citicorp officials say the rating changes will have little effect on the company. ''The lower ratings do not hurt Citicorp much in the pocketbook, but they are a blow to its prestige,'' said Ann Robinson, an analyst of banking company bonds at the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation.
 
Less Long-Term Borrowing
Nancy S. Newcomb, senior corporate officer in charge of funding at Citicorp, noted that the company had greatly cut back the amount of money it borrows in the long-term market. Over the last three years, long-term issues by Citicorp have averaged about $2.5 billion a year, down from $6 billion in 1986.
Rather than issue bonds backed by its own credit, Citicorp has turned to the sale of securities backed by pools of credit-card loans, which can be issued at lower interest. Sales of these securities have totaled more than $8 billion so far this year, exceeding the pace of 1989, when it sold $15 billion.
Growth in the deposits from Citibank's consumer banking business in New York has also reduced its need to borrow money in the wholesale markets, where the ratings are used, Ms. Newcomb noted. Since mid-1987, Citicorp's commercial paper outstanding has fallen to about $6 billion, from more than $11 billion, said Mr. Labriola of Fitch.
 
Rates Have Risen
Despite its reduced borrowing levels, the lower ratings have caused interest rates on Citicorp's securities to rise slightly.
Since Moody's warned in mid-April that it might lower Citicorp's ratings, rates have increased slightly, relative to Treasury bills, at weekly auctions of Citicorp commercial paper. Since the warning, rates for Citicorp's 91-day paper have averaged 49-hundredths of a percentage point more than the average rate for 91-day Treasury bills. During the nine weeks before Moody's warning, the 91-day rate averaged only 38-hundredths of a percentage point more than Treasury bills.
William King, a bond market analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company, estimated that rating cuts have also caused yields on Citicorp's long-term bonds to rise about a tenth of a percentage point, to about 1.5 percentage points more than Treasury issues.
While many banking companies have long-term bonds that sell at yields lower than Citicorp's, Mr. King noted that at current yield levels ''there is a lot of grass-roots support among investors for Citicorp issues.''

HEADLINE: Antitrust Limit Voted By House

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 5

 BODY:
The House of Representatives today approved a bill intended to enhance the competitiveness of American companies by limiting their liability for antitrust violations, over the objections of foreign investors who would not receive the legislation's benefits.
The bill was passed by a voice vote after a 40-minute debate in which House members expressed concern over the ability of American companies to compete in the global marketplace.
The measure, which had bipartisan support, would relax antitrust laws for joint ventures in manufacturing, a condition that already exists in joint research and development projects. By removing triple damages for antitrust violations in manufacturing, joint ventures would appear less risky to American companies, in the view of the bill's supporters, who say that the threat of costly damage awards has inhibited many such ventures even though they would not have violated the antitrust laws. 
 
Called Counterproductive
Foreign investors, however, had asked that the bill, the National Cooperative Production Amendments of 1990, not be considered, saying that the measure would prove counterproductive because it would discourage foreign participation in research ventures at a time when the United States was seeking access to foreign technology.
Representative Bill Frenzl, a Minnesota Republican, saying that ''we are trying to remove investment restrictions around the world,'' argued that the bill ''discriminates against international investment.''
Foreign companies are believed to enjoy an advantage because their governments support, rather than penalize, joint ventures. Some foreign governments coordinate and provide subsidies for ventures that would enhance technologies.
 
Restrictions Included
The bill passed today would extend the benefits of the National Cooperative Research Act of 1984, which only covered research and development ventures. Under today's bill, joint ventures for both manufacturing and research would not be eligible if foreign investors had an interest of more than 30 percent in any of the companies involved, or if the joint ventures were outside the United States or its territories.
Representative Jack Brooks, a Texas Democrat who is the chairman of the Judiciary Committee and who sponsored the bill approved today, accepted a change that would enable Canadian companies to benefit from the measure, in accordance with the Canada-United States free-trade agreement.
Foreign investors also complained that the measure would violate bilateral treaties that provided that foreign companies would receive the same treatment as domestic companies.
But supporters called it a long overdue measure that provided only a fraction of the assistance that some governments provide to make their companies competitive. And they noted that it would not bar joint ventures with foreign investors, but merely provide fewer benefits to those ventures.
A similar bill is pending before the Senate Judiciary Committee's Subcommittee on Antitrust, Monopolies and Business Rights, which plans hearings this summer. The bill is co-sponsored by Senators Patrick J. Leahy, a Vermont Democrat, and Strom Thurmond, a South Carolina Republican. The Senate bill would not exclude foreign investors from the benefits.
 
Hailed by Both Parties
During the House debate, both Democrats and Republicans hailed the measure as strengthening America's ability to compete overseas. Representative Norman Y. Mineta, a California Democrat, called the bill ''a large step toward helping United States high-tech industries resume their leadership'' in world markets.
Representative Carlos J. Moorhead, a California Republican, said that ''this is another logical and important step in the effort to assure that America remains economically strong as we enter the 21st century.''
Representative Ron Wyden, an Oregon Democrat, countered that ''foreign investors are outrageous in their criticism of this bill,'' noting that many foreign governments gave their companies far more help than does the United States in the form of subsidies, low-interest loans and other assistance.
 
Opposition to Exclusion
The Bush Administration favors the relaxation of the antitrust laws to promote joint ventures, but opposes the exclusion of foreign-owned companies. Representative Hamilton Fish, a New York Republican and a co-sponsor of the bill, said that the Administration position was prompted by ''some fear of foreign retaliation.''
Foreign investors tried unsuccessfully to persuade the Speaker of the House, Thomas S. Foley, a Washington Democrat, to remove the measure from the House calendar. The request was made by Elliot L. Richardson, chairman of the Association for International Investment, which represents foreign investors.
The voice vote, instead of a roll-call vote, provided anonymity for the many House members who have foreign investments in their states.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Cocaine Policy: Gauging Success

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
ITEM: In recent months the price of Bolivian coca leaf has fallen below production costs.
Item: The Miami wholesale price of a kilogram of pure cocaine rose by roughly 20 percent in the last quarter of 1989. Does this mean the war on drugs is being won? Probably not, argue the handful of economists who analyze the market for illicit drugs the way others plot perturbations in soybean supply and demand. Hard times for Bolivian coca farmers, they believe, are evidence of changes in distribution patterns, not a severing of the long chain of supply from the farmers' fields to the crack houses of America's inner cities. Moreover, the uptick in wholesale cocaine prices has not - could not -have much effect on the street price. 
The peculiar nature of the cocaine market, they assert, makes it almost impossible to win the war on the supply side. Only demand-side strategies hold much promise, and they have yet to win the hearts and minds of Washington's drug centurions.
The price of coca leaf in Bolivia, until recently the supplier of one-third of all the leaf used in cocaine manufacture, has indeed collapsed. And the most plausible explanation is that the regular routes between the fields in Bolivia and processing plants in Colombia have been disrupted by aggressive interdiction in both countries.
But as Peter Reuter, an economist at the Rand Corporation, notes, there is little evidence that supplies of the finished product have been significantly affected. Colombian manufacturers and distributors may be operating on their large inventories while they search for alternative sources of the raw material.
That would mesh with the interpretation of Bruce Bagley, a researcher at the University of Miami. Mr. Bagley believes that the brunt of the anti-drug effort in Colombia has been directed against Medellin producers, rather than their rivals in Cali. And the Cali group may be retreating to growing areas within Colombia, which are near the city.
But it is also possible, Mr. Reuter points out, that production lost in Bolivia has already been recouped in Peru, where the Shining Path guerrillas protect the fields and the lines of supply.
The land suitable for coca plant cultivation in Peru alone (and for that matter, in Bolivia, Colombia or Brazil) is far, far larger than the acreage needed to meet total international demand. And according to Mark A. R. Kleiman at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government, no law of nature restricts growth to Latin America: Indonesia was a principal legal supplier between the world wars. It follows that relatively modest efforts to stop the coca leaf traffic from one country would lead to a rapid switch to others.
But to Mr. Reuter, the worst news is the old news: supply-side strategies are inherently constrained by the pattern of markups on cocaine sales. In 1988, it cost just $750 to buy enough Peruvian coca leaf to make a kilogram of the pure drug. Colombian exporters of the processed 2.2 pounds charged just $1,900, while the importers who got the kilo past Miami customs received just $15,000 from major wholesalers.
Once divided and redivided for retail sale, however, the kilo was marked up to about $135,000. Thus a heroic effort to eradicate crops or smash supply routes that increased the cost of the leaf tenfold would have added just 5 percent ($6,750) to the cost on the street. Doubling seizures from importers - and presumably the ''valued added'' in transit - would have increased the competitive cost on the street by just 10 percent ($13,500).
By parallel logic, the 20 percent increase in the Miami wholesale price actually measured in 1989 would have increased retail costs by about 2 percent. In fact, Drug Enforcement Agency figures show no increase; the average street price remains well below 1986 levels.
If the supply-side approach is a task for Sisyphus, what might get the rock to the top of the mountain?
Mr. Kleiman would transfer anti-drug resources to street enforcement, reducing casual access and hence the demand from nonaddicted users. Mr. Reuter looks to education in the broadest sense -to the tales of death and destruction from cocaine that ought to scare away the curious. And as he points out, long-term evidence of decreasing use along with more recent reports of falling hospital admissions for cocaine abuse do offer a glimmer of hope.
But to date, the compelling economic logic against supply-side cocaine policy has apparently made the barest dent on the political culture. As long as Americans measure success in the drug war by acres of plants uprooted, tons of powder confiscated or arrests of young users, it probably will not.

HEADLINE: Dow Falls 10.19 on Weaker Bond Prices

BYLINE: By DANIEL F. CUFF

 BODY:
Stock prices retreated yesterday, as the recent record-setting run-up faltered in the face of weaker bond prices.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell by 10.19 points, to 2,925.00, in robust trading. Volume totaled 199.7 million shares, compared with 175.5 million on Monday. Declining issues numbered 813 with 774 advancing. 
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fell by 0.76, to 366.64.
The market was positive at the start, with the Dow gaining 12 points, but after the second hour it sold off and remained in a narrow trading range until it began to sink lower in the afternoon.
''The market was under the wrath of the bond market today,'' said Paul Kronlokken, an analyst at Piper, Jaffray & Hopwood in Minneapolis.
The analyst said he did not completely fathom why the bond market was down, as nothing occurred to revise hopes for lower interest rates or inflation. ''It was probably profit taking'' in the bond market, as well as the stock market, he said.
 
An 'Overdue' Pause
The pause was ''overdue,'' said another analyst, Robert B. Ritter of Ladenburg, Thalmann & Company, ''and I don't see how it was set off by any particular incident. The only thing I can see to isolate is that oil prices were down.''
Lower oil prices depressed stocks in the oilfield-service industry, creating selling, or the excuse to do so, after good run-ups in some stocks. Baker Hughes, was down by 2, to 27 5/8; Halliburton was off by 2 3/4, to 46 1/4, and Schlumberger was down by 2 3/4, to 55 3/4.
Airline issues, looking to prospects for cheaper fuel, gained. AMR, the parent of American Airlines, rose by 1 3/8, to 68 7/8, and Delta Air Lines added 5/8, to 80, helping to buoy the Dow Jones transportation index, which rose by 4.74, to 1,212.59.
AMR has been strong lately, and it was aided yesterday by a report projecting higher earnings for the second quarter and the year by a Timothy Pettee, an analyst for Merrill Lynch & Company. He also predicted no debilitating fare war between carriers this year.
Fluor's earnings for the second quarter disappointed analysts, and the stock fell by 1 7/8, to 46 7/8.
Most financial issues held their gains, with BankAmerica up by 1/2, to 33 1/8, and Citicorp rising by 3/8, to 25.
Philips Industries posted a 3 3/4-point, or 23.2 percent, gain, to 17 1/4. It agreed to be sold to Tomkins, a British industrial group, for $550 million, or $18.50 a share. The stock's percentage rise was the Big Board's largest.
Kellogg gained 3 3/4, to 72. Nomi Ghez, an analyst at Goldman, Sachs & Company, changed her rating to a buy, from a strong hold.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Mostly Down; Gold Prices Climb in U.S.

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar ended mostly lower yesterday, reflecting continued concern about the direction of interest rates. Gold prices rose following a mixed performance overseas.
Currency dealers said worries about the effects of a reunified Germany were lending some suppport to the dollar, but that was being overidden by concern about interest rates. 
Recent reports showing sluggish economic growth have some dealers worried that the Federal Reserve might be loosening its credit grip, they said. Lower interest rates often depress a currency. Economic data due out next week, including reports on consumer and producer prices for May, could shed more light on the economy's direction.
In Tokyo, where global trading begins, the dollar rose 0.01 yen, to 152.43 yen. It traded at 152.55 yen in London, and at 152.35 yen in New York, down from 152.65 on Monday.
 
Pound Stronger
The dollar weakened against the British pound. Sterling bought $1.6820 in London, up from $1.6745 on Monday, and $1.6880 in New York, up from $1.6770 on Monday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's quotes, were: 1.6840 West German marks, down from 1.6905; 1.4280 Swiss francs, down from 1.4340; 5.6785 French francs, down from 5.6960; 1,240.00 Italian lire, down from 1,243.00, and 1.17605 Canadian dollars, up from 1.17475.
Late dollar rates in Europe, compared with Monday's, were: 1.6910 West German marks, down from 1.6940; 1.4340 Swiss francs, down from 1.4390; 5.7020 French francs, down from 5.7080; 1.9070 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9068; 1,244.25 Italian lire, down from 1,245.50, and 1.1752 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1763.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $359.80 an ounce, up $1.20. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold of $359 an ounce, up $1.60.
Gold traded in London at a late bid price of $359.25 an ounce, up from $356.05 Monday.
In Zurich, the bid price was $358.60 an ounce, down from $363 late Friday. Zurich markets were closed Monday for a religious holiday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell 81 cents, to $359.87.
Silver prices strengthened. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $5.065 an ounce, up 1.6 cents from Monday. Silver rose in London, to $5.08 an ounce from $5.03.

HEADLINE: TAX REVOLT FADES AS CALIFORNIANS VOTE AN INCREASE

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ORESKES

 BODY:
More than a decade after they led a revolt against taxes and spending, California voters turned around in elections Tuesday and approved higher gasoline taxes, a looser limit on state spending and more than $4 billion in bonds.
As the final returns from California became available yesterday there was talk in Washington and state capitals of a watershed in the long struggle over taxes and spending.
''The tax revolt which allegedly started in California has been tempered by a realization that we have to make investments in the country,'' Speaker Thomas S. Foley, Democrat of Washington, said on Capitol Hill yesterday.
 
Firsts for Women, Blacks
The decisions on taxes and spending in California were among several important results from elections Tuesday in nine states. [Chart of election results, page B6.] Dianne Feinstein, the former Mayor of San Francisco, became the first woman to win the Democratic nomination for governor of California, and in North Carolina, Harvey Gantt, the former Mayor of Charlotte, became the first black person ever nominated by the Democratic Party to run for the United States Senate. 
The emerging power of the abortion issue was demonstrated anew as abortion rights supporters won a crucial victory in the Iowa Democratic primary for governor. But abortion opponents had their own victories in Republican primaries in California and Montana. [Page B6.] Not a 'Stifling' Increase Still, it was California's tax and spending measure, Proposition 111, that aroused the most attention. It doubles the state gasoline tax, from 9 cents to 18 cents over five years, and loosens the limits that have restricted state spending since voters approved Proposition 13 in 1978.
Gov. George Dukemejian, a Republican, noted that the voters had not approved ''some stifling general tax increase'' but rather a specific gasoline tax increase that will go directly to repair California's highways and improve mass transit.
Some opponents of government spending were disconsolate over passage of Proposition 111, while some liberal politicians viewed the vote as a sign that taxes, while hardly popular, can win voter approval if government leaders demonstrate a clear and specific need.
While gasoline prices vary greatly from week to week and around the state, a gallon of unleaded regular gasoline currently sells for about $1.12 a gallon in California. Backers of Proposition 111 said its average cost to each California motorist would be $60 a year.
California has one of the lowest gasoline taxes in the country, and is one of many states raising them this year.
The proposal was approved by 53 percent of the voter, with 47 percent opposing. Mervin Field, the California poll taker, pointed out that slightly more than one in four citizens had voted, but he added that his surveys suggested that nonvoters would actually have been slightly more prone to support the new taxes.
 
'Elimination' of the Revolt
''What you saw in the elections was a wholesale elimination of the tax revolt,'' said Arthur Laffer, the California economist whose supply-side economic theories in the late 1970's inspired Ronald Reagan's budget policies. Dr. Laffer particular pointed to the section of Proposition 111 that will loosen state spending limits.
Dr. Laffer, who had campaigned against the ballot measure, said he expected California's economy to slow as a result of higher taxes and government spending.
While politicians tended to view the California vote as indicative of a shift in public sentiment, they also were cautious, noting several special factors.
Proposition 111 and a companion transportation bond issue, they pointed out, were overwhelming favored by the leadership of both major political parties, as well as by unions, construction contractors and groups representing motorists and mass transportation interests.
Moreover, leaders of California's higher education system campaigned for the measure, even though none of the revenue would directly benefit their systems. They reasoned that the part of the measure loosening state spending would make it easier for them to win budget increases.
 
Only a Narrow Margin
Even with such formidable support and a disorganized opposition, the political analysts noted, the proposition passed by a fairly narrow margin. Indeed, in the closing days of the campaign, supporters feared they were losing. And while the backers spent more than $5 million on the campaign, far more than the opponents, in the end, voters cast ballots along predictable lines, according to a survey of voters as they left polling places Tuesday. The poll was conducted by Voter Research and Surveys.
Those who identified themselves as liberal supported the measure 2 to 1, while those who called themselves conservative were against it, 59 percent to 41 percent.
Low-income voters, for whom the tax would presumably consume a larger share of their incomes, opposed the measure, while the wealthiest supported it.
The outcome was being closely watched both in state capitals, where fuel tax increases are frequently proposed to finance transportation improvements, and in Washington, where there are several proposals for an energy tax increase if budget negotiators decide to raise taxes as part of their effort to reduce the Federal deficit.
Indeed, Federal officials have become increasingly uneasy as state after state increased fuel taxes, making it politically harder to raise such taxes nationally.
Aside from California, 16 states have increased gasoline taxes this year as they struggled to pay highway repair bills with no propsect of more Federal aid.
Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner said yesterday that the California vote was evidence that ''the people of this country will support additional taxes for infrasturcture if they can be shown where their money will go.''
 
Low Gas Tax in New York
But he also said it suggests that the taxes can be raised at the state level, which is where the Bush Administration has said the burden of increased spending on transportation should fall.
Mr. Skinner noted that New York has large highway and mass transit needs but a a low gasoline tax.
Governor Mario M. Cuomo of New York noted the importance of tying any tax increase to specific spending.
''The politicians have lost the credibility that would allow them to say we must raise your taxes to be spent as necessary,'' Mr. Cuomo said. ''They don't trust us to do it and I don't blame them. There has been that much waste.''
He said he had asked his staff to carefully review the California vote.

HEADLINE: Administration To Weigh Plan For Military Cut

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 6

 BODY:
White House and Congressional negotiators resumed their budget talks today, with the first indication that the Bush Administration is prepared to offer a plan for reducing military spending.
Defense Secretary Dick Cheney emerged from the daylong session, the first since the lawmakers' Memorial Day recess, and told reporters he would prepare a study showing the policy effects of a 25 percent cut in troops, ships and airplanes over five years.
But Democrats on the negotiating team said the study would also outline the dollar effect of such a cut, and added that it would probably yield a military spending level somewhat lower than the one proposed by the Administration in January.
 
Focus on a Single Plan
The move was the first agreement by the Pentagon to demands from lawmakers to focus on a single plan to reduce the number of troops, ships and air wings, and on the dollar implications of such a reduction. In the Air Force, a wing usually consists of 72 planes. 
Previously, the Pentagon has talked only about cuts in individual components of the military and has never provided Congress a detailed and comprehensive assessment.
Senator Sam Nunn, a Georgia Democrat who heads the Senate Armed Services Committee, noted that this was not the first time the Defense Department had discussed a 25 percent reduction in the structure of personnel, equipment and weaponry in the armed services. But he said the Pentagon had never actually put together the details or the budget implications of such a reduction.
''The Secretary is now willing to undertake in one week what he has been so far telling the Armed Services committees would take until Septemeber,'' Senator Nunn said. He said that while a 25 percent cut would not translate into an equal amount of spending cuts, he considered Mr. Cheney's agreement to produce the study ''real progress'' on a critical element of the Pentagon budget.
 
'Significant Savings' Seen
''It seems if you cut the force structure by 25 percent you would have significant savings in dollars,'' said Senator Jim Sasser, a Democrat from Tennessee who heads the Senate Budget Committee.
But Secretary Cheney insisted that the correlation was by no means certain. ''We're not talking about a 25 percent dollar reduction,'' he said. ''It's a 25 percent force reduction.''
Senator Nunn took the middle road. ''I don't think in the first year you're going to get anything like the dollar cuts talked about by the budget committees,'' he said. ''But I think it will translate into more military cuts than the Administration was talking about in January.''
The budget that the Administration submitted in January called for military spending - that is, actual cash outlays - of $303.3 billion in the fiscal year 1991, which begins on Oct. 1. This figure would mean cutting 1991 military spending about $3 billion below last year's level, after adjusting for inflation.
Using the same yardstick, the budget resolution adopted by the House earlier this year would cut spending by $11.5 billion; the measure adopted in the Senate Budget Committee would reduce it by about $13 billion. Senator Nunn has recomended that 1991 spending be cut by $10 billion, a figure that he said represented a 20 percent reduction in personnel, equipment and weaponry.
The Senator said he believed Mr. Cheney's aim was to achieve a 25 percent force structure reduction over five years. ''I don't think this is a number he threw out casually,'' Mr. Nunn said.
He also said he was particularly pleased that Congressional negotiators and the Pentagon now seemed to be talking about five-year military planning, an approach that he said would allow for a much more efficient reshaping of the military budget.
''At least we've got a group of people trying to put something together,'' Mr. Nunn said. ''In that sense it is real progress, a foundation on which we can build.
Representative Leon E. Panetta, a California Democrat who heads the House Budget Committee, called today's budget session ''the most substantive'' to date.
''It's certainly an important step in the right direction, but whether it takes us to a consensus on defense numbers remains to be seen,'' he said. ''At least we're talking about similar concepts, and the agreement that we focus on 25 percent force structure reduction over five years opens the door.''
A decision on military spending is critical because the Pentagon consumes about a fourth of the Federal budget, and savings in that area determine how much leeway Congress has in setting spending levels for other programs.
Earlier in the day House Democrats, saying they were increasingly frustrated with the lack of serious bargaining, laid plans to begin work on the 13 annual spending bills that finance Federal programs, using the budget measure adopted by the House earlier this year as an overall spending guideline.
''What are we going to do, just shut down the House and Senate and let the summit find all the answers when we don't even know where we are going?'' Mr. Panetta asked reporters. ''By July 4, if we're not talking about deficit options, really bargaining, then it is going to be pretty clear the summit is bogged down.''
House Republicans, in a view echoed by their Senate counterparts, protested that action on the spending bills now would undercut the budget talks and suggested that both the House and Senate direct the negotiatiors to produce deficit-cutting recommendations by June 28.
 
'An Act of Bad Faith'
''If they go through with that it's a major blow to our efforts to have a budget summit,'' said Senator Phil Gramm, a Texas Republican. ''It's an act of bad faith.''
By day's end, House Democratic leaders agreed to postpone for two weeks any action on spending bills to await the outcome of Mr. Cheney's study and any further progress it would encourage in the budget talks.
Under the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings balanced budget law, Congress and the Administration are required to pare the deficit to $64 billion for the fiscal year 1991 or accept automatic spending cuts that would mean deep cuts in domestic and military programs to reach the deficit target. But the law can be waived if economic growth registers below 1 percent in two consecutive quarters, and there is a growing undercurrent of sentiment on Capitol Hill that the weakening economy will force just such a course and eliminate the need for a ''grand compromise'' on the budget.
Democrats said that in their Memorial Day recess they had detected no sense of crisis about the deficit among voters, making the prospect for action on a budget compromise all the more difficult.
Representative William H. Gray 3d of Pennsylvania, the House Democratic whip, said, ''The question is not even whether they can put together a budget compromise, but whether the 16 or 17 people in the negotiations can walk out on the floor and sell it in an election year when nobody at home thinks there is a crisis.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: White House and congressional negotiators resumed budget talks yesterday. Representing the Bush Administration were, from left; John H. Sununu, White House chief of staff; Richard G. Darman, budget director; Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, and Defense Secretary Dick Cheney. (George Tames for The New York Times) (pg. A18)

HEADLINE: An Empire at Risk - Trump's Atlantic City;
Debt Forcing Trump to Play for Higher Stakes

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES with M. A. FARBER

 BODY:
For Donald J. Trump, the 43-year-old entrepreneur who built his business empire during the 1980's with borrowed money, the stakes are highest, and the game hardest, along the sandy Boardwalk of Atlantic City.
Mr. Trump is relying on his three casinos, including the recently opened Taj Mahal, billed as the world's largest, for the cash to keep his sprawling empire going. But restoring the strength of his once-lucrative gaming houses in a difficult market will require management skills that Mr. Trump has yet to demonstrate.
 
A Risk-Filled Business
In the seven months since a freak helicopter accident robbed him of his top casino executives, Mr. Trump has for the first time become directly involved in running these complex operations with thousands of employees, where management risk is as ever-present as chance at the gaming tables.
Since then, his casinos have been undermined by an exodus of senior managers, some of whom were dismissed and others who left complaining of Mr. Trump's overbearing and idiosyncratic style. Surviving staff members complain of low morale. Bills are not being paid on time, vendors say. And state regulators, growing more concerned, have stepped up a broad inquiry into all his holdings. 
In recent weeks, Mr. Trump has been huddled with his bankers, who are concerned about his ability to keep making timely payments on the debt he used to accumulate such properties as the Plaza Hotel and the Trump Shuttle. Underlying those talks is his need for cash, which his casinos could satisfy through either strong performance or by fetching high prices on the auction block.
Today Mr. Trump is by far the biggest casino operator in Atlantic City. ''When you go to Atlantic City,'' said Richard R. Wilhelm, once a Trump casino official and now the general manager of the Plaza Hotel in New York, ''you're going to Trump City.''
But the gaming market on which Atlantic City depends is weakening, hurt by a soft economy and too many casinos spending too much to lure customers. Even Mr. Trump forecasts that in a few years, half of the dozen of casinos now operating in Atlantic City may be out of business, though he says he firmly believes that his three will be among the survivors.
The New Jersey Division of Gaming Enforcement's examination, ordinarily performed before periodic relicensing, was moved up and beefed up because of worries about the debt on the Taj Mahal, Mr. Trump's other bond obligations and the impact the Taj would have on his other Atlantic City interests. Debt payments on his casino bonds total nearly $180 million a year and some estimates of his total debt payments run as high as $255 million.
''It was the confluence of all those factors that led us to choose to review Mr. Trump's holdings in Atlantic City and the state of his overall organization,'' said Anthony J. Parrillo, the division's director.
The strain on Mr. Trump may be showing. On a weekend in mid-May, Trump executives watched anxiously as their boss paced back and forth in the crowded baccarat pit at the Plaza casino. Akio Kashawagi, a Tokyo real estate tycoon who won $6.2 million in February, was back at the table and he was winning again.
The executives, who were ordinarily accustomed to Mr. Trump adding a touch of his celebrity to the ''quality glitz'' of his casino, were embarrassed to see him hovering near the table as Mr. Kashawagi - who eventually lost $9.9 million and complained about his treatment - wagered $200,000 a hand. In their minds, Mr. Trump's behavior indicated a nervousness ill suited to a casino operator.
''This was one of the most coveted gamblers in the world,'' a Trump executive said later. ''In the casino business, you don't sweat the action.''
 
His Challenge
A Tough Time For the Industry
Given his current cash problems, Mr. Trump sorely needs the abundant profits casino gambling once produced, and he says he remains confident that his Atlantic City business will strengthen soon.
''Frankly, I think Atlantic City over the next two or three years will be far greater than anything I could ever do in Manhattan,'' Mr. Trump said in a wide-ranging interview. ''I think it's far greater than anybody can do in Manhattan.''
That optimism is hardly universal. Competition among the dozen casinos in Atlantic City has been fierce and is getting worse, both industry analysts and casino executives say. Profit margins are shrinking and only a larger flood of middle-income people who gamble regularly, whose arrival is uncertain at best, can reverse the trend.
Industry analysts and casino executives warn that this precarious environment will be a challenge for even the most seasoned and stable management. For Mr. Trump, with little practical experience at running a casino, the test will be especially hard.
His record in recent months, these analysts, gaming regulators and some of Mr. Trump's own executives say, is not reassuring. His casinos have been mired in internal dissension and a degree of managerial disarray that even state regulators say is unsettling.
Asked about the recent shaky performance of his casino holdings, Mr. Trump unexpectedly blamed a number of current and past aides, including the three highly respected casino executives who were killed in a helicopter crash last fall. In recent months, he said, he has personally taken hold of the situation in Atlantic City and has appointed people he calls ''warriors'' to start restoring his casinos to the cash-generating health they once possessed.
''Let me tell you my biggest strength that nobody knows,'' Mr. Trump said. ''My biggest strength is that I get the best people for the job. People want to work for me. Trump does well with management.''
Others are not so sure. Mr. Trump is praised by some as an imaginative but conservative real estate developer and a wily negotiator who, as one longtime associate said, ''never lets you know the facts.'' But his skill as the chief executive of a day-to-day business, now employing about 15,000 people, is a question mark.
Since he took a more direct hand in his casino operations late last year, he has fired a number of senior managers. Others have walked out in disgust. ''I simply didn't want to work for Donald Trump any longer,'' said Jack O'Donnell, the former president of the Trump Plaza and a well-regarded gaming industry executive who quit last month. Mr. Trump has lashed out publicly at his own top aides in press interviews and on television, balked at complying with severance agreements and appointed executives to positions for which they seem to have little relevant experience. The result has been a level of friction that has become the talk of the industry - and that has made it increasingly hard for him to recruit managers.
''People who work there are terrified,'' one regulator said. ''People are hiding under their desks.''
 
His Entrance
The New Kid On the Block
Donald Trump was licensed as a casino operator in Atlantic City in 1982, flush from his early successes in Manhattan, including the renovations of the Commodore Hotel, now the Grand Hyatt, and the construction of Trump Tower, the commercial and residential complex that soars over a prime corner of Fifth Avenue's shopping district.
The New Jersey experiment with legalized gambling had been touched with scandal. The Casino Control Commission was reorganized after one its original members had been tainted in the political influence-peddling inquiry known as Abscam, and several prospective Atlantic City operators had been denied a licence because of possible ties to unsavory figures in the gaming world.
Against that backdrop, Donald Trump was welcomed in Atlantic City.
''He was an emerging celebrity in New York,'' one former regulator recalled. ''He was just beginning to be noticed. In our mind, he was the good guys. We had just disqualified two chief executives, and here was this young, vital guy.''
Mr. Trump's first license was approved after a one-day hearing.
His initial stake was a joint venture with the Holiday Corporation. Together, in 1984, they opened what is now called the Trump Plaza casino, on the Boardwalk at the end of the Atlantic City Expressway, an enviable location in a market that, unlike Las Vegas, was dominated by day-trip business.
The deal soon soured, and Mr. Trump sold bonds in 1986 to buy out his partner.
The year before, the Casino Control Commission refused a gaming license to the Hilton Hotels Corporation, which had just built a casino in the marina district, several miles from the Boardwalk. Mr. Trump stepped in to buy the property, which he christened Trump's Castle.
With ready access to credit, Mr. Trump began to find new ways to invest in casino gambling - buying the stock of publicly traded casino operators and later, selling at substantial profits.
Then he turned his sights on the owner of Atlantic City's oldest casino, Resorts International, which was bogged down in the costly and seemingly endless process of building a casino - the Taj Mahal - to replace the antiquated hotel it had converted for gaming in 1978.
In March 1987, Mr. Trump bought the founding family's controlling stake for $288 million. With his voting power, Mr. Trump persuaded the Resorts board to grant him a management contract that was so generous that it threatened to consume most of the company's future profits. Ultimately Resorts International was bought by the entertainer Merv Griffin. Mr. Trump ended up with the Taj Mahal and an additional $64 million in cash from the buyout of his contract.
With the Resorts deal behind him, Mr. Trump owns three of the 12 operating casinos, more than any other operator and the maximum allowed by law. Last year he purchased a fourth property, the failed Atlantis casino on the Boardwalk, and remodeled it into a non-casino hotel, the Trump Regency. His new Taj Mahal, at $1.3 billion, is the costliest and largest gambling house in town. All told, he controls more hotel rooms, more exhibit space and more employees than any other casino enterprise in Atlantic City. Of the estimated $2.3 billion in debt incurred by Trump entities in the past decade, more than $1.4 billion is attributable to his three casinos.
 
His Style
A Preference For Glamour
Mr. Trump's management style has always been quite personal, placing his trust in a small circle of close associates. One of his first casino managers was his wife, Ivana, who was named to run Trump's Castle casino soon after her husband purchased it. Mrs. Trump, of course, had never run a casino before, and spent only a few days a week in Atlantic City. She relied on a senior staff of experienced executives, few of whom remain part of the Trump casino team today. In any event, one casino industry analyst noted, a rapidly growing market is kinder to inexperienced management than a stagnant one.
When he became sole owner of Trump Plaza in 1986, Mr. Trump recruited Stephen F. Hyde from Steve Wynn's Golden Nugget casino hotel in Atlantic City. Mr. Hyde, an accountant with an unflappable demeanor, brought with him Mark Grossinger Etess, whose experience in the hotel industry began with at his family's hotel and country club in the Catskills.
Two other members of Mr. Hyde's team were John Benanav, who had worked for Mr. Hyde at the Sands Casino, and Mr. O'Donnell, who had been senior vice president of marketing and vice president of slot operations at the Golden Nugget and who entered the business as an executive of his family's Bally Manufacturing Company.
In an industry famous for backbiting, Mr. Hyde appeared to have few detractors. Rivals praised his skill, talent and decency, and consultants who have dealt with the Trump Organization for years credited Mr. Hyde with buffering the Atlantic City staff from some of Mr. Trump's whims and eccentricities.
After two years, Mr. Hyde was put in charge of all Mr. Trump's casino operations, further freeing his boss for the glamorous chores he seemed to prefer - escorting fellow celebrities through a long parade of prize fights, rock concerts, regattas, bike races and other promotional events.
At that time, with less competition and rapid expansion in the Atlantic City market, the Trump casinos routinely earned more than enough to cover their overhead and produce sizable surpluses for Mr. Trump. This was possible in part because he was able to postpone repayment of principal on his bonds, and borrow money for new projects.
But the cash flow from Mr. Trump's casinos in 1989 did not increase, as he expected, but fell. At the Castle, renovation work ate up a big chunk of cash; the cost of maintaining Mr. Trump's 282-foot yacht, berthed at the Castle marina for promotional purposes, further consumed earnings.
 
His Managers
Expressions Of Discontent
As a manager, Mr. Trump tends to be guided by his own preferences. The Plaza casino had to cope with Mr. Trump's decision to convert proposed retail space at the Boardwalk entrance into an oyster bar. The staff suggested that the oyster bar would be far less profitable than the shopping boutique called for in the hotel's plans.
But, a former executive involved in the planning said Marla Maples, a frequent guest at Mr. Trump's Atlantic City properties, had pushed for an oyster bar. Miss Maples is the model with whom it is said Mr. Trump is having an affair.
''Actually, a lot of people didn't want the oyster bar,'' Mr. Trump said. ''But we had the ice cream parlor on the other side and we felt this would be a better complement to the parlor.''
Both the Castle and the Plaza, moreover, were hurt in 1989 by one of the worst years in Atlantic City's gaming history. While Las Vegas gaming revenues climbed by 9.7 percent in 1989, gross revenues grew only 2.6 percent on the Boardwalk, down from 9 percent in 1988. One casino, the Atlantis, closed. Another, Merv Griffin's debt-ridden Resorts, filed for bankruptcy. As casinos vied for customers, promotional expenses soared.
Still, if Mr. Trump harbored any discontent with Mr. Hyde and the team he had assembled, it was not known in Atlantic City.
Then, in late 1989, the Trump Organization was dealt a blow from which it has not yet fully recovered. On Oct. 10, Mr. Hyde and Mr. Etess, along with Mr. Benanav, flew to New York for a news conference. On their return that afternoon, their chartered helicopter crashed, killing all aboard.
In most of his public statements, Mr. Trump has continued to lavish praise on the men who died. He named the arena at the new Taj Mahal after Mr. Etess, and recently dedicated the refurbished marina building at the Castle to Mr. Hyde.
Yet during a recent interview, he ascribed much of his troubles in Atlantic City - from weaker profits at the end of last year to the rocky opening of the Taj in April - to those men, and to others they hired.
''After the crash, when I started getting involved and watching the operation in Atlantic City, I didn't like a lot of the things that I was seeing,'' Mr. Trump said. ''I just saw things that I wanted changed. Steve was my great friend, but I just saw things that I frankly wanted changed because I wasn't satisfied.''
He went on to criticize the Hyde team. ''People were put into positions that I didn't agree with,'' he said. ''When they didn't work out, I immediately fired them and put the people that I wanted in there. Since that time, the place has been running flawlessly.''
But other casino executives do not share that view. Indeed, the opening at the Taj in early April brought simmering management problems to a boil.
Donald C. Wood, the chief financial officer at the Taj, was carried from the casino floor on a stretcher, suffering exhaustion and dehydration. Two days later, with Mr. Trump still fuming over the mishaps of the opening, he was fired. Donald Buzney, the new casino's chief personnel officer, was also dismissed in the aftermath of the opening and was unceremoniously told that key features of his severance agreement would not be honored. Executives throughout Atlantic City were stunned when Mr. Trump, in a national telecast of the ''Larry King Show'' from the Taj penthouse, complained about Walter Haybert, who was Mr. Etess's successor as president of the casino.
''We had a Type C personality running the hotel,'' Mr. Trump said. ''I've never made money in my life with a Type C personality. Type C is low key, you know, people that fall asleep.''
Mr. Haybert was soon demoted, and replaced as Taj president by W. Bucky Howard, a gaming specialist with little experience in the hotel side of the business. Edward M. Tracy, who had helped run a casino in Puerto Rico but had been with the Trump organization only nine months, was promoted from the presidency of the Castle to oversee all three of the Trump casinos. He was replaced at the Castle by Anthony Calandra, who had operated the Trump casino marketing office in New York, arranging junkets for high-rolling gamblers.
 
His Chances
Atlantic City's Critical Moment
The management turnover in the Trump casinos comes at a critical moment in New Jersey's experiment with gambling.
In the past, economic prosperity, the excitement of getting started and the limited number of gaming outlets in the resort, and elsewhere in the country, tended to obscure the flaws in the Atlantic City environment. The problems remain daunting: a leadership vacuum in local politics, persistent squabbling among many casino operators,an outmoded convention hall, a shortage of hotel space for the tourist trade, insufficient land for developing the sort of theme casinos that have embellished Las Vegas, inadequate air and rail service, a rundown business district, a cumbersome and costly regulatory process and, underlying it all, the question of whether there will be enough new gamblers.
How many casinos can survive, and in what condition, depends in part on the leadership in Trenton. And after eight years in which former Gov. Thomas H. Kean did little to address the concerns of the casinos, the state's second-largest industry, some assistance may be in the offing.
Gov. Jim Florio, who took office in January, has ordered ''a policy review of the whole spectrum of issues'' surrounding casino gaming, a senior official said, ''including the airport, the convention center, and the structure and function of the Casino Control Act itself.''
What is needed, said Carl F. Zeitz, who served for eight years on the Casino Control Commission and who has participated in the review process, are changes to encourage the casino industry to build ''10,000 new hotel rooms and four to six new casino properties in the next four to six years.'' Unless that happens, Mr. Zeitz said, ''Atlantic City will die on the vine; it will be the world's biggest bus station with slot machines.''
Other policy makers say such ambitions are unrealistic because of the lackluster regional economy, the expectation that other states will approve competing forms of legalized gambling and the cautious attitude in Atlantic City itself, where casino executives are waiting to see if the Taj can succeed after the busy summer season, without damaging all its rivals.
Now that he is pre-eminent in Atlantic City, Mr. Trump says he prefers to see a moratorium on casino construction, something that would enhance the value of existing properties. But even without a freeze, Mr. Trump insists that his casinos are valuable trophies that will be a rich source of profit for him - whether he simply enjoys their future cash flow or decides to sell them.
''It's all superfine stuff,'' he said. ''My stuff is all trophies. I could make a tremendous profit if I wanted to go public.'' It is an option he says he weighs regularly.
Real estate specialists say the better Atlantic City casinos can always be sold - for the right price. Mr. Trump has already tested the market with his Trump Castle casino, asking a ''ludicrous'' $750 million, one real estate investor said.
Mr. Trump could lower his sights and probably find a buyer for one or more of his gaming properties. But so long as he insists on a premium price - which he must do if he hopes to clear a healthy profit after paying debts - he may have no recourse but to continue playing what is, for him, the unfamiliar game of casino management.
If there is agreement about Mr. Trump on any score, it is that his next move is virtually impossible to predict. An executive who worked closely with him for years summed it up by saying that over the long run, Mr. Trump is really not committed to any strategy. ''His outlook is: if you win, it was right.''

LENGTH: 1153 words

HEADLINE: Soviet Thaw With Seoul: What Is Real Depends on Whom You Listen To

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 6

 BODY:
Within moments of the end of his meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Monday, the South Korean President, Roh Tae Woo, was broadcasting a message of victory back home, declaring that ''the cold war ice on the Korean peninsula has now begun to crack'' and predicting the imminent establishment of diplomatic relations with Moscow.
In the following two days, however, the Soviets have put a dramatically different, far less enthusiastic cast on the hastily arranged meeting in San Francisco. Making it clear that the session was only an opening step in a broader discussion about Korea's longstanding division, the Soviets treated it more as a first encounter between aspiring business partners than an epoch-making accord between sworn enemies.
The Soviet caution was reflected in statements from Washington today, where Presient Bush was briefed on the results of the talks by Mr. Roh. Administration officials indicated that the contacts were still very preliminary and that they could not predict when relations or concrete agreements would be reached. 
While few question that the meeting itself was a breakthrough, even some of Mr. Roh's aides concede that its substance fell short of the fevered build-up it was given at home. It took place as Mr. Roh is trying to reinvigorate his popularity in the midst of an economic slowdown and increasing problems with a new political coalition that he has put together with two longtime opposition leaders.
 
Trade as Panacea
For two years the South Korean leader has bet that expanding economic ties with the Soviets - trade doubled last year but still amounts to just $600 million - would slowly draw political concessions from the Soviets, further isolating the North Korean leadership of Kim Il Sung. The strategy is a reversal from the days when South Koreans were jailed for consorting with Communists. But it is too early to tell if it is working.
A senior Japanese diplomat with long experience in Asian affairs said today that while he viewed diplomatic relations between Moscow and Seoul as inevitable, Mr. Gorbachev knew he ''could not walk away from the basic tenets of his relations with North Korea.'' And the Soviet leader, he and others suggest, likely sees an opportunity to extract more trade and investment the longer he keeps Seoul waiting.
''The South Koreans are reading what they want into whatever transpired,'' Han Sung Joo, a Korea University professor of political science, noted today in Seoul, discussing how eagerly the South Korean news media have soaked up Mr. Roh's version of events. ''The Soviets were trying to minimize whatever transpired.''
 
Gorbachev Sidesteps Trap
Moreover, Professor Han suggests, the Soviets sensed the South Korean President's eagerness to demonstrate that he had usurped the North's biggest ally and source of funding, ''and Gorbachev refused to walk into that.''
''They know what we want and that we want it so badly,'' said Professor Han, speaking about Mr. Roh's longing to establish himself as the former general who ended 40 years of antagonism beween Seoul and the Communist world. ''They are going to get the last ounce of what we have to offer.''
So far, the silent player in all this has been North Korea. Seoul's announcement last week that Mr. Roh and Mr. Gorbachev would meet left the Communist Government in Pyongyang somewhat stunned.
Until hours before the meeting, North Korea's official press agency offered doubts that the leader of its biggest ally would meet the leader of its adversary - a view fostered by the fact that Soviets did not announce it. ''Our best information,'' a Western diplomat here said, ''is that the Soviets never even told the North in advance.''
That would be consistent with the many recent signs of strains between North Korea and the Soviet Union, including the expulsion of a Soviet reporter in Pyongyang and differences over opening the North to nuclear inspections. Nonetheless, one of Mr. Roh's close aides, Hyun Hong Choo, newly appointed as South Korea's United Nations representative, said he understood that Mr. Gorbachev was ''not in a mood to advertise'' his approaches to the South.
''They wanted to downplay the thing,'' he said. ''They don't want to make an ally angry unnecessarily. But the very fact that the meeting took place cannot be denied, and that has a symbolic meaning.''
 
Pyongyang's Press Is Silent
In the aftermath of the San Francisco session, North Korea's Government-controlled press organizations -the only outlets for information in the country - have ignored the event altogether. The eerie silence, many suspect, arises from the difficulty in divining Mr. Gorbachev's intentions, the same problem that faces Mr. Kim.
In the meantime, most close analysts expect a freeze on the sporadic North-South talks that, along with gradually mounting trade with the Soviets, have been the centerpiece of Mr. Roh's post-Olympics ''Nordpolitik.''
''Everything will stop for a while,'' said a senior Japanese diplomat who has been following the approaches each side has made. ''North Korea has to reach for some of Buddha's enlightenment to cope with the realities of the world.'' Others are not so sure. North Korea has been one of the few Soviet bloc countries to show no signs of a pro-democracy movement; news is so controlled that it is hard to know if the North Koreans have even heard of the happenings along the Berlin wall.
So far, the South Koreans have been so ebullient about the meeting that they have hardly taken notice of the Soviet Union's efforts to play it down. Newspapers in Seoul, and elsewhere in Asia, have heralded a fundamental change in the political order, and are already filled with indications of fisheries agreements and joint ventures.
 
Injured Feelings in Seoul
In a rare sour note, the English-language Korea Times noted today that Mr. Gorbachev absented himself from the news conference after the San Francisco talks and issued statements that made no reference to South Korea. The Soviet President, the newspaper suggested, ''was not faithful to the protocol worthy of a 'historic summit.' ''
Mr. Gorbachev, the paper added, kept Mr. Roh waiting for an hour and then treated him ''as if he was a private economic patron and not the head of state who had flown thousands of miles to confer on crucial matters of mutual concern.''
The photograph of the two leaders that has been splashed across South Korea's press shows a broadly grinning President Roh and a glum, tired-looking Mr. Gorbachev.
Over time, however, Mr. Roh is betting that the Soviets will determine that economic patrons are something to smile at, especially if they bring Samsung video recorders, Hyundai automobiles and jobs. Next month, lower-level negotiations are expected to continue on diplomatic recognition, which would spur even more trade. ''All we need now,'' Mr. Hyun said, ''is time.''

HEADLINE: Evolution in Europe;
Interpreters' Lot: Hours of Tedium and Moments of Precision

BYLINE: By DAVID BINDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 6

 BODY:
Did Mikhail S. Gorbachev say on Friday that centrally controlled economic planning was ''a vice,'' meaning immoral - or, did he say it was ''a vise'' constricting growth?
While the press, working off a phonetic version provided by a Washington transcription agency, reported the former version, the small band of Soviet and American interpreters who worked the summit know the Soviet leader said ''vise.''
Interpreting is an unusual craft requiring the concentrated attention of a boxer in a championship match, but often for hours on end. Almost the only occasion interpreters get to socialize or work in a relaxed manner is at state funerals, when their services are only scantily employed. 
 
Teams of Interpreters
For the latest Soviet-American summit meeting, between Presidents Bush and Gorbachev and their delegations, the American side deployed 20 interpreters while the visitors brought 15 from Moscow. They interpreted for Presidents Bush and Gorbachev, their wives, Barbara and Raisa, and for Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze.
''I was really amazed at this crew of Soviet interpreters,'' said Harry Obst, head of the State Department's Office of Language Services, who supervised the American end of the interpreting and translation tasks. ''They did really outstanding work, masters of the art.''
The Soviet team was led by Pavel Palazhchenko, a balding, meticulously dressed man in his 40's who, like some of his American counterparts, has had considerable experience interpreting at previous American-Soviet summit meetings.
 
Precision Without Emotion
Mr. Palazhchenko is known in the interpreters' guild as one who eschews any inflections or gestures while delivering an extremely precise English rendition of President Gorbachev's Russian.
''He makes no effort to get emotion across, assuming the words themselves will be enough,'' Dimitry Zarechnak, one of the American interpreters, said of Mr. Palazhchenko. ''He's very precise.'' Among the other Soviet interpreters was Sergei Berezhkov, who handled part of President Gorbachev's breakfast meeting Friday with 12 members of Congress. In response to a question by Sen. George J. Mitchell, Democrat of Maine, about the Soviet economy, the Soviet leader had criticized ''the old command planned system'' as ''a kind of vise on our entire economy.''
 
'Clamp' Becomes 'Cramp'
The Russian word he used was ''tiski.'' Mr. Berezhkov, performing simultaneous interpretation, said ''vise,'' but, then, according to Mr. Obst, realized this could be misheard as ''vice'' and added ''a kind of clamp,'' as a synonym to make clear that act of squeezing. An American transcription agency giving the text nevertheless made it ''vice'' and rendered ''clamp'' as ''cramp.''
Mr. Obst said this was typical of the vicissitudes of simultaneous interpretation, but he complimented Mr. Berezhkov's effort to make the meaning clear with a synonym. He noted that Mr. Berezhkov, who is in his 40's, also has the distinction of being the son of a Soviet interpreter, Valentin M. Berezhkov, who was translator for Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov in his negotiations with Joachim von Ribbentrop on the Soviet-German nonaggression pact of 1939.
The American summit interpreters were led by Mr. Zarechnak, who was born of Russian parents in Czechoslovakia and came to this country at the age of 4, and William H. Hopkins, a native of Storm Lake, Iowa. They have worked summits as a team since 1985, changing off every 20 minutes or so.
 
A Change of Technique
By agreement with the Soviet side, the diplomatic interpreters work from their own language into the language of their counterparts. Until about six years ago, the bulk of the interpreting was done ''consecutively,'' that is, following a fairly lengthy presentation during which the interpreter takes his own form of short-hand notes.
Mr. Hopkins recalled that, beginning with a meeting between President Reagan and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko in 1984, the interpreting switched to ''simultaneous'' - that is, following the speaker word for word with hardly a perceptible lag.
Simultaneous interpreting seems to induce more dialogue and to discourage lengthy set pieces. Mr. Hopkins said that President Gorbachev now delivers his message in shorter statements. ''He is a lot easier than he used to be,'' he observed.
 
More Scope for Gestures
Asked whether there is a bit of acting in the art of interpreting a foreign statesman, both Mr. Hopkins and Mr. Zarechnak grudgingly acknowledged that being center stage ''in big media events'' might involve some of that. ''I tend to gesture a lot,'' said Mr. Zarechnak, who is 46, and Mr. Hopkins, 48, said he, too, was gesturing ''more and more.''
Mr. Hopkins said: ''You can't upstage the principal. You don't stand up and try to do an imitation of George Bush in Russian. But, going into another language is like getting another personality.''
Mr. Zarechnak said professional interpreters take pride in their contributions to the broadening of languages. It was an American interpreter, Mr. Zarechnak said, who coined ''gumanitarny'' as a Russian translation of ''humanitarian'' in discussions of human rights issues. The term has now been adopted by the Soviet Government. Similarly, he said, an American translator came up with ''zabrasivayemy ves'' to convey the American strategic- arms term ''throw-weight'' to describe the payload-carrying capability of a nuclear missile and that, too, is now standard Russian usage.
 
Backgrounds Are Varied
Some are made interpreters and some are born, said Mr. Obst, who pointed out that only about half of his staff of 23 took college degrees in languages or interpreting. He himself came to the profession by way of translating, Mr. Zarechnak was originally a mathematician, and Mr. Hopkins was an academic.
The Office of Language Services does have facilities for training its own staff in 10 languages. It provides refresher courses for its veterans in a conference room with state of the art electronic equipment. It can also pipe in Moscow's daily main television news broadcast, Vremya, for Russian speakers to practice their simultaneous interpreting.
''What it takes is natural talent, knowledge and personality,'' said Mr. Obst, ''and you don't necessarily get those from school.''
But is it theater? ''I would never go on stage if I had only seen the lines for three minutes before the curtain went up and the role is like Hamlet,'' said Mr. Hopkins.

HEADLINE: Evolution in Europe;
Baker Seeks Europe Security Group Shift

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: COPENHAGEN, June 6

 BODY:
In an effort to parry Soviet hopes to have the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe rather than NATO take the leading role in shaping a new Europe, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d today offered his own ideas of how the 35-nation organization should evolve.
As he spoke at a conference meeting in the Danish capital, the Secretary of State addressed attempts increasingly to seize on the conference as a framework for building a pan-European security structure that could replace NATO and the Warsaw Pact, thereby giving Moscow a role equal to Washington's.
Established in 1975, the conference has no permanent secretariat, no home address and no staff. Rather, it has been up to now a floating set of occasional negotiations bringing together 33 European nations and the United States and Canada. 
Its most significant achievement to date is the Helsinki Final Act of 1975 - the last time the organization held a summit meeting -which set some basic standards of behavior in the field of human rights to which the West has held the Soviet Union and the states of Eastern Europe accountable.
Addressing the security conference's foreign ministers meeting in Copenhagen, which was devoted to expanding human rights, Mr. Baker said: ''Czechoslovakia's Charter 77 cited the Helsinki Final Act in defense of their unjustly persecuted countrymen. Now, the Charter's original members -President Havel and Foreign Minister Dienstbier to name only two - are leading the new Czech and Slovak Republic to democracy.''
 
NATO's Prospects for the Future
The security conference, NATO and the European Community, Mr. Baker continued, ''must now play a greater role in deepening and broadening European unity.''
With an eye toward Moscow, though, he quickly added: ''We must insure that these organizations continue to complement and reinforce one another. NATO will continue to serve as the indispensible guarantor of peace - and therefore the ultimate guardian of democracy and prosperity. As President Bush stressed with President Gorbachev at last week's Washington summit, we believe NATO will remain a cornerstone of both military security and political legitimacy in the new Europe.''
In order to head off any potential Soviet move to develop the security conference into an alternative to NATO, American officials understood that they had to take the lead in defining, and thereby limiting, how the pan-European organization should expand.
American officials say they have an interest in seeing the conference become something of an all-European club that would, in particular, give the Warsaw Pact members a sense of belonging at a time when their alliance will likely disappear and NATO will likely continue.
 
Security Conference Expansion
Mr. Baker laid out what he described as several ''ideas on how we can work together to improve C.S.C.E. as a process by reinforcing C.S.C.E.'s organization.'' Those were:
* The United States will press for ''regular consultations'' among the conference states, with foreign ministers meeting at least once a year and senior officials at least twice a year in order to ''invigorate the C.S.C.E. as a forum for high-level political dialogue.''
* The United States will support the holding of security conference meetings to review human rights, economics and security issues once every two years.
* Just as the Helsinki Final Act established a certain minimum standard of human rights, the United States will now push for the security conference to expand those core rights that all member states would have to honor to include the ''principle of free and fair elections, political pluralism and rule of law.''
* The United States will push for the conference to develop mechanisms for conflict resolution between European states and for greater military openness.
* The United States is prepared to begin prepatory work for a security conference summit meeting, the first since Helsinki, to be held in Paris as soon as a conventional-arms reduction agreement in Europe is concluded.
 
Large Group, Unwieldy Process
The notion that security conference could ever put NATO out of business seemed a bit unlikely as the organization was observed in action today. The group has so many members that it had to convene in an airline-hangar-sized conference room outside of Copenhagen, with the 35 foreign ministers seated around a horseshoe-shaped conference table the length of a football field.
It is clearly an unwieldy grouping, in which small states like Malta and the Vatican carry the same voting weight as the United States and the Soviet Union, insuring that concerted action in any direction is always based on the lowest common denominator.
On the United States-Soviet front, a senior Administration official told reporters today that Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union told Mr. Baker during their meeting Tuesday that despite President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's recent hint that Moscow would consider halting Jewish emigration if Israel did not prevent Soviet Jews from settling in the occupied territories, the Kremlin actually has no intention of altering its emigration policy.
The official quoted Mr. Shevardnadze as saying that ''we have no plans to change our approach to emigration,'' which is a policy of increasingly free immigration for Jews and other minorities.
