HEADLINE: Evolution in Europe;
Soviets to Repay Lend-Lease After a Trade Accord

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 6

 BODY:
Once the Soviet Union gets the lowest possible tariffs from the United States and access to American Government credits, Moscow will start repaying $674 million of World War II Lend-Lease debts to the United States, an agreement appended to the newly signed Soviet-American trade agreement says.
The text of the accord, which was made available by American officials, sheds new light on the financial relationships that are likely to emerge from the trade pact, which was signed Friday by President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union.
For the Soviets, debt repayment is the key to raising money in the American bond market. The Johnson Debt Default Act of 1934 bars credits to countries in default to the United States Government. 
The text was circulated as the Soviet Union's chief trade negotiator, Yuri N. Chumakov, told a group of American business officials at the Soviet Embassy here that there is broad support in the Soviet Parliament for the freer emigration legislation that President Bush has linked to the tariff cuts.
He said the legislation, which is now expected to come up in September, could pass unanimously. ''Everyone in the Parliament is for it,'' he said.
Soviet officials said Tuesday in Moscow that Parliament had not included the bill on its agenda for the session that ends June 14. The Parliament does not convene again until September. No reason for the omission from the current agenda was given.
President Bush has said that he will not submit the accord to Congress until the Soviets complete the legislation, which provides procedures for exit from and entry into the Soviet Union.
 
Severe Economic Straits
Responding to questions from the Americans, Mr. Chumakov, Deputy Minister for Foreign Economic Relations and the man who negotiated the trade agreement, said ''the emigration law was postponed because our economic problems are so pressing.''
The Soviets are trying to transform their system of centralized planning into a market-based economy. Also preoccupying Moscow leaders is the 28th Communist Party Congress, which is expected to take place next month.
The comments of Mr. Chumakov underscored the importance that the Soviets attach to the trade agreement, which would reduce tariff levels and ease two-way trade, which totaled about $5 billion last year.
Congress has added conditions to the trade agreement, signaling that it will not approve it until the Soviet Government stops trying to coerce Lithuania into revoking its declaration of independence.
Today, the House approved, 390-24, a nonbinding resolution calling for an end to such coercion. Its action was similar to a Senate resolution approved 73-24 last month.
The trade agreement contains a number of provisions that would ease two-way trade.

HEADLINE: States Turn to the Courts for Water As the Rain-Starved Missouri Falls

BYLINE: By WILLIAM ROBBINS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PIERRE, S.D.

 BODY:
To hear them talk, both the people who live upriver and those who live downstream on the Missouri River Basin are prepared to be completely reasonable. All they want, they say, is their rightful share of the mighty river's water and its benefits.
But after nearly three years of drought in the upper basin states, only a season of plentiful rain across the thousands of miles of the river's western watershed can resolve interstate tensions that became all too apparent in Federal court hearings in May.
''Do we all have the responsibility to be reasonable?'' said William Janklow, a former Governor of South Dakota. ''The answer is yes. Is everybody acting reasonably? Hell, no.'' 
The specific issue is whether water should be released from reservoirs upstream. And the answer, whatever it is, is worth hundreds of millions of dollars to the economies of the eight states that funnel water into the Missouri.
 
The Course of the River
The 2,315-mile river rises in western Montana, flows north and then southeast through a series of dams in Montana and North and South Dakota, and then south and east past Nebraska, Iowa and Kansas and through Missouri before flowing into the Mississippi. Although the Missouri River does not touch Minnesota, that state is also part of its watershed.
To those in the upper basin states, what is at stake is the future of fishing resources that support a burgeoning recreation industry. From Sioux City, Iowa, south to Kansas City, Mo., and then east to St. Louis, the main interest is the transportation network that supporters say is vital to farming and commercial interests.
The river in that 735-mile stretch, maintained for navigation by the Army Corps of Engineers, supports barge lines carrying about $92 million worth of grain a year downstream and returning with chemicals and fertilizers and other freight worth hundreds of millions of dollars.
In addition, dozens of other groups keep a nervous eye on the river level. These groups include those who use its water to irrigate farms, to generate electricity and to supply the water systems of dozens of cities and towns.
 
The Good and the Bad
''Let's manage this resource so we share the good as well as the bad,'' said Gov. George S. Mickelson of South Dakota as he greeted guests in his office here in Pierre the other day. ''So far, all we have had was the bad.''
Downstream in Kansas City, John Madgett, president of Midwest Terminal Distribution Services, sounded equally reasonable. ''We're willing to share, and we have taken our hits like everybody else,'' he said, referring to reductions in the depth of the river and in the loads that barges can carry.
But he contended that if South Dakota and its allies had won their court battle it would have killed downstream navigation for most of the 1990 season, which has already been shortened because of the water problems.
The reason, Mr. Madgett said, was a complication introduced by two endangered species of birds cited by the Corps of Engineers in its appeal of a district court ruling that barred release of upstream water. The birds, the least tern and the piping plover, nest just above the waterline, the corps said, and if it lowered the water level downstream temporarily, as the plaintiffs wanted, it would have been forced to keep water levels below navigable depths for the entire nesting season, which runs through August.
The navigation season, which normally ends on Dec. 1, is scheduled to close this year on Nov. 1.
 
Restraining Order Overturned
South Dakota, supported by North Dakota and Montana, sued in early May in Federal District Court in Bismarck, N.D., and won a temporary restraining order limiting releases of water from Lake Oahe, which backs up across hundreds of thousands of acres behind the Oahe Dam here and stretches into North Dakota.
Responding to the argument that releases were rapidly lowering the lake level in the critical spawning period of the walleye, a popular game fish, Judge Patrick Conmy ordered the corps to reduce releases until June 1.
But a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit held, in effect, that the lower court should not interfere with the complex management decisions that the corps must make.
As it turned out, nature gave both sides a reprieve. Heavy downstream rains forced the corps to limit the release of water from the dam.
As a long-term solution, Governor Mickelson said he would seek Federal legislation giving the courts clear jurisdiction over the corps's operations, and he has asked other governors of Missouri Basin states to meet with him on June 20 to try to resolve their differences.
Meanwhile, the corps has set up regional conferences seeking comments to help update the Missouri River Master Manual, its guidebook on river operations, in an effort to meet the area's multiple needs.
 
Limited Funds for Irrigation
The conflicts stem from problems of the Missouri basin that Congress tried to solve with the Flood Control Act of 1944. The measure was intended to provide four benefits for the states in the basin: flood control, irrigation, electrical power and navigation.
South Dakota, in particular, says it has given up more than it received. Although the legislation envisioned potential development of more than 900,000 acres for irrigation in the state, Congress never voted money for more than 24,000 acres. But South Dakota gave up 530,000 acres of its best bottomland, about 828 square miles, to be flooded by the impounded waters, Of $85.5 million a year in electrical power generated by the projects, $55 million is generated in South Dakota. But state officials say relatively little of that stays at home.
''South Dakota, which has most of the dams, gets the smallest amount of electricity,'' said Mr. Janklow, the former Governor. ''Even Minnesota gets more electricity from our reservoirs than we do.''
Others relate that disparity to relative sizes. Although South Dakota's land area is almost one-third greater than that of New York State, its population is slightly more than 700,000, about 280,000 less than Rhode Island's.
 
Money From Sports Fishing
South Dakota did develop a recreational fishing industry that attracts anglers seeking salmon, northern pike and walleye. Dr. Michael K. Madden, a University of South Dakota economist, said sports fishing brings in more than $41 million a year for the state and more than $125 million when money spent on boats, trailers and fishing licenses is included.
But resort owners say the reports of receding waters and limits imposed on catches because of the loss of spawn have discouraged many anglers from vacationing in South Dakota.
The stakes are strikingly evident at Spring Creek, about 20 miles north of here, where John and Marlene Brakss built a lakeside marina to cater to fishermen about three years ago. The gasoline pump that then stood at water level now requires a 100-foot fuel hose extension to service boats that pull up.
The water has receded so far that their mooring spaces can accommodate only a fraction of the number of boats that they were developed to handle.
''We built for 150,'' said Mrs. Brakss, as she looked grimly down to the dock. ''We can only get 35 in there now. Break-even is 50. So guess what happens if they keep releasing our water for the barges downstream.''

HEADLINE: Donations in U.S. Climb, but Worries Linger

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN TELTSCH

 BODY:
Americans gave $114.7 billion last year in philanthropic gifts, an increase over last year, but fund-raisers remain worried about the continuing adverse impact of 1986 tax laws.
Most of the gains came from an 11.7 percent increase in giving by individuals who provided $96.43 billion that went mainly to religious groups.
Giving by foundations and corporations also increased but at a much lower rate, to $6.7 billion and $5 billion, respectively, up from $6.15 billion and $4.8 billion.
The total combined giving by individuals, corporations and foundations in 1989 was 10.4 percent over the previous year, or 5.5 percent when adjusted for inflation, according to the American Association of Fund-Raising Counsel, whose Trust for Philanthropy issued its annual estimates of giving on Monday. 
But fund-raisers were worried that giving to certain areas declined, or barely held its own. For example, giving to education dropped slightly, and gifts to health institutions increased almost imperceptibly. And while donations to arts, culture and the humanities increased 5.4 percent, when adjusted for inflation, gifts to museums did not meet hopes.
''I don't know where that increase is going because it certainly is not coming into the museum community,'' said Edward H. Able, executive director of the American Association of Museums, a Washington-based organization representing 2,500 museums.
 
Problem for Museums
A large measure of museums' financial troubles, Mr. Able maintained, were traceable to the 1986 tax changes, which scaled down incentives to give and particularly reduced the benefits of donating property that had appreciated in value. ''As a consequence,'' he said, ''museums anticipating gifts are seeing potential donors selling their art works, which are going to Japanese and other foreign collectors, and America's cultural patrimony is hemorrhaging.''
The estimates of giving are developed by the association, which represents 32 leading groups engaged in raising money for universities, hospitals and other nonprofit organizations.
 
Optimism Is Questioned
Some analysts questioned this year's optimistic report, called Giving U.S.A. They pointed out that United Way, whose fund raising is regarded as a reliable barometer of giving by individuals, reported an increase in 1989 of only 7.2 percent over 1988.
The fund-raising association concluded that most of the 1989 increase came from a surge in gifts by individuals who contributed more than 84 percent of all giving from private sources.
The growth was attributed to the jump in personal income of almost 9 percent, a 21 percent rise in the prices of stock and also growing public awareness of causes like homelessness, AIDS and the environment. Also, a number of universities benefited from intensive fund-raising campaigns.
''Charities, and especially social service organizations, are increasingly aware they cannot depend on government support for their operating budgets or for expansion to meet the growing needs of clients,'' said Jimmie R. Alford, chairman of the association's Trust for Philanthropy.
Giving in the religious sector totaled $54.3 billion, a 12.9 increase over 1988. Education received $10.69 billion and health, $10 billion. Arts, culture and the humanities together received $7.4 billion. Social action organizations, like environmental or women's groups, received $3.6 billion and a catch-all category including foreign aid received $17.1 billion.
The increase in corporate giving was surprising to some fund-raisers who expected the total to drop in the wake of threatened takeovers.
''Despite all the wolf-crying from charities, corporate contributions have proved remarkably resiliant,'' said Anne Klepper, director of the Contributions Management Institute of the Conference Board, an organization of 2,500 corporate members. ''Corporations are still very much in business and entering the 90's with even higher hopes. Who knows what will happen on the international scene, in Eastern Europe or the Pacific rim?''

HEADLINE: Canada's Latest Identity Crisis

 BODY:
Once again, Canada is agonizing over a problem as old as the nation itself - the uneasy marriage between its English and French cultures. Antagonism has reached another crisis. There is even talk of Canada breaking apart. That seems unlikely, but the tension creates unwelcome uncertainty in America's closest ally. 
The trigger for the latest rift is a proposed amendment to the 1982 Constitution, which Quebec refused to ratify because it gives the province and its culture no special status.
Known as the Meech Lake Accord, the amendment is designed to mollify Quebec by declaring it to be a ''distinct society,'' permitting it to set its own policy in certain cultural areas. Quebec has already declared French to be its language, defying Canada's national bilingualism. At Quebec's insistence, the accord also gives individual provinces veto power over some national matters.
The accord expires June 23 unless all provinces have ratified it, and there are still two firm holdouts, Manitoba and Newfoundland. In an effort to turn the holdouts around, modifications to the Meech Lake Accord have been proposed. But these proposals have only enraged and strengthened Quebec's separatists, who have revived their threat of secession if the amendment isn't adopted as is. Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, his own popularity severely weakened by the introduction of a national sales tax, has been meeting with the provincial premiers for the past week, searching frantically for a compromise.
The crux of the matter is Canada's identity as a nation. It was created as one country 123 years ago out of a collection of British colonies. It remains an uncertain union of provinces vested with more local authority than the 50 United States have.
Quebec's concern is that, without constitutional protection, the English-language culture will eventually overwhelm the French. Quebec is economically viable; with Ontario, it forms the center of Canadian commerce and industry. But Quebec's birth rate has declined sharply in recent decades, an ominous sign to defenders of the French culture.
Living together as one nation hasn't been easy for Canadians, but the awful prospect of living apart has always saved the marriage. As close allies, principal trading partners, neighbors and friends, Americans can only hope for a resolution that will preserve and stabilize the union.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Pervasive Racism and Boycott of Korean Stores

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I agree with Ji H. Min, writing about the boycott of two Korean stores in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn (''As a Korean, I'm No Longer 'Neutral,' '' Op-Ed, May 19), when he points out that the economic relationship between Korean-Americans and African-Americans is symbiotic. I also agree that there's room for improvement by the merchants, but that the boycott must first end. Yet, as a fellow Korean-American, I am surprised by his naivete on a problem as pervasive as racism.
He suggests the boycotters are motivated by racism. Even if the boycotters themselves deny it, it is plain to many of us. Yet the blame cannot fall on one side only.
My parents, too, are Korean shopowners. And I can say, without disrespect, that they are racists. They are racists like the man from Bensonhurst who so earnestly says into the camera: ''I'm no racist. But I think all black guys are sneaks.''
They are racists like Sonny Carson and C. Vernon Mason, who, while accusing others of racism, say that they are antiwhite. People who like to believe that the only form of racism in America is institutional are sadly mistaken. Because each exquisite and distinctive piece of the mosaic needs clear differentiation from - and subtle denigration of - the cultural and racial other: pro-my group almost always means anti-everyone else.
Yes, racism is everyone's problem. But it is a problem not only because each of us is its potential victim, but because we are its unacknowledged perpetrators.
 
JOHN X. KIM
Closter, N.J., May 21, 1990

PUB-DATE: June 7, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 23, Column 5; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 742 words

HEADLINE: ON MY MIND;
Warmth and Ice

BYLINE: By A. M. Rosenthal

 BODY:
The Washington summit talks did not reveal a great deal new about George Bush, but they did tell us a lot about Mikhail Gorbachev - certainly more than he intended.
The meeting showed us again that President Bush is an intelligent, likable man who handles himself with style but has one important drawback as a player in international affairs. He likes things to be cost-free.
When issues of principle get involved that he thinks may interfere with what he wants, he just dumps them. Like, say, supporting the freedom movement in China or standing up to terrorists. 
At the summit talks it was Lithuania. First Mr. Bush told Mr. Gorbachev a trade agreement had to be linked to Lithuanian independence. Then, after listening to Mr. Gorbachev's pleas for support, out came a trade package for the Kremlin without Lithuania.
A familiar argument can be made for that kind of policy. But who wants to say that this country believes the ends justify the means? So the Administration tends to mumble while we cup our ears.
But there was more to the summit conference than Lithuania, or more precisely, no Lithuania. The arms talks left the Soviet Union with superior military strength on the ground. But the country is falling apart so fast that to use it against the West would demand an overwhelming national desire to commit suicide.
The agreements about reducing nuclear weapons are good for the soul and the pocketbook. But they still leave both sides - yes, there are still two sides when it comes to survival in a nuclear age - in terror of the destruction that has prevented great-power war for a half-century.
On Germany, Mr. Gorbachev hinted he would slowly do what the realistic Germans knew he would do one day -accept unified Germany in NATO in exchange for some face-saving language and a hefty German package of economic gifts and investments.
He has no other choice now. The Soviet Union and the West failed to work out a plan about how to deal with a unified Germany before it was suddenly upon them. After all, they only had 40 years or so.
Emotions count more than documents and speeches, as good diplomats know. The American public made the Gorbachev visit emotionally powerful. Wherever he went, Americans held out, so clearly it could almost be touched, their yearning to put fears and enmities behind them, to relax their neck muscles.
It was not what he said. A certain document contains all the hope and plans for the international common roof he talks about. Remember it, the United Nations Charter? Do we really need to start all over?
No, it was the exhilaration of seeing and hearing a man whom Americans believe is responsible for a new era of hope. They hugged him for that.
But in Washington, in a startling moment of self-revelation, Mr. Gorbachev showed the importance of not tying our destiny to his. He talks democracy, and perhaps even believes in a version of it, but in that moment he showed that he acts and thinks like a dictator.
The Arabs, he told a press conference, had been pressuring him about the immigration of Soviet Jews to Israel. Then came a threat: Unless Israel listens to him and prevents the new arrivals from living in the ''occupied territories,'' he will reconsider allowing them to leave the U.S.S.R.
Since only a handful of Soviet Jews have gone to live in the West Bank, the threat meant Israel had to prevent them from finding apartments in East Jerusalem, part of Israel's capital.
Sitting right there was President Bush. Mr. Gorbachev had promised him Moscow would soon put into law the right of Soviet citizens to leave their country.
The President sat strangely silent, listening to Mr. Gorbachev talk familiar Soviet talk - laws mean what the Communist Party or its boss intend at any given moment. This time Soviet promises about emigration were at stake. The next time, what?
The American public's reaching out to Mr. Gorbachev was a warm moment of history that will remain in the mind. So should the icy moment of self-revelation in Washington.
The truth remains: If we move with heavy foot in support of Mr. Gorbachev, and only Mr. Gorbachev, we can trample the hopes of the Soviet people, who want more freedom -and more food - than he is ready or able to give them.
And we can crush the new Soviet democratic movement, still forming, and its chance to lead the country to freedom - for which so many of its members were once imprisoned, so long and so cruelly.

PUB-DATE: June 7, 1990

SECTION: Section B; Page 1, Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 761 words

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
Turning Boycott Of Greengrocer Into Green Power

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
For almost five months, a chorus of shrill chants has defined the boycott by a group of blacks against a Korean-owned greengrocer on Church Avenue in Brooklyn. Meanwhile the real story behind the boycott was quietly unfolding around the corner.
On Saturdays, volunteers from the Flatbush Frontline Collective, which helped to organize the boycott, have been operating their own sidewalk fruit and vegetable stand under a bright blue canopy between the M & R Meat Market and The Curls Unisex Beauty Salon on St. Paul's Place.
That they are there at all is a largely untold story. Last Saturday the well-stocked, competitively priced operation claimed more customers than the Church Avenue greengrocery, where pickets drove away would-be shoppers by shouting insults and appeals for solidarity. 
Yet the very existence of the part-time market raises a fundamental, but largely unasked question: Where were these potential entrepreneurs before? Why did it take an altercation between a Korean grocer and a black customer accused of shoplifting to galvanize blacks concerned about economic power into taking a constructive stand?
''That's the first thing we hear,'' said Robert (Sonny) Carson, who has made a career of organizing protests, including the Church Avenue boycott. ''Why don't we open our own businesses instead of boycotting? We have seized the time. Now at least we can say that something came out of it.''
Mr. Carson said the stand makes a small profit, which is invested in the collective's other endeavors, including fliers and bullhorns for the boycott. ''They just want to make their money back and get a few pennies for their other expenses,'' he said.
A second stand has been operating Saturdays on Macon Street in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section, around the corner from another Korean-owned greengrocery, which was the target of a boycott in 1988.
''We're trying to set up a role model for other aspirants,'' Mr. Carson said. ''I can't answer why this has never happened before.''
The number of black-owned businesses in New York and the nation has grown, but it remains disproportionately small. Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, said that self-employed New Yorkers make up 6.7 percent of the city's total labor force, but only 3.4 percent of working blacks.
The Uptown Chamber of Commerce estimates that 30 percent of the businesses in Harlem are black-owned - down from 35 percent four years before. In central Harlem the figure is about 50 percent. Among the almost 160 members of a Church Avenue merchants' group, about 25 are black.
Black-owned businesses have benefited from corporate purchasing programs that encourage minority suppliers to bid. But Lynda Ireland, president of the Association of Minority Business Enterprises of New York, fears that those benefits will be undermined by Federal court challenges to such programs.
''We're not looking for a welfare situation,'' she said. ''Unfortunately it takes affirmative action sometimes to allow us to compete fairly.'' It also takes working capital, which is the goal of a modest loan program proposed by Borough President Howard Golden of Brooklyn in response to the boycott.
Near the dueling fruit stands the other day, a video store was promoting the Spike Lee film ''Do the Right Thing,'' which presciently captured the resentment behind the boycott.
''I bet you they haven't been off the boat a year before they open up their own place,'' says Coconut, one of three sidewalk philosophers surveying a Korean-owned market across the street. ''They already have got a place in our neighborhood - a good business occupying a building that had been boarded up for longer than I care to remember.'' Coconut suggests that either Koreans are geniuses or his black brethren are dumb.
''It's got to be because we are black,'' says M.L. ''There ain't no other explanation.''
To which Sweet Dick Willie replies, ''Tired of hearing that old excuse.''
Yesterday Mr. Lee said: ''The biggest reason why Koreans are able to do this is not that they come into the country with a lot of money, but they come in as families. That family is very intact. We should use the Koreans as a model.
''As far as the 90's are concerned, black people have to be about economic development,'' Mr. Lee said. ''For too long we've talked about how the white man has kept us down. That's a given. If we're to survive, we have to get into the entrepreneurial way of thinking.''
That change is beginning, but it is not going to happen by chants.
